Five astronaut boarded Discovery today for a second try at sending the Hubble Space Telescope into orbit to scan the outermost reach of the universe for clue to the beginning of time. Astronomers are starting to tingle again in anticipation of what the Hubble will be able to accomplish, said Lennard Fisk, head of NASA science activity. Air Force forecaster said there wa a 90 percent chance the weather would be favorable for launching the shuttle at the scheduled time of 8:31 am. EDT. More than a half million gallon of liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen were pumped into the space ship's fuel tank after midnight. The astronaut, wearing bright orange flight suit, climbed into the crew cabin just a dawn wa breaking over the Kennedy Space Center. The $1.5 billion telescope, NASA's costliest cargo, will give astronomer a new set of eye and ear that we don't have, said William Lenoir, head of NASA's space flight program. It's going to change our perspective altogether. I can't say what we're going to learn, but I'll be astounded if we don't learn many new thing. Discovery wa aiming for an altitude of 380 mile, the highest a shuttle ha ever gone, so the telescope can be placed in it proper orbit far above Earth's distorting atmosphere. It is the 35th shuttle mission. Columbia, which journey into space next month with the Astro observatory, sat on a launch pad 1.6 mile from Discovery, only the second time both pad have been occupied; the first wa in 1986 just before the Challenger explosion. Hubble ha been waiting to take it place in space since 1983, delayed by technical problem and the Challenger accident. The latest postponement occurred April 10, when Discovery's launch wa scrubbed four minute before liftoff because of a faulty power unit on the shuttle. The mood at the Kennedy Space Center wa considerably le festive than during the first launch attempt, when hundred of astronomer gathered with their family. The day after launch, mission specialist Steven A. Hawley will use the shuttle's mechanical arm to lift the 24,250-pound telescope into space. Veteran spacewalker Bruce McCandless II and Kathryn Sullivan will assist if a problem develops. Discovery will follow Hubble from 40 mile away for two day until after it lens cap is opened, exposing the finely polished 94.5-inch mirror to starlight. Hubble is not expected to start providing scientific data by satellite for a month or more after liftoff. However, NASA said it will release it first image an open star cluster in the constellation Carina a week after launch. In addition to the $1.5 billion cost of Hubble, $500 million ha been spent on spare part, astronaut training and computer software to operate the instrument. The European Space Agency contributed $250 million for 15 percent of the viewing time. NASA estimate it will cost $200 million a year to operate and maintain the telescope in space. During it 15-year working lifetime, the telescope will provide astronomer with 10 time better resolution and 25 time more sensitivity than ground-based observatory. As a result, they will be able to study star and galaxy so distant their light ha been traveling toward Earth for 14 billion year. Astronomers hope to learn whether the universe wa created 15 billion year ago a believed and uncover some of the mystery surrounding galaxy, black hole and quasar. Hubble also is expected to shed light on how and when the universe might end. The telescope is named for the late astronomer Edwin P. Hubble, who discovered during the 1920s that the universe is expanding. His work gave rise to the Big Bang theory that the universe wa created by a tremendous explosion. In addition to Hubble, Discovery carry a human skull filled with sensor to measure the space radiation that astronaut receive. It is the skull's third trip into space. The shuttle is to end it five-day mission with a landing at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. Discovery's five astronaut returned Sunday for a second attempt to launch the shuttle with NASA's most valuable and celebrated payload, the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope. Discovery is scheduled to lift off at 8:31 am. EDT Tuesday. We feel very confident that thing are going to go well this time, said Discovery's commander, Air Force Col. Loren J. Shriver. We're going to come out OK on Tuesday morning and, if not, we'll just keep trying until we do. That's kind of the name of the game here, Shriver said. NASA test director Mike Leinbach said Sunday that the countdown wa proceeding smoothly and the shuttle appeared to be in perfect condition. The countdown got under way Saturday afternoon. A faulty power unit forced the first launch attempt to be scrubbed four minute before liftoff April 10. The unit wa replaced with a new one, which test showed to be fine. Hopefully, we'll get the shuttle off the pad this time, Leinbach said. A 70 percent chance of favorable weather wa expected at launch time, with low cloud being the main concern, said the Air Force's Ed Priselac, shuttle weather officer. A weak cold front from the north wa expected to pas through the area by Monday night. The outlook is considerably better for Wednesday and Thursday, Priselac said. As Discovery's astronaut arrived from Johnson Space Center in Houston early Sunday afternoon, the shuttle Columbia wa being transported to a launch pad 1.6 mile from Discovery. It is only the second time both shuttle launch pad at Kennedy Space Center have been occupied simultaneously. The first time wa in January 1986; 16 day after Columbia lifted off, Challenger exploded. Columbia commander Vance Brand said he doe not believe the National Aeronautics and Space Administration is moving too fast with his shuttle. NASA expects to launch Columbia with an astronomical observatory called Astro no earlier than May 16, one week later than planned because of Discovery's two-week delay. In some case, it could be a problem having shuttle on both launch pad, Brand said. In this particular case, everything's fitting together. NASA ha until Saturday to get Discovery off the ground. After that, all launch attempt must be halted for eight day so Hubble's battery can be recharged. The six nickel-hydrogen battery will power Hubble from the time it is disconnected from Discovery's electrical system until it two energy-collecting solar panel take over in space. Discovery's payload bay wa sealed late Saturday night, drastically reducing the risk of contamination to the telescope's finely polished 94.5-inch mirror. Discovery will aim for an altitude of 380 mile, the highest a shuttle ha ever gone, so the telescope can be placed in it proper orbit far above Earth's distorting atmosphere. During Hubble's 15-year journey through space, astronomer expect to look back to nearly the beginning of time and solve some of the universe's most perplexing mystery. Astro will measure ultraviolet radiation undetected by Hubble and thus provide additional target for the telescope. The $100 million observatory also will focus during Columbia's nine-day mission on Comet Austin, believed to be on it first trip through the solar system. Both Hubble and Astro were scheduled for launch in 1986, but were delayed by the Challenger accident. The Hubble Space Telescope wa awakened from it self-induced sleep today but it wa still without the use of it high-speed antenna, and it science instrument were on hold, unable to begin any observation. We are out of the `safe-mode' right now, said Steve Terry, a supervisor of the engineer controlling the telescope. He said the telescope wa running on a normal control-all mode, where it own computer and sensor guide where it is pointing. Discovery's astronaut, meanwhile, packed their gear for a return to Earth Sunday, made some last-minute observation of Earth and talked with ground-based reporter about their flight. Pilot Charles Bolden said he wa especially upbeat about the widespread public awareness of the telescope, which is expected eventually to look back 14 billion light year nearly to the birth of the universe. It's hard to go somewhere and find someone who ha never heard of the Hubble Space Telescope, said Bolden. It make little kids' eye light up. It make little kid want to learn how to add and subtract and study science. The telescope's big eye ha remained open, but Hubble had been in a safe mode with all motion stopped because of earlier problem in linking the high-speed dish antenna with a relay satellite. The antenna are the primary link for relaying scientific data to the ground. Terry said that even in the safe mode, one of the tape recorder in the telescope read telemetry signal from all it system and that these would be played to Earth and analyzed when the antenna are working properly. We expect to use that data to investigate what happened, he said. Engineers are able to send command to the telescope via it secondary antenna but the communication system is not useful for scientific data, which must be transmitted at a high rate of speed. We're putting the scientific instrument in a hold mode, in effect a standby mode, he said. Shortly after 6 am. EDT, controller at the Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md., completed a series of command that took the telescope out of it safe mode and then began to run a 12-hour computer program to monitor Hubble's health. It will take another day before the $1.5 billion telescope is operating the way it wa supposed to at this point in the startup process, said Hubble deputy project manager Jean Olivier. We're backing up to a very deliberate and slow and careful approach to these problem, Olivier said Friday. This is not the time to do anything dumb. The telescope problem have put the flight center several day behind, but the five astronaut who deployed it earlier this week were sticking to their schedule. Landing is scheduled for 9:48 am. EDT Sunday at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., but flight controller were keeping a close watch on the weather. Winds were predicted to be about 20 mph with gust up to 29 mph. Mission rule dictate that headwind cannot exceed 29 mph at touchdown. The shuttle carry enough supply to stay in orbit three day beyond Sunday if necessary, NASA said. Mission Control awakened the crew member at about 1:30 am. EDT today by playing the song, Cosmos. Thanks for the wake-up music, it's pretty appropriate for today, said Commander Loren Shriver. The song wa selected in honor of Hubble Space Telescope, which is now open for business, said Mission Control commentator James Hartsfield. The astronaut were to finish up their experiment and photography today and pack for the trip home. They also planned to hold a news conference from space with reporter at the Johnson Space Center. Shriver and pilot Charles Bolden were to run through a series of test to make certain the shuttle's computer and control jet were ready for return to Earth. The crew deployed Hubble on Wednesday but they had stayed close to the telescope in case there wa trouble opening the aperture door. Mission specialist Bruce McCandless and Kathryn Sullivan were prepared to perform a space walk today to crank it open in orbit 380 mile above Earth. But that proved unnecessary when the door wa opened Friday morning, exposing the telescope's finely polished 94.5-inch eye to starlight for the first time. Two of Hubble's four position-stabilizing gyroscope stopped working when the door opened, but engineer later got them back on line. The gyroscope were knocked out by the motion and that, too, kept the telescope in the safe mode, said Dave Drachlis, director of orbital verification at Goddard. A colleague, Steve Terry, said Hubble's system were set at conservative limit for the first operation and that caused many malfunction. There also were two communication outage totaling several hour. Hubble is designed with safe mode so it can be the master of it own destiny in case contact with an orbiting communication system is lost for extended period, Terry said. NASA had planned to release it first test image from the telescope on Tuesday, showing an open star cluster in the constellation Carina. But Terry said that would be delayed because of the antenna problem. Scientific data will follow in a month or two. The telescope, named for the late astronomer Edwin P. Hubble, will enable astronomer over it 15-year working lifetime to look back 14 billion year and possibly determine the age of the universe. The universe is believed to have been created about 15 billion year ago in a cosmic explosion. Hubble provided the basis for the big-bang theory of creation. He discovered during the 1920s that the universe is expanding and that the farther the galaxy is from Earth, the faster it is moving away. After year of delay and a last-minute snag, the Hubble Space Telescope wa freed from the shuttle Discovery on Wednesday and, glinting in the sunlight, drifted into orbit on it 15-year search for new world. Mission specialist Steven Hawley released Hubble from the end of the shuttle's 50-foot-long mechanical arm after a delay in getting one of the telescope's solar wing unfurled. The first of NASA's great observatory is now on station at 330 nautical mile above the Earth, Mission Control's Jeffrey Carr said. The telescope really looked great a we flew away from it, and we sure hope it doe good work, Discovery commander Loren J. Shriver said later. The $1.5 billion telescope wa released at 3:38 pm. EDT a the shuttle entered it 20th orbit of Earth, nearly two hour and one orbit later than planned. The shuttle then backed away. Thank you very much for the ride, said Mike Harrington, director of orbital verification at Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md. Mission specialist Bruce McCandless and Kathryn Sullivan had been in the shuttle's airlock, ready to walk inspace to free the solar panel. That proved to be unnecessary. Close but no cigar, but better for the Hubble that it went the way it did, Sullivan said. She and McCandless had trained for nearly five year to make such a rescue mission. The first solar array unreeled from it mast at midday Wednesday a the shuttle passed 380 statute mile, or 330 nautical mile, above South America's eastern coast. It started providing power to the telescope's battery, which otherwise had only eight hour of charge. Deployment of the starboard panel, however, wa more troublesome. It wouldn't budge when latch were first released, then moved about a fifth of it 39-foot length, and stopped again. A third attempt rolled the panel out all the way. Houston, we see motion, Commander Loren J. Shriver reported. Hawley began the long process of releasing Hubble shortly after 7 am. EDT when he grasped it with Discovery's 50-foot-long mechanical arm and carefully hoisted the 12{-ton telescope high above the shuttle. Hubble wa taken off shuttle electrical power just before it wa lifted out of the cargo bay and wa operating on it own nickel-hydrogen battery. At one day, seven minute into the flight of Discovery, Hubble is now on it own internal power, Carr said. The game ha begun. The race is on. The clock is ticking. Worries that the telescope's instrument would be starved for electricity eased after the first solar panel wa stretched out. Television camera aboard Discovery showed the first array a it wa pulled from it reel slowly but steadily, the sun reflecting off the gold-colored panel and silvery telescope. Discovery wa 380 statute mile above Earth, 70 mile higher than any shuttle ha ever flown. The orbit wa dictated by the need to put the telescope above the Earth's distorting atmosphere. Discovery's five astronaut were awed by the view. I'd like to pas on the quote of the day from the on-board astronomer something to the effect that the big marble sure look far away today, Shriver said of Hawley. Astronomers have waited seven year for Hubble to take it place in space. The telescope originally wa scheduled for launch in 1983, but technical problem and the Challenger explosion pushed it back. The mission wa delayed another two week when a faulty power unit on Discovery forced the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to halt the first launch attempt four minute before April 10's scheduled liftoff. On Tuesday, Discovery finally blasted into space, transporting Hubble out of this world and in search of others. The telescope's 10-foot aperture door is to be opened Friday, exposing the finely polished 94.5-inch mirror to starlight. Discovery wa following Hubble in case the door doe not open properly. If a problem develops, McCandless and Sullivan will be prepared once again to walk in space. Fred Wojtalik, Hubble project manager, said the telescope would be tested Thursday for it ability to maneuever before the aperture door is opened. We want to be in full control so we don't ever endanger the Hubble by putting the aperture door close to the sunlight, he said. The telescope cannot focus into the sun because of the sensitivity of it five instrument. If all go well, the crew will land Sunday at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. NASA expects to release it first image from the telescope of an open star cluster in the constellation Carina on Tuesday. Data will follow in a month or two. Astronomers hope to look back to almost the beginning of the time, studying star and galaxy so distant their light ha been traveling to Earth for 14 billion year. They expect to determine precisely how and when the universe wa formed, currently estimated at 15 billion year ago. The telescope is named for the late American astronomer Edwin P. Hubble, who discovered during the 1920s that the universe wa expanding. He also wa responsible for helping to form the Big Bang theory of creation. Ground controller at the Goddard Space Flight Center finally made contact today with the two main antenna on the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope after trying for more than six hour to lock on. Applause erupted in the Hubble control center in Greenbelt, Md., a the glitch that marred Hubble's first full day in space wa solved. We have confirmation that we have achieved communication with the Tracking and Data Relay Satellite through the high-gain antenna system, said NASA's Dave Drachlis. Engineers had said all along they believed the antenna were working all right and that the problem wa in incorrectly pointing either the satellite or the TDRS, an orbiting communication satellite that act a a switchboard. In the successful attempt, they nearly doubled the width of the antennas' beam to take in more territory, from a sweep of 6.2 degree to 10.8 degree. The telescope's low-gain antenna, which receive and transmit information at a much slower rate and can be used in emergency, were working well. Space shuttle Discovery wa 46 mile away, available to remedy certain problem. The outage wa not a problem for which space walker would have been summoned. The five astronaut were otherwise busy making picture of storm over Texas from their 380-mile-high perch, and doing experiment. Steve Terry, director of a team calibrating various aspect of the telescope, said the first outage wa caused by human error and wa not a serious problem. It began between 1 and 1:30 am. EDT and lasted 45 minute to an hour, he said. The second failure occurred at 6:44 am. when controller attempted to send a signal to the telescope's two high-gain antenna through the TDRS. This time it wa a pointing problem, said Jim Elliott, a Goddard spokesman. It's a new spacecraft and we think inexperience dealing with it wa the cause. The telescope, embarking on a 15-year search for new world, wa released from the shuttle's cargo bay Wednesday after a last-minute snag that almost sent two astronaut on an emergency spacewalk. Mission Control awakened the crew early today with a loud rendition of the song Shout, a fraternity house favorite. Good morning, Discovery. I guess you're awake after that song, said Kathy Thornton, shuttle communicator. There are a lot of happy people down here. We saw a great deploy yesterday and Hubble had a good night while you were asleep. We appreciate the good word from everybody, replied Discovery Commander Loren Shriver. After Wednesday's deployment, Shriver gently backed Discovery away from the telescope and put the shuttle through a series of maneuver, the last one completed this morning, to park Discovery in orbit 46 mile behind Hubble. The telescope really looked great a we flew away from it, and we sure hope it doe good work, Shriver said Wednesday. Well, it sure is now, Loren, and thanks for all the great work you've done, replied Mission Control. Galileo is real proud of you. Scientists have hailed the Hubble NASA's most expensive unmanned spacecraft a the greatest advance in astronomy since Galileo raised a small telescope to his eye nearly 400 year ago. Discovery and it five astronaut will follow the telescope while controller at the Goddard center make sure Hubble is operating properly, such a responding to directional command. The next milestone is Friday, when the telescope's 10-foot aperture door is to be opened, exposing the finely polished 94.5-inch mirror to starlight. Then on Tuesday, NASA expects to release the first image from the telescope: an open star cluster in the constellation Carina. Data will follow in a month or two. If the aperture door doesn't open properly, Discovery could return to the telescope so two astronaut could perform a spacewalk to fix it. Hubble project manager Fred Wojtalik said the telescope would be tested today for it ability to maneuver before the aperture door is opened. We want to be in full control so we don't ever endanger the Hubble by putting the aperture door close to the sunlight, he said. Too much light could damage the telescope's sensitive instrument. On Wednesday, mission specialist Steve Hawley used the shuttle's 50-foot robot arm to gently grasp the 12{-ton telescope and hoist it from the cargo bay. One of the telescope's solar array unreeled from it mast a expected and started providing power to the telescope's battery, which otherwise had only eight hour of charge. But there wa trouble with the second panel. It wouldn't budge when the latch were released, and then moved about a fifth of it 39-foot length and stopped again. The panel rolled all the way out on the third attempt. By the final attempt, astronaut Bruce McCandless and Kathryn Sullivan were in their space suit in the airlock, 30 minute away from taking tool in hand and going on an outer-space maintenance call. Wojtalik said the cause of the problem is unknown. The 8{-hour procedure wa performed 380 mile above Earth, 70 mile higher than any shuttle ha ever flown. The orbit wa dictated by the need to put Hubble above the Earth's distorting atmosphere. Astronomers hope to use the telescope to look back to almost the beginning of the time, studying star and galaxy so distant their light ha taken 14 billion year to reach Earth. They hope to determine how and when the universe wa formed, currently estimated at 15 billion year ago. The telescope originally wa scheduled for launch in 1983 but wa delayed by technical problem and the Challenger accident. Discovery, which blasted into orbit Tuesday, is scheduled to land Sunday at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. Seven year late, the Hubble Space Telescope is where it belongs, out of this world and in search of others so distant that they may have been formed at the beginning of time. Less than five hour after it rode into space aboard the shuttle Discovery on Tuesday, the $1.5 billion telescope sent it first test radio signal. At the sign of life, applause and cheer erupted in Mission Control in Houston. As near a we can tell, everything look perfect, said astronaut Steve Hawley from the shuttle. Hawley's job on Wednesday will be to drop the telescope overboard for a 15-year stay in space. Discovery, trailing an arc of white smoke into a brilliant blue sky, carried the silver-colored telescope to an orbit 380 mile above Earth higher by 70 mile than any previous shuttle. There the Hubble will stay to search for yet-unseen wonder of creation with instrument that can look 14 billion year backward in time. Our window on the universe! NASA launch commentator George Diller exulted a the Discovery rose off it seaside launch pad. It's a beautiful day to have Hubble Space Telescope in orbit instead of here on Earth like it's been for so many year, said NASA administrator Richard Truly. Hubble's in it element and I'm delighted. The telescope wa supposed to be launched in 1983, but technical problem and the Challenger accident delayed it deployment. It suffered a further delay two week ago when the countdown wa stopped at the four-minutes-to-go point because of a faulty hydraulic unit on the shuttle. While it remained on Earth, the telescope cost $7 million a month to exercise and keep in readiness. In it first day in space, that checkout and testing continued remotely under control of the Goddard Space Flight Center in Maryland. On hand to watch the Discovery launching wa a contingent of scientist who have hailed the Hubble a the greatest advance in astronomy since Galileo raised a small telescope to his eye nearly 400 year ago. Truly referred to the early-day astronomer when he wa asked about the long delay in getting the telescope to it working station. Somebody the other day said, `Who remembers the day that Galileo picked up his telescope to look at the stars?' said Truly, a former shuttle astronaut. It doesn't matter what day we launch Hubble, it matter that we do it right. The telescope is 43 foot long and 14 foot in diameter, about the size of a railroad tank car. When it fly free, it will receive electrical power for it six scientific instrument from two wing-like solar array that extend outward on each side. It is named after the late astronomer Edwin P. Hubble, who theorized that the universe wa expanding and that the farther away a galaxy is, the faster it is traveling. That gave support to the theory that a massive explosion the Big Bang created the universe 10 to 20 billion year ago. The Hubble is expected to help provide the answer to two major questions: How old is the universe? How big is it? The telescope ha two mirror, one 94.5 inch in diameter, the other 12 inch. Two of the instrument are camera, two are spectrometer and one is a photometer. In addition, the fine pointing system act a a sixth instrument by providing precise measurement of distance. On Wednesday, Hawley is to grapple the 12{-ton telescope with the shuttle's mechanical arm, lift it out of the cargo bay, point it, and after a long checkout drop it overboard to orbit on it own. In the cargo bay, the telescope receives electrical power from the shuttle. But the juice is cut when the instrument is lifted out and it will depend on internal battery until the solar panel are extended to receive light from the sun. Should the solar panel not deploy, mission specialist Bruce McCandless and Kathryn Sullivan will be standing by, partially dressed in space suit, ready to go into the open cargo bay to unfurl the array manually. Discovery's launch wa not without it problem. With 31 second left in the countdown, the computer that run the final moment before liftoff refused to close a fuel valve and stopped the launch process. The problem wa overcome and the shuttle lifted off at 8:34 am. EDT, about three minute late. The shuttle is scheduled to land Sunday at 9:49 am. EDT at Edwards Air Force Base in California. On the way uphill, a Commander Loren J. Shriver put it, the shuttle's windshield wa splattered with several fleck of thing. He said the windshield wa streaked by the debris and that it also wa smeared when the spent booster rocket fell off during the climb to orbit. The astronaut also had problem with their UHF radio circuit, and one of the ship's small rear thruster wa inoperative. Neither problem wa considered serious. The shuttle that put the Hubble Space Telescope into orbit also carry an instrument used in the 1920s by astronomer Edwin Hubble: the eyepiece from what once wa the world's most powerful telescope. It's a great pleasure to have something of such historical significance and something that so directly symbolizes Edwin Hubble's fundamental contribution to astronomy, astronaut Kathy Sullivan said Friday a she circled the Earth in space shuttle Discovery. The eyepiece from the Mount Wilson Observatory's 100-inch Hooker Telescope wa carried into orbit by Sullivan. After she brings the eyepiece back to Earth, it will be placed on display at the observatory. It's basically a symbolic gesture from the past of astronomy to the future of astronomy, said Lyn McAfee, spokeswoman for the Mount Wilson Institute. The Pasadena-based group run the observatory, located in the San Gabriel Mountains outside Los Angeles. The discovery made by Hubble on the 100-inch telescope at Mount Wilson gave u a giant leap forward in our understanding of the universe, McAfee said. We believe the Hubble Space Telescope will do the same thing. The Hooker Telescope wa the world's most powerful telescope from it construction in 1918 until 1948, when the 200-inch Hale Telescope wa placed in operation at Mount Palomar Observatory northeast of San Diego. Using the Hooker Telescope, Hubble wa the first to determine the distance to a galaxy outside the Milky Way, the institute said in a statement. This crucial discovery provided the first definite proof that other galaxy existed far beyond the confines of our own local galaxy, the institute said. During the 1920s and 1930s, Hubble and an assistant used the Hooker telescope to take thousand of photograph of faint galaxy, showing that most of them were moving away from each other very quickly. This provided observational evidence for the concept, suggested by Einstein's Theory of Relativity, that the universe is expanding, the institute said. Hubble's work helped convince scientist the universe wa created in a giant explosion, called the big bang, an estimated 15 billion year ago. The Hooker Telescope wa mothballed in 1985 by the Carnegie Institution, former operator of the observatory, in a money-saving move. The institute hope to obtain fund to reopen it.
column5: The shuttle Discovery triumphantly launches the Hubble Space Telescope.
column6: Two weeks after an aborted first try, the shuttle Discovery roared from Cape Canaveral into orbit 380 statute miles above earth.  There it successfully released the $1.5 billion dollar Hubble Space Telescope from its cargo bay.  Now in the process of overcoming some start-up problems, the telescope should soon be operational.
column7: The shuttle Discovery soared into space to launch its history-making payload, the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope.  While orbiting at 380 statute miles above Earth, it will provide astronomers worldwide with 10 times better resolution and 25 times more sensitivity than ground-based observatories.  The telescope's release from the shuttle Discovery was delayed because a solar power panel took three tries before it fully unfurled.  Once released, ground controllers were unable to link up the telescope's two high-gain antennas with their assigned relay satellite.  However, scientists, optimistic that the Hubble will soon be operational, authorized the shuttle Discovery crew to return home.
column8: Following an aborted first try, the shuttle Discovery soared into space to launch its history-making payload, the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope.  Named after the American astronomer Edwin Hubble who did pioneering work leading to the "Big Bang" concept of the universe, it is NASA's most expensive spacecraft.  While orbiting at 380 statute miles above Earth during its expected 15-year working lifetime, it will provide astronomers world-wide with 10 times better resolution and 25 times more sensitivity than ground-based observatories.  Free of Earth's distorting atmosphere, it may be able to look back almost to the beginning of time.  The telescope's release from the shuttle Discovery came two hours and one orbit later than planned.  A troublesome solar power panel took three tries before it fully unfurled, causing the delay.  Two Mission Specialists astronauts were standing-by to unfurl the panel manually if necessary.  Then more start-up problems, ground controllers were unable to link up the telescope's two high-gain antennas with their assigned relay satellite.  A weaker back-up antenna system is working.  The telescope was placed on special flight modes until these start-up problems are resolved.  Confident that the Hubble will soon be operational, the shuttle Discovery is preparing to return home.
column9: Discovery carries $1.5 billion Hubble Telescope to space April 24, 1990
column10: On April 24, 1990, shuttle Discovery carried the Hubble Space Telescope 380 miles into space, then followed briefly to assist if necessary. In orbit above Earth's distorting atmosphere for 15 years, Hubble would see 10 times better than Earth telescopes. Hubble's launch had been delayed since 1983. Hubble cost $1.5 billion.
