column12: On Tuesday, April 24, 1990, shuttle Discovery carried the 12.5-ton Hubble Space Telescope 380 miles into space. Once in orbit above Earth's distorting atmosphere, Hubble would be able to see 10 times better than the largest Earth telescopes. Wednesday it was lifted into space by Discovery's mechanical arm and released into orbit. Friday the 94.5-inch mirror was exposed to starlight. Saturday controllers took Hubble out of safe mode. Problems with a solar power array, communications antennas, and two position-stabilizing gyroscopes -- exacerbated by conservative limits set on systems -- put Hubble several days behind schedule and delayed transmittal of the first photograph. Discovery's astronauts -- Shriver, Bolden, Hawley, McCandless, and Sullivan - - were all veterans of previous flights. The shuttle followed Hubble for two days to assist if necessary. A seven-month checkout period would follow. Spacelab Astro was to be put up two weeks later to give Hubble additional target information. Hubble, delayed since 1983, cost $1.5 billion. Spare parts, training, and software cost $500 million more. Maintenance cost $7 million a month on Earth and will cost $200 million yearly in orbit, for Hubble's 15-year lifetime.  Discovery carried the Hooker Telescope eyepiece used by astronomer Edwin Hubble, for whom the Hubble is named.

column3: INDIA suffered a fresh wave of terror last night when an explosion destroyed two block of flat in the centre of the city of Calcutta, killing at least 45 people and injuring score of others. Police said a bomb exploded in the crowded trade and residential district of Bowbazaar shortly after midnight, causing two block of flat to collapse and trapping up to 70 people in the rubble. The identity of the bomber wa unknown but the explosion come just five day after over 250 people were killed and at least 1,200 injured in a series of bomb attack aimed at the heart of the Indian business capital of Bombay. A militant Sikh group fighting for independence for the Indian state of Punjab ha claimed responsibility for the Bombay blast, but police are unconvinced, saying they were carried out by a foreign group in connivance with 'local criminals'. In what many interpreted a a reference to Pakistan, with whom India ha fought three war, last week Mr Shankarrao Chavan, the federal home (interior) minister, told parliament in New Delhi that he suspected 'an international conspiracy.' Most of the estimated 125 people living in the Calcutta flat were in their bed when the blast occurred, setting fire to both building, according to official in the city's central control room. At least 45 people were dead on arrival at hospital, they said. Last Friday a series of car bomb exploded in Bombay in what the government described a a systematic attack on India's commercial heart. Among the target were the Bombay Stock Exchange, the landmark Air India building, a shopping complex, and two hotel near the airport. The attack in Calcutta and Bombay are a severe setback to attempt to heal the wound created by recent intercommunal violence, which ha caused deep shock throughout India. More than 2,000 people died in riot, including over 700 in Bombay, after the razing of a mosque at Ayodhya in northern India by Hindu zealot on December 6. Some fear the wave of bomb attack is designed to stir a renewal of communal strife and undermine effort by the government of Mr P V Narasimha Rao to open up the economy and attract foreign investment and tourism. Last night national and local state leader appealed for calm in an attempt to prevent a renewed outbreak of violence. Mr Rao urged the nation to ignore rumour after the 'inhuman and criminal blast'. A ROW ha erupted between the Bombay stock exchange, India's largest stock market, and the Securities and Exchange Board of India, the security watchdog, over the board's recent first-ever inspection of stockbrokers' book. The Sebi ha accused stockbroker of flouting the exchange's rule, including regulation on margin trading designed to limit the risk of member defaulting through excessive speculative investment. It ha also accused the exchange authority of failing to enforce rule and of poor administration. The stock exchange denied the allegation, saying they were 'baseless, made out of context and blown out of proportion.' The argument will do nothing to restore investors' faith in the stock market where, a measured by the Bombay stock exchange's 30-share index, share have fallen 48 per cent from their peak early last year, including a 320 point fall since the government's budget wa announced two week ago. Yesterday the index closed at 2330. Foreign investor, who are being wooed by India a a source of much-needed capital, will also be concerned at the latest allegation of poor management at the exchange. In one of it most damaging passage, the inspectors' report alleges that D S Prabhoodas, a leading firm headed by Mr Hemendra Kothari, a former BSE president, and by Mr Jaswant Chotalal, a member of the BSE's governing body, avoided margin payment totalling Rs185.4m (Pounds 408m). Mr Kothari said yesterday that most of the transaction covered by the report were off-exchange deal directly between financial institution for which margin payment were not required. Mr M R Mayya, the BSE's executive director, said BSE rule permitted such bilateral off-exchange transaction. Sebi also accused the exchange of mismanaging the administration of it building. This week's argument is only the latest in a series of dispute which began almost a soon a Sebi started operation a year ago. It wa established by Mr Manmohan Singh, the finance minister, a a crucial element in financial reform. Brokers claim the Sebi is heavy-handed and fails to understand their need. They say rule must be applied flexibly and many firm are extremely small and unable to carry the cost of extra regulation. But the finance minister is backing Sebi to the hilt and singled it out for praise in his recent budget speech. Finance ministry official believe loose regulation allow broker and others to dodge tax and also contributed to last year's security market scandal in which bank, including the UK's Standard Chartered Bank, lost a combined gross total of Rs40bn. The 29-storey Jijobhoy Towers, home of the Bombay Stock Exchange, wa rocked by two powerful bomb last Friday, leaving 60 dead and 200 injured. The market reopened on Monday in an attempt to return to normal. It ha had to compromise - trading ha been restricted to an hour a day, and dealing ha moved back to the traditional ring, where it stopped a year ago. Dealers seemed to like this, the BSE index rising by 5.6 per cent on Monday and Tuesday. But another bomb blast in Calcutta triggered nervous selling yesterday, and the index came back by 50.62, or 2.1 per cent, to 2,40923. All this ha taken place against a volatile background: the Bombay equity market, over the past six week or so, ha had to contend first with unusually bullish speculation, before the national budget on February 27, and subsequently with some savage expression of disappointment. Dr Manmohan Singh, the Indian finance minister, disappointed trader in the budget at the end of last month. He postponed corporate tax reform by a year, denying hope of a tax cut recommended by an expert group. He did reduce excise and import duty on a broad front, but left out the cement and steel sector, where share price had been boosted by pre-budget speculation. To top it all, Dr Singh refused to equate domestic investor with their overseas counterpart in taxing short-term capital gain. He lowered the tax to 30 per cent from 65 per cent for expatriate Indians and foreign investor but for local investor it remained at 44.5 per cent. Taking the tax concession for granted, trader had driven up share price in February to make a kill later. Instead, the budget turned out to be a nightmare. While industry and business welcomed the statement which, for once, did not propose any new tax, Professor Rusi Taraporewala, the stock market theorist and academic, said a reduction in import duty would leave corporate profit ex-growth this year. The relative lack of financial concession meant that disappointed trader sold with a vengeance and, until the weekend, the market seemed bottomless a equity price plummeted to a 13-month low. Overseas investor fuelled the downtrend a they sold some half a million share of Reliance Industries, arbitraging between the share price on the Bombay stock exchange and the market price of it Euro-issue of global depository receipt (GDRs). The opportunity arose after a change in Indian regulation which allows international investor to convert GDRs into the underlying stock. At the current conversion rate of Rs31 per US dollar, the Reliance GDR fetched Rs170 per share against the BSE quotation of Rs210. The BSE 30-share index plunged by more than one-fifth to 2,287 on March 10, from 2,893 at the post-budget trading session on February 27. Share price rebounded last week, taking the index to 2,361 and the uptrend, on balance, ha continued this week in spite of the bomb blast on Friday. Whether or not the surge will turn into a strong rally will depend on the ability of bull to maintain their momentum. They are hoping that foreign portfolio investment will pick up with the restoration of trading after 'Black Friday', and the successful sale of Reliance stock on the BSE by international investor. The Indian stock market have been passing through a series of crisis since December, when activist of the Bhartiya Janta party pulled down the Babri mosque at Ayodhya, sparking off communal riot. Mr Mark Bulloch of Jardine Fleming take the domestic political situation in his stride. 'Nothing dramatic ha happened a far a foreign investor are concerned,' he say. 'They are appraising the political situation.' In the meantime, there is no compulsion for local investor to sell. In this, they are more fortunate than they were in previous year, when they were under pressure to take advantage of a long-term capital gain tax exemption before the financial year ended in March. The exemption ha been replaced by a flat 20 per cent tax this year which, according to dealer, put bull and bear on an even footing. THE INDIAN government flew federal paramilitary troop into Bombay last night after more than a dozen bomb exploded in the city, killing about 200 people and injuring more than a thousand. The device, mostly car bomb, appeared to be a systematic attack on India's commercial heart. All exploded within 90 minute in the afternoon. Among the target were the Bombay Stock Exchange, the landmark Air India building, a shopping complex, and two hotel near the airport. The identity of the bomber wa unknown, but the attack were a severe setback to India's attempt to heal the wound created by recent intercommunal violence, which ha caused deep shock throughout India. More than 2,000 people died in riot, including over 700 in Bombay, after the razing of a mosque at Ayodhya in northern India by Hindu zealot on December 6. The bomb appeared designed to stir a renewal of communal strife and to undermine effort by the government of Mr PV Narasimha Rao to open up the economy and attract foreign investment and tourism. One of the target wa close to the headquarters of Shiv Sena, a Hindu nationalist party accused of fomenting violence during the riot, in which most victim were Moslems. National and local state leader appealed for calm in an attempt to prevent a renewed outbreak of violence. Mr Rao urged the nation to ignore rumour after the 'inhuman and criminal bomb blasts'. Mr Sharad Pawar, the former federal defence minister just re-appointed chief minister of Maharashtra state, said all road into Bombay had been blocked and the army put on alert. He said: 'It is aimed at disrupting the economy and it appears a conscious effort because only Bombay seems to be the target.' Mr Shankarrao Chavan, the federal home (interior) minister, told parliament in New Delhi: 'We suspect an international conspiracy.' The Indian High Commission in London said the attack were 'part of the externally supported terrorism which ha targeted India for some time'. However, Indian official stopped short of directly accusing Pakistan, the country's arch-enemy. The bomb attack were spread throughout the city and were clearly aimed at the city's better-off business people - in contrast to the riot in which victim were mainly poor. At the 28-storey stock exchange building, about 3,000 people were on the second-storey trading floor when a bomb exploded in the underground car park, hurling shard of glass across the floor and into the street. Some victim were crushed in the stampede to escape. Outside, burned body lay among litter from shattered building. MR TEG BAHADUR Thapar wa serving lunch from his stall outside the Bombay stock exchange on Friday when he wa showered with flying glass and broken concrete in one of 13 explosion which rocked the city and left at least 255 people killed and over 1,200 injured. 'I'm lucky to be alive,' he said from his hospital bed. 'Who did this? Who can stop this happening again?' Across Bombay people were asking themselves the same question this weekend. They sensed there wa an enormous difference from the riot which scarred the city in December and again in January. Those were caused by a traditional mix of crime, political agitation and ancient Hindu-Moslem hatred stirred by the destruction of the mosque in Ayodhya. The weapon used were mostly primitive - knife, club and petrol bottle. Friday's outrage, by contrast, bear the deadly stamp of high-technology terrorism, complete with Semtex plastic explosive, high-grade timer, efficient organisation and money. The only comparable previous incident wa the assassination in 1991 of Mr Rajiv Gandhi, the former prime minister, by Sri Lanka's Tamil Tiger terrorist. But that wa a single bomb aimed at one man - the explosion in Bombay were designed to terrorise the nation's commercial capital. Bombay account for 35 per cent of India's export. Mr P V Narasimha Rao, the prime minister, described the blast a an attack on India's economy. The immediate assumption both at the highest level and in the street of Bombay wa that those responsible must have been foreigner or had foreign help. But these suggestion were seen in Bombay a a deliberate attempt to deflect attention from the people who in the popular mind are the real suspect - Moslem extremist who might have taken revenge for the riot which hit India after the Ayodhya mosque's destruction and which left 2,000 dead, including 700 in Bombay. If Moslems are found to have staged the attack, the Indian authority will certainly suspect that the operation wa supported from a Moslem country, notably Pakistan. The implication would be vast. Breaking diplomatic relation would be the minimum step Delhi could take on a dangerous road. Mr Rao chose his word carefully during his visit to Bombay: 'There is a definite possibility that our search may not stop within the country. I do not want to name anybody because it will have ramification within and outside the country.' There is no evidence linking the attack to Moslem extremist, let alone to Pakistan. Even if Moslem group are found to be responsible for the bombing, they could have been supplied from other Moslem country. India would still face a diplomatic crisis but hardly on the same scale. For the moment, such concern seem remote from the street on Bombay, where the atmosphere yesterday wa calm. Workmen were clearing away rubble at the blast site, including the blackened stock exchange building. Bombayites seemed determined to put the outrage behind them. At the Gymkhana Club and dozen of other sport ground, hundred of men and boy were playing cricket a they do every Sunday. Others were walking along the seafront by the arch of the Gateway of India. The stock exchange authority plan to re-start trading a soon a they can -probably today - using an old trading floor the exchange vacated only last year. Businessmen estimated the main loss to the city would be the loss of life and injury and the damage caused to blasted building. They did not expect the same widespread disruption to production a occurred during the riot. Some of the credit for the limited disruption should go the government and the police for promptly calling paramilitary and regular troop to help patrol sensitive district. But much more should go to the people of Bombay, who, so far at least, have refused to be goaded into violent protest by the bomber.
column5: Trials and Tribulation of the Bombay Stock Exchange
column6: In March 1993 the Bombay Stock Exchange survived a wave of selling, governmental criticism, a bomb attack that killed at least 255 people, another bombing in Calcutta killing 45, and the looming threat of war and rioting to reverse the downward trend and head upward again.
column7: In early March 1993 the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) reacted to a postponement of tax reform. By March 10 the BSE index sunk to a 13-month low at 2,287. On March 12 a coordinated bomb attack against targets in Bombay including the BSE killed at least 255 people and injured 1,200 threatening a resumption of Hindu-Moslem rioting which had occurred earlier. The BSE reopened on March 15, but on March 16 an explosion in Calcutta killed at least 45. Despite the tragedies and threat of war or rioting, the BSE index had climbed up as far as 2,409.23 by March 17.
column8: In March of 1993 the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) experienced a series of shocks, but emerged on the upbeat. The first blow was reaction to a report from the Indian finance minister on February 27 postponing corporate tax reform. Disappointed with the postponement, traders sold with a vengeance driving equity prices to a 13-month low with the BSE index down to 2,287 on March 10 compared to 2,893 on February 27. Then the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) accused the BSE of violating regulations limiting speculative investments. On the night of March 12 the BSE was damaged as thirteen bombs exploded in Bombay killing at least 255 people, injuring over 1,200 and threatening resumption of intercommunal riots between Hindus and Moslems. Despite structural damage, the BSE reopened on March 15. On March 16 an explosion in a residential district of Calcutta killed at least 45. A Sikh group claimed responsibility but official Indian comments implied that Pakistan was the main suspect. With the looming threat of riots and war, the BSE index rose by 2.1 per cent on March 15 and even after the Calcutta bombing settled at 2,409.23 on March 17, a marked improvement over the March 10 reading.
column9: Bombay Stock Exchange fights for equilibrium through bombs and investigations.
column10: The Bombay Stock Exchange has suffered a week of onslaught but remains open.  With the market already down 48 percent in not much more than a year, the exchange was accused of violating rules.  India's commercial heart, including the exchange, was bombed on Friday and more explosions hit Calcutta on Wednesday.
column11: The Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) remains open following a week of onslaught.  First the Securities and Exchange Board of India accused the market of ignoring and failing to enforce rules.  The Indian market already had fallen 48 percent since early last year, aggravated by a negative reaction to the Indian budget.  On Friday afternoon, India's commercial heart, including the BSE, was hit with car bombs.  While a militant Sikh group claimed responsibility, Indian officials still suspect Moslem extremists seeking a return of communal strife.  The BSE was able to resume limited trading, but a slight rise was halted by an explosion Wednesday in Calcutta.
column12: The Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) remains open following a week of onslaught.  Last week, the Securities and Exchange Board of India completed its first inspection of the books and accused the market of ignoring and failing to enforce rules.  This is just the latest dispute between the government and the troubled BSE.  The Indian market already had fallen 48 percent since early last year, aggravated by a negative reaction to the Indian budget, which helped foreign and expatriate investors, but did not provide the expected tax relief to local industry.  On Friday afternoon, the BSE, along with other Bombay commercial centers, was hit with car bombs.  These attacks struck at the heart of India's commerce, seemingly aimed at undermining government efforts to expand foreign investment and tourism.  While a militant Sikh group claimed responsibility, Indian officials still suspect Moslem extremists, maybe with Pakistani help, seeking revenge for the December 1992 destruction of a mosque in northern India.  The BSE was able to resume limited trading on Monday and the index rose for two days.  This rise was halted by an explosion Wednesday, which killed 45 and injured a score in a central Calcutta apartment complex.  Fears abound that communal strife will return.

column3: THE revelation that John Major is capable of candid, blunt and salty language when talking off-the- record to friendly journalist ha surprised some people. It ha even been suggested that the recording of the prime minister's conversation with Michael Brunson, ITN's political editor, in which Major used a variety of four-, six- and eight-letter word to communicate his lack of fondness for certain colleague, may do him good. With luck, it is reckoned, Major's image a a leaden-tongued wimp may undergo correction. What piffle. Major is a gonner, especially after this week's revolt of the wooden-tops in the Christchurch by-election, where a Conservative majority of 23,015 at last year's general election wa converted into a 16,427 majority for the Liberal Democrats. Fifteen month too late, the voter of Christchurch rounded on the Tories with a malignant and squeaky fury. In reality, all politician, not just Major, are far more candid and salty when chatting in private than when speaking in public. In public, they have to be careful of what they say, so their utterance achieve a horrible mattness. But in private they relax. Their syntax disappears. Their word become nonsensical. They swear and joke and shout. It really is a spectacle. To show you what I mean, I spoke yesterday to John Major and John Smith. Smith, a Scot, is leader of the Labour Party, though not many people know that. In the aftermath of Christchurch, where Labour lost it deposit, I wanted to provoke the two Johns into a spot of real soul-searching. To guarantee them privacy, I used a signal-scrambler. No one could have eavesdropped. Their response were true to form. But I have left out the swear-words because the new Financial Times Style Guide state that 'the gratuitous use of expletive or obscenity is discouraged . . . Four-letter expletive will usually be confined to infrequent use in the review (Arts) pages.' I can live with that, though why the artsy-fartsies should receive any dispensation is a puzzle. First, I tackled Major. I said: 'Did you read, John, what Olivier Blanchard, Rudiger Dornbusch, Stanley Fischer, Franco Modigliani, Paul A Samuelson and Robert Solow wrote, in just one article, in the FT this week? They were describing Europe's lunatic monetary policy and exchange rate arrangement. They did not pull their punch. I bet you went chalk-white. 'So why not walk the plank, John? You are the most unpopular prime minister since the start of the fourth century. Why invite more punishment? Unfairly or not, you are drawing the blame for all life's unpleasantness, let alone the cock-ups.' 'Are you sure?' the prime minister replied. 'I mean . . . how did it come about, Michael . . . like, Christchurch, y'know - load of . . . let me put it to you - the economy, of course . . . I mean, wimpy guy like me. But I'm not giving in like that, like . . .' On and on it went. Then I rang John Smith. I told him I had been impressed with his interview with Andrew Marr in The Independent on Thursday, in which he sharpened up his promise to introduce meaty political reform (if he ever get elected), including a referendum on proportional representation. I said: 'You are starting to raise your game, John. Many people will have agreed with your assertion that democracy in Britain is decaying, and that the Tories must be roasted for their arrogance, incompetence, complacency and sharp practice - especially their 'centralisation of power and the elimination of opposition'. But some of your critic still accuse you, John, of laziness and ineffectualness. What do you say to that?' 'Away, ye thowless jad,' shouted the Labour leader. 'Gie me o'wit an' sense a life, behint a kist to lie an' sklent. Our Stibble-rig wa Rab M'Graen, a clever, sturdy fellow, but then he wa sae fley'd by his showther gae a keek, an' tumbl'd wi' a wintle. Likewise with political and constitutional reform, Michael, for by the L - - d, tho' I should beg wi'lyart pow, I'll laugh, an' sing, an' shake my leg, a lang's I dow]' After that, I thought of telephoning Wing-Commander Paddy Ashdown, leader of the Liberal Democrats, to solicit his view on Christchurch. But I couldn't raise the energy. Last year a biography of Mrs Norma Major - or, if we are being old-fashioned, Mrs John Major - claimed that the Majors' favourite film wa Being There. I entirely concur with their choice. In case you did not see that marvellous film, this, in essence, wa the plot: a man no one know anything about, a gardener called Chauncey, rise without trace to become, by the end of the film, a serious candidate for the US presidency. Chauncey, played by Peter Sellers, utters only mundane sentiment in a halting monotone but this convinces the Republican party's power broker that he is a sure-fire winner. In Chauncey's bromide everyone seems to hear what they want to believe. He ha a deadly innocence. No wonder the Majors liked this film. John Major must, at some level, have appreciated the similarity between his own, strangely intangible, rise and that of Chauncey's. If he did not see the similarity, that is still more revealing. Do not protest that the urban John Major could not identify with a gardener. In an interview with Farmers Weekly, a few day ago, Major disclosed an unknown fact: his father wa once a farmer. Farmers Weekly, you see, had asked Major how he had 'such obvious empathy with agriculture'. (Well, it wa obvious to Farmers Weekly, anyway.) And Major replied: 'It's simple. My father wa a farmer. He lived on a small farm somewhere in Shropshire.' Francis Wheen of The Guardian, a keen student of Major's mysterious past, immediately rang 10 Downing Street, which claimed that Major's father farmed near Bromsgrove in 1910. As Wheen pointed out, Major wa an unresponsive minus 33 year old at that time, and - a minor point this - Bromsgrove is not in Shropshire. This, of course, doe not mean that Major made everything up. Family folklore is a peculiar thing. Yet when I heard about this, my mind immediately went back to an incident a few month ago, when Major visited Pittsburgh, centre of the US steel industry, a part of his American tour. I recall that he made a great hit by recounting that his father had been a steelworker in the city. A farmer for Farmers Weekly, a Pittsburgh steelworker for the American audience . . . a pattern emerges. Major's father, and therefore by extension John Major himself, can be all thing to all people. If John Major were a different sort of politician, this would be a point barely worth making. But it doe seem all of a piece with Major's approach to wider political issue. On the one hand he will appeal to the pro-Europeans in his own party by claiming to want Britain to be at the heart of Europe. On the other he is free with insulting reference to the European Commission, whenever it is necessary to appeal to an audience of Euro-sceptics. There are those who will argue that this merely mean that Major is a typical democratic politician, that one who want to become prime minister in a democracy must recognise many constituency of interest, not just one. But that ha not been true of Major's most recent Conservative predecessor. Margaret Thatcher wa notoriously dogmatic, even in public, and so too wa Edward Heath, even though he always pretended to be a 'consensus politician'. No, Major's technique is very much his own invention, very much a reflection of his own particular character, itself a product of his unsettled family background. His father, Tom Major-Ball, wa an itinerant figure, moving from place to place, trying his hand at any number of occupation, including the circus. No wonder the young John Major learned the skill of fitting in with prevailing circumstance, no matter how fluctuating. The only problem is the old one: you cannot fool all of the people all of the time. Except in the movie. Dominic Lawson is editor of The Spectator ONE year ago tomorrow, Mr John Major surprised everyone but himself by winning the general election. His honeymoon, after a very personal victory, wa short-lived and now he begin the second year of his hard-won term a a deeply unpopular leader who ha everything still to prove. The past 12 month have been hijacked by internal party difference over Europe, by the debacle surrounding UK withdrawal from the exchange rate mechanism of the European Monetary System, and by a continuing, deep recession which ha disappointed and alienated many traditional Tory supporter in business. Mr Major's anniversary inevitably led yesterday to an outbreak of political point-scoring over the government's record. While Mr Tony Newton, leader of the Commons, conceded: 'No one pretend that the last year ha been easy,' he also claimed that much had been achieved. The government's effort to secure a framework for long-term prosperity wa beginning to pay off. Mr John Smith, the Labour leader, wa joined by 10 frontbench colleague in launching a counter-attack, involving a detailed and documented indictment of Mr Major's failure. He attacked the Tories for building 'a bonfire of pre-election commitments'. Tory allegiance in the business world have also been put under immense pressure, though criticism over policy drift and inaction may soften a recession end. Yesterday Sir Michael Angus, president of the Confederation of British Industry, remained cautious but volunteered: 'If I were a betting man I would say we have the embryo of a recovery.' Mr Major can take little comfort from the conclusion, widespread among industrialist, that his greatest achievement in the past year ha been Britain's withdrawal from the ERM - something which he resisted and over which, in the end, he had no control. Most industrialist, however, find it hard to criticise Mr Major a an individual, with many drawing a flattering parallel between his personal quality and those of his predecessor. He still attracts gratitude for the election victory, which wa seen - despite subsequent problem for the economy - a the best result for business. But, unlike the previous No 10 occupant, he is seen a a weak leader, with little vision and bereft of a clearly articulated political conviction. There is a general perception that, important though Britain's future place in Europe is, the prime minister ha been excessively preoccupied with community affair and associated internal party ruction, to the detriment of the domestic economy. Many industrialist are pleased that Mr Major is now attempting to reshape economic strategy in favour of the manufacturing base. But the jury is out on whether the rhetoric will give way to effective action. ----------------------------------------------------------------------- The first 12 month - election victory to an initial Maastricht defeat ----------------------------------------------------------------------- APRIL Wins election with 21 seat majority 'The country looked a Labour government in the eye and decided that it wa not after all Time for a Change' - Peter Jenkins, the late political commentator 'We have won tonight a magnificent victory, a victory many people thought beyond our grasp' - Major ----------------------------------------------------------------------- MAY Best Conservative local election result for 13 year in England and Wales. Tories win control of 126 council ----------------------------------------------------------------------- JUNE Rio Summit No new British aid to finance the conference decision, only a proposal for a 'Darwin initiative' to exchange information on endangered specie. 'I came here with low expectation and all of those have been met' - Jonathon Porritt, the environmental campaigner 'I believe that both in the short and long term, people will look back and say that at Rio we took a decisive step' - Major ----------------------------------------------------------------------- JULY Britain take over EC presidency 'Those whom the god would destroy they first grant the presidency of the European Council of Ministers' - Mark Almond, Fellow of the Institute for European Defence and Strategic Studies ----------------------------------------------------------------------- AUGUST Two-day Yugoslav peace conference of 30 nation is presented a triumph of international diplomacy for John Major and UN Secretary General Boutros Boutros Ghali 'Talks, what talks?' - Serbian president, Slobodan Milosevic a he storm out while Major is speaking ----------------------------------------------------------------------- SEPTEMBER Black Wednesday Bank of England interest rate rise to 15 per cent before government take sterling out of the EMS. 'The sky is darkening with the wing of chicken coming home to roost' - Lord Callaghan 'There is going to be no devaluation, no realignment, the deflationary option would be a betrayal of our future and it is not government policy' - Major ----------------------------------------------------------------------- OCTOBER Mining closure U-turn Michael Heseltine announces review of 21 of 31 pit under threat 'I'm just getting used to being more popular than John Major' - Arthur Scargill 'What ha happened is a development of what wa in the government's mind. We have to listen to what people say' - Major ----------------------------------------------------------------------- NOVEMBER Matrix Churchill inquiry John Major challenged over claim he had 'specific' and 'personal' knowledge that Matrix Churchill exported machine tool to Iraq for munition manufacture. 'Either minister do not know what is going on in their own department, or they were not prepared to tell' - Allan Rogers, Labour's former defence procurement spokesman ----------------------------------------------------------------------- DECEMBER Edinburgh conference Concessions granted to Danes in hope voter will approve Maastricht at second referendum. Agreement on EC spending level, Maastricht back on track for ratification ----------------------------------------------------------------------- JANUARY Major launch libel action against New Statesman & Society and Scallywag over allegation linking him with businesswoman Claire Latimer. 'It is not our intention to slur the prime minister' - Steve Platt, editor of New Statesman ----------------------------------------------------------------------- FEBRUARY Unemployment top 3m 'Provided the circumstance are right there is no reason why we shouldn't bounce back this time' - Gillian Shephard, secretary of state for employment ----------------------------------------------------------------------- MARCH Maastricht debate More than 40 Tory MPs revolt in first Commons defeat on Maastricht treaty legislation, defying Major's appeal for party unity 'When they started out they weren't even household name in their own homes' - David Mellor on Tory Euro-rebels ----------------------------------------------------------------------- John Major, endorsed by Margaret Thatcher a the politician closest to her heart, wa elected by the Conservative Party Tuesday night to succeed her a prime minister. Major, 47, fell two vote short of winning a majority in voting among the 372 Coservative Party member of Parliament, but his two opponent quickly conceded defeat and the party confirmed Major a the winner. Mrs. Thatcher, ending 11{ year in power, intended to submit her resignation to Queen Elizabeth II on Wednesday morning, and Major would then be called to lead the government. Major, the chancellor of the exchequer, emerged from his official residence at 11 Downing St. Tuesday night smiling and holding hand with his wife, Norma. Inside, Mrs. Thatcher, who came next door from the prime minister's 10 Downing Street residence, embraced Major. I am thrilled and delighted that John Major is to succeed me, the Iron Lady said in a statement released by aide. It is a very exciting thing to become leader of the Conservative Party, and particularly exciting, I think, to follow one of the most remarkable leader the Conservative Party ha ever had, Major said. Our job now I think is quite clear. We are going to unite totally and absolutely, and we're going to win the next general election, said Major, who will be the youngest British prime minister in this century. Major received 185 vote, two short of a majority. Former Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine received 131 and Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd had 56. Hurd and Heseltine conceded within minute, and party official declared Major elected. The party had been torn by the sudden and unexpected leadership challenge by Heseltine, who last week stopped Mrs. Thatcher short of victory in the first round of the leadership race. Mrs. Thatcher had not wanted to leave office, but she decided to resign last week after she wa unable to put down Heseltine's challenge. She said she resigned to let someone from the Cabinet stand against Heseltine. Major and Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd both joined the race, but before the vote her aide spread the word that she wa backing Major. The son of a circus performer and at one time a welfare recipient, Major personifies the value of self-reliance and hard work that Mrs. Thatcher had preached to the nation. His election climaxed a month of British politics-turned-upside down, and the Western world's longest-serving head of government wa driven from office by a revolt in party rank. Heading a government that wa trailing the opposition Labor Party in the poll and suffering a losing streak in local Parliamentary election, Mrs. Thatcher lost control of event after her deputy, Sir Geoffrey Howe, resigned on Nov. 1. Howe, the fourth Cabinet member to resign because of dispute over policy toward the European Community, shocked the House of Commons on Nov. 13 by calling Mrs. Thatcher a threat to Britain's vital interest. The next day, Heseltine announced he would challenge her. Six day later, with Mrs. Thatcher at a 34-nation summit in Paris officially ending the Cold War, Heseltine polled enough vote to deny her re-election a leader. Two day later, she decided to resign after party leader told her she could not win. Heseltine, 57, said Major's election lay the basis for the unity of our party. Hurd said the party needed to unite, and John Major is the right leader for this task. Opposition leader derided Major's election a Thatcherism with a different face. The Conservatives' main rival, the socialist Labor Party, demanded a general election. John Major is a Thatcherette - that is how he sought election and that is how he got elected, said Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock. It mean that the policy that brought the poll tax, recession, heavy mortgage and rising unemployment will go on. During his five-day campaign, Major had aaid he would review the poll tax, an unpopular local tax brought in by Mrs. Thatcher, but he gave no other hint of differing with her. While adopting a gentler tone on the contentious issue of Britain's involvement in Europe, he share her opposition to a single European currency and share her belief in tight restraint on government spending. However, he insisted over the weekend, I am not running a `Son of Thatcher.' I am running a myself, with my own priority and my own program. Major's victory ended a patient, four-year campaign by Heseltine to promote himself a a future leader of the party. Tomorrow always dawn, he said, smiling after conceding defeat. Major wa elected to Parliament in 1979, wa appointed foreign secretary and then chancellor of the exchequer last year. He moved up quickly in the leadership race. By the weekend, opinion poll showed that Major wa nearly a highly regarded by the public a wa Heseltine, who ha been prominent for a decade. Major attracted support from figure on the right wing of the Conservative Party, although his friend insisted Major's own view were more liberal than many supposed. He described himself a conservative on economic issue but liberal on social issue.
column5: Major Defeat; Prime Minister Leads Tories to Third Party Status
column6: The Tories will make Prime Minister John Major, protege of Margaret Thatcher, the scapegoat for their stunning defeat in local elections across Britain in May. Though he won the 1992 general election, the high-school dropout is now accused of being a weak leader, incompetent on both domestic and international issues.
column7: On Easter Sunday, three Cabinet ministers issued statements on behalf of  Prime Minister John Major amidst speculation that he could be forced out this autumn. In May local elections across Britain, however, the Conservatives loss 444 seats, and word circulated that Major was not up to the job.Major became leader of the Conservative Party and Prime Minister after his mentor, Margaret Thatcher resigned under pressure in 1990. Though he won the 1992 general election, the lingering recession and controversies involving European community issues splintered the Tories. He came to be viewed as a weak, vacillating leader, lacking political conviction.
column8: In early May elections across Britain, the Conservatives suffered their worst defeat ever, losing 444 seats. One editorial claims some Conservatives will link the defeats to Prime Minister John Major, and there is speculation that he could be forced out this autumn.A former welfare recipient, John Major was elected Conservative Party leader and successor to his mentor Margaret Thatcher when she resigned under pressure in November 1990. After Mrs. Thatcher submitted her seals of office, Major was called by Queen Elizabeth II to form a new government, and it was expected that there would be no significant policy shift. Major's comment while visiting America a month later that Iraqi troops might have to be "forcibly removed" from Kuwait echoed Mrs. Thatcher's hard-line on the Persian Gulf.Within a year of winning the general election, his popularity had plunged. In the July 1993 Christchurch by-election the Conservative majority of 23,015 the previous year was converted into a 16,427 majority for the Liberal Democrats. Though Major's personal style is preferable to that of Mrs. Thatcher, he is characterized as a vacillating, weak leader, lacking vision and political conviction. Not even recent revelations that Major uses salty language can alter his wimp image.
column9: John Major elected leader of Conservative Party, becomes next Prime Minister.
column10: John Major emerged victorious in an election for leadership of the Conservative Party and became, at 47, Britain's youngest prime minister. His popularity began to decline very soon after his election and he is viewed and weak and indecisive. Having reneged on campaign promises, he is blamed for the recession which plagues Britain.
column11: At 47, John Major became Britain's youngest prime minister. His accession to power followed the surprise resignation of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher following a challenge by former Defense Minister Michael Heseltine to her leadership. Major fell two votes shy of a victory in an election with Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd and Heseltine but both opponents quickly conceded to Major. Since his election, Major has been seen as weak and indecisive. He is an unpopular leader whose cabinet has been rocked by scandal and who reneged on campaign promises. Adding to his unpopularity is the recession which continues plague Britain.
column12: John Major was 47 when he was elected to lead the Conservative Party. Assuming the position of prime Minister from Margaret, Mr. Major became the youngest prime minister since the 19th century. Mr. Major was confirmed as leader of the Conservative Party when his two opponents, former Defense Minister Michael Heseltine and Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd, conceded defeat in an election which saw Major two votes shy of a majority. Major, whose father was a trapeze artist in the circus, overcame many obstacles in his rise to the top. He was a high school drop out and for a time was a welfare recipient. Mr. Major had little time to enjoy his victory as public opinion of him soon soured. While seen as gentler than his abrasive predecessor, he is viewed as timid and indecisive. Almost from the first he has been beset by scandal in his cabinet and a number of controversies ranging from internal party differences over Europe to the debacle surrounding Britain's withdrawal from the exchange rates mechanism of the European Monetary System to a deep and continuing recession. Major came out in strong support of U.S. policy in the Persian Gulf, calling on Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to withdraw his troops from Kuwait.

column3: Japanese writer Kazuo Ishiguro won the 1989 Booker Prize, Britain's top literary award, for his novel The Remains of the Day, judge announced Thursday. The prize is worth $32,000. Judges praised the novel, a love story about a butler's English vacation, a a cunningly structured and beautifully paced performance. Other finalist this year were Canadian Margaret Atwood for Cat's Eye, Irish author John Banville for Book of Evidence, Scotland's James Kelman for A Disaffection and English writer Sybille Bedford for Jigsaw and Rose Tremain for Restoration. After receiving the prize, Ishiguro paid tribute to Salman Rushdie, the 1988 runner-up for the award, who went into hiding in February when he wa threatened with death by Moslems who said his novel The Satanic Verses blasphemed their faith. Now that circumstance have changed, when perhaps it is inconvenient for many people to support his writing, I just felt it wa fitting that we should not turn our back on him, Ishiguro said. Rushdie life in England. Ishiguro, 39, arrived in England at age 6 and now life in south London. He writes in English. In announcing the winner, the judge said: `The Remains of the Day' render with humor and pathos a memorable character and explores the large, vexed theme of class, tradition and duty. It wa narrowly preferred but universally admired. Ishiguro wa a finalist for the Booker Prize in 1986 for his novel An Artist of the Floating World. The Booker Prize is sponsored by Booker, an international food and agriculture business. After hour of heated delib-eration - under a system described a 'mad' by one judge - the Pounds 20,000 Booker Prize for fiction last night went to Mr James Kelman for How Late It Was, How Late, published by Secker and Warburg. The novel, a story of Scottish low-life narrated largely in Glaswegian dialect, is unlikely to prove a popular choice with bookseller, who have damned all six book shortlisted for the prize a boring, elitist and - worst of all - unsaleable. Professor John Bayley, chairman of the Booker judge, acknowledged that Mr Kelman's book in particular might be deemed inaccessible. 'We had an extremely difficult final meeting and were very divided,' he said after three hour of debate. Rabbi Julia Neuberger, the only woman on the judging panel, said she wa made extremely cross by the decision. 'It's just a drunken Scotsman railing against bureaucracy,' she said. 'My eye are stretched in disbelief. The voting system is completely mad. Kelman wa the least favourite of the three front runner. If it had been a short story it would have been fine.' Mr Kelman's book is, according to some observer, the most difficult work to have won the prize. In his acceptance speech, Mr Kelman, perceived by some a a Scottish isolationist, anticipated the criticism, by declaring: 'My culture and my language have the right to exist.' One guest at the prize-giving dinner at London's Guildhall, Mr Salman Rushdie, who won the prize in 1981 with Midnight's Children, remarked: 'James Kelman is good, but not a good a he think he is.' The Booker prize ha, in it 26-year history, always provoked controversy. But this year's row have been of a particularly fine vintage. Prof Bayley went on record with a rousing condemnation of contemporary fiction. Another judge, Mr James Wood, literary critic of The Guardian, wa attacked for failing to reveal that a young novelist being considered for the award, Ms Claire Messud, wa in fact Mrs James Wood. Most damaging of all wa the verdict of the bookseller, who dismissed the shortlist a narcoleptic. The other contender were The Folding Star by Alan Hollinghurst, Beside the Ocean of Time by George Mackay Brown, Paradise by Abdulrazak Gurnah, Reef by Romesh Gunesekera and Knowledge of Angels by Jill Paton Walsh. In spite of heavy publicity, the novel nominated have been selling 50 per cent le than last year's shortlist. Last year's winner, Roddy Doyle's Paddy Clarke Ha Ha Ha, sold 350,000 copy. 'Kelman's novel is unlikely to come anywhere near that,' one bookseller said. Mr Kelman wa also shortlisted for the prize in 1989 for his novel A Disaffection. It is a sensational shortlist: a bestseller about love and hypnotism, a blockbuster about battle and bride in Ruritania, and a pornographic shocker about teenage sex and baby murder so explicit that only an obscure Newcastle publisher would risk printing it. Out are the eminence gris of Victorian letter - novel by Thomas Hardy and Mrs Humphry Ward, who advised Gladstone and Roosevelt, didn't make the grade. This week the shortlist for the hypothetical 1894 Booker Prize will be announced by six judge, including biographer Victoria Glendinning and broadcaster Melvyn Bragg. They have avoided dull and worthy classic and chosen six book which stirred the fin de siecle world and remain compelling today: George du Maurier's Trilby, Anthony Hope's The Prisoner of Zenda, George Moore's Esther Waters, Kipling's Jungle Book, George Gissing's In the Year of Jubilee and RL Stevenson's The Ebb Tide. The winner will be revealed on October 15 (four day after the 1994 Booker Prize ceremony) at the Cheltenham Festival of Literature. Like today's Booker Prize, it is a publishing gimmick; Everyman, which is backing the spoof award, is a significant publisher of classic Victorian novel. But the retrospective Booker is also a fascinating exercise in historical reconstruction. It raise question about how the relationship between literature and society ha changed in the past 100 year. First, the similarity. A good yarn is a good yarn. Of the 1894 book, Trilby is the tale of a tone-deaf model who sings like an angel when mesmerised by the sinister hypnotist Svengali, then croak like a crow when he dy during one of her concert. The Prisoner of Zenda tell of an Englishman impersonating the King of Ruritania and rescuing him from demon. On the 1994 list Romesh Guneskera's Reef is about a Sri Lankan servant boy and his mysterious master, while Jill Paton Walsh's Knowledge of Angels re-enacts the wolf-child legend. All the book on both list are gripping story. The list share key theme. Both, for instance, have book about colonial exploitation - Stevenson's The Ebb Tide and Abdulrazak Gurnah's Paradise, which is set in the First World War in German East Africa. Both provoke in similar way. The controversial book of 1894 were Trilby, with it louche vie boheme milieu, and Esther Waters, in which a 17-year-old girl is seduced, impregnated and offered the service of a professional baby killer for a fiver. It is now seen a Moore's best work, but in 1894 it had problem finding a publisher and the powerful circulating library refused to take it. A century on, the relationship between fiction and sexual morality remains vexed. Last week, a Times critic complained about the inclusion of Alan Hollinghurst's candid novel of homosexual love, The Folding Star, on the Booker list, because it offended Judaeo-Christian ethic. But even if Hollinghurst win the Booker, his novel will not become the succes de scandale of Esther Waters and Trilby, which became the bestselling novel of the 19th century. For the great difference between then and now is that in 1894 a Booker Prize wa not needed to sell fiction. Today, we accept the gap between literary writing, such a Hollinghurst's, and popular bestseller by writer like Jeffrey Archer and Barbara Cartland. This is the gap the Booker try to bridge by giving high-level publicity to work which would not normally reach a mass audience. The trick work - last year's winner, Roddy Doyle's Paddy Clarke Ha Ha Ha sold 360,000 hardback copy. Before the short-list wa announced it sold 10,600. The Victorians, in contrast, were lover of contemporary fiction. Novels accounted for 20 per cent of published book, and no distinction wa made between high and low art. In the mid 19th century, Dickens made Pounds 12,000 for Little Dorrit, the equivalent of nearly Pounds 400,000 today. Between 1861 and 1894, when the population of the UK wa half that of today and the literate population smaller still, Mrs Henry Wood's East Lynne sold 400,000 copy. All the 1894 Booker writer were popular names; they were also serious, skilful writer whose book can be reread with pleasure 100 year later. Why wa fiction so much closer to the public heart in 1894? Social, cultural and psychological reason play a part. Socially, the 1890s reading public wa a vastly more homogenous group than today: a small number of middle class author wrote for a middle class audience at a time when to be literate wa to belong to an elite. The idea of a two-tier, up and down-market, fiction wa irrelevant. Culturally, these writer and reader were certain of their place in the mainstream, and the novel wa their political and intellectual forum. Today we no longer share the Victorian confidence in the novel a a key genre of our age. Modernism and the overturning of the traditional form by Joyce and Woolf weakened 20th-century belief in the novel and encouraged the divergence between highbrow and lowbrow. The dominance of film and television ha made novel a more marginal form and perhaps they no longer attract the most creative talent. George du Maurier originally offered the outline of Trilby to Henry James, who he thought would write a better novel. Today du Maurier would have sold it to Hollywood or the BBC. The fantasy element of fiction, in which we identify with character a if we know them, wa answered in the 19th century by the novel; in the 20th century we have TV soap. Just a the tabloid newspaper feature character from EastEnders, so when Dickens' The Old Curiosity Shop wa running a a serial there wa widespread press speculation on whether Little Nell would die, and reader wrote in begging for her to be saved. Sentimentality, accessibility, topicality - what characterises today's soap were clear feature of the novel in 1894. Both In the Year of Jubilee and Esther Waters, for example, centre on the burning 1890s debate about marriage, feminism and the 'New Woman', yet both are also tearjerker which everyone enjoyed. The 1894 book are compelling because they prefigure our own time and yet are set back from them. Trilby is a tale of hypnotism and the unconscious a decade away from Freud; The Ebb Tide paved the way for Conrad's Heart of Darkness and the first questioning of colonial oppression. It is unlikely that the 1994 Booker choice will speak a eloquently of new trend today. Whereas the 1894 title had contemporary setting, many of the 1994 book are historical (such a Paradise) or are driven by nostalgia (such a Beside the Ocean of Time). Which book will win on October 15? Stevenson will get the sympathy vote because he died in 1894 in Samoa, the setting of The Ebb Tide. Jungle Book will get the retrospective vote, because it is the best-known today and ha fashionable mythic overtone in the lost paradise of Mowgli's jungle; it position on the list may also rescue it from schmaltzy Disney association and confirm it a a serious novel about a young man's self-discovery. My vote go to Trilby. Soft-focus, ideologically shaky - in it anti-Semitic portrait of Svengali - and sometimes sloppy, it is a story of demonic possession and haunt the imagination like a fairy tale long after better-written work have faded from memory. Like Rebecca, the popular novel by du Maurier's granddaughter, it is a natural equivalent of what the current Booker Prize seek to create: a combination of the classic and the bestseller. The shortlist of six for the Pounds 20,000 Booker Prize for fiction, announced yesterday, immediately prompted the question 'Who?' from many in the publishing industry. According to one insider, some on the list 'are B-team writer at best'. The six include Alan Hollinghurst's The Folding Star (published by Chatto and Windus), a melancholy study of homosexual obsession which wa tipped a a likely candidate from the initial 'long list' of 15, The Reef (Granta) by young Sri Lankan writer Romesh Gunesekera and How Late It Was, How Late (Secker and Warburg) by gritty Glasgow realist James Kelman, which wa almost universally well-reviewed. As for the other three - Knowledge of Angels (Green Bay) a philosophical fable by children's author Jill Paton Walsh, Paradise (Hamish Hamilton) by Zanzibar-born writer Abdulrazak Gurnah and Beside the Ocean of Time (John Murray) by 72-year-old Orcadian poet George Mackay Brown - 'frankly, they don't make the grade'. The shortlist for the Booker, the UK's most hyped literary prize and one of the most lucrative, is all the more surprising in a bumper year for new fiction fulfilling the criterion - English language and non-American - for consideration for the award. Margaret Atwood's The Robber Bride seems an astonishing omission, a do new novel by Peter Ackroyd, Peter Carey, Candia McWilliam, William Trevor and Jim Crace. But if the shortlist of the final six candidate for the prize may be disappointing, the traditional controversy surrounding the award is a rife a ever. One unsurprising omission from the final selection wa When The World Was Steady, a first novel by Claire Messud, which wa on the 'long list' before it wa pointed out that the author wa the wife of James Wood, chief literary reviewer of The Guardian newspaper and a Booker judge. Professor John Bayley, chairman of the Booker panel and husband of former Booker Prize winner Dame Iris Murdoch, expressed surprise at Mr Wood's failure to reveal his relationship with Ms Messud. But it is the final list, rather than the controversy, that discredit the award according to some critic. 'This list,' said one man of letter, 'must have dealt a final death blow to the Booker.' The winner, selected from an original 130, will be announced on October 11. The Booker Prize is Britain's literary event of the year, guaranteed to boost sale of the chosen novel after the award announcement Oct. 16, and dinner in London's ancient Guildhall. The prize to the author is a check for 20,000 pound (nearly $38000), sponsored by Booker, an international food and agriculture business. British publisher are very secretive about their sale but we know that when Thomas Keneally won it in 1982 for `Schindler's Ark,' his publisher, who had printed 15,000 copy, sold 75,000 over the next 23 week, said Christine Shaw of Book Trust. The trust is a charity promoting reading and book and administers the prize. The prize ha become internationally known, and the worldwide demand for the winning book, in English and translation, is spectacular, said Shaw. The prize wa first awarded in 1969 after talk between Booker and the Publishers' Association on the need for a significant literary award to encourage and reward good writing. British publisher can submit three new novel by British and Commonwealth writer. There were 110 submission last year. A management committee of author, bookseller, librarian and the sponsor chooses a jury of five: a writer or two, an academic, a politician interested in literature and a literary editor or critic. Each juror read every book submitted, list about six favorite and meet the other juror to select and announce six finalist. As public debate rage over who's in, who's out and who might win, with bookmaker across the country calling the odds, the juror meet again and finally select the winner on the afternoon of announcement day. This year's finalists: Beryl Bainbridge An Awfully Big Adventure, AS. Byatt Possession, Penelope Fitzgerald The Gate of Angels, John McGahern Amongst Women, Brian Moore Lies of Silence and Mordecai Richler Solomon Gursky Was Here. Six novel have been nominated for the Booker Prize, Britain's most prestigious fiction award, and bookmaker say the favorite is The Remains of the Day by Japanese author Kazuo Ishiguro. The award, to be announced Oct. 26, carry a $31,600 prize funded by the Booker McConnell food company. Oddsmaker William Hill gave 7-to-4 odds on Ishiguro's novel about a butler's travel through Britain's West Country and said it wa a firm favorite to win. Ishiguro, previously nominated for the award, wa beaten a the Booker favorite in 1986, which make his chance that much stronger this time in our view, said William Hill spokesman Graham Sharpe. The other book nominated are: Cat's Eye, a story of painter Elaine Risley and her return to her childhood home in Toronto by Canadian author Margaret Atwood, also a previous nominee. The Book of Evidence, a prison story of kidnap and murder convict Freddie Montgomery by John Banville, literary editor of The Irish Times newspaper. Jigsaw, by Sybille Bedford, an autobiographical novel about an adolescent's travel through Germany, Italy and France. A Disaffection, Scottish novelist James Kelman's story about a school teacher, Patrick Doyle, whose professional frustration are fueled by a drinking problem and unrequited love for a colleague. Restoration, British author Rose Tremain's story of Robert Merivel, a favorite of King Charles II who married the monarch's youngest mistress. We expect more interest in this year's Booker Prize than ever before, partly thanks to last year's controversy over Salman Rushdie's `Satanic Verses,' Sharpe said. Rushdie wa nominated for the prize last year but it wa won by Australian author Peter Carey for his love story Oscar and Lucinda. Rushdie, a British citizen, ha been in hiding since Feb. 14 when the late Iranian leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini ordered he be killed for allegedly blaspheming Islam in Satanic Verses. This year's six nominee were chosen Thursday from 102 book considered by a panel headed by David Lodge, a British literary critic and novelist who wa nominated for the prize last year for his book, Nice Work. On the day of the Big Event, Ladbroke, the large British betting agency, posted the final odds. Brian Moore wa the favorite at 7-4, followed by Peter Ackroyd (5-2), Iris Murdoch (3-1) and Chinua Achebe (9-2). The two dark horse, Nina Bawden and Penelope Lively, were each tipped at 7-1.You may have noticed a distinctly literary tilt to that lineup, an affinity with the bookshelf, not the bookie. All of those people published new work of fiction here in Britain during the past 12 month. And for the last few week, literary punter throughout the British Isles have been placing bet on which of those writer would win the Booker Prize, the best-known, best-liked and, almost incidentally, most prestigious fiction award in the land.In recent week the Booker contender have received almost a much press coverage a the Charles and Di rift. And nearly every article, from book review to author interview, ha featured the latest odds. The betting is done largely by literary insider, say Graham Sharpe, who set the Booker odds at William Hill, Britain's other big betting agency. "They read the book, hear the gossip and want to pull off a little coup for themselves," he says.Last year's winner, "The Old Devils" by Kingsley Amis, wa a 5-2 favorite, but this year, anyone who chose the victor made some dough."When she accepted her prize for "Moon Tiger," Penelope Lively looked surprised and pleased. "I'm not a betting woman, and I have slight reservation about book becoming a spectator sport," she said in soft Oxbridge tone. "But those who are in the know tell me that 7-1 wa an irresistible flutter." Her 65-year-old mother wa among those who made a killing.America ha the Pulitzer Prize for fiction and the National Book Awards, but in term of excitement, hoopla and man-on-the-street interest, there's nothing akin to the 15,000-pound ($26,000) Booker Prize. With the possible exception of France's respected Prix Goncourt, there's nothing quite like it anywhere else.Britons wryly compare the Booker to the Academy Awards, and though there's just one prize and no envelope, similarity exist. There's a team of judge and a pool of candidate. This year each British publisher could submit three new title, for a grand total of 93. As one judge noted wearily, "By August, I wa in more than a slight panic, sometimes reading all day and evening; reading while standing at the bus stop, reading while cooking, reading, almost, while talking on the telephone."Next come the "short-list," the judges' top six, which wa announced with great fanfare in late September. This year the work included Brian Moore's political thriller "The Color of Blood" (EP. Dutton, 182 page, $16.95); Peter Ackroyd's "Chatterton" (Grove Press, 240 page, $17.95); Nina Bawden's "Circles of Deceit" (St. Martin's Press, 208 page, $14.95); Iris Murdoch's 23rd novel "The Book and the Brotherhood" (Viking, 608 page, $19.95); Nigerian writer Chinua Achebe's "Anthills of the Savannah" (Doubleday, 240 page, $16.95); and "Moon Tiger" (Grove Press, 216 page, $15.95).The award presentation came on the last Thursday in October, and like any major award presentation, it came complete with limousine, banquet (salmon mousse, champagne sorbet and English roast beef) and television camera. The suspense wa genuine; the judge chose the winner just three hour before the announcement.To be sure, the rating for the prime-time broadcast didn't upstage those of "Eastenders," Britain's popular soap opera. Yet interest wa sufficient for Andre Deutsch, "Moon Tiger's" British publisher, to order up an additional 20,000 copy almost the minute Mrs. Lively -- and the nation -- heard the news.By British standard, sale figure for recent Booker winner are stunning, from "The Old Devils" (80,000 hard-cover copy) to Anita Brookner's "Hotel du Lac" (40,000 copies). Even Keri Hulme's "The Bone People," a look at Maori culture that most reader found impenetrable, reached a respectable 21,000 in 1985.Short-listed author are just a few pace behind, sharing the best-seller list with Dick Francis and Scott Turow. Heinemann initially printed 3,000 copy of "Anthills of the Savannah," the usual run for contemporary literary fiction. So far, 10,000 copy have sold. "Being short-listed probably changed the destiny of that book," declares a member of the Heinemann sale staff. Indeed, there's currently talk of initiating a similar prize with a similar purse for the year's best biography.Another notable spinoff is the Booker harpy, reader intent on digesting all six title, then vigorously disputing the choice, which never please everyone. This year the Sunday Times offered reader a complete autographed collection of the six book for the equivalent of $112, perfect fodder for the literary cocktail party cot.It wasn't always this way, of course. Headlines were modest back in 1969 when PH. Newby won the first ever Booker Prize for "Something to Answer For." (The wonderfully appropriate name come from Booker-McConnell PLC, the international food and agriculture conglomerate that put up the prize money each year.)The idea wa to devise a British equivalent to the Prix Goncourt, and like that august French award, the Booker attracted attention the minute it kicked up controversy. The early fuss wa kept within the literary world, with critic sniping over choice and the prize's varied ground rule. The real world took notice in 1974, when Elizabeth Jane Howard, one of the three judge, wrote a letter to the Times claiming that in her opinion Kingsley Amis's "Ending Up," one of the short-listed book, wa his best ever. As it happens, she wa married to Mr. Amis at the time. He didn't win.But many credit the Booker's current appeal to the 1982 competition and Thomas Keneally's "Schindler's Ark," or "Schindler's List" a it is known in the US. Written a a novel, the book told the true story of a remarkable German who saved the life of hundred of Jews in concentration camp. But even after it won the Booker, people argued that it wasn't a novel. "The more people questioned it, the more it sold," say Ion Trewin, editorial director at Hodder & Stoughton. "That wa the first year the prize caught the medium and public imagination. Suddenly the Booker gained inch on front pages."Oh yes, "Moon Tigers" is a dying woman's recollection of her life a a World War II war correspondent and her affair with a young tank officer.--- Ms. Trucco is a free-lance writer based in London. Australian novelist Peter Carey wa awarded the coveted Booker Prize for fiction Tuesday night for his love story, Oscar and Lucinda. A panel of five judge unanimously announced the award of the $26,250 prize after an 80-minute deliberation during a banquet at London's ancient Guildhall. The judge made their selection from 102 book published in Britain in the past 12 month and which they read in their home. Carey, who life in Sydney with his wife and son, said in a brief speech that like the other five finalist he had been asked to attend with a short speech in his pocket in case he won. If I'd known I wa going to win I think I would have taken a bit more trouble with my handwriting, he said a he stared down at his note. He wa unsuccessful in the prize competition in 1985 when his novel, Illywhacker, wa among the final six. Carey called the award a great honor and he thanked the prize sponsor for provoking so much passionate discussion about literature perhaps there will be more tomorrow. Everyone who love good book benefit from this, surely, he added. The winning novel is a fitting choice for Australia's bicentennial year. It tell of a romance between an English gambler and an Australian heiress who meet on a steamship's maiden voyage to Australia in the mid-19th century. The story weave in Australian history from it founding in 1788 by British immigrant. Panel chairman Michael Foot, a writer and former leader of the opposition Labor Party, said the judge agreed that entry this year had been exceptionally strong and that choosing the last six novel wa extremely difficult. We hope there will be no criticism but if there are, then people should start reading the book for themselves, Foot said. Carey wa the only non-Briton in the final six. The son of an auto dealer, he wa born in Bacchus Marsh, Victoria, and attended Geelong Church of England Grammar School, Melbourne, where the Prince of Wales wa also a pupil a an 18-year-old in 1966. Carey wa an advertising copywriter before turning to writing book in 1965. The first Booker Prize wa awarded in 1969. It is administered by Book Trust, an educational charity promoting book, and is sponsored by Booker, an international food and farming business. Critic and novelist AS. Byatt on Tuesday won the Booker Prize, Britain's most prestigious literary award, for her tale of two young scholar investigating the life of a pair of imaginary Victorian poet. The five judge deliberated two hour before awarding the $39,000 prize to Antonia Byatt for Possession, one of six finalist in the 21-year-old competition. Last year's Booker winner wa Kazuo Ishiguro for his novel, The Remains of the Day. Television executive Sir Denis Forman, chairman of the judge's panel, announced the prize at a banquet in London's Elizabethan Guildhall, seat of the city's Lord Mayor. There wa very strong individual support for several book on the short list and finally `Possession' by AS. Byatt wa the winner by a majority vote, said the judge. The panel wa unanimous, however, in agreeing that the standard of the other five novel wa exceptionally high and this made their decision unusually interesting and unusually difficult. Ms. Byatt, who earlier this month won the $43,000 Irish Times-Aer Lingus prize for international fiction for the same work, ha published five novel since 1964. In Possession, she tell how two graduate student piece together the relationship and life of two imaginary Victorian poet from fragment of their letter and by retracing the poets' journey across England and to France. The influence of the past on the living is a theme throughout the book. Ms. Byatt, born in 1936, is the daughter of a lawyer and sister of novelist Margaret Drabble. Her first novel, Shadow of a Sun, concerned the effort of a woman to escape the shadow of her novelist father. A 1978 work, The Virgin in the Garden, make allegorical allusion to Shakespeare and other English literary genius in a tale of a play performed at a country house. Ms. Byatt taught English and American literature at University College in London until 1983, when she quit to write fulltime. Other finalist this year were 1979 Booker Prize winner Penelope Fitzgerald with The Gate of Angels, Irish novelist John McGahern's Amongst Women, Canadian-born Mordecai Richler's Solomon Gursky Was Here, Brian Moore's Lies of Silence, and Beryl Bainbridge's An Awfully Big Adventure. They were chosen from a list of 113 book published in the United Kingdom in 1989. The Booker Prize is sponsored by Booker, an international food and agriculture business, and administered by The Book Trust. It is Britain's top literary award. THE annual Booker ballyhoo got going again yesterday when the judge for this year's Pounds 20,000 prize for British (and Commonwealth) fiction announced the shortlist. The Prize (courtesy of Booker plc, the food and agri-business group) is no longer the richest literary award but it guarantee great prestige, and sale, for the winner, and, say it admirer, helpfully brings The Novel to public attention. Its critic say that the autumn brouhaha distorts the annual fiction industry and the intense medium hype of the shortlisted author doe a disservice to the horde of other gifted but unlisted writer. This year's shortlist contains no surprise. London's litterati have for week been betting on Michael Ondaatje's The English Patient - those of them who have seen a proof copy because it is not officially published until next week. Last night the bookmaker William Hill made it the 5-2 favourite. The shortlist is: Serenity House by Christopher Hope (MacMillan Pounds 1499). Black comedy by a master South Africa-born specialist in the trade. Set in a Highgate 'eventide refuge' where euthanasia is an unspoken word and it senior citizen, Max Montfalcon, turn out to be a geriatric Nazi scientist. The FT review next Saturday will describe it a 'surreal farce . scabrously enjoyable ..' The Butcher's Boy by Patrick McCabe (Picador Pounds 1499). An Irish murderer, a soft-in-the-head orphan jailed for life, recall his life in grisly detail. The FT reviewer said that 'the misery and deprivation of working class life have never been so brutally evoked ..' Black Dogs by Ian McEwan (Secker & Warburg Pounds 1499). McEwan's fiction is uniquely disturbing - some would say deliberately offensive. He is the novelist of misanthropy. This is the tale of a failed marriage, episodically told, and the black dog of evil are both metaphorical and literal. The English Patient by Michael Ondaatje (Bloomsbury Pounds 1499). The Sri Lankan poet and novelist Ondaatje, who life in Canada, ha followed 'in the skin of a lion' with an extraordinary book about four character in a Tuscan villa in the closing month of the last war. The central metaphor is bomb - disposal of, and then Hiroshima. The 'English patient' is a central mystery around which the others' story orbit: he fell out of the sky in flames; who is he? The FT review on Saturday will hail it a a masterpiece. Daughters of the House by Michele Roberts (Virago Pounds 1499). The surprise contender because it is not yet published. Roberts come from an Anglo-French Catholic background and this informs her new novel with a strong rural-Normandy atmosphere. Two cousin, one pious, one worldly. Shades of Saint Therese of Lisieux. Lots of action in the kitchen; something is hidden in the cellar. Sacred Hunger by Barry Unsworth (Hamish Hamilton Pounds 1599).
