column5: A survey of Britain's exciting Booker Prize for fiction novels.
column6: Britain's Booker Prize for fiction is awarded yearly from a long list of novels narrowed down to a final six. A panel of judges selects the winner. Odds are given and literary insiders bet on which book will win. The winner receives a cash award and great prestige and sales.
column7: Britain's Booker Prize for fiction novels is similar to America's Pulitzer Prize and National Book awards but more excitement is associated with it. British publishers each submit three new titles. The total of around 100 books is narrowed down to a final six by a panel of learned judges after they have read all the novels. Odds are given with reviews, and literary insiders bet on which book will win the prize. The winner is announced at a yearly banquet.The Prize is administered by Book Trust, an educational charity, and sponsored by Booker, an international food and farming business.
column8: America has the Pulitzer Prize for fiction and the National Book Awards but in terms of hoopla and excitement, there's nothing akin to Britain's Booker Prize. British publishers each submit three new titles for a total of approximately 100. There's a jury of judges, including writers, academics, politicians, editors and critics. Each juror reads every book and odds are given with reviews. The jurors then meet and select six finalists. Literary insiders bet on which book will win the Booker Prize. The winner is announced at a banquet in London's Elizabethan Guildhall, the seat the city's Lord Mayor, on the last Thursday in October. The authors can win up to $38,000. The event also guarantees great prestige and sales for the winner and brings the novel to public attention.Critics say the brouhaha distorts the annual fiction industry and the intense media hype does a disservice to other gifted but unlisted authors. On one recent occasion following heated deliberation between the judges, the chairman went public with a rousing condemnation of contemporary fiction.The Prize, first awarded in 1969, is administered by Book Trust, an educational charity promoting books. It is sponsored by Booker, an international food and farming business.
column9: Booker Britain's Most Prestigious Literary Award. Competition Hot. Wagering Heavy.
column10: The Booker Prize was established in 1969 to honor the best fictionwork by a British or Commonwealth author. The Booker Company is thesponsor. It is now Britain's most prestigious literary award. Winnersreceive a substantial monetary award. Booker creates interest,motivates bettors, and boost book sales.
column11: The Booker Prize was established in 1969 to honor the best work of fiction by a British or Commonwealth author. It is sponsored by Booker, an international food and farming business. The Booker carries a substantial monetary award, and is now Britain's most prestigious fiction prize. Judges name six finalists, and later select the winner from those six. The competition creates great interest and motivates bettors. It also boosts book sales.Three of the recent winners now live in Britain or a Commonwealth country, but were born elsewhere. Only books written in English can be entered into Booker competition.
column12: The Booker Prize was first awarded in 1969. It honors the best work offiction by a British or Commonwealth author published in Britainduring the preceding 12 months.  The Booker is now the best known andmost prestigious fiction award in Britain. It carries a substantialmonetary prize, and is administered by Book Trust, an educationalcharity. Booker, an international food and farming business, sponsorsthe Prize.British publishers can submit up to three titles forconsideration. Each year a management team selects a new panel ofjudges. They announce a list of six finalists. Bookmakers establishbetting odds, and heavy betting ensues, most of it by literarypundits. Interest builds in the period leading up to the announcementof the winner, usually in October.  The hype that accompanies theselection boosts book sales.Penelope Lively's "Moon Tigers" won in 1987. Peter Carey's "Oscar andLucinda" won in 1988. Kazuo Ishiguro's "The Remains of the Day" won in1989. Antonia Byatt's "Possession" won in 1990. Michael Ondaatje's"The English Patient" won in 1992, and John Kelman's "How Late It Is,How Late" won in 1994. In 1994 the short-list was severely criticized,and a hypothetical 1894 Booker was contested.

column3: Tens of thousand of people chanting Freedom! Freedom! trekked to a Moslem saint's shrine Saturday to campaign for the secession of Kashmir from India, witness and pro-separatist activist said. At least three people died in two separate incident on Saturday in Kashmir, the center of the four-decade-old separatist campaign, witness said. The death brought to 109 the number of people killed since Jan. 20 in the latest round of the secessionist violence and the government crackdown. Meanwhile, the president of the Pakistan state of Kashmir said in an interview Saturday that Kashmiris there had begun smuggling arm across the border to Moslem insurgent fighting for independence from India. President Abdul Qayyum, speaking to a reporter who traveled to Pakistan's Kashmir, said the people of his state also had been sheltering insurgent since India launched the military crackdown in it state of Jammu-Kashmir last month. In India's Kashmir, the 600-year-old shrine of Shiekh Nuruddin Wali at Charift Sharief, 20 mile northwest of Srinagar, became a sea of humanity a Moslem men, woman and child poured in from Srinagar and nearby town. Vehicles stopped 10 mile from the shrine a people thronged the road, said witness, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Supporters of the militant said they went to the shrine to seek the saint's blessing to liberate Kashmir from India. In Srinagar, the summer capital of Jammu-Kashmir state, resident were told by Moslem militant to put their clock back by 30 minute to correspond with the Pakistan standard time. The militant, led by the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, are demanding either independence for Jammu-Kashmir, the only Indian state dominated by Moslems. Groups of young Moslem men sat at street corner, stopping passer-by and telling them to adjust their watch. At least six fight broke out when people refused to comply, said witness who spoke on condition of anonymity. On Friday, at least 200,000 people marched to the office of the United Nations Military Observers Group in Srinagar, demanding a plebiscite in Kashmir, police said. Witnesses claimed that more than 600,000 people took part. The UN. group is posted to maintain a cease-fire line drawn between Indian- and Pakistani-held Kashmir after a 1948-49 war over the region. Residents, speaking on condition of anonymity, said security force fatally shot two men shouting anti-Indian slogan at Khrew, 15 mile southeast of Srinagar. In Srinagar, suspected Moslem militant shot and killed Ashok Kumar, a Hindu government employee, witness said, also speaking on condition of anonymity. Kumar wa suspected to be a police informer. India routinely accuses Pakistan of arming, training and supporting the militant. The government in Islamabad denies the charge but say the Kashmiri people have a right to self-determination. An AP reporter who traveled to Pakistan's Kashmir last week said state-run bank in the region have begun collection to help the uprising. Signs in dozen of bank called for donation for a holy war against India. Naveed Hussain, a government spokesman in Pakistan's Kashmir, said in an interview that $5,000 had been raised in a week and that the money would be used to train Kashmiri militia group in territory held by Pakistan. Kashmir wa divided between India and Pakistan after the two country were partitioned following the end of British colonial rule in 1947. Moslems blew up a truck carrying security force Wednesday, killing three soldier in the few hour the government relaxed a curfew designed to stop the Kashmiri separatist uprising, official said. In separate incident, militant shot and killed a Moslem they said wa a police informer and a Moslem died after he wa caught in an exchange of fire between militant and security force, official said. Also Wednesday, Moslem sniper fired on security force in three part of Srinagar during a five-hour relaxation of curfew, said Gov. Jagmohan of Jammu-Kashmir state. There were no casualty, he said. The curfew wa relaxed from 5 am. to 10 am. to allow people in the city of 1 million to shop for food and other essential. An around-the-clock curfew wa imposed Friday after security force the day before shot and killed 49 Moslem demonstrator marching into Srinagar to take part in a pro-independence rally. At least 1 million Moslems demonstrated to demand independence for the predominantly Moslem state; India is predominantly Hindu. Srinagar, the summer capital of Jammu-Kashmir, is the center of the separatist movement. At least 171 people have been killed in Kashmir since a government crackdown on the separatist movement began on Jan. 20. Leading national party decided Wednesday to send a high-powered delegation to Srinagar, according to the Press Trust of India news agency. It did not name the member, but it said they would go Thursday. The decision wa taken at the end of a daylong multiparty meeting on Kashmir called by Prime Minister VP. Singh. A joint statement after the meeting said despite their ideological and political difference, (the party) were one in defending the unity and integrity of the country, the news agency reported. Jagmohan said the truck wa driving around Srinagar distributing food to troop on street corner when it wa blown up by Moslem militant. He gave no further detail of the attack. The attack came amid government claim that security force arrested at least 12 leader of the Moslem group Hezbul Mujahedeen. Jagmohan said the militant, from Srinagar and the border town of Baramulla and Kupwara, have been arrested since Sunday. Hezbul Mujahedeen is one of 30 militant group fighting for secession. It is believed the second most powerful independence group after the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front. We are going to hit hard at anti-national element, there is no way they can get away with what they are doing, Jagmohan said. It may take a month, six month, maybe a year, but ultimately these anti-national elments are going to be neutralized. Jagmohan, a Hindu, wa appointed the state governor of Jammu-Kashmir on Jan. 18 in an attempt by the government to control the unrest. Kashmir ha been a problem for more than four decade following the 1947 partition of British colonial India into predominantly Moslem Pakistan and the mostly Hindu India. Jammu-Kashmir, then a princely state, chose to merge with India. Pakistan protested, claiming the territory because of it predominantly Moslem population. The two country have twice gone to war over the territory. The Kashmir portion of Jammu-Kashmir is mostly Moslem, while the southern Jammu segment is predominantly Hindu. Overall, about 65 percent of the state's 6 million people are Moslem. Nationwide, Moslems make up 12 percent of India's 880 million people and Hindus account for 82 percent. Exotic Kashmir, a tourist paradise of houseboat hotel and Mogul garden from whose name the English made cashmere, ha become a war zone of separatism and religious enmity. Military jeep carry senior government official and civil servant around Srinagar in these dangerous day, a soldier and paramilitary trooper try to stop a campaign of violence by Moslem separatist in the Kashmir Valley. Intelligence officer MK. Kaul command one of the jeep. At the beginning of a trip through the city of 1 million people, he turned to the four soldier in the jeep's rear seat and ordered: Check your weapon. Be ready to fire. Kaul settled into the front seat, a 9mm pistol in his right hand. These are bad day, he murmured. These die-hard terrorist can attack from anywhere. To his men, he said: Shoot them if you see them. On Monday, an around-the-clock curfew wa lifted from 5 am. until noon and store opened to crowd of customer. Soldiers in sandbagged bunker, armed with light machine gun, guarded main intersection. A spokesman for the Jammu-Kashmir state government said the situation wa peaceful and absolutely normal in Srinagar, the state's largest city. At least 72 people have been killed since the crackdown began Jan. 20 in an effort to curb attack on government official and building. Most of the dead have been Moslem militant shot by Indian troop. We are neither fighting a war nor trying to suppress any popular movement, said Jagmohan, governor of Jammu-Kashmir, the only state in predominantly Hindu India with a Moslem majority. We are fighting a handful of terrorist who are determined to create a law and order problem, said Jagmohan, a Hindu with a reputation for toughness. Other official in Kashmir say privately the situation is critical, perhaps the most serious threat India ha faced in 42 year of independence from Britain. It look like everyone here ha turned into a fundamentalist with firm belief that the day is not far off when they will become independent, a state police officer said. Kashmir wa a separate kingdom, ruled by a Hindu maharajah, when Britain relinquished colonial rule on Aug. 15, 1947, and the subcontinent wa partitioned on religious line into India and Pakistan. The Hindu king opted to join India, not Pakistan, and the dispute over Kashmir ha exacerbated relation since. Pakistan took the western part of Kashmir and India the eastern. Each accused the other of forcible occupation. They have fought war over Kashmir and the border question remains unresolved. UN. observer are stationed on the truce line and the two side occasionally trade gunfire. Officials will not say how many reinforcement have been sent to the Kashmir Valley since Jan. 20, but report from various source indicate 30,000-and 40,000 soldier and paramilitary troop have been deployed. It is the valley's heavily Moslem population that tilt the sectarian scale in Jammu-Kashmir state. Of the state's nearly 6 million people, 64 percent are Moslems and 32 percent Hindus. Most Hindus live in the southern Jammu area. Srinagar ha 150 mosque. This is the best breeding ground for Moslem fundamentalism, said a federal official who help coordinate the new security measure. Nearly every mosque ha a loudspeaker to summon the faithful to prayer and, more recently, to exhort listener to defend their faith and Kashmir. The resident are constantly bombarded with Islamic sermon and are reminded that fighting a `jihad' (Islamic holy war) is the most sacred duty of every Moslem, the federal official said, on condition of anonymity. Electricity wa cut off in the city Friday, which wa both the Moslem sabbath and India's national Republic Day on India's Republic Day, but many mosque loudspeaker continued operating because militant connected them to car battery. Intelligence report suggest the government ha an advantage because the separatist are not united. The most powerful group is the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, but there are several others, including the Allah Tigers, Hezb-e-Mujahed Hezb-e-Islami. India claim the fundamentalist get money and weapon from Pakistan. The Pakistanis deny it. Jagmohan, the governor, insists the main issue in Kashmir is economic development, not separatism. The people do not want violence or the so-called independent Kashmir, he said. The need of the hour is development. Let more tourist come. Let new school be built. Let new hospital come up. As he spoke, military officer waited in the next room to discus a new strategy to crush rebellion in what the tourist brochure call Paradise. Right now, Paradise look lost, at least temporarily. The army on Tuesday dispatched tank and troop reinforcement to the frontier with Pakistan, where soldier from the two nation have been fighting recently, official and witness said. Prime Minister VP. Singh told Parliament that Indian armed force were fully prepared to effectively deal with any eventuality. Indian and Pakistani troop clashed in a remote border area in the disputed Kashmir region Monday. Singh, who is also defense minister, said exchange of fire also occurred Tuesday. In Pakistan, a Defense Ministry spokesman, who cannot be identified under briefing rule, said Tuesday that Indian and Pakistani soldier exchanged artillery fire in the Kel sector along the cease-fire line dividing Kashmir into Pakistani and Indian region. He said there were no casualty among Pakistani soldier. The Pakistani official also said that on Monday and Tuesday, Indian soldier fired on Pakistani civilian traveling on a mountain road, injuring four people. He also said Indian soldier fired on an ambulance and a bus. There wa no report from India on the alleged firing. Despite the tension, official from both side said the incident did not appear to be serious. There is no cause for any undue concern since we trust that these localized incident will be contained and the situation defused, United News of India quoted Singh a saying in the Parliament. Singh said director of military operation from both country were in touch. He did not elaborate. The Pakistani official said: This is not a serious situation. It's just in one sector. It could be just a local incident. We don't know what it will lead to. We'll just have to wait and see. India and Pakistan have gone to war twice over Kashmir, in 1965 and 1971. Both side claim Kashmir, which ha been divided into Indian and Pakistani sector. Tensions over Kashmir flared again this summer. India accuses Pakistan of supporting a Moslem secessionist movement in the Indian sector by providing arm and training to Moslem militant. Pakistan, an Islamic state, denies the charge but say it will back any movement for self-determination by Kashmir's people. Jammu-Kashmir state is the only one of India's state with a Moslem majority. At least 1,034 people have been killed in the Kashmir valley since New Delhi cracked down on the secessionist movement on Jan. 20. Military official in Jammu, the summer capital of India-held Kashmir, said Tuesday that tank and troop reinforcement were dispatched to the border area. At least 20 tank and 30 truck with soldier left their quarter at Kaluchak and Baridrahamna for the frontier, said witness, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Indian military official said the additional troop were sent to Rajauri and Poonch sector, which were the scene of fierce battle in the war of 1965 and 1971. Pakistani troop fired on Indian security force who stopped a mob of Pakistani protester from storming across the border into disputed Kashmir, official said today. At least three demonstrator were killed Sunday night, a Defense Ministry spokesman said in Islamabad. Pakistan's state-run TV said the Indian guard killed a many a six. The trouble started after Indian border guard opened fire on hundred of Pakistanis who tried to cross a cease-fire line separating Pakistan-controlled Kashmir from the Indian-held region. A spokesman for the Indian Defense Ministry said Pakistani troop then fired about 200 round from light and medium weapon at Indian border post in the Uri sector. Indian force returned fire and the exchange continued for about half an hour, the spokesman said. No one wa hurt. A Pakistani official in Islamabad denied the accusation. Pakistani military authority and the Foreign Secretary are in touch with Indian authority to remove the misunderstanding, said Additional Foreign Secretary Khalid Mahmood in Islamabad. Pakistan's top diplomat in New Delhi, Bashir Babar, wa summoned to India's Foreign Ministry on Sunday and today and apprised of India's concern over the event, an Indian government spokesman said. A fluid 840-mile cease-fire line separate the Indian and Pakistani Kashmirs. Pakistan and Indian twice have gone to war over Kashmir, in 1948 and again in 1965. On Feb. 5, at least one person wa killed and 12 wounded when Pakistani mob tried to cross the cease-fire line near Jammu, 95 mile to the south. The two demonstration at the cease-fire line were to express support for Moslem militant who are fighting for independence for the Moslem-dominated state from the predominantly Hindu India. On Sunday, the Pakistani mob retreated when soldier of India's paramilitary border security force opened fire, said the Indian spokesman who refused to be identified. The mob returned a second time by which time it had become slightly dark, he said. That is when the Pakistani troop opened fire. A Pakistani spokesman, who also refused to be identified, said Pakistani army patrol repulsed a mob of some 1,200 demonstrator. Small group broke away from the crowd and slipped into the Indian-held territory, he said. An official of the Indian border security force, which normally patrol the border, said the Indian army today took control of the cease-fire line. Some men in the intruding crowd were armed with gun which they fired occasionally, he said. It wa becoming very difficult, our troop had to open fire, he said. Farouk Haider, vice-president of the militant Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front that is leading the uprising, said in Islamabad after the Indian firing that the situation is very confusing. Thirty-one people were wounded in the shooting, Haider said. Five were in critical condition in a hospital in Muzzafarabad, the capital of Pakistan-controlled Kashmir, he said, adding he knew of only one death. The 40-year-old conflict over Kashmir flared Jan. 20 after a government crackdown and the arrest of 250 suspected militant. Most of them were subsequently released, but the arrest sparked widespread violence. At least 85 people have been killed since the crackdown began. Most of the victim have been curfew-breaking protester shot by security force in Srinagar. Srinagar, the summer capital of Jammu-Kashmir, ha been the center of the secessionist movement that ha turned violent in recent year. The Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front had earlier campaigned for union with Islamic Pakistan but ha in recent year demanded independence and the status of a neutral country. About 64 percent of Jammu-Kashmir's 6 million people are Moslems, making it the only Moslem majority state in predominantly Hindu India's 25 state. Nationwide, Moslems make up 12 percent of India's 880 million population. Hindus comprise 82 percent. Troops battled mob of Moslem separatist in the Kashmir city of Srinagar over the weekend, and at least 21 people were killed and 100 wounded before the fighting subsided Sunday night, police said. Fifteen demonstrator were shot and killed Sunday, while six were fatally wounded late Saturday night, according to Mohammad Nomani, inspector general of Srinagar police. Militants defied a curfew and continued trading intermittent shot with government force on Sunday, official said. Witnesses, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the death toll wa at least 30, but that figure could not be confirmed. Nomani, speaking by telephone from Srinagar, the summer capital of Jammu-Kashmir state, said the fighting tapered off late Sunday afternoon a heavy rain lashed the city. But gunfire echoed through the deserted street until evening, one resident said, requesting anonymity. They (the troop) are shooting at anything moving, he said. It is a disastrous situation out there, said Ramesh Kaul, a hotel receptionist in Srinagar. At least 47 people have been killed in Jammu-Kashmir state since the beginning of the year in violence triggered by Moslem militant demanding independence or union with Islamic Pakistan. The separatist, led by the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, have often attacked government office and police official. The situation is tense and dangerous, the state's chief secretary, Moosa Raza, said in Jammu, the state's winter capital 95 mile south of Srinagar. Nomani said the police dispatched 25 car with loudspeaker into the city, to appeal to people to obey the curfew. The car were escorted by heavily armed troop from the paramilitary Central Reserve Police Force, he said. A 24-hour curfew wa imposed Saturday in a bid to quell escalating violence and mass anti-India demonstration in Srinagar and nearby town. But late Saturday, crowd defied curfew and surged into downtown Srinagar chanting Indian dog go back! and Long live Pakistan! local reporter said. They said the paramilitary troop opened fire, killing two people instantly and injuring 14. Four of them died later. As news of the shooting spread, thousand of Moslem men poured out of their home, the reporter said. They said protester recited verse from the Koran, the Moslem holy book. Some took up a chant urging mujahedeen, or Islamic holy warrior, to prepare for the final sacrifice in a showdown with India's Hindu-dominated government. Jammu-Kashmir's former state chief minister, Farooq Abdullah, issued a statement accusing authority of letting loose a reign of terror and repression. Abdullah's Moslem-dominated National Conference Party is closely aligned with the Congress Party of Rajiv Gandhi, the arch political foe of Prime Minister VP. Singh. Abdullah's government resigned Friday to protest the appointment of Singh's nominee a the state's new governor and imposition of governor's rule which amount to tighter federal control over the state. The curfew order wa one of the first act of the new governor, Jagmohan, a tough administrator who had cracked down on Kashmiri militant during an earlier stint a the state's governor. Jagmohan, a Hindu who us one name, took office Friday. Parts of Kashmir region are claimed by both India and Pakistan. The dispute started when the state wa partitioned between the two country when they gained independence from Britain in 1947. Srinagar's 800,000 people are moslty Moslem, a is a majority of population in the Kashmir region. The Jammu region is predominantly Hindu. India ha often accused Pakistan of aiding the Kashmiri militant, a charge Pakistan ha denied. Jammu-Kashmir is the only state with a Moslem majority in predominantly Hindu India. Moslems make up 64 percent of the state population of 5 million. Nationwide, Moslems comprise 12 percent of India's 880 million people, while Hindus comprise 82 percent. Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto on Thursday accused India of waging genocide in secession-minded Kashmir and of trying to start a war with Pakistan to deflect attention. Her remark raised tension further between India and Pakistan, which have been feuding over Indian-controlled Kashmir. The two country, which have fought war over the area in 1949 and 1965, have in recent week again built up their military force near the common border. India is indulging in genocide, Ms. Bhutto said at a news conference Thursday after returning from a weeklong tour of eight Moslem country in the Middle East and North Africa. Islamic scholar are being killed and innocent people are being slaughtered. This is deplorable, said the prime minister. She wa referring to the assassination of Maulvi Mohammad Farooq, the top Moslem cleric in Indian Kashmir. During his funeral procession Monday, Indian force shot to death 58 people. Ms. Bhutto returned late Wednesday from visit to Iran, Turkey, Syria, Jordan, North Yemen, Egypt, Libya and Tunisia, a high-profile diplomatic offensive to drum up support for Pakistan's stand on the Kashmir issue. Hindu-dominated India accuses Pakistan of arming and training Kashmiri militant fighting for secession of Jammu-Kashmir, India's only state with a Moslem majority. Pakistan, which is dominated by Moslems, denies the Indian charge. Since the Indian government ordered a crackdown on the militant in late January, more than 400 people have been killed. During her trip abroad, Ms. Bhutto said all her host country agreed that India and Pakistan needed to find a lasting political settlement of the 43-year-old dispute. However, she added, If subjected to aggression, we would have the full support of the Arab Islamic nation. Pakistan, I wa assured, would never be left alone. We believe the threat to peace are grave, she said. We cannot rule out the possibility of an armed conflict, but we do not believe war is inevitable, she told reporter. Ms. Bhutto said she opposes an independent Kashmir. She said it wa not envisioned when India and Pakistan gained independence in a 1947 partition. The prime minister again called for talk between Pakistan and India. She also said a neutral body should look into the charge made by both side. India ha already rejected both suggestion. Moslem extremist abducted a leading businessman and an educator Friday and threatened to kill them, a day after authority killed six militant crossing into Pakistan for arm and training, police said. Roads were blocked around Srinagar, where the hostage were seized, and soldier tightened security around the Kashmir Valley, where the government launched a crackdown Jan. 20 on the Moslem separatist movement. A telephone caller told a local reporter the abductor were also holding a third hostage and all three men would be killed within 24 hour of a Monday afternoon deadline for releasing three jailed militant. The caller claimed to speak for the Students Liberation Front, a branch of the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front fighting for autonomy in the predominantly Moslem state. India itself is overwhelmingly Hindu. Police source, who demanded anonymity, and the telephone caller both identified the new kidnap victim a Vice Chancellor Mushir ul-Haq of Kashmir University and LM. Khela, general manager of Hindustan Machine Tools Co. The caller said ul-Haq's private secretary also wa being held hostage, but that could not be confirmed. Moslem separatist had warned Indian government official to leave Jammu-Kashmir state before April or face the consequence. Police said the border violence took place in Kupwara district, where at least 20 separatist tried to sneak into neighboring Pakistan to receive military training and buy weapon. No detail were available. India say Pakistan train and arm the militant in Kashmir, at the far northern tip of India. Pakistan denies it. India and Pakistan have fought two war over the region since 1947, when both nation won independence from Britain. Pakistani and Indian troop exchanged fire for several hour today after a Pakistani soldier became the first military casualty on the troubled Kashmir border, officer and a western observer said. The soldier wa shot in the leg Sunday at a ceasefire line, several mile from the village of Chaukothi, official said on condition of anonymity. They said there were no report of casualty from today's firefight at the line, which divide Kashmir between Pakistan and India. The nation have twice gone to war over the Himalayan state, in 1948 and again in 1965. The former princely state wa divided between the two nation after British colonial rule ended in 1947. Relations between the neighbor have become increasingly strained since Jan. 20 when Indian troop launched a military crackdown on Moslem separatist in turbulent Jammu-Kashmir. The militant want India's only majority Moslem state to either become independent or join Pakistan. Jammu-Kashmir is an aberration in India, where 82 percent of the country's 880 million people are Hindus. The leader of both country have tried to soothe temper in the dispute and have said another war over the region is unlikely. However, Pakistani force have now sealed off the border area at Chaukothi, forbidding civilian from entering the area. The border crossing wa the scene of a bloody confrontation on Feb. 11 between Indian troop and Pakistani student, who were marching in solidarity with activist in Indian-held Kashmir. Indian troop killed three student and wounded several during that confrontation, a Pakistan defence ministry spokesman said. The two army also exchanged gunfire for about 30 minute before calm wa restored. A Paksitan army captain, who said he witnessed the firefight, said unlike the occasional shooting in the past, Indian soldier appeared to be aiming at Pakistani troop. The western observer said Sunday's shooting of the Pakistan soldier appeared to back up that assertion. In another sign of increased tension, Pakistani and Indian officer are no longer accompanying United Nations' military observer a they pas through the border. It is not a normal situation, the officer said. The border is extremely tense. Pakistan official said they were taking step to quell what one official called war fever on the Pakistan side. We are trying to tie the people down, said Amir Alan Khan, a retired lieutenant colonel who head Kashmir's civil defence. He said hundred of retired soldier have approached him to ask for order to fight the Indian army. The body of four Moslems were found in a Kashmir town Monday, five day after they were kidnapped by Moslem militant agitating for secession from India. The body, which had bullet wound, were found in the town of Sopore about 35 mile northwest of the Kashmir capital of Srinagar, said police official speaking on condition of anonymity. Anonymous caller to local newspaper and news agency office said the four were killed by the Hezbul Mujahedeen because they were police informer. The Hezbul Mujahedeen is one of more than a dozen Moslem organization fighting for independence of the Kashmir valley from India. Police official also reported the death of one soldier in a militant ambush of an army convoy in the district of Baramulla, northwest of Srinagar. At least three soldier were injured, they said. The death raise to 630 the number of people killed since security force began a crackdown on the Moslem movement on Jan. 20. The Kashmir valley, most of which fall in the Indian state of Jammu-Kashmir, is predominantly Moslem. Jammu-Kashmir is the only Indian state with a Moslem majority. Moslem militant earlier had demanded union with Pakistan, the Islamic nation on India's western border. But, of late, they have been demanding independence and the status of a neutral nation. A leader of the Moslem separatist movement in Kashmir tried to hurl a grenade into a police bunker Friday but wa killed in a volley of police gunfire. Tens of thousand of Moslems gathered later for the funeral. Comrades fired into the air and vowed to carry on the fight for independence from India. Ashfaq Majid Wani, 28, wa a leader of the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, a leading separatist group. He wa the front's area commander in Srinagar. Police said he tried to throw the grenade at a police bunker in downtown Srinagar while riding by on a motor scooter. The grenade went off after officer opened fire with automatic weapon. Three other people died in the melee, the police said. Hours later, thousand of resident gathered near Wani's house in an attempt to hold a funeral procession in defiance of a government curfew. But soldier and police prevented the procession and took Wani's body to a burial ground in a government ambulance escorted by a police jeep. Women wailed and beat their chest a Wani's body wa taken out of the ambulance and placed near the grave. Men shouted: Ashfaq's blood will usher independence! A group militant fired pistol and automatic rifle in the air. Witnesses estimated the crowd at 40,000. The firing continued intermittently for more than one hour until the body wa interred at 5 pm. We will carry forward Asfaq's mission, which wa to gain independence, said one militant leader holding a Soviet-designed Kalashnikov rifle. He refused to give his name. The secessionist movement ha been alternately simmering and flaring since 1948, when the Hindu ruler of the old princely state of Kashmir, faced with the option of merging either with India or Islamic Pakistan, chose India. column6: The Indian state of Jammu-Kashmir is the scene of continuing violence between the government and Muslim insurgents who are seeking to establish an independent nation.  More the 1,000 have been killed since January.  Since 1947, predominately Islamic Pakistan and Hindu-majority India have fought twice over this Muslim-majority region.
column7: The Indian government has been fighting Muslim insurgents in the state of Jammu-Kashmir for the last seven months.  More than 1,000 people have been killed.  India (predominately Hindu) and Pakistan (predominately Islamic) have fought two wars over Kashmir since the nations were established in 1947.  Jammu-Kashmir is 62 percent Muslim and the insurgents want an independent nation.  Violence is occurring primarily near Srinagar, the capital, and along the border with Pakistan.  India claims the insurgents are being trained and armed in Pakistan.  Pakistan denies these charges.  The two nations recently exchanged fire, but both say there is no cause for concern.
column8: Fighting has broken out sporadically in the Indian state of Jammu-Kashmir since January 20.  At least 1,034 people had been killed by late August.  The Indian government is battling Muslim insurgents seeking the formation of an independent, neutral, nation.  India (predominately Hindu) and Pakistan (predominately Islamic) have fought two wars over Kashmir since the nations were established in 1947.  Jammu-Kashmir is 62 percent Muslim.  Insurgent tactics have included bombings, kidnappings, killings of suspected police informers, ambushes of police vehicles, and attacks on police installations.  Large demonstrations have been held in Jammu-Kashmir and on the Pakistani border.  Indian tactics have include retaliatory fire, arresting and killing insurgent leaders, 24-hour curfews, disrupting and firing on demonstrations, and interfering with funerals of dead insurgents.  The state is now governed directly from New Delhi.In August, India increased border forces and operations and killed 80 infiltrators, claiming the insurgents are being trained and armed in Pakistan.  Pakistan denies these charges but says it does support the Muslims' crusade for "self-determination."  The Prime Minister of Pakistan has sought the support of other Islamic nations.  The two nations have exchanged fire on several occasions, but both say there is no cause for concern.

India and Pakistan hurl accusations and somebullets at each other but claim the situation is localized and not serious.

Moslem separatists began a campaign ofviolence in Jammu-Kashmir hoping initially to lead to union with Pakistanbut later for independence. Despiteincidences of soldiers firing across cease-fire lines, the two countriessaid the situation was local and not serious.
column12: Kashmir had been a separate kingdom ruled by a Hindu when Britainrelinquished colonial rule of the Indian subcontinent in 1947.   It waspartitioned on religious lines into India and Pakistan and Kashmir's Hinduking opted to be part of India.  The Jammu-Kashmir state is India's onlypredominately Moslem state with 64% of the state's 5 million people Moslem.Jammu-Kashmir has been a contentious issue between India and Pakistan fromthe beginning and the two have fought over it.  In 1990, separatistelements, most prominently the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, began acampaign of violence, including kidnapping, bombings, and assassinations.Initially, the Moslem separatists wanted to become part of Pakistan, butlater hoped to become an independent nation.  The Indian government began acrackdown in January of that year, imposing curfews and retaliating toinsurgent attacks.   By summer, police actions and separatists' violence hadresulted in over a thousand deaths.   India and Pakistan hurled charges ateach other with India claiming that Pakistan trained and armed theinsurgents, a claim that Pakistan denied. column3: DOCUMENTS which show for the first time that both Mr Robert Maxwell and his son Kevin were intimately involved in substantial purchase of share in Maxwell Communication Corporation, one of their own public company, have been obtained by the Financial Times. Meanwhile, a director of a secretive Swiss trust, Mr Werner Rechsteiner, ha broken his silence and ha admitted that transfer of MCC share to his trust, which are at the centre of an investigation by the Serious Fraud Office, were made on the instruction of Robert Maxwell. This is the first time that Mr Rechsteiner ha given detail of the relationship between his mysterious trust, Yakosa Finanzierungs, and the Maxwell family. The FT ha also obtained a letter and ha seen a corroborating fax which show that Mr Kevin Maxwell wa intimately involved in the purchase of 9m share by Yakosa and a further 16m share by Servex, another Swiss Trust. The MCC purchase by Yakosa and Servex are the object of an investigation by the SFO into an alleged illegal scheme to support the MCC share price. The SFO is also investigating whether Mr Robert Maxwell or Mr Kevin Maxwell breached the Companies Act by failing to disclose the purchase of the share by the Swiss trust. If either had a financial interest in the Swiss trust, the purchase should have been disclosed under company law, because they were both director of MCC. The document demonstrate that Bishopsgate Investment Trust, a private UK company controlled by the Maxwell family, provided Pounds 55.33m on behalf of the two Swiss trust so that they could pay for the MCC share. Goldman Sachs, the US investment bank, acted a broker to the deal. Goldman's lawyer are convinced that it acted properly. Mr Rechsteiner yesterday broke the silence he ha maintained since Robert Maxwell's death in November on the subject of his relationship with the Maxwell family. He said MCC share purchase had been 'going on for some time' through Yakosa. He denied that the share were bought for Yakosa's 'own account'. He said the share were bought for other 'foundations' and then 'held for a certain time.' He also stressed that ownership of the MCC share no longer rested with Robert Maxwell once they had been received by Yakosa: 'Yakosa is owned by the Maxwell Foundation,' he said. Mr Rechsteiner refused to say who controlled the Maxwell Foundation, which is based in Liechtenstein, but said it wa neither Robert nor Kevin Maxwell. The FT ha however obtained document showing that Mr Kevin Maxwell wa closely involved in the process of paying for 25m MCC share on behalf of two Swiss trust, Yakosa and Servex. On May 29 last year, Mr Kevin Maxwell sent a fax to Mr Larry Wood, an executive director of Goldman Sachs, telling him that two parcel of 12.5m MCC share each would be bought by the Swiss trust with Pounds 55.33m provided by BIT, a Maxwell private company. The fax, signed by Mr Maxwell, said that the fund would be remitted to Goldman Sachs 'by Bishopsgate Investment Trust PLC from it account at National Westminter Bank plc, 41 Lothbury'. Two other fax sent by Mr Kevin Maxwell to Mr Wood on the same day show that the former wa equally involved in the other end of the transaction, the sale of the 25m share. The Swiss trust bought the share, using Goldman a broker, from two Maxwell pension fund, Maxwell Communication Pension Trustee (Works Scheme) and Mirror Group Newspaper Pension Trustee (Works Scheme). Each pension fund sold 12.5m share at a price of 219.78p a share, or Pounds 27.47m in total. At 6.29pm on May 29, Mr Maxwell sent the two other fax to Mr Wood on behalf of the two pension fund. As a director of MGPT and a a trustee of MCCPT, he told Mr Wood to pay each pension fund what it wa owed to the NatWest account of BIT, which Mr Maxwell described a 'nominee' for the two pension fund. In other word, he told Mr Wood that the share were being bought for the Swiss trust with fund provided by BIT and that these fund should then be sent by Goldman back to BIT. In the event, on May 31, Goldman received the Pounds 55.3m by wire transfer in it account at Barclays. Goldman then levied it commission and expense on the deal of Pounds 385,000 and wired the remainder back to BIT's NatWest account. Scots bank bow out, Page 8 Claims to Israeli share, Page 8 Sir Nicholas Lyell QC, the attorney-general, will attempt to stop the curtain rising on Maxwell: The Musical, the West End show chronicling the life and time of the late Robert Maxwell. Fears that the musical might prejudice the criminal trial of the late publisher's son, Kevin and Ian, have prompted Sir Nicholas to apply to the High Court on Monday for an injunction to halt the production. The musical tell the tycoon's life story through updated version of familiar tune from Gilbert and Sullivan. Now in rehearsal, the show is due to open at London's Criterion theatre on February 11. The attorney-general's move to close down a West End production before it first night is regarded a without precedent. However, it is no more unprecedented, most lawyer say, than the prospect of the Maxwell brother having to commute to their trial at the Old Bailey past a theatre advertising the story of their father a 'the musical review that will make you laugh, sing - and be angry'. The musical, which ha cost Pounds 1.1m to put on, ha been produced by Mr Evan Steadman, a former chairman of one of Maxwell's private company. Mr Steadman indicated yesterday he intended the show to go on and that the attorney-general's application for an injunction would be contested. However, he said he wa leaving matter in the hand of his lawyer. Press coverage of the late publisher since his death ha already caused deep concern to the Maxwell brothers' lawyer . Mr Alun Jones QC, Kevin Maxwell's barrister, led call for reporting restriction to be placed on a recent High Court ruling that Robert Maxwell had been fraudulent in his dealing with share in Berlitz, the publishing company. Turning down his request, the judge asked him: 'Is it going to be your client's defence that Mr Robert Maxwell wa not guilty of misappropriation?' At that point, lawyer in court themselves fell about laughing. MR MICHAEL STONEY, a senior executive in a number of Maxwell company, is named a one of three people primarily responsible for more than Pounds 180m of 'unusual' payment from Mirror Group Newspapers bank account during the last financial year, according to the chairman's statement released with MGN account yesterday. Mr Kevin Maxwell and Mr Ian Maxwell, two son of the late Robert Maxwell, are named a the other two people most involved in these transaction. Mr Kevin Maxwell and Mr Stoney refused to provide MGN with information, the statement say. Sir Robert Clark, chairman of MGN, list a series of transaction - some of which he stress may have been perfectly legitimate - that took place in the past few month. He say legal action may be taken against a number of organisation, including Goldman Sachs, the US investment bank, over more than Pounds 40m in transfer from MGN if the bank wa aware that they were 'effected for improper purposes'. Notes to the account show that MGN made extraordinary provision of Pounds 421.5m in the year to December 29 1991, including Pounds 208.6m in pension deficiency and Pounds 122.4m in transaction with Maxwell-controlled company. Sir Robert say that during the year there were at least 28 'unusual' payment for more than Pounds 1m from the group's bank account, making a total of more than Pounds 180m. 'Some may well ultimately be established to have arisen under legitimate transactions.' Nine of the payment were authorised solely by Robert Maxwell. The others were authorised mainly by Mr Kevin Maxwell, Mr Ian Maxwell and Mr Michael Stoney, he say. One transfer to Goldman Sachs wa countersigned by Mr Ernest Burrington, former managing director, at the request of Mr Kevin Maxwell on the reported instruction of Robert Maxwell. Two authorisation were countersigned by Mr Lawrence Guest, former MGN finance director. Sir Robert say the MGN director do not believe that either Mr Burrington or Mr Guest knew there wa anything improper about these payment. With these exception, 'the independent director . . . were not involved in, and did not authorise or approve any of these payments,' he say. Sir Robert say the group finance department accepted assurance from the treasury department - which wa headed by Mr Stoney - about 'the nature of certain transactions' including payment to financial institution which were recorded a deposit. 'The treasury department arranged for it to appear that sum of interest had been credited to the group in respect of those 'deposits',' he say. In his report Sir Robert point to 'certain weaknesses' accepted by the MGN board: Internal control and operating procedure which failed to identify related party transaction and bring them to the attention of independent director for approval; Bank mandate authorised by Robert Maxwell and Mr Stoney which permitted the movement of group fund on the authority of Maxwell or director who were also director of Maxwell-controlled companies; The audit committee of non-executive director, which might have reviewed system and mandate, but wa not convened; The finance department's inadequate authority to verify and record the treasury department's activity. The report detail a Pounds 50m loan made by Bankers Trust in London last October which appears to have been used to pay off a loan from Bankers Trust in New York to Robert Maxwell Group, parent of the Maxwell private interest, Separately, the statement highlight three transfer of more than Pounds 40m from MGN to Goldman Sachs - Pounds 11m of this wa transferred on Robert Maxwell's signature to pay for previous dealing in Maxwell Communication Corporation stock. The balance wa for foreign exchange trade exposure incurred by Bishopsgate Investment Trust and Robert Maxwell Group, it say. He say MGN is inquiring to see whether it can establish if Goldman Sachs wa 'aware or should have been aware' that the transfer 'had been effected for improper purposes'. If so, he say 'it will be possible to seek order against them . . . for the sum paid.' He say MGN is considering legal action against professional adviser in relation to property lease, and hope to recover money through claim on insurance policy written on Robert Maxwell's life. ABOUT 20 bank became con-cerned last summer at the behaviour of business run by Robert Maxwell several month before he died and his business empire collapsed. Their concern arose when Maxwell Communication Corporation made late payment to them, a Financial Times investigation ha discovered. Yet although some bank became alarmed at the implication for the financial health of his empire, they did not discus their concern with each other or with authority such a the Bank of England. Mr Basil Brookes, MCC's former finance director, ha described his shock to the FT at discovering last August that MCC had failed to settle foreign currency transaction with about 20 bank on time. Starting about July 4 1991, MCC's treasury, under the authority of Maxwell and his son, Kevin, had begun to buy and sell enormous amount of foreign currency. In these 'spot' transaction, MCC would buy a currency in one financial centre promising to make payment in another centre. On a number of occasion, MCC received the currency, but did not make the payment - thereby giving itself an unauthorised loan. Mr Brookes say about 20 bank, including Lloyds, Bank of America, Goldman Sachs and Swiss Bank Corporation, were involved in the flurry of foreign exchange deal. At least Dollars 100m (Pounds 55m) in unapproved credit is thought to have been raised this way. A former Maxwell employee said some appeared to have been channelled into private Maxwell business. One banker said attempt to raise money by making late payment in the foreign market wa a relatively well-known ruse with the nickname called 'teaming and lading'. It also emerged yesterday that National Westminster Bank, the biggest lender to the Maxwell private company, felt badly let down by Maxwell because he failed to deliver fund on time at the end of July. At a meeting between Maxwell and Mr John Melbourn, a NatWest director, on July 10, NatWest refused Maxwell's request for a loan of Pounds 45m. NatWest wa upset three week later when it provided fund - le than Pounds 100m - to the Maxwell empire on the understanding that it would be repaid the same day, and then found that repayment wa not made. NatWest wa forced to convert this 'intra-day' transaction into a short-term loan, which wa eventually repaid. The bank told both Robert Maxwell and Mr Kevin Maxwell that it wa concerned that repayment had not been made, but it did not discus the problem with other bank or with the Bank of England. Instead, it pressed on with it policy of reducing the size of it loan to the Maxwell business. NatWest's loan to the Maxwell empire now total Pounds 182m, half the level of two year ago. Later last year, Robert Maxwell made many repayment to bank by looting pension fund asset and also carrying out unusual fundraising exercise with US investment bank, from which ten of million of dollar were borrowed at a high price.
