THE LATE Mr Robert Maxwell liked to think of himself a a 'strong ' chess player and there wa always a chess set in his suite in his London headquarters. 'There is no evidence to suggest that Maxwell actually wa a strong player or that he played in any tournaments,' said Mr Malcolm Pein, international chess master and director of Chess and Bridge, which yesterday took over the business and asset of Maxwell Macmillan Chess and Bridge. There may be doubt about Robert Maxwell's strength a a player but le about his enthusiasm for the game. In 1990, through The European newspaper, he sponsored a section of the World Chess championship in New York. And when Pergamon wa sold to Elsevier last year Maxwell kept the chess and bridge publishing business. Mr Pein said it had taken most of the year since Mr Maxwell's death to prise the business, which include Chess Monthly and Bridge Monthly from the administrator to the Maxwell empire. 'Price Waterhouse took month and month to come up with any information about the company,' said Mr Pein. Even when the new company had reached agreement to buy the business from Price Waterhouse, administrator to the public Maxwell company they then ran into trouble with Arthur Andersen, administrator to the private Maxwell business. Mr Pein said the new company wanted to use and pay for the premise of Maxwell Macmillan Chess and Bridge - prefabricated building in the village of Wheatley, Oxfordshire - until they found permanent premise. However, he said that Arthur Andersen wanted two year back rent. Despite the year of difficulty, Chess and Bridge is now set up in new premise in Euston Road, London. The company said it had the largest collection of chess and bridge book and product in the UK. Two writ have been filed alleging that Goldman Sachs, the US-based investment bank, assisted in diverting Pounds 55m from two pension scheme controlled by Robert Maxwell to ensure it own debt from Maxwell interest would be repaid. The writ were filed late last week in the State Supreme Court in Manhattan by trustee for Mirror Group Newspapers Pension Scheme and Maxwell Communication Corpora-tion Works Pension Scheme. The trustee seek more than Dollars 100m for the sale of share plus interest, commission charge and punitive damage from Goldman and Mr Eric Sheinberg, partner in charge of international equity trading. The writ centre on the purchase of Pounds 55m of MCC share from the pension scheme by two Swiss trust, Servex and Yakosa, which were transacted through Goldman and for which the scheme were never paid. The writ allege Goldman wa aware the trust were controlled by Robert Maxwell. The writ also allege that on May 28 1991 - the same date Mr Kevin Maxwell arranged for the pension fund share transaction to be paid for - Goldman wa due to receive Dollars 58.2m for an unrelated transaction selling MCC stock to an unnamed American lawyer 'with close connection to Robert Maxwell'. The writ claim that Goldman wa 'competing directly with it customer, the pension fund trustee, for payment'. On April 26 1991, they say, Mr Kevin Maxwell told Mr Sheinberg to sell the pension scheme share to the Swiss trust. On May 23 he told Goldman to remit the proceeds of the sale not to the pension scheme but to Bishopsgate Investment Trust, which Goldman knew or should have known wa controlled by the Maxwell family. The writ allege that after the deal wa struck Mr Trevor Cook, MGN pension fund administrator, told Goldman that proceeds of the sale should be paid to the pension scheme, but when Mr Kevin Maxwell ordered the proceeds to be paid to BIT. The writ say that Goldman and Sheinberg 'made no reasonable effort to determine who had actual authority to direct for the pension fund that the share be sold and where the more than Dollars 47m in proceeds from the transfer of the 12.5m share should go'. Goldman said it had 'received no money or other benefit from these transaction other than it brokerage commission of Pounds 110,000 which were substantially le than the amount of the applicable stamp duty paid to the Inland Revenue of Pounds 215,000'. Mirror's flagship publication is the tabloid Daily Mirror, with sale of three million copy daily. Last month, in another money-raising move, Mr. Maxwell's Maxwell Communication Corp. sold it Pergamon Press PLC unit for #440 million. In other change, Mr. Maxwell's son Ian, who ha been appointed deputy chairman of Mirror Group, will resign from his post at Maxwell Communication, where he wa joint deputy managing director. Maxwell Communication said last month that it management would be taken over by Kevin Maxwell, Ian's brother. Robert Maxwell bought Mirror Group in 1984 from Reed International PLC for #113 million. Through staff cut and heavy spending on printing facility, Mr. Maxwell built Mirror into one of Britain's most profitable newspaper group. In 1990, Mirror had profit of #37.2 million, or 28.2 penny a share, on revenue of #445 million. Proceeds from the share flotation will be used to strengthen and refinance the group's balance sheet. About #210 million will be used to pay back bank loan and the rest to pay in full a loan from Robert Maxwell Holdings Ltd. Salomon Bros. International is underwriting the international part of the offering, covering approximately one-third of the share on sale, to be privately placed with institutional investor in the U.S., Canada and Europe. The other two-thirds of the share are to be divided between private and institutional investor in Britain. A relatively low minimum-investment figure of #250 ha been set to attract small investor, particularly reader of Mirror publication.
column5: Death of Robert Maxwell raises questions of economic dealings.
column6: Economic confusion surrounds the publishing empire of Robert Maxwell following his death. Maxwell was found dead off the Canary Islands, apparently after having fallen overboard. Maxwell, along with his two sons, Kevin and Ian, and Michael Stone, a Maxwell executive, apparently were involved in the illegal transfer of funds.
column7: Economic confusion surrounds the mysterious death of publishing magnate Robert Maxwell. Maxwell, who put together a publishing empire following his immigration to Britain in 1940, was found dead off the coast of the Canary Islands after apparently having fallen overboard from his yacht. There are allegations that Maxwell, along with two of his sons, Kevin and Ian, and a senior executive in several Maxwell corporations, Michael Stoney, were involved in the illegal transfer of funds to help his publishing empire fend off debt. The scheme used Swiss trusts and a number of institutions, including the U.S. investment bank, Goldman Sachs.
column8: Robert Maxwell has been described as the Citizen Kane of his time. The mysterious death of this larger than life individual on November 5 has left the economic affairs of Maxwell Communications Corporation and Mirror Group Newspapers is a state of confusion. Maxwell was born in Czechoslovakia and immigrated to Britain in 1940 to escape the Holocaust. He put together and personally ran world-wide publishing empire that included Macmillan Publishing House in New York, Britain's Daily mirror, the Daily Record and the European and British Printing Company, and communications Corp., Britain's largest printing company. Improprieties have been alleged in the handling of funds which involve not only Robert Maxwell, but two of his sons, Kevin and Ian, as well as Michael Stoney, an executive in several Maxwell companies. At issue is the alleged improper transfer of funds in an attempt to handle his publishing empire's crushing debts. Among the interests named in the transfer of funds to two Swiss trusts, is the U.S. investment firm Goldman Sachs. Maxwell also is accused of using MCC in an effort to raise funds by making late payments on the foreign market. In doing so, MCC in effect gave itself an unauthorized loan.
column9: British entrepreneur Robert Maxwell and sons guilty of financial fraud.
column10: British media entrepreneur Robert Maxwell died in 1991 in the waters off Canary Island while on vacation. His sons Kevin and Ian took over the Maxwell business but were soon found guilty along with their father of using illegal financial schemes and looting pension funds to pay off crushing debts.
column11: British media entrepreneur Robert Maxwell, owner of the Mirror Group Newspaper Ltd. of Britain and publisher of Britain's Daily Mirror and the New York Daily News, died in 1991 in the waters off Canary Island while on vacation.  His sons Kevin and Ian took over the business but were soon implicated along with their father in an illegal scheme to deal with crushing debts. Allegedly, unauthorized loans were acquired by using a Maxwell company to buy currency in one financial center while promising, but often failing, to make payments to another center. Some repayments were made by looting pension funds.
column12: British media entrepreneur Robert Maxwell, publisher of Britain's Daily Mirror, bought the New York Daily News in 1990. He then planned to raise $448 million through the sale of shares in his Mirror Group Newspaper Ltd. of Britain. He bought Mirror Group in 1984 and turned it into one of Britain's most profitable newspaper groups.A year after the Daily News purchase, he was found dead in the waters off the Canary Island where he was vacationing on his yacht. Investigators say Maxwell siphoned money from his companies in an attempt to deal with crushing debts. Some $630 million was taken from his Mirror Group pension fund without authority. His sons Kevin and Ian, who took over the business, were investigated and found guilty for their knowledge of illegal schemes using two Swiss trusts, a private UK trust company and a US investment bank to support the Maxwell Communications Company (MCC). In a flurry of foreign exchange deals, the MCC would buy currency in one financial center promising, but often failing, to make payment in another center; thus getting an unauthorized loan. Some repayments were made by looting pension funds assets.

column3: Buenos Aires, 23 May (NA) -- Today, the Foreign Ministry said that control operation carried out by the corvette Spiro against a Korean-flagged [as received] ship fishing illegally in Argentine water were carried out "in accordance with international law and in coordination with the Foreign Ministry." The Foreign Ministry thus approved the intervention by the Argentine corvette when it discovered the Korean ship Chin Yuan Hsing violating Argentine jurisdictional water on 21 May. The Argentine Navy reported today that the corvette Spiro stayed near the Korean ship "given the adverse weather condition, and fulfilling it responsibility of sea search and rescue." The Korean ship, which had been fishing illegally in Argentine water, wa sunk by it own crew after failing to answer to the Argentine ship's warning. The crew wa transferred to the Chin Chuan Hsing, which wa sailing nearby and approached to rescue the crew of the sinking ship. The Navy reported that around 15 nautical mile off the coast of Malvinas and "in accordance with bilateral agreement with Great Britain, the Spiro transferred assistance responsibility to British authorities." The Foreign Ministry said "an understanding with the UK for operation in case of uninterrupted persecution of illegally fishing ship wa implemented." The Foreign Ministry also said the policy "is in accordance with the growing international opinion currently giving priority to the preservation, regulation, and the sustainable use of marine live resource and the effective punishment of violator of national law on the matter." An Argentine supply ship that ran aground off Antarctica sank Tuesday in heavy sea and high wind, the government said, and there wa concern oil in it hold could leak and damage the environment. The sinking of the 400-foot Bahia Paraiso followed warning from the US. National Science Foundation that the unspoiled Antarctic could face ecological disaster if the 250,000 gallon of diesel fuel aboard the ship were to spill. No injury were reported in the sinking. Tourists aboard and the crew had been evacuated from the vessel, which wa 600 mile south of Cape Horn, the tip of South America. Salvage effort had been hampered by 50 mph wind. The double-hulled oceanographic ship sank at about 10 p.m., the government news agency Telam said, citing a navy communique. Telam did not say whether the ship broke up or if diesel oil spilled when it went down. The depth of the water in which the ship sank wa not immediately known. The ship had been carrying supply including jet fuel, gasoline and canister of compressed gas to the Argentine Esperanza station near the tip of the Antarctic Peninsula, the National Science Foundation said in a statement released in Washington. The ship ran aground Saturday about two mile from Palmer Station, a US. research facility on the Antarctic Peninsula, the continent's tip. It sustained a 35-foot-long gash in it hull, and some of the 250,000 gallon of diesel fuel began leaking, washing ashore near Palmer station. The fuel killed some krill, a tiny shrimp-like creature that is a vital part of the Antarctic food chain, and ha affected penguin, sea gull and giant petrel bird, the National Science Foundation statement said. There were no immediate detail about the extent of damage to the wildlife in the pristine surroundings. Agency spokesman Jack Renerie said Tuesday before the ship sank that the leak, which wa threatening penguin and other wildlife, had stopped. Scientists are concerned that some research search project may already have been affected by the leak, a foundation statement said. It said two Argentine salvage vessel were expected to arrive Thursday or Friday. Before the sinking, Argentine official had discounted a spill. Telam quoted Argentine navy source a saying: The fuel it carried, both for itself and the Antarctic station, wa in steel drum so a spill is practically impossible. The 316 people aboard the ship when it ran aground, including 82 passenger and 234 crew member, were rescued by power boat and taken to Palmer Station. The passenger and most of the crew were taken by cruise ship to the South Shetland Islands, from which they were airlifted to the South American mainland Sunday. But 104 crewman remain at the station, said Renerie. Because the station is equipped for only 40 people, food ha been rationed to two meal a day, a National Science Foundation statement said. Leopold Gratz, the president of Parliament and one of the most powerful politician in the Socialist Party, resigned today over a scandal surrounding the mysterious sinking of ship 12 year ago. Gratz, 59, is the second senior Socialist official to step down because of his alleged involvement in the so-called Lucona scandal, the subject of a widely publicized investigation by a parliamentary committee. Interior Minister Karl Blecha, like Gratz a onetime protege of former Chancellor Bruno Kreisky, resigned Jan19. Blecha and Gratz have denied wrongdoing or aiding Udo Proksch, the prime suspect in the sinking of the ship Lucona in the Indian Ocean. Six sailor died. The Lucona's cargo wa officially described by Proksch a for a uranium processing plant and insured for $16 million. The insurance company ha never paid, claiming the cargo wa only scrap metal and alleging the vessel wa intentionally sunk to collect the insurance money. Proksch, wanted by Austrian justice on suspicion of murder and insurance fraud, ha been variously described to be living in Syria, the Philippines and Latin America. In several interview, Gratz described himself a a close friend of Proksch, but when Proksch fled to escape prosecution, Gratz criticized him. Gratz told Parliament today he would give up his seat in February, hence his post a president, one of the most prestigious post in Austria. My decision is a personal one and it is politically motivated, Gratz told the house. If it becomes impossible for the president to effectively take a stand on significant issue or to speak up on problem of parliamentarism because everybody is only interested in his context in a single other topic, then he cannot serve the National Council (parliament) in such a way a is his duty. In past newspaper story, Gratz wa accused of providing fabricated evidence from abroad to help Proksch in his claim that the controversial shipment wa for a uranium processing plant. Gratz, who denied the allegation, wa also accused of helping Proksch in several other way. Like Blecha, Gratz is to appear before the parliamentary investigation committee. A freighter carrying a cargo of beer sank in the North Sea today off the Dutch coast and all nine crew member were rescued from life raft, a coast guard spokesman said. The ship sank at about 12:45 pm. in high wind, some 28 nautical mile north of the island of Ameland. It wa not immediately clear what had caused the sinking 29 mile off the Dutch island of Ameland, according to the coast guard spokesman, who wa not identified. There were no casualty, he said. The coast guard official, who spoke in a Dutch radio interview, identified the ship involved a the Finnish-registered freighter Ra and said it had been carrying a cargo of beer. He did not give the ship's origin or destination. The nine crew member boarded two life raft after the sinking in high wind. They were taken ashore by a West German helicopter from the island of Borkum, about 30 mile from the site of the sinking, the official said. A Dutch navy aircraft and two life boat also rushed to the scene. Earlier report had said that the ship wa a passenger ferry, possibly one of the Dutch ship plying the frequent ferry lane between the coastal island and the Dutch mainland. Freight shipping in the area is also heavy because of it vicinity to the port of Delfzijl in the Netherlands and Emden in West Germany. A deep-sea inspection of the Bismarck suggests that the most powerful battleship in Adolf Hitler's navy wa scuttled by it own crew rather than sunk by the British in a celebrated battle, underwater explorer Robert D. Ballard said Thursday. During a 90-minute news conference, Ballard described how he his ocean-crawling robot located the Bismarck sitting upright and proud two week ago. Then the American oceanographer, whose father wa of British background and whose mother wa of German heritage, addressed himself to the German people in German. I am an underwater explorer, not a treasure hunter, he said, translating himself back into English. We found no human remains. We touched nothing and took nothing. . The future of the Bismarck is in the hand of the German people. He said he will disclose it exact location only to Germany so Germans themselves can decide whether to try to raise the ship, which sank after a battle May 27, 1941. Ballard, a senior scientist at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution in Massachusetts, said structural evidence satisfied him that the Germans scuttled the battleship rather than trying to surrender or allowing her to be sent down by British fire. Only scuttled ship tend to make it to the bottom in one piece, Ballard said. It appears the crew opened it up along it entire length. It wa clearly flooded, stem to stern. Maybe the Germans didn't want it taken a a war prize, he added. It is known that two year earlier, Hitler ordered the German pocket battleship Graf Spee scuttled after it wa cornered in the neutral port of Montevideo, Uruguay, and attacked by British ship. Hitler apparently wanted to keep the British from learning the secret of the Graf Spee's construction and weapon. In the 1941 battle, the Bismarck's main gun were quickly knocked out and the attacking British ship were out of range of her secondary gun, Ballard said, so it wa helpless and taking hundred of hit it sinking clearly inevitable. Rendered unsteerable by torpedo dropped by tiny fabric-covered British biplane, it wa unable to escape. Asked if the German commander couldn't have surrendered by ceasing fire, Ballard said in the fuzz of battle in fierce sea it would have been unlikely that the British would have recognized that the Germans were giving up. Again, he speculated, perhaps the Germans did not want the ship's technologically advanced equipment to fall into British hand. The Bismarck wa found by Ballard in more than 15,000 foot of water about 600 mile west of Brest, France. He said it wa in remarkably good shape, elegant, well preserved. Before the battle, British Prime Minister Winston Churchill had left convoy unprotected and thrown all his capital ship in pursuit with a ringing three-word command: Sink the Bismarck! Of the Bismarck's 2,200-man crew, only about 115 survived. British ship picked up 110 survivor but left with hundred of German sailor still in the icy water after spotting what might have been a German U-boat. German vessel later rescued only five more survivor. The story ha been recounted in book, song and a movie. The sinking occurred only eight day after the Bismarck left Gdynia, Poland, for her first operation. If unstopped, it could have posed a critical threat to convoy of merchant shipping and undercut British morale at a time when England stood virtually alone against combined German sea and air power. The British sent the warship Hood after the Bismarck but within five day of going to sea the Bismarck had sunk the Hood in a three-minute engagement, with the loss of all but three of the vessel's crew of 1,419. The Hood wa a symbol of British sea power, and it loss stunned the British public and the war government and made sinking the Bismarck a mission of crucial importance. Ballard said under law of the sea, the Bismarck remains the property of the German people. The sunken battleship wa discovered and photographed by the same remote-controlled robot that Ballard used four year ago to find the wreck of the Titanic, the British passenger liner that sank in 1912 after striking an iceberg. A yacht built for Adolf Hitler and sunk with great fanfare to commemorate the Voyage of the Damned wa mistakenly dropped on a delicate coral reef in a shallow shipping lane, official said Tuesday. They're going to have to move it, said Coast Guard spokeswoman Veronica Cady. The 85-foot Ostwind yacht wa supposed to become an artificial reef in 250 foot of water about two mile off the coast. It wa sunk June 4, 50 year after the US. Coast Guard turned away the SS St. Louis a it more than 900 Jewish passenger were seeking refuge from the Holocaust. The sinking site wa supposed to be near where the Coast Guard intercepted the St. Louis, whose passenger also were turned away by Cuba and forced to return to Europe. Most of the passenger later died in Nazi concentration camp. For unexplained reason, the Ostwind wa pushed off a barge about a mile north of the site, and is resting in 25 foot of water on a living reef. It wa truly an incredible, incredible historic event, and suddenly boom! somebody made a mistake, said Mayor Abe Resnick, a Holocaust survivor and a sponsor of the event. Federal and Dade County official who allowed Resnick to sink the boat are upset about the result. They didn't even come close, complained Susan Markely, an administrator with Dade's environmental department. Coast Guard Lt. Al Crespo said the yacht is balanced on a delicate living reef, threatening damage to coral and sponge. It's also close to an anchoring spot for freighter and other vessel heading to the port of Miami and ha been marked with a flashing buoy, he said. It's close enough that if a ship swing on it anchor, it could hit it, Crespo said. The Army Corps of Engineers said the Ostwind must be moved or cut to piece by June 22. If it's not, the government will remove it and bill Resnick. Resnick blame the mistake on AM. Daly Jr., captain of the tug that towed the yacht to where it wa sunk. Daly, however, said Chris Cadley, captain of a passenger boat that accompanied him, had agreed to lead him to the site. Cadley denied that, saying he only agreed to meet Daly off the coast. Resnick said someone will have to pay. I think's that's going to end up being decided by attorney, said Ben Mostkoff, the county's artificial reef director. The Ostwind wa built at Hitler's direction, although he rarely used it. After World War II, the badly decayed boat wound up in the hand of a Jacksonville marina owner. A Florida couple said their pleasure boat wa sunk by whale off Costa Rica and they survived 66 day at sea by eating raw fish and drinking purified water, the US. Coast Guard reported Sunday. William Butler, 60, and Simone Butler, 52, of Miami, were weak but recovering at a hospital in Golfito, Costa Rica, after being rescued by a Costa Rican Coast Guard ship Saturday afternoon, said US. Coast Guard Chief Petty Officer Egbert Vallecillo. The survivor told authority they lost about 50 pound each from the ordeal, said Vallecillo, who spoke to the couple by telephone early Sunday. The US. Coast Guard's Pacific Command is headquartered in Alameda, 10 mile east of San Francisco. William Butler told Coast Guard official their 40-foot pleasure boat Sibonay wa attacked and sunk by several whale on June 15 about 1,200 mile southwest of Costa Rica. They were large, according to Mr. Butler, Vallecillo said. But he didn't know how many whale. The couple's last radio contact wa June 13, when they talked to their daughter in Miami, the Coast Guard spokesman said. Vallecillo said he'd heard of boat running into marine mammal when there's poor visibility, but isn't sure if there are any recorded case of whale aggression. This happened in the early morning hour with good visibility, he said. This is the first (case) I've documented. As the boat wa sinking, the couple said, they grabbed fishing rod and a salt-water purifier and and got into a rubber lifeboat, where they remained for the next two month, Vallecillo said. As the lifeboat drifted slowly eastward over two month, the Butlers said, they caught between 400 and 500 pound of fish and survived multiple shark attack by sealing puncture with a raft repair kit. Butler told US. Coast Guard official that several time the couple spotted merchant ship but were unable to flag them down. On Saturday, a Coast Guard ship making it fishery patrol about 30 mile off the coast of Golfito spotted the raft and rescued the couple. They were sailing from Coral Gables, Fla., near Miami, to Honolulu, where they planned to vacation, Vallecillo said. Butler is an experienced sailor, he said. Their daughter, Sally Smith, and son, Bill Butler, were flying to Costa Rica on Sunday evening to be reunited with their parent, Vallecillo said. Greek diver have plunged 162 foot beneath the Aegean Sea and back into history, finding a treasure-laden Turkish warship sunk by Greek revolutionary in 1822. The remains of the wooden sailing ship were found near the island of Chios in the eastern Aegean at a point where historical account place the sinking of the Ottoman ship, according to Peter Nicolaides, a diver and salvage expert. The Bourloti Seimaz or Explosives Invincible wa set afire and sunk by Greek Admiral Constantine Kanaris in revenge for Turkish killing and looting on Chios. Thousands of islander died in the Turkish raid, which shocked other nation and swung Western European country behind the Greek struggle for independence from the Ottoman Empire. Greece won independence in 1830. The French painter Eugene Delacroix produced a famous picture, The Massacre of Chios, based on the raid. It's an incredible discovery, straight out of the history book we used to read in school about the War of Independence, Nicolaides said in an interview Friday with The Associated Press. Nicolaides, who heard about the wreck while teaching an underwater archaeology course to local diver last winter, started querying fisherman about where their net snagged on seabed obstacle. He pinpointed the wreck on May 3, he said. When I dived, I found ships' timber sticking out of the muddy seabed and dozen of object Islamic cooking pot, cannon ball, a candlestick, even a chalice from a Greek Orthodox church, he said. The ship wa obviously crammed with loot from Chios. I think there may be gold and silver item a well, he said. I also saw what I recognized a human bone, he added. He said the wreckage indicated the vessel wa at least 100 foot in length. According to historian, more than 1,000 people including 400 Greek captive were aboard the ship when Kanaris staged his attack in the early hour of June 7, 1822. The Greek admiral sailed from the nearby island of Psara, towing a boat stuffed with explosive. Its pointed bow wa rammed into the mouth of a cannon on the Bourloti Seimaz and a fuse lit. The Ottoman commander, Admiral Kara Ali, wa killed in the blast that split the ship. Kanaris and his crew of Greeks escaped. This is a very significant, very emotive find, coming from this particular period of history, said George Papathanassopoulos, the Culture Ministry's adviser on marine archaeology. Papathanassopoulos said the 162-foot water depth at the site will make investigation difficult since underwater archaeology rarely is attempted at depth over 113 foot, but he said, This is a ship that must be explored. Nicolaides said he hoped it would be possible to tap American and Turkish expertise to excavate the wreck a an international project. American expert from the Institute of Nautical Archaeology at Texas A & M University, working in cooperation with Turkish diver, have pioneered underwater excavation off the Turkish Aegean coast. Greek marine archaeologist focus on locating and surveying historic wreck scattered around the Aegean and rarely carry out excavation. Ferries are among the safest vessel afloat. But, a the tragic sinking of the Estonia with the loss of more than 800 life demonstrates, when they do go down the toll in human life can be high. As ferry increase in size, so the number on board at risk from mechanical failure or a crew error go up. The move to roll-on roll-off ferry with vehicle deck which run the entire length of the vessel ha increased the risk that, once the sea penetrates the hold through the bow door or a gash in the ship's side, it can lead to the vessel capsizing. The United Nations International Maritime Organisation (IMO) and it member, the ship-owning nation, have devoted much thought over the past two decade to ship safety. But the sinking of the Estonia should lead to a new review of ferry safety. Particularly worrying are the eyewitness report which suggest that water penetrated the bow door in a manner reminiscent of the sinking of the Herald of Free Enterprise in 1987. Unlike the Herald, the Estonia appears to have had it door closed, but ro-ros are undoubtedly very vulnerable to water penetration. Any review of ferry safety should focus on three main issue. First the subject of ferry design should be reconsidered. Additional stability could be provided by the addition of sponsons, stabilising bulge which project from the ship's side just above the water line. Greater resistance to an influx of water could be obtained by installing moveable barrier or bulkhead to break up the large car deck. These proposal were looked at by the British government in the wake of the sinking of the Herald of Free Enterprise. It calculated that it would cost between Pounds 70m and Pounds 85m to improve standard on the 57 vessel in the UK ferry fleet, with a further Pounds 22m in extra annual running cost. Higher cost would inevitably lead to higher fare - unwelcome to ferry operator when, on the short cross-Channel route, they face competition from the Channel tunnel. But the difficulty of pushing through fare rise would be nothing like a damaging to the ferry company a another disaster. Second, the IMO and national government must look closely at how to improve enforcement of existing regulation. The IMO ha been trying to move enforcement up it agenda, but it depends on the good will and professionalism of government and shipowner. Third, the IMO should be given support by national government in it campaign, launched yesterday, to improve crew training. Much of the regulation in recent year ha concentrated on improving the ship and it equipment. Above all, if new regulation doe turn out to be necessary, it must be introduced speedily. As thing stand, it can take year before change are ratified by enough government to give them force. The European Union, which Sweden and Finland are getting ready to join, could take a lead in speeding up the process. Ship safety is not, of course, just an issue for the ferry sector. Five (small) ferry were lost last year, according to Lloyd's Register. But this figure pale into insignificance compared with the 96 general cargo ship and 12 tanker which also went down. When a cargo vessel with a third-world crew go down in a distant ocean, very little attention is paid. If the loss of a relatively modern passenger vessel in European water can make shipping safety a higher priority for government and the public, this will be some small compensation for the loss of life from the Estonia. Two sailor were missing Monday evening after a 652-foot freighter en route from Greece apparently sank in rough sea 400 mile southeast of Cape Cod. Twenty-three crew member were rescued. The 23 sailor from the Star of Alexandria were found on a lifeboat and picked up by the merchant ship Ravenscraig, Coast Guard Petty Officer Randy Midgett said in New York. They're all in good shape, some minor cut and scrape, Midgett said. The two missing sailor were believed to be on a life raft, which wa the object of a hunt Monday evening by the 950-foot Ravenscraig and five Navy and Coast Guard search plane, official said. The Ravenscraig's crew spotted a second life raft, but it turned out to be empty. The cause of the sinking wa not immediately known, official said. The Star of Alexandria had been en route from Athens, Greece, to New York with a load of cement when it began taking on water in 12-foot sea and wind up to 35 mph, Midgett said. The first mayday call went out at 9:05 am. A Coast Guard jet from the air station on Cape Cod and a C-130 plane from Elizabeth City, N.C., converged on the ship. The lifeboat wa spotted around noon. The C-130 wa able to drop a radio into the water near the boat carrying the 23 crew member and they were able to establish communication, Midgett said. About four hour later, they were rescued by the Ravenscraig. The Star of Alexandria wa not spotted, and wa presumed to be sinking or sunk, Midgett said. Visibility in the rough sea wa five to eight mile Monday afternoon. The Star of Alexandria wa built in 1966, and wa registered in England. It wa designed to carry bulk freight, and wa owned by Caribene Investments Ltd. of Gibraltar, according to Bureau Veritas, a Paris-based shipping registry. The Ravenscraig had been bound for England, but it destination after it rescue mission wa not immediately known.
column5: Maritime Losses Continue. Estonia Lost With 800 Aboard. Bismarck Found
column6: Three freighters, two ocean-going yachts, a supply ship, a fishing vessel, and a ferry carrying 800 passengers were some of the maritime losses between 1888 and 1994.The German battleship Bismarck, scuttled off France in 1941, was located in 1989. A Turkish vessel, sunk in 1822, was located in 1988.
column7: Freighters sank off Cape Cod in 1989, and in the North Sea in 1988. A 1989 Austrian scandal grew out of the 1977 sinking of the Lucona. In 1989 an Argentine supply ship sank in Antarctica. In 1994 a Korean fishing vessel was scuttled while fishing illegally near Argentina. The Ostwind, once Hitler's yacht, was purposely sunk off Florida. An American pleasure boat was sunk by aggressive whales. In 1994 the ferry Estonia sank with 800 aboard.The German battleship Bismarck, scuttled in 1989, was located in 1989. A Turkish vessel, sunk in 1822, was found in 1988.
column8: Articles published between 1988 and 1994 demonstrate the widely diverse circumstances that surround the sinking of ocean-going vessels.Some articles addressed the locating of vessels sunk many years earlier. In May 1988 divers located a Turkish ship sunk by the Greek Navy in 1822. The Bismarck, Germany's most powerful battleship was scuttled off France in May 1941, and found in June 1944.The freighter Star of David went down in rough seas off Cape Cod on 17 April 1989. High winds prevailed when a Finnish freighter sank in the North Sea in September 1988. A 1989 scandal that involved Austrian politicians grew out of the mysterious sinking of the freighter Lucona in the Indian Ocean 12 years earlier.The Ostwind, a yacht built for Hitler, came to an ignominious end off the coast of Florida. In the same month whales attacked and sank the American pleasure boat Sibonay off Costa Rica.In January 1989 an Argentine supply ship sank two miles off the Antarctic Peninsula. A Korean vessel, fishing illegally in Argentine waters, was scuttled in May 1994 when apprehended by the Argentine Coast Guard.Eight hundred lives were lost when the ferry Estonia sank in 1994.
column9: Many causes responsible for sending ships to bottom of sea.
column10: Many reasons for ships sinking exist.  Ships that run aground from unseenhazards often sink.  Naval battles generally result in ships being sunk.Faulty design and rough seas may cause a ship to sink.  A crew may scuttleits ship to avoid capture or to conceal illegal activity.
column11: Severe weather at sea, faulty ship design, unseen obstacles, and hostileaction are some of the many reasons that ships sink.  At times, ships aresunk deliberately, by a dishonest owner in an insurance scam or by a navalcrew in wartime to foil an enemy or by a crew to conceal illegal activities.Loss of life very often accompanies a ship=B9s sinking.  Efforts to locatesunken ships are undertaken to determine why the ship went down and,sometimes, in the hope of recovering treasure.  Ships sinking are notuncommon events. In 1993, over 100 vessels went under.
column12: Ships sink for many reasons.  Many because of severe weather conditions atsea, some because they run aground, some because of design faults, some byhostile action, and some smaller vessels sink after encounters with marineanimals. Sometimes a ship sinking is deliberate.  Dishonest owners have sunktheir ships in order to collect insurance money.  Crews have deliberatelysunk their ship to prevent it from falling into enemy hands during wartimeor at other times to conceal evidence of illegal activity.  Older orderelict ships often serve to help establish a coral reef or become amemorial when sunk.  Many ships sink each year.  In 1993, 96 general cargoships, 12 tankers, and 5 ferries went to the bottom.Loss of life, sometimes heavy, usually occurs when a ship sinks.  A ferrysinking in 1994 caused more than 800 deaths.  Sea explorers search forsunken vessels to determine exactly where and often why they sank.  Somehope to recover treasures.Historic events have resulted from ships sinking.  In the 18th century, aship sinking figured in the Greek struggle for independence from the OttomanEmpire.  In the 20th century, two high Austrian government officialsresigned because of a scandal, which involved the sinking of a ship.

column3: John G. Tower ha fallen, but the sky ha not. For all the forecast of dire result if the Senate blocked Tower's path to the Pentagon, business is proceeding a usual. President Bush said the case wa closed and accepted Democratic assurance of future cooperation. That doesn't undo the resentment among some of Tower's more ardent Republican ally in the Senate and in some corner of the White House. Bush lieutenant claimed they had heard what sounded like assurance of support from a dozen Senate Democrats. They ended up with only three Democrats in the close-to-party-line vote against Tower. Nevertheless, a week after the former Texas senator wa denied confirmation a secretary of defens, the water have closed. There will be ripple, and some of them could be wave-sized. The good-behavior rule set in the debate over Tower's drinking habit and his lucrative defense consulting business are certain to be invoked a precedent whenever Republicans spot a Democratic target. We've established what will be known a the Tower standard, said Sen. John Warner, R-Va. That argument will be used by House Republicans challenging the financial conduct of House Speaker Jim Wright. But it will be a debating point, not a turning point, in a Wright controversy that wa ordained long before the Tower episode. While President Bush wa unwavering in his support of Tower, he burned no bridge to congressional Democrats. He insisted that Tower wa the best man for the job and he spoke out repeatedly for his choice, even after it wa clear that the nomination wa doomed. But he didn't get nasty about it, saying there wa no point in escalating the fight. That's over, he said 24 hour after the Tower defeat. That's history. And now we are going to go forward. The 53-47 vote against Tower wa a setback to Bush in the sense that it always is a defeat when Congress denies a president something he want. But this denial did not cost Bush a program, or a major campaign pledge, or the support of voter. Indeed, it could turn out that the Senate did the president a favor by sending Tower back to Texas instead of to the Pentagon. It wa a break Bush could not make with a political ally who had been after the Pentagon job since Ronald Reagan wa elected president. Tower had not been a Reagan man he had supported Bush for the 1980 nomination. And the Reagan White House went to some length to rule the senator out of the job he sought, declaring that the new president would not be nominating any Senate Republican for any Cabinet post. After Tower's long wait, Bush displayed his own loyalty, all the way to a losing vote when the standard, somewhat safer course would have been to withdraw the nominee. Tower not only shunned withdrawal; he offered condition that had to be humiliating, if only the Senate would let him have the job. Tower promised to quit drinking, taking the pledge on national television. And when that didn't work, he offered to become the first-ever probationary Cabinet member. Republicans proposed that he get the job for a six-month trial and then return for reconfirmation, a gimmick that would have changed the system and could have haunted the presidency. No deal. So Tower became the ninth Cabinet nominee ever to be rejected, the first who wa a former senator. Bush said he had been fighting for the right of a president to appoint his own Cabinet, but he avoided language that would have raised the political stake. Tower did not restrain himself. Battling for the job, he said withdrawal would damage Bush and rejection would be damning the president's judgment. He said his nomination had been turned into a vehicle for a major presidential defeat. Tower's advocate on the Senate floor said grave constitutional issue were at stake, that the authority of the presidency wa on the line, that the Senate will come to rue the rule it wrote in the Tower decision. But Bush said all along that the outcome, either way, would not hurt on other issue. Sen. Sam Nunn, chairman of the Armed Services Committee and the pivotal figure in the Tower defeat, agreed. He told his Georgia constituent that the Tower rejection would not hurt Bush's leadership. In Washington, `triumphs' and `setbacks' are short-lived, Nunn said, and that's particularly true of the president. Retired Sen. John Tower, the defense secretary-designate, underwent surgery Thursday to remove a colon polyp, a hospital spokesman said. Senator Tower is resting comfortably and is listed in fair condition, hospital spokesman Steve Habgood said Thursday night. The senator is expected to make a full recovery. Tower, 63, a US. senator from Texas for 24 year, wa admitted to Baylor University Medical Center on Wednesday after undergoing a colonscopy examination last week that revealed the polyp, Habgood said. A preliminary biopsy of the polyp showed it wa benign, Habgood said, but further result would be announced Friday by Tower's surgeon, Dr. RD. Dignan, of Dallas. Thursday's surgery took approximately three hour, Habgood said. When Tower underwent the colonscopy examination, a rectal polyp also wa discovered and removed. Tests of that growth showed it to contain some malignant but well differentiated cell, Habgood said. Further explanation of the first polyp removal would have to come from Tower's surgeon, who wa unavailable for comment Thursday night, the spokesman said. After leaving the Senate in 1985, Tower went into business a a defense consultant. He also served a an arm negotiator for President Reagan and he headed the White House's Iran-Contra investigative panel. President-elect Bush designated Tower a his defense secretary on Dec. 16. The nomination is subject to Senate approval. Defense Secretary-designate John Tower contradicted an earlier sworn statement when he told the Senate his work for a British firm involved no military matter, according to report published Saturday. Meanwhile, new question were raised about the thoroughness of the FBI's background investigation of the embattled nominee. One newspaper reported that several bizarre accident, including early-morning car crash and a hotel fire, apparently were overlooked in the probe. The Senate Armed Services Committee ha put the nomination of Tower, a former Texas senator and onetime chairman of the committee, on hold while it take a second look at Tower's personal habit, including his use of alcohol, and his link to defense contractor. Tower, who ha declined to be interviewed while his nomination is pending, ha denied in his Senate testimony any problem with alcohol or any conflict of interest concerning his business tie. A White House spokesman, Stephen Hart, declined on Saturday to comment on the latest report, saying it's (the nomination) before the committee. Tower's designated spokesman, attorney Paul Eggers of Dallas, did not answer a reporter's call Saturday. Larry Combest, R-Texas, issued a terse statement Tuesday supporting Defense-Secretary designate John Tower but refused to comment on a published report that he told Senate Armed Services Committee leader that Tower used to drink up to a bottle of scotch at a sitting. Were the writing le stiff and the narrative technique le choppy, "Consequences" might have been a classic case study of late 20th-century politics out of control. Given Mr. Tower's qualification for the job -- intelligence, patriotism and past chairmanship of the Armed Services Committee -- the nomination should have sailed through with flying color. Instead it sank like the Bismarck. Clearly and apparently to his surprise, Mr. Tower had made many enemy since his arrival in Washington in 1961, often rubbing even supporter the wrong way. The senator from the Lone Star State could be lordly, in his English-cut suit. When the Tower hearing opened, all manner of accusation came to public notice. The New Right activist Paul Weyrich claimed to have seen the senator consorting with A Lady Not His Wife. It wa reported that Mr. Tower had chased a secretary around his desk and had fondled woman at Bergstrom Air Force Base. The second wife, whom the senator had recently divorced, possessed a repertory of tale she cheerfully volunteered. At his hotel, Mr. Tower wa accorded that doubtful tribute to instant-celebrity status, the medium stakeout. The nominee issued fervent denials: He drank only wine, having long since sworn off scotch; he'd never chased secretaries; his service for defense-industry client had been proper and modest. None of the charge, at least on Mr. Tower's showing, proved to have the least substance. No use. Dirt is dirtier than purity is pure, a one of John O'Hara's character observes. Sen. Sam Nunn, Mr. Tower's successor a Armed Services Committee chairman, seemed initially to smile on the nomination; then the rumor mill started churning and he changed front. While endeavoring to look statesmanlike, Sen. Nunn leaned on moderate Democrats who would otherwise have supported Tower. Sen. Nunn made the campaign personal, say Mr. Tower -- vote for me or vote for him. Most Democrats, in the end, went with Sen. Nunn. What wa all this about? Morality? Mr. Tower suggests instead that Sen. Nunn, a presidential hopeful, discovered and seized an opportunity to show who wa really No. 1 on national defense. Sen. Nunn had every reason to know that the moral and ethical charge leveled at Mr. Tower, and investigated exhaustively by the FBI, were flimsy. Yet he waved them about anyway. When the medium retailed lurid and unsubstantiated story, Sen. Nunn pursed his lip like a Georgia Sunday-school superintendent and suggested that a drunken Mr. Tower might accidentally press the nuclear button. "Sam Nunn," Mr. Tower insists, "used the FBI inquiry to discredit me and to strike at the president of the United States. The essential chain of good judgment and goodwill broke down during my confirmation process." Sen. Nunn ha company on Mr. Tower's dishonor roll. There is Sen. Ernest Hollings ("a study in arrogance and pomposity"), Sen. James Exon ("one of the most excessive regular boozer in the Senate") and NBC's Andrea Mitchell ("the most viciously partisan reporter I've ever seen"), along with the Washington press corp. Sen. John Warner, a Republican, is depicted a falling all over himself to stay in good with Sen. Nunn. Mr. Tower feel, not without reason, that he wa arraigned on moral charge by cynical colleague and medium personage whom no one ever mistook for Southern Baptist deacon. "I don't so much resent my rejection by the Senate," Mr. Tower insists, "as the way it wa done." "Tower, you were lynched," Mike Wallace, the CBS correspondent, told him. Worse yet, the lynch mob remains at large. --- Mr. Murchison is a senior columnist for the Dallas Morning News. The Democratic-controlled Senate today rejected the nomination of former Texas Sen. John Tower a defense secretary, delivering a major rebuke to President Bush just 49 day into his term. The Senate's 53-47 vote came after a bitter and divisive debate focused on Tower's drinking habit, behavior toward woman and his business dealing with defense contractor. It wa only the ninth time in 200 year that the Senate ha voted to reject a president's Cabinet choice and the only time it ha done so early in a new administration. Vice President Dan Quayle presided over the Senate during the roll call, underscoring Bush's commitment to the nominee. The Senate gallery were packed and virtually all senator were in their seat a the roll wa called. The nomination of John Tower to be secretary of defense is not confirmed, Quayle intoned after the vote. Kansas GOP Sen. Nancy Kassebaum provided the biggest surprise of the final hour of debate when she became the sole Republican to declare her opposition. She said her most serious concern were over Tower's activity a a defense consultant after serving a an arm control negotiator. She also expressed doubt that he would pay enough attention to ensuring fairness for woman in the military. Tower's Republican defender began to speak of him in the past tense and the nominee also appeared to accept defeat, even before the roll wa called. Just moment ago I took a call from John Tower, said Sen. John Warner of Virginia, the senior GOP member of the Senate Armed Services Committee. His head is high, his voice is strong, Warner said. He asked me to convey thanks in his word to the troop who rallied to his support. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, moved to repair damage caused by the bitter struggle to relation between the Senate and President Bush. I know what's in my heart and in my mind, he told reporter. I want to directly, clearly and unambiguously say that this doesn't represent an effort to be harmful to the president. Dole agreed to a late-afternoon vote on the nomination after acknowledging the collapse of a last-minute bid to give Tower an extraordinary six-month trial period a defense secretary to prove he could abstain from drinking. The last few undecided senator declared their position. Sen. John B. Breaux, D-La., said he would vote against Tower. Sen. James M. Jeffords, R-Vt., said he would support the nomination. Senators from both party credited Tower's defeat to the decision to oppose him made by Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Armed Services Committee. When he made his decision all the other Democrats wheeled in behind him, said Sen. John Chafee, R-RI. With the prospect of defeat seemingly inevitable, White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said, If necessary, we'll come up with a (new) candidate very rapidly. Warner, a former secretary of the Navy; former Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld; former Rep. Jack Edwards, R-Ala.; and national security adviser Brent Scowcroft. Scowcroft replied No when asked this morning if he wa in line for the Pentagon job. It must be clear to all that people like the chief of staff and the national security adviser, any number of congressman and senator and any number of other outside expert have candidate on the tip of their tongue, Fitzwater said. column6: Former Texas Senator John Tower was killed in the crash of a commuter plane off the coast of Georgia. Senator Tower had been President Bush's nominee for Secretary of Defense. The Senate rejected the nomination following allegations of problems with alcohol and inappropriate dealings with defense contractors.
column7: Former Texas Senator John Tower and his daughter were killed in the crash of a commuter plane on Sea Island, off the coast of Georgia. Senator Tower had been President Bush's nominee for Secretary of defense, but the nomination was rejected by the Senate on the recommendation of the Senate Armed Services Committee. This was only the ninth time in history that a cabinet nominee has been rejected. The committee recommended rejection after hearing allegations about Tower's use of alcohol and his inappropriate behavior towards women. The committee also questioned his dealings with defense contractors after Tower gave contradictory testimony.
column8: Former Texas Senator John Tower was killed in a commuter plane crash on Sea Island, off the coast of Georgia. The crash, which killed everyone on board, also took the life of his daughter, Marian. Tower was recently the center of controversy when his nomination for Secretary of Defense was rejected by the Senate Armed Forces Committee and the full Senate. Tower became only the ninth nominee in history to be rejected. He also was the first nominee ever to be rejected so early in the term of a new presidency. Tower's rejection followed allegations of problems with alcohol. Tower admitted that he had been a heavy drinker in the 70s but that he has since limited his drinking to a glass of wine with dinner. Tower, twice divorced, also was accused of inappropriate behavior towards women. The Senate Armed Services Committee also called into question his contradictory testimony on his dealings with defense contractors. Tower told the committee that his advice to British Aerospace was limited to civil aviation matters while in a 1987 deposition written for his second divorce, he said he advised the company on selling certain systems to the defense department.

Tower's drinking, womanizing, and questionabledealings with defense contractors led to his defeat.  No lasting damage torelations between the Senate and the president are expected. Justbefore Senate Armed Services Committee confirmation hearings began, Towerhad surgery for the removal of a benign colon polyp.  Initially, members ofthe committee and early witnesses had praise for the former senator.However, later testimony suggested that Tower was a heavy drinker andwomanizer.  Tower conceded that years earlier he had problems with alcohol,but said those days were behind him.  Questions continued to surface thatthose days were not that long ago.  The FBI was lax in investigating thoserecent incidents.  An editorial supporting Tower conceded that he hadearlier "boozed it up and fooled around" but said that recent charges didnot have substance.  Tower's testimony that he had not dealt in defensematters when on the payroll of British Aerospace contradicted an earlierdeposition in which he said he did just that.  The committee, controlled byDemocrats, voted 11-9 against recommending rejection of Tower.  The fullSenate rejected Tower 53-47, with one Republican against him and threeDemocrats for him.

Sarbanes say he is not against political ambassador a such, noting that many of them compiled distinguished record. It is not the political ambassador that are the problem, Sarbanes said. Secchia a ambassador to Italy, but the panel's chairman said he feared Secchia might embarrass the United States because of his penchant for making gross remark. The committee's vote wa 13-0 in favor of Secchia, a former Republican national committeeman for Michigan and lumber industry executive. The chairman, Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., and Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., voted present, meaning they took no position. Pell inserted into the hearing record newspaper account containing the distasteful specific of Mr. Secchia's remark. At his confirmation hearing earlier this month, Secchia pledged to be far more careful a a diplomat in his use of colorful language than he had been in his different role a a political organizer and enthusiast. But Pell said he wa unpersuaded. Tact and careful speech are hallmark of successful diplomat, Pell said. Mr. Secchia ha demonstrated that he would bring opposite quality to the position of ambassador to Italy. Italian friend of mine telephoned me from Rome, aghast at the prospect of having Mr. Secchia represent the United States in their country, the chairman said. I believe that this nomination is a mistake, and in all likelihood Mr. Secchia will be an embarrasment to the administration and the United States, Pell said. But he said that since Secchia is the president's choice he would not try to block the nomination or delay action on it. President Bush ha named career diplomat Deane Hinton a ambassador to Panama, the White House announced Tuesday. Hinton, currently ambassador to Costa Rica, replaces Ambassador Arthur H. Davis, who wa recalled by Bush in protest of what the administration considered the stealing of the Panamanian election last May by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Bush sent Davis back to Panama City after the Dec. 20 invasion of Panama by US. force and installation of Guillermo Endara a president. Independent observer mostly concluded Endara had won the election by a hefty margin. Bush named Hinton a a recess appointment because Congress is not in session. That mean Hinton can serve until the end of next year before he must go before the Senate for confirmation. The appointment of the 66-year-old Hinton, with his long expierience on Latin American issue, is seen a a signal of the importance Bush is placing on restoring normal relation with Panama. Those relation steadily deteriorated after the United States indicted Noriega, once a ally particularly of the US. intelligence community, on drug trafficking charge in Florida. Hinton ha been ambassador to Costa Rica since 1987. Before that he wa ambassador to Pakistan from 1983 to 1987, and ambassador to El Salvador from 1981 to 1983. He wa assistant secretary of state for economic and business affair from 1979 to 1981, and before that US. representative to the 12-nation European Community, headquartered in Brussels, a State Department adviser on economic affair, and director and economic counselor of the State Department's Agency for economic Development in Chile and in Guatemala. Davis, a former State Department consultant and former ambassador to Paraguay, wa sent to Panama by President Reagan in 1986. Bush wanted to name his own ambassador and the time wa appropriate with the installation of a new government in Panama, said one administration official. Officials described Hinton a an experienced Latin America hand and a good person to have in place with the volatile development in the South American country. On Capitol Hill, Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, called Hinton highly qualified for the post because of his wide-ranging experience and expertise in Central America. However, Mitchell said he hoped Bush would send the appointment to the Senate after Congress convenes Jan. 23 despite the nature of the recess appointment.
column5: Bush ambassadorial nominees include veteran diplomats and big campaign contributors
column6: Veteran diplomats nominated by Bush as ambassadors included James Lilley (China), John Negroponte (Mexico), Deane Hinton (Panama), Harry Shlaudeman (Nicaragua), Thomas Pickering (India), Wesley Egan (Jordan), and Edward Perkins (UN). Bush also nominated campaign contributors Joseph Zappala (Spain), Marvin Semble (Australia), Della Newman (New Zealand), Joseph Gildenhorn (Switzerland), and Peter Secchia (Italy).
column7: Bush nominated veteran diplomats James Lilley (formerly CIA) to China, John Negroponte (who helped direct CIA aid to Contras) to Mexico, Deane Hinton to Panama,  Harry Shlaudeman to Nicaragua (over Melissa Wells), Thomas Pickering to India, and Wesley Egan to Jordan (interpreted there as signaling Jordanian importance to the US).  Edward Perkins became UN ambassador. Nominees Joseph Zappala (Spain), Marvin Semble (Australia), Della Newman (New Zealand), and Joseph Gildenhorn (Switzerland) were said qualified only by large campaign contributions, and nomination of loudmouth Peter Secchia (Italy) was called a mistake. Other nominations included Shirley Temple Black (Czechoslovakia), Thomas Melady (Vatican),  Keith Brown (Denmark), and William Howard Taft IV (NATO).
column8: Bush ambassadorial nominations of veteran diplomats included JamesLilley (former CIA officer) to China, John Negroponte (who asambassador to Honduras helped direct CIA aid to Nicaraguan rebels) toMexico, Deane Hinton (former ambassador to El Salvador and Costa Rica)to Panama following the US invasion, Harry Shlaudeman (formerambassador to Argentina, Peru, Brazil, and Venezuela) to Nicaragua(over early favorite Melissa Wells, who had no Latin Americanexperience and might have faced confirmation delays), and ThomasPickering (experienced in delicate situations concerning Iraq and ElSalvador) to nuclear power India. Jordan saw the appointment there ofseasoned ambassador Wesley Egan as a signal of Jordan's importance tothe US.  At the UN, Foreign Service Director Edward Perkins replacedPickering as ambassador and Ronald Spiers got the top-ranked Americanpost. The ambassadorial nominations of Joseph Zappala (Spain), MarvinSemble (Australia), Della Newman (New Zealand), and Joseph Gildenhorn(Switzerland) were approved despite charges that their onlyqualifications were large campaign contributions. Senate ForeignRelations Chairman Claiborne Pell called the nomination of PeterSecchia as ambassador to Italy a mistake because of his bigmouth. Routinely approved nominations included Shirley Temple Black(Czechoslovakia), Thomas Melady (Vatican), Keith Brown (Denmark), andWilliam Howard Taft IV (NATO).
column9: President's ambassador selections get Senate committee approval, some narrowly
column10: Most of President Bush's ambassadorial nominees won easy approval in senatecommittee hearings.  A few, however, faced opposition from Democrats incommittee who believed they were nominated only because of largecontributions to the Republican.  But all were finally approved.
column11: Some of President Bush's nominees for ambassadorships have been selected asa reward for large money contributions to the Republican Party, according toDemocratic senators, and some retired diplomats consider a few not to bequalified.   These nominees faced strong questioning from the Democratsduring committee hearings but did manage to get a slim approval from thecommittee.  Conservative senators objected to two of Bush's selections.Most of the president's picks won easy approval.  Two of Bush's picksreceived highly favorable reaction: a Latin American expert for ambassadorto Nicaragua, and the naming of Thomas Pickering, a well-known diplomat, toIndia.
column12: Senate confirmation hearings for President Bush's nominees forambassadorships have shown mixed results for the administration.  Somenominees like Shirley Temple Black the designated ambassador toCzechoslovakia, sailed through the process. The nominees for Spain,Switzerland, Australia, and New Zealand faced strong questioning duringSenate committee hearings but were eventually slimly approved.  Democratsand retired diplomats believed that three of the nominees had no realqualifications but were picked because of large money contributions to theRepublican Party. Democrats also had concern about the nominee to beambassador to Italy.   Senator Jesse Helms and other conservatives objectedto one nominee because he was a Democrat and were thought likely to havesuch strong objections to another that her name was withdrawn.  That womanwas initially picked to be ambassador to Nicaragua since that country was toinstall a woman as president but the potential objections led to a seasonedLatin American expert being named.  The administration picked ThomasPickering, the ambassador to the UN to be ambassador to India.  Thisselection of a well-known diplomat underscores the administration concernregarding the Indian subcontinent where India and Pakistan, both now nuclearcapable, continue to feud over Kashmir.

column3: Police bulldozed unstable brick and mud house today while those left homeless by an earthquake that killed at least 749 people sought shelter and awaited government aid. Casualty report continued to trickle in from remote part of this Himalayan mountain kingdom a relief worker fanned out through the foothill and valley. Sunday's pre-dawn quake struck near the India-Nepal border. Some road were flooded by heavy rain that followed the quake. Others had crack three foot deep or were blocked by boulder the size of house. At least 549 people were killed in Nepal, said Tek Bahadur Thapa of the Home Affairs Ministry. Dharan wa hardest hit. At least 131 body were found in the city of 100,000. Indian official have maintained since Monday that the death toll in their country wa 200 or le, but the figure wa questioned by opposition politician, survivor and the local medium, including the Times of India, a newspaper that generally support the government. They put the India death count at anywhere from 400 to 1,500. Indian official said 200 people were injured in the quake. Nepalese official listed 752 injured, down from their earlier estimate of 1,000. In Bhaktapur, a city of 50,000 where seven people died in the quake, 63-year-old Nhuchhe Raj Sakya said his five-story brick and mud house had nearly fallen down but that he and his family of 10 were still living in it. What else can we do? the goldsmith said. We have no tent. How can I leave my place? Prime Minister Marich Man Singh Shrestha visited Dharan on Tuesday and surveyed heap of brick that were once three-story and five-story house. Most of the victim died in their house, which were made of brick held together by mud that had loosened during the seasonal monsoon rain. Police Inspector G. Adhikari said bulldozer have demolished more than 50 house deemed too dangerous for habitation. We will continue to demolish house until we are satisfied (the one remaining) are safe to live in, he said. Adhikari said local official had not yet heard from the government on compensation or new housing for people whose home were demolished. The earthquake, which struck when most people were still asleep, registered 6.5 on the Richter scale and wa the deadliest quake in the region since 1950, when a temblor in the east Indian state of Assam killed 1,500 by official count and 30,000 by seismologists' account. The rumor started with anonymous telephone call and spread by word of mouth. In Dharan, men ran from house to house rousing people from their sleep. Rescuers searched through debris today for victim of an earthquake that ravaged one-third of this country's territory and part of India, killing at least 650 people and injuring thousand. The death toll wa expected to climb from Sunday's pre-dawn quake on the India-Nepal border, which triggered landslide and flood and wa the mountainous region's deadliest in 38 year. Officials in both country said they had yet to receive report from the remote Himalayan area hardest hit by the temblor, which knocked out power and communication and wa said to injure at least 3,000 people. Niranjan Thapa, Nepal's minister of state for home affair, told a news conference at least 450 were dead and up to 1,000 injured. He said official expected the number to climb. Indian official reported at least 200 people dead and more than 2,000 injured, most by debris from collapsing building. The quake, centered almost on the India-Nepal border, registered 6.5 on the Richter scale. Indian television today showed the devastation in the Indian state of Bihar: crumbled building, makeshift morgue lined with row of body wrapped in white shroud, damaged hospital ward packed with survivor. Medical team in India carried medicine and other supply to overcrowded hospital and the army wa deployed to help search for victim. But the monsoon, which hit the subcontinent in late June and usually last through September, hampered relief operation. Nepal's Thapa told a news conference that the rain have been a great hindrance in carrying out rescue work. Access to some area of this mountain country is impossible. He said 21 of the kingdom's 75 district suffered extensive damage. The hardest hit appeared to be Dharan, a sparsely populated border region where Thapa said at least 131 people died. Ninety percent of the remaining house are cracked, Shahi said, adding that most of the damage wa to modern house of stone and older house from mud and brick. Wooden house were not affected, he said. Many people were given shelter in school, guesthouse and public building, but most of the people do not want to leave their home, Shahi said. He said water supply were still adequate and there were no report of disease breaking out. Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi flew to Bihar to tour some of the hardest hit area. The government said it would release a detailed report after he returned to the capital tonight. Prime Minister Marich Man Singh Shrestha of Nepal visited some of the victim at Bir Hospital in his capital, Katmandu. The quake roused people from their sleep in Bihar and nine other Indian state and central and eastern Nepal. It lasted about a minute and aftershock continued for about an hour. Rail track sank into the soggy ground and bridge over rising river cracked, paralyzing train service and road travel in many part of the devastated area. Parts of northern Bangladesh and the capital, Dhaka, also felt the tremor. There were report that 50 people were injured, most by jumping from their house during the quake. Witnesses in Darbhanga, an Indian city of 800,000 about 45 mile south of the epicenter, said the only warning were hissing sound, rattling door and cracking window. Women began blowing conch shell, following an ancient tradition believed to appease the weather god. In Madhubani, the Bhootahi Balan River jumped it bank and flooded nearly 50 village. A temblor rumbled through the Indian state of Assam on the India-China border in August 1950. Official account said more than 1,500 people died, but seismologist said their record showed 30,000 were killed. Mourners paraded through the street of this medieval town, calling for revenge after a former legislator wa beaten to death by political rival while he wa distributing relief supply to earthquake victim. Hang the murderer, score of young men chanted a they marched in front of a jeep bearing the battered body of Karna Hyanju, once a sympathizer of the now-outlawed Communist Party. Witnesses said Hyanju wa beaten with umbrella and stick late Thursday afternoon, then dragged through the street for nearly two hour before police intervened. He died Friday at the Bir hospital in Katmandu, 7 mile west of Bhaktapur. Uttam Dhaubanjar, a 28-year-old bank employee and neighbor of the dead man, said Hyanju had been handing out blanket, milk and other food in Bhaktapur when he wa accosted by a group of men who accused him of giving relief supply only to his own supporter. He said many belonged to the same Communist faction that Hyanju once supported. People started beating him with umbrella, Dhaubanjar said. There were a lot of scratch on his body, and a lot of blood. It looked like one ear wa missing. Then they made a necklace of their shoe (by tying the lace together), put it around his neck and pulled him through the street. As Hyanju's body wa taken through the winding street of Bhaktapur, a 12th-century town of ancient Hindu temple, thousand of the town's 50,000 people jammed street, temple step and the balcony of brick and mud house. Rana, who is minister of local development and legislative, affair, called Hyanju's death political murder. Hyanju served in the Panchayat from 1981 until 1986 when he lost the backing of the Communists in Bhaktapur, traditionally a leftist stronghold. A strong earthquake triggered landslide and destroyed house in the mountainous India-Nepal border region early Sunday, killing at least 237 people and injuring more than 1500, official and news report said. Seismologists said it wa the deadliest earthquake to strike the Himalayan region since 1950. More than 100 people died when the quake rumbled through the eastern Indian state of Bihar, official said. In Nepal, authority said at least 137 people were dead. Officials in both country predicted the death toll would rise after they received report from remote area which were hit harder. The toll have come in only from urban area, said VK. Sharma, deputy secretary in the Bihar government. The temblor also jolted part of northern Bangladesh and the capital of Dhaka, but there were no immediate report of casualty or damage. Witnesses said window and door rattled, building cracked and people roused from their sleep ran screaming from their home a object tumbled from shelf and table. My bed rattled, then it began swinging, said RN. Rudra, a resident of Patna, the Bihar capital. My dog began barking and I rushed out of the house. At least 1,000 people were injured when the quake triggered landslide and house collapse in Bihar and the surrounding state of Uttar Pradesh, West Bengal and Orissa, all heavily populated, largely agricultural area. The quake also wa felt in Sikkim and Tripura, located in the Himalayan foothill, the Press Trust of India news agency said. In Nepal, a Foreign Ministry official, Shailendra Kumar Upadhyaya, said more than 500 people were injured and thousand of house collapsed from the quake's impact. Most of them (were) buried alive under collapsed house, said Indra Shrestha, a social worker involved in the rescue operation in Dharan Bazar, a township of about 100,000 people about 18 mile from the Indian border. Shrestha said rescue operation were being hampered by the monsoon rain, which hit the subcontinent in late June and usually last through September. Both country were rushing emergency medical team to the area. The Red Cross of Nepal issued urgent appeal for blood donation. In India's Bihar state, communication with Darbhanga, which appeared to be the worst-hit area, were disrupted. The Press Trust of India said a school hostel in the town collapsed, killing at least 17 child. It said more body were feared buried under the debris. The quake damaged most of the house in Darbhanga, the news agency said, quoting PK. Patnaik, the top civil administrator in the district. Deaths were also reported in the neighboring town of Munger, Keoti and Narpatnagar. The tremor also wa felt in the eastern city of Calcutta, Press Trust of India said. There were no immediate report of casualty but resident were quoted a saying window of several home vibrated and door rattled. The Seismological Observatory in New Delhi said the quake hit at 4:40 am. (7:10 pm. EDT Saturday) and wa centered 40 to 50 mile northeast of the town of Darbhanga in Bihar state, along the India-Nepal border. Observatory Director HN. Srivastava said the quake measured 6.5 on the Richter scale. Srivastava said the quake lasted about one minute and aftershock continued for about an hour. Seismologists warned aftershock could continue for day. The US. Geological Survey said it initial seismograph reading placed the center of the quake 100 mile southeast of Katmandu, the capital of Nepal. Geological Survey monitor in Golden, Colo., recorded the earthquake at a preliminary magnitude of 6.7 on the Richter scale. The Richter scale gauge the energy released by an earthquake a measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. A quake of magnitude 6 is capable of causing severe damage. Earthquakes are common in the Himalayan region. On Aug. 6 a quake of magnitude 7.3 shook the state of Assam, Manipur, West Bengal and Bihar. Four people were killed. India's worst earthquake wa in 1950, when at least 30,000 people were killed in Assam state.
column5: Strong Himalayan Quake Kills 704 in Nepal; 277 in India
column6: Sunday's strong, Himalayan earthquake, triggered landslides and collapsed houses. Authorities say 704 died in Nepal, 277 in India. Monsoon rains and aftershocks hampered search and recovery efforts throughout the quake area. Flooding is possible.Of Nepal' 157 Peace Corps volunteers, 154 have been found safe. India has no Peace Corp workers.
column7: The official death toll in Sunday's pre-dawn Himalayan earthquake is 981, 704 in Nepal and 277 in India. Many, especially in Dharan, Nepal, died when brick houses that used rain loosened mud between the bricks, collapsed in the 6.5 (Richter scale) quake. Bihar, India, where authorities say 200 died, is also threatened by flooding.  Monsoon rains and aftershocks hampered relief efforts and the search for victims throughout the quake area. Of Nepal's 157 Peace Corps volunteers, 154 have been found safe. India has no Peace Corp workers. The U.S., Britain, and the international community are sending aid to the devastated area.
column8: On Friday, Nepal updated its death toll from Sunday's Himalayan earthquake to 704 as reports arrived from remote area. In India, the official death toll rose to 277, 200 of which were in Bihar, but the press and others claim as many as 1500 may have perished. Bihar is also threatened by flooding from swollen rivers.The quake, measuring 6.5 on the Richter scale, struck at 4:54 a.m. (local). According to Nepal's Department of Geology, it was centered near Udayapur, Nepal. Monsoon rains, overflowing rivers, submerged bridges and roads and aftershocks hampered relief efforts and the search for victims in throughout the quake area.In Dharan, Nepal, over 131 bodies were found, most in collapsed houses that had used mud, loosened by rain, between the bricks. Karna Hyanju, a former Nepalese legislator, however, did not die in the quake. He was killed after being accused of distributing relief supplies only to his supporters. All but three of Nepal's 157 Peace Corps volunteers have been found safe. There are no Peace Corp workers in India. The U.S. is sending financial aid to both counties. Britain, U.N. agencies and the Red Cross sent medical teams to Nepal.
