column9: Massive earthquake devastates large areas of Nepal and India.
column10: The worst earthquake in this region since 1950, registering 6.5 on the Richter scale, hit near the Nepal-India border killing at least 750 and injuring thousands.  Earthquake damage and monsoon rains have paralyzed rail and road transportation thus hindering rescue efforts and isolating some remote areas.  Aftershocks kept people terrified for days.
column11: The deadliest earthquake in this region since 1950, hit near the Nepal-India border killing at least 750 people and injuring thousands.  The magnitude 6.5 quake, with its epicenter about 100 miles southeast of Katmandu, Nepal, was felt as far away as New Delhi and Calcutta.  The hardest hit areas were Bihar state in India and the Dharan district of Nepal.  Aftershocks kept people terrified for days.   Earthquake damage and monsoon rains have paralyzed rail and road transportation thus hindering rescue efforts and isolating some remote areas.  In Nepal police bulldozed more than 50 houses considered too unsafe to be habitable.
column12: The deadliest earthquake in this region since 1950 hit near the Nepal-India border.  At least 750 people died and thousands were injured.  The magnitude 6.5 quake, lasting about 40 seconds and with its epicenter about 100 miles southeast of Katmandu, Nepal, was felt as far away as New Delhi, Calcutta and northern Bangladesh.  The hardest hit areas were the Dharan district of Nepal, where 50,000 to 60,000 houses were destroyed and the Bihar state of India.  With cracks in the embankments of six Bihar state rivers, flooding could be the next threat there.  Aftershocks kept people terrified for days.  The army, police, and local inhabitants are taking part in rescue efforts in both countries.  Foreign aid began arriving.  Earthquake damage and monsoon rains have paralyzed rail and road transportation thus hindering rescue efforts and isolating some remote areas.  Nepalese police bulldozed more than 50 houses considered too unsafe to be habitable.  Concerned American parents heard from some of their Peace Corps volunteer children in Nepal where all but three volunteers have been tracked down. And in Bhaktapur, Nepal, political rivals of a former legislator accused him of distributing relief supplies to only his supporters and beat him to death.

column3: The actor who played Little Ricky on the I Love Lucy show said Wednesday he spent more time with Lucille Ball than he did with his own family in the five year he played the comedian's TV son. Miss Ball died of a ruptured aorta at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles Wednesday morning, hospital official said. She wa 77. She wa old and, of course, I knew about the heart attack, so I wa not shocked by her death, said Keith Thibodeaux, who at age 6 began playing Miss Ball's drum-playing son on the comedy series that continues in syndication around the world. I'm sure all this is going to hit me a little later on. Thibodeaux grew up on the set, playing Little Ricky from 1956 until 1961 under Miss Ball's watchful eye. I think the thing I remember most about Lucy wa that she wa very much in control of everything, said Thibodeaux, who began playing the drum at age 2, wa a professional drummer at age 4 and is now drummer with David and the Giants, a Christian rock group. He life in Jackson with his wife, Kathy, a ballerina. Thibodeaux, 38, said he got his break in show business when big band leader Horace Heidt persuaded his father to bring him from Lafayette, La., to California for the Swift Premium Hour, a traveling radio show that led to a string of one-night stand across the country. That led to an audition for the I Love Lucy role in Hollywood. I remember Lucy saying, `that's him,' and from that time I wa Little Ricky, said Thibodeaux, who then used the name Richard Keith. I signed a seven-year contract with the studio in 1956 and the first episode I wa in wa aired that December with Bob Hope I just turned 6. Thibodeaux said that during the series' run he spent a much time with Miss Ball a with his own family in Lafayette. And I spent more time with her off the set at her home than at the studio, he said. I remember her a very strict but with a lot of love. She had her way but despite all, she wa a great person, very, very talented. I know everybody remembers her a zany and wacky but that wa only on the show. Actually, she wa just the opposite and wa very serious. . That's what made her a great actress. He said Miss Ball often gave him gift and that he remembers spending at least one Christmas at her home. I remember she once gave me an Indian tepee, then my own dressing room, he said. She gave me bicycle and an identical set of drum. As a young girl in western New York, Lucille Ball hawked hot dog and popcorn at an amusement park a she dreamed of starring in movie, hometown friend recalled. She always talked about being a star, said Pauline Lopus, who went to school with Miss Ball and had kept in touch with her. Miss Ball, born 60 mile south of Buffalo in Jamestown on Aug. 6, 1911, grew up in nearby Celoron, a rural hamlet on Chautauqua Lake. Mrs. Lopus remembered the sitcom star on Wednesday a daring in many way. She tried to get me to run off (to Broadway), Mrs. Lopus added. But I didn't have the nerve. At 15, Miss Ball worked a a barker at the amusement park, screaming for people to buy popcorn and hot dog until she lost her voice. Later, she starred in high school play and got her start in front of a large audience on the vaudeville stage at the defunct Palace Theater in Jamestown. Although Miss Ball hadn't visited Jamestown since 1956 and had no family there, she stayed in touch with friend. Even though she wa a big star, she wa still just Lucy to u, said Irene Rosseti of Celoron. Mrs. Rosseti said Miss Ball recently sent her and her husband a letter on their 50th wedding anniversary. Miss Ball regularly donated money to charity, civic event and Jamestown Community College, said Jamestown Mayor Steven Carlson. On May 20, Miss Ball wa to receive an honorary degree from the college and had planned to return to Jamestown, now a city of about 40,000. Residents had put up poster saying Jamestown Loves Lucy in storefront and home window. After Miss Ball suffered a heart attack last week, resident decided to sign the poster and send them to her a a get-well greeting. More than 150 poster were sent with 10,000 signature. The 77-year-old comedian died Wednesday of a ruptured aorta, the main heart artery, at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, where she wa recovering from last week's emergency heart surgery. It is a sad day for all of u, said Nelson Garifi, an organizer of the welcoming event. But I'm sure that feeling is shared by many people around the world. Garifi, community relation director for the community college, said the honorary degree will be awarded posthumously. Future generation in Celoron will have a reminder of their famous resident every time they drive or walk down the street where she grew up it will be renamed Lucy Lane. Village official had planned formal ceremony renaming the street when she wa due in the area next month. But it will happen anyway, John Goodell of the village's historical society said Wednesday. When the society wa formed about a year ago, Goodell said: We sent an invitation to Lucille Ball to be a member, and she sent back a check for $500 for a life membership. It wa a check written in a very bold hand with a signature about a half inch high. Bob Thomas ha covered Hollywood for The Associated Press for 45 year. Thousands of Lucille Ball's fan shed tear for the woman who made them laugh, a three city held memorial service in which the redheaded comedian wa remembered with prayer and applause. She wa a whole package. There never will be another one like her. I love her, said a tearful Carol Burnett following a memorial Mass in suburban Santa Monica. More than a thousand people who packed the St. Monica's Catholic Church rose to their foot and clapped for several minute after television minister the Rev. Robert Schuller asked them to applaud the Lord for Lucille Ball. About 1,000 people also crowded a church in New York and 200 gathered in a Chicago church. All three memorial Masses began at 8 pm. Monday, the time Miss Ball's three most popular program were often broadcast. The 77-year-old comedian who starred in one of television's biggest all-time hit, I Love Lucy, died here April 26 of a ruptured aorta, a major blood vessel, eight day after emergency open-heart surgery. Miss Ball, known for her honed comedic timing, wide-mouthed expression and wacky antic, wa popular among generation of fan who watched I Love Lucy a a first-run show in the '50s and in three decade of rerun. She showed her love in the only way she knew how, by making you laugh, the Rev. James Fox told those gathered for the Roman Catholic Mass at St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. Broadcaster Diane Sawyer told the crowd that the death of Miss Ball may have settled a longstanding theological debate over whether there is laughter in heaven. A God who would have created her would never let her laughter be far from Him, said Ms. Sawyer. In Chicago, the Rev. Jack Wall told people at Old St. Patrick Church that God gave the world talent like Miss Ball to show u life is not a tragedy, but a comedy with a happy ending. She taught u that if we could love Lucy, we could love ourselves, Wall said. In announcing the service, Miss Ball's family said: Monday night wa the time when most of the nation wa used to being with Lucy. Two of the three long-running comedy show in which Miss Ball starred, The Lucy Show and Here's Lucy, aired Monday night. I Love Lucy had starting time on Mondays and other day. Lucille Ball gave the gift of humor which produced happiness, said Schuller at the Santa Monica service. Only God know how many husband and wife weren't speaking and then Monday night rolled around. Fans lined up to get in the Santa Monica church a much a four hour early. Florists delivered arrangement including a 3-foot heart of red carnation with the word I Love Lucy written across. Hundreds of people came forward during Holy Communion to receive blessing from three priest, including a woman wearing an I Love Lucy T-shirt. I think she would have loved it very much, and she lived her life for the people who were in that room tonight, said Lucie Arnaz, daughter of Miss Ball and the late Desi Arnaz. Gary Morton, Miss Ball's husband for more than two decade, attended a private service for his wife last month. The actress' remains were buried at Forest Lawn Memorial Park in Hollywood Hills. Bob Hope keep voluminous file, including the joke he delivered and people he ha performed with, and his first entry under Lucille Ball is an appearance with Hope in 1945 on a show called GI. Journal. I really can't remember many detail about it, said Hope, who pay tribute to his frequent co-star in an NBC special Saturday night. It's called Bob Hope's Love Affair With Lucille Ball. She died in April of this year. That first time together wa followed by four movie, frequent visit by Hope on I Love Lucy and regular appearance by Lucy on his television show. Lucy wa a very funny woman, Hope said. Even in private she could get off a great ad lib. But it's hard to compare her with other funny woman. It's like asking who's the best golfer. You have to go to the record. I don't think anyone ever had the success she had. She certainly hold the most record. A secretary dug the detail of that first joint appearance out of one of two vault where Hope keep everything pertaining to his long comic career. There are written record of all his show, copy of all the script, monologue and comic routine, audio tape of his radio show and thousand of other memento. GI. Journal wa on May 4, 1945. Hope's file reads: Spot: Lucille Ball . English play . For Charity Bazaar. Hope and Ball had actually known each other before they began working together. In fact, the late Desi Arnaz, her then husband, worked for Hope first. He said Ball asked him nearly 50 year ago to find a place on his popular radio show for band leader Arnaz. Stan Kenton wa leaving a my orchestra leader, Hope said. I gave Desi a spot on my show. We also gave him some line to speak. Every time he walked up to the microphone he dropped an enchilada. He could hardly talk, let alone get a laugh. When they started `I Love Lucy,' I said, `What's going on? This man is funny.' The night before she died I performed at the Music Center, he said. Lucy wa in the hospital and I saw her daughter, Lucie Arnaz, and said, `Isn't it wonderful she's doing better.' They called me the next day and said she had died. I said, `God ha her now, but we'll have her forever.' We'll be watching her performance for a long, long time. Bob Hope's Love Affair With Lucy will include clip from their movie and TV appearance, plus such guest star a Betty White, George Burns and Danny Thomas. I'm going through everything myself picking out the clip, Hope said. The last time she wa on my show wa my birthday show two year ago. We sang `I Remember It Well.' Our last time together in public wa at the Academy Awards in March. I think I'll do my tribute to her over a shot of that in the background. I think everyone remembers that. She wa on his radio show on May 27, 1947, at Detroit. The program note say, Lucille Ball: New York, clothes, car, picture. I could do a fashion show with her walking on stage, Hope said of the show clip he had been watching in preparing the special. She had great gown and hairdo. When she performed she would use different style. She'd change the way she read a line. She'd throw a line away one time, then she'd turn around and milk a line for laugh. Hope recalled his funny co-star in a sunny alcove in the living room of his Los Angeles home. It overlook the one-hole golf course in the back yard, and he wa attired in golfing clothes. Occasionally, he called his office in another building on the ground to check on a piece of information. Soon after the interview, he wa aboard a plane for a series of personal appearance around the country. Ball made 22 appearance on Hope's special and he wa on her show 10 or 12 time, he said. In their first movie, Sorrowful Jones in 1949, Hope played a racetrack bookie who's forced to become the foster father of a young girl whose real father wa killed by gangster in a racehorse fix. Ball wa a nightclub singer who help him look after the girl. It wa a remake of Little Miss Marker, which starred Shirley Temple in 1934. Next wa Fancy Pants in 1950, a remake of Ruggles of Red Gap. Ball played a rich rancher who acquires an English butler, played by Hope. Facts of Life wa in 1960, with Hope and Ball a married lover who have a tryst. Their last film wa Critic's Choice in 1963, in which Hope is a Broadway critic who ha to review a play written by his wife, played by Ball. Someone reminded me the other night of a bus tour we did of movie theater in New York to promote one our of picture, he said. I think it wa `Critic's Choice.' I found her very cooperative, very wonderful. We always had a lot of fun together. Lucille Ball, the daffy comedian whose harebrained scheme drove her television family crazy but delighted viewer for four decade, died Wednesday of a ruptured abdominal artery. She wa 77. The actress, star of the hugely popular I Love Lucy and related situation comedy seen in more than 80 country, had undergone major heart surgery April 18. She had been recovering steadily, getting out of bed and joking with the staff, but shortly before dawn Wednesday, she went into cardiac arrest due to internal bleeding and could not be revived, said Cedars-Sinai Medical Center spokesman Ronald Wise. She suffered a complete heart failure at 5 am. and 47 minute of resuscitation effort proved fruitless, Wise said. There wa nothing to indicate this would happen, Wise said. The heart itself apparently wa not involved in Miss Ball's sudden death. In the 6{-hour surgery at Cedars-Sinai, doctor replaced her aorta and aortic valve. Although the replaced portion of Miss Ball's aorta did not apparently fail, the entire artery wa in poor condition when she wa operated upon, said Dr. Robert Kass. Kass, who performed the operation, said at the time the tearing in Miss Ball's aorta progressed all the way down into her abdomen. Miss Ball, with her fire-engine red hair and siren wail, wa considered the queen of situation comedy and a pioneer of the sitcom format. I and 100 million others will miss her, said comedian George Burns. But we haven't lost Lucille Ball because she's still with u on television and we can see her on and on. Lucille Ball possessed the gift of laughter. But she also embodied an even greater treasure the gift of love, President Bush said in a statement. She appealed to the gentler impulse of the human spirit. She wa not merely an actress or comedienne. She wa Lucy and she wa loved. Her red hair, her antic on the screen, her timing and her zest for life made her an American institution, former President and Nancy Reagan said in a statement. Just the mention of her name brings a smile. . We love Lucy and will miss her deeply. It's a shock after working very closely with her and loving her for over 35 year, said Miss Ball's frequent sidekick, Gale Gordon, who wa in Edmonton, Alberta. While in the hospital, the comedian wa deluged with thousand of card, letter, flower and phone call from fan a far away a Australia and Europe. Miss Ball and her late former husband, Desi Arnaz, starred in I Love Lucy from 1951 to 1957 and have been seen since in widely syndicated rerun. The late Vivian Vance and William Frawley played their neighbor, Fred and Ethel Mertz. Her split-second timing, wide-mouthed wail and exaggerated pratfall made the I Love Lucy show one of the most popular in television history. Bridge club and bowling team changed their meeting night to watch Lucy and Ethel cook up still another ridiculous scheme that would push their long-suffering husband to exasperation. Miss Ball's real, onscreen pregnancy marked a milestone in television, and an estimated 44 million viewer more than for the inauguration of President Eisenhower tuned in on Jan. 19, 1953, to watch Lucy Ricardo have Little Ricky. The real birth occurred just four hour before the previously-filmed show wa broadcast. Miss Ball's singularity a a comedian wa matched by her talent a a show-business entrepreneur. She and Arnaz established one of TV's first major independent studio. Desilu, a their production company wa called, made some of the top comedy show of the 1950s and '60s, including December Bride, Our Miss Brooks and Make Room for Daddy. As testament to their value a prime-time star, Miss Ball and Arnaz signed an $8 million, no-cancellation, two-year contract with CBS in 1953 the largest in television history at the time and a figure scarcely any TV star can touch today. The couple stopped making weekly I Love Lucy show in 1957. Despite rich and two child, Lucie and Desi Jr., their marriage foundered, and the couple divorced in 1960. In 1961, Miss Ball married nightclub comic Gary Morton, who became her executive producer, and remained on TV for 12 more year in the weekly Here's Lucy and The Lucy Show. Miss Ball wa born Aug. 6, 1911, in Jamestown, N.Y., the daughter of an electrician and a concert pianist. Young Lucy, a brunette, wa dazzled by the stage, but her ambition were discouraged by an acting school They sent my mother a letter saying she wa wasting her money, Miss Ball once said and she turned to modeling under the name Diane Belmont. Her ad for Chesterfield cigarette caught Hollywood's eye, and in 1933 she went to California. As a blonde, she appeared with the Marx Brothers in Room Service, with Fred Astaire in Follow the Fleet and with Katharine Hepburn and Ginger Rogers in Stage Door. In all, she appeared in more than 75 movie. In 1940, her tress colored the fiery trademark red, Miss Ball met Arnaz, a rumba star. They married within six month. In 1951, when CBS decided to move her radio series, My Favorite Husband, to television, Miss Ball insisted that Arnaz be her co-star. But the network wasn't sure Arnaz would be a hit with the American public. The couple went on a nationwide vaudeville tour and proved audience would watch a leggy, blue-eyed comedian and a Cuban-born band leader with a heavy accent. They also produced their own pilot episode on borrowed money. CBS relented, and I Love Lucy wa an immediate success. The show revolutionized television sitcom production in the day before videotape. It wa filmed in advance before a live audience, employing three camera instead of the traditional one used for motion picture. The actress wa last seen at the 61st Academy Awards ceremony March 29, where the svelte actress received a standing ovation and laughed freely throughout her brief bit with Bob Hope. Her last series Life with Lucy, once again co-starring Gordon wa carried by ABC at the start of the 1986 season. But the show, her first series in 12 year, wa canceled after le than two month when it drew spectacularly low rating. She felt terrible. . It really devastated her, daughter Lucie Arnaz said at the time. Miss Ball also played a bag lady in the 1985 TV movie Stone Pillow, considered one of the most challenging role of her career. She wa hospitalized for dehydration when it wa over, but the movie wa a minor critical and rating success. Just this month, Miss Ball had signed a deal for a reported $750,000 with Putnam to publish her autobiography. Said CBS Chairman William Paley: Lucille Ball will always be the first lady of CBS. . Lucy's extraordinary ability to light up the screen and brighten our life is a legacy that will last forever. Funeral arrangement were pending. An outpouring of sympathy from president to childhood neighbor followed the death of Lucille Ball, but many said the queen mother of comedy will live on through television rerun and her influence on comedy. The daffy, redheaded comedian whose harebrained scheme drove her television family crazy and delighted viewer for four decade died Wednesday of a ruptured abdominal artery at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center. She wa 77 and died eight day after emergency heart surgery. A private burial wa planned, reportedly with no funeral service in accordance with Miss Ball's wish. God ha her now, and, thanks to television, we'll have her forever, said comedian and longtime friend Bob Hope. Hospital switchboard were swamped with condolence call and thousand of card after Miss Ball's death, spokesman Ron Wise said. Miss Ball's family requested that any flower sent to the Medical Center in her memory be distributed to other patient. Miss Ball maintained her sense of humor even when she wa critically ill. Following her operation last week, her first word to her daughter, Lucie, were: Wouldn't you know this is the day I wa going to get my hair done. Miss Ball had been improving steadily from the heart surgery, so her death came a a shock. She had been walking, her spirit were up. Her family wa with her, Wise said. She responded a well a anyone could respond to that kind of surgery. He said she woke up early Wednesday complaining about a sudden pain in her back, and in a matter of second went into a full cardiac arrest that wa caused by a ruptured aorta. Miss Ball and her late former husband, Desi Arnaz, starred in I Love Lucy from 1951 to 1957. In the ground-breaking show, still seen in syndication worldwide, the late Vivian Vance and William Frawley played their neighbor, Fred and Ethel Mertz. Probably a lot of what she did rubbed off on what I do, said actress-comedian Jane Curtin, star of the sitcom Kate and Allie. But it couldn't be helped, because I memorized her show. The show, one of the most popular in television history, wa distinguished by Miss Ball's faultless timing, rubber-faced expression, wide-mouthed wail and extravagant pratfall. Working with Lucy wa like receiving an MA. or a PhD. in comedy, recalled Joan Rivers. What she forgot about comic timing and delivery is more than most of u will ever learn in a lifetime. Comedian Whoopi Goldberg said: Lucy wa great because she represented every person. She showed u human foible and gave u a chance to laugh at ourselves. Miss Goldberg said her favorite episode involved a visit by the I Love Lucy character to Hollywood, where Lucy and Ethel spotted actor William Holden in a restaurant. That wa how we would all react to seeing a movie star in a restaurant, Miss Goldberg said. She wa looking at him in a compact mirror, and trying to look at him surreptitiously. And that's just an example of how everyone can identify with Lucy. Bob Rosati, who life down the street from the Beverly Hills home Miss Ball shared with husband Gary Morton, said he wa watching a rerun of I Love Lucy on Wednesday morning when the screen went black and the word In Memory of Lucille Ball, 1911-1989 appeared. I felt I had lost someone in my family. I couldn't believe it, said Rosati, 40. I wa watching Lucy like I do every morning. She's one of the most-admired lady in this town. He wa among a group of fan who stood reverently outside Miss Ball's home on Roxbury Drive a florist delivered basket of flower to the house. Tour van passed by in a non-stop procession. On Hollywood Boulevard's Walk of Fame, flower arrangement were placed on Miss Ball's two star one for her film work, one for television. Budd Friedman, owner of the Improvisation comedy club, said, The world of comedy ha lost it first lady. Her death is an irreparable loss . to our industry. Actor Danny DeVito recalled getting a personal congratulation from Miss Ball in 1981 when he won an Emmy for the TV series Taxi. It made it like it had been blessed, he recalled. Admirers included President Bush, in Southern California at the time of Miss Ball's passing, and former President Reagan. Her red hair, her antic on the screen, her timing and her zest for life made her an American institution, the former president and Nancy Reagan said in a statement. Just the mention of her name brings a smile. . We love Lucy and will miss her deeply. Lucille Ball possessed the gift of laughter, Bush said. But she also embodied an even greater treasure the gift of love. She appealed to the gentler impulse of the human spirit. She wa not merely an actress or comedienne. She wa Lucy and she wa loved. To baby boomer, a happy chunk of our childhood is missing, said Saturday Night Live comedian Victoria Jackson, who wa born two year after I Love Lucy went off the air a a regular series. She didn't make me laugh out loud, I remember, she just made me happy about life. Said comic Tim Conway: We're going to miss this lady, but not really, because she's still here. All those wonderful thing they did together . those wonderful TV show . are still available. Although Miss Ball hadn't visited her hometown of Jamestown, N.Y, since 1956 and had no family there, she had stayed in touch with friend. Irene Rosseti, who now life in Celoron, N.Y., said Miss Ball recently had sent her and her husband a letter on their 50th wedding anniversary. Even though she wa a big star, she wa still just Lucy to u, she recalled. Lucille Ball wa mourned Wednesday by the western New York hometown she left for Hollywood more than half a century ago. It is a sad day for all of u. But I'm sure that feeling is shared by many people around the world, said Nelson Garifi, organizer of a homecoming for Miss Ball that wa to have been held next month. She wa always so full of life, said Pauline Lopus, who went to school with Miss Ball and had kept in touch with her. It seemed like she would just go on forever. The 77-year-old comedian died of a ruptured aorta, the main heart artery, at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, where she wa recovering from emergency heart surgery last week. The American Heart Association's Jamestown office wa deluged with call from Miss Ball's fan who wanted to make a memorial donation, official said. We just can't process a many memorial a we've received, said office manager Nathan Lax. Miss Ball wa born Aug. 6, 1911, in this city of 40,000 people about 60 mile south of Buffalo, the daughter of an electrician and a concert pianist. She grew up in nearby Celoron, a rural hamlet on Chautauqua Lake. Friends said some of the characteristic of her most famous role the zany, excitable star of television's I Love Lucy were evident during her childhood. Mrs. Lopus said Miss Ball dreamed of fame, either a a dramatic actress in New York City or a a dancing girl in musical. At age 15, she worked a a barker at a local amusement park, screaming pitch for popcorn and hot dog until she lost her voice. In high school, she starred in high school play and made her first appearance before a large audience at the now-defunct Palace Theater here. As a model, she caught Hollywood's eye and in 1933, she wa off to Hollywood. Although the comedian hadn't visited Jamestown since 1956 and had no family there, she regularly donated money to charity, civic event and Jamestown Community College, said Mayor Steven Carlson. Miss Ball wa to have received an honorary degree from the college at the homecoming scheduled for May 20. Residents had hung poster saying Jamestown Loves Lucy in storefront and house window. After she fell ill last week, resident signed the poster and sent them to her a a get-well greeting. They sent more than 150 poster with 10,000 signature. The honorary degree will be awarded posthumously, said Garifi, who is community relation director at the college. Celoron had planned to rename a street in Miss Ball's honor during her visit, and still plan to rename it a Lucy Lane, said John Goodell of Celoron's Historical Society. Goodell said that when the group wa formed about a year ago, We sent an invitation to Lucille Ball to be a member, and she sent back a check for $500 for a life membership. Actor Gale Gordon, a sidekick of Lucille Ball from radio day who appeared with her in three television series, recalled on Wednesday how the comedian never thought of herself a particularly funny. Oh, but when she told a story or recalled an event that happened she always illustrated it with her body and her face, the 83-year-old Gordon said in a telephone interview. She never saw it, but she wa extremely amusing. Gordon, who is appearing in a play in Edmonton, spent the day in an Edmonton hotel room, mourning the death of Lucille Ball in a Los Angeles hospital Wednesday at age 77 and quietly remembering his funny friend. The world will miss her greatly, the actor said. I personally will remember her a the best talent of her kind in the world . a wonderful, warm friend and a bit of a genius the only one I've ever really known. In his first television series alongside Miss Ball, Gordon wa the flustered banker Mr. Mooney in The Lucy Show from 1962-68. The next six year saw him a Harrison Carter on Here's Lucy. They were reunited briefly in 1986 for the short-lived Life With Lucy. Gordon first met Miss Ball in 1947 on the radio program My Favorite Husband, which later became I Love Lucy on television. I thought she wa a very good-looking young woman, and very talented, he recalled. She wa very pleasant to work with. None of u knew what wa going to happen television wa very young then and it wasn't taken too seriously. We never dreamed it would ever become the power it wa . and the great star it would produce. Gordon last spoke to Miss Ball from Edmonton on his birthday, Feb. 20, when she called to wish me a happy birthday a she ha done for year and year. Gordon ha done regular stint for year at a chain of Edmonton-based dinner theatre called Stage West. He is currently appearing with that company's Mayfair Dinner Theatre a a priest in the play Mass Appeal. The play ha another month to run and Gordon say that mean he won't be able to attend Miss Ball's funeral. I couldn't do that because it would put people out of work, he said. She would be the first one to scream her head off if I did that. Here are highlight of Lucille Ball's career: 1911 Born Aug. 6, 1911, in Jamestown N.Y., the daughter of an electrician and concert pianist Desiree Ball. 1926 Begins career in show business in New York a a chorus girl. 1933 Goes to Hollywood a movie showgirl for RKO, later becoming a successful actress appearing in more than 75 film. 1940 Marries Desi Arnaz, a Cuban percussionist and bandleader when both were making the movie Too Many Girls. 1951 They form Desilu Productions with $5,000 and I Love Lucy begin it historic six-year domination of television comedy. Earlier in the year, they have their first child. 1953 I Love Lucy episode in which Lucy Ricardo give birth to Little Ricky is telecast the same day that Lucille Ball, in real life, give birth to second child, Desi Jr. 1957 Desilu purchase RKO studio and begin producing other program. 1960 The Arnazes divorce, with Desi selling his share of the studio to Lucy for $3 million. 1961 Miss Ball marries night-club comic Gary Morton, who becomes her executive producer. 1962 Miss Ball go solo, returning to the airwave in The Lucy Show. 1967 Miss Ball sell company to Gulf & Western for $18 million. 1968 The Lucy Show is redesigned and becomes Here's Lucy. It run until 1974. 1974
column5: Lucille Ball, TV's comic genius, had major impact on the industry
column6: Lucille Ball, who died in April 1989 at the age of 77 starred along with her husband Desi Arnaz in perhaps the finest television series, "I Love Lucy". Together they founded Desilu Productions, which eventually took over RKO and produced very popular television shows.  Expressions of sympathy poured in from all over the country.
column7: Lucille Ball, who died in April 1989 at the age of 77, will long be remembered.  She made her craft look easy, spontaneous and unrehearsed.  The result was the durable and probably the finest series in television, "I Love Lucy".  She starred in the show along with her husband Desi Arnaz, and together they founded Desilu Productions, which eventually took over RKO Studios and television and produced many popular television shows.  The couple had two children and divorced in 1960.  Condolences poured in form all over the country in which she was credited with helping to establish television as the nation's leading entertainment industry.
column8: Lucille Ball, who died in April 1989 at the age of 77, will long beremembered.  She made her craft look easy, spontaneous andunrehearsed.  The result was the durable and probably the finestseries in television history, "I Love Lucy".  She starred with herhusband, Desi Arnaz, in the '50s show and together they founded DesiluProductions, which eventually took over RKO Studios.  She was anastute businesswoman as well as a talented entertainer and Desiluproduced some of the most popular programs of the '50s and '60s. Balland Arnaz divorced in 1960.  They had two children.  At her deaththere was an outpouring of sympathy from the very famous to thousandsof her ordinary fans.  She was particularly remembered in her hometownof Jamestown New York where she had contributed to local charities,civic events and Jamestown Community College.  Following the breakupof her first marriage, she married Gary Morton, her husband at herdeath.  Miss Ball had a successful career before television, starringin 75 films.  She died in Los Angeles, following emergency heartsurgery.  William Paley, Chairman of CBS said that she helped toestablish television as the nation's leading entertainment industryand that her legacy would last forever.
column9: Everyone loved Lucille Ball, the queen of television comedy.
column10: When Lucille Ball died at 77, fans from presidents to neighbors to co-stars to critics paid tributes to her life, person and comedic skills.  Although she was a chorus girl, model, movie star, and television entrepreneur, she is best remembered for "I Love Lucy," a 1950's show that revolutionized television comedy.
column11: The Queen of TV comedy and entrepreneur, Lucille Ball, died on April 26, 1989 at 77.  Presidents, comedians and actors, neighbors, residents of her hometown, television critics, surviving co-stars, and just plain fans paid tributes to her.  More than 2,000 attended three memorial services.  She was a chorus girl, model, and in 75 movies, but is best remembered for her physical and verbal comedy and superb timing evident on television.  She and her husband, Desi Arnaz, revolutionized television comedy with "I Love Lucy," which was filmed before a live audience, becoming a rerun gold mine, still seen world-wide.
column12: The Queen of TV comedy, Lucille Ball, died on April 26, 1989, from a ruptured abdominal aorta.  President Bush, former President Reagan, the president of CBS, American comedians and actors, neighbors, residents of her hometown, television critics, and just plain fans paid tributes to her.  Her burial was private, but more than 2,000 attended three memorial services held on May 8.  Bob Hope, a frequent co-star and friend, created a TV special in her honor.  Two of her surviving TV co-stars, Gail Gordon and Keith Thibodeaux, remembered her fondly.  She is best remembered for her physical and verbal comedy and superb timing.  She was born in 1911 in Jamestown, N.Y., and, after staring in high school plays, became a model and chorus girl, moving in 1933 to Hollywood.  There, she was in over 75 movies, usually playing the second banana.  In 1940 she married Desi Arnaz, and together they revolutionized television comedy with "I Love Lucy" which started in 1951.  Filmed with three cameras before a live audience, it became a rerun gold mine and has been seen in 80 countries.  After her divorce, she remarried and continued to be a successful television entrepreneur and star of television and screen.

column3: Hitting Baghdad where it hurt, more country have joined a U.N.-sanctioned boycott of oil from Iraq and Kuwait. On Tuesday, country ranging from powerful Japan to neutral Switzerland to tiny Cyprus cut off petroleum import in an effort to convince the Baghdad government to withdraw it troop that invaded Kuwait on Thursday. Turkey announced it wa shut down the twin Iraqi oil pipeline that run through it to the Mediterranean carrying half of Baghdad's crude output and cutting off trade with Iraq. Baghdad's only other major pipeline exporting crude run through Saudi Arabia, where the flow ha been drastically reduced. The UN. Security Council on Monday voted to impose broad economic sanction against Iraq for invading small oil-rich Kuwait. The measure forbids loan to Iraq or Kuwait and prohibits any activity, including the transfer of money, that would help the two country export their good. Sanctions adopted by the European Economic Community on Saturday froze Iraqi asset and suspended the purchase of oil from the two Arab country. More than 90 percent of import from Iraq to the 12-nation EEC are petroleum product. The EEC also suspended arm sale to Iraq. Switzerland, which is not a member of the United Nations, made the unusual move Tuesday of joining the UN. sanction and banned all trade with Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. In addition, Switzerland prohibited all payment and other financial transfer to Iraq and Kuwait. Denmark, Norway and Sweden also announced embargo on all trade with both country. Japan's participation in the UN. sanction wa seen a especially key since Tokyo usually ha taken a low profile in the Middle East, which supply much of it petroleum need. Japan import 99 percent of it oil. China joined the UN. decision to embargo arm sale to Iraq, but ha been le vocal than other major country in condemning the invasion. China sold arm to both Iran and Iraq during their eight-year war and is a major Iraqi trade partner. Cyprus' sacrifice in joining the embargo wa to give up 70 percent of it oil import, government spokesman Akis Fantis said. Cyprus ha sufficient oil supply to last until the end of August, he said, but we are already in the process of taking step to secure alternative source . The worldwide closing of rank against Iraqi oil import is likely to lead to even higher petroleum price, which have already risen dramatically since the invasion and could have a major impact on the world economy. Wholesale oil price soared to five-year high in New York on Monday. France will introduce control Thursday on price of petroleum product to prevent refiner from using Iraq's invasion of Kuwait a an excuse to raise price, acting Premier Pierre Beregovoy announced Tuesday. An official with the Petroleum Association of Japan said he wa unaware of any increase yet in the price of gasoline for consumer. The official, who refused to be further identified, said it would be at least three month before the sanction could be expected to force higher gas price in Japan. An Iraqi airway jet carrying 78 foreigner and a number of Iraqi citizen arrived today, the first commercial flight allowed out of Iraq since it invaded Kuwait, a Japanese Embassy spokesman said. The mostly Japanese tourist arrived at Amman airport at 6:15 pm. (11:15 am. EDT) along with 34 member of an Iraqi football team, said the spokesman on condition of anonymity. It wa not immediately known if there were Americans on board. He said that the plane wa due to leave Amman for an undisclosed destination. The spokesman said the plane wa supposed to land in Vienna, but it wa denied landing right. The UN. Security Council on Monday voted economic sanction that ban all trade and military tie with Iraq. Jordan's information minister, Ibrahim Izzedine, said earlier today that the US. government had asked Jordan to facilitate the entrance from Iraq of American diplomat and their dependent. Izzedine said the request wa made through the US. Embassy in Amman. Thousands of Westerners have been stranded in Kuwait and Iraq since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Thursday. They include more than 350 who were on a British Airways flight that wa caught in the unrest in Kuwait. A British Airways spokeswoman said today a substantial number of those passenger arrived safely in Baghdad on Monday. Among the passenger were 28 Americans, who also turned up in a Baghdad hotel and appear to be fine, a US. official said in Washington. In addition, a Kuwaiti businessman said about 1,000 people a day were fleeing Kuwait through the desert to Saudi Arabia. The businessman, who arrived in London on a British Airways flight from Bahrain today, said Kuwaitis and expatriate, including Westerners, were joining convoy to escape the Iraqi force. Jordan's border with Iraq had been closed from the Iraqi side since Thursday morning, when Iraq invaded Kuwait. The provisional government of free Kuwait set up by Iraq had threatened Sunday to hold hostage citizen of country imposing sanction on it. A US. diplomat said Washington had instructed American citizen living in or visiting Iraq and Kuwait to leave when circumstance permit. Here are some quote on Iraq's invasion of Kuwait: Here is a brief chronology in the dispute between Iraq and Kuwait over oil production and their common border. July 17 Iraqi President Saddam Hussein accuses Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates of flooding the oil market and driving price down, and that the move cost Iraq $14 billion in lost oil revenue. He further charge that Arab state in the Persian Gulf are conspiring with the United States and Israel to weaken Iraq's economy and undermine it military buildup. July 18 Iraq accuses Kuwait of stealing $2.4 billion worth of oil from well along the disputed border with Iraq and of seeking to wreck Iraq's economy by overproducing oil and thus pushing down price. July 20 Kuwaiti official suggest Iraq's sudden outburst of belligerence is aimed at getting it creditor including Kuwait to write off billion of dollar in debt from the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. July 24 The US. Defense Department announces that US. Navy warship and aircraft are holding a short-notice exercise in the Persian Gulf with the United Arab Emirates, about 600 mile southeast of the Kuwait-Iraqi border. Kuwait reinstates a state of alert it declared July 16 and canceled after three day of tension between the two oil-producing country. July 25 The Iraqi government in Baghdad say that it will not be intimidated by US. pressure in it oil dispute with neighboring Kuwait, and Saddams summons the US. ambassador for talk. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt say Iraq and Kuwait plan to meet in Saudi Arabia in an effort to resolve their dispute. July 26 OPEC minister in Geneva agree to halt overproduction in hope of pushing up the price of crude oil. Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates pledge to abide by the agreement. Analysts say Saddam clearly influenced the outcome of the meeting. July 31 Kuwaiti and Iraqi delegation meet in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, to negotiate the oil and border dispute. Diplomats say Iraq ha massed 100,000 troop on Kuwait's border, more than triple the number originally estimated. That number dwarf the Kuwaiti army, which ha a total of about 20,000 troop. Aug. 1 Iraq pull out of talk on the 2-week-old border, oil and money dispute with Kuwait shortly before it sends it force to invade the oil-rich sheikdom. Aug. 2 Iraq's powerful army overrun Kuwait before dawn with tank-led troop quickly seized the ruler's palace and other government building. THE INVASION: Iraq's troop, led by about 350 tank, crossed the border at dawn Thursday, and seized the Kuwaiti palace and government building 40 mile away. Early Friday, the invader controlled Kuwait city, the capital. The soldier were also making sweep through the southern oilfield, according to resident and Lloyds' insurance service in London. Diplomatic source estimate more than 200 Kuwaitis were killed or wounded, mainly from the Emiri Guard which bore the main brunt of the invasion. Kuwait's Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah fled to safety in Saudi Arabia. THE FORCES: Iraq, a country of more than 17 million, ha the Arab world's most battle-trained army, and had massed more than 100,000 soldier on the Kuwaiti border. Kuwait, an oil-rich city-state, ha 1.9 million resident 60 percent foreigner and an army of 20,300 soldier. CAUSE OF CONFLICT: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq accused Kuwait of stealing oil from it territory and forcing down oil price through overproduction. Kuwait and UN. diplomat dismissed Iraq's claim that it invaded at the request of Kuwaiti revolutionary. REACTION: The UN. Security Council voted 14-0 to condemn the invasion. President Bush denounced it a naked agression. He froze Iraq's asset in the United States and blocked almost all Iraqi import, including oil. The order also froze Kuwait property under US. jurisdiction a move intended to keep Iraq from seizing it. The Soviets also condemned the invasion and stopped arm sale to Iraq. Kuwait's US. ambassador said the nation had asked for American military intervention. A Pentagon source said a US. naval group wa diverted toward the Persian Gulf. Oil price soared in frenzied trading amid fear the invasion would reduce the supply of oil. Iranian editorial writer are rejoicing now that the world is waking up to one of their most hated bogeymen: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. A Monday headline: We warned you Frankenstein would torment his own creator. Saddam attacked Iran in September 1980 after a series of border skirmish, spawning a war that dragged until an August 1988 cease-fire. The conflict ha still not formally ended. Iran's late fundamentalist patriarch, the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, vowed for year to unseat Saddam. Never at a loss for a vivid phrase, he compared accepting the cease-fire with Saddam to drinking poison. The status of Great Satan wa reserved for the United States, the all-encompassing public enemy No. 1 for the Islamic Republic. Iran frequently accuses both the US. and Saddam of trying to undermine the Islamic revolution. Saddam conveniently boast of having alone staunched the tide of radical Islam. In fact one of his reason for invading Kuwait on Thursday, the Iraqi press noted, wa it gall in demanding back ten of billion of dollar loaned to Iraq during the war Saddam say he fought for all Arabs. Over the past six month, successful U.N.-sponsored effort toward face-to-face negotiation between Iraq and Iran robbed Iranian newspaper and television commentator of a favorite target. Saddam's overthrow of the emir of Kuwait changed all that. Old score came brimming to the surface. Kuwait, after all, reflagged tanker in the United States during the Iran-Iraq war, ushering in the reason for the arrival of the US. Navy in the Persian Gulf in force. Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency printed excerpt Mondya of an editorial from the Ettela'at newspaper that wa headlined: Foster child turn rapaciously on nourisher Kuwait. It noted that Kuwait had blindly supported Iraq, little knowing that it wa feeding a wild beast in her own neighborhood. Saddam ha also been called generalissimo and The Invader. Under the Frankenstein headline, IRNA said in it own commentary: For the time being, tiny Kuwait . breathes no more. With it sheikh a stateless person, and it powerful dinar which bankrolled the Iraqi military mere garbage, Kuwait is a nonentity, swallowed up by the dangerous pet it reared. Despite all the attention to the dangerous pet, the Great Satan ha not been forgotton. According to Iran's pundit, the Great Satan planned it all. It wanted to get the Navy back in the Persian Gulf.
column5: Iraq invaded Kuwait August 1990. US sent navy, world imposed sanctions.
column6: On August 2nd, 1990, Iraq invaded Kuwait with 100,000 troops, destroying government  installations and killing 200. Saddam Hussain, claiming invitation by revolutionaries, accused Kuwait of driving down oil prices and stealing Iraqi oil. The US sent naval forces to the Persian Gulf. The US, UN, and EEC imposed economic and military sanctions. Oil prices soared.
column7: On August 2nd, 1990, Iraq occupied Kuwait with 100,000 troops, destroying government buildings and installations, killing 200, and replacing fleeing Kuwaitis with Iraqis. Saddam Hussain accused Kuwait of overproducing to drive down oil prices and stealing oil from Iraqi border wells. Iraq claimed it invaded at revolutionaries' request. Kuwait said Iraq invaded because Kuwait pressed for war loan repayment. Kuwait appealed for US and UN help. Bush pledged to defend its Persian Gulf interests and sent a naval group. The US, UN, and EEC imposed widely-supported trade and military sanctions against Iraq and Kuwait. Iraq threatened to hold citizens of sanction-imposing countries hostage. Oil prices soared.
column8: On August 2nd, 1990, 100,000 Iraqi troops massing on Kuwait's border crossed over, occupying the country and destroying all government buildings and installations except for the water system and oil equipment. Over 200 Kuwaitis were killed or wounded. Iraq facilitated residents' departures then trucked in Iraqis to replace Kuwaitis and change the population's make-up. Thousands fled to Saudi Arabia, including the leadership. Jordan also took in refugees.Saddam Hussain accused Kuwait of exceeding OPEC production quotas to drive down prices, and stealing oil from Iraqi border wells. Iraq claimed it invaded at the request of Kuwaiti revolutionaries who staged a coup, which Kuwait denied. Kuwait said Iraq invaded because it demanded Iraq pay back billions loaned during the 1980-1988 Iran-Iraq War. Iran rejoiced that the world was waking up to Saddam Hussein.  Kuwait appealed for US and UN help. Bush said the US would take any action necessary to defend its Persian Gulf interests and diverted a naval group to the Gulf. The US, UN, and EEC imposed trade and military sanctions against Iraq and Kuwait, supported widely by other countries. The Soviets and China stopped Iraqi arms sales. Iraq rounded up Westerners in Kuwait and threatened to hold hostage citizens of countries imposing sanctions. Oil prices hit five-year highs.
column9: Iraq invades and occupies Kuwait, bringing worldwide anger and sanctions.
column10: With little warning, Iraq invaded tiny Kuwait on August 2, quickly taking the country.  Many fled as Iraq began rounding up foreign nationals, flying some to Jordan.  Reactions to the invasion have been strong.  The United Nations' trade and military sanctions are being honored.  Oil prices are soaring.
column11: After two weeks of accusations and maneuvering, Iraq invaded tiny Kuwait on August 2 with 100,000 battle-trained troops, quickly taking the country.  While the Kuwaiti emir and refugees fled to Saudi Arabia, Iraq began rounding up foreign nationals and repopulating the nation with Iraqi citizens.  Some foreigners were taken to Iraq, while some were flown to Jordan.  Reactions to the invasion have been strong. The United Nations Security Council unanimously passed trade and military sanctions and President Bush said he would defend U.S. interests.  Iran rejoiced.  Most nations are strongly enforcing these sanctions as oil prices soar and Iraq begins defensive preparations.
column12: The Iraqi occupation of Kuwait began on August 2 when masses of combat-experienced troops poured across the border, quickly taking the country.  The Kuwait emir fled to Saudi Arabia.  The dispute began in mid-July when Iraq, a nation with 17 million, accused tiny Kuwait of stealing oil and flooding the market.  As Iraqi troops mobilized, efforts to avoid a confrontation failed.  While Iraqi said it invaded at the request of Kuwaiti revolutionaries, a Kuwaiti spokesman called this a false pretext.  President Bush said he would defend U.S. interests in the Persian Gulf.  Iran, which fought an 8-year war with Iraq, rejoiced that the world saw the "Frankenstein" created by the United States and Kuwait.  The United Nations Security Council unanimously passed trade and military sanctions against Iraq and Kuwait.  Most nations strongly enforced these sanctions, as oil prices soared.Iraq rounded-up foreign nationals in Kuwait, including passengers of a British airliner, and took many to Iraq.  An Iraqi jet finally brought some to Jordan on August 7.  Refugees poured into Saudi Arabia.  Some reported that Iraqis were moving in and being given Kuwaiti identities.  Iraq began evacuation drills and warned of U.S. or Israeli actions.

column3: Iran is deliberately underreporting the number of casualty from Thursday's massive earthquake out of fear of a political backlash, leader of a group seeking to overthrow the country's Islamic leadership say. The regime is very much fearful of public outrage, said Shahin Gobadi, spokesman for the People's Mojahedin of Iran. They're very much afraid of the political aftershock. As Gobadi spoke Friday, member of the organization denounced Iran's government at a noisy rally held in a park across the street from the White House. Northern Iran wa stuck Thursday by an earthquake measuring between 7.3 and 7.7 on the Richter Scale. Iran ha told the United Nations that the death toll is at least 36000, but Gobadi said his organization ha received estimate closer to 100,000. Gobadi said the country cannot properly assist earthquake victim because it treasury ha been spent in a war with neighboring Iraq and against internal opposition. They have been very late in assisting the people, he said. Sympathy for the earthquake victim wa a secondary issue for the chanting, flag-waving rally participant, who also carried sign criticizing their native country. Planning for the event began three week before the earthquake, but part of the Friday's activity focused on Iran's stricken resident. Gobadi said shoddy housing in which the government forced people to live wa the cause for the widespread loss of life. This regime ha brought them nothing but devastation and misery. This regime ha devoted all of it resource to a senseless war with Iraq and to oppression of the people at home, he said. A U.N.-sponsored cease-fire wa declared last year after eight year of the Iran-Iraq war. Iran's Islamic republic wa established in 1979 after Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi wa deposed by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and militant seized the US. Embassy in Tehran, taking 66 Americans hostage. The United States broke diplomatic relation with Iran in April 1980. The shah died in exile in July 1980, US. hostage were freed six month later and Khomeini died last June. Gobadi said his 25-year-old group had helped depose the shah but had no part in organizing the Islamic republic. Even in this tragedy for which we grieve we cannot trust the regime in Iran, Rep. Mervyn Dymally, D-Calif., told an estimated 3,000 people attending the rally. There were many, many victim before this tragedy and there are victim now whose need need to be addressed by the people of the United States, he said. Dymally, a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, praised President Bush's offer of humanitarian aid to Iran but said Bush must make sure the assistance is channeled through non-government group. The State Department said Friday that Iran wa willing to accept earthquake relief from the American Red Cross and other US. humanitarian organization. An anti-American newspaper in Iran said Sunday the United States is partly to blame for the death of ten of thousand of people in last week's earthquake. The criminal role of America in Iran's past became evident once again in the recent earthquake, the Jomhuri Islami said in an editorial reported by the official Islamic Republic News Agency. Our people, even under the rubble, chant `Death to America' and pray to God to cut off the hand of the United States . even those hand stretched out to help, it said. It argued that by plundering Iran's oil and other resource for 25 year, the United States had prevented the use of even a small part of the national wealth for urban development project and advanced (anti-seismic) building construction system. Even after it expulsion from Iran, the US. government by imposing economic sanction and launching several other plot, halted the renovation of the country, the editorial added. The newspaper wa implying that with these action the United States had blocked the diversion of fund to earthquake safety measure. If the United States ha real humanitarian objective and intended to help the Iranian nation, it should do only one thing, stop hatching plot, the newspaper said. It called on Iranians to reject relief offer by the United States and other government whose hand are stained with the blood of the Iranian people. Iran, at odds with the United States since the 1979 seizure of hostage at the US. Embassy in Tehran, ha said it would welcome relief from the American Red Cross and other US. humanitarian group. The two nation have no diplomatic tie. Countries worldwide, both friendly and hostile to Tehran's Islamic government, sent supply, medical personnel and condolence to Iran, where about 40,000 people have died in an earthquake. Iran's deadliest earthquake since 1976 jolted the northern part of the country Thursday, devastating town and injuring at least 100,000 people. The United States sent a message of condolence and expressed it willingness to provide humanitarian aid. Iran, which ha had no diplomatic tie with the United States since the 1979 seizure of hostage at the US. Embassy in Tehran, said it would welcome relief from the American Red Cross and other US. humanitarian group. Moderate Arab country with which Iran ha had prickly relation Egypt, Saudi Arabia and Jordan also offered their support. An official statement distributed late Friday by the Saudi Press Agency said the kingdom followed with deep sorrow the news of the tragedy. The kingdom of Saudi Arabia . declares it readiness to help in extending assistance to those harmed by the tragedy, wishing to help ease the pain of the afflicted from among the son of the Iranian Moslem nation, it said. Jordan announced Saturday it wa sending medical aid to Iran, but detail were not immediately clear. King Hussein sent condolence to Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani on Friday in what is believed to be the first direct contact between Jordanian and Iranian head of state in almost a decade. Jordan backed Iraq in the eight-year Iran-Iraq war, which ended with a cease-fire in August 1988, and at one point sent hundred of Jordanian volunteer to fight alongside Iraqi soldier. Egypt wa sending two military plane with supply, the Middle East News Agency reported. President Hosni Mubarak offered the aid in the framework of Egypt's concern to provide help for brother and friend, especially at time of natural disaster. The official Soviet news agency Tass reported that a professional lifesaving team from the Armenian capital of Yerevan flew Saturday to Iran. The team gained experience in the devastating 1988 earthquake in Armenia that killed 25,000 people. Thousands of resident in the predominantly Moslem Soviet republic of Azerbaijan, which border Iran, donated ton of flour, rice and tea, and contributed more than $500,000 to a special earthquake fund, Tass said. The Italian Red Cross sent a plane to Iran Saturday with relief supply, including tent, blanket and medicine. In Paris, the French government, which already ha sent a 200-member civil defense team including rescuer, medical personnel and search dog said Saturday it would send an entire mobile hospital unit if Iran wanted it. In West Germany, the Foreign Ministry said that it wa sending tent, blanket, hospital equipment and cooking equipment to Iran. Eight ton wa being shipped Saturday and the government ha chartered a jumbo jet to transport 100 ton of equipment Monday. At the Vatican, Pope John Paul II sent aid to earthquake victim and a message of condolence to Iranian leader. The Vatican said in a statement that the donation of an unspecified amount wa to provide for the most immediate need of the population hurt by this huge earthquake. John Paul also sent a telegram to the papal nuncio, or diplomatic representative, in Tehran saying the pope is praying fervently for the wounded and the family of the victim. The Indian government said it would donate medicine, blanket and other relief supply worth more than $500,000. China's Red Cross said it wa sending $106,000 worth of relief supply, state-run television said Saturday. The Polish government wa sending 5 ton of powdered milk, a ton of bed sheet, a ton of medicine and 3 ton of blanket and clothing, according to Polish medium report. Malaysia wa providing more than $90,000 in relief aid. Foreign Ministry Secretary-General Ahmad Kamil Jaafar told reporter Saturday the money would be used to buy medicine, food, powdered milk, tent and other essential item. The earthquake that struck northern Iran brought reminder of another quake that devastated Soviet Armenia in 1988. Like Thursday's earthquake in Iran, the Dec. 7, 1988, earthquake in Armenia killed about 25,000 people. Most died in structure that collapsed when the quake hit. It's very similar to what we had in Armenia, said Russ Needham, a geophysicist with the US. Geological Survey. The Armenian quake wa measured at 6.9 on the Richter scale, but Thursday's earthquake shook the earth with a magnitude of 7.7 according to the US. Geological Survey. In the Iranian quake, the casualty count wa pushed up by the fact that people were indoors and asleep at the time, just after midnight. Many of the victim lived in fragile home built of a ceramic-type brick or adobe that collapse easily. In the Armenian quake, a Soviet parliamentary report later blamed the high number of fatality on shoddily built building. Most casualty from earthquake are caused by something falling on top of you, said Needham in a telephone interview from Golden, Colo. The quake struck an area of Iran where most of the building are built on a flood plain of loosely deposited soil that shift in an earthquake and allows structure to collapse, Needham said. The 7.7-magnitude quake wa the largest ever recorded in that area, where two major plate of the earth's crust meet, he said. Iran is in a very active seismic region, he said, and that there have been many smaller quake. Twelve earthquake greater than magnitude 7 have occurred in Iran during the last 30 year, Needham said. A quake of magnitude 7 is considered a major earthquake, capable of widespread, heavy damage in populated area. The earthquake that devastated Iran early Thursday took ten of thousand of life because people were asleep in fragile home built on flood plain, an earthquake expert said. Most casualty from earthquake are caused by something falling on top of you, said Russ Needham, a geophysist with the US. Geological Survey that monitor ground motion around the world. The quake hit at 12:30 am. in Iran, when most of the people were in their home, Needham said Thursday in a telephone interview from Golden, Colo. At least 25,000 people died and thousand were injured in the quake, which demolished score of village and buried thousand of people in the rubble of their home, Iranian official said. Needham said most structure in that area are built of a ceramic-type brick or adobe that collapse easily. It's very similar to what we had in Armenia, he said of the Dec. 7, 1988, earthquake that killed about 25,000 people. A Soviet parliamentary report later blamed the high number of fatality on shoddily built building. The Armenian quake wa measured at 6.9 on the Richter scale, but Thursday's earthquake shook the earth with a magnitude of 77. The shock wave traveled through the mountainous section of coastal Iran where most of the building are built on a flood plain of loosely deposited soil that shift in an earthquake and allows structure to collapse, he said. The 7.7-magnitude quake wa the largest ever recorded in that area, where two major plate of the earth's crust meet, Needhams said. Iran is in a very active seismic region, he said, and that there have been many smaller quake. Twelve earthquake greater than magnitude 7 have occurred in Iran during the last 30 year, Needhams said. A quake of magnitude 7 is considered a major earthquake, capable of widespread, heavy damage in populated area. The estimated 50,000 dead in the Iran earthquake make it the world's fourth deadliest quake in the past half-century. Here is a list of the major quake of the past 50 year. The location is followed by the Richter scale magnitude and the number of dead. Iran, June 21, 1990, 7.3 to 7.7 on the Richter scale, 50,000 dead (estimated). Soviet Armenia, Dec. 7, 1988, 6.9, 25,000. Iran, Sept. 16, 1978, 7.7, 25,000. China, July 28, 1976, 8.2, 200,000 officially, 800,000 unofficially. Guatemala, Feb. 4, 1976, 7.5, 22,778. Peru, May 31, 1970, 7.7, 66,794. Iran, Aug. 31, 1968, 7.4, 12,000. Iran, Sept. 1, 1962, 7.1, 12,230. Morocco, Feb. 29, 1960, 5.8, 12,000. Soviet Turkmenia, Oct. 5, 1948, (no Richter reading available), 110,000.
column5: Worldwide Response to Devastating Iranian Earthquake
column6: The Iranian earthquake of June 21, 1990 which killed at least 50,000 and left 400,00 homeless elicited an outpouring of aid from around the world, both from countries friendly and from those hostile to Iran's Islamic government. The assistance from the United States was such since the hostage crisis of 1979-80.
column7: An earthquake of magnitude 7.7 hit northwestern Iran on June 21, 1990 killing at least 50,000 people and leaving 400,000 homeless. The quake occurred when most people were inside asleep and hit a coastal floodplain where loosely deposited soil shifts easily and caused the fragile adobe homes in the area to collapse. The Iranian president appealed for international aid and the response was overwhelming, both from countries friendly to Iran's Islamic government and from those hostile. Assistance from the United States was the first such since the hostage crisis of 1979-80. Their respective critics blamed the U.S. and Iranian governments for the high death toll.
column8: An earthquake hit northwestern Iran on June 21, 1990 killing at least 50,000 people and leaving 400,000 homeless. The death toll made this the fourth deadliest earthquake worldwide in fifty years. The quake measured 7.7 on the Richter scale and exacted particularly heavy casualties since it occurred when most people were inside asleep and hit a coastal area of loosely deposited soil that shifts, causing the adobe homes in the area to collapse. The Iranian President appealed for international aid from all countries except Israel and South Africa. Countries around the world, both friendly and hostile to Iran's Islamic government, responded quickly. The aid from the United States, including funds and supplies raised by Iranians in California , was channeled through the Red Cross and Red Crescent. This was a rare example of U.S.-Iranian cooperation after the hostage crisis of 1979-80. Countries as diverse as Egypt, China, India, Malaysia and the Soviet Union sent help. Even Salman Rushdie, the Indian-born author of "Satanic Verses," condemned to death by the Iranian ayatollahs, contributed $8,600. All was not sweetness and light, however. In Iran an anti-American newspaper blamed the high death toll on the United States and in Washington Iranian opposition leaders blamed it on the Iranian government.
column9: Devastating earthquake kills up to 55,000 in mountainous northern Iran.
column10: An earthquake in northern Iran Thursday morning killed as many as 55,000 and injured thousands more. The earthquake measured between 7.3 and 7.7 on the Richter scale and is the largest ever recorded in that area. The U.S. will provide aid through the American Red Cross and other U.S. agencies.
column11: The mountainous area of northern Iran was rocked by an earthquake measuring between 7.3 and 7.7 on the Richter scale early Thursday morning. Killing as many as 55,000 people and injuring thousands of others, the earthquake occurred as most people were asleep. The United States will be providing $300,000 in supplies through the American Red Cross and other U.S. agencies. Iran, which broke diplomatic ties with the U.S. in 1979, has welcomed the aid. Russia has begun to airlift supplies into the area and is sending a rescue team from Soviet Armenia, the site of a devastating 1988 earthquake.
column12: An earthquake measuring between 7.3 and 7.7 on the Richter scale struck northern Iran shortly after midnight on Thursday, killing as many as 55,000 people and injuring 10's of thousands more. The earthquake, which occurred in the mountainous area along Iran's coast, was the worst ever recorded in that area. Humanitarian aid began to pour into the area as the Soviet Union sent a professional life saving team from Soviet Armenia, the sight of a devastating earthquake in 1988. Although the United States broke diplomatic ties with Iran in 1979, Washington was arranging to provide humanitarian relief through the American Red Cross and other U.S. agencies. Iran has said it would welcome such supplies. An opposition group as accused the Iranian government underestimating the number of casualties and of devoting all of its resources to a war with Iran rather than providing adequate housing. On the other hand, an anti-American newspaper in Iran said the U.S. was partly to blame because it caused the Iranians to divert needed cash fromHousing projects and building earthquake resistant buildings. This is the fourth largest earthquake in the world in the last 50 years. The other three were in China in 1976, Soviet Turkmenia in 1948 and Peru in 1970.

column3: Gorbachev wa set to board a plane in the Crimea, where he wa vacationing at the time of Monday's coup, for the two-hour flight to Moscow, said a deputy to Russian Defense Minister Konstantin Kobets. Earlier report that the plane had already taken off were incorrect, official said.;The Soviet leader, in a statement for radio and television, said he wa fully in command of the situation and that the coup leader would bear "full responsibility" for their actions.;In the United States, President Bush hailed Gorbachev's return to power and said the coup leader had "underestimated the power of the people, underestimated what a taste of freedom and democracy brings.";The three-day coup, one of the most tumultuous development in recent Soviet history, unraveled in a series of swift and dramatic development today:;(check) Tanks and armored personnel carrier moved away from the Russian parliament, scene of the worst violence of the coup. A 2 1/2-milelong column of tank and truck headed out of Moscow.;(check) The leader of the national legislature demanded Gorbachev's reinstatement. The full legislature nullified the coup leaders' emergency decrees.;(check) Press restriction were lifted. "I'm sorry, comrade, but I'm very excited!" said a Soviet TV announcer, grinning broadly after he wa allowed for the first time to criticize the coup leaders' actions.;(check) The Communist Party, apparently seeking to salvage it own image, denounced the takeover.;(check) In the secessionist Baltic republic, which had borne the brunt of the post-coup crackdown, some Soviet troop began returning to their permanent base. Latvia joined neighbor Estonia today in declaring immediate independence from the Soviet Union.;The coup's failure could deal a fatal blow to organized, high-level effort to thwart reform drive in the Soviet Union by Gorbachev and Yeltsin and significantly alter the balance of power that ha characterized Soviet power for the six-year Gorbachev era.;The country's future course depends, however, on who remains in power. Although Yeltsin supported Gorbachev during the coup, the two men maintain different approach to Soviet reforms.;Yeltsin addressed the Russian parliament today and said the Soviet Union had just "gone through a most tragic moment in it history, and perhaps the most tragic moment.";Gorbachev's foreign minister, Alexander Bessmertnykh, who had dropped out of sight during the coup, reappeared today and called the takeover a page in Soviet history that "has got to be turned.";The national legislature invalidated all decree made by the coup leader, national lawmaker Yuri Karyakin told the Russian legislature. Karyakin said the legislature's executive council demanded Gorbachev's return to power.;With the coup's demise, the Communist Party moved to salvage it own credibility. It called the takeover unconstitutional and demanded a meeting with Gorbachev, the party chief, the official news agency Tass said. The party renounced any connection with the coup leaders.;Thousands of people had kept up their vigil at the Russian parliament building after overnight clash with Soviet troop that left at least four dead. They cheered when the announcement of the coup committee's departure came over a loudspeaker.;"This show the strength of our democracy," said Leonid Abramtsov, who wa marching with a band of teen-agers waving the red, white and sky-blue flag of the Russian republic.;The plane reportedly carrying the coup leader wa said to be headed to the city of Bishkek, formerly called Frunze, the capital of Kirgizia, 2,100 mile southeast of Moscow, according to Radio Russia, which speaks for Yeltsin. It wa not immediately known why the coup leader would travel to Kirgizia.;But source at the airport told the Associated Press that only KGB chief Vladimir Kryuchkov wa on a plane, and it wa headed to the Crimea. He reportedly wa accompanied by Communist Party No. 2 leader Vladimir Ivashko.;The republic-run Russian Information Agency said Vice President Gennady Yanayev, the nominal head of the coup committee, wa still in his Kremlin office. The report could not be independently confirmed, and the discrepancy could not be clarified.;Despite the force brought to bear by the coup leader, they were unable to dislodge Yeltsin from the Russian parliament, where he rallied the opposition, to enforce the curfew, or prevent large demonstration nationwide.;The state of emergency wa declared after hard-line element in the military and Communist Party ousted Gorbachev, declaring he wa ill.;The junta had seemed unable to cope with ten of thousand of people who erected barricade around Yeltsin's stronghold in the parliament.;There were also huge anti-coup demonstration in Moscow, Leningrad, Kishiniev and other city, a well a strike by coal miner in Siberia.;Early today, before the coup fell apart, column of tank and armored personnel carrier had moved around central Moscow. One patrol of the armored vehicle wa trapped by furious demonstrator just after midnight a it tried to break through a barricade.;Two people were confirmed shot or crushed to death a the vehicle tried to fight their way through, and witness said a third person wa killed. A Russian republic official, Col. Viktor Samailov, told the independent news agency Interfax that four people were shot or crushed to death in the clash. In the United States, President Bush said he spoke to Gorbachev and the Soviet leader wa "calling the shots" again. Bush said the hard-line coup leader had "underestimated the power of the people, underestimated what a taste of freedom and democracy brings.";The coup, one of the most tumultuous development in recent Soviet history, unraveled in a series of swift and dramatic development today:;(check) Tanks and armored personnel carrier moved away from the Russian parliament, scene of the worst violence of the coup. A 2 1/2-mile-long column of tank and truck headed out of Moscow.;(check) The leader of the national legislature demanded Gorbachev's reinstatement. The full legislature nullified the coup leaders' emergency decrees.;(check) Press restriction were lifted. "I'm sorry, comrade, but I'm very excited!" said a Soviet TV announcer, grinning broadly after he wa allowed for the first time to criticize the coup leaders' actions.;(check) The Communist Party, apparently seeking to salvage it own image, denounced the takeover.;(check) In the independence-minded Baltic republic, which had borne the brunt of the post-coup crackdown, some Soviet troop began returning to their permanent base. Latvia joined neighbor Estonia today in declaring immediate independence from the Soviet Union.;The coup's failure could deal a fatal blow to organized, high-level effort to thwart reform drive in the Soviet Union by Gorbachev and Yeltsin and significantly alter the balance of power that ha characterized Soviet power for the six-year Gorbachev era.;The country's future course depends, however, on who remains in power. Although Yeltsin supported Gorbachev during the coup, the two men maintain different approach to Soviet reforms.;Gorbachev's foreign minister, Alexander Bessmertnykh, who had dropped out of sight during the coup, reappeared today and called the takeover a page in Soviet history that "has got to be turned.";At a news conference, Bessmertnykh promised that reform would continue and that Moscow would honor it international commitments.;The national legislature invalidated all decree made by the coup leader, national lawmaker Yuri Karyakin told the Russian legislature. He gave no detail about the vote. Karyakin said the legislature's executive council demanded Gorbachev's return to power.;Word of Gorbachev's imminent return to the capital came from Lev Y. Sukhanov, a long-time Yeltsin deputy. He said Gorbachev would fly from his vacation retreat in the Crimea to the Soviet capital with Vladimir Ivashko, the deputy general-secretary of the Communist Party and other aides.;With the coup's demise, the Communist Party moved to salvage it own credibility.
