It called the takeover unconstitutional and demanded a meeting with Gorbachev, the party chief, the official news agency Tass said. The party renounced any connection with the coup leaders.;Thousands of people had kept up their vigil at the Russian parliament building after overnight clash with Soviet troop that left at least four dead. They roared with approval when the announcement of the coup committee's departure came over a loudspeaker.;The plane reportedly carrying the coup leader wa said to be headed to the city of Bishkek, formerly called Frunze, the capital of Kirgizia, 2,100 mile southeast of Moscow, according to Radio Russia, which speaks for Yeltsin. It wa not immediately known why the coup leader would travel to Kirgizia.;The radio said official of the Russian republic would try to intercept the plane and have it passenger arrested.;But source at the airport told the Associated Press that only KGB chief Vladimir Kryuchkov wa on a plane, and it wa headed to the Crimea, where Gorbachev reportedly had been placed under house arrest. He reportedly wa accompanied by Communist Party No. 2 leader Vladimir Ivashko.;The republic-run Russian Information Agency said Vice President Gennady Yanayev, the nominal head of the coup committee, wa still in his Kremlin office. The report could not be independently confirmed, and the discrepancy could not be clarified.;Bush, in Maine, told a news conference that Yeltsin told him in a telephone call that he believed that five of the coup leader left Moscow and that one of them, Prime Minister Valentin Pavlov, wa in the hospital.;Despite the force brought to bear by the coup leader, they were unable to dislodge Yeltsin from the Russian parliament, where he rallied the opposition, to enforce the curfew, or prevent large demonstration nationwide.;The state of emergency wa declared after hard-line element in the military and Communist Party ousted Gorbachev, declaring he wa ill. Few believed it.;The junta had seemed unable to cope with ten of thousand of people who erected barricade around Yeltsin's stronghold in the parliament.;There were also huge anti-coup demonstration in Moscow, Leningrad, Kishiniev and other city, a well a strike by coal miner in Siberia.;Early today, before the coup fell apart, column of tank and armored personnel carrier had moved around central Moscow. One patrol of the armored vehicle wa trapped by furious demonstrator just after midnight a it tried to break through a barricade.;Two people were confirmed shot or crushed to death a the vehicle tried to fight their way through, and witness said a third person wa killed. A Russian republic official, Col. Viktor Samailov, told the independent news agency Interfax that four people were shot or crushed to death in the clash. Gorbachev threw out his foreign minister, Alexander Bessmertnykh, and his acting defense minister, and named a new head of the KGB. And Yeltsin, with Gorbachev's blessing, fired the head of state-owned media.;The Moscow City Council, meanwhile, ordered all Communist Party building in the capital sealed and all telephone service to party and KGB building cut. About 2,000 protester blockaded the Communist Party headquarters in Moscow, declaring they were trying to prevent the removal of document that might contain evidence linking party member to the coup. Some of the demonstrator chanted, "Down with the Communist Party!";Yeltsin, who had led the nationwide resistance to the coup, announced a ban on Communist Party activity in the Russian republic, the army, police unit of the Interior Ministry and the KGB, which for decade helped enforce Communist rule. Some of the many new decree issued by Yeltsin went beyond the official bound of his power a Russian Federation president.;In his speech before the Russian parliament, Gorbachev wa compelled to affirm a legitimate the decree issued by Yeltsin during the three-day coup. It wasn't clear whether the Soviet president had intended to back Yeltsin's latest decree, and he balked at proposal by Russian deputy to outlaw the Communist Party, saying it would divide the nation.;Gorbachev told the deputy that the government would prosecute those responsible for the takeover. "They wanted to turn u into meat. They wanted to annihilate u, and for that they must bear the severe responsibility," the Soviet president said.;He accused the Communist Party Central Committee of panicking during the coup. "There are people who lost their head, all sense of responsibility. You could even call them traitor! Traitors!";At one point during the session, Gorbachev dramatically held up what he said were the minute of a secret Cabinet meeting during the coup that revealed who backed the emergency decree. He said many of them "hemmed and hawed," but most voted in support of the takeover.;Today's meeting displayed unprecedented openness in which deputy repeatedly interrupted Gorbachev and argued with him.;Gorbachev drew applause from deputy when he announced that the party's headquarters in Moscow wa sealed.;The meeting of Gorbachev and Yeltsin wa the first since the coup collapsed to discus the takeover and to deal with official who backed the putsch.;In his speech, Gorbachev praised "the outstanding role" of Yeltsin, his sometimes adversary, in halting the hard-line Communist coup. Yeltsin ha been a strong foe of Communist Party influence in the country; Gorbachev, however, warned in his speech against "any kind of anti-Communist hysteria.";Yeltsin often commented during Gorbachev's speech, and Gorbachev deferred to him several time on detail of what happened during Gorbachev's detention.; Standing ovation;The Soviet president's opening comment drew a standing ovation from the lawmaker in the parliament. Yeltsin led the opposition to the coup from the parliament building, where supporter rallied to build barricade and form a human shield against expected attack. The coup plotter never dared mount a frontal assault on Yeltsin's headquarters during the standoff.;As the face of the Soviet government continued to change in the aftermath of the failed coup, hundred of angry resident marched toward Communist Party headquarters in Moscow intent on proving the party wa behind the coup.;In other developments:;(check) Only one of the eight top leader of the coup remained at large early today -- Oleg Baklanov, deputy of the state Defense Committee.;(check) In Kirghizia, Kirghiz President Askar Akaev said the republic would take control of the headquarters of the Kirghiz wing of the Communist Party, a well a the local Lenin Museum. Akaev said the party would be compensated.;Publication suspended; In Moscow, Yeltsin today nationalized the hundred of printing plant in the Russian republic.;He suspended the publication of six Communist Party newspaper and ordered new chief for the official Novosti and Tass news service, charging they had supported the takeover.;The action by Yeltsin, who quit the party last summer, came amid a growing wave of anger at the Communist Party, six of whose top party official were arrested for instigating the coup.;In a major blow to the crumbling party, the acting head of the KGB today affirmed Yeltsin's ban on Communist Party activity in the security service, Tass said. A KGB directive also banned any other political party in the KGB, for decade used by Communist regime to intimidate dissident and anti-Communist activists.; Bold protests; The firing of Bessmertnykh followed criticism of his silence during the coup. Bessmertnykh, 57, wa the latest official to step down or be removed after the failed takeover. He wa not seen publicly after the coup began, and he didn't re-emerge until the coup leadership began to collapse. Bessmertnykh said he had been ill and unable to act.;The arrest of the former KGB chief and other Communist Party hard-liners inspired ten of thousand of demonstrator to undreamed-of daring Thursday.;They expressed their anger and disgust with the organization responsible for killing million of Soviet citizen and now caught conspiring to return to their old dictatorship.;At KGB headquarters on Dzerzhinsky Street, thousand shook fist and shouted, "Executioners!" They smeared "Down with the KGB!" and a swastika on the front of the building in white paint. The "coup people," a President Bush dubbed them, could not have miscalculated more profoundly. They thought the issue wa Mikhail Gorbachev, and apparently believed that by neutralizing Gorbachev and threatening everyone else, they could quickly take charge of the country.;But the people of the Soviet Union apparently concluded that the real issue wa not Gorbachev himself, but the new political culture of freedom and even democracy that his reform had created. For the first time in their thousand-year history, Russians asserted their independence from autocracy, and the autocrat fell.;There will be much to sort out in the month ahead. But almost certainly the failure of the counterrevolution will accelerate the democratic revolution it tried to choke. That revolution will alter the country, creating a new, decentralized and probably smaller Soviet Union much more quickly than anyone anticipated.;Gorbachev's own standing also will be transformed by these event. It seems unlikely that he can escape the consequence of his own past miscalculation -- especially the miscalculation that led him to embrace the very men who led this putsch against his rule. Gorbachev wa the most resourceful and creative political leader of the late 20th century, but this week he wa trumped by Boris Yeltsin, who will now rightly be seen a the man who saved him.;Yeltsin had two talent that Gorbachev lacked. One wa the ability to stay close to the Russian people a their world wa transformed by Gorbachev's revolution -- hence his thumping victory in this spring's first presidential election in Russia and Gorbachev's abysmal standing in the poll. Yeltsin's second talent wa his eagerness to challenge the apparatus of the Soviet Communist Party, the world from which both he and Gorbachev emerged.;Gorbachev could never shuck his party apparatchik's skin. Instead of reaching out to new idea and new people a Yeltsin ha, he surrounded himself with traditional Communist Party official and worried about the impact of new scheme and idea. Gorbachev thought Vladimir Kryuchkov of the KGB, Boris Pugo of the Ministry of Interior, Dmitri Yazov of the Red Army and Gennady Yanayev of the Communist Party were necessary bedfellow whose presence in his entourage could protect him from conservative force that hated his reform. Instead, they turned out to be mortal enemies.;If they had been only personal enemy, Gorbachev might have been undone by them. But when they closed the new, liberal news medium and reverted to the Stalinist tradition of the big lie, the member of the State Emergency Committee threatened not just Gorbachev but also the new Soviet Union -- a society that offered it citizen an unprecedented opportunity for dignity, self-reliance and freedom. For year, Soviets and Western Kremlinologists had debated whether the change that created this new Soviet Union were irreversible. Tuesday, it became clear that they were.;Of course, Gorbachev initiated those change, and history will credit him for that. He also refused to acquiesce to the state of emergency that those responsible for the coup apparently asked him to endorse last weekend.;It is intriguing in assessing the coup's failure that men trained a thug by some of the most violent and mean-spirited institution created by any state could not, in their moment of truth, behave like thug and kill their compatriot. They left Gorbachev alive and Yeltsin at large; they let the Western medium report their coup a it unfolded; and they allowed foreign radio station to broadcast news of it back into the country. Even their own news medium, under strict control, conveyed the fact that there wa widespread resistance to their attempted coup.;By Tuesday night, the Emergency Committee wa in a confrontation with the political legitimacy of Yeltsin, and this proved an unequal contest. As Gorbachev had previously discovered in his negotiation with Yeltsin over a new union treaty, the legitimacy provided by the 50 million vote that Yeltsin received in the election for president of the Russian federation wa a formidable political force.;At first blush, the botching of the coup wa surprising -- couldn't the vaunted KGB and it ally run an efficient putsch? But these were representative of the political class that turned one of the world's richest nation into a basket case. Perhaps their coup should be seen a a desperate and forlorn effort to deny a truth that proved undeniable -- that the Stalinist system had failed so utterly there wa simply no way to redeem it. Gorbachev chose to ignore warning about the right's impending attempt to seize power. Some warning came from Gorbachev's liberal adviser, such a Alexander Yakovlev, shortly before the coup. But, incredibly, the clearest signal came from the hard-liners themselves.;A leading conservative journalist, Alexander Prokhanov, known a the "nightingale of the General Staff," published a transcript of his conversation with the head of the General Staff Academy, the commander-in-chief of the Soviet Navy and Gorbachev's deputy at the Defense Council, Oleg Baklanov. With remarkable candor, Baklanov called for a military takeover a an appropriate step to avert reform that would result in a fundamental transformation of the union. Needless to say, Baklanov delivered on that warning and joined the Gang of Eight.;Gorbachev ignored these warnings.;To some -- an admitted minority -- the thought of a Gorbachev conspiracy is comfortably within the range of the traditional Soviet art of deception known a maskirovka. And to layman, something that odd could make sense in a country where illness can mean anything from the flu to a precipitous fall from power.;The most volatile fuel for the conspiracy theory came directly from Gorbachev himself, in his Thursday news conference in which he described his three day under house arrest in the Crimea.;Among the questions: If Gorbachev's 32 armed guard remained loyal to him throughout, why wa there no conflict with the opposition delegation that notified the president of the coup? Why didn't the coup leader incapacitate Gorbachev's guard, or at least separate them from him?;If Gorbachev's contact with the outside world wa limited to intercepting Western radio outlet on an ancient shortwave radio, how wa he able to describe the news conference given by the collaborator, down to his view of their trembling hands?;It is highly unlikely that the hard-liners had been set up or ordered by Gorbachev to launch a hopeless coup attempt in order to improve his political standing. Such a scenario would require an unprecedented degree of selfless commitment to Gorbachev on their part.;A more plausible scenario is that Gorbachev wa initially a full member of the conspiracy, which, with his participation, could have clung to the fig leaf of constitutionality and would have thwarted the new Union Treaty, to have been signed last Tuesday, which provided for transfer of key lever of power from the federal presidency to the leader of republics.;It is possible that, unwilling to take a huge risk and openly side with the hard-liners at the start of the coup, Gorbachev had decided to become ill and wait out the initial phase under virtually self-imposed confinement in his summer residence.;Gorbachev did reveal, however, that two important official had visited him in Crimea at the outset of the coup. One wa head of the KGB department responsible for the security of Soviet leaders; the other wa V. Boldin, Gorbachev's closest aide, by the president's own admission a man of absolute loyalty to him. One can't help but wonder whether these two visitor came to deliver an ultimatum to Gorbachev and put him under arrest in the event of his non-compliance, or to deliver important document from fellow junta member at the outset of their joint enterprise.;Conspiracy theorist grope for motif -- Gorbachev wanted to ferret out disloyal element in his government, to make himself a hero and to delay the scheduled signing of a treaty that would have lessened his power. But there is virtually unanimous agreement on one point. Gorbachev put into power the very hard-liners who fronted the coup and kept them in power despite their vocal muttering about him. Cut to a row of dour Communists in ill-fitting gray suit announcing Gorbachev's illness and a palace coup. The camera zoom in on the impassive face of the two men last seen in Gorbachev's office.;What is going on here?;OK, it's a hackneyed device that would only work in the movie. But then, this week's event in the Soviet Union have all the making of a spy thriller.;Kremlinologists who dabble in conspiracy theory are working overtime, though they insist that their darkest imaginings be clearly labeled "pure speculation.";"Once you have a palace coup, the possibility are endless," said Robert Conquest, a senior research fellow at the Hoover Institution. "Russian politics are full of very strange things.";For all we know, Conquest joked, Gorbachev could be injected with drug to change his personality or KGB scientist could produce a body-double to impersonate him.;"His friend would know, but would you or I?" Conquest said. "That would be going a bit far.";A more intriguing scenario ha Gorbachev conspiring with the coup plotter to engineer a transformation of the Soviet political landscape. The thinking go like this:;With his popularity at rock bottom, Gorbachev, a lifelong creature of the KGB, hatch a false coup in order to step out of the way while hard-liners and liberal battle each other. The coup fall apart and Gorbachev triumphantly return with a level of legitimacy he never enjoyed before.;The theory could explain the apparent bungling of the coup plotter, said author Joseph Finder, whose 1991 novel, "The Moscow Club," foreshadowed many of the element of the current crisis.;Finder, who said he did not subscribe to the scenario, nonetheless pointed out that tank did not begin to roll until hour after Gorbachev's supposed arrest. Russian President Boris Yeltsin wa not arrested, and Leningrad wa left alone.;Speculation wa not unique to Kremlin watcher in the United States.;Theorizing wa rampant in the street of Moscow on Tuesday, said San Francisco businesswoman Kimberly Getto, who sent a long fax detailing speculation, fueled by the fact that many of the tank encircling the Russian parliament building had no ammunition. Gorbachev did not want bloodshed, according to the theory.;The Democratic Reform Movement, headed by former Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, Gorbachev's longtime ally, floated the same possibility in a statement Monday.;"It's highly implausible, but not to be excluded, that Gorbachev himself agreed to a withdrawal, thinking he'd show them they still needed him," said Norman Naimark, director of Stanford's Center for Russian and East European Studies. "The degree of connivance is difficult to gauge." At the news conference -- Gorbachev's first since the coup against him collapsed on Wednesday -- the 60-year-old leader condemned the takeover a being against "the people, against democracy.";Earlier, he told reporter he would have killed himself rather than submit to any forced arrangement with the coup leader. "I said I wouldn't make any deals," he said then. "Otherwise, I would have had to commit suicide.";Gorbachev detailed his purge of coup leader, including Defense Minister Dmitri Yazov. He named a new acting KGB chief, interior minister and defense minister, and said he would do everything to "drive out the reactionary force from the Communist Party.";Gorbachev pledged cooperation with Russian republic President Boris Yeltsin but said he had no plan to leave the Communist Party.;"I am convinced that socialism is correct. I am an adherent of socialism.";When asked if Yeltsin now had more power than he did, Gorbachev said, "We have been bound together by the situation.";Looking and sounding angry, he described the plotter a "primitive and crude and crafty" and scoffed at their announcement that he had stepped aside because he wa ill. "Their hand were shaking the whole time," he said derisively.;Despite his display of anger, the Soviet president said the failure of the coup could ultimately help ensure the continuation of his reform. "We have to see this a an enormous opportunity," he said.;At his news conference, Gorbachev made a point of publicly praising Yeltsin, whose folk-hero stature wa enhanced during the coup a he rallied hundred of thousand of his supporter to resist.;Before dawn today, Gorbachev flew back to Moscow from the Crimea, where he had been confined to his summer home during his brief ouster.;The Soviet president, who wa reported to have slept for a few hour in his dacha outside Moscow after returning from the Crimea, arrived at Moscow's Vnukovo Airport unannounced, under heavy security. He looked somewhat disheveled, clad in a windbreaker and a shirt with open collar.;Appearing on Soviet television after his arrival, Gorbachev looked haggard and unshaven, with deep line around his eye and mouth. Later, at his news conference, he at first spoke haltingly, but then appeared to recover his composure and spoke in a forceful voice.;Gorbachev said his captor cut off all communication and that his only source of news during the coup had been from foreign broadcast, including the BBC and Voice of America, received on a makeshift radio set up by his personal guards.;"This ha been a very difficult, an extremely difficult lesson for me. It's my, you might say, my drama," he told reporters.;"Everything wa done to weaken me psychologically," Gorbachev said. "It wa hard. It is hard to say it now, but that's how it was.";He said that early on in the coup, he tried to find out who wa behind it.;"I picked up one of the telephone I have and it wasn't working. I picked up a second, a third, a fourth . . . everything wa cut off," he said.;"Every day, morning and night, I demanded . . . that my communication be restored and that an airplane be brought immediately so I could be returned to Moscow," he said. He wa being held at his vacation home in the Crimea.;Gorbachev said the coup leader demanded that he resign.;"I said, 'You will never live that long (to see me resign).' ";He called the crisis "one of the most difficult trial of the entire history" of his six-year rule.;Gorbachev said his 32-man personal guard stayed with him throughout the coup.;The 60-year-old president said the crisis had been difficult for his family, especially his wife, Raisa, who "took it very hard.";"Best of all, my granddaughter Anastasia didn't understand anything that wa going on," Gorbachev told reporter. "She wanted to go to the beach; that's all that concerned her. But the guard wouldn't let her go to the beach; they were concerned something would happen.";When it became clear the coup wa failing, Gorbachev said he prepared himself and his family for the possibility that they would be killed by the conspirators.;"You know that it appeared a though they might have done something to me. They might have killed me and my whole family and made it look a if . . . they were acting in the name" of the acting president.;"These people might have done almost anything," he said. Gorbachev told an audience at the Russian parliament that the government would prosecute those responsible for the takeover. "They wanted to turn u into meat. They wanted to annihilate u, and for that they must bear the severe responsibility," the Soviet president said.;He accused the Communist Party Central Committee of panicking during the coup. column5: Soviet President Gorbachev survives coup but loses popularity to Yeltsin.
column6: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev returned to power as the coup against him collapsed. Although the junta couldn't cope with the resistance of thousands of people around the Russian Parliament, the real issue was not Gorbachev but the new political culture he initiated and the popular anti-Communist stand of Boris Yeltsin.
column7: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev returned to power as the coup against him collapsed, unraveling swiftly as junta was unable to cope with thousands of people who created barricades around the Russian Parliament, Russian President Yeltsin's stronghold. The national legislature demanded Gorbachev's reinstatement and the Communist Party, seeking to salvage its image, denounced the takeover.The real issue for the coup failure was not Gorbachev but the new political culture of democracy he initiated. At first Gorbachev and Yeltsin appeared as equals but Yeltsin, who challenged the Communist Party and stayed close to the Russian people, trumped Gorbachev.
column8: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev returned to power as the coup against him collapsed while he was vacationing in Crimea. The coup unraveled swiftly as the junta was unable to cope with thousands of people who erected barricades around Yeltsin's stronghold, the Russian Parliament. The national legislature demanded Gorbachev's reinstatement and nullified the coup leaders' decrees. The Communist Party, seeking to salvage its image, denounced the takeover. The coup people thought they could take over by neutralizing Gorbachev.However, the real issue was not Gorbachev but the new political culture of freedom and democracy his reforms had created. Gorbachev initiated the changes but his standing was transformed when he was trumped by Russia's President Boris Yeltsin who, unlike Gorbachev, challenged the Communist Party and stayed close to the Russian people. Gorbachev and Yeltsin at first appeared as equals while launching a purge of the Communist Party, although Gorbachev balked at Yeltsin's proposals to ban the Communist Party. Later, Yeltsin made it clear in the Russian Parliament that Gorbachev has authority only if agreeing to share power and intensify the march toward a democracy and a free economy.There is speculation that Gorbachev orchestrated the coup in order to ferret out the disloyal.
column9: Gorbachev returns to Moscow after failed coup; Yeltsin key role
column10: The attempted coup in the USSR fell apart three days after the house arrestof President Mikhail Gorbachev in the Crimea.  Thousands of citizens ralliedin support of Boris Yeltsin who led the opposition to the coup.  Gorbachevwas returned to the presidency but Yeltsin was emerging as the new leader.
column11: Soviet hard-liners staged a coup in order to prevent implementation ofGorbachev's reforms. Some viewers suspected a Gorbachev role in the coup asa ploy to solidify his position. The coup ended after three days due mainlyto opposition by Boris Yeltsin who rallied thousands in opposition.  Coupleaders were arrested and Gorbachev was returned to the presidency.Gorbachev still hoped to implement reforms working through the CommunistParty.  Yeltsin, however, had quit the party and wanted to see its influencelessened.  Yeltsin was clearly moving into a greater leadership role in thenew Russia.
column12: Soviet hard-liners attempted a coup in order to thwart the impending signingof the new Union Treaty incorporating the reforms of Soviet PresidentGorbachev.  The coup leaders put Gorbachev under house arrest in the Crimea.Russian President Boris Yeltsin led opposition to the coup, which did nothave popular support, and it was put down after three days.  Gorbachev wasreturned to Moscow and was reinstated as president.  Some observers wonderedabout Gorbachev's actions just before the coup attempt since he had ignoredample warnings that it might happen. Conspiracy buffs even wondered ifGorbachev might have even been part of the planning.Upon his return to power, Gorbachev ordered the arrest of the coup leadersand made new appointments to key positions.  The putdown of the coup meantthat the reforms giving more authority to the republics would go forward.Gorbachev and Yeltsin approached the reforms differently.  Gorbachev wantedto work through the Communist Party, but Yeltsin had quit the party andwanted to see its influence lessened.  Yeltsin was clearly more in touchwith the people.  The two leaders made a joint appearance at the RussianParliament where it became increasingly clear that Gorbachev's authority waswaning while Yeltsin's was ascending.

column3: The arrival Wednesday of African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela prompted an outpouring of praise and encouragement from politician and supporter. A sampling of their comments: In the 15 month since he walked free from prison, Nelson Mandela ha played the chief role in talk with President FW. de Klerk and the white government. He ha presided over an African National Congress divided and not yet organized for politics. He ha spent his moral capital trying, unsuccessfully, to end the murderous conflict between black political factions.; Now Mandela is confronted with his wife's conviction for a brutal criminal offense. He ha loyally defended her innocence. He ha seemed to hear no voice to the contrary. But event have caught up.; The radical in the ANC may well use the trial and conviction of Mrs. Mandela to arouse member against Nelson Mandela's policy of peace and negotiation.; There are rumor that at a national conference next month the radical will try to move such older leader a Mandela and Walter Sisulu aside to a nominal senior role.; It is a gloomy picture: an elderly man bearing the hope of peace in South Africa beset by problem, personal trauma on top of political. But I think it would be wrong to conclude that the South African drama is necessarily heading toward a tragic end.; One reason for a degree of optimism is the way South Africans on all side, most of them, have dealt with Winnie Mandela's trial: calmly and fairly.; During the year of white supremacy the law ha been viciously misused. But from all one can tell, this trial wa handled professionally by the judge, Justice Michael Stegmann.; The reaction to the verdict and six-year prison sentence wa also mild. Surprisingly few supporter gathered outside the court to cheer Mrs. Mandela. The ANC issued a detached statement saying that the last word had not been spoken in the case. Archbishop Desmond Tutu said "the movement is larger than any individual."; A more fundamental reason for hope is that FW. de Klerk and Nelson Mandela -- and those for whom they speak -- have a common interest in creating a new, non-racial South Africa. They need each other. Without their agreement, there can be no solution, no outcome that leaf a viable country.; The next step is formal negotiation. They can come only when the government take further step to meet the reasonable ANC demand for action against violence -- in particular, a ban on the carrying of so-called "cultural" weapon such a spear. How can the government look away when 1,000 Zulus carrying spear and machete slaughter township residents?; The time factor is crucial now. Negotiations must start soon if the moderate center of the public, black and white, is to retain hope for a peaceful solution. World and time press on Nelson Mandela. A 3-year campaign that ha succeeded in getting Northeastern University to award an honorary degree to jailed South African nationalist leader Nelson Mandela ha raised objection from some faculty and student. Northeastern announced plan to award the degree honoring Mandela on May 13, ending a long effort by student seeking to change a university policy barring honorary degree for anyone who could not be present at the ceremony. The degree is to be accepted by South African Archbishop Desmond Tutu, who is scheduled to be in Boston for a benefit dinner. Law student last September began a campaign of demonstration and vigil on the campus. They hung a banner from the second floor of the law library that said: Honor Nelson Mandela. Before he wa imprisoned, said third-year law student Sarah Ottinger, Nelson Mandela wa an . attorney and an activist who worked against apartheid. That's the message we wanted conveyed to student. South Africa's white-minority government say it will free Mandela only if he renounces the use of violence by force seeking political power for black in the country. Some faculty member and student, including many black, have criticized the administration's plan for the event, saying no effort wa made to include them. I don't even know what office is sponsoring it, said Keith Motley, dean and director of the African-American Institute, a student group. We got a memo from the administration saying they need six usher, but that's it. You'd think at least we'd be clued in to what's going on. This started out a something noble, something we've tried to have done for three year, said Ottinger. We are very, very sorry it happened this way. It wasn't meant to turn out like this. The trustee decided in January that Mandela should get the honorary degree. Students set up a committee to contact Mandela's family to get their approval. University spokesman Paul Jones said letter were sent to Mandela's wife, Winnie, and his two daughters: Zenani, a student at Boston University, and Makaziwe, a student at the University of Massachusetts at Boston. However, Northeastern still ha not received approval from the Mandela family, The Boston Globe reported. Unidentified assailant hurled a grenade and fired shot today at the home of relative of Nelson Mandela, killing a baby girl and injuring her parent, police said. African National Congress official said the dead child and her parent were distant cousin of Nelson Mandela. They denied South African police and press report that the child wa Mandela's great-granddaughter. Police said they did not know who wa responsible for the attack. No group took immediate responsibility. Police Lt. Govindesamy Mariemuthoo said the attack occurred before dawn at the home of Monde Mandela in the black township of Soweto. The blast badly damaged part of the house, knocking hole in the wall and causing extensive damage. The police officer said a baby girl wa killed and her parent injured. He gave no other detail on the victim. He said the room in which the injured couple had been sleeping wa destroyed. ANC official said the dead child wa the great niece of Mandela's father, making her a distant cousin of Nelson Mandela. The dead girl's father, Monde Mandela, run a small grocery shop. The ANC official said Nelson Mandela wa close to the Monde Mandela family. An ANC statement said, The ANC note the curious coincidence of an attack on a man bearing the Mandela name at this time. Given the distant connection between Mandela and the family, police said they did not know if the attack wa deliberate or just a random attack linked to the general violence. Mandela wa reportedly attending a political meeting in the eastern province of Natal today. Soweto and other black township around Johannesburg have been hit by black factional fighting that ha killed about 800 people since August. The fighting ha pitted follower of the ANC against Zulus of the conservative Inkatha group. Mandela ha repeatedly accused security force of manipulating the violence to derail government effort to end apartheid and share power with the black majority. The police have denied Mandela's charge. Mandela wa released in February after 27 year in jail for opposing the white minority government. He is closely guarded by ANC operative, and there have been report of threat on his life in recent month. Mandela and other ANC leader have been negotiating with President FW. de Klerk to pave the way for full-scale talk on ending apartheid, the South African system of racial separation. De Klerk ha promised to end white-minority rule. Mayor David Dinkins warned Jewish group against protesting the visit of anti-apartheid leader Nelson Mandela to New York City, saying the protest might insult the black community, a newspaper said today. The mayor also asked member of the organized Jewish community to dissuade more radical group from disrupting the visit, the Daily News said. Mandela, leader of the African National Congress, will visit eight city from June 20 to July 1. There is a danger of many people who hold Nelson Mandela in very, very high esteem taking great umbrage at any public protest, Dinkins said. I think it's sad and unfortunate and tactically very, very unwise, because this man is an international symbol of freedom and especially so seen by person of color, Dinkins told the newspaper in an interview. Leaders of several Jewish-American organization plan to meet Mandela on Sunday in Geneva. The organization want the South African leader to clarify his position on Israel. Mandela ha embraced Yasser Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, in public and ha compared the struggle of Palestinians to that of black South Africans. Rabbi Abraham Weiss of the Hebrew Institute announced his Coalition of Concern will hold a protest at Mandela's public welcome in New York because of the anti-apartheid leader's unbending anti-Israel stance. City councilman Noach Dear and state assemblyman Dov Hikind said if Mandela doe not make a strong statement in support of Israel, they would take out ad in newspaper and hold demonstration. Four imprisoned African National Congress leader, convicted in 1964 with Nelson Mandela, were allowed to visit their ANC colleague at his isolated prison house, an activist said today. The four men, all held at Pollsmoor Prison in Cape Town, were taken to nearby Victor Verster Prison on Dec. 23 and spent about six hour with Mandela, said Dullah Omar, an activist and family friend of the Mandelas. Mandela wa moved to the suburban-style home on the prison ground Dec. 7 after recovering from tuberculosis at a private clinic in Cape Town. Mandela's wife, Winnie, said after visiting her husband last month that he is being held practically in solitary confinement at the house. The four men who visited Mandela are Walter Sisulu, Andrew Mhlangeni, Raymond Mhlaba and Ahmed Kathrada. The men were convicted along with Mandela and three others at the same trial in 1964. All were given life sentence for their activity with the ANC, the main guerrilla group attempting to overthrow the white-led government. All of them except Sisulu had not seen Nelson since 1986, and they were very excited at being able to spend time with him, Omar said. Of the three co-defendant not at the Dec. 23 gathering, two have been released and one remains at the Robben Island Prison near Cape Town. The Prisons Service declined to confirm or deny the visit. A representative of the African National Congress said Saturday the South African government may release black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela a early a Tuesday. There are very strong rumor in South Africa today that on Nov. 15 Nelson Mandela will be released, said Yusef Saloojee, chief representative in Canada for the ANC, which is fighting to end white-minority rule in South Africa. Mandela the 70-year-old leader of the ANC jailed 27 year ago, wa sentenced to life in prison for conspiring to overthrow the South African government. He wa transferred from prison to a hospital in August for treatment of tuberculosis. Since then, it ha been widely rumored Mandela will be released by Christmas in a move to win strong international support for the South African government. It will be a victory for the people of South Africa and indeed a victory for the whole of Africa, Saloojee told an audience at the University of Toronto. A South African government source last week indicated recent rumor of Mandela's impending release were orchestrated by member of the anti-apartheid movement to pressure the government into taking some action. And a prominent anti-apatheid activist in South Africa said there ha been no indication (Mandela) would be released today or in the near future. Apartheid is South Africa's policy of racial separation. The largest family group to visit black leader Nelson Mandela since he wa jailed 27 year ago gathered in Cape Town for a meeting Tuesday with the prisoner on his 71st birthday. His wife, Winnie Mandela, arrived Monday night and indicated she did not expect Mandela, leader of the African National Congress, would be freed soon. She said that opinion came from her husband, who she visited last week after Mandela's July 5 meeting with President PW. Botha. That meeting sparked speculation that Mandela would be freed this year. He is serving a life term after being convicted of sabotage and plotting to overthrow the white-dominated government. Mrs. Mandela, referring to her earlier visit with her husband, told reporters: He said from that meeting with PW. Botha we musn't construe a indicating his release. His release wasn't even there. In fact it wa not on the agenda at all. Mrs. Mandela, dressed in black a an expression of mourning, spoke with reporter at the DF. Malan Airport. She said the family normally spent Mandela's birthday at home, fasting and praying, but member would visit him this year on his birthday because he ha invited u to come and share it with him. The family said 14 relative, including child from both of Mandela's marriage, would go to Mandela's house at the Victor Verster prison farm in Paarl, north of Cape Town. In addition to Mrs. Mandela the group will include three of Mandela's child, one daughter-in-law, eight grandhildren and a great-grandson. Mrs. Mandela showed reporter a huge cardboard birthday card in the black, green and yellow color of the outlawed African National Congress, the largest guerrilla group fighting the government. She said the card wa made by member of the National Union of Mineworkers. It is very nice but it is also at the same time very sad, she said of the planned birthday celebration. After all, he is not at home. Mandela wa allowed to meet last Friday with five other ANC member convicted with him in 1964 of trying to overthrow the government and still imprisoned in Cape Town, according to Dullah Omar, a family friend and attorney. Mandela ha been in prison since 1962 when he wa sentenced to five year for leaving the country illegally and organizing an illegal strike. He wa given a life sentence following the 1964 conviction. Omar said Tuesday's family gathering will be an occasion with a strong theme of sadness because after the reunion they will leave Mr. Mandela to resume his lonely life. Mandela's oldest grandson, Mandla, 14, arrived Monday evening from Swaziland where he is a student at a private school. Mandla is the son of Makgatho Mandela, the prisoner's eldest son by his first marriage to Evelyn Ntoko Mase, who life in the black township of Soweto and wa not expected to join the reunion. Makgatho Mandela came to Cape Town with his wife, Zondi, his daughter Indaba and 4-year-old Thembela, Mandela's great-grandson. Thembela is the grandson of Tembikile Mandela. Tembikile, Mandela's son by his marriage to Evelyn Ntoko Mase, died in an automobile accident in 1970. Evelyn Ntoko Mase, the cousin of ANC leader Walter Sisulu who ha been imprisoned with Mandela, married Nelson Mandela in 1944. They had four child. One of their daughter, Makaziwe Mandela-Amuah, arrived with her three child from the United States, where she is studying for a doctoral degree in anthropology at Amherst College in Massachusetts. She said, He (Nelson Mandela) belief that education is the key to all door and he would like to see all of his child get an education; in fact all of the black child . because you cannot claim to want to rule the country and be the leader of the future if you have people who are untrained and don't have any skill. Mrs. Mandela-Amuah said of her father's possible release, I always firmly believe that you can't predict what the South African government will do.
column9: Mandela released from prison; end of apartheid in South Africa near
column10: Nelson Mandela spent 27 years of a life sentence in prison for conspiring tooverthrow the apartheid government of South Africa. World leaders hailed hisrelease in 1990 and considered him a hero.  His efforts to negotiate an endto white minority rule were complicated by factionalism and the imprisonmentof his wife, Winnie.
column11: Nelson Mandela, a leader in the African National Congress' opposition toSouth Africa's policy of apartheid, spent nearly 27 years in prison.  He wassentenced to life in prison in 1964 for conspiring to overthrow thegovernment.  He became a rallying point for nations that were pressuringSouth Africa to end its all-white government.  World leaders hailedMandela's release in 1990, and he was welcomed as a hero when he traveled,including a visit to New York City.  In-fighting among black elementscomplicated Mandela's role in negotiations to end white-minority rule inSouth Africa.  Also, Mandela's wife, Winnie, was imprisoned, complicatingmatters.
column12: Nelson Mandela joined the African National Congress in 1944 and participatedin black protests and civil disobedience opposing the apartheid governmentof South Africa.  He was arrested several times, and in 1964, was given alife sentence for conspiring to overthrow the government.  Many countriespressured South Africa to end its all-white rule, and Mandela's imprisonmentbecame a cause celebre.  In 1988, Mandela's 70th birthday was celebratedoutside South Africa.  Northeastern University planned to award an honorarydegree to Mandela.  Rumors began to spread that South Africa would releaseMandela to gain international support.  President Botha would do so if herenounced violence.  Mandela refused.Mandela contracted tuberculosis in 1988.  After being cured, he was moved tobetter quarters and was permitted visits from family and even ANC leaders.Mandela was released in 1990, as world leaders cheered.  He visited New YorkCity and received accolades from politicians and black leaders.  However,American Jewish leaders were hesitant since he had compared the Palestinianstruggle to that in South Africa.Mandela was among black leaders negotiating with President de Klerk to endapartheid.  His task was complicated by violent factions among blacks and byhis wife, Winnie, being imprisoned for a violent crime.
column13: Nelson Mandela, leading opponent of South Africa's white-led government, freed from prison after 27 years.
column14: Nelson Mandela, the leading opponent of South Africa's white-led government was freed after 27 years in prison on February 11, 1990.  From prison, he had led the fight against the government's policy of racial segregation, apartheid.  In 1964 he was convicted of conspiracy to overthrow the government and was sentenced to life in prison.
column15: Nelson Mandela, the leading opponent of South Africa's white-led government was freed after 27 years in prison on 11 February 1990.  From prison he had led the fight against the government's policy of racial segregation, apartheid.  He was convicted in 1964 of conspiracy to overthrow the government and sentenced to life in prison.  International pressure had been mounting for his release and many governments had imposed sanctions on South Africa.  He continued the fight for black human rights after his release, but had many problems to overcome including factional fighting between the ANC and the Zulu Inkatha group.
column16: Nelson Mandela, the leading opponent of South Africa's white-led government was freed after 27 years in prison on 11 February 1990.  From prison he had led the fight against the government's policy of racial segregation, apartheid.  He, along with other members of the African National Congress, was convicted in 1964 of conspiracy to overthrow the government.  Over the years, international pressure had been mounting for his release and several governments had barred imports from South Africa or investments in the country.  Upon his release Mandela continued the fight for black human rights, but he faced many problems.  He attempted to negotiate an end to the violence between the ANC and the Zulu Inkatha group, which had resulted in many deaths in the Black townships.  His wife was convicted of kidnapping and sentenced to 6 years in prison.  Nelson joined the ANC when he was 26 and rose to a leadership position. The ANC was outlawed in 1960.   He was sentenced to five years in prison in 1962 for illegally leaving the country and for organizing a strike.  Mandela was highly praised during a visit to the United States after his release, but Jewish groups were critical of his support for the Palestine Liberation Organization.

column3: Viktor Alksnis, former USSR Supreme Soviet deputy, today reminded u of his existence. [Correspondent Irina Zaytseva] Viktor Alksnis, born 1950, Latvian, former deputy of the Supreme Soviet of the former USSR, soldier, resigned from the Army in order to fight for the restoration of the USSR. During the October event he left the White House with a head wound and wa taken to hospital. After a long interval Viktor Alksnis held a news conference today in the Slavjanskaya Hotel. He began it with a short statement, the essence of which come down to the fact that the adoption of the Latvian citizenship law violates not only human right, but creates the condition for a conflict similar, in his opinion, to the one in Yugoslavia and the Caucasus. It wa not only the Latvian Government Alksnis accused of this, but also the United States. According to him, during the latest visit to the United States by [Latvian President] Guntis Ulmanis, sanction wa obtained for the adoption of the aforementioned discriminatory law. [Begin Alksnis recording] And thus carte blanche wa given for mild ethnic cleansing of the Russian speaking population of the republic. [end recording] [Zaytseva] Apart from that, Alksnis added, according to information received from reliable source, certain circle in Moscow want conflict in Latvia. [Begin Alksnis recording] A certain scenario exists to drive a so-called security corridor along the route Daugavpils-Yekabpils-Riga where stringent ethnic cleansing of the Latvian population will take place in reply to the mild ethnic cleansing of the Russian population in order to bring so-called independent Latvia to it knee. [end recording] [Zaytseva] Journalists asked for more precise information about what Alksnis called reliable source. [Begin Alksnis recording] You understand that I cannot name these source. But I can say that they are fairly authoritative. [end recording] [Zaytseva] Asked what he intends to do, Alksnis said his opportunity are unfortunately limited, and that is why he is appealing to journalist. In his opinion, only joint effort can bring this information to the attention of world public opinion, point out the seriousness of this issue, and avoid the coming tragedy. Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Friday proposed tougher legislation to punish Soviets who seek to kindle ethnic unrest, saying nationalist passion benefit opponent of his reform. The Soviet leader told a meeting of the Communist Party leadership that inter-ethnic relation were worsening in some region of the country, due in part to active resistance put up to perestroika by corrupt group. Perestroika, or restructuring, is Gorbachev's program for widespread economic and social change. State-run medium also indicated Friday that a crackdown had begun on people in Armenia who continue to agitate for annexation of a mostly Armenian enclave in the neighboring republic of Azerbaijan. The six-month conflict between the two republic over control of the Nagorno-Karabakh district ha led to mass rally, strike and ethnic violence since February. The Supreme Soviet Presidium, the government's top executive body, intervened July 18. It rejected any change in Nagorno-Karabakh's status but called for measure to develop the region's economy and culture. The conflict over Nagorno-Karabakh is one of the most rancorous domestic dispute faced by Gorbachev since he became Communist Party chief in March 1985. He indicated Friday he want to defuse tension between ethnic group, but also to punish those who transform the tension into a political crisis. Gorbachev spoke before a plenary meeting of the Central Committee, the party's policy-making body. A summary of his remark wa distributed by the official Tass news agency. Gorbachev outlined the reason for a current aggravation of tension between ethnic group in some region of the Soviet Union, Tass said. Among the cause, Gorbachev listed a lack of concern for many year for the specific requirement of people and ethnic group, inadequate control by the mass over the activity of executive personnel, and active resistance put up to perestroika by corrupt group. Tass said that after Gorbachev noted that nationalist passion benefit all anti-perestroika force, he suggested increasing accountability in Soviet law for kindling ethnic strife. Tass did not give detail of Gorbachev's suggestion. At the July 18 Presidium meeting, the Soviet leader accused corrupt conservative who oppose his reform of hiding behind the Nagorno-Karabakh annexation drive. Gorbachev said the ground for tougher legislation come directly from Article 36 of the 1977 Soviet Constitution, which say the law can punish any advocacy of racial or national exclusiveness, hostility or contempt. Tass said Gorbachev made other proposal on how to resolve ethnic tension, including an increase in power for each of the country's 15 republic, a law on equal use of the more than 100 language spoken in the Soviet Union and some economic autonomy for the country's republic and region. In particular, the Baltic republic of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, forcibly incorporated into the Soviet Union in 1940, have demanded more say in their own economic and government affair. The labor newspaper Trud said 44 people in Yerevan, Armenia's capital, will face criminal charge following an incident in which activist seeking the annexation of Nagorno-Karabakh attached slogan to their car and drove around the city. The paper did not give the date or size of the mobile demonstration, but said 155 driver have had their license revoked and 310 were fined. In it July 18th decision, the Presidium also ordered local law enforcement agency to ensure order wa restored in the Caucasus Mountain region. Tass reported Friday that the situation wa stabilizing in Armenia, but said that at the urging of instigator, some strike and protest were continuing. The international community is starting to look beyond the conflict in the former Yugoslavia, and is becoming increasingly aware of the true magnitude and seriousness of ethnic and political conflict in the former Soviet Union. The problem is indeed a pressing one. The dispute in the Transcaucasus, central Asia, and elsewhere in the former Soviet Union are causing great suffering for those involved. They are a source of legitimate concern to the Russians, who are worried by clash close to their border. They are concerned too about the safety of ethnic Russians living in those country where there are conflict, and about the economic and social consequence of refugee fleeing to Russia (whose potential number is estimated at more than 2m). They believe that the problem in some of the former Soviet republic are either ignored or misunderstood. The Russians fear that if they do nothing, the conflict will worsen and probably spread. They argue that they have a legitimate concern in trying to resolve conflict that threaten their security. They ask why, when the international community is engaged in peacemaking and peacekeeping in many of the world's trouble spot, similar effort should not be undertaken in the hot spot near them. Equally, these dispute are of legitimate concern to Britain, it western partner and the whole international community, both for humanitarian reason and because such flashpoint risk provoking regional instability. If uncontrolled, they pose a variety of threat to European security, including increased traffic in drug and arm a well a international terrorism. Crises in Russia's newly independent neighbour may also complicate Russia's relation with the west: unless they are carefully handled, they risk prejudicing the emerging relationship between u. The west is sometimes suspicious of Moscow's attitude. There are no difference about the need to resolve these conflicts: but there are difference over how to go about it. The British government will not underwrite Russian involvement unless it is sure that peacekeeping troop will not turn into occupying force. Nor are country that secured their independence when the Soviet Union wa dissolved keen that the west should concede to Moscow the same role it played in the Soviet empire. They fear that this would compromise their sovereignty. When they are willing for Russian troop to play a peacekeeping role, they want there to be some form of international monitoring. This ha meant that, even though the west lack the resource to engage directly in those trouble spot, it ha been wary of appearing to endorse Russian involvement instead, in case it had imperial tendency. If we are to fashion a joint approach by Russia and it western partner to the problem of peacekeeping in the former Soviet Union, we must address all these concern. Clearly Russia ha an important role to play in this area. If the Russians want international recognition and more active support from the international community, the west in turn need guarantee that Russia will not regard recognition of it involvement a giving it carte blanche in the former Soviet Union. Peace-keeping in the former Soviet Union, a indeed peacekeeping elsewhere, must comply with internationally recognised principle. It need to be looked at on a case by case basis. Respect for the sovereignty of the newly independent country must remain paramount. We agreed that the principle underlying Russian, CIS or international peacekeeping operation would need to include: strict respect for the sovereignty of the country involved; an invitation from the government concerned and the consent of the party to the conflict; commitment to a parallel political peace process; a clear mandate setting out the role of the peacekeeping force (which should whenever possible be multinational in character); and an exit strategy for the peacekeeping force deployed. These principle should help stimulate a dialogue and political settlement between the party to the conflict, focus attention and, where possible, resource on the settlement of conflict in the former Soviet Union. All this will help enhance Russian peacekeeping practice. Although the Conference for Security and Co-operation in Europe and the UN lack the resource to put large number of peacekeeper on the ground themselves, they may be able to suggest measure to enhance transparency and to monitor the peace process. Extending co-operation within the North Atlantic Co-operation Council, and also co-operation between Russia and Nato, might help improve training for Russian peacekeeper. This is an area we shall need to explore further. We also need to put much more emphasis on preventive diplomacy. One of the way in which we can help prevent conflict is to strengthen the democratic institution in the newly independent country of the former Soviet Union. The CSCE and other international institution can play an important role here, drawing the newly independent country into a more active dialogue on way of promoting democratic value and principle. We discussed way of strengthening the CSCE's role, including the role of the High Commissioner for National Minorities, at the recent Rome ministerial meeting. We must try to find way of managing and resolving tension before they erupt into conflict. It will not be easy, but we must try. Potentially explosive cocktail of ethnic and political animosity could spread the fire of intolerance all too easily to other country and region. We need to deal with it together in the spirit of partnership. And we need to deal with it urgently. Our security is indivisible and we must ensure it by vigorous and imaginative effort aimed at promoting peace for all a well a right for all. The author are UK foreign secretary and Russian foreign minister RUSSIA flew 3,000 special force to halt ethnic fighting in the troubled Caucasus mountain at the weekend, it second troop deployment in a week to support a beleaguered government in it former empire. Russian President Boris Yeltsin sent Spetsnaz commando and elite police to Vladikavkaz, capital of the Russian autonomous republic of North Ossetia, 1,100 mile south of Moscow. The troop were sent to halt fighting between Ossetians and a regional ethnic group, the Ingush, who official claimed were setting fire to Ossetian-owned home. Scores were reported killed and injured in street fighting between Ossetians and Ingush in the past several day. Ingush rebel were reported yesterday to have taken hostage 80 Russian interior ministry soldier based in the region. A local official said the soldier were seized on Friday in the Dzhermen settlement, located near the regional capital, Vladikavkaz, and populated mostly by Ingushis, Mr Felix Gutnov, spokesman for the North Ossetian interior ministry, said. The Ingush, who declared an independent state in June, are demanding the return of land that Russian leader Josef Stalin expropriated in 1944 and declared part of North Ossetia. Mr Yeltsin and Russian Prime Minister Yegor Gaidar held emergency meeting on the crisis on Saturday and yesterday. At the same time, the North Ossetian government said it would distribute Russian army-supplied automatic weapon to civilian volunteer. 'The Russian authority are strong enough to make all those violating the law respect it,' Russian Deputy Prime Minister Georgy Khizha, Mr Yeltsin's specialist on the Caucasus, told Russian television. The Russian action mirrored recent development in the former Soviet republic of Tajikistan, where Russian troop have also been deployed. The Central Asian nation, which ha yet to form it own army since the Soviet Union collapsed last December, ha also distributed weapon to civilian. On October 26-27 Russian soldier played a crucial role in crushing a coup attempt in the Tajik capital of Dushanbe. The Caucasus mountain, which stretch from southern Russia to the border of Turkey and Iran, are engulfed by several conflict. Among them are Georgia's war with Abkhazian separatist, and Azerbaijan's conflict with ethnic Armenians in Nagorno-Karabakh. Moldavia, acting to defuse one of the Soviet Union's most explosive ethnic conflict, agreed Sunday to comply with a Kremlin order to reconsider it law making Moldavian the republic's official language. The republic's parliament acted in response to a decree issued on Dec. 22 by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the official news agency Tass reported. Gorbachev also gave the republic 10 day to dissolve a new national guard and to come up with measure guaranteeing equal right for all ethnic group within it border. Tass said the Moldavan parliament agreed to disband the nationalguard and to revise a law that Gorbachev said restricted the right of minority. Ethnic tension ha gripped Moldavia, a largely agricultural republic bordering Romania, during it push for independence from the Soviet Union this year. The unrest turned violent last month, when government troop clashed with activist, leaving four dead. Gorbachev said the conflict had reached critical level, and he put part of the blame on the Moldavian Supreme Soviet for enacting law that discriminate against minority. Alarmed by rising Moldavian nationalism, two of the republic's minority group have begun their own separatist movement. The Gagauz, a group of about 150,000 Turkish Christians, declared a new republic in southern Moldavia. In the eastern part of Moldavia, more than 300,000 ethnic Russians and Ukrainians have joined in declaring a new republic along the Dneister River. All three group claim discrimination by Moldavians. In particular, they resent a new law making Moldavian the official language and requiring people in dozen of job ranging from doctor to hairdresser to pas Moldavian language test by 1995. Tass did not say how the Moldavian parliament would modify the law. Moldavian is identical to Romanian except for the Cyrillic script Josef Stalin imposed on the republic. It is spoken by two-thirds of the republic's resident. Soviet hard-liners want Gorbachev to impose a state of emergency and presidential rule in troubled zone throughout the ethnically and geographically diverse country. Gorbachev said the declaration of the Gagauz and Dniester republic wa illegal under the Soviet and Moldavian constitution, a were election to form legislature and any action by those body. The Moldavian legislature ha also voted to declare the election null and void. After resident of the Gagauz region began holding local election in late October, the Moldavian legislature clamped a two-month state of emergency on the region, restricting movement in and out of the area and banning public rally. Volunteer brigade of college-age Moldavians, who then flocked to the region to try to stop the separatist movement, were ordered dissolved by Gorbachev's decree. The volunteer were organized by nationalist group, including the Moldavian People's Front. A CEASEFIRE in Moldova wa threatened yesterday when a truck driver transporting militiaman wa shot dead by machinegun fire in the self-proclaimed Trans Dnestr republic, home of the Russian-speaking minority. The shooting came shortly after the ceasefire came into effect between the Moldovan authority, dominated by ethnic Romanians, and the minority based in the republic on the east bank of the river Dnestr. At least nine people have been killed in clash over the past week. As in the more severe conflict in Nagorno-Karabakh, the underlying tension are growing and neither side belief it is losing. In other respect, however, the conflict are quite different and illustrate the complexity of conflict with which the former Soviet Union is now faced. The Trans Dnestr conflict stem directly from the breakup of the Soviet Union while Nagorno-Karabakh ha been a source of tension between Azeris and Armenians for century. Moldova (formerly Moldavia) wa finally taken under full Soviet control in 1944. The Soviet leadership sought to stifle any attempt to preserve it former link with Romania - calling Moldovan a separate language from Romanian, and constructing a separate history for the Moldovan people. Industry wa largely situated on the left bank of the Dnestr, in the sliver of the republic next to Ukraine, and largely staffed by Russians and Ukrainians. Ukrainians and Russians together represent some 27 per cent of the population, with Moldovans accounting for 64 per cent. The little republic (4.5m people) wa slow to respond to the stirring of reform. When it did, in 1989, a language movement quickly put the hardline Communist Party on the defensive and it lost power in 1990 to the present nationalist government, headed by President Mircea Snegur, the former secretary of the Moldovan Party's central committee. From the beginning of the nationalist movement, it wa clear that the Russian and, to a lesser extent, the Ukrainian minority would be hostile, reacting to law establishing Moldovan a the official language and to call for renewed union with Romania with strike and demonstration, and, finally last year, proclaiming Trans Dnestr independent under a Russian president, Mr Igor Smirnov. During the August coup last year, the Moldovan government stoutly rejected it and the Trans Dnestr authority welcomed it, siding with the Soviet army in it brief effort to impose military rule. Thereafter, the two side have gathered military force. The Trans Dnestr side ha been augmented by Cossacks from nearby area returning to their traditional role a defender of Russia's border. The daily Izvestia reported yesterday that the Cossacks appear to have appointed themselves mercenary for the Russians (they are paid from Rbs2,000 to Rbs5,000 a week by the Trans Dnestr authorities). TROOPS OF the former Soviet Union were ordered to pull out from the Armenian enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh yesterday after they were fired on during clash between Azeri and Armenian militant. Marshal Yevgeny Shaposhnikov, the Commonwealth of Independent States' defence minister, announced the decision a fighting worsened in the disputed territory in spite of effort to secure a truce. The enclave is administered by Azerbaijan but largely populated by Armenians. The order for the pull-out of the 366th motorised regiment follows the death earlier this week of a handful of soldier caught in the fighting between Armenian guerrilla and Azerbaijani force. Fighting flared again yesterday in the capital Stepanakert, where the regiment is based. Azerbaijani and Armenian official claimed their civilian target were under particularly vicious attack. Marshal Shaposhnikov, who is also commander-in-chief, ha long warned that he would withdraw troop rather than allow them to become target of ethnic conflict in the former Soviet Union. No date have been given for the withdrawal. Troops under fire along the Armenian-Azerbaijani border will also be withdrawn. Commanders of the Trans-Caucasus military district, which encompasses Georgia a well a Armenia and Azerbaijan, have been ordered to rebuff attack on military installation. Azeri and Armenian official say sophisticated weapon, including combat helicopter, tank and armoured personnel carrier, are being used by guerrilla on both side in the four-year-old conflict. Armenian militant attacked the last Azeri stronghold in Nagorno-Karabakh yesterday, according to Azerbaijan's interior ministry, which said resident of the town of Shusha fled a helicopter gunships swooped down from snow-covered mountain. Armenians in the enclave want unification with Armenia, but Azerbaijan will not give up any territory. Ethnic violence killed 148 people and wounded 885 this month in the Central Asian republic of Kirghizia, the official news agency Tass said Wednesday. Tass said 748 of the injured had to be hospitalized and said a search wa continuing for a police officer who vanished June 7. No new outbreak were reported in the region near the border city of Osh in western Kirghizia, where clash arising from a land dispute began on June 2 between ethnic Kirghiz and Uzbeks, both Sunni Moslems. The argument involves allocation of land in a densly populated region where housing is scarce. It wa the latest in a series of bloody civil conflict to trouble President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's government. Maj. Gen. Alexander Grienko, chief of the Interior Ministry's Political Department, said that in two year of civil strife mainly ethnic clash in the Soviet Union, about 24,000 people have been arrested. He said in Moscow on Tuesday that ministry troop had to be used in 13 region of the Soviet Union because of such outbreak, Tass said. Grienko said 16 ministry soldier were killed, four were reported missing and more than 1,000 wounded. Tass did not quote Grienko on how civilian casualty. The general wa quoted a saying these conflict were often accompanied by riot and pogrom, arson and massacre of innocent people, (and) complete or partial destabilization of the situation. Besides unrest this month in Kirghizia and Uzbekistan, ethnic violence also ha been reported in recent year in Georgia, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan and Tadzhikistan. The government ha decided to give ethnic Germans and Crimean Tatars who were expelled from their homeland by Josef Stalin their own autonomous region but it will take year, Tass reported Wednesday. The ice ha been broken. A start ha been made. We're working on creating such autonomy, said Rafik Nishanov, chairman of a chamber of the Soviet legislature, in remark carried by the official news agency. However, he said, the nut and bolt of how to create the region still had to be worked out. For example, a 10-year program on resettlement. People can't just be expelled from the area for others to move in. The Tatars of the Crimea and the ethnic Germans who lived on the Volga River were forcibly resettled during World War II, when Josef Stalin kicked people out of their homeland on the ground they could not be trusted to occupy strategic area. The Tatars and Germans, among others, long have been agitating to return from Siberia and Central Asia to their traditional land, and last month the Supreme Soviet legislature declared that all people exiled under Stalin should be considered politically rehabilitated. But other people now occupy the land and house that belonged to the exile, and re-establishing their dominion in their home region will not be so simple. The Supreme Soviet took the basic decision that the two autonmous region should be created on Nov. 28 but kept it quiet, apparently fearing explosive reaction from the population now living in the region. It wa also a potentially dangerous precedent: The Soviet Union is a patchwork of well over 100 ethnic group, and many of them have outstanding territorial claim. Trouble already ha been reported between ethnic Germans and Russians in several city on the Volga. Residents of the Saratov and Volgograd region have protested the prospect of seeing many of the nation's estimated 2 million Germans descending on them. Ethnographers estimate there are some 500,000 Crimean Tatars in the Soviet Union, and another 1 million in Turkey. Their protest near the Kremlin in 1987 demanding to be allowed to return to their homeland were among the first test of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's promise of greater democracy. Several thousand Tatars have been filtering back to the Crimea each year despite the lack of wholesale permission to return. A wave of some 100,000 ethnic Germans emigrated to West Germany this year, but many would probably stay if they could be assured of their own republic, said Irina Ostroukh, a researcher at the Soviet Institute of Ethnography who study ethnic Germans. The Nov. 28 plan approved by the Supreme Soviet recommended excluding from the German region area where resistance to German resettlement wa strongest in order to avoid ethnic conflict. The explosive conflict between Armenians and Azerbaijanis over the Nagorno-Karabakh region ha led to 200 death and hundred of thousand of refugee in the last two year. Both side claim control over the mountainous enclave. The Supreme Soviet charged the government with creating a commmission to determine how to create the region for the Germans and Crimean Tatars. RUSSIA and Georgia yesterday deployed 'blue helmet' troop to stop ethnic fighting in the disputed region of South Ossetia in the first peace-keeping operation since the collapse of the Soviet Union, Reuter report from Moscow. Reports from the remote Transcaucasian region said hundred of heavily armed Russian troop from the 104th paratroop battalion moved into a 7km-wide security zone separating rebel South Ossetia from the rest of Georgia. Georgian national guard occupied similar position on their side of the border and pulled out all their men from the South Ossetian capital of Tskhinvali. But Itar-Tass news agency said gunfire overnight near the city killed four civilian and injured two others, underscoring the difficulty facing the operation. The mission wa the first peace-keeping attempt anywhere in the former Soviet Union, whose disintegration last year ha prompted wave of bloodletting in ethnic flashpoint from the Romanian to the Afghan border. Reports from the former Soviet republic of Moldova said several people had been killed overnight in fresh ceasefire violation between government force and separatist. In the Transcaucasian republic of Armenia, Radio Russia said five civilian had died overnight in Azerbaijani shelling, the latest victim of a four-year undeclared war which ha killed 2,000 people. Russia and Georgia were cautiously optimistic that Ossetia could be the first region of the former Soviet Union where armed conflict could be resolved with the help of 'political measure and actions'. South Ossetia is part of Georgia but want to unite with neighbouring North Ossetia, which wa assigned to Russia by Stalin. Hundreds have been killed since 1990 in fighting between Georgians and Ossetians. The peace-keepers have been issued with UN-style light-blue helmet band and matching chevron on their sleeve. They will be joined later by a multi-ethnic force - Russians, Ukrainians, Ossetians and other mountain people - under the nominal command of North Ossetian leader. The peace-keepers' mission is to form a physical barrier between the two side, opening the way to future talk. The greatest threat is expected to come from hundred of armed fighter on both side, operating independently in a dozen or so band outside the control of either Russian or Georgian authority. Interfax news agency said Russia's Vice-President Alexander Rutskoi, at present on a visit to Moldova, proposed a similar peace-keeping operation there.

column3: The Chinese government say that 300 soldier, thug, bystander and student have been killed during the martial law occupation of Beijing. But most other estimate of casualty are far higher. State Council spokesman Yuan Mu said on Tuesday that 7,000 people, including 5,000 soldier, have been injured and 400 other soldier are missing and may be dead or wounded. Non-official source say Yuan's figure on civilian casualty are far too low, but most have different estimate on the number of victim. They range from 500 to 12,000 people slain. In Washington, US. intelligence report indicate 3,000 people probably were killed, according to a US. official who spoke on condition of anonymity. He said estimate of the number of dead could go higher. Nearly all of the death and injury occurred Saturday night and early Sunday when troop, firing randomly into large crowd, smashed through barricade to reach Tiananmen square and attack demonstrator demanding democratic reform. One doctor said Sunday that a quick check of 10 hospital placed the death toll at 500. Other source, compiling various report and survey, estimated more than 1,000 people had been killed. That number ha increased with additional detail and rumor of killing. Some official of China's Red Cross said 2,600 people were killed but Beijing's Red Cross office ha refused to provide any figure. One Hong Kong newspaper reported 5,000 death and 30,000 injured. An Eastern European diplomat, whose country ha good relation with China, insisted that 12,000 people were slain by soldier a they attacked protester in Tiananmen Square. That figure is certainly high. Probably fewer than 10,000 people were in the square when the troop moved in and most were able to escape unharmed. But student who had joined the Tiananmen occupation said hundred of colleague from the Academy of Fine Arts who were huddled around their Goddess of Democracy statue in the square were shot or crushed by tank. Beijing University student said 150 of their fellow student who were in the square are missing. There were rumor that after the square wa cleared troop burned many corps in large bonfire and other body were removed by helicopter and garbage truck to minimize the death count. Yuan's statement said only 23 of the 300 people fatally injured were student. The exact number of people killed may never be known. Victims were taken to dozen of hospital, clinic and home, and there is no indication the government will reveal many detail of the tragedy. And the death toll mount.
