Troops manning checkpoint in central Beijing continue to fire on unfriendly crowd and victim fall. Here is a look at key event in the student pro-democracy movement that led to Sunday's assault by soldier on protester in Tiananmen Square: April 15 Former Communist Party chief Hu Yaobang dy. Beijing University student put up poster praising him and indirectly criticizing opponent who forced his resignation after student demonstration in 1986-87. April 17 Thousands of student march in Beijing and Shanghai, shouting Long live Hu Yaobang! Long live democracy! April 27 More than 150,000 student, with wide support from people on the street, surge past police line and fill Tiananmen Square, chanting slogan for democracy and freedom. April 29 Officials meet with student leader, but independent student group are not satisfied and continue a class boycott at 41 university. April 30 Beijing's Communist Party chief, Zhao Ziyang, meet with student representative. May 4 About 100,000 student and supporter march on Tiananmen Square to celebrate the 70th anniversary of China's first student movement. Demonstrations are held in Shanghai, Nanjing and other city. About 300 journalist protest outside the official Xinhua News Agency. May 9 Journalists petition the government for press freedom. May 10 Thousands of student bicycle to major medium office in a press freedom demonstration. Another protest is held in the provincial capital of Taiyuan. May 13 About 2,000 student begin a hunger strike in Tiananmen Square. May 14 Thousands flock to the square to back the student. The number fasting rise to 3,000. May 15 The government deadline for student to leave the square pass. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's welcoming ceremony planned near the square must be moved to the airport. May 16 Hundreds of thousand occupy the square. Journalists and intellectual join the protest. May 17 Zhao plea for student to leave. Students reject his appeal and hold march that generate 1 million supporter in Beijing. May 18 About 1 million people, including many worker, again take to the street to show their support for the hunger striker. Li Peng issue a stern lecture to student leader and refuse to discus their demand. May 19 A tearful Zhao visit weakened hunger striker. Li also visit the student briefly. The student later decide to end the hunger strike. May 20 Martial law is declared in part of Beijing. Zhao reportedly resigns after failing to persuade Li and other hardliner to compromise. Students resume their hunger strike, then abandon it, saying they will need their strength for the struggle ahead. May 21 Students claim to reject an order by Li Peng to leave the Tiananman Square or face military action. Defying martial law, hundred of thousand of people remain in the square or block intersection to prevent troop from reaching it. May 22 Hundreds of thousand of people again block major road and senior military leader say they are resisting order to order their troop on the protester. At least one military convoy is reported to withdraw. May 23 One million people take to the street to demonstrate for democracy. May 25 Li make his first appearance since declaring martial law. State- run radio say 27 of 29 province support martial law, and military unit announce they support martial law. May 26 Sources say Zhao and another leading liberal, Wan Li, head of the legislature, are under house arrest. May 27 Beijing student leader propose student end their occupation of Tiananmen Square. Non-Beijing student resist and the sit-in continues. May 28 About 80,000 people, many student from outside the capital, stage a demonstration, but unlike in past rally few worker participate. May 30 Students unveil their Goddess of Democracy, a replica of the Statue of Liberty, on the square. The government call it an insult to the nation. Students rally outside police headquarters to protest the detention of three member of an independent labor union. May 31 The first of several pro-government rally is staged by farmer and worker in Beijing suburb. The participant, ordered to show up, show little enthusiasm. June 1 The Beijing Municipal Government warns foreign journalist that under martial law they must receive approval for all press coverage. Coverage of the demonstration is banned. June 2 More than 1,000 troop appear outside the railway station in a show of force. June 3-4 Tens of thousand of troop make several attempt to move on the square but are driven back by crowd of hundred of thousand of people supporting the student. Riot squad beat and fire tear gas at demonstrator. A final push is made the evening of June 3, and soldier begin firing on crowd. Troops surround and enter the square June 4 in the early morning hour and thousand of protester flee. Hundreds are wounded and many dead. Dawn broke Sunday over a battle-scarred Tiananmen Square with tank and rifle-toting troop ruling the vast expanse occupied the day before by student seeking a freer society from their communist ruler. A low cloud of smoke covered much of the 100-acre square a bonfire set during the night's confrontation continued to smolder. Hundreds of helmeted troop were deployed on the monument to revolutionary hero in the square's center and thousand more at important intersection nearby. Tanks moved into place on what had hour earlier been a rag-tag squatter's camp of tent for the pro-democracy student. The battle for Tiananmen wa primarily fought in the street leading to the square, where score of people fell trying to prevent column of troop and armored military vehicle from moving on the student. Gunfire could be heard from several side, and tracer zipped through the sky above Mao Tse-tung's mausoleum, one of the main monument to Chinese communism in the square. Torched bus and army vehicle on the street around Tiananmen billowed acrid smoke. Troops first entered the square from the south, when a column trotted toward the student encampment about 1 am. (noon EDT Saturday). They took up position to the east after a brief skirmish involving club and stick with student. More soldier were deployed in front of the Great Hall of the People to the west, and a huge convoy with armored vehicle rolled down Changan Avenue to the north side. The few thousand student remaining in the square stayed calm a they quietly gathered on the step of the heroes' monument. I'm not afraid, several said a the heavily armed troop encircled. Hundreds of supporter continued to mill around the square, many dressed more for a summer outing than a military battle. Loudspeakers blaring government and student announcement engaged in a noisy propaganda battle throughout the night. The government is corrupt, you've been tricked, the student roared. The state-run speaker warned that troop would use every mean at their disposal to clear the square and that remaining student would bear responsibility for the consequence. At 4 a.m., the lamposts that dot the square went ominously dark, and the student loudspeaker played the Internationale, the socialist anthem. A Taiwan singer staging a hunger strike for democracy took the microphone and proclaimed: We've achieved a big victory. . We're not afraid to die, but we've already lost too much blood. After the light went back on a half hour later, a voice vote by the student showed most wanted to leave the square to avoid further bloodshed. They quickly filed out under the banner of their school, carrying the quilt and padded jacket that offered warmth during the 22-day sit-in. Neither the student nor the Beijing resident who arrived to show support could control their tear. Go with u, they told their supporter, who applauded the student a they retreated. As they sobbed, many student defiantly shouted: We shall return! and flashed V-for-victory sign. Gone from Tiananmen Square are the pro-democracy banner and the tent of China's freedom movement, replaced by tank, armed guard and the chant of drilling soldier. The army on Thursday allowed the people of Beijing their first glance of the 100-acre expanse since the military swept into the capital six day ago, leaving hundred dead and crushing a movement for political change. Troops moved back their barricade, making it possible for city resident to walk to the edge of the square, which for seven week stood at the heart of the movement. Buses and bicyclist today were allowed to pas by Changan Avenue, which border the north edge of the square. The spot once occupied by the Goddess of Democracy, a 33-foot-high replica of the Statue of Liberty, wa taken by a tread-wheeled armored personnel carrier. When student built the statue last week, for a few day it became a symbol of the movement for democratic reform and an end to official corruption. On Sunday morning, a tank crushed it. In all, 80 tank and 40 armored personnel carrier lined the northern part of the square. The Monument to Revolutionary Martyrs, where the student took a final stand early Sunday, wa swept clean. Poems and poster calling for a more open China have disappeared from it side. Chinese Red Cross official estimate 3,600 people were killed and 60,000 injured over the weekend, citing a Chinese students' organization, the Union of Chinese Students in West Germany. The government say nearly 300 people, mostly soldier, were killed; diplomat and Chinese say up to 3,000 died. Soldiers drilled in Tiananmen's center, their cadenced shouting echoing around the vast expanse. A crowd of official stood on the roof of the Great Hall of the People, overlooking the square. From this same roof five day earlier official watched a a jubilant mass of demonstrator enveloped 5,000 troop and blocked their entry to the square. Inside the square, soldier could be seen shuffling about, their uniformed jacket stripped off, wash basin in hand. There wa a relaxed air of the inside of an army barrack a unarmed troop carried food and walked slowly together, talking and laughing in group. The area once housing students' tent ha become a holding area for a huge fleet of troop truck. On the southern perimeter, a single line of tank and a cordon of soldier blocked the square from the thousand of bicylists who pedaled slowly by, peering into Tiananmen. Near the square, troop placed barbed wire in front of one street. Soldiers were billeted in a construction site, their laundered fatigue drying on the scaffolding. Next door, troop, their assault rifle slung nonchalantly over their shoulder, stood and chatted outside a discotheque. They look like they , said one local resident. I hope they know that we still don't want them here. Here is a chronology of event that began Saturday in Tiananmen Square: 1 am. Saturday (12 noon EDT Friday) Tens of thousand of troop enter Beijing from the east marching toward Tiananmen Square, China's symbolic political heart. Military unit also seen approaching from the west and the north. 2 am. The main body of troop is stopped several hundred yard east of the vast square by thousand of people. 2 am. to 9 am. Troops straggle away from their position near the square, walking in small group followed by watchful resident. 12 noon Two truckloads of People's Armed Police attack crowd outside Beijing Hotel east of the square and up to 30 people injured. 2 pm. About 5,000 troop emerge from Great Hall of the People on the western side of the square and are surrounded by crowd. People's Armed Police fire tear gas and use club to beat protester west of the square in a 30-minute attack. 4:30 pm. Stone- and bottle-throwing demonstrator skirmish with troop outside the Great Hall. Troops swinging belt attack crowd. Some soldier injured by flying debris. 6 pm. Thousands of resident surround two troop convoy on a main highway in northeastern Beijing. 7 pm. National television repeat martial law regulation and warns people to stay off the street and away from Tiananmen Square. 8:30 pm. Troops retreat into the Great Hall. 9 pm. More than 20,000 people block a 26-truck convoy about 2{ mile east of the square and thousand of others converge on the square to protect student demanding demoncratic reform. Crowds throw rock at troop contingent 4{ mile west of Tiananmen. 9 p.m.-10 pm. Troops hurl tear gas then open fire on the crowd. 12 midnight Armored vehicle break through barricade and about 40 truck carrying military personnel slowly advance toward the square from the west. 1 am. Sunday. Troops dash through flame caused by a burning-bus barricade at the major intersection of Xidan west of the square. More people shot a troop fire at crowd. A smaller group of about 1,000 military personnel enters the square from the east and shooting erupts. 2 am. Thousands of troop arrive at the west side of the square and some of the rifleman open fire. 3:30 am. Military unit surround the square, trapping several thousand student inside. 4:30 am. Armored personnel carrier enter the square. Students are told by loudspeaker that troop will move in and clear the area. 5 am. Demonstrators, many walking hand-in-hand, begin leaving the square, ending their three-week occupation. Chinese troop stormed Tiananmen Square early Sunday, shooting and beating their way through crowd of pro-democracy protester in clash that witness and doctor said killed at least 32 people. Hundreds were wounded. The troop cut a violent swath through the heart of Beijing to get to the the square, rolling through barricade and surging mass on the surrounding street. By 3:30 a.m., soldier and riot police had surrounded Tiananmen, boxing off several thousand student and supporter concentrated around a monument to revolutionary hero in the center. A half hour later, light were turned out. The square wa in darkness. You have to give up all hope, student said over their loudspeaker at the monument. You have to give your life to the movement. Students sang the Internationale, the communist anthem. At 4:30 a.m., armored personnel carrier entered the square and troop began moving slowly toward several thousand student clustered around a monument to revolutionary hero in the center. Sporadic gunfire could still be heard on the outskirt of the square a troop shot at crowd of thousand. The death and casualty toll wa believed to be mounting rapidly. Ambulances and bicycle pedicab went back and forth hauling away the wounded. One man wa seen shot in the back, another in the head. An official loudspeaker on the square announced that the troop were moving in to clear the area a soldier prepared to advance from all four side. Ho Te-chien, a Taiwanese singer who defected to China in 1983 and ha been active in the student movement, urged the student to leave. We're not afraid to die, but we've already lost too much blood, he said over a student loudspeaker. A 33-foot-high replica of the Statue of Liberty, set up by student last week, remained standing. The main street leading to the Tiananmen, China's symbolic political center, were sealed. Thousands fled from the square, where hundred of thousand of people had gathered to support student in the third week of a sit-in. The assault came two week after Premier Li Peng declared martial law in Beijing and sent troop to the city. Hundreds of thousand of resident responded by blocking road with truck and their body. In Washington, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Saturday the situation in China had become ugly and chaotic. This will disturb the United States government, and will disturb the American people, considerably, he said. The secretary hinted that there could be repercussion to the Chinese government's use of violence. The standoff between troop and protester had been tense but largely peaceful for week, with soldier seemingly reluctant or unable to move against the crowd until the first widespread violence broke out Saturday afternoon. A doctor from the Fuxing Hospital in western Beijing, where troop began firing on street people, said the hospital had taken in 15 dead and so many wounded they had to be put in garage. A doctor from another hospital said 12 people died there. One soldier wa killed when he wa run over by an armored personnel carrier rushing toward the square, and another man wa reported shot to death in a street clash elsewhere. A Swedish visitor, Tom Hansson, said he saw three people shot to death in clash south of the square. The government is fascist! How can they do this to me? How can they do this to the people? cried a 28-year-old man who wa shot in the leg. Most of those shot on the square were hurling rock at the troop and people close to their front line. A government loudspeaker on the square charged the student with counterrevolutionary turmoil and said the military wa taking necessary mean to end their rebellion. Sporadic clash and dozen of injury were reported on Saturday a soldier made several attempt to reach the square. They retreated momentarily under barrage of rock, shoe and other object, then resumed their most violent push at about 8 pm. Saturday, firing weapon and using tear gas and club a they moved toward Tiananmen. Thousands of troop armed with rifle marched up the east side of the square, beating people who got in their way. Students threw Molotov cocktail and other object at them. One armored personnel carrier rammed into a burning bus on Changan Avenue, the main street running along the square, and wa torched by student. Two people inside were dragged out by the crowd and beaten severely. Other armored personnel carrier drove up and down the avenue smashing down lane divider and other barrier set up by citizen to block the army's way. More than 5,000 people chanting Freedom will survive! packed a Chinatown park this morning in a memorial service for student slain by soldier in Tiananmen Square. They then marched through the street in a funeral procession. The god are cry for what's happening in China today. It's a great tragedy, said Harry Zinn of International Ladies Garment Workers Union Local 2325, addressing the crowd through a steady rain. Our heart go out to the people of China. The crowd, which stood respectfully and silently during a traditional funeral ceremony, waved banner and wore button honoring the martyr of Tiananmen Square and calling for democracy in China. After the service and several speech, the crowd marched through the street of Chinatown, led by a casket and a traditional Chinese funeral bier containing fruit and incense. As they headed up Mulberry Street, a major street in Chinatown, they walked beneath a 30-foot black banner strung across the road. This ha united the Chinese people for one cause to overthrow the government and establish democracy, said Peter Lee, one of the student organizer of the service. We must never allow them to crush another body. The funeral procession stretched for block through Chinatown, tying up traffic. Demonstrators planned another rally later in the day outside the United Nations. Here is a look at key event in the student pro-democracy movement, the government crackdown and the fighting between rival army factions: Here is a look at key event in the student pro-democracy movement and at event since Sunday's assault by soldier on protester in Tiananmen Square:
column5: Tiananmen Square Killings Not Fatal to Pro-democracy movement.
column6: The deadly use of military force against its citizens by the government of China in Beijing's Tiananmen Square June 3-4, 1989 left thousands dead, resulted in great damage to China's repute abroad, exacerbated internal disputes, and was not a fatal blow to the pro-democracy movement in China.
column7: The military assault on pro-democracy students in Tiananmen Square onJune 3-4, 1989 cost at least 2,600 lives and perhaps as many as12,000. 2,000 students had encamped in the square and begun a hungerstrike in May and a million citizens rallied to their support. Whenthe declaration of martial law did not intimidate the students andtheir supporters, the government resorted to the use of massiveforce. The pro- democracy movement started after the death of formerCommunist Party chief Hu Yaobang on April 15, 1989 with studentsshouting "Long live Hu Yaobang! Long live democracy!"
column8: On June 3, 1989 at 1 a.m. tens of thousands of troops entered Beijing marching toward Tiananmen Square to dislodge student pro-democracy demonstrators who had  encamped there for three weeks. Within 28 hours the students were dispersed at a cost in lives estimated by the Chinese government at 300-400, by officials of the Chinese Red Cross as 2,600, and by others as between 3,000 and 12,000. The crisis was not at an end, however, as soldiers continued random shooting of civilians and rival factions of the Chinese army started shooting at one another. During June 5-9 governments around the world condemned the brutal suppression advising theirnationals to leave Beijing. Chinese abroad mourned the dead. Anti-government demonstrations spread to Shanghai, Nanjing, and other cities. The pro-democracy movement had its origin with the death of former Communist Party chief Hu Yaobang on April 15, 1989. By April 17 thousands of students marched in Beijing and Shanghai shouting "Long live Hu Yaobang! Long live democracy!" The protest movement focused on Tiananmen Square when 2,000 students began a hunger strike there  and a million citizens rallied to their support. When declaration of martial law did not intimidate the protesters the government resorted to the massive use of troops and firepower.
column9: Chinese Troops Crush Student Reformers. Thousand Killed In Tiananmen Square.
column10: Chinese troops fought through crowds of protesters on 3 June 1989, killing thousands as they crushed the reform-minded student demonstrators in Tiananmen Square. Surviving students fled the square, ending their defiant three-week occupation of the square. Later demonstrations in other Chinese cities protested the Beijing slaughter.
column11: Firing indiscriminately on the crowds as they advanced, Chinese troops broke through barricades of reform-minded protesters late on 3 June1989 and reached Tiananmen Square after being rebuffed in earlier attempts. Early the next day they routed the surviving demonstrators who fled the square that had occupied for three weeks in defiance of government orders. Thousands died in the two days of violence. The bloody weekend was the climax of trouble that had escalated since April.Later demonstrations in other large Chinese cities protested the Beijing slaughter. The United States suspended all military sales to China.
column12: Late on Saturday evening, 3 June 1989, Chinese troops broke through barricades on streets leading to Tiananmen Square. The soldiers fired indiscriminately on the crowds as they scattered resisters. The troops had previously been unsuccessful in reaching the square. By noon on 4 June the troops had crushed the demonstrators for political reform and forced them to flee the square they had occupied for three weeks in defiance of  government orders issued under martial law. The army soon removed evidence of the protest , including the student-built replica of the Statue of Liberty.The bloody weekend was the climax of trouble that had been escalating since April. It had grown tense, but largely peaceful during the three weeks prior to 3 June.The government insisted that only 300 were killed. The Chinese Red Cross said 3,600 died and 60,000 were injured. Most of those killed on 3 and 4 June fell in streets leading to Tiananmen.Demonstrations in Shanghai, Nanjing, and other large Chinese cities on 5 June protested the slaughter in Beijing. The United States suspended all military sales to China. Many foreign embassies urged their citizens to leave Beijing.

column3: Beijing, June 20 (XINHUA) -- Floods continue to have serious effect in Guangdong, Hunan and Jiangxi Provinces and the Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region in southern China. Information from the State Flood Control and Drought Relief Headquarters revealed that the flood peak on the Xijiang River today reached Guangdong Province. By eight o'clock yesterday morning, a peak flood water level of 25.91 m [meters] wa recorded at the flood monitoring station of Guangxi's Wuzhou city, 10.91 m above the danger level. Flood water ha entered urban and suburban area of Wuzhou city, and most of it transport and telecommunication with the outside were suspended. This city border Guangdong and lie on the Xunjiang River, the name for the upper reach of the Xijiang River. The speed of the flood-water wa recorded a 46,200 cu [cubic] m per second, the most ferocious since the founding of New China in 1949. The flood peak on the Beijiang River in Guangdong Province passed through Qingyuan city by 23:00 hour last night, and the water level wa recorded a 14.72 m, about 4.22 m above the danger mark; the speed wa 17,400 cu m per second. Flood control work in the Pearl River (Zhujiang) Delta area is also very intense. The State Council, China's highest governing body, recently sent a joint working group formed by the Ministries of Water Resources, Construction and Civil Affairs to help fight flood in Guangxi and in Guangdong. At 11 o'clock on Saturday, the flood peak on the Xiangjiang River passed through Changsha city, capital of central China's Hunan Province. The water level recorded at the local monitoring station wa 38.93 m, some 3.93 m above danger level. High flood water level were also recorded at Hengyang and Xiangtan city. About 118 town of eight prefecture and city along the Xiangjiang River were flooded. Flood water ha also entered more than 20 street and lane of Changsha, and more than 300,000 city dweller were affected. More than 400 factory and 5,000 shop were forced to stop production or stop business. More than half a million Armymen and local resident, under the leadership of the Hunan provincial party provincial committee and provincial people's government, are going all out to fight the flood. By 22:00 hour last night, the flood peak passed through Nanchang city, provincial capital of Jiangxi. Statistics from the local monitoring station show that the flood water level wa 25.42 m, about 2.62 m above the danger mark, and the speed of the flood wa 19,100 cu m per second. The Jiangxi provincial party committee and people's government are mobilizing local people and the troop stationed there to combat the flood. The State Flood Control and Drought Relief Headquarters ha sent special team of people to help fight flood in Hunan and Jiangxi. Meanwhile, drought is continuing to blight most area of northern China and northeastern China, with about 15.3 million hectare of land affected. In the drought-stricken area, 12 million people and 12 million head of livestock are short of drinking water, according to the State Flood Control and Drought Relief Headquarters. Comrade Wen Jiabao [member of CPC Central Committee Secretariat] and his party left Changsha for Zhuzhou and Xiangtan yesterday. He inspected the flooded area, including Zhuzhou City's Xiawan dike, the Hexi New and High Technology Development Zone, and Linghuayuan and Xiangtan's Yangtianhu, Xingxiadi, Zhoujiangdi, and Shiwandalou, where rescue and relief work wa in full swing. After listening to report submitted by the two city on their effort to fight the flooding and do relief work, he issued important instruction. Comrade Wen Jiabao fully affirmed the initial victory that the two city have scored in their flood fighting and relief work under the leadership of the provincial party committee and government. He said: In fighting flood and doing relief work, the broad mass of cadre and people in Zhuzhou and Xiangtan sacrificed their interest to rescue a large number of industrial and mining enterprise, the Beijing-Guangzhou Railway, the 107 National Highway, and city and thus minimized the loss caused by flood. This fully show that, with party leadership and the socialist system, we will be able to overcome all difficulty. Regarding the work in the next stage, he pointed out: We should continue to take flood fighting and relief task a the focus of our current work and simultaneously do a good job of reform, opening up to the outside world, stability, other field of work, and industrial and agricultural production. He said: After the water recedes, we should firmly grasp the opportunity and repair the damaged dike and embankment. As the highest flood season ha not yet arrived, we should be prepared at any time to meet new flood peak head-on rather than slacken our effort. We should try every possible mean to provide food, clothing, and shelter to flood victim, pay special attention to preventing and curing disease, and concentrate effort on the resumption of production and the reconstruction of home. He particularly stressed: The current flooding ha revealed problem in the construction of water conservancy facility and urban flood control. In the past, inadequate consideration ha been given to urban flood control and the coordination of urban and rural flood control. In the next step, we should earnestly draw a lesson from this negative experience. Governor Chen Bangzhu urged the party committee and government of Zhuzhou and Xiangtan to convey Comrade Wen Jiabao's regard and instruction on behalf of the party Central Committee and the State Council for the broad mass of cadre and people to the party committee and government at all level a soon a possible, earnestly implement them, and effectively carry out the work of fighting flood, doing relief work, and helping oneself by engaging in production. Fuzhou, June 22 (CNS) -- Flood lasting for ten or more day in Fujian Province ha brought about heavy loss in agriculture there. According to the latest information offered by the Provincial Agricultural Bureau, a total area of 2.465 million mu of crop have been hit by the flood and of which, 446 000 mu of crop will have no yield, 1.957 million mu of grain have been heavily hit and some 300 million kilogram grain are expected to be lost. Among nine city and prefecture in Fujian, those seriously hit by the flood are Sanming, Nanping, Ningde, Fuzhou, Quanzhou and Putian. Of these, Sanming City is worst hit by the flood. In May, the city wa hit by the heavy rainstorm and had big loss and now it suffers again from the flood with some 600 000 mu of crop damaged by flood and 200 million kilogram grain expected to be lost. Per caput possession of cultivated land in Fujian is only 0.05 mu. Even if in the normal year, grain output there is not self- sufficient. The consecutive flood ha made agricultural production situation there more grim. Disaster-relief group have been sent to the flood-stricken area striving for minimizing loss. Changsha, June 19 (XINHUA) -- This capital of central China's Hunan province ha been hit by flood in the wake of a succession of rainstorm on the upper and middle reach of the Xiangjiang River. The water level of the river, which flow through Changsha, is still rising sharply, according to local source. By four o'clock this afternoon the level recorded at the Changsha monitoring station had risen to 38.93 m, some 0.56 m higher than the highest figure ever previously recorded. The flood ha caused serious loss to people along both bank of the river, especially in Changsha, according to the source. In the early hour of yesterday six village and one fishing ground at Yulushan township were flooded when an embankment collapsed. Most of the 15,000 people affected by the flood there have been evacuated to safer place. By six o'clock yesterday afternoon 19 dyke in the Changsha area had collapsed, and a total of 128,000 urban and rural resident had been affected. A partial collapse of the grand Longwangang embankment at the Xihu fishing ground in the Wangyuehu district of Changsha ha put the life and property of 60,000 people in danger. But thanks to the concerted rescue effort of 2,000 local cadre, resident and soldier there wa no loss of life. The city government of Changsha ha asked resident within the endangered area to relocate themselves and remove their property to safer place, in case of the occurrence of more serious flooding. By the early hour of this morning road and surface of bridge in the Wangyuehu district had been inundated. The flood water had also reached the boulevard along the Xiangjiang River, Xiahe Street and the western part of Zhongshan Street in Changsha proper. So far, more than 500,000 soldier and local resident have moved in to help fight the flood. Meanwhile, the Changsha city committee of the Communist Party ha held an emergency meeting, urging all department and the people of the whole city to carry forward the spirit of continuous fighting and unite a one in battling the flood. Wang Maolin, secretary of the Hunan Provincial Party Committee, who is now in the province's southern city of Zhuzhou to direct anti-flood effort there. In a telephone call to the Changsha city government, he called on local official to adopt effective measure, ensure the safety of the life and property of the resident of Changsha and make an overall success of the work to conquer the flood. Guangzhou, 19 Jun (XINHUA) -- Jiang Zemin, general secretary of the CPC Central Committee Political Bureau and chairman of the Central Military Commission, and Li Peng, premier of the State Council, are very much concerned about flood in Guangdong Province. Recently, they repeatedly inquired about the flood situation in the Zhu Jiang valley, particularly that of Bei Jiang and Xi Jiang. They expressed their deep concern for the people in the flood-hit area, a well a extended their warm greeting to the vast number of cadre, officer, and men of the People's Liberation Army; armed police officers; and public security police who battle on the frontline against flood and provide disaster relief. Jiang Zemin and Li Peng gave important directive for current flood prevention and disaster relief task in Guangdong. They expressed the hope that under the leadership of the Guangdong provincial party committee and government, the Guangdong army and people would make concerted effort in disaster relief; earnestly help flood victim solve their living problems; and go all out to battle flood to ensure the safety of the Bei Jiang dike, Guangzhou city, and the Zhu Jiang Delta. Guangzhou, June 23 (XINHUA) -- The highest flood peak on the Xijiang and Beijiang Rivers have passed, said Zhu Senlin, governor of south China's Guangdong Province. While inspecting flood control and relief work in Qingyuan city on the Beijiang River yesterday, he attributed Guangdong's success in combating this flood -- almost the biggest in 100 year -- to concerted effort by the armymen stationed in Guangdong and local resident. More than 200 people lost their life in the natural disaster, which destroyed 189,000 room and ruined crop on 1.2 million hectare. The flood wa caused by successive torrential rainstorm in the Xijiang and Beijiang River valley in early and middle June. Major flood monitoring station on the two river recorded their highest water level, all four meter above the danger mark. Local government at various level in the province have paid close attention to flood control work, and leading government and communist party official of different locality have gone to the flood-fighting front. No breach of major embankment or reservoir were reported despite the most serious flood in a hundred year, effectively protecting the safety of the provincial capital, Guangzhou, and the Pearl (Zhujiang) River Delta. But the loss caused by the flood were quite serious, said the governor. According to him, 11 million people in the province's nine city and 55 county were affected, and more than 200 people died in the natural disaster, with 189,000 room destroyed and 1.2 million hectare of crop ruined. The direct economic loss were set at 10.2 billion yuan. The governor warned that though the flood danger had receded, the determination to fight possible further flood could not slacken, a this is just the beginning: the main flood season, which usually begin in late July and early August, ha not yet arrived. He urged local official to be on constant alert against further possible flood and be meticulous about flood prevention and control measure, while doing their utmost to help flood victim, assisting them to resume production a soon a possible and maintaining social stability. Beijing, June 26 (XINHUA) -- Floods have all receded along Xijiang, Beijiang, Xiangjiang and Ganjiang except at a section of the Xijiang River in Wuzhou city, Guangxi, a spokesman from the State Flood Control and Drought Relief Headquarters announced today. The spokesman attributed the falling water level to the major water conservancy project which help to mitigate loss. Meanwhile, he said, tension ha been eased in the Pearl River delta a the latest tropical storm ha been weakened after landing in Yangjiang city, Guangdong Province. Floods hit Guangdong, Guangxi, Hunan, Jiangxi, Fujiang and Zhejiang province following the first heavy rain and flood which typically hit China from the south to the north from June to August. Earlier report said that successive torrential rainstorm in the Xijiang and Beijiang river valley in early and mid-June resulted in a big flood, one of the most serious in 100 year, in Guangdong Province and caused heavy loss. Major flood monitoring station on the two river recorded their highest water level, all four meter above the warning level. In an urgent conference late yesterday, the Guangdong provincial government urged locality to help flood victim with food, shelter, clothing and medical care so that no one would die of hunger and no epidemic disease would break out in the flooded area. The province ha allocated 300 million kg of grain and 110 million yuan in cash along with over 10 million ton of such farm production supply a chemical fertilizer and diesel oil to the flood-stricken area. Meanwhile, 740 million yuan in loan and another 50 million yuan in donation have also been sent to flooded area in Guangdong Province. While inspecting flood control and relief work in Jiangxi Province, through which the Ganjiang flow, Wen Jiabao, alternate member of the Political Bureau and member of the Secretariat of the CPC Central Committee, said the flooded area should work hard to mitigate loss through their own effort and with support from various department. While inspecting Nanchang, the capital city of Jiangxi, and Fengcheng, Xingang, Jian and Taihe, on June 24-26, Wen said the key to mitigating economic loss is to resume production a soon a possible. The locality should waste no time in implementing various measure to resume production and rehabilitate their homeland, he said. As one of China's major bread basket, Jiangxi is of key importance to China in agricultural production, Wen said. It ha a direct bearing on the grain supply in south China. He urged the local government to farmer resume agricultural production. The following is a recorded report filed by this station's reporter on the front line of the province's battle against the flooding yesterday. [Begin recording] Dear audience, it is now almost noon on 20 June. I'm reporting in Changshanyuan at the eastern gate of Changsha City. This morning, Provincial Party Committee Secretary Wang Maolin, provincial Governor Chen Bangzhu, and some other provincial party and government leader arrived here in Changshayuan, on the front line of the province's flood resistance effort, to direct the fight against the flooding. Governor Chen Bangzhu and vice Governor Zheng Peimin just arrived back in Changsha at about 0700 this morning after attending a Beijing meeting. As soon a they stepped out from the train, they set out for Changshayuan, the front line of the province's flood resistance. I interviewed Governor Chen Bangzhu here on the spot. [Reporter] How are you, Governor Chen? You have inspected some flood-stricken area in Changsha City this morning. Will you please tell our audience something about the province's flood situation? [Governor] This year, Hunan ha been hit by a flood of a severity unseen for the past 100 year in term of both water level and quantity. Over the past few day, the broad mass of Army personnel and people across the province have been bravely fighting the flood and have been making concerted effort to provide disaster relief to afflicted area, with the result that some of the province's key dam have remained sound and economic loss have been reduced to a minimum. I would like to take this opportunity to extend my warm regard and thanks to the broad mass of Army personnel and people fighting in the front line of the province's battle against the flood. At the moment, the province's flood situation remains very serious, because the water level is still high. According to weather forecast and meteorological report, the province is expecting more rain to fall over the next few day. We will definitely encounter more hardship and difficulty. Under the current circumstance, the broad mass of Army personnel and people across the province should further step up their work and devote more energy to flood prevention and disaster relief work, this being an overriding task at the moment. We are full of confidence that, under the leadership of the CPC Central Committee and the State Council, the broad mass of the Hunan Army personnel and people will be able to overcome the difficulty and hardship caused by natural calamity such a flooding, waterlogging, and so on and will win a complete victory in the on-going flood prevention and disaster relief struggle. [end recording] Beijing, 21 Jun (XINHUA) -- According to the State Flood Control and Drought Relief Headquarters, after the largest or the second largest flood peak since the liberation of China occurred a few day ago in the Xi Jiang, Bei Jiang, Xiang Jiang, and Gan Jiang river, water level in these river are dropping slowly; however, high water level will remain in these river for the next few day. Due to interaction of the Bei Jiang and Xi Jiang, the Zhujiang Delta will face a high water-level test. Heavy rainfall over a wide area since mid-June resulted in the largest flood water since liberation of the country in the Xi Jiang, Bei Jiang, and Xiang Jiang river. The flood water in Guangdong's Xi Jiang crested in Gaoyao County on 20 June; the water level in Gaoyao's Xi Jiang dropped to 13.37 meter at 0600 today. A flood peak occured in Bei Jiang in Guangdong's Sanshui at 0400 on 20 June, raising the water level to 10.39 meter -- the largest flood level ever recorded. The water level droppped to 10.16 meter at 0600 today. Drops in water level in Guangdong's Bei Jiang and Xi Jiang do not mean that Guangdong's flooding situation have eased, because flood water in the Xi Jiang and Bei Jiang will remain at high level for quite long a period and will enter the sea after the two flood water jointly flow through the low-lying Zhujiang Delta. In particular, the sea tide may add to the flood water on 25 June. With these factor combined, the Zhujiang Delta, which ha a developed economy and a forest of factory, will face the most rigorous flood water test since the liberation of the country. The situation in the Xiang Jiang is also not an easy one. The flood peak passed Changsha on 19 June, but the water level at the Changsha Station wa still at 25 meter at 0200 today [1800 GMT 20 June]. Because the water level ha remained high for a long period, several dangerous situation have occured along the river's dike. Dike reinforcing work need to be stepped up. The flood peak in Gan Jiang entered Boyang Lake on 20 June. However, due to continued rain over the last few day, the water level in the upper reach west of Ganzhou ha begun to rise again. At 0800 today, the water level at the Ganzhou Station wa 100.95 meter, 3.45 meter above the warning level.
column5: Record setting floods ravage much of south China.
column6: Torrential rains have caused the worst flooding in 100 years in many areas of southern China.  Six provinces and many cities are seriously affected.  Government officials provided help with the flood fighting and relief efforts, but noteworthy was the direction provided by Wen Jiabao, member CPC Central Committee Secretariat.
column7: Floods being called the worst in 100 years have hit major parts of Guangdong, Guangxi, Hunan, Jiangxi, Fujian and Zhejiang Provinces.  They were caused by torrential rains in the Xiangjiang, Xunjiang, Xijiang and Beijiang river valleys.  Cities most seriously affected where Changsha, Zhuzhou and Xiangtan in Hunan Province, Wuzhou in Guangxi Province and Sanming in Fujian Province. Central Party official Wen Jiabao visited Changsha, Zhuzhou, Xiangtan and Jiangxi cities to offer appreciation, encouragement and guidance for the ongoing flood fighting and relief work, and to direct the resumption of industrial and agricultural production.  He emphasized measures to salvage the rice crop.
column8: Floods being called the worst in 100 years have hit major parts of Guangdong, Guangxi, Hunan, Jiangxi, Fujian and Zhejiang Provinces.  They were caused by torrential rains in the Xiangjiang, Xunjiang, Xijiang and Beijiang river valleys.  Cities most seriously affected where Changsha, Zhuzhou and Xiangtan in Hunan Province, Wuzhou in Guangxi Province and Sanming in Fujian Province. At the Changsha city monitoring station, the water level rose to 38.93 meters, some 0.56 meters above the previous record.  500,000 soldiers and civilians fought to contain the floodwaters there.  In Wuzhou city, the Xunjiang River's floodwater speed was recorded at 46,200 cubic-meters-per-second, the most ferocious since the nation's founding in 1949.  In Guangzhou Province 200 people died, 189,000 rooms were destroyed, and 1.2 million hectares of crops were ruined.  Economic losses were set at 10.2 billion yuan.  Many local, provincial and Central Party members provided support and expressed their concern, including Chairman Jiang Zemin and Premier Li Peng.  Noteworthy were the efforts of Central Party official Wen Jiabao.  He visited Changsha, Zhuzhou, Xiangtan and Jiangxi cities to offer appreciation, encouragement and guidance for the ongoing flood fighting and relief work, and to direct the resumption of industrial and agricultural production.
column9: China Floods Receding; 200 Dead in Guangdong; Substantial Crop Losses
column10: Flooding in south and central China provinces due to June storms has subsided, but 200 people died and substantial agricultural losses were recorded. Party officials praised those who battled the floods and assisted victims. Officials urged everyone to work to minimize losses, especially in Jiangxi, one of China's major bread baskets.
column11: Flooding in Guangdong, Hunan, Jiangxi, Guangxi, Fujiang and Zhejiang provinces that followed after heavy June storms has subsided, but in Guangdong 200 people died and 1.2 million hectares of crops were ruined.  Fujiang also suffered substantial agricultural losses. Wen Jiabo (CPC Central Committee Secretariat member) and other officials toured the flooded areas. They praised the soldiers and civilians who battled the floods, saved key infrastructure and industrial resources and assisted victims. The people were urged to concentrate on recovery efforts and actions to minimize economic losses. Resumption of agricultural production in Jiangxi, one of China's major bread baskets, was of particular concern.
column12: A State Flood Control and Drought Relief Headquarters spokesman said flooding in central and south China have subsided.Heavy June storms caused flooding in Guangdong, Hunan, Jiangxi, Guangxi, Fujiang and Zhejiang provinces. In Guangdong, the Beijiang and Xijiang rivers peaked at 14.72 meters and 25.91 meters, respectively. The Beijiang level was a record; the Xijiang peak was 25.91 meters above the danger level. Over 200 people died and 1.2 million hectares of crops were ruined.In Hunan, the Xiangijiang River flooded Changsha, affecting over 300,000 residents and closing over 400 factories and 5,000 shops.Jiangxi, a major agricultural province, was flooded by the Ganjiang River, while in Fujian, the floods exacerbated the typically low grain production. Approximately 446,000 mu of crops in Fujiang were lost and 1.957 million mu of grain have been heavily hit.  The Xunjiang River flooded Guangxi's Wuzhou city and its suburbs and knocked out telecommunications. Many officials, including Comrade Wen Jiabo (CPC Central Committee Secretariat member), toured the flooded areas. They praised the soldiers, police officers and civilians who battled the floods, saved key infrastructure and industrial resources, and assisted the victims. The people were urged to concentrate on recovery efforts and actions to minimize economic losses.

column3: Public interest in the Earth's troubled climate may be washed away with the heavy rain that are needed to end the current US. drought, weather expert warned during a drought symposium here. Society tends to flit from hysteria to hysteria, said Pat Michaels, Virginia's state climatologist and moderator of the symposium. He said the 1988 drought, although not a dry a a 1986 drought in many place, ha drawn much attention because some of the affected area include large medium center. I'm worried . that when the next drought happens, we are going to have to rediscover the climate problem, said Michaels, president of the Association of State Climatologists. Experts said Thursday that the greenhouse effect the warming of the Earth's atmosphere ha brought needed attention to change in the global climate, even though it is not directly related to the drought. Many of the 13 climatologist and meterologists at the symposium agreed that the Earth's temperature is warming, but they debated whether it is a short- or long-term phenomenon and it impact on Earth. However, Alan Hecht, director of the National Climate Program in Washington, D.C., said the uncertainty mean policymakers should begin to deal with the possible effect, especially undertaking policy that make sense in their own right. Mankind must reduce reliance on fossil fuel, he said, by becoming more energy efficient, replanting forest and investigating alternative energy supply. Scientists have warned in recent year that Earth's atmosphere is gaining in carbon dioxide and other gas, which trap heat and cause the overall temperature to rise. Besides fossil fuel, the depletion of forest in South America ha been blamed for the increase of carbon dioxide and methane. Some have warned that higher temperature will change the character of many country, for example drying out the US. Midwest or melting polar ice cap. The symposium wa sponsored by The Weather Channel, an Atlanta-based cable network, which broadcast the meeting live. Earlier Thursday, the climatologist were told the movement of planet and the moon and sunspot may help lead to drought in the Southeast. There is some evidence that a Jupiter go around the sun at it fastest point, there are drought condition in the Southeast in the month of April and October, Georgia state climatologist Gayther Plummer said. However, David Rodenhuis, director of the federal Climate Analysis Center in Washington, said he wa skeptical of Plummer's thesis. There's an enormous number of possibility that one could chase, Rodenhuis said. The next business of the scientist is to . extend the range of analysis and look for cause and effect. The crippling drought hitting North America is expected to reduce world grain stock to level that may cause food shortage in many poor country, the UN. Food and Agriculture Organization reported today. The agency project world cereal production in 1988 to total 1.785 billion ton, only two million ton more than last year's level, which wa already below the expected production. If the drought in the United States ended now, grain production would fall close to the low level of 1983, when a drought and farmers' participation in a government crop reduction program decreased output, the agency reported. As a result, world grain stock are projected to fall below 310 million ton, or 17 percent of the level the agency considers necessary to safeguard world food security, the report said. If crop condition in the United States and Canada continue to deteriorate, the ratio could drop even further. Such a development would have serious implication for the food security, particularly of many low-income, food-deficit country, the report said. The high grain price resulting from a lower supply would hit poor, food-importing country the hardest, the UN. agency warned. It said the rising price could also reduce food aid from developed country. The most severely hit crop are coarse grain mostly maize, barley and oat, the report said. The agency projected good harvest in other part of the world. In Asia the yearly monsoon rain started on time, and production in Europe and the Soviet is expected to be larger than last year. Grain production in South America should be slightly lower this year than last. In the Sahel region of sub-Saharan Africa, however, locust flourishing in unexpectedly heavy rain have damaged this year's harvest. Potential crop loss from the pest could hit 1 million ton, FAO said. Weather expert discussed the drought Thursday and it possible cause and effect, and said they hoped to produce a consensus on how much longer it will last. All of the speaker at the 1988 Drought Symposium called for more research and study. There's an enormous number of possibility that one could chase. The next business of the scientist is to eliminate the possibility of . and extend the range of analysis and look for cause and effect, said David Rodenhuis, director of the federal Climate Analysis Center in Washington. The symposium attended by 13 state and national expert wa sponsored by The Weather Channel, an Atlanta-based cable network, which broadcast the meeting live. John Hope, the network's hurricane specialist and a former forecaster with the National Hurricane Center in Miami, Fla., said the drought in the Southeast might be lessened or ended in the next few month by a heavier than normal hurricane season. Hope said current weather condition point to more tropical storm, more of which should become hurricane, in this hurricane season. He stressed that a hurricane's effect on drought is variable, depending on the intensity and speed of the storm. Nevertheless, he said, some Southeastern state get a much a 25 pecent of their rainfall in some month from hurricane. Georgia state climatologist Gayther Plummer told the symposium he thought the position of the planet Jupiter had something to do with drought in the Southeast. However, Rodenhuis said he wa skeptical about Plummer's thesis. It's very necessary to be cautious and analytical about the issue, he said. Heavy rain deluged some drought-hit area a Congress began working on a package of relief for America's farmer, and farmer in Kentucky today greeted the arrival of the first shipment of hay airlifted free from Oregon. Everything look so good with a bit of rain over the past 24 hour, farmer Herman Krone said Tuesday at his 2,800-acre farm in southern Illinois, which President Reagan plan to visit Thursday during a tour of the drought-stricken area. However, Krone said, almost one-third of his 1,200 acre of corn already have been lost. Marth Wilkinson, wife of Kentucky Gov. Wallace Wilkinson and business manager of the family's farm, wa at Louisville's Standiford Field today for the arrival of the first hay shipment from Portland, Ore. United Parcel Service plan to ship free of charge 20 to 30 ton of hay from Portland to Louisville each day for the next two week. The Agriculture Department, meanwhile, issued a report predicting severe damage to the harvest from the drought. It estimated, for example, that corn output this year would shrivel to 5.2 billion bushel, down from 7.06 billion last year. The dry weather is the largest drought that our nation ha ever experienced, Agriculture Secretary Richard E. Lyng told legislator. I think history will show that it's truly more mammoth than any of u ha ever experienced. Extremely heavy rain fell Tuesday in section of Texas, Louisiana, Oklahoma and Arkansas. In Texas, more than 6{ inch fell in 75 minute in Mesquite, washing a pickup truck and several car into a creek and leaving some home 8 inch deep in water. Water wa up to the top of car in Garland and street flooding wa reported in Heath. Nearly 6 inch fell in DeQueen, Ark. Showers and thunderstorm were widespread over the Middle Atlantic States, the Tennessee Valley and the Gulf Coast state. Thunderstorms boomed today over the Dakotas and Minnesota. In Washington, the House and Senate Agriculture committee began working on wide-ranging legislation that would provide payment of up to $100,000 each to farmer whose crop have been wiped out by the dry spell. House Agriculture Committee Chairman E. Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, called for final action on the measure by mid-August. The drought ha dried up pasture, forcing livestock farmer to go far afield for hay. The hay that arrived in Kentuky today will be stored at a fairground, and distributed next week by lottery to farmer, who will pay for the hay, official said. It seems like everyone in the state want this hay, state Department of Agriculture spokesman Roger Nesbitt said Tuesday. The delay ha angered some farmer, such a Bernetta Smith, who expects to run out of hay for her 147 beef cow in one to two day. I don't see any sense in storing it because people need this hay. I don't understand it, she said. At least 50 truckloads of hay gathered from the Carolinas and Virginia are being shipped to Ohio on Thursday in a drive organized by the Charlotte Motor Speedway and the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing. Despite the recent rain, community with dried-up water supply continue to restrict water use. Until the drought end, the 650 resident of Vintondale, Pa., about 50 mile east of Pittsburgh, will have to do without running water from 7 pm. to 7 am. every day, Mayor Michael Palovich said Tuesday. Palovich said he wa trying to arrange for an emergency supply to be trucked in. The drought ha had a silver lining for angler in the Reno, Nevada, area. The state Board of Wildlife Commissioners removed the limit on catch at Rye Patch and Lahontan reservoir because the reservoir are expected to be dry by the end of summer, leaving fish high and dry. Here is a state-by-state summary of drought development Wednesday: Weather forecaster today were offering drought-stricken farmer little prospect of relief in separate outlook for the next 30 day and three month. A new climate assessment of the ongoing drought said many area now experiencing extreme drought have le than a 4 percent chance of recovering from the drought within 3 month. The disappointing forecast came a President Reagan headed to the Midwest to inspect drought-plagued farm. On Tuesday the Agriculture Department reported sharp decline in the outlook for several crop. That wa followed Wednesday by a 30-day forecast from the National Weather Service saying that drought-stricken area from the Dakotas east to New York and from the Canadian border to Oklahoma, Arkansas and Tennessee are likely to continue to be short of rain. That area, which includes the major grain-growing state where crop already are suffering, is given a 55 percent chance of le than normal rainfall. And some state in the center of the area, stretching from West Virginia to Nebraska and from Wisconsin to Missouri, may be even drier. They are given a 60 percent chance of being short of precipitation. A slice of southern California, including Los Angeles, is the driest area in the forecast, with a 70 percent chance of having below normal rainfall. The rest of coastal California also will be dry, the forecast said. The outlook also say there's a 55 percent chance of hotter than normal temperature through the US. heartland from New England to Idaho and from the Canadian border to Oklahoma. Within that area, the chance of high temperature are above 65 percent in Wyoming, while central Midwestern state have a 60 percent chance of above average temperature. Wetter than normal weather is predicted for west and south Texas, and part of New Mexico, Arizona and Utah. Normal precipitation is forecast for the Atlantic and Gulf coast state, along with the Northwest and northern Mountain States. The Weather Service said normal temperature are expected for the Atlantic state from Virginia south, and for the Gulf Coast state. West Texas and New Mexico may be cooler than normal, but the far West is expected to see it normal quota of summer heat. The separate drought impact assessment, issued by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Climate Office, point out that predicting an end to the drought is a complex thing, since dry spell have no normal lifetime. The low 4 percent probability of an end within 3 month is based simply on a statistical analysis of past drought, the agency said. The report noted that a of the end of June, 29 percent of the continental United States wa experiencing severe or extreme drought, with part of 35 state affected. That put the current drought on the same level a the one in 1911, but still le severe than the drought of 1936, 1931, 1956 and 1934. Kentucky's governor ha criticized the federal government for being too slow in dealing with the drought, and Iowa's governor warns that farmer in his state still face potential disaster despite up to five inch of rain over the weekend. Crews began installing pump on barge Monday to haul fresh water to southern Louisiana town plagued by rising salt level in the lower Mississippi River. Meanwhile, House Speaker Jim Wright said in Washington he hope that a relief package with disaster payment of up to $100,000 for drought-stricken farmer will win committee approval and be ready for floor action in Congress this week. Here is a state-by-state summary of the latest drought developments: The drought may force the government to ease crop acreage control next year to help the United States rebuild it grain inventory, Agriculture Secretary Richard E. Lyng said Monday. But the United States will continue to be a major player in world agriculture and in 1989 should be able to bounce back from this year's drought loss, he said. Lyng's remark were prepared for delivery at a meeting of farm magazine, extension, advertising, co-op and broadcast editor. A larger portion of the United States suffered from some degree of drought stress in May and June than at any point since record began in 1895, he said. Moreover, on July 2, about 35 percent of the contiguous United States wa in the severe to extreme drought category, he said. In 1934, more than 60 percent wa so rated, and in August 1954 more than 50 percent wa in that category. Because of the large early season area now experiencing drought in the U.S., 1988 appears to have the potential to approach or exceed the drought-affected area of the 1930s and 1950s, Lyng said. Even with the severe drought, there will be an adequate supply of food grain and livestock feed grain so that the United States will be able to take care of our domestic need and our export demand, he said. Lyng said total consumption of 1988 crop will probably be somewhat le than previously estimated because price are much higher. But it is important to note that we will have no shortage, that we will still be able to accommodate the need of our overseas buyer, he said.
column5: Worst drought in nearly a century affects major grain growing areas.
column6: The worst drought to hit the United States since 1895, when record keeping began, has damaged grain crops in the major grain growing states and could lead to food shortages in poorer nations. The drought has forced some states to import hay from other states. Communities in many states have imposed tight water rationing.
column7: A severe drought continues to affect large areas of the United States and climatologists warn that the future could see more unless steps are taken to halt the earth's rising temperature. The drought is the worst since records began being kept in 1895 and hasaffected grain production across the nation. Grain supplies are expected to fall to 17 percent of what is required to safeguard world food security. Communities in the areas affected have restricted water use and Oregon has begun to ship hay to Kentucky. Some areas have seen some relief as heavy storms hit large sections of the country.
column8: A severe drought has affected large portions of the United States as rainfall was below normal in major grain growing states. The drought, rated severe by July 2, is the worst noted since the U.S. began keeping records in 1895 and affects about 35 percent of the contiguous United States.  If conditions continue, the areas affect could exceed the 60 percent of 1934 and the 50 percent of 1954. The drought has caused grain and soybean futures to drop and grain stocks are projected to fall below 310 million tons, or 17 percent of what is considered necessary to safeguard world food security. Many poorer nations could face food shortages as grain prices rise. Many communities from Iowa to Alabama face water shortages that leave officials seeking alternate water supplies. Other areas have imposed bans on outdoor water use. Heavy storms which have spread across the nation have brought deluges to Texas and Arkansas, tornados to Kansas, and damaging high winds to Michigan and Indiana but water restrictions will remain in effect for the immediate future. Kentucky received its first of hay from Oregon. Farmers in Kentucky, as in other states, were forced to seek hay elsewhere when the drought dried up pastures.
column9: Prolonged 1988 drought affects crops, livestock, water, jobs; prompts aid
column10: In mid-July, 1988's drought was predicted to continue three months. Severe storms brought tornadoes, hail damage, and lightning-sparked fires. States issued heat alerts. Weather experts attended a Drought Symposium. Grain futures and certain jobs fell. Hay was transported for free. Aid, loans, and reduced controls for farmers were proposed.  Drinking water was short. Livestock sales increased.
column11: In mid-July, 1988's drought looked record-breaking. Further drought was predicted based on past records. Severe storms brought tornadoes, hail damage, and lightning-sparked fires. States issued heat alerts. Weather experts who attended a Drought Symposium urged continued attention to climate and greenhouse-effect reduction. Crop declines were forecast and grain futures fell. Adequate domestic and export supplies were expected. UPS, railroads, and truckers transported hay for free. Federal aid, state loans to farmers, and eased future crop controls were proposed. Reagan visited drought areas. Farmers sued reneging insurers. Drinking water was hauled in and dam flows reduced. Livestock sales increased. Cannery, mill, and  logging jobs fell. Highway projects were accelerated.
column12: In mid-July, 1988's drought looked record-breaking. Predictions were for month-long hot, dry weather in grain-growing states and rain elsewhere, and a 4% chance of three-month recovery based on past-drought analysis. Rain was insufficient. Severe storms brought tornadoes, hail damage to crops, and lightning-sparked forest fires. Temperatures topped 100 and states issued heat alerts. Weather experts attending a Drought Symposium urged continued attention to climate, and energy policies to reduce the greenhouse effect. One theorized a relationship between drought and Jupiter's orbit. Crop declines were forecast and grain futures dropped. Adequate domestic and export supplies were expected. Higher prices would reduce consumption. Poor, food-importing countries would suffer most. Good harvests in Europe and Asia were projected. Georgia itemized hay sources. UPS, railroads, and truckers transported hay to Kentucky and Ohio for free. Congress proposed up to $100,000 aid to farmers. States provided funds for farm loans. President Reagan visited drought areas. Easing of 1989 crop acreage controls was considered. Farmers sued a company reneging on drought insurance. Drinking water was hauled to towns. Dam flow reductions endangered neighbors' supplies. Catch limits disappeared at reservoirs. Gamefish and turkeys were depleted. Livestock sales increased. Cannery jobs fell. Laying off mill workers and banning logging was considered. Few rain interruptions accelerated highway projects.

column3: THE INVASION: Iraq's troop, led by about 350 tank, crossed the border at dawn Thursday, and seized the Kuwaiti palace and government building 40 mile away. Early Friday, the invader controlled Kuwait city, the capital. The soldier were also making sweep through the southern oilfield, according to resident and Lloyds' insurance service in London. Diplomatic source estimate more than 200 Kuwaitis were killed or wounded, mainly from the Emiri Guard which bore the main brunt of the invasion. Kuwait's Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah fled to safety in Saudi Arabia. THE FORCES: Iraq, a country of more than 17 million, ha the Arab world's most battle-trained army, and had massed more than 100,000 soldier on the Kuwaiti border. Kuwait, an oil-rich city-state, ha 1.9 million resident 60 percent foreigner and an army of 20,300 soldier. CAUSE OF CONFLICT: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq accused Kuwait of stealing oil from it territory and forcing down oil price through overproduction. Kuwait and UN. diplomat dismissed Iraq's claim that it invaded at the request of Kuwaiti revolutionary. REACTION: The UN. Security Council voted 14-0 to condemn the invasion. President Bush denounced it a naked agression. He froze Iraq's asset in the United States and blocked almost all Iraqi import, including oil. The order also froze Kuwait property under US. jurisdiction a move intended to keep Iraq from seizing it. The Soviets also condemned the invasion and stopped arm sale to Iraq. Kuwait's US. ambassador said the nation had asked for American military intervention. A Pentagon source said a US. naval group wa diverted toward the Persian Gulf. Oil price soared in frenzied trading amid fear the invasion would reduce the supply of oil. Administration and congressional official agree that the CIA did it job. Since last week, President Bush had been warned by intelligence analyst that what originally looked like a military bluff wa quickly turning into the kind of troop deployment that could be used to invade Kuwait or even Saudi Arabia. Central Intelligence Agency Director William Webster even hand-delivered certain fresh detail on the Iraqi buildup to National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft. Among the assessment he conveyed wa a conclusion that, by this week, President Saddam Hussein's force would be capable of penetrating Kuwait or Saudi Arabia. The agency lacked hard evidence of an intent to invade, intelligence official say. But a the buildup grew, the CIA became more alarmed, partly because Mr. Hussein is so unpredictable, and partly because, unlike many other Arab leader, he ha been known to carry out his threat. Saudi Arabia ha been subdued in it reaction to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, which place Iraqi force near the oil-rich kingdom's border. Oil executive said Saudi Arabia ha not and will not take the most potent action possible against Iraq closing the pipeline that carry Iraqi oil for export across Saudi Arabia to the Red Sea. The executive said the Saudis believe this would give Iraq's belligerent president, Saddam Hussein, an excuse to attack and occupy Saudi oil field 150 mile south of Kuwait, giving Iraq control of more oil than any other country in the world. The only direct Saudi statement since the invasion wa made by an anonymous government spokesman through the official Saudi Press Agency the day after the Iraqi move. The statement said Saudi Arabia wa following the Kuwait situation with extreme concern and that King Fahd would be seeking to calm the situation and to find a solution in a manner ensuring the interest of all. The statement did not condemn the invasion. The only tangible help Saudi Arabia gave the Kuwaiti government in the wake of the invasion wa to shelter member of the ruling family, including the emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, and the crown prince. Both nation are tightly run by royal family and have been close ally. The Saudis also allowed the Kuwaiti royal family to briefly operate a radio, reportedly from a mobile van, in the area around the Saudi-Kuwait border. But Friday the radio went off the air after a desperate call: The people of Kuwait appeal to you oh brother, oh Arabs, oh beloved brother, oh Moslems, rush, rush to their help. It wa not known if the radio had been discovered by the Iraqis or shut down by the Saudis to avoid provoking Saddam at a time when fear were being expressed that he might invade Saudi Arabia a well. Saudi Arabia border Kuwait and Iraq's invasion force were reportedly near the Saudi border. The Saudis did condemned the invasion a part of a joint statement issued by the Gulf Cooperation Council, in which it is allied with Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar, Oman and Bahrain. The six state issued a statement saying, We strongly condemn and are very sorry for this attack that one Arab state took against another Arab state. . We do not recognize anything resulting from it. Iraq's 1-million-member armed force is clearly too much for the joint 3,000-member Gulf Cooperation Council force or Saudi Arabia's 65,700-member army. Saudi Arabia wa also one of the 14 member of the 21-member Arab League that condemned the invasion in the same term a the Gulf Cooperation Council. The Arab League, with one-third of it member voting against the resolution or abstaining, wa clearly unable to take any direct action. Turkey ha also refused to take action and ha not commented about President Bush's suggestion that it cut off Iraq's oil pipeline to the Mediterranean. Two parallel pipeline pump Iraqi crude oil to a terminal at Yumurtalik at the eastern corner of Turkey's Mediterranean coast and constitute Iraq's major oil export outlet. Ruling party member said today that the government, fearing a US. air attack, wa distributing automatic weapon to ten of thousand of supporter and preparing to evacuate the Iraqi capital. A boycott of Iraqi oil forced Baghdad today to close one of two pipeline in Turkey that were pumping the bulk of Iraq's exported oil, Turkish official said. A British official said Iraqi troop rounded up American and British visitor in Kuwait and taking them to Iraq. The Foreign Office spokesman said most were passenger from a British Airways flight stranded in Kuwait since the Iraqi invasion Thursday. There is no evidence that they are in any way in trouble, the official said. Saudi Arabia wa reported reinforcing it troop along the Kuwaiti border following concern Iraq may try to invade it. Pentagon source said the USS Independence and it carrier battle group are now on station in the Arabian Sea, a position that would allow it to launch fighter plane into the Persian Gulf region. Gulf-based diplomat said soldier from the American rapid deployment force, formed to react to crisis in the Middle East, had been dispatched to the area. In other developments: The new Kuwait government installed by Iraq hinted it might take hostage or seize property of nation that take punitive measure against Iraq. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein said the 100,000 soldier who invaded Kuwait began to pull back Sunday. President Bush said Iraq wa lying. Oil price jumped more than $3 a barrel on news Europe and Japan were joining the embargo of Iraqi oil. Stocks slumped worldwide. Hospital official said at least 300 Kuwaiti and Iraqi soldier were killed during the invasion. In London, Kuwaitis arriving on a special plane said 700 Kuwaitis died. The embargo of Iraqi oil grew over the weekend to include Japan and the European Community. Along with the United States, they bought more than half Iraq's exported oil, with most of it pumped through Turkey. An official of the state-run Turkish pipeline company BOTAS said pumping stopped at one of the two Turkish pipeline at 5 pm. Iraq reduced flow in the second, wider, pipeline to 70 percent of capacity, they said. There wa no comment from Iraq. The two pipeline pump Iraqi crude from Kirkuk oil field in northern Iraq to a terminal at the northeastern tip of the Mediterranean. They carry 70 million ton of crude annually, providing the outlet for the major share of Iraqi export. The BOTAS official said all the country participating in the embargo purchase their Iraqi crude from the Turkish outlet. Iraq also export oil through a Saudi Arabian pipeline and via tanker in the northern Persian Gulf. A Foreign Office spokesman said today a saying a total of 366 people had been assembled by Iraqi troop in Kuwait, mostly passenger from a stranded British Airways flight. They were being transported by bus to the Iraqi border. Baghdad did not give any reason for it action. Immediately after the invasion Thursday, 11 Americans were rounded up by Iraqi troop. They turned up safe in Baghdad. The new Iraqi-installed foreign minister of Kuwait, Lt. Col. Walid Sa'oud Mohammed Abdullah, warned against further sanction in a statement broadcast Sunday by Iraqi radio. Countries that resort to punitive measure against the provisional free Kuwait government and fraternal Iraq should remember that they have interest and national in Kuwait, he said. Iraqi soldier invaded Kuwait after complaining that it violation of OPEC production quota wa driving down world crude price, lowering Iraqi oil revenue. Saddam also accused Kuwait of stealing oil from a field that includes land both side claim. The respected Middle East Economic Survey reported today that Kuwait's oil export facility had been shut down. It also said there wa considerable doubt Saudi Arabia, with the world's largest oil reserve, would be willing to make up the potential world oil shortage. Kuwait and Iraq together account for one-fifth of the 23.5 million barrel produced daily by the 13 OPEC nation. Tensions remained high in the region; a US. official said in Washington that Iraqi troop massed on the Kuwaiti-Saudi border were apparently digging in. An American technician at a secret Saudi Arabian base said the kingdom had sent 200 to 300 tank toward it border with Kuwait. Oil industry source in Saudi Arabia reached by telephone from Bahrain said Saudi troop were entering the region of Khafji, near the border. Residents reached by telephone reported intense air activity near the Saudi airport overnight. The Washington Post reported today that Egypt wa mobilizing some element of it armed force to assist Saudi Arabia in the event of an invasion. US. official said there wa no indication Iraqi troop were preparing to invade Saudi Arabia. But Bush sent Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to the kingdom to confer with it leader, and the White House said Secretary of State James A. Baker would go this week to Turkey. Saadi Mehdi Saleh, the Iraqi army commander, wa quoted by the Al-Iraq newspaper a saying ten of thousand of volunteer had joined the army to defend what he called Iraq and the revolution in Kuwait. Americans, he wa quoted a saying, should understand that the people of the great leader Saddam Hussein cannot be frightened. Local member of the ruling Baath party said preparation were under way to evacuate all of Baghdad's 4 million people to camp outside the city. They were being told that the US.
