Stop light and neon light were knockedout in Myrtle Beach.One eyewitness said `It's like a light show,' said AmyGarrison, a reporter at WKZQ AM-FM in Myrtle Beach.In Charleston, the hurricane littered street with tin roofs,palmetto frond and chunk of bark. Businesses were closed andclasses at public school and university canceled. Riley orderedresidents of one-story home to evacuate.Hospitals stockpiled supply, discharging any patient wellenough to go and moving others to hospital inland to make room foremergency patient, official said.About 12,000 people had checked into 83 shelter across the stateas of Thursday evening, and more were expected, said Bennish Brown,a spokesman for the Emergency Operations Center in Columbia, 220miles northwest of here.We tried to close the door but people are sneaking in sidedoors, said Elaine Skelton, a registered nurse working at theConway High School shelter near Myrtle Beach. We tried to postguards at the door, but people were still coming in.American Red Cross relief effort were buckling under the numberof evacuee, said Brian Ruberry, a spokesman in Savannah, Ga., whoappealed for help.Right now the Red Cross is sheltering ten of thousand ofpeople all along the Eastern seaboard. This of course is at the sametime that we're sheltering 25,000 people on Puerto Rico and theother Caribbean islands.We're beginning to feel the squeeze. Our resource are verytight. Right now Hugo is shaping up to be one of our biggest reliefoperations of the decade.At midnight, the center of Hugo wa near latitude 32.7 degreesnorth and longitude 79.9 degree west, forecaster said. Thehurricane's speed had picked up to 22 mph from 20 mph earlier.Near it center, Hugo's muscle reached wind of 135 mph, up from125 mph earlier in the day and 105 mph the day before. North andSouth Carolina can expect tornado linked to Hugo for the next twodays, according to the hurricane center.The coastal area could expect hurricane force wind for 10 to 12hours once the eye come ashore, official said. A hurricane warningwas in effect between Fernandina Beach, Fla., and Oregon Inlet, N.C.By late afternoon, Hugo wa upgraded to a category 4 hurricane onthe Saffir-Simpson scale of strength, the second mightiest category,which indicated it could cause extreme damage.It strengthened more than we thought it would, Sheets said,adding that Hugo would cause severe flooding a it moved up theAppalachians.The timing of the landfall wa critical because of the storm'stidal surge, a dome of water 10 to 15 foot high that would feed anormal 5-foot high tide that peak after 2 a.m.On top of that will be wave, Sheets said earlier, and inmany place on barrier island the building will be swept cleanoff.It's taken the devastation caused byHurricane Hugo to stimulate repayment of a 211-year-old debtbetween two city almost 1,000 mile apart.As a way of repaying a kindness dating to 1778, Kingston israising money to help Charleston, S.C., recover.After Kingston, then New York's capital, wa burned in October1777 by the British, New York Gov. George Clinton received a letterfrom South Carolina Gov. Abraham Livingston. The letter includednearly 1,000 New York pound to help Kingston resident get throughtheir crisis.This money ha been received for the charitable purpose ofalleviating the distress of the now-indigent inhabitant of thetown of Kingston, who by the ravage of the enemy are reduced topoverty and want, Livingston wrote on March 31, 1778.Kingston Historian Edwin Ford remembered the letter whenHurricane Hugo ravaged the Carolinas last week. I figured theyhelped u, we should do something for them, Ford said.On Wednesday, a local Red Cross chapter began collectingdonations for victim of the hurricane.A lot of people have been calling, asking to send donationsdown there, said Susan Lawlor, executive director of the UlsterCounty Chapter of the Red Cross.On Tuesday, New York state sent two airplane full of food,clothing and water to part of the Caribbean ravaged by Hugo. A NewYork National Guard C-5A cargo plane also left Tuesday to pick upequipment in Mississippi and take it to Puerto Rico.Another cargo plane wa scheduled to leave Stewart Air ForceBase in Newburgh, taking 70 ton of food, water and other suppliesto Puerto Rico.This historic city ha survived theravages of earthquake, battle and storm in it storied300-year-history, but it faced perhaps it greatest test of all inHurricane Hugo.The storm, packing wind of up to 135 mph, raged into CharlestonThursday night.This is a dangerous, killer hurricane, the like of which fewpeople who have lived all their life in Charleston haveexperienced, warned Mayor Joseph P. Riley Jr.Hugo wa the first major hurricane to strike Charleston sinceHurricane Gracie came ashore 70 mile to the south in 1959.The seaside community ha suffered through many disaster, bothnatural and man-made.The worst in recent decade wa in 1938 when a tornado torethrough the city, killing 32 people, injuring hundred and causingan estimated $2 million in property damage.Charleston, a city of pastel-colored antebellum structure liningquaint street and alleyway, is where the Civil War began in 1861.The city ha survived the shot and shell of two war and anynumber of smaller hurricane, politely referred to by Charlestoniansof refinement a September gales.But the worst natural disaster to beset the city occurred on thehot night of Aug. 31, 1886, when the ground rumbled in what somefolks thought wa a prelude to Judgement Day.The great Charleston earthquake wa felt a far away a Chicagoand New York City.Measuring 7.7 on the Richter scale of ground motion, theearthquake claimed an estimated 110 life, destroyed 102 buildingsand tossed most of the city's 14,000 chimney into the streets.In recent year, the city ha attracted million of visitorsannually who tour it historic building and visit it nearby finesand beaches.Charleston ha received international acclaim a home to SpoletoFestival U.S.A., founded by composer Gian Carlo Menotti. Organizerslike to refer to Spoleto a the world's most comprehensive artsfestival.Hurricane Hugo will go down in the record book a the costliest storm insurer have faced so far, but it won't cause property-casualty premium rate to rise immediately, analyst and company official say. The property claim service division of the American Insurance Service Group, a trade association, is expected to announce it estimate of total insured loss tomorrow. "Hugo will be the biggest hurricane loss on record," said one official, far surpassing the $752.5 million insurer paid out after Frederick ripped through several Gulf Coast state in 1979. The impact on premium rate could be minimal for now, analyst expect, because the biggest loss will be in the personal insurance area -- for home and auto. Most company typically set aside fund from premium they collect every year to cover claim they might have to pay in the future. In the last three year, hurricane and storm season have been relatively mild, so insurer haven't had to dip into these fund. And since Hugo also stormed through the Caribbean, foreign insurer are at risk for some of the damage on those island. Yet, some analyst believe Hugo's huge loss will make a dent in the industry's capital and crimp cash flow; that could make insurer le likely to slash premium rate further in coming month. Rates have been falling since late 1986. Udayan Ghose at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. belief these reason might cause rate to edge higher by mid-1990. For the time being, the loss from Hugo "will be substantial, but they won't be something the industry can't handle," said Charles L. Ruoff, director of strategic planning at Fred S. James & Co., a New York-based insurance broker. For instance, State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Co. estimate it will pay claim totaling more than $400 million to homeowner and for some small business. Nationwide Insurance Co., a mutual company based in Columbus, Ohio, said Hugo "is the single largest claim disaster" it ha seen in it 63-year history. The company, which is the largest home and auto insurer in North Carolina and No. 3 in South Carolina, ha already received 16,000 claim from the stricken region. Claims could total $100 million, a spokesman said. For some insurer, Hugo wa a double-whammy. New York-based Continental Corp., which is a big insurer in Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands and South Carolinas, said it will take a $50 million pretax charge against earnings this quarter, reflecting it net exposure to the damage caused by the hurricane. "Hugo will be particularly costly to us," said John P. Mascotte, Continental's chairman. Philadelphia-based Cigna Corp., which ha extensive domestic, foreign and reinsurance operation in the area Hugo hit, and USF&G Corp. in Baltimore, a big insurer in the Carolina region, could also be forced to take one-time charge against third-quarter earnings, analyst said. Some of USF&G's loss hit very close home -- it Charleston office wa destroyed by the hurricane. Both USF&G and Cigna declined to predict whether they would take a charge; USF&G said it would be responsible for the first $22.5 million of loss, and it reinsurance would cover the bulk of additional loss. Hugo could have a marginal impact on third-quarter income at Travelers Corp., Aetna Life & Casualty Insurance Co. and Chubb Corp., according to industry analyst. Mr. Ruoff at Fred S. James belief that even if loss from Hugo total a much a $5 billion, insurer won't feel enough "financial pain, such a not being able to pay shareholder dividends," to compel them to boost premium rate right away. He explained that in the first six month of this year, net income for the industry declined slightly from 1988, but insurance company were still earning an adequate rate of return on equity. He also noted that the industry's aggregate net worth or policyholders' surplus, currently at $125 billion, is also plentiful. Generally, insurer can book about $3 of premium for every $1 of surplus. Right now, premium total about $200 billion, he said. An official at Nationwide Insurance noted that the company ha $1 of surplus for every $2 of insurance that it writes. Insurers also buy protection for themselves through reinsurance by paying another company a portion of the premium to bear some of the loss. Michael Lewis at Dean Witter Reynolds said loss from Hugo could be big enough to "temporarily" increase reinsurance rate. Although reinsurance will limit the exposure of some company, the loss they must still cover could hurt third-quarter result. Niagara Exchange Corp., based in Buffalo, N.Y., said Monday it will report a loss from operation for the third quarter, and possibly for the year, because of the substantial loss that it Charleston Insurance Co. unit face a a result of the hurricane. State Farm, the nation's largest home insurer, doesn't buy reinsurance. It belief it reserve are plentiful enough to absorb it loss, a spokesman said.
column5: South Carolina Coast Evacuation Before "Killer Storm" Hugo Saves Lives
column6: The insurance industry expects Hugo, the Category 4 hurricane that struck the Carolinas and the Caribbean last week, to be the costliest storm ever. Most companies, however, can cover the losses. Because South Carolina residents heeded evacuation warnings from the Hurricane Center, Hugo claimed only 17 lives in the state.
column7: The two largest property insurance companies in the Carolinas, State Farm and Nationwide, estimate Hurricane Hugo losses at $600 million, making it the costliest hurricane ever.Hugo, a Category 4 storm dubbed a "killer hurricane" by Charleston's mayor, struck the city Thursday night. Though there was significant damage, only two were killed in Charleston, 17 total in South Carolina. Officials credit the low number of fatalities to residents who heeded Hurricane Center warnings and evacuated before the storm's arrival.Kingston, New York, assisted by Charleston during the Revolutionary War, is repaying the kindness by sending money to help the city recover.
column8: American Insurance Service Group says Hurricane Hugo, which ravaged the Caribbean and the Carolinas last week, is responsible for record hurricane losses. State Farm Insurance expects claims of approximately $500 million in the Carolinas. Nationwide Insurance is projecting claims near $100 million. Though the Hugo-related losses are substantial, most companies have sufficient funds to cover them. Some companies, however, will reduce third-quarter earnings.Hugo slammed into Charleston Thursday night with top winds of 135 mph. Upgraded to a Category 4 hurricane hours before it struck the historic city, it caused widespread damage throughout the Carolinas. Only two lives were lost in Charleston, however, and only 17 total in South Carolina. Officials credit the low number of fatalities to residents who monitored the hurricane and evacuated.  Computer models at the National Hurricane Center used satellite information to track Hugo's path into Charleston. Before the storm's arrival in South Carolina, the governor declared a state of emergency and National Guardsmen were ordered to assist a mandatory evacuation of coastal barrier islands and shorefront. Thousands fled inland or went to shelters.Kingston, New York, assisted by Charleston during the Revolutionary War, is repaying the kindness by sending money to help the city recover.
column9: Forecasters Saved Lives During Deadly Hurricane Hugo
column10: Hurricane Hugo which hit Charleston, S.C. head-on the night of Sept. 21, 1989 was the costliest storm in the city's 300-year history. Despite widespread devastation (insured losses approached $5 billion) there were only 17 deaths in South Carolina and only two in Charleston itself thanks to accurate forecasting in time for an effective evacuation.
column11: On Sept. 21, 1989 Hurricane Hugo hit Charleston, South Carolina head-on with winds at 135 mph causing extensive property damage, but claiming only 17 lives in all of South Carolina and only two in Charleston itself. The relatively low casualties were a result of an accurate prediction of the point of windfall by hurricane forecasters, effective evacuation measures and good response from residents. Total insured losses from Hugo were estimated near $5 billion, by far the costliest storm to ever hit the area, but insurers expressed confidence in being able to satisfy all claims.
column12: Hurricane Hugo approached the Carolina coast on Sept. 21, 1989 with its windspeed up to 125 mph and threatened to hit between Savannah, GA and Charleston, S.C. It hit Charleston head-on with winds of 135 mph and then proceeded northwestward hitting other population centers rather than heading up the coast or out to sea as expected. Fortunately Hurricane forecasters analyzing computer predictions, satellite data, the history of similar storms and the current path of the hurricane made an accurate educated guess as to the point of landfall in time for threatened residents to evacuate. As a result, only 17 deaths resulted in all of South Carolina and only two in Charleston which took the brunt of the storm. Charleston had been through many hard times in its 300- year history, but Hugo was by far the worst hurricane in its experience. Total insured losses from Hugo were estimated near $5 billion but insurers were confident that they could handle all claims. Disaster aid came to Charleston from an unexpected source. Kingston, New York  raised funds to aid Charleston in thanks for 1,000 New York pounds sent by the South Carolina governor in 1778 to help the citizens of Kingston after it was burned by the British.

column3: A South Carolina school where a gunmankilled two 8-year-old girl Sept. 26 will send card and offer wordsof encouragement to a California school that lost five pupil in ashooting rampage.We will tell them they can survive this, said Kat Finkbeiner,a physical education teacher whose jaw wa shattered in the shootingspree last year at Greenwood's Oakland Elementary School. I wouldtell them, `Lean on your community, share the sorrow.' We've livedthrough this. I know we can help.On Sept. 26, a man with a history of mental problem opened firewith a handgun at Oakland Elementary School, killing two youngstersand wounding nine other people. Ms. Finkbeiner helped subdue thegunman, Jamie Wilson, 19.On Tuesday, a 26-year-old drifter with a long crimnal recordopened fire with an assault rifle at Cleveland Elementary School inStockton, Calif., killing five child and wounding 30 other peoplebefore taking his own life.It's unpleasant. It's unhappy, but they can live through it;they can be happy another day, Ms. Finkbeiner said.Children at the Greenwood school will be asked to send card tothe California school, while the principal, Eleanor Rice, and Ms.Finkbeiner said they will contact official at the Stockton schoolto offer encouragement.Our wound have not closed. We are still hurting. It make usmore compassionate for these people, the principal said.Eveline Higginbotham, the third-grade teacher in whose classroomthe two little girl died, said the California tragedy just bringsit all back again.I'm just in shock, she said.Within hour of the schoolyard shootingsthat left five child and the gunman dead and 30 wounded Tuesday,dozens of translator rushed to assist the many Southeast Asianparents who arrived at the hospital desperate for word of theiryoungsters.I would imagine it is absolute panic. They are not sure whathappened, not sure what's going on around them, said Laura Dixon,of the Charterhouse Center refugee program, in Stockton, describingthe scene translator found when they arrived at San Joaquin CountyGeneral Hospital.Many of the parent speak no English and were unable to askwhether their child were among those killed or wounded when aheavily armed gunman in combat fatigue invaded Cleveland ElementarySchool and opened fire before taking his own life.They do have people on staff at the hospital, but they are sooverloaded they need every extra person they can secure, saidDixon, whose organization began calling throughout Stockton forvolunteers speaking Southeast Asian language. About a dozentranslators were sent to the county hospital, after official therecalled for help.In recent year, thousand of Southeast Asians have settled inStockton, drawn in part by the farming and fishing that flourish inthe area. School official said 60 percent of the child wereSoutheast Asian refugee either from Cambodia, Laos or Thailand.All five of the child killed were of this background,authorities said.A Stockton woman who run an after-school program teachingEnglish to Cambodian refugee dispatched 25 translator, includingvolunteers from all over the city, to the school and the hospital,Dixon said.The San Joaquin County Mental Health Department told Dixon agrief center might be established at Charterhouse to help survivors,whose recovery will be complicated by the language barrier.Charterhouse is funded by the Episcopal Church and privatedonations.Here is a profile of the gunman who took the life of fivechildren at a Stockton, Calif., school Tuesday. It is based oninformation from police and relative, and on background reported bythe Sacramento Bee newspaper.Grieving relative and friend gatheredat memorial service Saturday to mourn the five school childrenslain by a camouflage-garbed, suicidal drifter.Although there are some people in the United States who do badthings, most of the people in the United States do good things,said Patricia Busher, principal of Cleveland Elementary School,where the killing and the wounding of 29 student and one teacherhappened last Tuesday.The tragedy that occurred at our school could have happenedanywhere. There is no way to protect u from this kind of tragedy. this senseless tragedy. In time, some of the cutting edge of thepain will go away, Busher said.Her speech, at a memorial service attended by 200 people for thefour Cambodian child killed, wa translated a she spoke into theCambodian language.Tragedy ha followed you, state Sen. John Garamendi told thefamilies, refugee from a country where more than 1 million peoplewere killed in execution and enforced hardship after a 1975communist takeover.The service, held in Central Methodist Church, wa for 8-year-oldOeun Lim, 9-year-old Rathanan Or, 8-year-old Ram Chun and 6-year-oldSokhim An.During the morning, a Catholic funeral mass and burial were heldfor 6-year-old Thuy Tran, daughter of Vietnamese refugees.Another memorial service for the four Cambodians wa plannedSunday at a mortuaryGov. George Deukmejian planned to speak at a service Mondaymorning for all five child at Stockton Civic Auditorium. Peopleattending that service were asked to follow a Southeast Asiancultural tradition and wear black-and-white ribbons.Patrick Edward Purdy, who turned a gun on himself after firingmore than 100 round from an AK-47 semi-automatic assault rifle atCleveland Elementary, where he had attended grade school, wa buriedFriday in an unmarked grave in a family plot at Lodi.Ten of the wounded child and the wounded teacher remainedhospitalized Saturday. Three child were discharged Friday.Stockton police said they have located all of Purdy's closerelatives, except for his mother, identified a 43-year-old KathySnyder. Police said she ha had four different surname and thatwhen she renewed her driver's license a year ago, she used anaddress in La Mesa that turned out to be a chemical shed.Grief-stricken family and friend mournedthe death of five school child gunned down during recess, whilethe killer wa buried nearly unnoticed in a nearby town.Parents and teacher continued counseling the child whowitnessed Tuesday's schoolyard slaying, trying to help them dealwith the tragedy.Patrick Purdy, 24, opened fire outside the Cleveland ElementarySchool with an AK-47 semiautomatic assault rifle, firing more than100 round, killing five child and wounding 29 others and oneteacher.Three day and night of prayer began Thursday for two of theyoungsters killed, and service for the other child were beingheld today and Monday. Gov. George Deukmejian wa to attend Monday'sservices.Purdy wa buried Friday in nearby Lodi, said his grandmother,Julia Chumbley. He wa interred following a service at CherokeeMemorial Cemetery, which several of his relative attended, she said.Fourteen of the wounded student were still hospitalized, butmost were reported in improved conditions.At Cleveland School, about three-quarters of the school's 970pupils had returned to class by Friday, about three time thenumber who attended Wednesday, but it wa anything but a routineschool day.Counselors and school psychologist were assisting teacher inclassrooms, and some parent sat in with their child to comfortand reassure them.One mother, who asked not to be identified, told reporter thather youngest son, a 7-year-old second grader who wa on playgroundwhen the shooting occurred, would only come back to school if shestayed with him.They're making it back, slowly but surely, she said, addingthat she planned to spend Friday a she did Thursday, at her son'sside in the classroom.Cleveland School is in the heart of California's third-largestcommunity of refugee from Southeast Asia, and nearly two-thirds ofthe school's population is from Asia. All of the dead child werefrom refugee family, a were 19 of the 29 wounded.School authority said they were particularly concerned that thekilling might not only revive the psychological trauma of thehorrors they experienced in Southeast Asia, but that those familiesmight flee from the area without accepting counseling if they feareda racial motive in the attack.We want to pas the word to the community that this is not aracist act . It could happen to anybody, anywhere, anytime. Thisis a crazy action from one individual. It is not racism, said AnTran of the Southeast Asian Refugee Resettlement Program.Stockton Police Capt. Dennis Perry also repeated that there wasno evidence that Purdy, who committed suicide after the attack, wasspecifically targeting Asians.It wasn't any one race or group of people. He hatedeverybody, Perry said of Purdy, who a a child 14 year earlierhad attended Cleveland School.A man fired several dozen shot from anautomatic rifle in an elementary school Tuesday, killing sixchildren, wounding at least 35 other people and then shootinghimself in the head, authority said.We have at least one suspect in custody who ha a gunshot woundto the head, Deputy Police Chief Ralph Tribble said.Bruce Fernandez, spokesman for the county office of emergencyservices, said six people had died.Ellen Rich at St. Joseph's Medical Center said eight victim werebeing treated there, and said the total, including those beingtreated at other hospital, wa 35 wounded.We have at least 30 people that we've sent out to areahospitals, said Police Chief Jack Calkins.The attack at Cleveland Elementary School came shortly beforenoon. Other child were kept in their room, said John Klose,Stockton Unified School District information officer.Police Sgt. James Monk said his office learned that a man wentberserk with an automatic weapon and we have several (people) down.Several dozen shot were heard from an automatic rifle, saidMonk.Children whose family escaped thehorrors of the Vietnam War saw their schoolyard turned into akilling field, the target of a silent gunman armed with a rifle anda pistol bearing the word victory.After the massacre at recess, the body of three Southeast Asianchildren were outlined in blue on the playground of ClevelandElementary School where they died. Two others had been dragged byteachers inside to a classroom, but also died. Twenty-nine otherpupils were wounded, along with a teacher.There wa shooting all over. . I wa scared, saidsixth-grader Binh Hoang, who wa born in Vietnam in 1975 in thefinal day of war and had never before heard gunfire. Everybodywas cry in my class.Police said a drifter identified a Patrick Edward Purdy, 26,armed with two handgun and an AK-47 assault rifle, entered theschool ground around noontime Tuesday and fired about 60 roundsbefore he shot himself to death.Afterward, a large handgun and the assault rifle lay on theground near a pool of blood and the gunman's body. The wordvictory wa written on the pistol handle.Binh said she wa sitting in math class when the shooting beganoutside the wood-and-stucco school building. Her teacher toldstudents to get under their desks.The gunfire startled Michael Cuevas, whose first thought wa thatthe University of the Pacific fraternity near his house werefiring their miniature cannon again.But the shot repeated too rapidly for a cannon, and the screamof siren that followed told him this time wa no prank.I never thought a tragedy of this magnitude could happen inStockton, said Cuevas, a 29-year-old marine clerk at the Port ofStockton who life down the street from the elementary school.It's always in some other town, some other place. It's a shockto my sens. I don't think it's even hit me a hard a it's goingto. You don't know whether to be excited, or confused or what.Police car and news reporter crowded the street, whichtypically is busy only when parent pick up and drop off theirchildren.Why here? said Jeff Russell, 37, who wa born and reared inthe neighborhood. This ha always been a sleepy little town. (Theshooting) put u back on the map.Lutheran and Baptist church border the school in a neighborhoodof ranch-style home, postage-stamp lawn and street lined withsycamore and oak tree in this agricultural city of 150,000 people60 mile southeast of San Francisco.The 40-year-old neighborhood near the University of the Pacificis still home to many retired couple who raised their familesthere. But the city ha been changing with the influx of SoutheastAsian refugees.When school official called clergy to console grieving families,Buddhist priest in sandal and saffron robe arrived along withtheir white-collared Christian counterparts.About 60 percent of Cleveland Elementary's student are ofSoutheast Asian descent, said John Klose, spokesman for the StocktonSchool District. The five child who were killed were Vietnameseand Cambodian.This is one of our best neighborhood school, Klose said.Of all of our school that I would think of something like thishappening, this would be the last one I would think of.Across the street, Sarah Abbott stood astride her bicycle andgazed at the school where she graduated many year ago. Theprofessional nanny said she wa at the house of her 97-year-oldgrandfather about a block from the school when the gunman set hiscar on fire before starting to shoot.When the car exploded, my grandpa's house just shook, Abbottsaid. It scared me. . It wa just too close.The 26-year-old drifter with a long criminalrecord who launched a mute, murderous assault on a Californiaelementary school Tuesday wa described by his aunt a a loner andchildhood alcoholic, police said.Patrick E. Purdy purchased an AK-47 rifle in this Portland suburbseveral month ago, then returned to his hometown of StocktonCalif., where he used the gun to kill five child and wound 29others, along with a teacher, at Cleveland Elementary School beforetaking his own life, authority said.Purdy, who went by the alias of Patrick West, had lived with anaunt and uncle in Sandy from the first of July until late October,said Sandy Police Chief Fred Punzel. He later moved to Lodi, Calif.,where he listed his mailing address under the name of hisgrandmother, Julia Chumbley, although he did not live with her,authorities said.I'm shocked. It's just horrible. I don't understand why and Iprobably won't ever know why, said Ms. Chumbley, a 63-year-oldretired cannery worker.It trouble me to think that such a terrible thing can happen.It's like a nightmare. This sort of thing happens to others, notyou. Your own grandson.Stockton is about 15 mile southwest of Lodi.Punzel said Purdy's aunt, Julie Michael, told me he wa a lonerand a a child he wa an alcoholicMrs. Michael said through a closed front door at her residencethat she wa too upset to talk to reporters.Her next-door neighbor, Pat Thomas, 45, said she met West when helived with his relative last summer.He seemed like a real nice young man, she said. He wa herelooking for work.However, Purdy had an extensive criminal history, mostly inthe Los Angeles area, said Lucian Neely, deputy police chief inStockton, an agricultural city 60 mile east of San Francisco.Purdy had no criminal record in Sandy, Clackamas County orPortland, authority said.Neely said Purdy originally wa from Stockton and that he hadpurchased the gun at the Sandy Trading Post Aug. 3.Punzel said Mrs. Michael told him Purdy left Oregon for a job asa boilermaker in Texas. That job fell through and he went toMemphis, Tenn.The aunt and uncle last heard from Purdy at Thanksgiving, when hewas in Connecticut, Punzel said.His mother life in Sacramento, Calif., and his father wa killedin 1980 or 1981 when he wa struck by a car a a pedestrian, Punzelsaid.State Division of Motor Vehicles record identify Purdy as5-foot-11, 150 pound, with blue eye and blond hair, said spokesmanDave Davis.
column5: Man fires into California schoolyard, killing five and wounding 30.
column6: On January 16, 1989, Patrick Edward Purdy, 24, fired an AK-47 into a playground at Stockton, California's Cleveland Elementary School, which he had attended. He killed five children and wounded 30, then killed himself. The slain children were Southeast Asian. Purdy had drifted around the country searching for work and had a long criminal record.
column7: On January 16, 1989, Patrick Edward Purdy fired an AK-47 automatic assault rifle into a crowded playground at Cleveland Elementary School in Stockton, California, killing five children and wounding 30, then killing himself. All the dead were children of Southeast Asian refugees, as were 60% of the school's students. Translators and Buddhist priests assisted families, and returning students received counseling. A South Carolina school where a similar attack occurred sent encouragement. Governor Deukmejian spoke at one memorial service. Anti-racism statements were made. Purdy, 24, attended Cleveland Elementary  through third grade. A loner, he had drifted around the country searching for work and had a long criminal record.,
column8: On Tuesday, January 16, 1989, Patrick Edward Purdy entered the grounds of Cleveland Elementary School in Stockton, California and fired an AK-47 automatic assault rifle into a crowded playground. He killed five children and wounded 29 others and a teacher, then killed himself. All the dead and 19 of the wounded were children of Southeast Asian refugees, as were 60% of the school's 970 students. Translators and Buddhist priests assisted families, who received financial aid from the county victim assistance program. Students returning to school received counseling. A South Carolina school where a similar attack occurred sent encouragement. Governor Deukmejian spoke at one memorial service and was considering a ban on assault weapon sales. Anti-racism statements were made but authorities denied a racial motive in the attack. Purdy, AKA West, 24, blond and blue-eyed, attended Cleveland Elementary  through third grade. He dropped out of high school and took welding classes, then drifted around the country searching for work. He had many LA area arrests for minor offenses, served jail time, and attempted suicide. He had military and white supremacist leanings. He was described as a loner, child alcoholic, dangerous, and mildly retarded. His father was struck by a car and killed in 1981. His mother remained unlocated.
column9: Drifter opens fire in schoolyard, killing five and wounding 30.
column10: Five students of Asian descent were slain in the schoolyard of Cleveland Elementary School shortly before noon. Another 29 students and a teacher were wounded in the attack. Their killer, Patrick Edward Purdy, lay dead nearby of a self-inflicted gunshot wound. Purdy was a drifter with a long history of problems with the law.
column11: Five children were slain in the schoolyard of Cleveland Elementary School on Tuesday, the victim of a drifter with a troubled past. Patrick Edward Purdy, armed with an AK-47 and a pistol, entered the crowded schoolyard just before noon and opened fire. When the shooting was over, five students lay dead and 29 others, as well as one teacher, were wounded. Purdy lay dead of a self-inflicted gunshot wound to the head. Cleveland Elementary School is two-thirds Asian and the five students, one Vietnamese and four Cambodian, as well as 19 of the wounded were all Asian.
column12: Patrick Edward Purdy, a drifter with a troubled past, returned to the elementary school where he attended kindergarten through third grade and killed five children. Armed with an AK-47 and a pistol with victory written on it, Purdy went to Cleveland Elementary School in Stockton and opened fire in the crowded schoolyard at recess. Firing over 100 rounds in a few minutes, Purdy killed five students and wounded 29 others as well as a teacher. He then committed suicide with the pistol. Purdy was described by his aunt as a loner and a child alcoholic. He had a long history of trouble with the law and had served at least two jail terms. Cleveland Elementary serves the third largest Asian refugee community in California and the five students killed as well as 19 of the 29 students were Asian. One of those killed, a Vietnamese student, was buried Saturday following a Catholic mass. Traditional Buddhist prayers were being held for three of the four Cambodian students slain. A community service is being planned at the Stockton Civic Center on Monday. Governor Deukmejian, who will be attending the event, has asked that everyone wear black and white ribbons in keeping with Southeast Asian tradition.

column3: Torrential thunderstorm sent a flashflood surging through a valley into this Ohio River town, killingat least 11 people, leaving 51 missing and score of othershomeless Friday, authority said.Raging floodwaters late Thursday swept home off foundation andwashed away car. About 200 people were reported evacuated incentral Ohio.The valley are choked with debris, Gov. Richard Celestetold reporter after flying over the hilly Appalachian region ineastern Ohio. A wall of water wiped a path through the area.The governor declared a state of emergency, and dispatched about50 National Guardsmen to the area.The Federal Emergency Management Agency declared Belmont County,which includes Shadyside, and Jefferson and Franklin countiesdisaster area, making federal aid available to residents.Seventeen county now have been declared disaster area because offlooding or tornado since May 29.Ten body were taken to the Bauknecht Funeral Home inShadyside, said Bob Bell, funeral director. One body wa taken toBellaire City Hospital, he said.Chuck Vogt, Belmont County coroner's investigator, also saidthere were 11 confirmed dead.Earlier, Fire Chief Mark Badia had said 14 adult and twochildren were dead. The name of the victim have not been released.County Sheriff Tom McCort, who said he wa running the recoveryeffort, said 51 people in Shadysville and Meade Township, where thetwo creek run south of the village, were missing a of 8:45 p.m.The list wa compiled through telephone inquiry withtownspeople and relative and interview with people evacuated fromthe area.About 200 people came and went from a Shadyside disaster centerduring the day, seeking news of missing friend and relatives.Vogt said two body were found in the Ohio River and one wasfound in a field next to the river after water receded. He said therest were found in the creek, which flow into the river.Some of the body were taken to a funeral home that set up atemporary morgue in Shadyside, about 10 mile south of Wheeling,W.Va.Officials from Ohio, West Virginia and the US. Coast Guard weresearching the Ohio River for survivor and body, and Badia saidNational Guardsmen were to continue searching the creek throughoutthe night.At least five house along Wegee Creek were washed away, and twocars were floating in water in one of the basement. Anything thatwas still standing wa covered with at least 6 foot of debris suchas tree, appliance and furniture.The National Weather Service issued no flood warning before thedisaster, although it did issue a flood watch, said Al Wheeler,deputy meteorologist in the bureau's Cleveland office.Weather service office in Cleveland, Akron, Columbus andPittsburgh showed the storm had diminished over eastern Ohio whenit had actually intensified, Wheeler said.Thursday night's thunderstorm caused flash flooding across awide area of central and eastern Ohio, northern West Virginia andwestern Pennsylvania. The flood closed road, damaged home andforced hundred of people to evacuate.But no place wa hit with anything approaching the ferocity ofthe flooding in Shadyside.About 5.5 inch of rain fell between 7:30 pm. and 11 p.m.,turning two Ohio River tributary outside the village of 4,300people into dangerous torrents.About 35 building, including a tavern, were damaged along WegeeCreek, and 50 building were hit by a flood along Pipe Creek, fourmiles south of Wegee Creek, said Dick Quinlin, Belmont Countyemergency service coordinator.Part of the tavern wa washed away when water caved in the backwall, said Judy Phillips, a sheriff's department spokeswoman. Shesaid two patron were accounted for, but she could offer noestimate of how many were inside at the time.One man wa found clinging to a bar stool, said state Sen.Robert Ney, whose district includes Shadyside.I've never seen anything of this magnitude. There wa nowarning, Ney said.Rescuers pulled people from three car in Wegee Creek, whichflows through Shadyside and into the Ohio River, said Badia.I don't know how to describe it. . You've got to see it tobelieve it, Badia said.One resident, Robert Ramsey, said his wife, Rose, wa crushed todeath in their house by the water.There wa no complete accounting of death, said Karen Bovek, aspokeswoman at a Shadyside Fire Department command center set up ana school.You're talking mile and mile of country road that haven'tbeen gotten to yet, she said. It's a disaster here.There also wa flooding in Jefferson County, north of Belmont,in Licking County in central Ohio, and in northwestern WestVirginia and western Pennsylvania.It's a pretty good mess, especially in the northern end of thecounty, said Clarence Weston, a dispatcher with the MarshallCounty Sheriff's Department in Moundsville, WVa. We had 3.5inches of rain in a two-hour period last night.Most of the problem in West Virginia were confined to roadclosures and basement flooding.At least 25 people were evacuated during the night in thePittsburgh suburb of Etna, where some home had up to 5 foot ofwater in their basement, said borough manager Bill Skertich. Theyreturned to their home Friday.Landslides were reported in the Pittsburgh area, and many citystreets were closed during the storm.The flooding wa more serious in Licking County, Ohio. WayneTresemer, the county's Disaster Services director, said water wasstanding up to 5 foot deep in some street in the town of Newark,and the fire department and other agency used boat to evacuatesome residents.Two inch of rain caused flooding in Franklin County in centralOhio and 3.75 inch of rain wa dumped on Holmes County innorth-central Ohio, the National Weather Service said.In Jefferson County, just north of Belmont County in the easternpart of the state, 50 to 60 resident were evacuated in Adena,where water wa 6 to 8 foot deep in street because of creekflooding.Flood water in most area had subsided by Thursday night,according to authorities.The mother of a 12-year-old girl sweptaway by a flash flood wa clinging to hope that her daughter wasalive but perhaps unable to get home, a family friend said Saturday.Janice Trigg's daughter, Kerri, wa among nearly three dozenstill missing Saturday night, two day after the flood hit easternOhio.She keep saying Kerri Jo may have amnesia, or she can't moveto get help. That's a mother's hope, said the friend, BettyKreiter, 67.Searchers for the missing used trained dog to sniff through therubble and along the bank of the Wegee and Pipe creek, whichempty into the Ohio River, in an effort that stretched five milessouth of this town.Workers also sifted through debris that collected at theHannibal lock and dam on the Ohio River, about 25 mile south.Relatives of the missing were staying with friend and family,said the Rev. Robert Gracey, who wa counseling flood victim at aschool turned into a relief center.Kerri had been playing at a friend's house when the one-storyhome suddenly wa washed away in the flood Thursday night.The friend, 9-year-old Amber Colvin, wa swept down Wegee Creekand into the Ohio River, but survived a seven-mile ordeal byclinging to logs.Amber wa released from a hospital Saturday aftertreatment for minor injuries.She said she last saw Kerri when the two, alone in the house,jumped into a bathtub for safety in the storm. The tub wa washedinto the creek.Throughout the town, there were story of fear, luck and closecalls. Deanna Hulderman, 48, said she and her husband, Clancey,were pulled under by Wegee Creek flood water at a bar but werereunited about a half-hour laterMrs. Hulderman said she, her husband and about seven others werein the 3Ks bar when a wall collapsed and water rushed through.I saw my husband go under and get washed away. He wa yellinghow much he loved me, and then I went under, Mrs. Hulderman said.I began praying `God, don't let me die like this,' and the nextthing I knew I wa standing on my foot, and the water went downMrs. Hulderman said firefighter rescued her husband at themouth of the creek near the Ohio RiverCapt. James Boling of the Ohio National Guard said localauthorities told him some of the bar patron remained unaccountedfor.Kathy Schramm, 37, said she, her husband and their two childrenfled their two-story house before water washed through. When theyreturned, the basement and first floor were flooded, and thesurrounding area looked like a big lake.I looked up at a house on the hill, and it looked like it wason stilt on the water, Mrs. Schramm said.Cement block were all that remained ofhomes, fallen branch stood where tree used to be and muddystreams meandered through the outskirt of this Ohio River townafter a furious flash flood.Residents donned short and hip-waders Friday to begin puttingtheir life back together after 5{ inch of rain fell in 3{ hourslate Thursday, churning floodwaters that left at least 11 peopledead and 51 others missing early today.The shock had not worn off, said police officer Bruce Fink,whose bristly face bore sign of more than 20 hour on duty,including work at a temporary morgue set up at a funeral home.We have counselor back there now, but we've lost wholefamilies. It's just been devastating, he said Friday night.Fink said he feared there wouldn't be enough funeral home tohandle the dead in this eastern Ohio town of 4,300 people.Allan Hans called the flooding the devil's work.I lost everything but my car and the clothes I'm wearing, hesaid.Hans said he wa sitting in his trailer when he heard a branchcrack and went to check out the noise. He saw rushing water, ran totell neighbor and moved his car. The trailer wa swept away by thetime he returned home.John and Sue Wright, whose home rest on the bank of PipeCreek, estimated they lost about $20,000 worth of property.I wa one of the lucky one. What I lost, I can replace,Wright said.Although it wa the center of rescue operation, downtownShadyside suffered no apparent flood damage. But it wa a differentstory on the outskirt of town, in the heart of Ohio's richest coalfields.Cars were mired roof-deep in mud, and guardrail and chunk ofconcrete were torn from roads.A 20-foot, 18-inch thick beam that held a sign leading to 3K'sBar near Pipe Creek wa twisted like a pretzel by the force of whatwitnesses described a a wall of water.People moved rubble and made makeshift repair to bridge thatspan McMann Creek, which link home to Ohio Route 147. Manybridges were washed away.Small tractor and four-wheel-drive vehicle were the only meansof transportation in much of the stricken area.At least 170 member of the Ohio National Guard were called into patrol and to help rebuild flood-swept road, said Stacie Gilg,a spokeswoman for the Ohio Emergency Management Agency.Disasters always bring out the curious, and this wa noexception. By Friday night, traffic jammed Ohio Route 7, whichskirts the Ohio River and is the main north-south road through town.Belmont County Sheriff Tom McCort said he suspected many of thevehicles belonged to sightseers.McCort said there were no serious attempt at looting. He saidhe wa pleased with the assistance of young people.One young man turned in a strongbox filled with valuable coinslost in the flood, the sheriff said.The kid . handed me this box and it wa unlocked, McCortsaid. It really made me feel good.Thunderstorms swept through central andeastern Ohio, causing flooding that killed at least ten people,left dozen missing and forced hundred of others from their homes,officials said today.Two creek just outside this Ohio River village of 4,300 peopleoverflowed when about 4 inch of rain fell Thursday night in aboutan hour.It created a wall of water, said Jim Williams of the OhioEmergency Management Agency. The problem we're having right nowis accounting for the people we can't find.Williams said 40 to 60 people remained unaccounted for at midday.Belmont County's sheriff's Sgt. Bart Giesey said 10 people wereconfirmed deadGov. Richard Celeste declared a state of emergency and surveyedthe area.The raging water knocked home off their foundation and washedaway a bar filled with people in Shadyside, an Appalachian Mountainfoothill town.Temporary morgue were set up at Bellaire City Hospital and afuneral home in Shadyside. Four body were brought to the hospitalfrom the Shadyside area, hospital spokesman Lawrence England said.England said the four body were taken to the Bauknecht FuneralHome in Shadyside. Patty Valloric, director of the funeral home,said seven body had been brought there.The Shadyside Fire Department set up a command center at theJefferson Elementary School to coordinate rescue efforts.Command center spokeswoman Karen Bovek said official had nocomplete death toll figure. Authorities were searching for victimsin rural areas.You're talking mile and mile of country road that haven'tbeen gotten to yet, she said. It's a disaster here.Shadyside about 10 mile south of Wheeling, WVa. is inBelmont County, a mostly hilly, rural area in eastern Ohio.Acting Mayor James Amato said the storm created a deluge thatknocked home off their foundations.There are a lot of trailer out in this area that got hit,he said.Belmont County Sheriff's Department spokeswoman Judy Phillipssaid a Shadyside bar full of people wa washed away when watercaved in the back wall. Two people were accounted for, she said.But she could offer no estimate of how many were in the bar.Shadyside Fire Chief Mark Badia said rescuer pulled people fromthree car in Wegee Creek, which flow through Shadyside and intothe Ohio River.I don't know how to describe it . you've got to see it tobelieve it, Badia said.There also wa flooding in Jefferson County, north of Belmont,and Licking County in central Ohio.The Ohio department of transportation and natural resources,the State Highway Patrol, the Public Utilities Commission of Ohioand the American Red Cross are assisting state government inassessing the damage, Ohio Emergency Management Agency spokeswomanStacie Gilg said.About 200 resident were evacuated from their home in centralOhio after 3 inch of rain fell in an hour, flooding street andwashing out rural roads.Residents from Newark and Marne in Licking County spent Thursdaynight in three emergency shelter, said Licking County DisasterServices Agency spokesman Neil Snelling. Sixty resident were fromone street in Newark.Nobody ha been hurt, but everything is pretty wet here,Snelling said.The Newark Fire Department and other agency evacuatedresidents in low-lying area of Newark and the neighboring villageof Marne, said Wayne Tresemer, Licking County Disaster Servicesdirector.He said water wa standing up to 5 foot deep in some street onthe city's east side, and the Newark Fire Department and otheragencies used boat to evacuated some residents.Licking County wa already among 14 Ohio county covered in adisaster declaration issued by President Bush for storm earlierthis month, and people who suffered loss from Thursday night'sstorms will also be eligible for assistance, Ms. Gilg said.In Jefferson County, 50 to 60 resident were evacuated in Adena,where water wa 6 to 8 foot deep in street because of creekflooding.Two inch of rain caused flooding in Franklin County in centralOhio and 3.75 inch of rain wa dumped on Holmes County innorth-central Ohio, the National Weather Service said.Flood water in most area had subsided by Thursday night, theweather service and local authority said. The forecast for todaycalled for a slight chance of thunderstorm in central and southernOhio.The death toll from flash flood thatswept through a rural area of eastern Ohio rose to 20 Sunday assearchers dug along two creek and dived into the Ohio River.Sixteen people remained missing.Workers used shovel and pick to dig along the creek bank, andsifted through debris at place marked with red flag, where searchdogs indicated they'd detected human scent, said National GuardCapt. Jim Boling.Divers worked where the two creek empty into the Ohio.Four body were found Sunday. But two of those were notimmediately identified, and the list of missing wa not revised toaccount for them.The number missing dropped to 16 with the other two body andthe removal of two other names: a woman who called to say she wassafe and a person who authority weren't sure lived in the area,said coroner's investigator Chuck Vogt.The 20th victim wa pulled from the mouth of Pipe Creek at theOhio River, about seven mile south of Shadyside, Vogt said.Another body wa found in debris along Wegee Creek, and two bodieswere found earlier in the Ohio, he said.That brought the confirmed death toll in Thursday's flood to20, including five children.Twenty-three dog team from four state were searching forvictims, said Boling. The digging will continue at least throughTuesday, said Fire Chief Mark Badia.The thing you find once you start into these brush pile andpiles of tree are car, and they have to be torn apart andsearched separately, Badia said. Everything you turn up createsa different situation.But Vogt said he doubted many of the missing would be foundalive.It's just been too long. I don't think there's anybody aliveout there, he said. You can't swim out there that long in theOhio River.The Wegee and Pipe creek overflowed Thursday night duringstorms that poured 5{ inch of rain onto eastern Ohio in 3{ hours.The flood destroyed a many a 70 house and damaged up to 40others.Authorities said Friday that 60 people were missing; some ofthose were later found dead, while others notified authority thatthey were safe.Officials also learned that some of those feared missing hadmoved out of the area. Officials were comparing county propertylists and data from the Census Bureau with information fromresidents and relative, Boling said.Investigators Sunday blamed the flash flood on an unusuallyheavy rainstorm that overwhelmed the designed flow capacity ofthreebridges over the creek. Badia said rainwater running downhillsides forced debris into the creek, forming dam at eachbridge. The dam broke under the water pressure.Eventually the bridge couldn't hold any more. The debrisbroke loose, and that's when we got three big gush of water, hesaid.As rescue effort continued, the National Guard cleared roadsand bridge leading into the stricken area.Eighteen Ohio county have been declared federal disaster areassince tornado and flooding first struck May 25.Across the border in West Virginia, Gov. Gaston Caperton saidSunday he had no precise dollar figure on damage from floodingFriday along a five-mile stretch near New Martinsville and innearby Ohio County, but estimated it will run into million ofdollars.No death or serious injury were reported.Caperton toured flooded area in Wheeling and the Doolin Runcommunity near New Martinsville. He said he saw tremendousdevastation to hundred of house, house trailer and cars.State Public Safety Secretary Joseph Skaff estimated thatrepairing and replaceing bridge and road will cost about $750,000.National Guard soldier helped with cleanup Sunday.The death toll from last week's flashflood mounted to 21 today when a body wa found in the Ohio River,and authority said there wa little hope for the 14 people stilllisted a missing.It's just been too long. I don't think there's anybody aliveout there. You can't swim out there that long in the Ohio River,said Chuck Vogt, Belmont County coroner's investigator.The search for the missing wa suspended briefly this morningwhen a thunderstorm rolled through the area. Heavy rain fell forabout 45 minute, swelling Wegee Creek, one of two creek thatoverflowed in Thursday night's flash flood.By midmorning, the muddy creek wa nearly crossing a road aboutthree mile upstream from where the flood inflicted the mostdamage. Lt. Dean Irvin of the Ohio Army National Guard said therewere no immediate report of additional property damage.The body found this morning wa in the Ohio River nearMoundsville, W.Va., about 10 mile south of Shadyside, according toChuck Vogt, Belmont County coroner's investigator.The number of name on the list of missing dropped from 18 to 14with the identity of three victim and a call by one personalerting authority that she wa safe, Vogt said. One of therecovered body remains unidentified. Authorities are not rulingout the possibility that other people not on the list could bemissing.Four body were recovered Sunday.Officials said Friday that 60 people were missing; some of thoselater were found dead, while others notified authority that theywere safe and official learned that still more had moved out ofthe area.Wegee and Pipe creek overflowed during storm that dumped 5{inches of rain in 3{ hour. The flood destroyed a many a 70houses and damaged up to 40 others.Most of those whose home and belonging were swept away by thewall of water will have to put their life back together largelywithout benefit of insurance.Few people in the coal-mining and steel-making area carriedflood insurance, and homeowners' insurance will not cover damagefrom Thursday's flood, resident and insurer said.We didn't think we needed to have flood insurance. For what?That creek never flooded. Then this. Everybody just got wipedout, said Julia Kulazenka.Rainwater running down hillside had forced debris into thecreeks and formed dam at bridge spanning them, Shadyside FireChief Mark Badia said.Eventually the bridge couldn't hold any more. The debrisbroke loose, and that's when we got three big gush of water,Badia said.The home Mrs. Kulazenka shared with her husband until his deathlast July wa damaged a Wegee Creek raged out of control. She saidreplacing a machine shop, garage, deck and automobile she and herson owned would cost more than $80,000.They told u homeowners' won't do u no good. So unless thegovernment help u rebuild, I don't know what I'll do with thisplace, Mrs. Kulazenka said.The Federal Emergency Management Agency said it will open anoffice Tuesday in Shadyside to accept application from residentsfor low-interest loan and grant to help them rebuild.Before the flood, land in the Wegee Creek valley fetchedhandsome price, said Kulazenka's son, Charles Kulazenka. That wasespecially welcome to resident, many of whom were either retiredor laid off from job in coal mine in Belmont County, whereunemployment in April wa 6.8 percent.Ground wa at a premium down here before this because it wasjust outside the city limit (of Shadyside). It wa quiet andpeaceful and people were looking to buy and build new home outhere. Now, you couldn't give it away, Kulazenka said.But we can't be bitter, though, because we've got our lives,and a lot of our neighbor, real close buddy, weren't thatlucky.
column5: Ohio Flash Flood Kills 21; 14 Still Missing; Dozens Homeless
column6: Thursday night's flood in Ohio left twenty-one dead, 14 missing and dozens homeless. Two creeks outside Shadyside overflowed, knocking homes off their foundations and washing away a bar. Authorities said dams formed by debris at bridges broke under pressure, creating a "wall of water." Area residents are eligible for federal aid.
column7: The violent thunderstorms that struck central and eastern Ohio Thursday left twenty-one dead, 14 missing, and dozens homeless. Two creeks outside Shadyside overflowed in the heavy rain. Authorities said dams formed by debris at bridges broke under the water pressure, creating a "wall of water." Homes were knocked off their foundations and a Shadyside bar was swept away. Dog teams assisted in the search for victims. The National Weather Service had not issued a flood warning before the disaster.Gov. Celeste declared a state of emergency. The Federal Emergency Management Agency will open an office in Shadyside to accept applications for aid.
column8: The death toll from last week's floods reached 21 today when a body was pulled from the Ohio River. Hope is fading that the 14 people still listed as missing are alive. Violent thunderstorms swept through central and eastern Ohio Thursday night. The Wegee and Pipe creeks outside the Ohio River village Shadyside overflowed when about 4 inches of rain fell in about an hour. Authorities said dams formed by debris at bridges broke under the water pressure, creating a "wall of water." Homes were knocked off their foundations and a bar in Shadyside was swept away. In Licking and Jefferson counties, about 200 people were evacuated from their homes. Many residents recounted stories of narrow escapes and lost property.Few people carried flood insurance, and homeowners' insurance will not cover the damage. The Federal Emergency Management Agency will open an office in Shadyside to accept applications for aid. The National Weather Service said a flood watch, but not a warning, was issued before the disaster.Gov. Richard Celeste declared a state of emergency. The Shadyside Fire Department established a command center at the Jefferson Elementary School to coordinate rescue efforts. Authorities said dog teams assisted in the search for victims.
column9: Eastern Ohio floods kill 21, some still missing; damage extensive
column10: Eastern Ohio flash floods resulting from 5.5 inches of rain in less thanfour hours killed 21 persons and caused extensive damage. The governordeclared a state of emergency and sent in the National Guard.  Fourteenpersons remain missing a week later.  Few homeowners had flood insurance tocover damage.
column11: The death toll from floods in eastern Ohio rose to 21 and may to highersince 14 persons are still missing.  Torrential rains caused two creeks nearShadyside, Ohio, overflow and create a wall of water 15 to 20 feet high.The flood raged through the valley demolishing a crowded tavern and at least70 houses.  Governor Celeste declared a state of emergency and sent NationalGuard troops into the area to assist.  Dog teams were used to search forsurvivors and bodies.  Few of the damaged homes were covered by floodinsurance so the owners must look to federal assistance.
column12: Flash floods raged through small towns along the Ohio River in eastern Ohioon Thursday.  Death toll from the flood was put at ten initially, but wasraised to 21 as more bodies were found.  The number may still go highersince little hope remains for the fourteen still unaccounted for.  Thefloods hit two creeks near Shadyside, Ohio, about 10 miles south ofWheeling, West Virginia.  Five and a half inches of rain fell in slightlymore than three hours. The flood created a wall of water 15 to 20 feet highas it tore through the area.   The force of the raging water demolished acrowded tavern in Shadyside.  A nine-year-old girl who was swept into thecreek and on into the Ohio River miraculously survived a seven mile ordealby clinging to logs.Ohio Governor Celeste declared a state of emergency after surveying thearea.  The National Guard was brought in to patrol and help rebuild roads.Dog teams from four states were used in searching for survivors and bodies.Few homeowners had flood insurance to aid in rebuilding lost or damagedhomes.  The Federal Emergency Management Agency planned to acceptlow-interest loan and grant applications.

column3: Already they're saying it's thebiggest happening in astronomy since Galileo put his eye to atelescope.So, step right up folk, and discover the wonder of theuniverse. See how big it is. Learn it age. Look at light created14 billion year ago and arriving at your eye only this instant.Ride along to the beginning of everything, almost, to the BigBang of 10 or 20 thousand million year ago. See star born and seethem die. Watch galaxy form. Follow the flow of gas into theMilky Way's halo. Peer deep into the universe, past so many starsin our own galaxy that it would take a person more than a lifetimeto count, to a hundred billion other galaxy each with about 200billion stars.For scientist, and then the rest of u, all that becomespossible now that the space shuttle Discovery ha carried theHubble Space Telescope into the sky to see what no one ha seenbefore. The telescope, a silvery tube a long a a tanker truck,has an unmatched ability to detect and capture the faintest light.Light, speeding along at 186,000 mile a second, is themessenger of creation. Tracking the trail of light from today tothe first moment contains all the information we will ever haveabout the creation of the universe.The Hubble promise to give science an open window perhaps tothe first echo of creation. This is a world-class event, even ifastronomy is not your thing.Superlatives?In the history of optical astronomy there have been two greatleaps in the resolution of the universe: Galileo's telescope in theautumn of 1609, and the Hubble Space Telescope in April 1990. Eric J. Chaisson, a senior scientist at the Space Telescope ScienceInstitute in Baltimore.One more?No one ever made anything that good, James Westphal,California Institute of TechnologyAnother?Dr. Lennard Fisk, NASA's chief scientist, predicts that theHubble telescope will literally be the dawn of a new era inastronomy.Eras rarely can be proclaimed in advance. But the HST, namedafter Edwin Powell Hubble, hold that kind of promise.Hubble wa an astronomer in the first half of the century whoconcluded not only that distant galaxy are moving away from Earthbut that the farther away they are, the faster they move. Thetheory of an expanding universe supported the belief that theuniverse originated in a cosmic explosion and that all matter isstill rushing from the site of that so-called Big Bang.Astronomers think the Big Bang occurred 12 billion to 20 billionyears ago and sent the entire universe flying out at incrediblespeed and heat. Eventually matter cooled and condensed intogalaxies, star and planets.There are bigger telescope than the Hubble, but they are all onEarth and all subject to a major limitation the atmosphere which is fine for breathing but lousy for seeing through. Theproblem of skywatching through layer of air ha been likened tobirdwatching from the bottom of a swimming pool.The Voyager spacecraft, which sent back astonishing view ofEarth's sister planet, had to travel 12 year to get close enoughfor picture a they whizzed past. With the Hubble, say scientistEdward Weiler, such picture are possible any time we want.The telescope is 42.5 by 14 foot and consists of a 94.5-inchprimary mirror that gather incoming light.On a clear, dark night you can see a flashlight from two milesaway, say Weiler, chief NASA scientist on the Hubble project.With a 28-power telescope you can see it on the moon 250,000miles away. With the HST you could see a firefly in Australia fromWashington.Ground controller at the GoddardSpace Flight Center finally made contact today with the two mainantennas on the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope after tryingfor more than six hour to lock on.Applause erupted in the Hubble control center in Greenbelt, Md.,as the glitch that marred Hubble's first full day in space wassolved.We have confirmation that we have achieved communication withthe Tracking and Data Relay Satellite through the high-gain antennasystem, said NASA's Dave Drachlis.Engineers had said all along they believed the antenna wereworking all right and that the problem wa in incorrectly pointingeither the satellite or the TDRS, an orbiting communicationssatellite that act a a switchboard.In the successful attempt, they nearly doubled the width of theantennas' beam to take in more territory, from a sweep of 6.2degrees to 10.8 degrees.The telescope's low-gain antenna, which receive and transmitinformation at a much slower rate and can be used in emergencies,were working well.Space shuttle Discovery wa 46 mile away, available to remedycertain problem. The outage wa not a problem for which spacewalker would have been summoned.The five astronaut were otherwise busy making picture ofstorms over Texas from their 380-mile-high perch, and doingexperiments.Steve Terry, director of a team calibrating various aspect ofthe telescope, said the first outage wa caused by human error andwas not a serious problem. It began between 1 and 1:30 am. EDT andlasted 45 minute to an hour, he said.The second failure occurred at 6:44 am. when controllersattempted to send a signal to the telescope's two high-gainantennas through the TDRS.This time it wa a pointing problem, said Jim Elliott, aGoddard spokesman. It's a new spacecraft and we thinkinexperience dealing with it wa the cause.The telescope, embarking on a 15-year search for new world, wasreleased from the shuttle's cargo bay Wednesday after a last-minutesnag that almost sent two astronaut on an emergency spacewalk.Mission Control awakened the crew early today with a loudrendition of the song Shout, a fraternity house favorite.Good morning, Discovery. I guess you're awake after thatsong, said Kathy Thornton, shuttle communicator. There are alot of happy people down here. We saw a great deploy yesterday andHubble had a good night while you were asleep.We appreciate the good word from everybody, repliedDiscovery Commander Loren Shriver.After Wednesday's deployment, Shriver gently backed Discoveryaway from the telescope and put the shuttle through a series ofmaneuvers, the last one completed this morning, to parkDiscovery in orbit 46 mile behind Hubble.The telescope really looked great a we flew away from it, andwe sure hope it doe good work, Shriver said Wednesday.Well, it sure is now, Loren, and thanks for all the great workyou've done, replied Mission Control. Galileo is real proud ofyou.Scientists have hailed the Hubble NASA's most expensiveunmanned spacecraft a the greatest advance in astronomy sinceGalileo raised a small telescope to his eye nearly 400 year ago.Discovery and it five astronaut will follow the telescopewhile controller at the Goddard center make sure Hubble isoperating properly, such a responding to directional commands.The next milestone is Friday, when the telescope's 10-footaperture door is to be opened, exposing the finely polished94.5-inch mirror to starlight.Then on Tuesday, NASA expects to release the first image fromthe telescope: an open star cluster in the constellation Carina.Data will follow in a month or two.If the aperture door doesn't open properly, Discovery couldreturn to the telescope so two astronaut could perform a spacewalkto fix it.Hubble project manager Fred Wojtalik said the telescope would betested today for it ability to maneuver before the aperture dooris opened.We want to be in full control so we don't ever endanger theHubble by putting the aperture door close to the sunlight, hesaid. Too much light could damage the telescope's sensitiveinstruments.On Wednesday, mission specialist Steve Hawley used the shuttle's50-foot robot arm to gently grasp the 12{-ton telescope and hoistit from the cargo bay.One of the telescope's solar array unreeled from it mast asexpected and started providing power to the telescope's batteries,which otherwise had only eight hour of charge.But there wa trouble with the second panel. It wouldn't budgewhen the latch were released, and then moved about a fifth of its39-foot length and stopped again. The panel rolled all the way outon the third attempt.By the final attempt, astronaut Bruce McCandless and KathrynSullivan were in their space suit in the airlock, 30 minute awayfrom taking tool in hand and going on an outer-space maintenancecall.Wojtalik said the cause of the problem is unknown.The 8{-hour procedure wa performed 380 mile above Earth, 70miles higher than any shuttle ha ever flown. column5: How the Hubble Space Telescope Finally Got Into Orbit
column6: After a delay of seven years caused by technical problems and the Challenger accident, the Hubble Space Telescope was launched on space shuttle Discovery on April 24, 1990 and four days later was orbiting on its own 380 miles above the earth's atmosphere. The system still had problems but great potential.
column7: Scientists were elated with the successful launch of space shuttle Discovery with the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) aboard on April 24, 1990. Deployment of the telescope was originally scheduled for 1983 but was delayed by technical problems and the Challenger accident.  Although the communications and electronics systems of the HST still presented some problems, by April 28 the telescope was in orbit 380 miles above the earth's atmosphere with the potential of providing 10 times better resolution and 25 times more sensitivity than ground-based observatories. The Discovery astronauts were permitted to return to Earth.
column8: Deployment of the Hubble Space Telescope (HST), originally scheduled for 1983, was delayed by technical problems and the Challenger accident in 1986 and did not take place until April 1990. The HST had two mirrors, one 94.5 inches in diameter and the other 12 inches. Electrical power was provided by two wing-like solar arrays. It was named after Edwin P. Hubble who discovered in the 1920s that the universe is constantly expanding. Scientists regarded the telescope as the greatest advance in astronomy since Galileo, providing 10 times better resolution and 25 times more sensitivity than ground-based observatories.  A successful launch of space shuttle Discovery with the HST aboard took place at 8:34 a.m. April 24, 1990 and Discovery ascended into orbit 380 miles above Earth. On April 25 the HST was placed in orbit on its own with Discovery trailing behind to provide astronaut assistance if needed. The HST's aluminum aperture door was successfully opened on April 27 exposing the telescope's 94.5- inch mirror to starlight. By April 28 there were still problems with the electronic and communications systems, but procedures were in place to take care of these, the HST was in orbit, and the Discovery astronauts prepared for return to earth on April 29, 1990.

column3: And for the sentimentalist, there will be 83-year-old Johnny Kelleystarting in his 60th Boston Marathon. There have only been 35 edition of thisrace run without him.; The last three Boston marathon have turned intoreckless speed duel. They have produced five of the top 10 time and eight ofthe top 15 in the race's storied history.; They also have resulted in arace of attrition, with many of the early speedsters burning out completely orfaltering in the late stages.; Along the historic route that begin inHopkinton, west of Boston, and end in Copley Square in the Back Bay sectionof the city, checkpoint record have fallen at an alarming rate.; Forexample, all 11 checkpoint record were shattered through the first 20 mileslast year, either by Simon Robert Naali or Juma Ikangaa, both of Tanzania.Neither won.; The winner wa 1988 Olympic champion Gelindo Bordin, whooutsmarted the early pacesetter by running a patient, calculating race.;Running alone about 200 meter behind a pack of six Africans, Bordin passedthem all by 21 mile and went on to win in 2 hour, 8 minute, 19 second, thesecond-fastest time in the race's history, behind only the 2:07:51 by Rob deCastella in 1986.; Ikangaa finished a distant second in 2:09:52. It wa histhird consecutive runner-up finish in Boston.; Ikangaa is back again, alongwith several other formidable Africans. They include Ibrahim Hussein of Kenya,the 1988 winner in 2:08:43, the third-fastest time in Boston and one secondahead of Ikangaa; Abebe Mekonnen of Ethiopia, the 1989 champion in 2:09:06,Boston's eighth-best time; Douglas Wakiihuri of Kenya, the 1987 world championand 1988 Olympic silver medalist who is making his Boston debut; and Naali,the third-place finisher in the 1990 Commonwealth Games.; Among thosechasing them will be John Treacy, the 1984 Olympic silver medalist and thethird-place finisher in Boston in 1988 and 1989; Geoff Smith, the Bostonwinner in 1984-85; Ed Eyestone, the top-ranked US. marathoner; SalvadorGarcia, the runner-up to Wakiihuri in last year's New York City Marathon; andRolando Vera, who finished third in his marathon debut in Boston in 1990.;The women's division also is filled with many respectable entrants.;Foremost among them are Kristiansen, the 35-year-old Norwegian who hold theworld record of 2:21:06 and won in Boston in 1986 and 1989, and Samuelson, 33,the U.S.-record holder at 2:21:21, 1984 Olympic gold medalist and Bostonchampion in 1979 and 1983.; Challenging them will be Uta Pippig, WandaPanfil and Kim Jones.; Pippig finished second in Boston last year in acareer-best 2:28:03. Panfil won the London Marathon in 2:26:31, her personalbest, and won the New York City Marathon in 1990.TOMORROW evening, just before the Olympic closing ceremony, the last and oneof the most prestigious event of the Games will be held. It is also withoutdoubt the most gruelling. Run in high heat, high humidity, high pollutionlevels and over an extraordinary course, the Barcelona Olympic men'smarathon will prove one of the most physically demanding ever run. There arelots of figure to show why. It is estimated that when the race begin inMataro, a seaside town north of Barcelona, the temperature will be analready-uncomfortable 25`C. Towards the marathon's end, however, radiantheat thrown off by building could be subjecting the runner to atemperature of up to 30`C. More debilitating still, relative humidity inBarcelona in August rise a high a 80 per cent. With more than 10kilometres still to go, most of the course is an upward run. The last 4.6km,which take the runner 60m higher still to the Olympic stadium at the top ofthe hill of Montjuic, ha an average gradient of more than 4.5 per cent, andincludes some section of 7 per cent, equivalent in skiing term to a steep'red' run. But we do not need figure to convince u of the extraordinarydifficulty of tomorrow's race. Last Saturday, in the Olympic stadium, Iwatched the final moment and aftermath of the women's marathon, begun atthe same time of day and run in similar condition. Never in any eventvoluntarily entered into, sporting or otherwise, have I seen such sign ofphysical and mental distress. The race wa won by the Unified Team'sValentina Yegorova in 2 hour 32 minute, a time considerably slower thanthat achieved by woman on le demanding Olympic marathon course in LosAngeles and Seoul. After her nearest competitor, Japan's Yuko Arimori, camein eight second later, they had the energy - between bout of grimacing andlowering their head to their knee - to embrace each other and smile forthe cameras.It wa a different story in the 'mixed zone,' the area under the stadiumwhere athlete recover after their event. As runner after runner stumbledand limped into the room - several were brought in senseless on stretcher -the scene seemed to be populated by exhausted boat people rescued afterweeks of exposure and deprivation at sea.As a photographer calmly shot off a roll of film a foot from her face,Manuela Machado of Mexico and another runner stood vomiting violently into apotted palm. Several competitor lay prone and gasping on the ground aswater wa poured over them; others stood hunched over, grasping theirabdomens.If anyone moved at all, it wa with agonised face and the slowest ofhobbles. These are not the sort of scene likely to promote enthusiasm formarathon running or for the ideal of Olympic competition.Chris Brasher, organiser of the London marathon, wa on hand to witness thesuffering, and wa incensed.
