Male marathon runner will face the same kindof problem with heat, humidity, and an over-demanding terrain, he said.In his opinion, gearing the marathon to prime-time TV viewing and having theevent end at the top of a hill for the sake of stadium spectator wasunjustified and a 'sell-out to commercialism.'To put on the marathon in the late afternoon, rather than first thing inthe morning (the normal practice), and then to make them run 4km up a hillis just criminal in my opinion,' said Brasher, a former Olympic gold medalathlete and noted sportswriter.I spoke to Britain's Steve Brace, winner of the Paris marathon in 1989 and1990, the Berlin marathon last year and a competitor in the Barcelona event.He agrees that the run will be highly demanding, and while he regardsOlympic marathon running a a pinnacle of his career, he is cautious abouttomorrow's slog.Like almost all the athlete running tomorrow, Brace is a professionalrunner who specialises in marathon. He take an objective, long-term viewof his profession. As an income-earner, marathon running is an activity withliabilities and limitation, and requires business management a well asphysical ability.The winner of the London marathon earns a tidy Dollars 50,000 and the NewYork, Boston and Japanese run are all in the same prize-winning category.But these and le financially-rewarding event are physically debilitating,and can only be won if a competitor is in top physical shape.With their career and financial prospect in mind, top-level runnersnormally only run two marathon a year. As Brace say, when you have onlytwo pay-days out of 365, you choose, plan and train for them with greatcare.Brace train extremely carefully indeed. 'Running a marathon is the easypart,' he say. 'The hard part is the lead-up to achieving the performancelevel required.' He start training three month before an event by running80 mile a week and then building progressively. For the last six week heruns 120 mile a week.Normally he would hope that such a routine brings a pay-off. But the Olympicmarathon is an exception: the only top-level marathon that carry no prizemoney. Brace say that in spite of the prestige and possible financialspin-offs involved, 'it doe not necessarily make sense to run to win.'Given the highly demanding nature of the course and their desire to preservephysical condition for race that do bring in money, he say, many runnerswill give le than their best effort.Nonetheless, there are plenty whose consideration stretch beyond the purelyfinancial. Italian Gelindo Bordin, who came first in the 1988 Seoul Olympicmarathon, is a strong contender. So is Djibouti's Ahmed Salah, who camethird in Seoul. Ibrahim Hussein of Kenya and Hiromi Taniguchi of Japan arealso possible winners.None of them, though, will make a molehill out of the steep and formidableascent of Montjuic.A crowd the size of a small city will squeeze past a starting line here March 1 to run 26 mile, 385 yard. And cheering every step of that distance will be more than a dozen corporate sponsor and licensee. Makers of car, soda pop, sportswear, copier, computer -- even a hospital -- have tagged their name to the Los Angeles Marathon. In the promoter's word, this run is "a marketing event on legs," reflecting marathoning's growing importance in upscale product promotion. Runners, it seems, are a well-heeled lot. A study by Mercedes-Benz found that 42% of family head making $40,000 a year or more jog regularly. Of potential buyer showing up at Mercedes dealer, 47% are jogger. With those number in mind, the car maker ha become a sponsor of three marathon -- in New York, Boston and Los Angeles -- a well a other running race. Marathons have had corporate backing for some time. But Los Angeles is ahead of the pack in making distance running a commercial spectacle. The city that invented the corporate-sponsored Olympics ha created a marathon unlike others -- artfully dressed a an Olympic-type amateur race, but built from the ground up to make money for the closely held company that control it -- a well a for the city. "I took air and made an event," say William Burke, the founder and president of Los Angeles Marathon Inc. For a man whose running day ended with his high school track team, Mr. Burke is turning a lot of head in the world of marathoning. Last year, it first time out, the Los Angeles race attracted nearly 11,000 runner -- four time the number forecast and enough to make it the third -- largest race in the US. The event also pulled in about $4 million in cash and service from it sponsor, leaving the organizer with $370,000 in red ink. This year, Mr. Burke and his partner, Marie Patrick, expect to gross about $5 million in cash and service and to break even. Next year, they say, a profit is possible. More than 18,000 runner are expected this year. An audience of perhaps a million and a half or more will line the route, drawn in part by advertisement on 75 million Coca-Cola can and 2,500 billboard around the Los Angeles area. Marketing expert say the festive atmosphere of big crowd in the street make marathon attractive to sponsor. For the cost of a 30-second ad on the Super Bowl, a company can sponsor a marathon and "take over a city," say Lesa Ukman, editor of Special Events Reports, a Chicago-based newsletter. The Los Angeles organizer and sponsor have perhaps done more than their counterpart elsewhere to publicize the event. Los Angelenos are seeing plug for the race on million of grocery bag, milk carton and loaf of bread, in addition to soda can, billboard and other source. The venerable New York Marathon is taking note. The New York Road Runners Club, organizer of the race, stopped promoting the event some year ago because it had all the runner it wanted. Now, Fred Lebow, the group's president, say he is encouraging sponsor to promote the race a the Los Angeles sponsor do. The promotion in Los Angeles is unabashed. "We tell people that if they're looking for a new way to crack the Los Angeles market, this is it," say Mr. Burke. The pitch ha attracted the like of Coca-Cola Bottling Co. of Los Angeles; Vons Cos., a large supermarket chain; the Los Angeles Times; the Sears Savings Bank unit of Sears, Roebuck & Co.; Eastman Kodak Co., and Tandem Computers Inc. One supporter is Ellesse USA, a sportswear and shoe producer. A $50,000 fee enables the company to use the marathon's name in it ads; Ellesse will spend an additional $100,000 dressing race personnel in T-shirts and warm-up suit, showing it clothes at the marathon's public "Expo" of sponsors' ware, and posting a dozen big street banner along the course. The company ha rented more than 500 billboard at a cut-rate price of $120,000 from Patrick Media Group, a marathon sponsor. The discount, about 50%, wa important. "We couldn't have bought that kind of exposure normally," say Susan Cialone, Ellesse's advertising director. Ellesse, which also sponsor the New York run, find the West Coast event more freewheeling. "They have let u do whatever we want," say Ms. Cialone. For instance, product banner along the route -- almost impossible to arrange in New York -- are a snap in Los Angeles. The city, in fact, is a partner in the race. After competitive bidding, it awarded an eight-year contract to Los Angeles Marathon Inc. to put on the race. The exclusive franchise call for the race organizer this year to pay a minimum $60,000 fee or 4% of gross cash receipt to the city. The organizer also will pay the cost of city service for the marathon, estimated at $100,000. The race sponsor and city official are trading freely on the good will generated by Los Angeles's role a host of the 1984 Olympics. The logo of the marathon is a shield with laurel wreath. Some poster show the Los Angeles Coliseum with it torch and giant Olympic symbol. "The World Returns to Los Angeles," proclaims one Mercedes-Benz ad. Race director are called "commissioners," a term borrowed from the 1984 Olympic organization, in which Mr. Burke wa commissioner of tennis. And like the Olympics, Los Angeles Marathon Inc., portraying the race a a civic celebration, thrives on volunteer. Some 7,500 people will work for free to monitor the course on race day. And two-thirds of the race's office staff work without pay. "I couldn't buy this," Mr. Burke say, gesturing around the crowded race headquarters. Not everyone work for free. Big-name runner, for instance, want to be paid a lot. And here, the organizer have pinched penny. While some runner will be paid to appear, this year's field, like last year's, lack some of the superstar who race in Boston, New York and London. Grete Waitz, one of the best woman marathoner, wanted $100,000 to appear in Los Angeles; she wa turned down. Mr. Burke say the Australian runner Rob de Castella made it known through his agent that he wouldn't run any marathon in the spring but, for $25000, he'd be happy to say the Los Angeles event wa tempting. Mr. Burke say he slammed down the phone. "We won't spend extraordinary amount of money on any single runner to the detriment of the other runners," he say. Mr. de Castella's agent denies the story entirely. What Los Angeles lack in superstar, it plan to make up for in number. This year's race may challenge New York and London a the largest marathon ever run. Some 20,500 started the New York race last year. Mr. Lebow, organizer of the New York event, say next year's Los Angeles Marathon will surpass that number. For one sponsor, this may be a mixed blessing. Orthopaedic Hospital, a not-for-profit institution whose sponsorship is part of a publicity campaign, provides emergency care station along the marathon route. Last year, one of every 20 runner needed aid. Along with sprain, strain and blister came more serious case of exhaustion and hypothermia. A spokeswoman says: "We advised 250 people to quit the race."The Olympic trial, scheduled for January, have made Nichols' job mucheasier this year. Most top-ranked US. woman are looking for any summer-timemarathon in which to run and the San Francisco version offer excellentconditions.; The hill of San Francisco make this marathon challenging. Theweather, however, make it one of the few enticing race held from June toSeptember. Early morning temperature range in the low 50 in late June.;"This is the only place in the world where you can have a marathon in themiddle of summer," Nichols said.; Defending champ back; Last year'swinner, Janis Klecker of Minnetonka, Minn., is entered. The field also boastsJanine Aiello of Albuquerque, N.M.; Michelle Bush-Cuke of Berrien Springs,Mich.; Christine Gibbons of Elmwood, N.J.; Lesley Lahane of Chestnut Hills,Mass.; Julie Shea-Graw of Raleigh, N.C., and Jane Welzel of Fort Collins,Colo.; All seven woman have run marathon under the 2-hour, 40-minutebarrier. Klecker turned in a 2:39:52 on the 26.2-mile course.; Welzel isthe 1990 national champion, Gibbons ha won 26 marathon, Lahane is a formercross-country national champion and Aiello twice ha finished second in SanFrancisco.; A test for Shea-Graw; Shea-Graw, 32, finished third in the 1981New York City Marathon and wa consistently ranked among the top five Americanrunners throughout most of the early '80s. She wa the top qualifier for the1980 Olympics team that missed the Moscow Summer Games because of a U.S.boycott.; This will be Shea-Graw's first race outside of North Carolinasince 1986, when she took time off to have a child.; "I've run some localraces," Shea-Graw said. "This is going to be a test for me. If it go well,then I'll up the ante and give my training the time that is needed to becomecompetitive again."; Shea-Graw's best time is 2:30:11.; "I had somemajor injury and wanted to have a child," Shea-Graw said. "But now it's timeto get on with my career"Mr. Kelley is in training for the Boston Marathon -- his60th Boston Marathon. And even at the age of 83, he probablywill finish ahead of a large number of the 13,000 runnersexpected to compete -- officially or unofficially -- on April15.Bill Rodgers, a four-time Boston Marathon winner who plansto run again this year, marvel at Mr. Kelley: "It'sincomprehensible that a man his age is doing what he's doing.I'm struggling at the age of 43. . . . This isn't golf."Even the thought of running a course of 26 mile and 385yards leaf some of Mr. Kelley's rival of yesteryeargasping. "Aghast is more like it," say Leslie Pawson, 86, athree-time Boston champion who ran against Mr. Kelley half acentury ago. "My doctor says: `No running, whatsoever.' Ican't even remember when I ran my last marathon."John Adelbert Kelley is a throwback to a time whenmarathoners did it for glory and cab fare. A two-time winnerin Boston (1935 and 1945) and runner-up seven time, Mr.Kelley is to be the oldest competitor in the race this year-- a he ha been for 15 yearsMr. Kelley is such an institution that Hopkinton, Mass.,where the race begin, ha made him an honorary citizen.("That mean I don't have to pay tax there," he jokes.) Twostate trooper will run alongside the 5-foot-6, 130-pound Mr.Kelley into Boston so he won't be trampled by "groupies," ashe call them, clamoring to shake his hand. Last year, fiveJapanese runner were waved away by the bodyguard, a theysidled up to the old celebrity during the race. Recalls SuniTomomitsu, one of the runners: "At first we thought, `Ohwow, he's like Mafia man.' Then we said, `Oh no, this is niceJohnny Kelley.' In Japan, he is awesome."Though he isn't the oldest person ever to enter the BostonMarathon, Mr. Kelley is the oldest to run it. Peter Foley,who wa born in 1859, wa a regular until he wa well intohis 80. But he walked the course. Starting at dawn (sixhours before the official noon start), Mr. Foley wouldeventually saunter across the finish line in the moonlight.Of course, Mr. Kelley -- not to be confused with the otherJohn Kelley, who won the Boston Marathon in 1957 -- isn't therunner he wa in 1935 when he won the race, in 2 hour, 32minutes, 7 second. His best time ever wa in 1945: 2 hours,30 minute, 40 second. Last year he finished in 5 hour, 5minutes. He hope to do better in 1991. "That's not aprediction, just a goal," he says.When John Kelley first toed the line in 1928, George Bushwasn't yet in kindergarten, Joe DiMaggio wa an unknown andNike wa the winged goddess of victory, not a running shoe.In those day, Mr. Kelley recall, he ran in black leatherhigh-jumping shoe that he cut open at the toe with a razorblade. "I would have loved to run with the worst pair ofsneakers on the market today," he says.Back then, the sport didn't have much of a following.Today, of course, the Boston Marathon is a big deal, coveredby TV from start to finish and offering $402,000 altogetherin prize money."The winner get a medal and $55,000," say Mr. Kelley. "Igot a medal and beef stew. God bless them," he add. "Theydeserve it."The rosy-cheeked, supple Mr. Kelley is a medical wonder.Each year, he visit the Cooper Clinic at the Aerobics Centerin Dallas for a battery of endurance test. "Physiologically,whatever that mean, I got all A's," Mr. Kelley report ofhis checkup four month ago."What that means," explains Kenneth Cooper, the physicianwho wrote "Aerobics" and several sequel and is now at workon a book on elderly athlete, "is that Johnny ha the bodyof a man 23 year younger. He's going to be one of the starsof my book." Mr. Kelley's resting pulse rate -- 60 beat aminute -- is well below the average person's 72 beats.(That's good.) On the stress test the clinic give, Mr.Kelley hold the endurance record for his age group.A mechanic for Boston Edison Co. before he retired in1972, Mr. Kelley started running in the evening after workmore than six decade ago. His only purpose wa to relax andhave some fun. "All day long, I did what my bos told me todo," he recall. "But when I ran at night, I felt free. I rantill I wa exhausted."In 1928, when he wa 21, he entered his first BostonMarathon but didn't finish. He dropped out three-quarters ofthe way through the race. Then, in 1933, he finished 37th ina field of about 200 runner. In all the year since, he hasmissed the race just once, in 1967. (He ha competed, alltold, in 112 marathon, including the 1936 and 1948 OlympicsMr. Kelley well know the jagged course from Hopkinton todowntown Boston:The first challenge come five mile into the race, wherea set of little hill can get a psyched runner to wasteenergy charging up the slope. A mile and a half later,there's new reason to beware: The smell of Cavanaugh'sBakery can set off hunger pangs.An Exxon station in Wellesley mark the halfway point. Asteep descent into Newton Lower Falls can jar a tiredrunner's bone. Then, at the end of a long column of oak andmaple tree, is Heartbreak Hill, his nemesis. It cost him atleast two victory, he say. And finally there's the HauntedMile, a stretch where many runner have collapsed. Boston'sskyline, 2 1/2 mile in the distance, can seem so far away.Though still going strong, Mr. Kelley acknowledges themarathon get tougher each year. To compensate, he trainsharder. He used to start preparing in earnest at the end ofJanuary. "In recent year, I've been in training 12 month ayear," he say, though the serious stuff -- a daily one-hourrun, sprint on the track and long, 2 1/2-hour run everyother week -- begin in December. (He doesn't count the mileshe put in, a many long-distance runner obsessively do, buthe say he wouldn't object to an estimate of about 50 mile aweek)Mr. Kelley always train at 5 a.m., and alone: "It's aquiet time, no traffic; the air is fresh and sweet." Hisroutes vary. In January, he prefers the frozen sand of thebeach. With the approach of spring, he take to the alder andscrub-pine hill and bluff where the sun can be seen risingover Cape Cod Bay. After his morning run, he spends a coupleof hour painting (still life and Cape Cod scenes), a hobbyhe took up about 25 year ago.Unlike many runner, Mr. Kelley doesn't bother withstretching exercise before he run in the morning. "This ismy warm up: I empty the dishwasher, I set up the coffeepot,but I don't plug it in. I set up the breakfast table. Then Icheck the outside temperature to see what clothes to wear."He and his wife, Laura, live in a two-bedroom ranch-stylehouse here in East Dennis, with more than 350 trophies,medals and sweat-stained marathon number scattered about. Heisn't particular about brand of shoe ("I wear them all") orwhat he eats ("I never eat broccoli, but I love steak and icecream")Mr. Kelley aim to run till he is at least 100 year old."He's a strange man," say Laura Kelley, in awe of herhusband's vigor. The 82-year-old Mrs. Kelley add, "I justtry to stay in his shadow, but I have a hard time even doingthat."In a rare moment of reflection, Mr. Kelley explains whatmakes him tick: "I paint because I like it. I run because Ilike it. If for some reason I don't finish the marathon, Idon't owe an apology to anyone. But I'll tell you, the BostonMarathon -- with all those people waving -- is better than mybirthday."Television watcher of the 19th annual New YorkCity Marathon followed the step-by-step progress Sunday of theleaders, but many spectator on the course scanned the thousand ofrunners for a familar face.The winner in the field of 23,478 largest ever for a marathon wa Steve Jones of Wales, who finished in 2 hour, 8 minute and 20seconds, only seven second off the course record. Grete Waitz ofNorway won the women's division for a record ninth time in 2:28:07.Marybeth Torpe wa hoping another runner would run fast herboyfriend Tony Giannelli.She and several others had staked out the corner table at arestaurant on First Avenue to get a good view of the runner a theyromped off the Queensboro Bridge.Their hope on seeing Giannelli depended on how fast the Yonkersnative ran. We have to leave this table by 12:30. The manager'skicking u out, said one of Giannelli's friend, Pete Koogan.Torpe wa eager for Giannelli to finish, too.I'm going to ask him to marry me today, she said, holding upthe rose she planned to give him.Crowds cheered for the those in the lead pack and the also-ranson the warm, sunny autumn day.Lynne Avery, a sophomore at Morristown (N.J.) High School, waitedon First Avenue near 60th Street hoping to catch a glimpse of herEnglish teacher, Robert Paciorkowski. But she wa not taking anychances on missing himMr. Paciorkowski told u if he saw a television camera, he'dwave to u, Avery said a she held a small portable televisionin her hand.All along the marathon route, volunteer handed drink torunners, but Rick Fairlamb of Glen Rock, N.J., had prepared aspecial elixir of carrot juice. He handed them out to the 50 or sorunners in the Natural Living running club who passed his tableat 61st Street and First Avenue.Last night I went into Brooklyn and got 500 pound of carrotsfrom a food co-op. We juiced them starting at 5 this morning, hesaid.In Central Park, Richard Borrego stood on the railing with abullhorn, waiting for his favorite in the race to pas. He didn'thave any trouble finding them.I'm cheering for Grete and Steve Jones, Mr. Borrego said,referring to the winners.They're both so courteous, full of good sportsmanship. Theyalways help other runner. They never knock other runner, Borregosaid. And that's the way it should be.In Washington, D.C., more than 13,000 people from 23 countriesand 49 state ran the Marine Corps Marathon, which offer no prizemoney and pride itself on being the people's race.Jim Hage, a lawyer from Lanham, Md., who had never won a majormarathon, pulled away from two-time champion Brad Ingram in the lasthalf mile to win in 2:21:58.But a unique subset ha formed: people who like to do both at the sametime. And to help these folk along, company arrange tour for marathonvacations. The result? Bangkok in November, London in April and Stockholm inMay.;"Skiers have mountain range, tennis player have resort, why can't arunner take a marathon vacation?" said Thorn Gilligan, president of MarathonTours in Boston. "A runner should be able to enjoy a closed city for a day.It's a celebration for the sport a much a a competition.";Gilligan took5,500 people last year on 20 tour to country from Bermuda to Moscow. Inaddition to air fare and hotel, runner are guaranteed spot in restrictedentry race such a the London Marathon. Qualifying time are not required.; London, the most popular European city to visit, hold the world's largestmarathon (April 12 next year). Berlin's race (Sept. 27, 1992) ha grown withthe demise of the wall.;"Most marathon take you through city, so you geta chance to see thing you'd never see on a sightseeing bus," said Fred Lebow,president of the New York Roadrunner's Club and director of the New YorkMarathon. Lebow ha run in 32 marathon, including London, Paris, RomeStockholm, Iceland, Seoul and Vienna.;"The most exciting thing is the startof the race," he said. "Each city ha something unique.";The city aredifferent, but most marathon include a carbo-loading pasta party the nightbefore, medical exam, a post-race celebration, commemorative T-shirts andawards to finisher. Entry fee vary; Brussels is $16, Venice $40.;MarathonTours includes the entry price in the package. Going to Bermuda, for example,costs approximately $900 from San Francisco. The price includes round-trip airfare, four day and three night at the Grotto Bay Beach hotel (per person,based on double occupancy), full breakfast and dinner, a welcome cocktailparty and post-race party and discounts.;England ha similarorganizations: Sports Tours International and Keith Prowse, a company thatspecializes in British theater, sport and concert tours.;But it isn'tnecessary to run 26.2 mile to go on a running vacation, especially if it's afamily trip. Some marathon, like Portland's, include additional races: afive-mile run, a five-mile walk and a kid run. Tel Aviv ha a half-marathonand a fun run. Budapest offer a half-marathon and a mini-marathon along theDanube.;There are also trip that incorporate running into the sightseeingschedule. Running coach Pat Savage and Hal Higdon, a senior writer forRunner's World, are taking a group to Ireland in June. The eight-day trip willleave from Chicago and will include sightseeing, guided run and a fun runfrom Malahide Castle to Swords.;"On a running vacation you plan somethingaround running everyday," Higdon said. "We know the unique scenic route andput together special runs.";Some run are intriguing because of currentevents. The Tel Aviv Marathon course went past house hit by Scud missilesduring the Gulf War. The Belgrade Marathon wa held despite Yugoslavia'sturmoil. The Munich course is the same a the 1972 Olympic route and finishesin the same stadium.;Running 26 mile just to see a city definitely isn'tfor everyone, but at the very least, it's a way to kill two bird with onestone. In the recent Chicago Marathon, a German man ran with a camera,snapping photo every few miles.; IF YOU'RE INTERESTED;If you're interestedin combining a vacation and marathon, here are some firm to contact:;(box)Marathon Tours, 108 Main St., Charlestown, Mass. 02129. (617) 242-7845.; (box) Roadrunner Tours, 2815 Lake Shore Dr., Michigan City, Ind. 46360. (219879-0133.;(box) Keith Prowse, based in England. (8OO) 6MY-TOUR.;(box)Sports Tours International, 91 Walkdon Rd., Walkdon, Worslay, Manchester M285DQ, United Kingdom. (061) 703-8161.
column5: Marathons attract both professional athletes as well as amateur runners.
column6: Marathons attract both professional athletes as well as amateur runners.  Some marathons concentrate on the commercial and moneymaking side of marathons, while others attract world-class runners.  Still others are organized simply for the sport.  Tour companies sponsor international trips organized around marathons.  One 83-year old plans to run in the Boston marathon.
column7: Marathons attract both professional athletes as well as amateur runners.  Some marathons, such as Los Angeles', concentrate on the commercial and moneymaking side of marathons, while other cities such as New York, Boston and San Francisco attract world-class runners.  Still others, such as the Marine Corps marathon which bills itself as the "people's race," are just for the sport.  Tour companies sponsor international trips organized around marathons, offering clients a chance to run in some of the most popular marathons in the world.  Age is no barrier to marathon running.  John Kelley, 83, plans to run in the Boston marathon.
column8: Marathons attract both professional athletes as well as amateur runners.  Some marathons, such as Los Angeles', concentrate on the commercial and moneymaking side of marathons, while other cities such as New York, Boston and San Francisco attract world-class runners.  Prior to the 1992 Olympic trials, topped ranked women marathon runners flocked to San Francisco, one of the only cities in the world suitable for summer running. The 1992 Barcelona Olympic marathon was one of the most grueling ever.  Run in the late afternoon heat and humidity, it featured a course where the last 10 kilometers was mostly uphill.  Other marathons are geared more to amateur runners than professionals. The Marine Corp marathon in Washington D.C offers no prizes and bills itself as the "peoples race". The San Diego marathon in 1990 was won by relative newcomers to long-distance running in what the men's winner described as a "weak field". Tour companies sponsor international trips organized around marathons, offering clients a chance to run in some of the most popular marathons in the world.  Age is no barrier to marathon running.  Eighty-three year-old John Kelley planned to run in his 60th marathon in Boston.  He won the event in 1935 and 1945.
column9: Marathons Popular Worldwide. Thousands Participate. Cities Advertise Attractions. Lure Runners
column10: Nearly all the world's major cities sponsor an annual marathon. They are popular events. Thousands participate over the 26.2 distance. Most marathons offer prize money to winners, but most in the participating throngs run for self-satisfaction. Climactic conditions and a city's beauty and history attract runners.
column11: Marathons are contested over a course that measures 26 miles and 385 yards. They are very popular, and most of the world's major cities organize an annual marathon.. Tour companies even put together "marathon tours" to accommodate runners. Most marathons offer substantial prize money to race winners, but most in the throngs of participants run only for a sense of accomplishment.Each city tailors its marathon to provide the best of its natural beauty and history. London has the largest, and Boston the most storied. San Francisco and San Diego boast of their weather conditions.
column12: The exact distance of a marathon is 26 miles and 385 yards. It is often expressed as 26.2 miles. Marathons are very popular, and major cities of the world organize marathons that draw thousands of participants. London, Berlin, Rome, Paris, Stockholm, Vienna, Budapest, Brussels, Munich, Bangkok and Tel Aviv are some of the cities that organize annual marathons. Tour companies even offer "marathon tours" to distant marathons. Most of the thousands who run do so only for self-satisfaction, but others compete for monetary prizes offered by most marathons. The Marine Corps marathon in Washington, D.C. is one that does not offer prize money.Marathons are usually run in the early morning hours to take advantage of cooler temperatures and cleaner air. The organizers of the 1992 Barcelona Olympics were criticized for contesting the marathon in the late afternoon heat.The London Marathon is the world's largest. The Boston Marathon is the most storied. It goes back almost a century, and in 1992, 83 year-old John Kelley was planning to run in his 60th Boston Marathon. The Los Angeles Marathon is renown as the best-marketed marathon. An Diego and San Francisco pride themselves for providing the most marathon-friendly weather.

column3: Emperor Hirohito left $13.06 million in taxableproperty, a tax office near the Imperial Palace announced Monday.It wa the first time that tax authority have disclosed theamount of an emperor's taxable estate, an official in the KojimachiTax Office said. Until the end of World War II, emperor wereregarded a living gods.Hirohito died of cancer on Jan. 7 at age 87. He wa succeeded byAkihito, his eldest son. Hirohito's wife, Nagako, became empressdowager.Akihito ha paid $2.99 million in inheritance tax on his halfof his father's estate, which he divided evenly with his mother. Theempress dowager, a Hirohito's spouse, wa exempt from payinginheritance tax, Kyodo News Service reported.The Japanese constitution, drafted by US. occupation forcesshortly after the end of World War II in 1945, stipulates theemperor is the symbol of the state and the unity of the people.Hirohito's estate included stock and other personal belongings.Three sacred treasure a mirror, sword and jewel which weretransferred from emperor to emperor, were tax-exempt, a were about3,180 item of art owned by Hirohito that were donated to the state,the tax office official said.Emperor Hirohito ha lost nearly 40 pound in thetwo month since he fell ill and now weighs only 66 pound, a palaceofficial wa quoted a saying Friday.The 87-year-old emperor's condition weakened Friday, but doctorsspeculated that a scab had stopped internal bleeding in his upperintestinal area, said Imperial Household Agency spokesman KenjiMaeda.Hirohito ha suffered repeated bout of bleeding but ha notdischarged blood in nine days.The emperor responds to query from aide but is lesstalkative than before, Maeda told reporter. He added that doctorssometimes have trouble determining whether Hirohito is awake.News report quoted Maeda a saying Hirohito ha shed much of hisnormal 104 pound during his confinement and now weighs about 66pounds.Hirohito had a temperature of 99.1 degree Friday evening, upslightly from the morning. His normal temperature is about 95.9degrees.Doctors have said he suffers from jaundice and anemia. Maeda saidthe emperor's heart and kidney were functioning normally.Since Sept. 19, when he wa confined to intensive care aftervomiting blood, Hirohito ha received 42 pint of blood intransfusions.Palace official have not given detail on Hirohito's illness,and they would not comment on Japanese news report that the emperorhas pancreatic cancerUS. prosecutor pressured Japan's wartime primeminister, Gen. Hideki Tojo, into changing testimony at his trial toavoid incriminating Emperor Hirohito in war crime, a televisiondocumentary claims.The British Broadcasting Corp. documentary, detail of which werereleased Wednesday by it maker Edward Behr, said the U.S.prosecutors worked with the emperor's aide to find a way to avoidputting Hirohito on trial.The documentary challenge Hirohito's image a a peaceful manforced to go along with his generals' plan and alleges among otherthings that he:Must have known about the massacre of at least 20,000 Chinese atNanking in 1937 because he received regular detailed report fromthe China front.Knew more than a month in advance of Japanese plan to attackthe US. navy at Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941.The BBC will show Hirohito Behind the Myth on Jan. 24.Behr is a Paris-based journalist. His biography of China's lastmonarch wa used for the award-winning film The Last Emperor.It ha been reported previously that American prosecutor wantedto keep Hirohito out of the war crime trial and asked Tojo tosuggest the emperor had consented reluctantly to the war on theadvice of the High CommandGen. Douglas MacArthur, commander of the US. force occupyingJapan, wrote in his book Reminiscences that he fended offpressure from Britain and the Soviet Union to indict Hirohito,arguing that would touch off a guerrilla war.Behr told The Associated Press in a telephone interview Wednesdaythat the documentary will be shown in the United States by PBS onMarch 13.The BBC ha also sold it to Australia, Austria, Canada, HongKong, Israel, Korea, the Netherlands, Norway, Spain and Sweden.Hirohito died Saturday at the age of 87.The documentary say the decision not to prosecute Hirohito camefrom President Harry S. Truman and that Tojo's evidence wa alteredso the emperor would not be incriminated.To the rest of the world, he wa known a EmperorHirohito, but in Japan his given name wa seldom used. In Japanesehe wa simply called Tenno Heika, meaning His Majesty The Emperor.The foreign habit of using his name rankled some Japanese, whofound it impolite, and unnecessary since to them there is only oneemperor. Some Japanese complained that after his death it evenbecame inaccurate to call him Hirohito because he ha been given theposthumous name Showa.In Japanese history, he will be recorded a Emperor Showa, thename he chose for his reign soon after he became emperor in 1926. Itmeans Enlightened Peace, and ha been succeeded by Heisei, orAchieving Peace, the name the government chose for the reign ofHirohito's son Akihito a few hour after the emperor died Jan. 7.But for the convenience of the rest of the world, which is not soable to keep track of the person behind the changed name, evenofficial agency have used the name Hirohito in English-languagepublications.The obituary issued in English by the Foreign Press Center, whichis supported by the Foreign Ministry, wa headed His late MajestyThe Emperor Hirohito.English-language newspaper published in Japan quickly beganusing the name Showa for Hirohito after his death, but it did notbecome truly official until Jan. 31, when Emperor Akihito conducteda ceremony in which Showa became the late emperor's posthumous name.A stone tablet placed in his tomb is engraved only with theposthumous name and the date of his death and burial.The custom of renaming emperor after the completion of theirreigns began after the death in 1912 of Emperor Meiji, Hirohito'sgrandfather.In Japan, year are numbered according to the emperor's tenure onthe throne. Thus 1926 became Showa 1 a Crown Prince Hirohitoascended to the throne on Dec. 25 when his father, Emperor Taisho,died. The year 1927 wa Showa 2, and 1989 wa Showa 64 untilHirohito's death on Jan. 7. Now this year is Heisei 1.The Japanese custom of changing imperial name is not uniqueamong world royalty, where an individual may have a variety of namesand title in a royal career. In Britain, Prince Andrew became theDuke of York upon his marriage in 1986.Emperor Hirohito's blood pressure and pulse droppedsharply Thursday, but the vital sign later returned to normal asthe ailing monarch's internal bleeding continued.Hirohito, 87, discharged more blood and wa given emergencytransfusions, but wa resting peacefully by nightfall, an imperialpalace spokesman said.Hirohito's blood pressure fell from 132 over 60 in the afternoonto 112 over 50 by evening, and his pulse from 104 per minute in themorning to 84 in the evening, said Kenji Maeda, chief of theImperial Household Agency's General Affairs Division.The emperor's blood pressure ha returned to what is normalfor him, and the head court physician say he is not worried,Maeda said.One of Hirohito's daughter, Atsuko Ikeda, said Wednesday theemperor had coughed severely during her visit to him and had hardlyresponded to her.On Thursday morning, Hirohito's two son, Crown Prince Akihitoand Prince Hitachi, visited him, and he wa fully conscious andalert, a senior palace source said.The monarch ha been bedridden for a month with an intestinalhemorrhage.There wa renewed bleeding Thursday and the pace of thedischarges wa quickening, Maeda said.Hirohito ha received nearly 22{ pint of blood since hisillness worsened Sept. 19, and the transfusion had put a strain onHirohito's heart and kidney, Maeda said without elaborating.The only solid food Hirohito ha eaten since falling ill are afew spoonful of porridge. Otherwise he is being fed intravenously,which give him 600-700 calorie a day, said the senior palaceofficial, who refused to be identified.Before his illness, Hirohito wa taking about 1,300 caloriesdaily, the official said.The emperor complains of fatigue but doe not appear to be inpain, he said.Crown Princess Michiko, Hirohito's daughter-in-law, scaled downcelebrations for her 54th birthday Thursday, canceling atraditional birthday news conference, another palace official said.She planned a quiet gathering with member of the imperial family,the official said.World leader sent Japan message of condolence and somedeclared state of mourning after Emperor Hirohito's death Saturday,but painful memory of World War II still generated criticism ofthe Japanese monarch.President Reagan said Hirohito's 62-year reign spanned one ofthe most tumultuous, and yet at the same time constructive era inthe history of mankind.It wa also an era of unprecedented reconciliation. His Majestyplayed a truly heroic role in bringing hostility between our twopeoples to an end, Reagan said, referring to Hirohito's decisionto end World War II.President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union sent hissincere condolence and profound sympathy to the Japanesepeople.His two-sentence telegram made no mention of wartime hostilitieswith what still is known officially a militarist Japan. TheKremlin currently is striving for better tie and increased tradewith Japan.India declared a three-day national state of mourning in honor ofHirohito and Norway's King Olav V announced a three-week courtmourning. President Francois Mitterrand of France opened aninternational conference on chemical weapon with a minute ofsilence.But some reaction to Hirohito's death wa cool in South Korea,which endured year of harsh colonial rule by Japan.While President Roh Tae-woo of South Korea sent his condolences,a government party statement added, We reserve further comment,considering the unhappy past and the current Korea-Japanrelationship.China extended condolence and Taiwan said it will send adelegation to the funeral.But Taiwan's daily United Evening News said:It wa an irony that while Hirohito apologized to the UnitedStates and Europe for the war, he did not direct a single word toChina to show his sorrow.Most historian believe Hirohito wa a powerless figurehead buthad approved order that led to the attack on Pearl Harbor and putmost of East Asia under an often brutal Japanese rule. Hirohitocalled on his nation to surrender in 1945.The emperor's death drew mixed reaction in the Netherlands, whichlost more than 20,000 people under Japan's wartime occupation of theformer Dutch East Indies.The government said it sent it sympathy for the loss that hasbefallen the Japanese people, without mentioning the name ofHirohito, branded a war criminal by survivor of the wartimeoccupation of the colony that became Indonesia in 1949.To many war victim, only now ha World War II finally come toan end, said Gen. Ruud Boekholt, chairman of the August 15Commemoration Foundation, a group representing 127,000 Dutchcitizens who underwent Japanese internment.Daily, they still feel the pain of the wartime suffering thatwas inflicted on them in the name of Emperor Hirohito, Boekholttold The Associated Press.But Indonesian President Suharto cabled his condolence to CrownPrince Akihito, Hirohito's eldest son who immediately ascended theChrysanthemum Throne, and said he will personally pay the lasthomage to Hirohito, presidential spokesman Moerdiono said.Pope John Paul II expressed his condolence and sent telegram toHirohito's family, Vatican radio reported.Queen Elizabeth II said she wa saddened and Prime MinisterMargaret Thatcher said she share the Japanese people's sorrow. Butopposition lawmaker said Britain should boycott his funeral.No one should go to that funeral from this country, said RonBrown, a lawmaker of the opposition Labor Party, who denouncedHirohito a a war criminal of the worst kind.It would be a grave insult to the many men and woman ...imprisoned in slave camp, he said. Many of them died, but thosewho survived still suffer today.King Juan Carlos of Spain, King Faisal of Saudi Arabia and otherPersian Gulf monarch, King Birendra of Nepal and Sultan MahmoodIskandar of Malaysia also sent condolence to Akihito.Brazil called Hirohito a superior symbol of the Japanesenation, it culture and it anxiety in a period of drastictransformations in the world and his country and in a time of gravenew challenge in the world.World leader from President Reagan to Malaysia's king mournedtoday's death of Emperor Hirohito, who surrendered a broken nationto the Allies in World War II but presided over it rise to economicpre-eminence.Reaction to Hirohito's death at age 87, however, wa decidedlycool in several Asian country, including South Korea, whichendured year of harsh colonial rule by Japan.While South Korea President Roh Tae-Woo sent his condolence, agovernment party statement added, We reserve further comment,considering the unhappy past and the current Korea-Japanrelationship.The main opposition party led by Kim Dae-jung said, We havecomplex feeling at the death of Hirohito in view of Japan's 20-yearrule over Korea during his reign.A leading newspaper in Seoul, The Joong-Ang Daily News, wrotethat Hirohito's death reminds all the Korean people of a disgracedperiod and . humiliation. . Hirohito is the symbolic figure whomust assume most and final responsibility for (Japan's) preposterouscrimes to the Korean people.Korea wa divided into the communist north and the capitalistsouth in 1945, when US. and Soviet troop ended Japan's rule thatbegan in 1910 with Japan's forced annexation of the peninsula.There wa no official comment from the nationalist Chinesegovernment because of the lack of diplomatic relation betweenTaiwan and Japan, but the mass circulation Chinese daily UnitedEvening News said:Asian people who suffered from the slavery and invasion ofJapan's militarist during World War II may bury their animositywith Hirohito's death. . Chinese suffered the most from theJapanese invasion.It wa an irony that while Hirohito apologized to the UnitedStates and Europe for the war, he did not direct a single word toChina to show his sorrow.Now, Hirohito ha died. We may not want tocollect the reparation, but we shall never forget the painfulhistoric lessions.In the United States, President Reagan said in a statement, HisMajesty's 62-year reign spanned one of the most tumultuous, and yetat the same time constructive era in the history of mankind anage of unprecedented economic collapse, a most vicious war,astonishing scientific acheivement, and dramatic political andsocial change throughout the world.It wa also an era of unprecedented reconciliation. His Majestyplayed a truly heroic role in bringing hostility between our twopeoples to an end, Reagan said, referring to Hirohito's decisionto end World War II.In New Zealand, Prime Minister David Lange said Hirohito's deathmarks the end of an era.During his reign he saw the transition from the most turbulentperiod in Japan's modern history to the stability and prosperity oftoday, Lange said.President Corazon Aquino of the Philippines sent condolence tothe imperial family and her foreign secretary, Raul Manglapus, aJapanese prisoner of war during World War II, praised Hirohito asa stabilizing factor in the creation of a democratic Japan.He provided a figurehead that kept the Japanese people firmlycommitted to peaceful mean of achieving their national goals,Manglapus said.Condolences also came from King Sultan Mahmood Iskandar ofMalaysia to Hirohito's oldest son, Crown Prince Akihito, whoimmediately ascended the Chrysanthemum Throne.Prime Minister Bob Hawke of Australia paid his respect in amessage to Japanese Prime Minister Noburu Takeshita: Throughouthis long life, the emperor wa held in the highest esteem by hispeople. Now, a Japan enters a period of mourning and prepares for anew age, our thought are with you.But Bruce Ruxton, an official of the Returned Services League,which representing almost 300,000 Australian war veteran, saidthere would not be too many tear shed around the world. Hedescribed Hirohito, whose role in the war ha been debated, a oneof the worst war criminals.Marine biologist paid homage to another facet of the monarch'slife his 12 book published on hydrozoa, or sea animal. RobertHessler of the Scripps Institution of Oceanography in La JollaCalif., said Hirohito preferred the quiet study to his destined roleas leader.The poor man didn't really get to do what he wanted to do. Hehad to be emperor first, then second a scientist and normal humanbeing, Hessler said.TOKYO (AP Emperor Hirohito will be remembered for oneoverwhelming decision during his 62-year reign: Japan must bow todefeat for the first time in it history and end the Pacificconflict in World War II.Shortly after that decision, and for most of his reign, Hirohitobecame a figurehead, isolated from his subject by tradition andsteeped in his great love, the study of marine biology. He wa thelast survivor among the national leader of the World War II era.But in his first 20 year, the Son of Heaven wa worshiped asa divinity descended from the Sun Goddess Amaterasu.The solitude of animal and plant life under the sea which sointrigued Hirohito wa in keeping with the character of the man whobecame the 124th occupant of the Chrysanthemum Throne at the age of25 on Christmas Day 1926, designating his reign Showa enlightened peace.The emperor wa generally portrayed a having played nosignificant role in planning or carrying out Japan's militaryadventures in the 1930s and 1940s. But it wa his first effectivedecision a emperor, and his most courageous, that ended the Pacificconflict.On Aug. 10, 1945, four day after history's first atomic bombdevastated Hiroshima and one day after a US. bomber dropped thesecond atomic bomb on Nagasaki, the general and admiral ofImperial Japan's wartime government argued for hour in thesweltering bombproof shelter beneath the Tokyo palace.Should Japan agree to the Allies' surrender demand, or fight onuntil annihilation?Speaking in what some of those present described a a slow andobviously nervous monotone, Hirohito, the spiritual and titularleader, offered his opinion for the first time. He spoke of hissorrow over the soldier and sailor killed in the long war, and offamilies who lost everything in air raids.I cannot bear to see my innocent people suffer any longer, hesaid. Ending the war is the only way to restore world peace and torelieve the nation from the terrible distress with which it isburdened.Then, evoking a memory of his grandfather, the Emperor Meiji,whose reign (1867-1912) saw the end of 250 year of feudal Japaneseisolation from the outside world, Hirohito told the officers:The time ha come when we must bear the unbearable.In the day that followed, Hirohito continued his break withtradition. In a national radio broadcast Aug. 15 the first timeordinary Japanese ever actually heard his voice he personallyannounced the decision to surrender.He told the ravaged nation that the war situation ha developednot necessarily to our advantage.Three week later, Hirohito donned a silk cutaway coat, stripedtrousers and a top hat to meet the Allied commander, Gen. Douglas A.MacArthur, at the US. Embassy in Tokyo. It wa the first timeHirohito had ever gone to see anyone, and the first of several callson the general who had led the Pacific war against Japan and becameits postwar governor.On New Year's Day 1946, at MacArthur's insistence, the emperorpublicly renounced his divinity. It wa a choice that enabledHirohito to remain a the symbolic head of his nation and assuredthat he would not face charge a a war criminal, a some abroad haddemanded.It also wa an act that seemed to relieve no one a much a thisgentle, shy and retiring man who never seemed very comfortable a aliving god.The emperor's status in the eye of many Japanese changed to thatof a kind uncle.He became a widely respected authority on marine biology. Hepossessed rare collection of marine life, discovered severalspecies himself and wrote or co-authored at least 12 book onhydrozoa, or sea animal, his specialty.In recent year, his life had become the subject of a popularcomic book series.Still, Hirohito and the imperial system remained important toJapan.A nationwide survey by the daily newspaper Mainichi Shimbun inMarch 1987 indicated more than 80 percent of 2,184 people polledsupported the imperial system, while only 11 percent said it shouldbe abolished. Five percent said the emperor should have more power.From 1946 to 1954, Hirohito toured Japan to encourage the peopleto rebuild.The Imperial Household Agency, which ran his affair, saidHirohito considered the postwar period one of the most fulfillingtimes of his life, in which the nation made a phenomenal recoveryfrom a war that cost 3.1 million Japanese lives.Despite the humanization of the Imperial family, Hirohitoremained under strict control of the Imperial Household Agency.Protocol wa maintained at nearly all time and he wa prohibitedfrom speaking on any controversial subject.Hirohito wa born on April 29, 1901. In accordance with age-oldimperial custom, he wa taken from his parent a an infant to bereared in isolation by household functionary and trained for onerole, that of emperor.His education came a Japan surged into the modern world. Thefeudal samurai ethic wa still strong; when his grandfather died,Gen. Maresuke Nogi, the mentor for the 11-year-old prince, calmlycommitted ritual suicide to follow the emperor, his master, to thegrave.Hirohito studied government and law with private tutor. When hewas 20, his father, Emperor Taisho, sent him abroad the first timeany member of the immediate imperial family wa allowed outsideJapan.Hirohito visited England, Scotland, France, Belgium, theNetherlands and Italy, receiving various decoration. He wa alsoreceived by Pope Benedict XV.The young man handled money for the first time, paying his ownfare on the Paris subway. He developed a passion for bacon and eggsand it became a lifelong breakfast habit. A palace chamberlain saidin a 1980 interview that Hirohito shunned Japanese food unless itis forced on him by an unwitting host.Hirohito also acquired a preference for Western clothes. He wasnever seen in public wearing traditional Japanese garb, and a palaceofficial confided that the Emperor of Japan did not even own akimono.Hirohito became prince regent on Nov. 25, 1921, after his fatherbecame a mental and physical invalid, became emperor five yearslater and wa formally enthroned in 1928.
column5: Asians Cool to Hirohito's Death; U.S. Possibly Helped Emperor Avoid Trial
column6: Japan's Emperor Hirohito, renamed Showa after his Jan. 7 death, reigned for 62 years. He will be remembered for surrendering in WW II. Though mourned by many, Asians often viewed him as a symbol of Japanese aggression. A BBC documentary claims Truman helped Hirohito avoid a war crimes trial.
column7: Japan's Emperor Hirohito, posthumously named Showa, left a $13 milliontaxable estate.  He died of cancer on Jan. 7.Hirohito is remembered for surrendering in WW II. Though many worldleaders mourned his passing, South Korea and others viewed him as asymbol of Japanese crimes against Asian people.Generally portrayed as a peaceful man, a January BBC documentaryclaims that Truman decided not to prosecute Hirohito for war crimes,and that Japan's wartime prime minister was pressured into changinghis testimony to avoid incriminating the emperor.  An LA newspaperpublished a letter to the editor after Hirohito's death alsoquestioning his innocence.
column8: Emperor Hirohito, who died on January 7 of cancer after several months of internal bleeding, left a taxable estate of approximately $13 million. Posthumously named Showa, or Enlightened Peace, the name of his reign, Hirohito will be remembered for his most courageous decision in his 62-year reign: Japan must surrender and end the Pacific conflict in WW II.Though many world leaders mourned his death, painful WW II memories sparked criticism of the monarch. South Korea sent condolences, but a government party statement added, "We reserve further comment, considering the unhappy past." A Taiwanese newspaper noted that "while Hirohito apologized to the United States and Europe...", he did not direct a single word to China..." Generally portrayed as having had no significant role in the war, a BBC documentary by Edward Behr challenged this view, alleging that Hirohito had advance knowledge of the Pearl Harbor attack. The show also claims that President Truman decided not to prosecute Hirohito for war crimes, and Japan's wartime prime minister, Gen.Tojo, was pressured into changing his testimony to avoid incriminating the emperor. A letter to the editor of an LA newspaper after Hirohito's death also expressed doubt that he was blameless.
column9: Emperor Hirohito, controversial World War II  leader of Japan dies.
column10: Emperor Hirohito of Japan died in 1989 at the age of 87 after a long illness.  He was emperor During World War II and while some regard him as a powerless figurehead, others believe he was complicit in Japan's war crimes.  He is succeeded by his son Akihito.
column11: Emperor Hirohito of Japan died in 1989 at the age of 87.  He ascended the throne in 1926 and presided over one of Japan's most tumultuous eras.  The last of the World War II generation of leaders, Hirohito was a controversial figure, even in death.  While western leaders generally, Asian leaders whose countries suffered under the Japanese military in World War II were cool.  While some historians regard him as a powerless figurehead, others believe that he was complicit in Japanese war crimes.  Hirohito died of cancer after a long illness and is succeeded by his son Akihito.
column12: Emperor Hirohito of Japan died in 1989 at the age of 87.  He ascended to the throne in 1926 and presided over one of Japan's most tumultuous eras.  The last of the World War II generation of leaders, Hirohito was a controversial figure, even in death.  While many western leaders praised him, many Asian leaders, whose countries suffered under the Japanese military during World War II were cool.  While most historians believe that Hirohito was a powerless figurehead, others believe that he had to have known of the massacre of thousands of Chinese in Nanking and of the plan to bomb Pearl Harbor.  Some believe that the U.S. covered up his complicity in war crimes after the war to avoid unrest in Japan.  After the U.S. dropped the atomic bomb on Japan, Hirohito announced Japan's surrender in a radio address to his nation.  After the war, Hirohito was just a symbol but the imperial system has remained important to the Japanese people.  Hirohito had traveled in Europe and had a preference for Western food and clothes.  With few real responsibilities, he spent much time in the study of marine biology.  He died of cancer after a long illness and  is succeeded by his son Akihito.

column3: The Summer Olympics will be rememberedfor moment of glory like that enjoyed by US. diver Greg Louganisand the startling moment of disgrace when the gold wa strippedfrom Canadian sprinter Ben Johnson.The Soviet Union won the first U.S.-Soviet Olympic medal contestsince 1976, getting 55 gold medal to 37 for East Germany and 36for the United States. Host South Korea rose to fourth in the worldwith 12 golds.The fear of terrorism and massive civil unrest promptedextraordinary security, but neither bogey materialized a nearly10,000 athlete from 160 country tested their mettle in 16 daysof competition ended Sunday.As always, there were shining moment of glory, from an openingceremony with exotic dancer and parachutist to a closing withhugs and tear, firework and dance, and the mascot of Seoul andBarcelona, the site of the 1992 Games, floating together into thestarry night.Louganis claimed his second pair of gold medal after hittinghis head on a springboard. He said he talked with his coach aboutquitting the Olympics after hitting the board and opening a cutthat needed five stitch to close.We walked and discussed all the thing we had gone through toget there, he said. I decided to stay in, and I'm glad I did.Louganis said Sunday he is retiring from diving to begin anacting career.What had been the highest moment of the Games Ben Johnsonrocketing to victory over US. great Carl Lewis in a 100-meter dashworld record led to the deepest pain when the Canadian wa caughtcheating with muscle-building anabolic steroids.Twenty year from now, when most of the record set in Seoul arebroken, the impact of Johnson's disgrace will still be felt ifathletes and trainer heed the event here and end doping.There have been high point and some low point, and the mostimportant low point wa Ben Johnson, Juan Antonio Samaranch,president of the International Olympic Committee, said today.That wa indeed a blow.But catching Johnson and expelling him and nine other athleteswith positive drug test wa an indication that we have won thebattle against doping, Samaranch said.Sports official from the United States and the Soviet Union onSunday announced Sunday they would join force to work towards theelimination of drug from sport.A statement issued by the US. and Soviet Olympic committeessaid the group would investigate using the exchange of testingteams, lab result and technical data; education programs; anduniform penalties.For the United States, a serious problem at the Seoul Games wasa rising tide of anti-American sentiment.It wa exacerbated by NBC's coverage, which the Koreans saw asanti-Korean and insensitive to local culture; the arrest of severalAmerican athletes; and the perceived rudeness of the US. team atthe opening ceremony.The Soviets, meanwhile, cultivated friendship by bringing in theBolshoi Ballet, the Moscow Philharmonic, film, a photo exhibit andcopies of the Communist Party newspaper Pravda.The announcement of an unprecedented sport exchange programbetween South Korea and the Soviet Union and the arrival of thefirst Soviet diplomat since World War II also warmed relations.Soviet athlete, a they did in Calgary, Canada, during theWinter Games, made a special effort to meet with local people.American athlete tended to isolate themselves.All those difference became apparent at the sporting events,where Koreans often cheered louder for the Soviets or East Germansthan they did for Americans, despite a close 40-year relationshipwith the United States.Still, there were Louganis and other Americans to unabashedlycheer for like sister-in-law Florence Griffith Joyner and JackieJoyner-Kersee, who led an assault on the track and field recordbooks, and Louganis.Griffith Joyner won gold in the 100, the 200 and the 400-meterrelay, and silver in the 1,600-meter relay. She set a world recordin the 200 and an Olympic record in the 100. Joyner-Kersee won twogolds, taking the heptathlon with a world record 7,291 point andthe long jump with an Olympic mark of 24 foot, 3{ inches.The 1988 Summer Olympics, kept free ofterrorism but tainted by drug scandal, closed Sunday with thepealing of a medieval bell to symbolize the sorrow of parting. TheUnited States finished third in medals.The 1000-year-old, 72-ton Emille Bell, which according toKorean legend ha the saddest tone of any in the world, tolledfarewell to the more than 9,000 athlete from 160 nation whoparticipated in the 24th Olympiad.The 16-day event, conducted under extraordinary security,wrapped up with the Soviet Union winning the lion's share of the237 medal events.The Soviets took home 132 medal, including 55 gold, the mostever in a Summer Olympics without a major-power boycott. EastGermany had 102 medal and 37 gold, and the United States 94 medalsand 36 gold.Many felt that the United States wa robbed of a second-placetie for gold when judge awarded a bout to a South Korean boxerover American Roy Jones in the 156-pound event on the final day ofcompetition.Because of boycott in 1980 and 1984, the Games were the firstmeeting between the Soviet Union and the United States since 1976in Montreal, and matchup between the two nation provided some ofthe Games' highlights.The US. men's volleyball team beat the Soviets to defend its1984 Olympic championship, providing consolation for America'supset in the men's basketball quarterfinal. America also defeatedthe Soviets in women's basketball and men's water polo.At least 1 billion people watched the Olympics via a 115-nation,worldwide TV hookup. The Seoul Games had the greatest number ofathletes (9633), the most country, the most gold medal and themost venue (34).Communist North Korea, which demanded a role in the Games,boycotted them, but the only sport power to follow suit wa Cuba.Among the highlights:Greg Louganis won the Olympic Spirit Award a top Americanathlete Sunday for winning gold medal in platform and 3-meterspringboard diving. He accomplished the same feat in 1980 andbecame the first man to sweep the event twice.The 28-year-old Louganis, who hit his head on the board in thepreliminaries and received five stitch, announced his retirementfrom diving and said he wanted to pursue acting.Sisters-in-law Florence Griffith Joyner and JackieJoyner-Kersee led an American assault on the record book in trackand field.Griffith Joyner won gold in the 100, the 200 and the 400-meterrelay, and silver in the 1,600-meter relay. She set a world recordin the 200 and an Olympic record in the 100. Joyner-Kersee won twogolds, taking the heptathlon with a world record 7,291 point andthe long jump with an Olympic mark of 24 foot, 3{ inches.Kristin Otto of East Germany won six gold in swimming.American swimmer Matt Biondi won seven medal, five gold, whileJanet Evans earned three gold in the pool for the United States.Daniela Silivas of Romania dominated women's gymnastics,winning three gold, two silver and a bronze.West German Steffi Graf completed tennis's first Golden Slam,winning the gold medal a well a all four Grand Slam tournament Wimbledon and the U.S., French and Australian Opens in a calendaryear.There were low moment a well.Canadian sprinter Ben Johnson, the most prominent of 10 athleteswho tested positive for drug, wa stripped of his gold medal inthe 100 meter and title of world's fastest man, and flew home indisgrace, his career in jeopardy. He wa accused of usingmuscle-building steroids.Four other medal two Bulgarian weightlifting gold, aHungarian weightlifing silver and a British judo bronze also werestripped for drug, and five non-medalists tested positive forsubstances ranging from caffeine to diuretics.Early in the Games, five people connected to the Korean boxingteam were suspended for attacking a New Zealand referee after aKorean lost a decision to a Bulgarian. Another Korean boxer stageda 67-minute sit-in in the ring to protest his loss. AnthonyHembrick, a US. boxer expected to win a gold, never got to fight;his coach misread the schedule and he missed the bus to the arena.Two gold medal-winning US. swimmer were arrested for carryinga stone lion's head out of a hotel bar, but charge were dropped.American runner Johnny Gray kicked a taxicab in an argument withits driver. He wa arrested and released.Security measure against the possibility of terrorism wereextraordinary, including metal detector, numerous checkpoint andID card, but except for scattered protest by student radicals,the Games proceeded without incident.At the closing ceremony, before the great torch wasextinguished, Korea passed the Olympic flag to representative fromBarcelona, site of the 1992 Games.Time ran out for the US. athlete whenthe Winter Olympics ended Sunday, with a team headed by BrentRushlaw a tick away from a US. bobsled medal and Dutch speedskater Yvonne van Gennip a triple gold medalist with time to spare.The best America could do wa six medal, it worst Winter Gamesshowing in 52 year. Two of the six were gold medal, won by BrianBoitano in figure skating and Bonnie Blair in speed skating. Blairalso won a bronze in speed skating, making her America's onlydouble winner.The Olympics wrapped up Sunday evening with a rousing closingceremony before 60,000 people in McMahon Stadium. The 250 figureskaters who performed included past and present medal winner aswell a young skater from Albertville, France, site of the 1992Winter Games, and Seoul, South Korea, site of this year's summerGames.Athletes marched in carrying miniature Olympic torch, andbanners reading Until We Meet Again in eight language weredraped along the top of the stands.Earlier Sunday, Rushlaw and his three team member missedwinning the first US. bobsled medal in 32 year when they wasbeaten by .02 second for the bronze.Van Gennip took more than six second off her own world recordin the 5,000 meter to win her third gold medal. American MaryDocter wa 22.87 second behind. East Germans finished 2-3 in therace.Finland won the hockey silver medal, handing the Soviets theirfirst loss of the Games, 2-1. The Soviets clinched the gold medalFriday night, and America finished seventh for the second straighttime.In 1936, America won just four medal, but only 51 wereavailable then. This time, 138 medal were handed out.The Soviets finished first in both number of gold medal, with11, and total medal, with 29, a record for the Winter Olympics.East Germany's athlete won nine gold, 25 overall; whileSwitzerland's team came in third in both gold medal, five, andoverall medal, 15.Four other team also bested the United States in term ofoverall medals: Austria, West Germany, Finland and the Netherlands.The late Jesse Owens, whose performance at the1936 Olympics put the lie to Hitler's boast of racial superiority,picked up a fifth gold medal Wednesday for humanitariancontributions in the race of life.President Bush presented the Congressional Gold Medal to hiswidow, Ruth Owens, in a ceremony at the White House also attendedby three daughter and teammate of the track legend.This Saturday mark the 10th anniversary of Owens' death at age66.The president later hailed Owens's multiple gold medal in theBerlin game a victory for humanity in prepared remark to abanquet sponsored by the US. Olympic Committee.The Olympics, like democracy, are a kind of dialogue a waythat nation can converse in the language of friendly competition,not deadly conflict, Bush said.Bush called Owens, who wa black, an Olympic hero and anAmerican hero every day of his life . born with the gift ofburning speed.He wa always the fastest, said Bush, recalling theafternoon in May 1935 when the Ohio State runner broke three worldrecords and tied a fourth in the space of 45 minutes.Talk about a guy in a hurry, Bush laughed. He wa theepitome of that.At the 1936 Olympic Games in Berlin, Owens captured four goldmedals in the broad jump, 100-meter dash, 200-meter dash and400-meter relay.The Berlin Games were to be the showcase of Hitler's theorieson the superiority of the master race until this 23-year-old kidshowed up, Bush said. It wa an unrivaled athletic triumph. Butmore than that, it really wa a triumph for all humanity.Bush, borrowing a phrase from Ruth Owens, said it wa not thoseathletic feat but his humanitarian contribution in the race oflife that earned Owens the Congressional Gold Medal.Owens devoted himself to working with youth and serving a aspecial ambassador for sport, said Bush. He said the athlete'slegacy life on through the Jesse Owens Games, a playgroundOlympics; the Jesse Owens International Trophy for amateur athletesand the Jesse Owens Foundation, which award scholarship to needyyouth.Despite the many honor, his greatest satisfaction came fromhis work with youth, said Mrs. Owens, 74.Attending the ceremony along with Owens' family were formerOlympians Mal Whitfield, Harrison Dillard and Herb Douglass; formerteammates John Chavers, Samuel Devine and Chester Thomas, and twoOhio Democrats, Sen. Howard Metzenbaum and Rep. Louis Stokes, whospearheaded the drive to strike the medal.The silver-haired Mrs. Owens, standing outside the White Houseafterwards, called the event absolutely beautiful. She added:I'm sure with the sun shining straight down, Jesse's watching us,too.The 1984 Summer Olympic Games weren't even over when advertiser began clamoring for pixie gymnast Mary Lou Retton. She went on to grin relentlessly through some $5 million worth of commercial endorsement -- surely an Olympic record in itself. But when the 1988 Summer Games ended Sunday night, so, too, did the chance for American athlete to follow in her footstep. Ad agency executive, who spend every fourth year glued to their TV set, hoping to pick out the next star to hawk their clients' product, say that this Olympiad wa a dud. "I suspect this will go down a the dullest in the history of the Olympics," say Jerry Della Femina, chairman of ad agency Della Femina McNamee WCRS. "This is the first Olympics without passion, and without passion you don't have testimonial. Without hero, you don't have anyone that anyone want to emulate." On the surface, the Games seemed to offer all the drama that usually make for lucrative endorsement contract. Who could forget diver Greg Louganis smacking his head on the springboard, then coming back to win two gold medal? Or flamboyant Florence Griffith Joyner, her two-inch fingernail raking the air a she won the 100-meter sprint? But even these two, along with Jackie Joyner-Kersee, who won the women's heptathalon and the long jump, may find it more difficult than in previous year to turn gold medal into gold in the bank. The fact is, say many marketer, Olympic gold ha lost much of it commercial luster. "I don't think it's big money like it used to be," say Michael Goldberg of National Media Group Inc., the New York sports-marketing firm that represents Ms. Retton. "It used to be kind of a knee-jerk reaction to do an ad campaign around an Olympic athlete. It just doesn't happen anymore." Certainly, this year's winning Olympians will have no trouble securing contract from specialized sports-equipment outfitter and speaking invitation from obscure trade group. But the major, high-paying endorsement -- such a those with soft-drink company and fast-food outlet -- just don't seem to be surfacing, at least not yet. Earlier this year, sport marketer estimated that a gold medal won during the Summer Games could earn a personable athlete more than $1 million in endorsement. Now, marketer say, these medalist will be lucky to pull in $100,000 to $500,000 a year. Advertisers can reel off a litany of reason why these Olympics aren't igniting much spark. For one thing, they suffer by comparison with the 1984 Summer Games, so exciting because they were held in Los Angeles and because, in the absence of boycotting Soviet-bloc country, the Americans won 83 gold medal. The 1988 Games, by contrast, were broadcast from halfway around the world, and the Soviets trounced the Americans, 55 gold medal to 36. What's more, marketer say, this year's drug scandal cast a pall over the Games, especially the incident involving Canadian sprinter Ben Johnson, who lost his gold medal after testing positive for steroid. NBC's TV coverage also get it share of the blame. Marketers say it wa so bland and skipped so frequently from one event to another that there wa little chance for excitement to build. The constant commercial interruption, which led to rating that were much lower than expected, didn't help, either. During most of the past Games, "there wa enough continuous TV coverage so that, much like a soap opera, it wa possible to get involved in the life and in the competition," say Leigh Steinberg, attorney for ice-skater Brian Boitano, a gold medalist at the 1988 Winter Games. But not this summer, he say. Recent change in Olympic rule, meanwhile, have led to a glut of Olympians in search of endorsement deal. Before the 1984 Games, most Olympic athlete weren't allowed to make commercial unless they gave up their amateur status. Now, they can appear in a many ad a they want, but the income must go into a trust fund for training expense. "Every year, more and more Olympic people are out there wanting to do commercial -- basically, everybody is available," say Daisy Sinclair, a vice president with ad agency Ogilvy Group Inc. As a result, while once an "aura" surrounded an Olympian, now "the bloom is off." Companies also are becoming more sophisticated in their approach to celebrity endorsement. Increasingly cost conscious, they will no longer hook up with an Olympian just because the company president like the athlete's sport. And after year of paying big buck to Olympic star only to see them fade into obscurity, company have finally gotten the hint that Olympian fame is of the most fleeting variety. "If you think your phone will ring off the hook if (you win) a gold medal, it isn't going to happen anymore," say Stephen Disson, senior vice president of marketing for ProServ Inc., a Washington sports-marketing firm. Companies now know that "six month from now there will be other hero from other sporting events" for them to consider. Ad agency BBDO Worldwide's attitude toward the Olympics is becoming typical. It us sport star in it commercial for Pepsi Light and Oppenheimer Mutual Funds but ha no plan to call on any of 1988's Olympians. "I prefer to use athlete who are in the public eye on a regular basis, like football and basketball players," say Charles Miesmer, the agency's executive creative director. "People like Michael Jordan have 10-plus year in their sport career, all in a row, so I don't have to worry about the public saying, 'Carl who?'" And don't look for any of 1988's winner to start showing up on Wheaties box, either. General Mills Inc., which ha featured Ms. Retton and decathalon gold-medalist Bruce Jenner on it Wheaties box in the past, say it look for three quality in an endorser: career achievement, popular appeal and off-the-field accomplishment. A spokeswoman say that none of this year's crop meet all three criterion. So far, Ms. Joyner-Kersee ha had the most visible endorsement. Even before the Olympics began, she had made commercial for Primatene mist and 7-Up. And, according to her agent, Pearl Hodge of World Class Management, she is now "in the process" of signing with McDonald's Corp., to work on behalf of it effort to aid underprivileged child. Ms. Joyner-Kersee's sister-in-law, Ms. Griffith Joyner, may soon take the endorsement lead. Advertisers say with her good look and fashion flare, she is attracting more interest than any of the other medal winner. (The sprinter's manager couldn't be reached for comment.) Another Olympian with endorsement potential is swimmer Matt Biondi, who won five gold medal. Mr. Biondi ha already signed a swim-wear contract with Arena USA Inc., and Parkes Brittain, his agent at Advantage International Inc., say his client "will definitely be in a high-income ring, the highest you can name." Then there is Mr. Louganis. Since winning two gold medal during the 1984 Summer Olympics, the diver ha had little luck with major endorsement. And a few marketing executive say that even his second sweep of the diving event may not up his potential. "When most advertiser are looking for the male hero, the word 'macho' trail along very closely," say Marty Blackman of Blackman & Raber, a sports-marketing firm in New York. "I don't find Louganis a macho guy." Still, other marketing professional say that Mr. Louganis's dramatic recovery after smashing his head ha secured the diver's future. His manager, Jim Babbitt, won't comment on any contract offer. He will say, however, that his client ha "done just fine. He isn't unhappy. He dive to perform; he doesn't dive for dollars." ---Winning EndorsementsThere is only one former Olympian among the top sport endorser of last year.ATHLETE: Arnold Palmer (Golf)NATIONAL ENDORSEMENTS:
