goldturned into disappointment Saturday a East Germany's Katarina Wittwon her second straight Olympic championship and Canadian ElizabethManley took home the silver before a crowd of cheering countrymen.It's over. Back to school, said Thomas, who won the bronzemedal despite three faulty landing. I'm not going to make anyexcuses. I wa really skating well this week. It wasn't supposed tohappen, I guess. But I tried.While the top two skater in the world staged a shootout tomusic from Bizet's Carmen, Manley wa so sensational in thefreestyle that she finished first with seven judge. Combined witha fourth in the compulsory figure and a third-place finish in theshort program earlier in the week, the performance put Manley insecond place.Witt, a three-time world champion from East Germany, became thefirst repeat single champion since Dick Button took Olympic goldin 1948 and '52. Sonja Henie of Norway wa the only woman to do itbefore Witt, winning in 1928, 1932 and 1936.Thomas, of San Jose, Calif., the first black to win a U.S.figure skating crown and the 1986 world champion, skated poorlySaturday after doing well earlier in the Games.By contrast, Manley had the sellout crowd at the OlympicSaddledome enraptured. They cheered, hooted and stamped their feetwhen she finished hitting every element of her program.Jill Trenary of Minnetonka, Minn., finished fourth. She wasfifth heading into the long program, worth 50 percent of theoverall score.Thomas' bronze wa the third figure skating medal here for theUnited States. Brian Boitano won the men's crown, and a bronze inpairs went to Jill Watson and Peter Oppegard.In addition to the three figure skating medal, the US. teamhad three speed-skating medals: one each gold, silver and bronze.Speed skater Bonnie Blair, America's only double medalist, triedagain Saturday in the 1,500 meter but finished fourth, well offthe pace. She won the gold in the 500 and the bronze in the 1,000meters.As the Olympics winded up it next-to-last day, the Soviet Unionhad 27 medal, including 11 gold, while East Germany in secondplace had 22, including nine golds.Florence Griffith Joyner twice smasheda world record Thursday a she blazed to a gold medal in the200-meter sprint.She also stayed on target to become the second woman to win fourtrack and field gold medal in a single Olympics.Griffith Joyner dashed to her second gold in 21.34 seconds,shattering the world mark she had set just 90 minute earlier inher semifinal heat. In that race, she ran 21.56, eclipsing the9-year-old mark of 21.71 set in 1979 by Marita Koch of East Germanyand equaled three time since.In her 200 quarterfinal heat Wednesday, Griffith Joyner ran anOlympic record 21.76 seconds.Griffith Joyner, who set an Olympic record Sunday in winning the100 meter, had a big lead Thursday a she turned the curve for thefinal 100 meter. She glided to the wire.I know I can run much faster, she said. I felt veryrelaxed. That's the key.Griffith Joyner, 28, is scheduled to run in the 400-meter relaySaturday and may compete in the 1,600-meter relay that day.Noted for her long, painted fingernail and racy, colorfulbodysuits, Griffith Joyner of Los Angeles ha a chance to match the1984 quadruple gold medal performance of US. sprinter and longjumper Carl Lewis, and by Fanny Blankers-Koen of the Netherlands in1948.TONIGHT in the big stadium in Barcelona the athletics is dominated by thefour relay final. Tonight it is nation versus nation.What the relay demonstrate more clearly than any other athletics event isthat at the Olympics the race ha traditionally gone to affluent country -or to those, rather, that choose to lavish resource on athletes.The US ha comfortably won the most relay medal, followed by Britain, theformer Soviet Union, the former West Germany (not even counting the six wonbefore 1939), the former East Germany, France and Canada.Britain alone have won more relay medal (23) than all the Caribbean islands(nine) and Africa (four, including one for South Africa). The Dutch, withone, have more relay medal than all the nation of Asia (nil) and SouthAmerica (nil) combined. The Cuban women's 100 metre relay team of 1968 and1972 are the only woman from outside the developed world to have won relaymedals.With a little luck - with their nerve-stretching hand-overs the relaysalways require a little luck - the developing country will continue thegentle redistribution of medal. But although they have talent, few canmatch the strength in depth of the traditional relay powers.The US 4x400m squad ha been weakened by the injury to Danny Everett. Evenso they rested Steve Lewis, the 400m silver medallist, in last night'ssemi-finals. In the 4x100m heat James Jett replaced Carl Lewis but Lewisran impressively in last night's semi-final and tonight will pursue hiseighth Olympic gold.One thing that became clear on Thursday, when Lewis won his seventh goldwith victory in the long jump, wa that while winning at the Olympics maybring other athlete excitement or relief, Lewis simply adores theexperience.When Voula Patoulidou, looking up at the giant video screen after thewomen's 100m hurdle final, suddenly realised, to her astonishment, that shehad won a gold medal, she went delightfully and utterly potty, a did theother 25 Greeks in the stadium, including Queen Sofia of Spain.Lewis, on the other hand, seemed unsurprised when Mike Powell wa unable tooverhaul him in the long jump. Even though the long jump had not finishedand even though 5,000m runner were trudging through a semi-final, Lewisbegan at once an extremely hammy lap-and-a-half of honour.He tried to orchestrate a Mexican wave. This is a man who derives immensepleasure from winning in front of a packed house. Lewis will be difficult tosuppress tonight.Noureddine Morcelli of Algeria will be hard to beat in the men's 1,500m.Morcelli is one of five Africans in the final striving to increase theircontinent's tally of just three Olympic medal (all Kenyan) in this event.Even here there is a US connection: Morcelli attended Riverside CommunityCollege in California, to hone his running on good tracks.On Thursday night, Morcelli cruised through his heat in first place afterthe gentlest push on the accelerator. The Moroccan Rachid Al-Basir followedhim down the straight, a respectful step behind, looming over his fellowArab and glancing anxiously round like a bodyguard. Morcelli ha not beenbeaten in the 1,500m since 1990.
column5: International and Olympic gold eludes or elates competitors and nations.
column6: International athletic competition, particularly the Olympics, can bring glory and wealth to some.  It can also bring disgrace to those caught using drugs.  Nations as well as individuals share the honors.  The former Soviet Union seemed to always top the "most-medals-won" list.  However, the U.S. superstars enjoy the most fame.
column7: In the world of international competition, the Olympics are special.  It is here that national pride is displayed, individual dreams are realized and fame is attained.  The summer Olympics with its gymnastics, track and field, and swimming events will showcase superstars such as Mary Lou Retton, Carl Lewis, Florence Griffith Joyner and Greg Louganis, some of whom capitalize on their fame and glory with lucrative advertising contracts.  The Winter Olympics generally highlight the figure skaters, speed skaters and downhill skiers.  Sometimes an Olympian acquires lifelong fame, as happened to Jesse Owens, who in 1936 soundly defeated Hitler's "master race" competitors.
column8: In the world of international competition, the Olympics are special.  True, world records can be established elsewhere, such as at the World University or the World Cup games.  But consider, in the 1988 Summer Olympics from Seoul, Korea, at least one billion people, via a 115-nation worldwide TV hookup, watched more than 9,000 athletes from 160 countries compete.  Sometimes dreams of Olympic gold are dashed, as happened to U.S. figure skater Debi Thomas, who, expecting gold, only placed third.  National pride is a factor.  The 1988 summer Olympics in Seoul, Korea gave us the first meeting between Soviet Union and United States competitors since 1976.  The Soviets captured most medals, the U.S. third most.  However, among those "third-most" U.S. competitors were superstar gold medalists Greg Louganis, Florence Griffith Joyner and Jackie Joyner-Kersee. Unfortunately, at these games Canadian sprinter Ben Johnson was disgraced by having his gold medal stripped away because of drug use.  The Olympics can lead to material wealth, such as experience by 1984 gymnast pixie, Mary Lou Retton or to long-lasting fame such as that of Jesse Owens, the black American who in the 1936 Berlin Olympics put to the lie Adolph Hitler's theories of a master race.
column9: Olympic Games: Good or Bad, But Always Center Stage
column10: The US has had many Olympic heroes such as Jesse Owens in 1936, and FlorenceGriffith Joyner, Carl Lewis,, and Greg Louganis more recently.  But US teamshave not always won the most medals, losing mostly to the Soviets.  Thegames generate greatest interest in the US when their teams dominate.
column11: The US had its worst Winter Olympic showing in 52 years the1988 Games withfew medal winners.  In the 1988 Summer Games in Seoul, the US faired betterbut was still outpaced by the Soviets.  Those games were marred by drugusage and suffered from poor TV coverage.  US medal winners included theflamboyant Florence Griffith Joiner, her sister-in-law Jackie Joyner-Kersee,Greg Louganis, and Carl Lewis.  An earlier Olympic hero, the late JesseOwens was honored with a Congressional Gold Medal.  The more affluentnations continue to dominate in the Olympics, especially in relay events.
column12: The US had its worst Winter Olympic showing in 52 years the 1988 Games.  Theonly gold medal winners were Brian Boitano in figure skating and BonnieBlair in speed skating.  Debi Thomas, the US hope in figure skating had tosettle for a bronze after East Germany's Katarina Witt took gold andCanadian Elizabeth Manley the silver.  The Seoul Summer Games were a muchbrighter arena for the US with multiple gold medal winners, but the Sovietswere the overall winners.  Drug usage disqualified several athletes, mostnotably Canadian sprinter Ben Johnson.  Because the US showing did not equaltheir domination in the Los Angeles Games four years earlier (boycotted bythe Soviets) and because of unimaginative TV coverage, lucrative endorsementcontracts did not appear to be forthcoming for the winners.The late Jesse Owens, hero of the 1936 Berlin Games was honored with aCongressional Gold Medal, which was given to his widow by President Bush.Teams from affluent nations usually dominate Olympic relay events, and thatwas expected to happen in Barcelona in 1992.  The US has an imposing groupof runners in those events.In non-Olympic years, World Cup and World University Games featured manysuccessful Olympic athletes.

column3: Mourners sobbed and shook their head in disbeliefSunday a ten of thousand viewed the flower-draped body of AndreiD. Sakharov in a huge outpouring of grief for the man described ashis country's conscience.Crimean Tatars and Jewish refuseniks two of the groupsSakharov helped joined rank-and-file Communists, teacher andengineers in filing past the body of the physicist, Nobel PeacePrize winner, human right advocate and legislator.Based on official source, an estimated 45,000 people filedthrough, and the flow of mourner continued into the night. Afriend of the family, speaking on condition of anonymity, said heheard estimate that 70,000 mourner viewed the body before it wasreturned to Sakharov's apartment at midnight.My God! Forgive u! one elderly woman cried out a she sawSakharov's body in an open coffin, sloping to the floor of thebeige marble Youth Palace in central Moscow. She apparently meantto apologize for not recognizing his contribution earlier.A mound of red and white carnation grew steadily at Sakharov'sfeet, and a spotlight wa focused on a portrait showing Sakharovwith his hand over his mouth, deep in thought. An organ and pianoalternated dirges.Sakharov died Thursday alone in his study at the age of 68,apparently of a heart attack, ending a three-decade fight againstthe jailing of innocent people, for free emigration, fordisarmament and other causes.Sunday wa the first of two day of memorial ceremony, and theoutpouring wa remarkable for a man who wa once ostracized andcommitted to nearly seven year in internal exile in the remotecity of Gorky.There were sign of grief throughout this snowy capital of 9million people, a though a government leader had died. The hugeline of mourner, sometimes four deep and heavily bundled againstbelow-zero temperature, stretched a mile from the palace andpoured continuously out of a subway station.So many people wanted to see Sakharov's body lying in state thatauthorities extended the viewing period by four hour and moved thecoffin so two row of mourner could file past.Roald Z. Sagdeyev, a member of the official funeral commission,said about 3,000 people an hour were arriving initially, but theofficial news agency Tass said that rate doubled later, making forum total of 45,000 by nighttime.Police lined the sidewalk where people waited. Sakharov's widowYelena Bonner, pleased authority were not turning people away,praised them for being very democratic.In her first detailed public comment on her husband's death,Bonner said she hope he will not be idolized.I would not wish a living person he ha lived an animated,happy life to be turned into an icon, an icon which could be usedby various force in their interest, Bonner said in an interviewbroadcast on Soviet TV.She said, however, that she hope Sakharov's writing, publishedabroad long ago, will become widely available in his homeland sothere can be a conversation of the people of the future withAndrei Dmitrievich.Mourners carried small portrait of Sakharov and red and whitecarnations to place near his coffin. One man, Sergei Kosykh,brought his 7-year-old daughter along.My daughter, who is being brought up with the belief thatthere is nobody greater than (Soviet founder Vladimir) Lenin, Ihave brought her here today just to show her the person greaterthan Lenin, he said.A middle-aged woman drew from Russian literature to reflect onSakharov's contributions.He wa like the man from one of Maxim Gorky's tale who usedhis own bleeding and living heart a a torch to lead people tolight and truth, said the woman, a teacher who declined to giveher name.Sakharov always wa telling the truth and by doing so forcedour leadership to do the same, said Boris Sorokin, a 50-year-olddesigner.Unofficial shrine sprouted outside Sakharov's southeast Moscowapartment, where candle flickered alongside his portrait. Outsidethe office of the weekly newspaper Moscow News on Pushkin Square,a popular gathering place for political activist, portrait andflowers were displayed.An entry in a notebook for mourners' comment outside Sakharov'sapartment building declared, The conscience of the nation hasdied.Moscow News an organ of the official press, which had brandedSakharov an utterly ignorant person took the rare step Sundayof publishing a special edition devoted to the activist.Four page were filled with picture of him, condolencetelegrams from exiled writer Alexander Solzhenitsyn and PresidentBush and a text of Sakharov's last public remark, a speech hedelivered hour before his death in which he said the Soviethierarchy wa leading the country to a catastrophe.On Sunday night, Soviet TV's newscast Seven Days also paidtribute to Sakharov, leading the program with a 10-minute report onhim.The Communist Party daily Pravda published a poem by YevgenyYevtushenko that read in part:History's most peaceful rebel, in dying, did not come downfrom the cross, but left a horrifying hole in the moral fabric ofthe world.On Saturday, Pravda published what amounted to a public apologyto Sakharov.President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other Soviet leader said inan obituary that Sakharov had been the victim of grossinjustices and praised him a a man of honesty and sincerity.Bonner, Sakharov's constant companion and fellow human rightsactivist, sat closest to the coffin, clutching a black handbag andperiodically closing her eye. A son and daughter from his firstmarriage and son and daughter of Bonner also attended, along withfour grandchildren.Gorbachev wa expected to pay his last respect Monday, when thefuneral is planned, and on Sunday wa represented by Yevgeny M.Primakov, chairman of the funeral commission and a non-votingmember of the country's ruling Politburo.The foreign dignitary expected to take part in Monday'sceremonies include Lech Walesa, head of Poland's Solidaritymovement, who will be making his first trip to the Soviet Union,and former refuseniks Yosef Begun and Vladimir Slepak, who now livein Israel.Israel's best known Soviet dissident, Natan Sharansky, wasrefused a visa when he applied for permission to travel to Moscow,said Sharansky's spokesman, Avraham Ben-Yaakov. Begun and Slepaksaid they would lay a wreath on Sakharov's grave in Sharansky'sname.Soviet medium once branded Andrei D. Sakharov atraitor, but a Moscow weekly ha now provided a sympatheticportrait of the human right activist and his wife.This week's issue of the newspaper Moscow News said thatSakharov long ago understood the need for change in the SovietUnion.The article make a clear attempt to refute some of the pastcharges leveled at Sakharov and his wife, fellow dissident YelenaBonner, by Soviet official and the state-controlled media.Moscow News also pointedly note that the 1975 Nobel Peace Prizewinner ha praised Mikhail S. Gorbachev's campaign for social andeconomic reform.The 66-year-old Sakharov and his wife lead a frugal existence intheir seventh-floor Moscow apartment, eating cabbage, beet soup,potatoes and other simple fare, and Sakharov insists on washing thedishes afterward himself, the paper said.It said their two-room home wa always filled with peopleseeking Sakharov's aid, and that the word most often heard thereare: Help me. But Moscow News asked: Can he really doeverything?Although the full-page article wa the longest on Sakharov todate in the Soviet press, it made only indirect reference to thenearly seven year he spent in exile after criticizing theKremlin's intervention in Afghanistan.Sakharov, a brilliant physicist, wa allowed to return to Moscowin December 1986 from his forced residence in the closed city ofGorky, where he wa banished without trial in January 1980.In effect, sometimes Sakharov bitterly joke that he'd like toreturn to Gorky for a few month to be able to work alone onscientific work, Moscow News said. Of course, concerning Gorky,that's a bitter joke.Since his return to Moscow, Sakharov ha been a vocal supporterof Gorbachev's program for nationwide reform that includes thepolicy of glasnost, or greater openness on selected topics.He simply belief that something helped change the thoughtsof the majority into state policy, Moscow News said.He callsperestroika (restructuring) an enormous event for our country andfor the entire world.However, Sakharov ha insisted on speedier progress in improvingthe Soviet record on human right, and during a Jan. 15 meeting inthe Kremlin, he handed Gorbachev a list of 200 people he said wereimprisoned for their views.Moscow News noted that in 1975, in a tract titled Knowledgeand the World, Sakharov set forth his view on Soviet affairs.Those writing have not been published in the Soviet Union.Now we can definitely see parallel between what he said then,and those idea that we are putting forward today, Moscow Newssaid.Sakharov called for a ban on nuclear testing long before theKremlin. The human right activist, one of the most prominentmembers of the dissident movement that reached it peak in the1970s, sought openness in Soviet society year before glasnostbecame Communist Party policy.Much of the Moscow News article seemed designed to undo harmcaused to the Sakharovs by previous press campaign against them.It said one Soviet book accused the Sakharovs of living inoriental luxury and engaging in scandal between spouses.Moscow News said Sakharov wa stubborn, unassuming, anundisputed member of his country's intelligentsia and a man withhis own view on how to deal conscientiously with world affair andthe demand of this life.His strong conviction even extend to his insistence that he dothe dish after meal, wrote the reporter who visited Sakharov athis apartment.What is that, Andrei Dmitrievich, your hobby? asked MoscowNews correspondent Gennady Zhavoronkov.Not all guest are able to wash the dish conscientiously,Sakharov replied.Andrei D. Sakharov, the father of the Sovietdissident movement, finally received a 1973 human right awardThursday night during his first trip to New York City.Sakharov received the Human Rights Award from the InternationalLeague for Human Rights at a reception at the home of Ronald Lauder,the former US. ambassador to Austria.The 67-year-old Nobel Peace Prize winner is on his first trip tothe West, le than two year after Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachevfreed him from internal exile in the city of Gorky. The human rightsactivist wa banished in 1980 to the closed city for opposing theSoviet occupation of Afghanistan.About 200 guest, including author Elie Wiesel, Brooklyn DistrictAttorney Elizabeth Holtzman, designer Caroline Roehm and ABCtelevision's Barbara Walters, attended the reception.The ceremony wa closed to the medium. Sakharov, wearing a blueberet and plaid scarf, made no statement a he left the receptionand entered a waiting limousine.Sakharov is the honorary president of the league, which ha itsheadquarters in the United States and more than 40 affiliate groupsaround the world, including the Moscow Human Rights Committee, whichSakharov and his colleague founded in 1971.Sakharov arrived in the United States on Sunday to visitrelatives and receive medical treatment before going to Washingtonfor a White House visit and a board meeting of the InternationalFoundation for the Survival and Development of Humanity, of which heis a director.A Soviet newspaper ha painted a highlysympathetic portrait of Andrei D. Sakharov and Yelena Bonner,countering past attack on the dissident couple once branded astraitors by the state-run media.But the account in Moscow News only indirectly mentioned thenearly seven year Sakharov spent in forced internal exile forcriticizing the Soviet drive into Afghanistan, indicating thattopic is still too sensitive.In it latest issue, the weekly devoted it entire back page todescribing the home life of Sakharov, 66, the 1975 Nobel PeacePrize winner, and said the word most often heard in hisseventh-floor Moscow apartment are help me.Sakharov's apartment on a major thoroughfare ha been a meccafor Soviets seeking his aid since he and his wife were allowed toreturn from exile in the closed city of Gorky in December 1986.Since then, Sakharov, who wa one of the creator of hisnation's hydrogen bomb, ha vocally supported Soviet leader MikhailS. Gorbachev's reform campaign, but ha called for the liberationof all political prisoner and more improvement in the field ofhuman rights.Past Soviet report, published before Gorbachev became Sovietleader, accused Bonner of marrying Sakharov for his money and saidthe couple lived in oriental luxury amid scandal betweenspouses.Moscow News depicted the couple a living peacefully andfrugally, eating cabbage, beet soup, potato, and other simplefare, and marveled that Sakharov, a member of the prestigiousAcademy of Sciences, always doe the dish himself.While Sakharov wa in exile in the closed city of Gorky, theauthor of a book that accused him of leading a luxurious andscandal-ridden existence came to ask for an interview, Moscow Newssaid.Sakharov put a copy of his book in front of him and proposedthat he write an apology for all the lie that were published,the paper said.It reported that when the unidentified author refused, Sakharovsaid, It's too bad that duel are abolished in our time, andslapped him.Sakharov ha been quoted numerous time by Soviet medium sincehis return from exile, but the article in Moscow News wa thelongest devoted to him so far.But most of the newspaper's circulation is among foreigntourists and reader abroad, so relatively few Soviets would seethe Sakharov article. As well a appearing in Russian, Moscow Newsalso print edition in English, French and other languages.Andrei D. Sakharov urged member of the Academy ofSciences on Monday to reject the leadership's list of candidate forthe new Soviet legislature, which doe not include the Nobel PeacePrize winner.The 67-year-old nuclear physicist and human right activist, whowon the Nobel in 1975, said in a speech to the academy that manyscientists objected to the slate for Sunday's election approved bythe leadership in January.Sakharov and several other well-known proponent of reform aremissing from the list. The official news agency Tass quoted him assaying, however, that scientist were upset not because Sakharovwas not nominated, but because the role of scientific institutionswas ignored.He called for reversal of what he called the anti-democraticdecision, which produced a list of what critic describe asold-guard manager of scientific institutions.A vote on the academy candidate is scheduled for Tuesday.Sakharov wa nominated from several geographic district for aseat in the new 2,250-member Congress of People's Deputies, but hedecided to refuse the nomination and fight for an Academy ofSciences seat.Under an election law approved in December, 750 seat in thelegislature are reserved for the Communist Party and it affiliatesand for professional, social and trade union organization. Theother 1,500 will be filled by representative of the 15 Sovietrepublics and their electoral districts.Those in the academy who support Sakharov hope to force a newround of nomination by mustering enough support to deny allnominees a majority, said Andrei Mironov, a former politicalprisoner.That would force the academy to start over and produce a new listof nominee under term of the new election law.Twenty-five seat were allotted to the academy, but it gave fiveto affiliated society and association. From 121 nominee, theacademy leadership chose 23 candidate for the remaining 20 seats.Although 60 research institute nominated Sakharov, he wa notchosen for the final slate. The leadership's decision inspiredwidespread press criticism and a demonstration at the academy'sMoscow headquarters.Tass said 1,108 academician, corresponding member andrepresentatives of reseach institute attended the three-day meetingthat began Monday.The first three day of this week may become the `hottest'spring day for Soviet scientist, it said, alluding to theleadership's rejection of such reformer a Sakharov, spacescientist Roald Sagdeev and sociologist Tatyana Zaslavsakaya.The agency acknowledged many scientist were unsatisfied withthe slate of candidates.Mironov said two other academician also spoke on Monday in favorof new nomination. No detail of their remark were available.In what amounted to a public apology, Mikhail S.Gorbachev and Soviet leader today eulogized Andrei D. Sakharov asa man of honesty and sincerity who suffered great injustice atthe hand of previous rulers.An obituary signed by Gorbachev, five other member of theruling Communist Party Politburo and 50 other leading official andscholars wa printed along with a picture of Sakharov on page 4 ofthe party daily Pravda.Such obituary are reserved for favored public figure andscientists, and Pravda emphasized the importance of the 1975 NobelPeace Prize winner by printing a decree about the formation of afuneral commission in a black box on it front page.Sakharov, 68, died Thursday night in his study, just hour afterurging fellow member of the Congress of People's Deputies tocreate a formal opposition to the party in their drive to break itsseven-decade strangehold on political power.A distinguished scientist and public figure, a man of honestyand sincerity ha passed away, the obituary said. Everythingthat Andrei Dmitrievich did wa dictated by his conscience, hisdeep humanitarian convictions.The obituary noted Sakharov wa exiled in the industrial city ofGorky about 250 mile east of Moscow from 1980 to 1986.Gross injustice were permitted in relation to A.D.Sakharov, it said.It wa signed by Gorbachev and fellow Politburo member NikolaiI. Ryzhkov, Vadim A. Medvedev, Lev N. Zaikov, Alexander N. Yakovlevand Vitaly I. Vorotnikov.However, the signature of several other Politburo members,including KGB chief Vladimir A. Kryuchkov and leading conservativeYegor K. Ligachev were missing. Absence of their signature couldsignify that the disagreed with part of the obituary.Ligachev, interviewed by the Tass news agency on Friday, hadsaid he disagreed with Sakharov but respected him.It wa Leonid I. Brezhnev, now blamed by Gorbachev forpermitting stagnation and corruption to overcome the Soviet system,who exiled Sakharov for criticizing the Soviet intervention inAfghanistan.Gorbachev called Sakharov in Gorky in December 1986 and told himhe could return to Moscow.The Soviet leader told reporter at the Congress of People'sDeputies that Sakharov's death wa a great loss.Even though the two often tangled at the Congress, Gorbachevsaid he respected Sakharov. He wa not some sort of politicalintriguer, the Soviet president said Friday.Gorbachev said he would attend Sakharov's funeral Mondayafternoon in southwest Moscow's Vostryakovskoye Cemetery.Several hundred people gathered outside Sakharov's apartmentbuilding Friday evening, holding candle and wreathing hisphotograph in flower. Memorial service were scheduled Sunday atthe city's main youth center, and on Monday at the Lebedev physicsinstitute where Sakharov worked and the Academy of Sciences, ofwhich he wa a leading member.The popular nighttime TV program Vzglad showed a briefinterview with his widow, Yelena Bonner, discussing the funeralarrangements.The obituary also praised Sakharov's vision a a scientist,which made him the youngest-ever member of the Academy of Sciencesat age 32 and led to his inclusion in a group that developed theSoviet hydrogen bomb.But it said that Sakharov realized the danger of the weapon hehad helped create.Working on the creation of weapon of mass destruction, A.D.Sakharov understood early the danger for humanity of their wideproduction and testing, and stubbornly placed before the governmentthe question of limiting such test, it said.But at that time his appeal were not accepted, it said.He kept these same position in the future.The visit by human right activist Andrei D.Sakharov to the United States ha gone virtually unreported by statemedia, with a radio broadcast saying only he had voiced oppositionto the US. Star Wars program.That report from Radio Moscow, carried on itsinternational-service news program Tuesday, apparently wa the onlymention made by Soviet medium of Sakharov's visit to the UnitedStates, which began Sunday.Radio Moscow said Sakharov made the comment about the Reaganadministration's space-based anti-missile program at a Boston newsconference.Sakharov, winner of the 1975 Nobel Peace Prize, is scheduled tospend two week visiting relative in the United States, undergoingmedical test and promoting a new international organization hebelongs to.A celebrity in the West since he helped form the Soviet dissidentmovement of the 1970s, Sakharov spent nearly seven year in internalexile after criticizing the Kremlin's military drive intoAfghanistan.President Mikhail S. Gorbachev allowed him to return to Moscow inDecember 1986. Some statement and article by Sakharov have beenprinted in the Soviet medium since then, including an article lastweek in a magazine that opposed some element of Gorbachev'sblueprint for political and electoral reforms.Other activity by Sakharov have gone unreported here, includinghis delivery to Gorbachev of a list of 200 Soviets reportedly heldin prison, labor camp or psychiatric hopsitals because of theirpolitical views.The official Tass news agency reported Wednesday that theorganization Sakharov belongs to the International Foundation forthe Survival and Development of Humanity held it first session inBoston the previous day.Tass made no mention of Sakharov in it three-paragragh report,but said the Soviet delegation to the meeting wa headed by YevgenyVelikhov, vice president of the Soviet Academy of Sciences.
column5: Nobel laureate Andrei Sakharov, Soviet human rights activist, died 1989
column6: Andrei Sakharov, Soviet hydrogen bomb developer and prominent 1970s dissident, won the 1975 Nobel Peace Prize. He was exiled to Gorky from 1980-1986. Sakharov supported Gorbachev's reforms but urged improved human rights.  In April 1989 he was elected to parliament. He died in December 1989, aged 68, of an apparent heart attack.
column7: Andrei Sakharov helped develop the Soviet hydrogen bomb but urged its limitation. He was a prominent 1970s dissident and won the 1975 Nobel Peace Prize. In January 1980, after criticizing Soviet intervention in Afghanistan, Breshnev exiled him to Gorky. Gorbachev allowed Sakharov and his wife Yelena Bonner's return to Moscow in December 1986. Their apartment became a mecca for aid-seekers. Sakharov supported Gorbachev's reforms but urged improvement in human rights and a nuclear testing ban.  In April 1989 he was elected to parliament after Soviet physicists voted secretly to nominate him. Sakharov, 68, died in December 1989 of an apparent heart attack after urging creation of an opposition party.
column8: Physicist Andrei D. Sakharov became the youngest member of the Soviet Academy of Sciences and helped develop the Soviet hydrogen bomb, but urged limiting its production and testing. He was a prominent 1970s dissident and won the 1975 Nobel Peace Prize. In January 1980, after Sakharov criticized Soviet intervention in Afghanistan, Breshnev exiled him to Gorky. Gorbachev allowed Sakharov and his wife Yelena Bonner to return to Moscow in December 1986. There they lived simply in a two-room, seventh-floor apartment which became a mecca for Soviets seeking aid. Sakharov supported Gorbachev's reforms but called for speedier progress in human rights, political prisoner liberation, and a nuclear testing ban. In November 1988 he visited the US, underwent medical tests, and promoted a world peace foundation. In April 1989, he was elected to parliament after Soviet physicists voted secretly to nominate him. He warned of national economic catastrophe. Sakharov died alone in his Moscow apartment in December 1989 at the age of 68, of an apparent heart attack, hours after urging creation of an opposition party. World and Soviet leaders and press eulogized him as a sincere man who suffered great injustice and helped change Soviet society. 45,000 grievers filed past Sakharov's body. Sakharov had four children and four grandchildren.
column9: Sakharov Dead. Soviet Physicist, Rights Advocate, Nobel Peace Prize Winner
column10: Andrei Sakharov died in December 1989. The Soviet physicist helped develop the hydrogen bomb, but was better known for winning the  Nobel Peace Prize. His advocacy of human rights and criticism of the Kremlin resulted in a seven-year exile. His obituary constituted a public apology for the treatment afforded him.
column11: Andrei Sakharov was a physicist who helped develop the Soviet hydrogen bomb. He later gained widespread fame as a human rights advocate and the 1979 winner of the Nobel Peace Prize.His constant criticism irked the Kremlin. In 1980 he criticized the invasion of Afghanistan and Breznev exiled him to Gorky. Gorbachev freed him in 1986. Sakharov praised Gorbachev on foreign affairs, but criticized his economic policies. Sakharov was elected to the Soviet Congress of People's Deputies in April 1989.Sakharov died suddenly on 14 December 1989. His obituary, signed by Gorbachev, was tantamount to  public apology.
column12: Andrei Sakharov, 68, a Nobel Peace Prize winner and a human rights activist, died in Moscow on 14 December 1989. Sakharov was a physicist who attained hero status for his work on the Soviet hydrogen bomb. He later made himself a nuisance to the Kremlin with his continual calls for improvement in the rights of the Soviet people. In 1973 the International League for Human Rights gave him an award, but he was not able to accept it until his first visit to New York City in 1989. His humanitarianism won him the 1975 Noble Peace Prize.His gadfly activities throughout the 1970s exasperated the Kremlin. In January 1980, when he criticized the invasion of Afghanistan, President Brezhnev exiled him to the closed city of Gorky.President Gorbachev freed Sakharov in December 1986. He and Yelena Bonner, his wile and fellow activist, settled in Moscow. He praised Gorbachev for the new direction in foreign affairs, but loudly criticized the slow pace of economic reform. In April 1989 Sakharov was elected to membership in the Soviet Congress of People's Deputies.Sakharov's obituary, signed by Gorbachev and published in Pravda, and the outpouring of remorse constituted a public apology for his exile.

column3: More than 4,000 worker at a coal mine inthe southern city of Jastrzebie went on strike today to demandlegalization of Solidarity and higher wage, a spokeswoman said.The strike in Jastrzebie, about 275 mile southwest of Warsaw,comes on the eighth anniversary of the founding of the outlawedtrade federation.Solidarity spokeswoman Katarzyna Ketrzynska said worker on theovernight shift at the Manifest Lipcowy mine stayed outside themine shaft all night and were joined by worker arriving for themorning shift.She said security officer blocked miner on the afternoonshift, which start at 2 p.m., from entering the ground to jointhe striking miner. The strike began at noon today, according toKatrzynska.She said the miner are demanding the legalization of Solidarityand reinstatement of worker fired for union activity. Theworkers are also calling for higher wage and better workingconditions, and are requesting two lawyer and two economist toassist them in the negotiations.Manifest Lipcowy is the second mine in the industrial region ofSilesia to experience unrest.Workers at the Rudna copper mine near the city of Wroclaw stageda protest rally Monday to demand improved safety condition and thereturn of Solidarity activist to work. Three member of Solidaritywere barred Saturday from working.Solidarity wa crushed in 1981, when the government imposedmartial law, and wa banned nearly a year later by parliament.On Aug. 16, 1980, worker at factory around the northern portof Gdansk joined striking shipyard worker to form Solidarity, thefirst and only independent trade federation in the Soviet bloc.More than 10,000 coal miner in fourstates were off the job today to express sympathy for miner inVirginia and West Virginia who have waged a bitter strike sinceApril against the Pittston Coal Group.Miners in Pennsylvania and Kentucky today became the third andfourth state to report walkout at coal company. The sympathystrikes began Monday in West Virginia and spread to Indiana lateThursday.One United Mine Workers representative said today that theIndiana walkout wa prompted by Thursday night's telecast of CBS'48 Hours, which focused on the Pittston strike, in which 1,600miners have been off the job since April.Pittston dropped out of the Bituminous Coal Operators Associationto negotiate with the union independently, and the two side havefailed to reach an agreement despite 16 month of negotiations.UMW official gave conflicting indication of whether they areresponsible for the wildcat strike. Some said they are asking unionmembers to return to work, but Tommy Buchanan, internationalexecutive board member in UMW District 20 in Birmingham, Ala., saidtoday the final decision on whether 5,000 Alabama miner will jointhe strike will be with union President Richard Trumka.It might be two day. It might be a week. It will startwhenever it come down from the union president, Buchanan said.Union spokesman Joe Corcoran wa not in his office and ha notreturned phone call this week.The head of the coal industry bargaining unit said he had noplans to confer with the Pittston on the wildcat strikes.I would no more try to tell someone else how to run theircompany than I would expect someone else to try to tell me how torun my company, said Robert H. Quenon, president of PeabodyHolding Co., the nation's largest coal producer, and chairman of theBituminous Coal Operators Association.Quenon flew to Charleston from St. Louis on Thursday to meet withreporters and express Peabody's and the association's concern aboutthe walkout.An estimated 2,300 United Mine Workers member stayed away fromtheir job today in Pennsylvania. Most worked for Rochester &Pittsburgh Coal Co. operation in central Pennsylvania, where 1,600miners failed to report for work at midnight Thursday, said companyspokesman Hank Waneck said.About 290 miner at Peabody's Camp No. 1 mine in MorganfieldKy., didn't report for work today, said company spokesman Tom Clarke.At least 270 miner were off the job at two mine in Indianatoday, spokesman said. Mark Arnold, a spokesman for UMW District 11in Terre Haute, attributed the action to the CBS show.When the miner saw that last night, that kind of set them offto where they decided to walk out, he said.About one-third of West Virginia's 24,000 miner were reportedoff the job today. Some 600 miner in Wise County, Va., who walkedout earlier in the week returned to work this morning.The coal company contend the walkout at company other thanPittston violate a no-strike clause in the 1988 national contractthe union signed with the association. Pittston did not take part inthat agreement.Union official have not returned phone call this week, but inthe past they have said they have not authorized the walkout.I think the union leadership ought to exercise it leadershiprole and do what they can to lead the miner back to work, Quenonsaid. That's why we have a union. That's why we have an agreementwith the union to set out the term and condition under which wewill have labor to run our coal mines.And we expect that to be honored.BFN[Text] Donetsk Oblast [no date a received] -- As UNIAN reported, miner at the "Ordzhonikidzevuhillya" coal production association and the "Yenakiyevo" and "Poltava" pit went on strike in Yenakiyevo on 27 June, demanding payment of wage arrears. The strike continued at these mine on 28 June. Some of the miner at the Karl Marx, "Chernovonyy Zhovten," "Chervonyy Profinter," and "Yunkom" pit joined the strike. A total of 1,200 of the association's 2,248 worker are on strike. A rally consisting of 350 miner wa held on 28 June near the town council building where demand were made to pay the wage and dismiss the director general of the "Ordzhonikidzevuhillya" production association.A strike committee consisting of 12 person wa elected (one of the member is a former Komsomol leader and former USSR people's deputy Viktor Honcharov) and it wa decided to continue the strike until the demand that had been raised have been completely fulfilled.On 28 June, 118 of 258 worker on the second shift at the "PivdennoDonbass" mine of the "Donetskvuhillya" production association in the town of Ugledar refused to start work for the same reason -- delay in paying wage. After a meeting with the mine's director, who promised to pay the arrears, the miner on the third shift returned to work.On 27 June, all miner on the fourth shift at the "Karbomid" and "Pervomaysk" mine in Pervomaysk, Lugansk oblast, refused to start work (142 and 157 miner respectively).In the opinion of the mine's representative, who wished not to be identified, the strike ha a clear political hue -- to attempt to compromise the existing authority and, particularly, President Leonid Kravchuk before the second round of presidential election. According to some report, among the leader of the striking pit there are member of the Kuchma-Hrynyov Interregional Bloc of Reforms.As Kostyantyn Fesenko, chairman of the coal industry worker trade union, informed a UNIAN correspondent, Viktor Yushchenko, the chairman of the National Bank of Ukraine, in a telephone conversation on 29 June, gave assurance that the money for the miners' wage a well a subsidy for the following month would be found and forwarded in the next few days.The National Union of Mineworkers said an estimated 200,000 black gold and coal miner in South Africa will begin a strike Sunday night for higher wage and better working condition, in what it said would be the largest job action ever to affect the mining industry in that nation. The strike initially would cover more than half of South Africa's gold mine and about one-fifth of it coal mine, said Cyril Ramaphosa, the union's general secretary. If worker in mine not included in current negotiation join in sympathy strike, a total of 300,000 miner could be on strike, he said. Gold and coal account for more than half of South Africa's foreign-currency earnings. The union's announcement produced little immediate reaction on South African financial market, where analyst said a strike had been expected and probably wouldn't have much impact unless it lasted more than a month. Mine owner reportedly have been building stockpile for several week in anticipation of a strike. Mining companies' share rose along with the price of gold, but the metal's rise came mainly in reaction to increased tension in the Persian Gulf. The South African rand wa slightly firmer. Mr. Ramaphosa said the union is demanding a 30%, across-the-board wage increase for black miner, who the union say earn an average of 225 rand ($109) a month. The Chamber of Mines, which represents the nation's six biggest mining house, say black miner earn about twice that much. It implemented wage increase ranging from 15% to 23.4% last month. Anglo American Corp., the huge South African mining house, warned against a strike, saying miner had received a good wage increase in July and wouldn't gain further raise by a job action. But "at this stage it seems the strike seems inevitable," said Mr. Ramaphosa, who added that there hadn't been any negotiation with management since a strike ballot received "overwhelming support" during the week of July 12. He also warned of possible confrontation with police, saying: "We have issued instruction to our member that if they are attacked they should defend themselves." Miners' strike in recent year have featured clash with police, leaving dozen of people dead. "The total mine that will be affected are 28 gold mine around the country and 18 collieries," the union official said. "Our union is at the same time in dispute with a number of other company, where strike action could take place at any time, should the various mine management refuse to accede to our members' demands." He said such other company included De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd., the world's largest diamond miner. In addition to the general wage increase, Mr. Ramaphosa said the union is demanding pay for black miner doing dangerous work. The black miner also are asking for 30 days' leave each year, and a paid holiday on June 16, the anniversary of the 1976 Soweto riot. They also want an increase in death benefit to five year from two.Strikes by ten of thousand ofminers in this Siberian coal region spread to four more of theSoviet Union's coal field, Tass reported today.The official news agency said coal miner in Vorkuta in the farnorth, the Don River city of Rostov in southwestern Russia and theUkrainian industrial center of Dnepropetrovsk walked out Wednesday.Miners in the Karaganda region in Soviet Central Asia todayrefused to work, Tass said. By evening, 14 mine in the region, homeof the country's third-largest coal field, were reported at astandstill.Tass said their demand were similar to those of striking minersin the Donetsk and Kuznetsk coal basin, who are seeking greaterlocal control over their industry and better wage and livingconditions.Kuznetsk, in western Siberia, and Donetsk, in the Ukraine, arethe country's two leading coal basin and the strike amount to thecountry's worst labor unrest since the 1920s. Novokuznetsk is amajor city in the Kuznetsk region, where the strike began 10 daysago.The government ha acknowledged that living and workingconditions for miner in the region are abysmal and ha madegeneral pledge of improvements.Tass reported Wednesday that some miner in Siberia had returnedto work after the government made pay concessions.The government also ha promised to send extra meat, buttersugar, tea, leather shoe, furniture and car to relieve shortagesin the region, the Communist Youth League newspaper KomsomolskayaPravda said today.But the newspaper and Tass reported more disturbance in theUkraine. Komsomolskaya Pravda quoted a communist official in theDonetsk city of Makeyevka a saying, The scale of the strike isgrowing. Practically all the coal enterprise of the city havestopped work.Miners in Vorkuta, Rostov and Dnepropetrovsk all walked off thejob on Wednesday, Tass said.In Vorkuta, striker sent a letter to the Kremlin asking for anurgent resolution of the sharp economic and social problem of thecoal sector, and also specific problem of worker of the farnorth, Tass said.In Rostov, miners' economic demand included extra pay forevening and night shift, longer vacation and an increase in theprice of coal to world market price, the news agency reported.In Dnepropetrovsk, which is 150 mile from Donetsk, workers'demands mirrored those of Donetsk and Kuznetsk miners.In Karaganda, striker said they walked out to protest incompletenews account of miners' demand in the Kuznetsk strike, accordingto Tass.President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said Wednesday the strike couldimperil his reform and that there were report of railway workersbeing urged to strike.He said that if labor trouble spread, We may have to take suchextreme measure that it will hurt what we've been doing tooverhaul the economy through greater attention to free-marketmechanisms.He did not elaborate.Strikes are rare in the Soviet Union and were ended by forcebefore Gorbachev gained power in March 1985.Tass today said that the Kuznetsk strike had reached a turningpoint, with nine out of 11 mining center back at work.It wa not known how many more employee were back on the jobtoday. On Wednesday, Tass said that 24,000 striker in Kuznetsk wereback at work and 150,000 remained on strike.State television said Wednesday that the strike in the Donetskbasin had spread to 70 of it 120 mine, more than triple theprevious number, and that mine construction worker had joined.In a report from the Donetsk city of Yenakiyevo, television saidsteel and coke-chemical plant were on the verge of a stoppagefor lack of coal.Earlier report in the official press had said operation atsteel and power plant were affected by short supply of coal andcoke.Gorbachev told the national legislature Wednesday that thestrikes had deprived the nation of more than 1 million ton of coal.The government ha agreed to most miner demand, including thoseon pension and overtime, Gorbachev said. But he said that settlingsome longer-term issue would take up to a month.Tass outlined a concession package that includes bonus pay tonight shift and for men using jackhammers.Strikers also have complained about poor housing and shortage ofconsumer good and food, and the government ha made general pledgesof improvement in those areas.President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today thatthousands of striking coal miner and other worker are urgingrailway employee to join the work stoppage and that the unrestthreatens his economic reforms.Strikes have shut down more than 200 mine and factory in thecountry's two top coal-producing region, official report said. Ina report to the Supreme Soviet, Gorbachev said they have resulted ina 1 million-ton drop in coal production.Following Gorbachev to the podium, legislator Anatoly Saunin saideach lost work day cost million of ruble that might otherwise helpimprove living condition. You mustn't hold a knife to thethroat of the government, he told strikers.Saunin, from the Donetsk region of the Ukraine, the country's topcoal region, said the number of striking mine there increased from20 on Tuesday to 58 today.Now there are report of call to railroad worker to join thestrike a of Aug. 1, Gorbachev said during the parliamentarysession, which wa broadcast on television and radio.Such a development of event pose a threat to theimplementation of plan projected by the policy of perestroika, hesaid, referring to his effort to restructure the economy.Miners began walking out July 11 in Siberia's Kuznetsk Basin coalregion. Workers in other industry in the region soon followed. OnSaturday, miner in the Donetsk coal basin began walking off the job.The miner are demanding more local control over their industryas well a higher wage and better living conditions.Gorbachev said he and Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov sent a telegramto miner in the Ukraine assuring them that any concession grantedto Siberian miner would apply to other mining region a well.He blamed some of the miners' discontent on anti-socialistelements but said he understood their basic demands.Government negotiation with strike committee have resolved mostof the miners' demand, including those on pension and overtime,but some longer-term question will take up to a month to settle,and the miner are refusing any delay, he said.Central authority have so far balked at granting miner morecontrol over their industry.If the strike spread to other sector of the economy, We mayhave to take such extreme measure that it will hurt what we've beendoing, Gorbachev said, without specifying what step he would take.He said the lost coal production could not be recovered byincreasing the mines' output because they already work at fullcapacity.Recent report have put the total number of striker in theDonetsk and Kuznetsk region at more than 112000, but the numberappeared to be rising.Because of disrupted coal delivery, the strike threatened acatastrophe at metallurgical and electrical power plant, Tasssaid.The Politburo sent to Kuznetsk Nikolai N. Slyunkov, a member ofthe ruling Communist Party body who worked several year in thetractor-building industry and ha spoken about labor discipline.He held marathon meeting with striker Monday night and Tuesdayand addressed 30,000 people in the main square of Prokopyevsk, 2,100miles east of Moscow.Miners in the Donetsk Basin are demanding a 40 percent wageincrease for night work, improved living condition, a fixed day offand retirement after 20 year of underground work.They also demand that the Coal Mining Ministry trim itsmanagerial staff.Tass carried a report Tuesday denying that the Soviet Union'sthird major coal region, Karaganda in Kazakhstan, also wa on strike.A proposed law on ending strike and other labor conflict isbeing rushed through the Supreme Soviet legislature, Tass said.A spokesman for the strike committee in Prokopyevsk, ValeryLegachev, said Tuesday that Slyunkov promised to increase thearea's regular food supply by 20 to 30 percent, a well a soapand washing powder.Izvestia, the government newspaper, reported Tuesday thatSlyunkov promised higher pay for night work, longer vacation and adoubling of the wholesale price of coal to pay for the benefits.The strike are believed to be the nation's worst since the1920s, when the country wa gripped in revolution, civil war and apower struggle. Records from that period are sketchy, but fightingwas widespread and industrial production wa severely disrupted.Until Gorbachev came to power in 1985, the official medium did notreport job action in the Soviet Union. Underground reportsdescribed strike that were of much shorter and not a widespread asthose in Kuznetsk and Donetsk.Most of the country's 1.2 million coal miner are still working, but outputin some key region ha been halved, saddling Gorbachev with a substantiallabor and fuel problem even a he struggle to revive the Soviet economy.;The strike is the new union's first major test of strength. It began March 1as a warning action in the Karaganda coal field of Kazakhstan and theKrasnoarmeisk area of the Ukraine but gradually spread to all of the country'smajor coal regions.; The striker are seeking wage increase of at least100 percent, better working condition and earlier retirement. They claim thegovernment ha not kept promise it made to raise miners' living standard assettlement of a nationwide coal strike in July 1989.; The 1989 strike,which involved more than 500,000 miner, made only economic demand. Thistime, Shushpanov said, the miner also want three major politicalconcessions.; First, he said, they want "real sovereignty" for the 15Soviet republic. They are unhappy with Gorbachev's proposed Union Treaty,which would leave the central government in control of the economy, defense,foreign policy and communication, he said.; Second, the union is demandingmore power for Gorbachev's Federation Council, which includes the presidentsof all the republics.; Finally, the union want a "law on property" thatwould define what belongs to the government and allow private ownership ofland and industry, including some mine, he said.; According to the statenews agency Tass, the strike ha spread to the Donetsk coal basin of theUkraine, the Vorkuta and Inta region of northern Russia, and the Kuznetskcoal basin of western Siberia.WORKERS AT KGHM, Poland's copper producing combine went on strike yesterdayas coal mining union staged token stoppage in a third of the country'spits in a major challenge to the government's economic policies.The strike at KGHM in Lubin, western Poland, where mining unionsrepresenting some 40,0000 worker have been demanding a 30 per cent wageincrease, came despite a management offer at the weekend to increase wagesby 20 per cent. Menayev, an engineer at theTaldinski Severny open pit mine on the outskirt of Prokopyevsk.Strike committee member Vyacheslav G. Akulov stressed that theminers had agreed to interrupt the strike, not to end it.He said the miner would hold the government to it word: Ifthe government doesn't keep it promise, we will go back onstrike.The 26-member strike committee met today with a half-dozenrepresentatives to the national parliament and called for municipalelections to be advanced from the spring to the first half ofNovember.The last local election in Kuznetsk were held two year ago,before Gorbachev's reform made election more democratic byoffering multiple candidates.The strike wave began 11 day ago in Kuznetsk, the country'ssecond-largest coal field.Tass said late Thursday that strike had ended at six mine inthe Donetsk region but that most mine in the area remained onstrike.Miners at three shaft in Chervonograd, near the Polish border,joined the walkout Thursday night, said Anatoly M. Dotsenko, aspokesman for the Ukrainian Helsinki Watch Group.The coal industry employ more than 1 million workers.Tass today quoted Coal Minister Mikhail I. Shchadov a sayingthe government agreed to make all Soviet coal operationseconomically and legally independent.He said authority had agreed to additional payment for nightand evening shift and to give worker Sundays off.Beginning Aug. 1, mine and other industry in the coalmining complex will gain the right to sell for negotiated pricesin the USSR and abroad product which they make over and above thestate plan, Tass quoted the agreement a stipulating.It said local manager will be able to raise coal price toreflect actual production costs.Gorbachev is trying to end the longtime Soviet practice ofsetting price for good that bear no relation to their free-marketvalue and encourage and end to central control of the economy.Akulov said that beginning Jan. 1, the Kuznetzk coal basin willbecome economically autonomous.The Coal Mining Ministry will continue to run the mine, butthe miner will have a much greater say setting production levelsand allocating the profit, he said.Our politics have gotten freer under perestroika, Akulovsaid of Gorbachev's economic reform program. Romanians appear solidly opposed tothe strike, angered by the miners' demand for an average wage of theequivalent of Dollars 290 a month. Most worker earn le than Dollars 80.Workers in the same trade union confederation a the miner have ignoredappeals by their leader to strike in solidarity.The Ministry of Industry argues that the 6m tonne of pit coal produced eachyear in the Jiu Valley's 13 mine is not a vital source of energy. Theregion's coal supply two nearby power station but these plant, whichtogether account for only 4 per cent of the country's electricity capacity,could also be run using lignite and gas.The ministry further argues that the miner are in danger of pricing theircoal out of the market. According to the ministry, if the miners' paydemands were met, the cost of their coal would double. The rank and file havecome out because they want more money to compensate for the difficultconditions in which they live and work.They are also following the call of their charismatic leader, Mr MironCosma, the man who led them on protest to Bucharest and secured theirearlier wage increases.Mr Cosma's motive for calling the strike - for which, surprisingly, he hasthe support of RAH, the state-owned coal mining company - are le obvious.The ministry of industry and finance are conducting investigation intocharges of fraud and embezzlement by Mr Cosma and several senior RAH companyofficials. In recent month, Mr Cosma hasclaimed he ha evidence that senior government official, includingPresident Ion Iliescu, called miner to Bucharest a part of plan toconsolidate their own power.Mr Cosma appears increasingly willing to talk if his demand are not met. column5: Coal miners strike in major coal regions around the world.
column6: Major strikes, mostly by coal miners seeking higher wages, seriously disrupted industries throughout the world from 1987 to 1994 in South Africa, Poland, Romania, the Ukraine, Siberia and Central Asia in the Soviet Union.  In the United States, coal miners' strikes occurred in Virginia and West Virginia, Pennsylvania, Indiana and Kentucky.
column7: Instances of industrial unrest for wage increases 1987-1994:August 1987:  South African black gold and coal miners strike; August 1988: Jastrzebie, Poland coal miners and port workers strike; June 1989: Virginia, West Virginia, Pennsylvania, Indiana and Kentucky coal miners walkout; July 1989 and November 1989: strikes by coal miners and factory workers throughout Ukraine, Siberia and Central Asia; June 1991: coal miners strike in Kazakhstan and the Ukraine spread to all major Soviet Union coal regions; July 1992: Polish copper-producing combine strikes in sympathy with coal miners; August 1993: Coal miners strike in Romania's Jui Valley; June 1994: coal miners strike in Donetsk Region, Ukraine.
column8: Worldwide industrial strikes for wage increases 1987-1994:August 4, 1987:  200,000 South African black gold and coals miners may begin a strike.August 17-18, 1988:  Coalmine workers in Jastrzebie, southwest of Warsaw, went on strike to demand legalization of Solidarity and higher wages.  Szczecin port workers and Morcinek mine workers declared sympathy strikes.June 16, 1989:  Pennsylvania, Indiana and Kentucky coal miners walked out in sympathy for miners in Virginia and West Virginia.July 19-21, 1989:  Strikes in the Soviet Union by coal miners and factory workers have shut down over 200 mines in the country's top coal-producing regions from the Ukraine through Siberia and Central Asia.November 2, 1989:  Miners in the Northern Vorkuta region expanded their strike and blocked coal shipments.June 6, 1991:  A one-day coal miners' strike in Kazakhstan and the Ukraine spread to all major coal regions.July 21, 1992:  A copper-producing combine in Lublin, Poland went on strike as coal-mining unions staged stoppages in a third of the country's pits.August 9, 1993:  Coal miners in Romania's Jui Valley went on strike again.June 29, 1994:  Miners at six coal production associations and pits in the Donetsk Region of the Ukraine went on strike.
column9: Minors throughout the world use strikes for political and economic ends.
column10: Miners throughout the world have used strikes not only to achieve economic gains, but also to gain greater control over their industries and to achieve political ends.  In addition to higher wages, miners in the Soviet Union struck for more local control of their industry and in Poland miners struck for the legalization of Solidarity.
column11: Miners throughout the world have used strikes not only to achieve economic gains, but also to gain greater control over their industries and to achieve political ends.  Miners in Poland, Romania and in every region of the Soviet Union have struck for higher wages and better living conditions and also and for more local control. In Poland, miners struck for legalization of Solidarity.  In South Africa miners struck for better wages and working conditions and in the U.S. miners walked of f the job in sympathy for fellow miners in a bitter dispute with a coal company.
column12: Miners throughout the world have used strikes not only to achieve economic gains, but to gain greater control over their industries and to achieve political ends.  Miners in Poland struck not only for higher wages, but also for the legalization of Solidarity and the reinstatement of workers fired for union activity.  They also wanted a clear restructuring strategy for their industry.  Coal miners throughout the Soviet Union struck for more local control of their industries as well as better living and working conditions.  The labor unrest was the Soviet Union's worst in 60 years.  Until Gorbachev rose to power in 1985, strikes were not tolerated.  Miners in Kazakhstan and the Ukraine demanded real sovereignty for the 15 Soviet republics as well as a law to allow private ownership of industry and land.  Coal miners in Romania, spearheaded violent anti-reform rampages and well as demand for increased wages.In South Africa coal and gold miners were to begin a strike for higher wages and working conditions.  Coal and gold account for more than half of South Africa's foreign currency earnings.In the United States coal miners in four states walked off the job in sympathy for miners in a bitter dispute with Pittston Coal Group.

column5: Storm causes death and injuries from Midwest throughout East coast.
column6: A powerful storm swept across the Midwest and into the Eastern states leaving 27 dead, hundreds injured, and thousands homeless. A tornado laid waste to Huntsville, AL, killing fourteen. Four people were killed in Palmetto, Georgia, and seven children died in a school in Newburgh, NY when a roof collapsed.
column7: A powerful storm brought tornadoes, high winds, and thunderstorms across the Midwest, Mississippi Valley, Southeast and Northeast on Wednesday and Thursday. Twenty-seven people were killed, more than 500 injured, and thousands left homeless. The worst hit was Huntsville, AL when a tornado laid waste a wide swath through the city causing the death of at least fourteen people and over 400 injuries. Another tornado killed four people in Palmetto, GeorgiaIn Newburgh, NY, strong winds caused a school roof to collapse killing seven children and injuring eighteen. The storm caused one death in New Jersey and another in New York City.
column8: A powerful storm system brought tornadoes, high winds, thunderstorms Wednesday and Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi Valley, Southeast, and Northeast. Reportedly, 27 people were killed, more than 500 injured, and thousands left homelessThe worst hit was Huntsville, AL when a tornado with winds up to 250 mph laid waste a wide swath through the city and caused the death of at least fourteen people and injuries to over 400. Many were trapped for a while in vehicles, apartment complexes and shopping areas. The rubble was 10-14 feet deep and rescuers were hampered by darkness and plunging temperatures. State officials estimated the damage in excess of $100 million. Four people were killed by a tornado in Georgia.Moving north Thursday, the storm caused heavy damage in Illinois, Pennsylvania, Washington, DC, Maryland, Virginia, West Virginia, Delaware, New Jersey and New York. In Newburgh, NY, a tree crashed through a school roof killing at least seven children and injuring eighteen. One person died in New Jersey and another in New York City. Thunderstorms dropped large hailstones in Indiana and Tennessee. Kentucky and Louisiana were damaged by 65 mph winds. Snow was falling west of a cold front moving east from the Rockies.
column9: Violent storms spawned by cold front ravage the East, 27 dead.
column10: A powerful cold front, spawning tornados, violent thunderstorms and heavy rainfall, moved through the eastern half of the United States on November 15 and 16.  Twenty-six were killed with injuries or damage reported in 13 states.  Huntsville, Alabama was hit hardest, when a tornado caused $100 million in damage.
column11: A powerful cold front moved through the eastern half of the United States on November 15 and 16, spawning tornados, violent thunderstorms, and heavy rainfall.  Thirteen states reported deaths, injuries, or damage.  Hardest hit was Huntsville, Alabama, where a tornado leveled a shopping district, apartment development, and elementary school.  Seventeen were killed, 463 injured, and 1000 left homeless.  Damages were estimated at $100 million.  President Bush declared Huntsville a disaster area.  Marilyn Quayle and Alabama's governor and senators toured the area on November 18.  This storm front killed nine others, including seven school children in Newburgh, New York.
column12: A powerful cold front moved through the eastern half of the United States on November 15 and 16, carving a deadly path of destruction.  The abnormally warm air preceding the front spawned tornados, violent thunderstorms, and heavy rainfall.  Tornados struck in at least seven states.Hardest hit was Huntsville, Alabama, where a tornado roared down a major street near rush hour, leveling a shopping district, apartment development, and elementary school.  Seventeen were killed, 463 injured, and 1000 left homeless.  Witnesses recall a huge roar, water and winds, screaming, hiding, and helping others.  Roads were blocked and power and telephone lines were cut.  Rescuers, including National Guard troops, worked all night sifting through the rubble.  Damages were estimated at $100 million, with about $1 million needed to provide emergency clothing and temporary housing.  President Bush declared Huntsville a disaster area.  Marilyn Quayle, wife of the Vice President, toured the area with Alabama's governor and senators on November 18. Near Newburgh, New York high winds caused an elementary school cafeteria to cave in on November 16.  Seven children were killed and 18 injured.  A truck driver also was killed in New Jersey and a woman died in Illinois.  Injuries occurred in five other states.
