After the 45-minute service, the family attended aprivate reception with Moosally.The Navy said 45 victims' family attended the service.At a press briefing following the reception, Moosally praisedthe hundred of men who fought the fire for their courage.God gave birth to 500 hero, the captain said. Fire on aship is the most terrifying fear . you have nowhere to run.Our extensive training paid off, he said. Besides thefirefighting crew, we had cook, engineer, deck seaman, Marinesall fighting to save the ship.Moosally said the blast occurred just a he wa turning to ViceAdm. Jerome Johnson, commander of the 2nd Fleet, to tell him towatch the No. 2 turret because it contained his best crew.This wa my best turret, Moosally said. He said turret chiefZiegler wa the most meticulous of men. He wa my No. 1 chief ofthe 84 chief aboard.Nobody in that turret did anything unless they werequalified, Moosally said.Moosally refused to give a definite answer to reporters'questions about whether the damaged turret could be repaired,saying the battleship could operate without it if necessary.All but 11 men in the huge gun turret died almost instantly lastWednesday when the explosion ripped through it. At the time, theIowa wa conducting open sea gun exercise off Puerto Rico.The Navy said the investigation into the blast is continuing.Navy official have refused to speculate on the cause of theexplosionCmdr. John P. Morse, the Iowa's weapon officer, said the gunswere thoroughly inspected the morning of the accident, and Moosallysaid he had no hesitation about the guns' safety.I'll be in the turret for the first shot to go off, thecaptain said.One of the survivor, Gunner's Mate 3rd Class Kendall L. Truitt21, of Tampa, Fla., said that at first the men down in the powdermagazine in the lowest level of the turret didn't know anything waswrong.We were waiting for the gun to fire, and we weren't sure, hesaid. When the men discovered that no one wa answering theinterior turret communication link, Truitt ordered the powderreturned to the magazine and the compartment evacuated.The sailor found smoke everywhere a they climbed throughhatches and up ladder outside the turret toward the sea deck,Truitt recalled.My first thought wa that I'd better get to a lifeboatstation, because if the fire got to the magazine thing would bebad, he said.Navy investigator will be looking at allpossibilities of human or mechanical error in their effort todetermine what caused the explosion that killed 47 aboard thebattleship USS Iowa, official say.It could take month before the probe is completed and theresults released publicly, Navy spokesman Lt. Cmdr. Alan Dooleysaid Sunday.A seven-member team of investigator boarded the battleship aday after the explosion flashed through the Iowa's No. 2 gun turreton Wednesday.They're looking at any evidence of human error or mechanicalerror, or anything technical, said Lt. Janet Mescus, aspokeswoman at the Navy's information center at Norfolk, Va., theship's home port. The Iowa returned to Norfolk on Sunday.They're moving a quickly a they can, Lt. Mescus said, butadded, They want to be thorough and that take time.Dooley said the investigation would be fairly complexbecause there were no witness. There were 11 survivor inside theturret, all on the lowest deck loading powder from the ship'smagazines, the Navy said.Dooley said no information would be released until the probe iscompleted, and the Navy ha refused to speculate on the cause ofthe explosion, which damaged only the inside of the turret.But The New York Times reported Sunday that Navy team whoentered the turret immediately after the blast found the No. 2gun's breech open and undamaged, with the practice projectile thatthe gun wa to have fired still there.The Times cited unidentified source a saying this indicatedthe explosion occurred while the bag containing 550 pound ofpropellant powder were still being loaded into the gun.Navy gunnery officer believe the explosion occurred when thebags were being transferred from a powder hoist to the gun, thenewspaper said. They said flame and hot gas from the blast wentdown the hoist to the lowest deck; if the transfer of powder to theguns had been complete, the hoist would have been sealed off.The Navy on Sunday released an amateur videotape of theexplosion, which wa made by an officer on the bridge of the Iowawho wanted to record the firing of the guns.The investigation team is headed by Rear Adm. Richard D.Milligan, former commanding officer of the battleship USS NewJersey, and it also includes expert on gunnery and weapons.The 16-inch gun on the USS Iowa, which can loba shell the weight of a Volkswagen 23 mile, have an outdateddesign that is unfit in the nuclear missile age, critic say.They're old-fashioned and inherently dangerous. They all oughtto be eliminated, retired Rear Adm. Eugene LaRocque of the Centerfor Defense Information said Thursday. I don't know what more ittakes to get people to recognize this ancient technology is nolonger appropriate on warships.But the Navy defended the 16-inch gun, the mightiest in use onany ocean, after an explosion killed 47 sailor Wednesday aboardthe battleship Iowa while a turret crew loaded gunpowder for targetpractice.This gun . remains the finest naval gun in the world. It wasthe pinnacle of gun design art, and it is still a front-linesystem, said Capt. Larry Seaquist, commander of the Iowa untillast May.The main criticism is that the big gun requires gunpowder packedin silk bag to fire 16-inch-diameter shell from it 62-foot-longbarrel. It work like the breech-loaded gun that roared during theCivil War: A shell is placed into a barrel and then charged withgunpowder in a separate package.In the Iowa's case, 660 pound of powder six 110-pound bag is needed to fire a projectile weighing up to 2,700 pound at aspeed of 2,500 foot per second. An electric spark ignites thepowder.The extremely flammable silk is supposed to burn away during theburst, but some red-hot debris may remain or explosive gas canbuild up in the barrel. Air pressurized to 3,000 pound per squareinch can be blown into the breech to clear away debris to guardagainst a blowback, which happens when powder ignites beforethe breech is closed.In newer gun, powder is packed in metal container. Missiles,the backbone of the modern Navy's attack capability, haveintegrated propellantsCapt. James Bush of the Center for Defense Information, aprivate think tank often critical of Pentagon policy, said the Iowaexplosion could have been caused by smoldering debris, a blowbackor a mishap in the handling of powder.It wasn't unexpected. It wasn't a surprise. This is dangeroustechnology. It's archaic, Bush said. These are the only gun inthe Navy that still used bagged powder.The Navy said Thursday that none of the gun in the Iowa turrethad been fired before the explosion took place.The Navy also on Thursday placed a moratorium on firing the bigguns, found only on the Iowa and it three sister battleship, theNew Jersey, the Wisconsin and the Missouri.In a larger sense, critic say the battleship themselves, oncethe mainstay of gunboat diplomacy, have outlived their purpose.Despite 16-inch-thick armor plating, the battlewagon arevulnerable to submarine and missile attack. The 20-mile range ofthe 16-inch gun is almost worthless in an era when missile can befired at much greater distances.We can do almost anything with a missile and do it better,Bush said.Battleships reached their heyday in World War I and wereintended to fight other ships.The Iowa, first launched in 1942, wa the first of an entireclass of US. battlewagon built to conquer Japan.It supported Marine amphibious landing and shelled shoretargets, but the aircraft carrier emerged a the Navy's top weaponbecause naval battle were waged without ship ever seeing eachother. The Iowa also fought off Korea.The Iowa and three sister warship were ordered out of mothballsin the Reagan administration's military buildup six year ago. Theywere upgraded with Tomahawk cruise missile, 20mm gun and Harpoonmissiles.One of the battleship, the New Jersey, bombarded Syrian andDruze position in Lebanon a part the US. peacekeeping role in1983. But the 16-inch gun often missed their target, which theNavy blamed on unreliable powder from World War II.There wa no military need to return these ship to activeduty, said the CDI's LaRocque. Their only military utility isto bombard Third World country, and the era of gunboat diplomacyis over.The scarred battleship USS Iowa made asomber return Sunday to it home port, where about 3,000 familymembers and friend of the crew welcomed loved one who escaped anexplosion that killed 47 sailors.Sailors in white with black arm band lined the rail a thehuge vessel docked at the Norfolk Naval Base's Pier 5 at 5:41 p.m.,just one minute later than Navy official had estimated. Twentyminutes later, family started filing aboard the ship, exchangingtearful embrace with the returning sailors.They wanted to get here on schedule and were anxious to gethome, said Capt. Steven Karalekas.The explosion Wednesday flashed through the Iowa's No. 2 gunturret, which extends six deck down into the ship. There were 11survivors inside the turret, all on the lowest deck loading powderfrom the ship's magazine, the Navy said.Two of the surviving crewman of No. 2 turret stood on top of thefire-blackened turret a the ship pulled into the pier, with fullcrews on the ship's two other turret, the Navy said.The No. 2 turret wa in the same position a when the explosionoccurred, facing right with the left and right gun elevated. Thecenter gun, where the blast occurred, wa depressed.When the 887-foot vessel first appeared there were scatteredcheers by those on the dock, but all remained silent a the shippulled into the pier. The somber mood wa heightened by the lack ofbands, and few wave were exchanged a the ship dockedAdm. Powell Carter, commander in chief of the Atlantic Fleet,was on the dock to greet the vessel. As it docked, three Marinesraised a flag to half-mast at the stern of the ship.The Navy kept the news medium about 300 yard from the families,and reporter were not allowed to talk with the family or thecrewmen.The violence and power of the turret explosion wa shown in anamateur videotape released by the Navy on Sunday. The tape wa madeby an officer on the bridge of the Iowa who wanted to record thefiring of the big guns.The detonation, which appears to blast away the gasket-likerubber bloomer that seal the turret's gun slit, is followedby a jet of intense fire and thick smoke from the front and base ofthe gunhouse.The videotape cut immediately to damage control firefightersspraying heavy stream of water onto the turret.Throughout the Norfolk area, church dedicated prayer Sundaymorning to the family of Iowa crewmen.We have lost 47 of our number in a tragic way, said Cmdr.John L. Fitzgerald, a chaplain, in a service at the Norfolk NavalAir Station. Our faith help u to handle what science cannotanswer, the mystery of death.A red rose, a yellow ribbon with the number 47 on it and a bookcontaining the name of the dead were taken to the altar.Fitzgerald said the Iowa tragedy and that of a recently lostSoviet submarine put political difference aside and unite thehuman family a one.On Monday morning, President Bush will lead a memorial servicein a base hangar that can accommodate 3,000 people.The family of the victim were invited, but Navy officialssaid they did not know how many would attend. None of the victimslisted the Norfolk area a their hometown.The explosion occurred during exercise off Puerto Rico. ThePentagon said it happened before the middle 16-inch gun of thethree-gun turret had been fired. The gun, the largest on any shipat sea, use six 110-pound bag of black powder to fire a2,700-pound projectile up to 23 miles.The Navy ha refused to speculate on t
column5: Bush Attends Memorial for 47 Killed in USS Iowa Explosion
column6: On Monday President Bush and the USS Iowa commander attended a memorial at Norfolk Naval Air Station for 47 sailors that were killed in an explosion of the battleship's No. 2 gun turret last Wednesday. The Iowa was conducting firing exercises near Puerto Rico at the time. The Navy is investigating.
column7: On Monday President Bush and the USS Iowa commander attended a memorial at Norfolk Naval Air Station for 47 sailors that were killed in an explosion of the battleship's No. 2 gun turret last Wednesday.The Iowa, a WW II battleship returned to duty in 1982, was conducting firing exercises near Puerto Rico at the time. The Defense Department said the blast possibly originated with a gunpowder bag used to fire the one-ton shells. Eleven people inside the turret, all on the lowest deck loading powder, survived. The Navy is investigating the accident. Firings of the 16-inch guns have been suspended.
column8: Relatives of the 47 victims killed in the explosion aboard the Iowalast Wednesday were among the 6000 people who attended a memorial atNorfolk Naval Air Station on Monday. President Bush and Iowa commanderCapt. Moosally attended the service.The USS Iowa, a WW II battleship returned to duty in 1982, wasconducting firing exercises northeast of Puerto Rico when the blastoccurred in the No. 2 gun turret. The Defense Department said itpossibly originated from a 110-pound gunpowder bag used to fire shellsweighing over a ton a distance of 23 miles. Eleven people inside theturret, all on the lowest deck loading powder, survived the Navysaid. The gun had not been fired.  Two of the 11 survivors stood atopthe fire-blackened turret when the Iowa docked at Norfolk Naval BaseSunday.The Navy released a videotape of the explosion made by an officer ofthe Iowa who was recording the firing of the big guns, but it won'tspeculate on the cause of the tragedy.The Navy is investigating the causes of the accident and the SenateArmed Services Committee will hold hearings.The Pentagon ordered a moratorium on firings of the 16-inchguns.
column9: Explosion in WWII-era battleship kills 47 during training exercise
column10: An explosion in a battleship Iowa gun turret on April 19, 1989 during a training exercise killed 47. Investigators say the explosion occurred while gunpowder was in transit. In Norfolk, thousands welcomed the Iowa home and President Bush spoke at a memorial service. Critics say the WWII-era 16-inch guns are outdated and dangerous.
column11: An explosion in the battleship Iowa's No.2 turret on Wednesday, April 19, 1989, during a training exercise NE of Puerto Rico, killed 47. Naval investigators concluded the explosion occurred while gunpowder was in transit from a powder hoist. Thousands welcomed the Iowa home to Norfolk on Sunday, with sailors with black arm bands lining the ship's rails and surviving guncrew members standing atop the blackened No.2 turret. On Monday, President Bush spoke to mourners at a Norfolk memorial service. A moratorium was placed on firing the WWII-era 16-inch guns, which are criticized as outdated and dangerous. The Senate Armed Services Committee will hold hearings on the explosion.
column12: An explosion in the battleship Iowa's No.2 turret on Wednesday, April 19, 1989, during a training exercise NE of Puerto Rico, killed 47. Naval investigators concluded the explosion occurred while gunpowder was in transit from a powder hoist. Crew in upper turret chambers died instantly in the explosion and fire while those at lower levels suffocated as the blast sucked out oxygen. Eleven escaped from powder magazines at the turret's base. On Sunday, 3000 family and friends welcomed the Iowa home to Norfolk. Sailors with black arm bands lined the Iowa's rails and two surviving guncrew members stood on the blackened No.2 turret. On Monday, President Bush spoke to 8000 mourners at a memorial service and Iowa commander Capt. Fred Moosally praised the victims. A moratorium was placed on firing the 16-inch guns, which are criticized as outdated and dangerous, using gunpowder packed in silk bags that are rammed into a gun after the shell and ignited by electric spark. Newer guns' powder is packed in metal containers. Missiles have integrated propellants. The four WWII-era battleships came out of mothballs in 1982. Critics say they have outlived their purpose but the Navy disagrees and is keeping them in service. The Senate Armed Services Committee will hold hearings on the explosion.

column3: Here is a chronology of Hurricane Hugo's destructive path acrossthe Caribbean into South Carolina:Residents took forecaster at their wordwhen they warned of Hurricane Hugo's fury, and the low number ofdeaths from the powerful storm can be credited to this healthyrespect, authority said.The storm, which caused billion in damage, claimed 17 life inSouth Carolina, and only two were in the Charleston area, whichbore the brunt of Hugo's 135 mph winds.We just feel very thankful about that, said Mayor Joseph P.Riley Jr. Several thousand of people who were in the sheltersand the ten of thousand of people who evacuated inland werepotential victim of injury and death.Riley and other official credited resident with monitoring thehurricane a it spun toward Charleston, and heeding evacuationwarnings.The last big storm to hit South Carolina wa Hurricane David in1979, which hit the coast after pounding southern Florida.Since then several big storm have threatened but veered away,and official were worried that Charlestonians wouldn't heed Hugo'swarnings.We've had so many close call, said Gary Garnet, ameteorologist with the National Weather Service.But this storm wa very, very strong, he said. This timethey realized it.Glen Ellis, a Red Cross official, estimated that 18,000residents in Charleston and the three surrounding county headedfor shelters.Tens of thousand more got into their car and headed upInterstate 26 toward Columbia.Mayor John Bourne of North Charleston, where there apparentlywere no storm-related death, credited people for heeding thewarnings.It wa bad, but it could have been a lot worse, he said.You've just got to say nice thing about the people.Meanwhile, Garnet had some good news for storm-wearyCharlestonians: late Saturday the tropic were quiet with no otherstorms brewing.There's nothing to worry about out there, he said.This historic city ha survived theravages of earthquake, battle and storm in it storied300-year-history, but it faced perhaps it greatest test of all inHurricane Hugo.The storm, packing wind of up to 135 mph, raged into CharlestonThursday night.This is a dangerous, killer hurricane, the like of which fewpeople who have lived all their life in Charleston haveexperienced, warned Mayor Joseph P. Riley Jr.Hugo wa the first major hurricane to strike Charleston sinceHurricane Gracie came ashore 70 mile to the south in 1959.The seaside community ha suffered through many disaster, bothnatural and man-made.The worst in recent decade wa in 1938 when a tornado torethrough the city, killing 32 people, injuring hundred and causingan estimated $2 million in property damage.Charleston, a city of pastel-colored antebellum structure liningquaint street and alleyway, is where the Civil War began in 1861.The city ha survived the shot and shell of two war and anynumber of smaller hurricane, politely referred to by Charlestoniansof refinement a September gales.But the worst natural disaster to beset the city occurred on thehot night of Aug. 31, 1886, when the ground rumbled in what somefolks thought wa a prelude to Judgement Day.The great Charleston earthquake wa felt a far away a Chicagoand New York City.Measuring 7.7 on the Richter scale of ground motion, theearthquake claimed an estimated 110 life, destroyed 102 buildingsand tossed most of the city's 14,000 chimney into the streets.In recent year, the city ha attracted million of visitorsannually who tour it historic building and visit it nearby finesand beaches.Charleston ha received international acclaim a home to SpoletoFestival U.S.A., founded by composer Gian Carlo Menotti. Organizerslike to refer to Spoleto a the world's most comprehensive artsfestival.Supercomputers, satellite and the expertise ofseveral hurricane forecaster predicted the destructive pathHurricane Hugo would follow, giving people plenty of time to fleethe South Carolina coast.But hurricane tracking remains an uncertain science.Forecasters at the National Hurricane Center used computer modelsto track Hugo's path into Charleston, S.C.All the world's knowledge about meteorological condition andforecasting change in those condition is embodied in thosemodels, said Thomas Pyke, head of National Oceanic and AtmosphericAdministration's satellite service.Pinpointing the exact point of Hugo's landfall wa difficult, butforecasters said Friday that the landfall wa predicted in time forevacuation.Overall, I think the tracking model gave u a very good ideawhere Hugo would be so official in South Carolina could act in atimely manner, said research meteorologist Colin McAdie.The real forecasting problem with Hugo wa predicting theintensity of the storm, which wa upgraded to a Category 4 hurricanejust hour before it slammed into Charleston.It is very difficult to predict change in intensity because wedon't have very reliable computer model for that, McAdie said.We really need to improve on our forecasting ability of strength.The hurricane specialist were surprised by the last-minuteincrease in wind speed, which wa reported to them by Air Forcereconnaissance.Hurricane specialist Gil Clark, who ha tracked hurricane for 35years, said that a couple of decade ago, the only forecasting toolswere report from aircraft or ships.We had no radar or satellite then, so needle to say ourforecasts were le accurate, Clark said.In the late 1960s, the weather service began using satellite toobtain a global weather picture. Information from the satellite isused to improve the accuracy of the large-scale model thattelevision viewer see every night.Using the information from the satellite, supercomputer at theNational Meteorological Center in Suitland, Md., send information tothe hurricane center where a tracking model constantly change toaccount for current weather condition and the position of thehurricane.To determine the track of the storm, the forecaster analyzesupercomputer prediction, satellite data, the history of similarstorms and the current path of the hurricane.Then they make an educated guess about the landfall.Meteorology professor Kerry A. Emmanuel of the MassachussettsInstitute of Technology criticizes the current forecasting system.Congress and the American people are suffering from thecollective delusion that our data problem have been solved bysatellites and that just isn't true, Emmanuel said.Satellites can give a pretty picture, he said, but not enoughinformation about the wind and temperature that affect ahurricane's path.Most of the information actually used to predict hurricanescomes from flying airplane into the hurricane, and they do a verygood job, Emmanuel said.Forecasters say the accuracy of satellite picture is improvingevery year so long-range forecasting should become more precise.We have to remember that those model used are only guidanceproducts, Pyke said, and that it's ultimately the job of theforecaster to predict the storm's path.Hurricane Hugo struck South Carolina withrenewed fury Thursday after thousand of coastal resident insoutheastern state grabbed what they could carry and fled inland onjammed highways.This is a disaster staring u right in the eye, Mayor JosephP. Riley Jr. said from his City Hall command post in Charleston,where the hurricane downed power line, snapped tree and causedutility transformer to explode.All we can do now is pray and hope all the precaution we havetaken have been sufficient, Riley said a Hugo's eye bore in onthe city. I just hope and pray we can get through this without anyloss of life.By midnight, 119 mph wind were reported in Charleston. The roofcracked at City Hall, a 188-year-old brick building that haswithstood several hurricane, and torrent of water poured into thepaneled council chamber. Phone and electric service to the commandpost wa knocked out.Hurricane-force wind first hit the coast by 9:15 pm. EDT, andabout three hour later the eye of the storm passed over the Isle ofPalms just east of Charleston, said Bob Sheets, director of theNational Hurricane Center in Coral Gables, Fla.The eye wa about 10 mile across and top wind were still at 135mph.Hugo wa expected to turn gradually to the north, causing severeflooding a it moved up the East Coast. The storm posed a 19 percentchance of hitting New York City and a 16 percent chance of hittingBoston before Sunday night, the hurricane center said.As Hugo neared the coast, road from Hilton Head to Myrtle Beach,200 mile north, were nearly empty, a were the boarded-up resorttowns themselves. Power line and tree were downed in some spotsand water flooded road. Stop light and neon light were knockedout in Myrtle Beach.One eyewitness said `It's like a light show,' said AmyGarrison, a reporter at WKZQ AM-FM in Myrtle Beach.In Charleston, the hurricane littered street with tin roofs,palmetto frond and chunk of bark. Businesses were closed andclasses at public school and university canceled. Riley orderedresidents of one-story home to evacuate.Hospitals stockpiled supply, discharging any patient wellenough to go and moving others to hospital inland to make room foremergency patient, official said.About 12,000 people had checked into 83 shelter across the stateas of Thursday evening, and more were expected, said Bennish Brown,a spokesman for the Emergency Operations Center in Columbia, 220miles northwest of here.We tried to close the door but people are sneaking in sidedoors, said Elaine Skelton, a registered nurse working at theConway High School shelter near Myrtle Beach. We tried to postguards at the door, but people were still coming in.American Red Cross relief effort were buckling under the numberof evacuee, said Brian Ruberry, a spokesman in Savannah, Ga., whoappealed for help.Right now the Red Cross is sheltering ten of thousand ofpeople all along the Eastern seaboard. This of course is at the sametime that we're sheltering 25,000 people on Puerto Rico and theother Caribbean islands.We're beginning to feel the squeeze. Our resource are verytight. Right now Hugo is shaping up to be one of our biggest reliefoperations of the decade.At midnight, the center of Hugo wa near latitude 32.7 degreesnorth and longitude 79.9 degree west, forecaster said. Thehurricane's speed had picked up to 22 mph from 20 mph earlier.Near it center, Hugo's muscle reached wind of 135 mph, up from125 mph earlier in the day and 105 mph the day before. North andSouth Carolina can expect tornado linked to Hugo for the next twodays, according to the hurricane center.The coastal area could expect hurricane force wind for 10 to 12hours once the eye come ashore, official said. A hurricane warningwas in effect between Fernandina Beach, Fla., and Oregon Inlet, N.C.By late afternoon, Hugo wa upgraded to a category 4 hurricane onthe Saffir-Simpson scale of strength, the second mightiest category,which indicated it could cause extreme damage.It strengthened more than we thought it would, Sheets said,adding that Hugo would cause severe flooding a it moved up theAppalachians.The timing of the landfall wa critical because of the storm'stidal surge, a dome of water 10 to 15 foot high that would feed anormal 5-foot high tide that peak after 2 a.m.On top of that will be wave, Sheets said earlier, and inmany place on barrier island the building will be swept cleanoff.Amid the uproar of live coverage by themajor network and score of other medium organization, NationalHurricane Center forecaster went about their business of monitoringHurricane Hugo.The whole system look chaotic, but it work, said BobSheets, the center's director.On one side of a large room dominated by a U-shaped bank ofmonitoring equipment were the forecaster, making meticulouscalculations about where the deadly hurricane will strike andgetting emergency operation going in those areas.On the other side were the medium a pack of reporter, cameraoperators and technician, jockeying for second of Sheets' time andtidbits of his expertise.In the center wa Sheets himself. Surrounded by camera, wiresand two dozen journalist with pad and telephone, the ubiquitousred-headed meteorologist ha appeared on television all week next toa large satellite monitor showing colorful image of Hurricane Hugo.During prime news time, competing technician and cameraman shoutand make rude hand gesture for people to get out of their shot ofSheets.At his back, casually dressed forecaster who have been working12-hour day tracked the storm via computer and satellites.We obviously don't like this and could probably do a betterjob, but everyone know now because of the medium, said hurricanespecialist Max Mayfield. In the Caribbean, we were not so certainthe word got out. But we know the Carolinas have been evacuated.When a hurricane warning go into effect, It's a $50 millionstatement, said meteorologist Joel Cline, referring to the cost ofemergency preparation and evacuation plan that must be implementedwhen the warning is posted.If we weren't here, then you wouldn't know that a storm wa outthere, he said. Before the hurricane warning system wasestablished, a storm of Hugo's power would have cost thousand oflives. But early today, after day of warning and proper evacuationprocedures, there were no immediate report of death despitewidespread damage in Charleston and other coastal area of SouthCarolina.I like to think that we make a difference a far a human livesare concerned, Cline said.After Hugo's landfall, Sheets and the other forecaster began towind down from the hectic pace they had maintained for the lastseveral day. But, he warned, the hurricane center still isfollowing three other weather system that have moved into theAtlantic between the United States and Africa, and another storm inthe Pacific.I hate to say we're breathing a sigh of relief because peopleare getting clobbered to death, meteorologist Mark Zimmer said asthe storm pounded Charleston, SC. But we've done all we can.Damage from Hurricane Hugo, which stormed through the Carolinas and the Caribbean last week, will reduce third-quarter earnings for several insurer. New York-based American International Group Inc. expects net loss related to Hugo to reduce pretax earnings between $35 million and $45 million. Analysts said AIG ha told them that it must cover the first $35 million of loss and that it reinsurance agreement will cover the bulk of the remaining damage. AIG insured property in Puerto Rico, the eastern Caribbean Islands and the coastal region of the Carolinas. St. Paul Cos., based in St. Paul, Minn, said the pretax cost of Hugo shouldn't exceed $50 million. That amount take into consideration what St. Paul expects to recover under it reinsurance contract, the company said. Philadelphia-based Cigna Corp. is expected to disclose Hugo's likely impact on it earnings sometime today. Udayan Ghose, an insurance industry analyst at Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York, estimate that Cigna's third-quarter per-share earnings could be reduced by between 50 cent and 65 cent a share on an after-tax basis. That would wipe out 35% to 40% of his $1.40-a-share earnings estimate for the third quarter. State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Co. said it State Fire & Casualty Co. unit estimate claim payment from Hugo will exceed $400 million in South Carolina alone, far surpassing the company's record payout for a single disaster. When damage in North Carolina and Virginia are added, the company said, the payment will exceed $500 million. It said that is more than three time the previous record of $165 million set by Hurricane Alicia, which hit the Houston-Galveston, Texas, area in 1983.The greenhouse effect may breed bigger anddeadlier hurricane in the future, storm up to 50 percent strongerthan Hugo and last year's record-setting Gilbert, somemeteorologists say.Hugo blasted the eastern Caribbean and the Carolinas with 135 mphwinds this past week, killing at least 41 people.Just before Hugo struck the US. coast, it pressure wa measuredat 940 millibar. That made it among the 12 strongest hurricanesthis century to hit the United States, the National HurricaneCenter's Miles Lawrence said today.Gilbert, whose wind reached 180 mph, tore up the Caribbean lastyear, killing 300 and causing $2 billion damage. It wa the mostpowerful hurricane ever recorded.Gilbert seems to be about the upper limit of a hurricane withcurrent ocean temperature, said Kerry Emanuel of the meteorologydepartment at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.But if the sea warm up, say by 3 to 6 degree Fahrenheit, thewind speed might be 25 percent higher which mean the destructiveforce would be more like 50 percent higher, he said.Stephen Schneider, deputy director of the National Center forAtmospheric Research in Denver, said his research suggests thewarming trend is already here.Schneider, an expert on the greenhouse effect and author of a newbook Global Warming, said six of the 10 hottest year in thelast 100 occurred in the 1980s.He project that the 1990s will be even hotter.Hugo demonstrated the effect of warm Atlantic water when itswinds jumped from 105 mph to 135 mph a it passed over the GulfStream before hitting the East Coast, Schneider said.You'll get worse hurricane if the Caribbean is warmer, hesaid. And I think there are better-than-even odds that you willhave stronger hurricanes.Emanuel said if the ocean temperature climb, moderate hurricanesof the future could grow to Gilbert's strength and future Gilbertswill be even stronger.Gilbert wa so strong that Bob Sheets, director of the nationalhurricane center, said forecaster may have to use an intensityscale of 1-6 in the future, instead of the current 1-5, with fivethe highest.The computer model Schneider us show that in a worst-casescenario, over the next 100 year the world's temperature could jumpby 10 degree if carbon dioxide and methane gas which bothcontribute to the greenhouse effect continue to pour into theatmosphere unchecked.It is possible that even though the world a a whole heat up,the Caribbean could somehow remain cooler. But he said that isunlikley.That's not what the model are showing, Schneider said. Andthat's another reason I'd like to slow down global warming.
column5: Record damage by 1989's Hurricane Hugo in Caribbean and Carolinas
column6: In September 1989, Category 4 Hurricane Hugo, with 135mph winds, damaged the eastern Caribbean then hit South Carolina, where coastal residents fled inland or into shelters. 17 Carolinians were killed. Satellites, computers, and reconnaissance planes helped forecasters monitor Hugo's progress. Insurance claims broke records. The greenhouse effect could raise future storms' destructive power by 50%.
column7: Category 4 Hurricane Hugo did extensive damage in the eastern Caribbean on Sep 17, 1989, and on the 21st hit Charleston, South Carolina with 135mph winds. It killed 17 in the state. Coastal residents fled inland or crowded into shelters. Satellites, a computerized tracking model, and Air Force reconnaissance planes helped forecasters at the National Hurricane Center monitor Hugo's progress. Pinpointing landfall and intensity were difficult. Billions in insurance claims made Hugo the most expensive storm to date. Ocean warming caused by the greenhouse effect could increase future storms' destructive power, demonstrated by Hugo jumping from 105 to 135mph winds as it passed over the Gulf Stream.
column8: Hurricane Hugo, starting as a wave off Africa on Sep 11th, 1989, grew to a Category 4 hurricane. It did extensive damage in the eastern Caribbean and on the 21st hit Charleston, South Carolina with 135mph winds. The storm claimed 17 lives in the state. Coastal residents fled inland or crowded into shelters. Supercomputers at the National Meteorological Center in Suitland, Maryland sent satellite information on Hugo's progress to the National Hurricane Center in Coral Gables, Florida. There, forecasters aided by a computerized tracking model and Air Force reconnaissance planes that flew into the storm monitored Hugo's progress. Pinpointing Hugo's landfall and intensity were difficult. State Farm and Nationwide, the two dominant insurers in the Carolinas, expect $600 million in claims from Hurricane Hugo. Overall claims will exceed the record $752.5 million after Hurricane Frederic in 1979. Reinsurers will pick up much of the costs.  The billions paid out this year will reduce insurers' third-quarter earnings and cause insurance prices to rise.  Unchecked carbon dioxide and methane gas emissions could create a greenhouse effect that would warm oceans 3-6 degrees, resulting in hurricanes 50% more destructive than Hugo. Hugo demonstrated the effect of warm water when its winds jumped from 105 to 135mph as it passed over the Gulf Stream.
column9: Hurricane Hugo Could Have Been Deadlier. Stronger Storms Forecast.
column10: On Sept. 21, 1989 Hurricane Hugo hit Charleston, S.C. head-on causing extensive property damage, but hundreds or thousands of lives were saved by hurricane forecasters and emergency workers who facilitated a massive evacuation before the storm hit. Scientists warn that global warning could cause hurricanes much stronger than Hugo in the future.
column11: After killing 20 and leaving about 100,000 homeless in the Caribbean, Hurricane Hugo hit Charleston, S.C. head-on at midnight of Sept. 21, 1989 with winds of 135 mph. Although seventeen were killed in the Carolinas and property damage there exceeded $750 million, hundreds or thousands of lives were saved by advance warning of the storm from the National Hurricane Center and prompt response of officials and the populace. Scientists have warned that if global warning should cause sea temperature to rise 3-6 degrees Fahrenheit, we may well experience future hurricanes with half again the strength of Category 4 Hugo.
column12: September 17-18, 1989 Hurricane Hugo devastated Guadeloupe, Montserrat, Antigua, the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico with winds reaching 150 mph, leaving in its wake 20 killed and about 100,000 homeless. It slowed down on Sept. 19 only to pick up strength again on Sept. 21, hitting Charleston, S.C. head-on at midnight with winds up to 135 mph. Moving inland it lost strength and at 6 A.M. Sept. 22, 1989 was downgraded to a tropical storm. Seventeen were killed in the Carolinas and the overall damage to property there was more than $750 million. As the storm proceeded forecasters at the National Hurricane Center with the help of satellites and supercomputers analyzed available data and made an educated guess about the landfall on the U.S. coast. Charleston and the Carolina coast were alerted and a massive evacuation took place. Advance warning, heeded by local officials and the populace, undoubtedly saved hundreds or thousands of lives. Although hurricane forecasting has come a long way it is still not an exact science. Other hurricane research indicates that storms much stronger than class four Hugo may be in the offing. Scientists predict that if  sea temperature increases by 3-6 degrees Fahrenheit, the destructive force of hurricanes would increase by 50 percent.

column5: President Aquino Survives Controversies and Uprisings; Marcos Unwelcome Dead or Alive
column6: President Aquino, successor to Marcos, has survived two major coup attempts and several mutinies. She has faced political controversies, including opposition to an agrarian reform leader and a split with her Vice President. In 1989 she refused to let Marcos, critically ill in Hawaii, to reenter the country, dead or alive.
column7: With military firepower, President Aquino ended the Oct. 4-6 uprising. She has survived two major coup attempts and several mutinies. Recently, in a reversal of policy, Aquino said she would negotiate with Communist guerillas. Aquino's, political controversies include her opposition to the nomination of agrarian reform leader Secretary-designate Abad, and her Vice President's refusal to condemn an insurrection in 1989.Aquino succeeded Marcos who was accused of stealing billions from the government. In 1989 she refused to let Marcos, critically ill in Hawaii, to reenter the country or to allow him to be buried in the Philippines.
column8: President Corazon Aquino used military firepower to end the military led rebellion on Mindanao. The Oct. 4-6 uprising never spread to other islands. Aquino has survived two major coup attempts and several military mutinies. The current rebellion is the latest of several military mutinies. In August Aquino reversed a long-held policy and said she was willing to negotiate cease-fires with Communist guerillas and former soldiers who have staged coup attempts. In December 1989 a confrontation between pro-coup supporters and Aquino supporters occurred at the Philippine consulate in Los Angeles.Aquino's government has also had its political controversies. Her opposition to the nomination of Secretary-designate Abad raised doubts about her commitment to social reform. In 1989, her Vice President refused to condemn the insurrection that was then unfolding.Aquino rose to power in 1986 after dictator Ferdinand Marcos, accused of stealing billions of government funds, was ousted. June1988 news stories quoted sources saying Aquino would allow Marcos to return to the Philippines to stand trial, but a year later she stated the critically ill Marcos could not return to die, nor could he be buried in the Philippines.Aquino traveled to West German in 1989 seeking economic assistance.
column9: Marcos, military, Communists, agrarian policy, and economy plague Philippine President Aquino.
column10: Philippine President Corazon Aquino was beset with problems from 1988 to 1990.  Ferdinand Marcos plagued the earlier years, even when he became terminally ill.  Economic problems, agrarian reform, overseas Filipinos, Communist insurgents, and the mutinous military tormented her administration.  Coup attempts continued even after she sought reconciliation.
column11: Philippine President Corazon Aquino's administration was beset with problems from June 1988 to October 1990.  Ferdinand Marcos plagued the earlier years.  Swiss bankers required a criminal prosecution to release information on his funds.  His wife, Imelda, and his supporters wanted him to be allowed to die, or at least be buried, in his homeland.  Her agrarian reform policy suffered a number of setbacks.  Economic problems were the focus of her 1989 European trip.  Six military coups and many military mutinies against her government occurred.  Communist insurgents continued their 21-year campaign.  In April 1990, she was willing to negotiate with the insurgents and renegade military.
column12: Philippine President Corazon Aquino's administration was beset with problems from June 1988 to October 1990.  Her predecessor, Ferdinand Marcos was exiled to Hawaii, but had allies in the Philippines and continued to create dissension.  Swiss bankers required a criminal prosecution to release information on the $10 billion he allegedly stole and deposited in Switzerland.  After he became terminally ill, his wife, Imelda, and his supporters wanted him to be allowed to die, or at least be buried, in his homeland.  Aquino refused all requests citing security reasons.  From a landlord family, Aquino's agrarian reform policy suffered a number of setbacks.  Economic problems were the focus of her 1989 European trip, where she touted improvements in the growth rate under her leadership and sought debt relief and foreign investments.  The Philippine military created a continuing problem, leading coups and mutinies.  The December 1989 attempted coup divided Filipinos in Los Angeles and involved Aquino asking for help from United States forces stationed there.  Criticized for past indecisive actions, Aquino quickly ended the October 1990 coup attempt on Mindanao.  Communist insurgents continued their 21-year campaign.  In April 1990, she said she was willing to negotiate with the insurgents and renegade military.

column3: There wa plenty of blame to go around at theend of the lengthy and traumatic McMartin Pre-School molestationtrial, but no one wa willing to accept it.In the nation's longest and costliest trial, Raymond Buckey andhis mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, were acquitted Thursday on 52child molestation charge. The jury deadlocked on 13 other charges.Afterward, the district attorney who filed the case criticizedthe current district attorney. The current district attorney blamedhis predecessor and defense attorney. And some of the parent ofchildren who attended the school blamed everybody.The system is not going to protect child, said JackieMcGauley, a parent who belief her child had been molested butdidn't testify in the case. Life is not fair, said RobertCurry, whose son attended the McMartin school. I tell my childrenall the time . there is no such thing a fair.The district attorney who originally pursued the case said hewould not have done anything differently.Robert Philibosian, now in private practice, angrily dismissedaccusations that he played up the McMartin case in 1984 with thenews medium acting a eager accomplice to boost his publicprofile a he ran for district attorney.I wa a professional prosecutor for 16 year before this casewas brought, he said. To have people who know very little aboutprofessional or prosecutorial ethic, to criticize me personallythat I have some political motive is totally unjustified.Philibosian instead pointed the finger at the man who defeatedhim, current District Attorney Ira Reiner. Philibosian said Reinerhurt prosecutor's chance by dismissing charge against five of theoriginal seven defendant and criticizing the case in a 1986 60Minutes interview.But Reiner, calling his dismissal of charge for lack ofevidence the decision we're proud of, said the trial took solong because of the state's ponderous criminal justice system,delay tactic by defense attorney and a mess left behind byPhilibosian.This is a case I inherited, Reiner said.In interview, many juror said they believed some of thechildren were molested, but the prosecution never established thatthe defendant were responsible.Even if you accept that the child were molested, it didn'tnecessarily mean they were molested at the McMartin Pre-School,said juror Brenda Williams.Jurors in the McMartin Pre-School molestationcase denounced the technique of a child therapy center and apolice department letter that inflamed parent and ignited the case.Seven juror who spoke with reporter in a joint news conferenceafter acquitting Raymond Buckey and his mother, Peggy McMartinBuckey, on 52 molestation charge Thursday said they felt somechildren who testified may have been molested but not at thefamily-run McMartin Pre-School.And they said some child may have merely repeated storiestold them by their parent and interviewer at Children's InstituteInternational.The private child therapy center, which specializes in abusedchildren, videotaped interview with child from the McMartinschool after report of molestation surfaced. Jurors saw the tapesin which interviewer used anatomically explicit puppet andleading question to elicit description of molestation fromchildren.Asked what led to acquittal, juror Brenda Williams focused onthe taped interview from the center juror call CII.The CII interview I could not accept them, Mrs. Williamssaid. I believe the child believe what they were saying wastrue. But at CII, I could not tell if the child were saying whatwas told to them (by interviewer) or if they were repeating whattheir parent had told them.If the CII tape had not been entered into evidence and I hadnot seen them, I could have believed the child a little more,'Mrs. Williams said.The CII tape did not help me. They gave me a lot ofreasonable doubt, agreed juror Julie Peters, 47, a supermarketmeat wrapper.The child were never allowed to say in their own word whathappened to them. All the question were leading. They never had achance to tell their story, said juror John Breese, 51, amedical technician and grandfather of five.I tried to believe the child, said juror Daryl Hutchins28, an oil company lease operator. But if the child wa socontaminated (by the interview) I couldn't.Equal criticism wa aimed at a letter sent in 1983 by theManhattan Beach Police Department to parent of McMartin schoolchildren. The letter alerted parent to a claim of molestation atthe school and to Buckey's arrest.The police letter should never have been sent, said jurorSally Cordova, 27, a supermarket checker. It put the informationout there too early. The whole city knew.At that point, juror said, they felt parent had beenprogrammed to believe their child had been molested.One child said his parent told him that he wa molested evenbefore he went to CII, Mrs. Williams recalled.The panelist said they threw out entirely the most fantasticallegations, including some children's account of being molestedin a car wash. We just dismissed those, said Mrs. Williams.They said a series of medical slide shown to them lacked impactbecause they weren't sure what they were seeing in the photo ofchildren's genitals.Although they acquitted defendant of most charge, the jurorsdeadlocked on 13 count. Some said they were unsure whether Buckeywas a molester but were sure the prosecution had failed to proveits molestation allegation against him beyond a reasonable doubt.Jurors said they didn't rule out that some child in the casewere molested but not by these defendants.Even if you accept that the child were molested, saidjuror Mark Bassett, the evidence didn't establish that they weremolested at the McMartin Pre-School.The panelist said they were aware of the trial's enormous tollon defendant a well a child and parents.I think everybody is a victim, said Ms. Peters. I don'tthink anybody came out of this case a winner. I think it's sadbecause everybody lost something. The defendant their life havebeen ruined. They lost their business, their reputation. It's sadMrs. Williams added, The child have to live with this. Theparents have to live with this. There's nothing I can say that willmake it better.As for themselves, the juror said their life were put onhold for nearly three year. Bassett lost his job a a researchcomputer scientist when his company folded. Mrs. Williams gotmarried. Breese said his wife died during the trial and he hassince remarried.It's been very hard, said Mrs. Williams, a telephone companyservice representative. There were day when I thought I couldn'tstand it anymore.I don't really know my job anymore, she said. It's goingto be hard getting back into the real world.The jury foreman and four other juror declined interviews.The McMartin Pre-school molestation case wasthe longest criminal trial in US. history. Here is a chronology ofthe case:Ray Will Die is scrawled inbig black letter on the faded green paint of the McMartinPre-School, testimony to the rage inflamed by the notoriouschild-molesting case.Former McMartin teacher Raymond Buckey and his mother, PeggyMcMartin Buckey, were acquitted Thursday of 52 charge of molestingstudents. Jurors were deadlocked on 13 other counts.Whatever happens on those charge, few in thisupper-middle-class Los Angeles suburb would disagree with the judgein the trial, William Pounders, who once said, The case haspoisoned everyone who had contact with it.Sue Brown, a receptionist at a medical office across the streetfrom the school, said she had two friend who were involved in thecase and had been convinced of the Buckeys' guilt.I think they got off scot-free, Brown said. I'm reallysick about it.Alan Lagunoff, whose son, now 10, testified against the Buckeys,stood in front of the run-down, long-closed nursery school andtalked about his disappointment.The defense did everything to prolong the case and theprosecution did not do enough research to prosecute the caseproperly, he said.A cold wind blasted leaf across the schoolyard a Lagunoffleaned on the rusted chain-link fence surrounding the dilapidatedL-shaped building.I'd like to see the school become a center for abusedchildren, he said. It should be put to some good use ratherthan tear it down.But another longtime Manhattan Beach resident disagreed.I'd like to see it torn down, said Brenda Platt. I'd liketo have no memory of this.Platt, who ha two child aged 1 and 3, said she ha seriousdoubts about placing them in a day-care center because of theMcMartin trial.I think (the McMartin case) is a disgrace to Manhattan Beachand society. It's totally upsetting, Platt said.Linda Geisert, another resident of the beach city, wa alsoupset.I'm greatly disappointed in the legal system and quite franklyin the juror, Geisert said.For all his disappointment, Lagunoff said he did not feel theprosecutors should retry the remaining 13 counts.It would be just more of the same circus, he said.We put so much faith and hope in our court, said RobertCanter, 74. And this is what we get frustration.A therapist defended her interview ofalleged victim in the McMartin Pre-School molestation trial,despite criticism by several juror who said leading questionsundermined the prosecution's case.The jury on Thursday acquitted Raymond Buckey and his mother,Peggy McMartin Buckey, of 52 child molestation count anddeadlocked on 13 other counts.Therapist Kee McFarlane later defended her work with hundred ofMcMartin student, and suggested that the goal of therapy are atodds with the legal standard required for a successful criminalprosecution.What is in the interest of child is not always in theinterest of the legal system, she said.Evidence introduced by prosecutor in what became the longestand most expensive criminal trial in US. history includedvideotaped interview of the alleged victims.Many of the interview were conducted at an early stage of thesexual abuse investigation by MacFarlane, a social worker anddirector of the Child Sexual Abuse Center at Children's InstituteInternational.MacFarlane said Thursday she still belief child from theschool had been molested and that they had not fabricated theiraccounts of abuse.This agency would never have gone all the way through what wehave if we did not believe these child, she said.At least seven juror who attended a news conference agreed theevidence showed child had been molested. But the juror weresharply critical of the interviewers' technique at the institute.The child were never allowed to say in their own word whathappened to them, said juror John Breese. All the questionswere leading.If the CII tape had not been entered into evidence and I hadnot seen them, I could have believed the child a little more,juror Brenda Williams said.But MacFarlane said that the interviewing technique were sound,noting that small child must be interviewed differently thanadults.I didn't put word into their mouth, she said. I tried toenable them to get over their fears.MacFarlane acknowledged that some procedure could have beendone differently, including conducting more interview over alonger period of time. Emmons, saidsome good may come out of the case.It ha greatly increased the awareness about the issue ofchild sexual abuse and about the problem of prosecuting thesecases, she said.Thursday's acquittal in the McMartinPre-School molestation case outraged parent who said prosecutorsbotched it, while those on the defense side proclaimed a triumph ofjustice over hysteria and hype.Mother-and-son defendant Peggy McMartin Buckey, 63, and RaymondBuckey, 31, wept a the verdict were announced. Prosecutors must decide whether to try those chargesin a new trial.I just said, `I told you Ray,' Mrs. Buckey said. Asked ifher son wa surprised, she said. He had fear, definitely.Buckey avoided reporter and slipped out the courthouse with hislawyer.If it can happen to seven innocent people it can happen toyou, too. If it had not been in my faith in God I wouldn't be heretoday, she said.But several parent of former student at the school said theBuckeys won because the system lost.It wa never done properly, said parent Alan Lagunoff, whomoved to Central California from suburban Manhattan Beach. I haveto sit back and figure out what to do with my son. I don't know what the message is thatthe jury wanted to get out. I'm anxious to hear that.Charles Buckey, father of Raymond and husband of Mrs. Buckey,suggested Deputy District Attorney Lael Rubin, who prosecuted thecase for it entire six year, wa motivated by personal ambition.My concern primarily wa Lael Rubin, who is `anything goes' inorder to secure a conviction. . If you don't win, you don't getpromoted, he said.Juror Brenda Williams said the evidence failed to convince thejury beyond a reasonable doubt in 52 of the charges.Even if you accept that the child were molested, it didn'tnecessarily mean they were molested at the McMartin Pre-School,Ms. Williams told reporters.Raymond Buckey spent nearly five year in jail without bailduring the case, which defense attorney said wa the result ofcommunity hysteria sparked by bizarre allegation by the alcoholicmother of one child at the preschool.Some observer accused then-District Attorney Robert Philibosianof using the spectacular charge to boost his failing re-electioncampaign against Ira Reiner, who beat him and now run the districtattorney's office.Philibosian, however, insisted he would not have handled thematter differently.Ira Reiner ha had that case for five year, and I am notgoing to take any public criticism directed at me. Let him respondto the criticism, said Philibosian, now in private law practice.Also criticized wa the decision by investigator to use aprivate child therapy group, Children's Institute International, toconduct the original interview with the child. Defenseattorneys maintained that question by the institute's researcherswere leading and prejudicial.Jurors agreed.We never got the children's story in their own word, saidjuror John Breese.Children's Institute official didn't immediately returntelephone call seeking comment.Originally, there were seven defendant, including RaymondBuckey's sister, Peggy Ann Buckey, and Virginia McMartin, thefounder of the school, mother of Mrs. Buckey and grandmother ofRaymond Buckey.Hundreds of allegation of child molestation were filed in thecase, which gained worldwide attention with it tale ofunderground tunnel at the school and Satanic rituals.The focus of the case shifted dramatically over the year asReiner reduced the number of charge and dropped five defendantsafter reviewing the case. The underground tunnel were never found.No proof wa ever produced of Satanic rituals.Reiner said the system must be changed to prevent such long,expensive prosecution.It took far too long and cost far too much money to have whathas been called perfect justice. We need reform, Reiner said,adding that in trying to describe the case, Insane is the wordthat come to mind.The case wa the longest and the costliest in American judicialhistory, at 2{ year and $15 million. I tell my child all the time . there isno such thing a fair, said Robert Currie, whose son attendedMcMartin but didn't testify at the trial.It's really a travesty for a case to take this long, saidMs. Rubin, the prosecutor. ...Not only for the family, thechildren in this case, but also for the defendant a well.Jurors who have reached verdict on 52 countsin the McMartin preschool molestation case said Wednesday they aredeadlocked on the remaining 13 charge in the nation's longest,costliest criminal trial.Superior Court Judge William Pounders received a note from thejurors a they ended their day's deliberation and called a hearingfor Thursday to discus the deadlock and possibly opening the 52sealed verdicts.In an interview Wednesday evening, Pounders said he would dealwith the deadlocked count first, either declaring a mistrial onthose count and reading the sealed verdict, or sending the juryback to resume deliberation on the undecided counts.He said the verdict could also be read before sending the juryback. column5: Buckeys acquitted in record trial; rancor remains; more will follow.
column6: The McMartin Pre-School molestation trial ended Thursday without any convictions.  Reactions to the verdict were strong, ranging from tears to finger pointing.  The case began in 1983 and became a media-fed witch-hunt ending with the longest, costliest criminal trial in history.  It will continue to reverberate in civil courts, bookstores and on television.
column7: The longest, costliest, criminal trial in American history, the McMartin Pre-School molestation case, ended Thursday without finding Raymond Buckey or his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, guilty.  The California case began in 1983 and became a frenetic, media-fed, witch-hunt.  Reactions to the verdict included tears, no surprise, disappointment, anger, excuses, and finger pointing.  Jurors criticized elements of the case and said some of the children may have been molested, but the prosecution failed to prove the defendants responsible.  Other parties defended their own roles, but blamed others or the system.  Reverberations will continue in civil courts, bookstores, and on television.
column8: The longest, costliest, criminal trial in American history, the McMartin Pre-School molestation case, ended Thursday.  The jury acquitted Raymond Buckey and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, on 52 counts and deadlocked on 13.  The case began in 1983 and became a frenetic witch-hunt led by the California media.  At one time, seven defendants, 135 charges, and over 400 children were involved.  Following the verdict, defendants wept, while parents decried the system for failing their children.  The judge was not surprised.  Jurors faulted the children's videotaped interviews, saying the interviewer asked leading questions.  Jurors believed some may have been molested, but the prosecution failed to prove the defendants responsible.  The therapist conducting the interviews defended her technique.  The current and former Los Angles district attorneys blamed each other and denied their ambitions influenced the case.  The pre-school's neighbors were disappointed and concerned about the building.Reverberations will continue.  Several books and television movies are planned, although the response of the networks is not known.  Two civil suits by former defendants are underway and Mrs. Buckey said she plans to sue.  Parents of the children may decide to file civil charges because the burden proof is lower. A harassed minister seeks disability retirement.
column9: A verdict of innocent returned in the McMartin Pre-school trial.
column10: The McMartin Pre-School child molestation trial ended in acquittal for Raymond Buckey and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey. The jury found the McMartins innocent of 52 counts, but deadlocked on another 13, causing a mistrial on those counts. Parents of the children involved in the trial were angry and expressed disappointment with the acquittal.
column11: The McMartin Pre-School child molestation trial, the longest criminal trial in U.S. history, ended with a verdict of innocent for Raymond Buckey and is mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey. The jury found the Buckeys innocent on 52 of the charges but deadlocked on another 13, causing a mistrial on those charges. Prosecutors must now decide if they want a retrial on the deadlocked charges. Originally involving 7 defendants, including Raymond Buckeys sister and grandmother, the charges against the sister and grandmother as well as three employees of the school were dropped. Parents of the children involved expressed anger and disappoint at the verdict.
column12: The McMartin Pre-School child molestation case, the longest and costliest criminal trial in U.S. history ended with the acquittal of Raymond Buckey and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, on 52 charges. A decision has yet to be reached on whether to retry Buckey on the 13 charges on which the jury deadlocked. The case originally involved Buckey and his mother, as well as his sister and grandmother and three other employees of the school. The charges against the sister, grandmother and the three employees were dropped for lack of evidence. In reaching their verdict, the jury said that the videotaped interviews of the child were a factor in finding the Buckeys innocent. The jurors felt the interviewers asked leading questions and never allowed the children to tell their own story. A number of the jurors stated that they believed some of the children had been molested but that the prosecution had not proven that Raymond Buckey was responsible. The verdict was greeted with anger by the parents of the children involved who felt the prosecution and the legal system had let them down. The judge in the case remarked that the case had poisoned everyone it touched.

column3: Tank-led Iraqi troop invaded Kuwait before dawnThursday, seizing the ruler's palace and other governmentbuildings, Kuwaiti official reported.,The Iraqi government of President Saddam Hussein said theKuwaiti government had been overthrown.The invasion come nearly two week after Iraq massed troop onKuwait's border in a dispute over an oilfield and Kuwait'sviolation of OPEC oil production quota, which had kept down theprice of crude.The Iraqis have occupied all of Kuwait! one Kuwaiti officialshouted in a telephone interview.They have seized all administrative building, including theinformation ministry which house the (state-run) radio andtelevision station, said the official, who spoke on condition ofanonymity.Diplomats said about 350 Iraqi tank wheeled into the capital afew hour after crossing the border 40 mile away before dawn.The invader, whose force far outnumber those of smallerKuwait, were led by the elite Republican Guard that did the bruntof the fighting in the 1980-88 war with Iran. The troop set uproadblocks at major intersection in the capital.The invader surrounded the palace of the ruler of Kuwait, SheikJaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, the official said. Residents in thepalace's vicinity said it wa seized after two hour of heavyartillery barrages.The whereabouts of the emir, whose family ha ruled thecity-state for almost 250 year, wa not immediately known.The bombardment of port and airport wa vicious, eyewitnessessaid.Thousands of resident attempted to flee south toward SaudiArabia in their car. Kuwait's official radio broadcast a desperateplea for help from other Arab nations.The Kuwaiti Embassy in Washington reported only that there weremany casualty in the fighting, which follows a flareup in aprotracted dispute over a border oil field, but gave no numbersearly Thursday.Residents said there were about 50 tank around the emir'spalace and the neighboring US. Embassy. The embassy did no answerits telephones.The British Embassy wa hit by shellfire and the Sheraton andHilton hotel evacuated their clientele, source said.The air space over Kuwait wa closed, with airliner turned away.The Bush administration demanded immediate withdrawal of theIraqi force and added that it wa reviewing all option in itsresponse to the Iraqi aggressionUS. warship have been on short-term alert 600 milessoutheast of the Iraq-Kuwait border since July 24 because of thetensions in the oil-rich Persian Gulf region, scene of heavyfighting in the Iran-Iraq war.The White House said it had no report of harm to Americans. TheUnited States ha extensive business tie to Kuwait, and the U.S.community in the nation slightly smaller than New Jersey issizeable, in the thousands.The White House denounced the incursion, issuing a statementthat said, The United States strongly condemns the Iraqi militaryinvasion of Kuwait ...We have conveyed this message to the Iraqi ambassador inWashington and to the Iraqi government through our embassy inBaghdad.We deplore this blatant use of military aggression inviolation of the UN. charter.In New York, UN. official said the Security Council wa tobegin an emergency meeting early Thursday.Reaction wa swift elsewhere. The British government said thearmed incursion is clearly a grave threat to peace and stabilityin the area and of immediate concern to the international communityas a whole.The Iraqi action wa expected to dominate talk betweenPresident Bush and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher when they meetlater Thursday in Aspen, Colo.Iraqi official on Wednesday had abruptly walked out on talk inJiddah, Saudi Arabia, complaining that the Kuwaiti representativeswere not negotiating seriously. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypthad intervened beginning July 25 to set up the talk in a bid tocool tension between the two OPEC members.In Baghdad, Saddam's government announced Thursday that theKuwaiti government had been toppled.Kuwait radio went off the air briefly, but came back ondifferent wavelenghs with martial music and Kuwaiti patriotic songs.Saddam's ruling council issued a statement from Baghdad sayingan interim government had been established in Kuwait but the claimcould not be immediately and independently confirmed.Iraq ha responded to the request from interim government offree Kuwait and decided to cooperate with it, the Iraqi statementsaid.It said the troop no number were given were in Kuwait todefend the revolution and the Kuwaiti people. There wa no furtheridentification of the revolutionary government.Iraq warned too that any foreign troop trying to interfere withits action would be attacked.More than 60 percent of the country's 1.8 million resident areforeigners.Kuwaiti force had engaged the Iraqi invader with heavyartillery in a failed attempt to repulse them, government officialscontacted by telephone earlier Thursday said.Iraqi, which is the size of California, ha an estimated 1million troop among it 17 million populace, compared to 20,300members of the Kuwait armed forces.In Baghdad, the official radio interspersed martial music withsongs with slogan like, Greetings to the Revolution in Kuwait.The invasion followed massive troop movement to the south onWednesday.In Kuwait early Thursday, the rattle of automatic gun soundedand explosion in rapid succession shook local resident from theirsleep and the Kuwaiti Cabinet quickly assembled.Residents in downtown Kuwait reported formation of French-madeMirage jet fighter of the Kuwaiti air force taking to the sky inthe direction of the border region.The street were empty; some people on rooftop of their housesreported hearing gunblasts growing in intensity and speed. Momentslater army tank and armored personnel carrier were moving in thedirection of the Royal Palace, apparently to reinforce the guards.Kuwait is a former British protectorate that gained independencein 1961. Its resident are among the wealthiest in the worldbecause of the country's vast oil reserves.In Tokyo, the dollar moved sharply higher along with oil pricesduring morning trading Thursday on news of Iraq's invasion.Iraqi President Saddam Hussein seemeddetermined to solve his financial problem and fulfill territorialambitions by dethroning the government of neighboring Kuwait.The invasion, unprecedented in modern Arab history, reflectedthe brutality Saddam ha used to crush all opposition at home sincecoming to power in 1979.The sentence for criticizing Saddam is death, and the presidentconsidered Kuwait's oil overproduction and the subsequent fall inthe price of oil a personal affront to Iraq.Iraqis will not forget the saying that cutting neck is betterthan cutting mean of living. For Kuwait on Thursday, he wa a dark knight.Asked the reason for the invasion, Kuwait's ambassador toWashington Sheik Saud Nasir Al-Sabah said at a news conference:Ambition. Hegemony. EDT),Bader said.Earlier in the day, the Iraqi ambassador, Mohamed Al-Mashat, wassummoned to the State Department afternoon for a meeting withAssistant Secretary John Kelly.Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Kelly repeated to theIraqi envoy the US. desire for a peaceful solution to the tensionswith Kuwait and urged Iraq to respect to sovereignty of all nationsin the region.Kelly told a House subcommittee Tuesday that while the UnitedStates ha no treaty obligation that would mandate militarysupport for Kuwait, the United States doe believe strongly inrespect for territory of all state in the region.The United States, whose Persian Gulf naval patrol helped Iraqdefeat Iran in the 1980-1988 war, ha six warship in the area.They have been conducting exercise since July 23 with force ofthe United Arab Emirates, some 700 mile southest of Kuwait.Iraq had moved about 100,000 troop to it border with Kuwaitafter claiming that Kuwait's production of oil beyond quota of theOPEC cartel had depressed the world price, thus diminishing Iraq'srevenue, and that Kuwait had been stealing oil from a field thatstraddles the border.Iraqi official on Wednesday walked out on talk in Jiddah,Saudia Arabia aimed at resolving the 2-week-old crisis withneighboring Kuwait and complained that Kuwait wa not negotiatingseriously.Iraq threatened to invade once before, in 1961 after Britainended it protectorate over Kuwait. Yves Fortier declared, This madman must be stopped.Cuban envoy Ricardo Alarcon said Cuba would vote for sanctionsagainst Iraq only if the council imposed sanction on South Africafor occupying Namibia, Israel for occupying Palestinian territoriesand the United States for invading Panama.In Kuwait, the Iraqi-installed provisional government, in astatement carried by the Iraqi News Agency, told other country torefrain from taking punishing measure against it or Iraq. Theprovisional government said country have to remember they haveinterests and citizen in Kuwait.Kuwait's UN. Ambassador Mohammad Abulhasan told reporter thatthe Iraqi-installed government wa employing pure blackmail bysaying it could not ensure the safety of foreigner if theirgovernments support sanctions.In Aspen, Colo., British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcherrenewed her call for the United Nations to apply a total economicembargo against Iraq unless it withdraws immediately from Kuwait.Iraq's invasion of Kuwait defies every principle for which theUN. stand. If we let it succeed, no small country can ever feelsafe again. The law of the jungle take over, she said, inremarks at the Aspen Institute.The UN. role in the Iraq-Kuwait crisis assumed increasingimportance after divided Arab nation cancelled an emergency summiton the invasion.On Thursday, the Security Council condemned Iraq's invasion,demanded immediate and unconditional troop withdrawal, andthreatened to impose sanction if Iraq did not pull out.Sunday's session wa scheduled after weekend meeting of thecouncil's five permanent member the United States, the SovietUnion, China, Britain and France and between the United Statesand representative of the Non-Aligned Movement. They are thenations with the power to veto proposals.The United States contends that stiff sanction by a unitedinternational front are necessary to punish Iraq and to force it towithdraw from Kuwait, which wa invaded Thursday.The radio of Kuwait's new Iraqi-installedgovernment claimed that Iraqi troop began pulling out of Kuwait onSunday, but the United States said it doubted a withdrawal wasreally under way.The radio announcement came three day after Iraq invaded Kuwaitand one day after Baghdad said it had replaced the oil-richkingdom's ousted monarchy with a new government made up of nineKuwaiti army offices.Iraq also said Saturday that it wa creating a new Kuwaiti armyand that 100,000 Iraqis, the approximate number of soldier Baghdadtook over Kuwait with, had volunteered for the new military force.In other developments:The White House continued to seek the immediate andunconditional withdrawl of all Iraqi troop, and it thanked themany nation who have condemned the invasion and imposed economicsanctions on Baghdad.After several day of debate, Japan on Sunday banned all oilimports from Iraq and Kuwait and halted Japanese export to bothcountries. Tokyo said it would suspend all loan to Iraq andKuwait, ban Japanese investment there, and freeze Iraqi asset inJapan. Japan, which import 99 percent of it oil, had relied onIraq and Kuwait for more than 11 percent of it oil import. TheWhite House hailed Japan's move and said Prime Minister ToshikiKaifu called President Bush on Sunday at Camp David to inform himabout the sanctions.Although ten of thousand of Iraqi troop reportedly remainedmassed near Kuwait's border with Saudi Arabia, Washington said onSunday there wa no indication that any soldier had moved intoSaudi Arabia.The White House said that 11 American oil worker rounded upafter the invasion had been brought to Baghdad, talked with U.S.Embassy official, and were in good shape. It said that accountsfor all missing Americans.An unconfirmed report said a warplane from the deposed emir'sair force in Kuwait bombed an Iraqi military headquarters nearKuwait city. It wa not clear where the plane came from or whetherits reported attack caused any damage.The radio of Kuwait's new government, monitored in Bahrain,quoted it military correspondent a saying the pullout beganat 8 am. (1 am. EDT).Iraqi President Saddam Hussein allowed reporter based inBaghdad to be taken south to Basra overnight to observe the firstIraqi troop return home.But at the White House, press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said onSunday morning: We have no independent or confirmable informationon this report (of the withdrawl beginning). Saddam Hussein'sactions in the past have raised serious skepticism about hisintentions.Iraq declared earlier that the provisional government installedby Baghdad is capable of ensuring security in the occupied country.Baghdad television ha said the new government is headed by Col.Ala Hussein Ali and that he hold the position of prime minister,commander-in-chief of the armed force, minister of defense andinterior minister. The other eight member were lieutenant colonelsand majors.But Kuwait's embassy in Amman, Jordan, on Sunday dismissed thenew government a a list of fake name and said Ali is Saddam'sson-in-law.A similar report appeared in one of Cairo's leading newspapers,Al-Ahram. It quoted the Kuwait Embassy in Tunis which said that Aliworks with Saddam's administration in Baghdad.The Iraqi news agency carried a Kuwait-datelined statement itsaid wa from the provisional government, denying any of itsmembers were Iraqis.In Jordan, Prime Minister Mudar Badran said his nation will notrecognize the new government because that would hinder Arab effortsto end the conflict.U.S., French and British warship, meanwhile, steamed toward thePersian Gulf. President Bush said Friday that if Iraq moved againstSaudi Arabia it would be attacking US. vital interest. OnSaturday, Bush said in Washington that the use of force inresolving the crisis remains an option. Saudi Arabia ship 1.2million barrel of oil to the United States daily.Fitzwater said on Sunday that there wa no indication Iraqiforces had moved into Saudi Arabia, even though ten of thousandsof them have been reported to be within 5 to 10 mile of the Saudiborder.In Washington, Iraqi ambassador Mohammed al-Mashat on Saturdaydenied US. and other foreign report suggesting that Iraq plan toinvade Saudi Arabia.Saddam ordered the invasion of Kuwait after accusing it ofstealing oil from a field that straddle their disputed border. Healso blamed Kuwait for a fall in oil price that cost Iraq $14billion, saying it contributed to the oil glut by cheating on itsOPEC oil cartel production quotas.Iraq's powerful army invaded this small oil-richkingdom early today.
