Tank-led troop quickly seized the ruler'spalace and government building, and the emir fled to Saudi Arabia,Kuwaiti official said.Kuwait's US. ambassador said the Iraqis occupied all governmentbuildings in the capital and were moving south toward the country'soil facility. He appealed for US. military intervention.A Pentagon source said US. Navy ship were diverted to theregion, but President Bush said the subject of intervention wa notbeing discussed.The Iraqis have occupied all of Kuwait! a Kuwaiti governmentofficial shouted in a telephone interview. Diplomatic source inthe Persian Gulf estimated that more than 200 Kuwaitis were killedor wounded.The Iraqi government of President Saddam Hussein claimed itinvaded at the request of revolutionary who had already staged acoup and established The Provisional Government of Free Kuwait.Kuwait and UN. diplomat labeled the coup report a farce.The assault followed two week of tension between Kuwait andIraq, caused by Iraqi accusation that Kuwait stole oil from adisputed border area. Saddam also accused Kuwait of exceeding OPECproduction quota, thus driving down the price of oil, a majorIraqi revenue source.The attack had wide-ranging ramifications:Oil price soared $3 a barrel in early trading because of fearsthe invasion would disrupt supply. Prices were about $2 higherlater.President Bush signed order freezing Iraqi asset in theUnited States and blocking most Iraqi import, including oil. Oilaccounts for 97 percent of Iraqi import to the United States andmakes up about 3.5 percent of US. oil consumption. Bush also frozeKuwaiti asset to prevent Iraq from seizing them.The Soviet Union, Iraq's main arm supplier, halted weaponssales.The UN. Security Council voted 14-0 to denounce the invasionand demanded immediate withdrawal of Iraqi troops.A Pentagon source said the aircraft carrier USS Independence,escorted by a six-ship battle group, wa diverted from the IndianOcean toward the gulf, where other US. ship were alreadypatrolling.Secretary of State James A. Baker III planned to fly to Moscowto issue a rare joint statement Friday with Soviet Foreign MinisterEduard A. Shevardnadze about the invasion. The plan, which wasannounced in Washington, illustrates the dramatic improvement inrelations between the superpower, who once routinely lined up onopposite side of most regional disputes.Kuwait's US. ambassador, Sheik Saud Nasir al-Sabah, toldreporters in Washington: We are desperate for any help we canget. He appealed specifically for American intervention.In recent day, diplomat said Iraq had massed more than 100,000troops at the border. Kuwait's entire armed force ha 20,300soldiers.Bush said the United States would take whatever stepsnecessary to defend interest in the gulf. Asked if this includedmilitary force, Bush said: We're not discussing intervention.But he said he would not discus military option publicly.It wa the first time in modern history an Arab nation hadinvaded another and taken over it government.Kuwait's army wa no match for Iraq, battle-hardened after eightyears of war with Iran. Iraq ha emerged a the Arab world'sstrongest and most militant military power, and Saddam ha a vastarsenal of chemical and conventional weapons.Diplomats said about 350 Iraqi tank wheeled into the capital afew hour after crossing the border 40 mile away at dawn.Witnesses said the bombardment of port and military airport byartillery and the air force wa vicious.The invader surrounded the palace of Kuwait's ruler, SheikJaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah. Residents said the palace wa seized afterabout two hour of heavy artillery barrages.Diplomats said Sheik Fahd al-Ahmed al-Sabah, one of the emir'sbrothers, wa killed while trying to defend the palace.There were about 50 tank around the palace and the neighboringAmerican Embassy, resident said.The al-Sabah family ha ruled the city-state for almost 250years. The Kuwaiti ambassador said the leader were safe in SaudiArabia.Operating from an unknown location, al-Ahmed's governmentresponded to the formation of the provisional government bystating: Kuwait is Kuwait to it people, let by the emir, SheikJaber, and his Crown Prince Sheik Saad.
column5: Iraq invades Kuwait; the world reacts.
column6: Iraq, after first accusing Kuwait of wrongdoing, invaded its oil-rich neighbor with 100,000 tank-led troops.  It quickly overran the Kuwaiti capital and then continued on to southern oil facilities.  The United States led the United Nations in condemning this action and imposing tough economic and military sanctions.
column7: Saddam accused Kuwait of costing Iraq billions by exceeding OPEC production quotas thus driving down oil prices.  He further accused Kuwait of "stealing" Iraqi oil from a common oil field on their border.  He then invaded Kuwait, claiming to do so at the request of Kuwaiti revolutionary coup leaders.  The United States led the western world and the United Nations in calling the coup a sham, denouncing this invasion and imposing strong economic and military sanctions on Iraq in an attempt to get them to withdraw.  Oil prices surged while Saddam warned against foreign intervention.  The U.S. dispatched warships to the area.
column8: It appeared that Iraq's President Saddam Hussein was determined to solve his countries financial problems and territorial ambitions by conquering Kuwait.  Iraq emerged from its 1980-1988 war with Iran with a debt of approximately $80 billion.  Saddam accused Kuwait of costing Iraq billions in oil revenues by exceeding OPEC assigned oil quotas, thus driving down the price of oil.  He further accused Kuwait of stealing Iraqi oil from an oil field common to their border and also of conspiring with the United States and Israel to weaken Iraq economically and militarily.  Breaking off perfunctory negotiations with Kuwait, Iraq invaded, claiming it responded to a request for help from Kuwaiti revolutionary coup leaders.  Iraq quickly overwhelmed a mismatched Kuwaiti military, captured the capital and continued south to the oil facilities.  The United States called the coup a farce.  Kuwait's U.S. ambassador asked the United States to intervene militarily.  U.S. President George Bush called for an "immediate and unconditional" withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait.  Although not willing to publicly discuss military options, Bush said all U.S. options remained open.  His administration led a United Nations embargo of Iraqi exports, including oil, and Iraqi imports.  Iraq retaliated by rounding up hundreds of foreign nationals in Kuwait.
column9: Saddam Hussein Defied United States and United Nations
column10: On August 2, 1990, after Saddam Hussein had charged Kuwait with unfriendly acts, 100,000 Iraqi troops invaded and quickly occupied Kuwait. Despite strong diplomatic moves by the U.S. and the U.N. Security Council, Iraq remained defiant and moved troops toward the Saudi Arabian border. As of August 6, 1990 the situation was ominous.
column11: In July 1990 Saddam Hussein accused Kuwait of violating OPEC production quotas and stealing oil from wells along the Iraq-Kuwait border. The two countries agreed to talks to settle their differences, but on the first day of the talks the Iraqi representatives walked out. The next day, August 2, 1990, 100,000 Iraqi troops invaded and quickly occupied Kuwait. Despite strong diplomatic efforts, Iraq remained defiant, rounding up several hundred Britons, Americans and West Germans in Kuwait and taking some of them to Iraq. As of August 6, 1990 Iraqi troops were massed on the border of Saudi Arabia and the U.S. warned that its vital interests were involved.
column12: On July 17, 1990 Saddam Hussein accused Kuwait of violating OPECproduction quotas and of stealing oil from wells along the countries'disputed border. Tension increased July 24-25 as the U.S. announced a"short-notice exercise" in the Persian Gulf and Iraq said it would notbe intimidated by U.S. pressure. Tension eased when Iraq and Kuwaitagreed to talks, but by the time the parties met on July 31, Iraq hadmassed 100,000 troops on the Kuwaiti border. The next day Iraq pulledout of the talks and on August 2,1990 invaded and quickly occupied allof Kuwait. President Bush froze Iraqi assets in the U.S. and blockedmost Iraqi imports. The U.N. Security Council denounced the invasionand demanded Iraq's withdrawal. The Pentagon stepped up air patrolsand movement of warships into the Persian Gulf. When, on August 6, theU.S.  pushed strong sanctions against Iraq through the U.N. SecurityCouncil, Iraq struck back, rounding up several hundred Britons,Americans, and West Germans in Kuwait, taking some of them toIraq. Iraqi troop concentrations menaced the Saudi Arabian border andthe U.S. warned Iraq of vital American interests in Saudi Arabia, butas of August 6, 1990 it was a stand-off. Iraq was in possession ofKuwait and oil prices soared on the international market.

column3: Here is a state-by-state look at the tornado and severethunderstorms that have killed at least 27 people, injured morethan 500 and left hundred homeless since Wednesday:A powerful storm system brought strong wind and heavythunderstorms to the Northeast on Thursday, causing flooding andwidespread property damage. Seven child died when a wallcollapsed in a school cafeteria near Newburgh, N.Y.Tornadoes were reported in New Jersey, Delaware, Virginia andNew York, although the National Weather Service wa unable toconfirm them. The same storm system caused tornado in sevenstates in the South and Midwest on Wednesday, and wa blamed for 17deaths in Huntsville, Ala.The storm wa particularly violent because it occurred along aline of extreme variation in temperature. High temperature recordsfell in advance of the storm and sharply colder weather lurkedbehind it.Record high were recorded in Binghamton, N.Y., where it wa 61degrees, Bridgeport, Conn., (66), and Burlington, Vt., (69). Arecord wa also set in Miami, where it wa 89.Thunderstorms continued across the Ohio Valley overnight andduring the morning. Storms that might have been tornado damaged aresidence and a store near Richmond, Va., and uprooted about 600feet of tree near Wilmington, Del. Other storm that might havebeen tornado were reported near Peekskill, N.Y., and PiscatawayN.J., during the afternoon.Strong thunderstorm caused a concrete-and-glass wall to blow inon a cafeteria during lunchtime at the East Coldenham ElementarySchool near Newburgh. Seven child were killed and 18 injured.There were report of damage from strong thunderstorm and gustywinds in eastern Virginia, Maryland, Delaware, New Jersey, easternPennsylvania and eastern New York state. Winds gusted to 65 mph inBaltimore, 76 mph in Lancaster, Pa., and 100 mph at Great Valley,Pa.A tornado watch wa posted for northeast New York state, much ofVermont and much of New Hampshire.Thunderstorms also produced locally heavy rain and flooding. Aflood warning wa posted over portion of upstate New York. Nearlytwo inch of rain fell east of Utica, N.Y., at the Little FallsReservoir, which overflowed and caused flooding.Water wa eroding the Lyons Pond Dam near Dolgeville, N.Y.,causing flooding there.Snow wa falling west of the cold front. A winter storm warningwas posted for northwest Wisconsin, in the snowbelt near LakeSuperior. Winter storm warning were posted for much of lowerMichigan, northwestern upper Michigan and north central Indiana.Winds gusted to 63 mph at Whitefish Point, Mi., and nearblizzard condition extended over eastern upper Michigan.Overnight snowfall across upper Michigan included 12 inch atVan Riper State Park and 10 inch near Neguanee.Heavier snowfall during the 6 hour ending at 1 pm. ESTincluded 4 inch at Houghton Lake, Mich., 3 inch at MarquettePellston, Saginaw and Sault Ste. Marie, all in Michigan, and 2inches at South Bend, Ind.Heavy snow warning were posted for the northwest and northernmountain portion of Pennsylvania. A snow squall warning wa postedfor northeast Ohio.Cold weather wa expected to invade the Southeast, with warningsof freezing overnight temperature posted for Friday morning inGeorgia, Alabama, northwest Florida, most of Mississippi and allbut extreme southeast Louisiana.The low temperature for the nation Thursday morning wa 8degrees below zero at Bismarck, N.D.Temperatures around the nation at 3 pm. EST ranged from 7degrees at Fergus Falls, Minn., to 88 degree at Miami, Fla.A tornado slammed into a shoppingdistrict, a residential area and a school Wednesday, killing atleast 15 people, injuring more than 300 and trapping people in carsand home, authority said.It's total destruction where the tornado hit. Cars are piledon top of each other under pile of rubble where building used tobe, said Danny Cooper, state emergency management director inMontgomery.Emergency official in Huntsville reported 15 confirmed deaths,said Henry Jurnigan, a duty officer with the state EmergencyManagement Agency in Montgomery. Mayor Steve Hettinger said 305people were injured and about 500 displaced by the tornado thatstruck while street of this northeastern Alabama city filled withrush-hour traffic.Rescue team with crane and floodlight searched the rubblethrough the night for injured or dead.Several people are still trapped in vehicle and apartmentcomplexes and shopping area, said police spokesman Ben Jenningsafter the twister touched down between 4 and 4:30 pm. in thecity's south section.It may be tomorrow before we have a final count, Gov. GuyHunt said at the state's disaster center in Montgomery.The governor dispatched 50 National Guardsmen, along with searchand rescue equipment.Rescuers picked through pile of rubble 10 to 14 foot deep, andCooper said police were unable to determine the extent of thedamaged area. Rescuers also were hampered by darkness and plungingtemperatures.We're even having a few snowflake, said Cooper. Hightemperatures in Huntsville were expected to be in the 30 Thursday,he said.Witnesses said the downtown Jones Valley Elementary School, theWaterford Square and adjacent Queensbury apartment complex werereduced to rubble by the tornado.The only thing left standing wa a door frame, newsphotographer Mike Mercier said of the school, which wa empty ofstaff and pupil when the tornado hit. Police reported one personkilled in a car outside the school.Authorities said at least five were killed at Waterford Squareapartments, three at a business school, Southern Junior College,which is located in a converted movie theater, and others inscattered areas.Rescuers are digging in the rubble, state trooper WL. Kellysaid. He said two people were killed when the twister hit housetrailers in rural area east of Huntsville. The fifth death wasreported near the shopping district.The city is home to Marshall Space Flight Center and the Army'sRedstone Arsenal, but no serious damage wa reported from the spaceagency or weapon testing center.We've called in trooper from around the state to help,Kelly said.Telephone communication and electricity were disrupted by thetornadoes and WAAY-TV, the only station still broadcasting,reported widespread damage.It came in with a huge roar, an enormous amount of water, andit just started shaking and tearing at everything it could get holdof, said real estate broker Ike Carroll, who wa in his car whenthe twister struck.It started picking car up and pushing them around, . someof them upside down, some of them just strewn around, he said.Heavy overhead power line started snapping just like a circusperformer would snap his whip, Carroll said.All of these heavy arcing, flashing line that were justpopping and snapping over the top of u . it wa a if you werelooking into an arc-welder, they were so bright, he said.WAAY reported at least one person died when the roof of abusiness collapsed from wind that overturned car in the area. Anearby shopping center also wa damaged.Humana Hospital administrator David Miller said doctor werehaving difficulty reaching the hospital because of blocked roads.The National Weather Service earlier said a tornado hit the eastAlabama hamlet of Mellow Valley, severely damaging at least onehome and causing some injury. Weather official said people weretrapped inside a collapsed house.A spokeswoman for the Clay County Sheriff's Department saidpeople were injured at one house in a rural area 30 mile east ofSylacauga.Another tornado touched down about 1:30 pm. a severe weatherswept across much of Alabama and the National Weather Serviceplaced most of the state under a tornado watch.A third tornado wa reported shortly before 3:30 pm. crossingthe Coosa River near Titus in east Alabama, the Weather Servicesaid.In Georgia, five people were injured, four critically, and atleast 200 people evacuated after a tornado struck two mobile homeparks and an interstate highway near Palmetto, about 25 milessoutheast of Atlanta, authority said.Authorities in southwestern North Carolina said a pair ofstorm-spawned tornado struck around 10:45 p.m., destroying avacant house in Henderson County.The National Weather Service also reported tornado inflictingminor property damage in Kentucky and Mississippi.A violent storm that spun tornado across the South and Midwestblew north Thursday, knocking a cafeteria wall down on top oflunching schoolchildren in upstate New York. The two-day toll wasat least 27 dead and hundred injured.The cafeteria cave-in claimed the life of seven child nearNewburgh, N.Y., and death also were reported in New York City, NewJersey and Illinois. Seventeen people died Wednesday in HuntsvilleAla., when a tornado packing 250 mph wind struck virtually withoutwarning, laying waste to a wide swath of the city.The storm churned around a collision of record warm air andextremely cold air. The result wa tornado and unusually severethunderstorms.By far the worst damage wa in Huntsville, where an estimated1,000 people were left homeless and National Guardsmen stood watchagainst looting Thursday.No body were believed left in the rubble, but portion of thecity resembled a bombing target. A shopping center and cluster ofapartment building were leveled. Cars were piled atop each other.Utility pole had been snapped like twigs.The National Weather Service said the tornado path had coveredbetween eight and 10 mile and that it wind speed were a high as250 mph.It's like taking six to 10 city block and putting them in ablender and putting it on liquefy, said rescue worker Bob Caraway.As the storm moved north on Thursday, it knocked over tree andripped the the roof off house in West Virginia, injuring fourmembers of one family, two seriously. The storm also causedflooding in Washington, D.C., blew the window out of skyscrapersin Philadelphia and destroyed a house in Piscataway, N.J.A truck driver died when his tractor-trailer overturned in highwinds on a bridge connecting Elizabeth, N.J., and New York City. ANew York City woman died after being hit by a steel beam blown offa water tower.In Wyckoff, N.J., high wind knocked a power line onto a gasline, sparking a fire that forced the evacuation of 20 homes,according to police. No house were burned.The cafeteria collapse occurred at the East Coldenham ElementarySchool in Newburgh at about 12:30 p.m., when from 113 to 125students in first, second and third grade were eating lunch, saidNewburgh police Chief John Kulisek.State Police and survivor said they believed the school wa hitby a tornado, but the National Weather Service said it could notconfirm that until investigator went to the scene.The center section of a cinder-block and glass wall fell in onthe cafeteria, showering the pupil with glass and concrete.You are talking about huge concrete block that fell on top ofthe kid, state police Lt. Robert Hughes said.Seven child age 7 and 8 were killed and 18 others wereinjured, four critically, official said.In eastern Connecticut, more than 75,000 Northeast Utilitiescustomers lost power in the afternoon, and 18,000 remained withoutpower at 9 p.m., spokeman Jeffery Kotkin said.Tornadoes were reported Wednesday in Mississippi, AlabamaGeorgia, South Carolina, North Carolina, Kentucky, Ohio andIndiana. A severe thunderstorm in Illinois claimed one life andcaused several million dollar in damage.Altogether, the storm were blamed for at least 27 death andmore than 500 injury over the two days.In Alabama, Gov. Guy Hunt said he would ask President Bush todeclare Huntsville a disaster area to open the door to million ofdollars in federal relief. Mayor Steve Hettinger said no firmdamage estimate were expected until Friday, but he put the numberof homeless at 1,000.Hunt assigned nearly 200 Guardsmen to assist in the cleanup andhelp law officer guard against looting. Police spokeswoman SusanWilliamson said there had been minor looting the night of the stormbut no arrests.The temperature, which had risen to 73 before the stormWednesday, plunged into the 30 early Thursday while rescuersworked through the night under the glare of floodlights.The light, powered by generator, produced an eerie glow in aarea that wa otherwise largely without power. Tall crane liftedthe heavy rubble, while worker with flashlight picked through thesmaller pieces.As daybreak came, people began returning to the scene, some tolook for valuable in ravaged car or business, others simply outof curiosity. Many carried camera or videocassette recorders.Police Maj. Robert Moder said there wa no indication thatanyone wa left in the rubble.We don't have any report of people missing, he saidThursday morning.Moder said 463 people were injured and more than 150 of thoserequired at least overnight hospital treatment. Authorities hadsaid 19 people were killed but later lowered the death toll by two.All but one of the victim, who ranged in age from 7 to 67, werekilled along Airport Boulevard, a busy thoroughfare that seemed tobe a guide for the tornado on it deadly march. The other victimperished on the city's outskirt, authority said.Most of the dead were in apartment and store that were torninto twisted wreckage, or in car blown off the pavement.The tornado seemed to catch everyone by surprise.It wa fast, said Lucy Lee Rusk, who moved to a Red Crossshelter after her apartment wa battered by debris. It wa likeone big pop and that's when everything went.The National Weather Service had issued a severe thunderstormwarning at 3:54 p.m., but the tornado struck with no real warning,said Brenda Page of the service's office. A tornado warning wasbroadcast at 4:39 p.m., two minute after the twister wa sightedon the ground at the old Huntsville airportMs. Page said radar showed a strong storm but not the conditionsusually visible during tornadoes.Danny Cooper, director of the Alabama Emergency ManagementAgency, said three people were seriously injured in an earliertornado that hit a home in Clay County in eastern Alabama. He saida tornado in northwestern Alabama's Lauderdale County destroyedthree homes.Alabama Power Co. reported Thursday that violent wind hadbattered the switchyard of the Farley Nuclear Power Plant nearDothan on Wednesday night, causing about three gallon ofconcentrated PCBs to spill. A spokesman said no one wa injured,the nuclear plant wa not affected and a cleanup of thecancer-causing chemical wa under way.Thunderstorms wreaked havoc across the middle Mississippi Valleyand the Southeast on Wednesday with lethal tornado, wind up to100 mph and hail up to the size of baseballs.At least four tornado pounded the Huntsville, Ala., area. Onetwister smashed into a residential district, a shopping area and aschool, killing at least two people and causing dozen of injuries,police said.Southern Illinois wa also hard hit by the storm, with onewoman killed by a falling tree, about 20 people injured and powerlines downed.Elsewhere, snow fell from the northern Rockies to the upperGreat Lakes, while unseasonably mild weather continued in the East.People in Alorton, Ill., a village of 2,700 about five milessoutheast of East St. Louis, were injured when tree fell on theirhouses or mobile home, said Bill Gamblin of the St. Clair CountyEmergency Services and Disaster Agency.At Parks College in Cahokia, Ill., eight mile south of East St.Louis, aircraft hanger were twisted and flattened and smallaircraft tossed around the airport by high wind, the NationalWeather Service said.Storms in the area generated wind estimated at 80 to 100 mph,the weather service said.The thunderstorm developed along and ahead of a strong coldfront and swept eastward from Missouri and Arkansas.Thunderstorms crossing northeastern Arkansas whipped up highwind which blew away metal roofing being installed on a high schoolgymnasium at Lepanto and dumped hail up to 2 inch in diameter atLeachville.Heavy thunderstorm, possibly a tornado, struck the northGeorgia town of Palmetto late Wednesday, causing extensive damage,authorities said.In central and southwest Ohio, thunderstorm packing wind up to66 mph destroyed barn and a trailer home and tore the roof offseveral building. Some injury but no fatality were reported.An afternoon thunderstorm in east-central Alabama formed atornado which damaged at least one home, and the Clay CountySheriff's office said an unknown number of people were injured inone house.Thunderstorms sweeping across Tennessee spun off a tornado insoutheastern Madison Country, and dropped hail a big a baseballsnorth of Jackson, the weather service said.Hail stone a big a tennis ball fell near Huntingburg, Ind.,the weather service said.The heaviest rainfall during the six hour up to 1 pm. EST was1.22 inch at Peru, Ind.Wind up to 65 mph damaged roof, power line and tree in partsof Kentucky and Louisiana, the weather service said.Severe thunderstorm also developed over Alabama and SouthCarolina during the afternoon, and the weather service reported atornado north of Greenwood, S.C.Other shower and thunderstorm, with locally heavy rain, werewidely scattered along the northern Atlantic Coast.Light snow associated with an arctic cold front extended fromeastern Wyoming and northeastern Colorado into western Minnesota.Snow also fell across part of northern Wisconsin and UpperMichigan.As much a 1 to 2 foot of snow wa possible by Thursday morningalong the Lake Superior shore of Wisconsin.Strong northwesterly wind ushering the cold air into thenorth-central state gusted above 40 mph during the afternoon,creating wind chill reading colder than 25 degree below zero.Snow, high wind and rapidly falling temperature associated withthe cold front briefly produced near-blizzard condition inNebraska late Wednesday morning.Unseasonably warm weather continued in the East with afternoonreadings in the 60 in New England, and in the 80 over Florida,southern Texas and southern Louisiana.Wednesday morning's low for the Lower 48 state wa 9 degreesabove zero at Ely, Nev.
column5: Powerful storm causes death and destruction across the United States.
column6: Tornadoes, high winds, and thunderstorms caused severe damage in Midwestern, Eastern, and Southeastern states. The worst area hit was Huntsville, AL where a tornado killed 14 people. Heavy winds caused the death of seven school children in Newburgh, NY, one person in New York City, and another in New Jersey.
column7: A powerful storm system brought tornadoes, high winds, heavy thunderstorms, and large hailstones across the Midwest, Mississippi Valley, Southeast and Northeast on Wednesday and Thursday. Twenty-seven people were killed, more than 500 injured, and hundreds left homeless. The tornadoes struck mostly across Midwestern and Southeastern states. A devastating tornado struck Huntsville, AL laying waste to a wide swath through the city and causing death to 14 people. A tornado killed four people in Palmetto, Georgia.Heavy winds caused the death of seven children in a school in Newburgh, NY, one person in Elizabeth, NJ, and another in New York City.
column8: A powerful storm system brought tornadoes, high winds, heavy thunderstorms, and large hailstones across the Midwest, Mississippi Valley, Southeast, and Northeast on Wednesday and Thursday. Reportedly, 27 people were killed, more than 500 injured, and hundreds left homeless. The storms developed ahead of a strong cold front sweeping eastward from Missouri and Arkansas.Tornadoes were reported in Indiana, Ohio, Kentucky, New Jersey, Maryland, Delaware, North Carolina, Georgia, Alabama, and Mississippi. The worst damage was in Huntsville, AL where a tornado laid waste a wide swath of the city and caused the death of 14 people. Four people were killed by a tornado in Palmetto, Georgia.  Sixty-five mph winds damaged Kentucky and Louisiana.Strong winds and heavy thunderstorms caused heavy damage in Illinois, the District of Columbia, Maryland, Delaware, New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania, and West Virginia. In Newburgh, New York, a tree crashed through a school roof killing at least seven children. One person was killed in Elizabeth, New Jersey and another in New York City. Thunderstorms dropped large hailstones in Indiana and Tennessee.Snow was falling from the northern Rockies to the Great Lakes. Storm warnings were also posted in Pennsylvania and cold weather was expected in the Southeast.
column9: Tornadoes and thunderstorms cause death and destruction in fourteen states.
column10: A series of tornadoes and sever thunderstorms swept through fourteen states and Washington, D.C. causing death and destruction.  At least 27 people have died, more than 500 are injured and hundreds are homeless.  The most severe damage was in Huntsville, Alabama.  The Governor asks that Huntsville be declared a disaster area.
column11: A violent storm spawned tornadoes and thunderstorms across the Midwest and South, then blew north knocking over a school cafeteria wall in upstate New York, killing seven children.  Altogether, fourteen states and Washington D.C. were affected.  The toll from the two-day storm is at least 27 dead and over 500 hundred injured.   Property damage is in the millions.  The worst damage by far was in Huntsville, Alabama where a tornado slammed into a shopping district, a residential area and a school, leaving at least 14 dead and injuring nearly 300.  The Governor called in State Troopers and the National Guard to assist.
column12: A violent storm that spawned tornadoes and thunderstorms across the Midwest and South then blew north knocking over a school cafeteria wall in upstate New York, killing seven children.  Altogether, fourteen states and Washington D.C. were affected.  The toll from the two-day storm is at least 27 dead and over 500 hundred injured.   Property damage is in the millions.  Hundreds have been left homeless and tens of thousands lost electricity.  The worst damage by far was in Huntsville, Alabama where a massive tornado slammed into a shopping district, a residential area and a school, leaving at least 14 dead and injuring nearly 300.  It touched down between 4 and 4:30 p.m. when city streets were filled with rush hour traffic.  Ike Carroll, a real estate broker, said, "It started picking up cars and pushing them around, some of them upside down, some of them strewn around.  Heavy overhead power lines started snapping just like a circus performer would snap his whip."  Governor Guy Hunt called in State Troopers from throughout the state to help.  He is also using the National Guard to assist in the cleanup and to protect against looting.  The Governor plans to ask President Bush to declare Huntsville a disaster area.

column3: Former President Reagan thanked British PrimeMinister Margaret Thatcher for backing him up when other alliesbacked down, heaping praise on his political soulmate a she headsoff into the sunset.Margaret Thatcher wa a completely reliable ally and partnerof the greatest personal integrity, Reagan said in a statementafter Mrs. Thatcher announced her impending retirement.I could always count on her wise counsel, her firm support,and her loyal friendship, Reagan saidMrs. Thatcher on Thursday succumbed to the challenge mounted byMichael Heseltine, who resigned a her defense minister in 1986.Reagan and the prime minister dubbed the Iron Lady formed aformidable duo in the 1980s and made no secret of their mutualregard. They often stood side-by-side at international gatheringsand called each other Ronnie and Margaret.Two year ago, a they met for the final time before Reagan leftoffice, the president said he wa leaving the White House withconsiderable satisfaction in the knowledge that Margaret Thatcherwill still reside at No. 10 Downing Street.Reagan, who spent Thanksgiving with friend at his Bel-Air home,called her resignation in the face of strong opposition aselfless and courageous decision in what she belief is the bestinterests of her country.The former chief executive wa always grateful to Mrs.Thatcher's support of his conservative approach to foreign affairsduring his own eight-year tenure.In 1986, when the US. bombing of Libya wa criticized by worldpowers, Mrs. Thatcher wa the only ally who supported Reagan andallowed the bomber to fly from British bases.When Britain fought Argentina for the Falkland Islands, theUnited States wa forced to choose between two ally. Reagan sidedwith Mrs. Thatcher.She also encouraged Reagan's nurturing of the huge Pentagonbuildup, and backed US. effort to install medium-range missilesin Europe, despite opposition from NATO allies.Both leader adopted a hard line toward the Soviet Union, butwere quick to warm up to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev asthe Cold War thawed.Reagan credited Mrs. Thatcher's resoluteness for playing akey role in ending the tension between the Western democracy andthe Eastern Block.She stood up to the Soviets and let them know she meantbusiness, he said.Both were ardent advocate of the free market and privateenterprise.While the United States became mired in debt in the era ofReaganomics, the British economy thrived on Mrs. Thatcher's radicalpolicies during her nearly 12-year rule. Average earnings were upby nearly one-third and more Britons owned their home during hertenor.Like Reagan, however, Mrs. Thatcher wa accused by liberal ofwidening the gap between the rich and poor in her country, and bothclashed with organized labor.For almost a decade, Margaret Thatcher wasregarded at the White House a America's best friend, the trustedally whose strong view reinforced the conservative tone ofadministration policies.Among Western ally, she wa alone at Ronald Reagan's side in1986 in supporting the US. bombing of Libya. In the Persian Gulfcrisis, she boldly joined with George Bush in sending troop to theMiddle East.You always know where she wa and what she believed, Bushsaid upon hearing of her decision to resign. She ha always beenan outstanding ally of the United States, he said. I will missher.There were many doubter around the world when Reagan arrived inWashington with an economic program of free-market capitalism thatseemed out of step with the time. Mrs. Thatcher wasn't one of theskeptics; she wa advocating a similar program at home.They shared rocky relation with organized labor. Reagansuccessfully fired the nation's air traffic controller, dealing adevastating blow to labor. She, too, smashed restive unions.On foreign policy, she frequently wa more right wing thanReagan - certainly more so than Bush.Reagan never made any secret of his special affection for theBritish prime minister. They were ideological soulmates and calledeach other Ronnie and Margaret. At international gathering, theyusually were side by side.Two year ago a they met for the final time before Reagan leftoffice, the president said he wa leaving the White House withconsiderable satisfaction in the knowledge that Margaret Thatcherwill still reside at No. 10 Downing Street.She later wrote him a Dear Ron letter in which she praisedhim a a great president, one of the greatest.Like Reagan, she wa deeply suspicious of the Soviet Union.Together they advocated a hard line toward Moscow and championedmilitary readiness - even though she wa the first to recognizeMikhail S. Gorbachev a a leader she could do business withMrs. Thatcher encouraged the huge Pentagon buildup that Reagannurtured under the theme of peace through strength. She wa a bigbacker of US. effort to install medium-range missile in Europeand always seemed cautious - perhaps reluctant - when it came todisarmament.When Argentina and Britain clashed militarily over the FalklandIslands, the United States wa forced to make a painful choicebetween two ally. Ronnie sided with Margaret.Washington's special relationship with London seemed to slipwhen Reagan left power. Bush and Mrs. Thatcher disagreed publiclylast year over her government's decision to deport Vietnamese andCambodian boat people who were fleeing their country to HongKong.Bush, a veteran of world politics, knew many leader around theglobe. Mrs. Thatcher suddenly seemed to be just one of the gang.The Berlin Wall wa collapsing and it appeared a if Bush foundGerman Chancellor Helmut Kohl more interesting than Mrs. Thatcher.She wa merely one in a parade of foreign dignitary who got theprized invitation to visit Bush at Camp David this year.Nevertheless, Bush said he expected the special relationshipbetween the United States and Great Britain to remain on a steadykeelMrs. Thatcher did her part, demonstrating her loyalty. Forawhile she and Bush were seemingly alone in their suspicion ofGorbachev's unilateral cutback in troop and arm in Europe, andappeared uncertain how to respond.Under intense pressure from Congress, Bush began to warm to theSoviet leader. Now they seem almost best of friends.On the Persian Gulf, Bush said he would not rule out possiblemilitary force, and ordered a huge buildup of troop to make histhreat credible. Mrs. Thatcher, characteristically, wa tougher.She said that unless Saddam Hussein got out of Kuwait soon, theWest would have to use military force to dislodge him.She called Saddam a loser, and the state-controlled Iraqinews agency replied that she wa an old hag.Now, she is leaving. No one suspect that Britain's newleadership - whoever it is - will take a soft line toward Iraq.Yet, if the going get tough, it might have been comforting forBush to be able to hear the tough old line from Thatcher.Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's internationaladmirers praised her courage and achievement Thursday after sheannounced she would resign. Even her foe tempered scorn withpraise for a formidable adversary.Said President Bush, I will miss her.He called her an outstanding ally of the United Statesadding, You always knew where she wa and what she believed.Vitaly Ignatenko, spokesman for Soviet President MikhailGorbachev, told the independent Interfax news agency: Political,economic and cultural tie between our country have become ofgreater importance in the Thatcher era. Our relation . weremarked by constructivism and dialogue.The reluctance Mrs. Thatcher showed toward increasing Europeanunity wa the source of most criticism. But in a joyful andunambiguous response, Iraq saw the Persian Gulf crisis a cause ofher downfall.Bitterness wa undisguised in the comment from Argentina'sNicanor Costa Mendez, foreign minister during his country's 1982Falklands War with Britain.I can't say that it make me sad, he said. I believe thatthe extreme position - unnecessarily extreme, unjustifiablyextreme - of the prime minister were one of the cause of the war,and one of the biggest impediment to achieve agreement after.Socialist President Mario Soares of Portugal singled out hersystematic opposition to the advance of the European Community.During her long mandate, he said, the preoccupation ofsocial justice receded many time before purely developmentobjectives, causing a climate of discontent in British publicopinion to which Mrs. Thatcher appeared insensitive.But Soares also lauded the British prime minister a adetermined politician (who) took courageous position on criticaloccasions in international life and without doubt marked an era inthe contemporary history of her country.German Finance Minister Theo Waigel noted, Despite hercritical position on some question of European integration, sheaccomplished a great deal for European politics.A neutral letter from Socialist President Francois Mitterrand ofFrance told Mrs. Thatcher she had marked an important moment inthe history of your country and that of Europe.Iraqi government spokesman Naji al-Hadithi said growingopposition to her hard line against Iraq over it invasion ofKuwait buried Mrs. Thatcher just a the 1956 crisis overBritain's attack on the Suez Canal ruined former Prime MinisterAnthony Eden.Britain stepped in after Egypt nationalized the canal.On Thursday, Britain announced it wa nearly doubling it troopsdeployed in the gulf a part of the multinational force arrayedagainst Iraq, sending 14,000 more soldier to join the 16,000already in the region.South African President FW. de Klerk praised Mrs. Thatcher, whoopposed sanction on South Africa, for standing up to worldpressure and standing by Pretoria.She had faith in South Africa's ability to solve it problemsin a democratic way . She had the courage of her convictions,he said.Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel saidafter hearing ofher resignation that Israel feel a moment of sorrow because weall know this special personality, Mrs. Thatcher, who did manythings and wa an outstanding leader.Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan said the British primeminister is a rare leader of firm conviction who wa invigoratedthe United Kingdom and I feel great regret that she ha withdrawnfrom the front line.Belgium's prime minister, Wilfried Martens, applauded thedetermining role she played during more than 10 year in her owncountry and on the international scene.Said Prime Minister Bob Hawke of Australia, Even those likemyself who have been at odds with Margaret Thatcher on particularissues have admired her courage and tenacity of purpose.Whatever the force arrayed against her, she wa alwaysprepared to pursue with the utmost vigor those position in whichshe believed.Dutch Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers said, In the many year thatshe placed such an important stamp on the policy of the UnitedKingdom, Mrs. Thatcher ha shown that she doe not avoid makingdifficult decision that she deems to be in the nation's interest.This, too, is such a decision which deserves respect.Former French President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, now alegislator in the European Parliament, said Mrs. Thatcher'sdecision to quit wa dignified and courageous.Margaret Thatcher will be seen with Winston Churchill a thegreatest British prime minister of the last 50 year. The curtainhas fallen on the Iron Lady. She deserves our congratulations.Even European Commission President Jacques Delors, Mrs.Thatcher's archenemy in Europe, spoke of his high esteem forher, despite their differences.Alfred Dregger, parliamentary leader of Germany's governingChristian Democratic Union, said Mrs. Thatcher played a major rolein securing Western solidarity in the historical conflict forfreedom and democracy. We thank her for that.Former President Reagan spoke with great warmth of his closestforeign ally.Margaret Thatcher's resoluteness played a key role in endingthe Cold War, he said. She stood up to the Soviets and let themknow she meant business. Her deep and abiding dedication to theprinciples of liberty and democracy served a an inspiration tooppressed people everywhere who knew that Margaret Thatcher wouldnever waver in her belief that all men and woman are entitled tolive in freedom.Margaret Thatcher set the example of what a womancould achieve in British society, but her critic say she didlittle else to help woman along.For some, it wa enough that her political career reached theheights.One woman wrote to The Independent newspaper last week that her7-year-old daughter wondered what title Mrs. Thatcher's successorwould hold, since he couldn't be called prime minister, that's agirl's name.Emma Nicholson, a Conservative Party lawmaker, said it wa onceunthinkable that a woman would ever be a British prime minister.She ha broken the mold once and forever, Ms. Nicholson said inan interviewMrs. Thatcher, who trained a a chemist before studying law,said she viewed herself a prime minister, not a a woman. Shebelieved the battle for women's right had been largely won and wasno believer in feminism.What ha it ever done for me? she once askedMrs. Thatcher, who stepped down on Thursday, urged woman to getinvolved in politics, but did little to pull them up the ladder.Several female lawmaker were appointed to junior executiveposts in various ministry, but the only woman to serve in aThatcher Cabinet wa Baroness Young, leader of the House of Lordsfrom 1981 to 1983.The truth is that although Mrs. Thatcher is a woman, shedoesn't believe in the advancement of woman, Clare Short, a LaborParty lawmaker, said last month.Edwina Currie, a former junior health minister, said any otherprime minister would have had several woman in and out of theCabinet.It's Margaret's fault that the only people standing (tosucceed her) wear trouser, Mrs. Currie said last week. Trree menare vying to succeed her a Conservative Party leader and thusprime minister in a vote by party lawmaker set for Tuesday.Traditional male attitude remain strong in Britain, from theupper-crust, all-male club of London to the topless woman pictureddaily in the tabloid press.Women are paid le than men and are poorly represented inmanagement job and in Parliament.However, campaigner for woman right say there are encouragingsigns at the grassroots.The critical mass of woman have entered middle management ingovernment and business, said Lesley Abdela, a founding member ofthe 300 Group.The group seek equal representation for woman in the 650-seatHouse of Commons, which now ha 43 female members.Women represented 43 percent of the British labor force in 1988,compared with 40 percent in 1979 when Mrs. Thatcher became primeminister. Britain ha a higher proportion of working woman thanother European Community countries.Though Mrs. Thatcher never made a priority of women's issues,she did introduce some helpful legislation: tax concession forworkplace nurseries; independent taxation for married women; andlegislation to compel absent father to pay child benefits.But a prime minister, she angered feminist by oftenemphasizing women's traditional role of homemaker andcare-givers.Angela Rumbold, the Conservative Party's minister for women'sissues, contends that an enormous amount ha been done forwomen during the Thatcher years.I'm not sure what she could have gone beyond promoting peoplewho were there just because they were woman, she said in aninterview. Margaret Thatcher is a great meritocrat. She believesin getting people to succeed on their merits.Jo Hawkins of the 300 Group, which is seeking equal number ofwomen in the House of Commons, belief Mrs. Thatcher'sextraordinary ability made it difficult for her to understand theneeds of the average woman.She would say that anybody can do it, just stick to yourprinciples and get up and do it, Ms. Hawkins said. I thinkbecause of her character, her personality and her amazingself-confidence, she isn't aware of how the normal personstruggles.Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher ha weakened herposition and kicked off the race to succeed her by saying she plansto step down after winning another term, opposition leader andpolitical observer said.A pro-Thatcher newspaper today said she had merely stated theobvious and that her statement were no cause for astonishmentMrs. Thatcher told The Sunday Correspondent in an interviewpublished Sunday that she hoped to lead her Conservative Party to afourth successive election but said it wa unlikely she would tryfor a fifth.I think people would think it wa time for someone else tocarry the torch, she told the newspaper.The Sunday Times of London said in a commentary: Mrs. Thatcherhas committed a colossal blunder.She ha given the rider for the Tory succession theirstarting order year in advance of the actual race, thenewspaper said.The next election must be held by the summer of 1992, but it isexpected Mrs. Thatcher will call it in 1991Mrs. Thatcher, who turned 64 last month, ha never previouslymade it clear in public when she plan to retire a party leader.She wa elected in 1979, the first female prime minister in Europe,and won re-election in 1983 and in 1987, when she said she plannedto go on and on.Earlier this year, Mrs. Thatcher overtook Liberal Lord Asquith's1908-1916 tenure a prime minister to become Britain's longestcontinuously serving prime minister of the 20th centuryMrs. Thatcher's popularity is the lowest of any prime ministersince opinion poll began in Britain 50 year ago, and seniorcolleagues have publicly admonished her to change her leadershipstyle following the surprise resignation of her treasury chief,Nigel Lawson.Lord Callaghan, former Labor prime minister whom Mrs. Thatcherdefeated in 1979, said her comment had considerably weakened herposition.If her party win the next election, it is expected Mrs.Thatcher would step down before her term end to allow hersuccessor to choose a time to call a new election.My guess is that the Tory party will want someone a leaderwho could take them through the next Parliament, Callaghan said.If Mrs. Thatcher resigns while in office, her successor electedby the party automatically becomes prime minister with approval ofQueen Elizabeth II, but convention dictate that he or she seek amandate in a general election a soon a possible.The Sunday Times speculated she would step down by 1994. Mrs.Thatcher would celebrate her 69th birthday that year and herhusband, Denis, will be 79 and his age may have been a factor inher decision, the newspaper said.The newspaper predicted the opposition Labor Party will try topromote leader Neil Kinnock a the occupant-in-waiting of 10Downing St., who is ready, able and willing to complete a fullterm.Kinnock called Mrs. Thatcher's comment the interview ofsomeone preparing herself for quitting. Mentally, Margaret Thatcheris preparing herself for packing her bags.In an editorial today, the pro-Thatcher Daily Telegraph saidMrs. Thatcher wa merely stating the obvious by indicating shewould not seek a fifth term.Even were she not to fight a fifth election, Mrs. Thatchercould yet enjoy seven more year in charge, it said.By then she would be in her 70, and her devoted husband adecade older . Nonetheless, what other politician would beexpected to entertain an inquiry about his or her intention inseven year time? And can it really be a cause for astonishmentthat Mrs. Thatcher is unwilling to commit herself to politicalactivity in her mid-70s and beyond?
column5: Britain's Iron Lady, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, resigns on Thursday.
column6: The Iron Lady of British politics, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, retired on Thursday. Her retirement, which took world leaders by surprise, followed a decision by her cabinet members not to support her in an upcoming vote. Mrs. Thatcher served longer than any other prime minister in the 20th Century.
column7: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher resigned on Thursday after her cabinet withdrew its support in an upcoming vote. The move was seen as an attempt to head off a campaign by former defense minister Hazeltine to wrest control of the Conservative Party. The announcement took President Bush, and other world leaders, by surprise. Mrs. Thatcher's special relationship with the Reagan administration was well known. Strong willed, the Iron Lady, was prime minister for over 11 years, longer than any other prime minister of this century. While prime minister, she is credited with turning around the declining British economy as well as helping shape international politics.
column8: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, the Iron Lady of British politics, resigned Thursday. Serving for over 11 years, longer than any prime minister in the 20th Century, the announcement of her resignation took the world by surprise. Mrs. Thatcher was the first woman prime minister in Great Britain and is credited with reviving the faltering British economy in the early '80s. Former President Reagan had nothing but praise for Mrs. Thatcher. While he was still in office, the two shared a special relationship, calling each other Margaret and Ronnie and often appearing together at international gatherings. The relationship with American cooled with the coming of the Bush administration but had improved in recent months. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev also had nothing but praise for Mrs. Thatcher and her attitude to the Soviet Union softened after her meeting with him. Her critics were not less vocal. Iraq rejoiced at her departure, while Argentina was guarded it its comments. Critics at home complained about her lack of sensitivity to women's issues. Queen Elizabeth II, awarded Mrs. Thatcher the Order of Merit on Friday while elevating her husband, Denis, to the hereditary title of baronet, dispelling rumors of animosity between the two women.

column3: A ranking member of Chancellor HelmutKohl's party demanded the Soviet Union hand over Erich Honecker,who is wanted by German authority on manslaughter charge, anewspaper reported on Saturday.Federal lawmaker Johannes Gerster said refusal to turn over thedeposed East German leader for trial could burden Bonn andMoscow's outstanding relation, the Neue Osnabruecker Zeitungnewspaper reported.A Berlin court ha issued an arrest warrant for Honecker, 78, onthe manslaughter charge. He is accused of issuing shoot-to-killorders to East German guard at the now-fallen Berlin Wall.Honecker ha denied all charge against him, including that hewas personally responsible for the estimated 200 people who diedtrying to escape his repressive government.He ha taken refuge at a Soviet military hospital in Beelitz,outside Berlin.Soviet official have said Honecker is staying at the hospitalfor humanitarian reason, and German police need permission fromthe Soviets to gain entry.I demand that the Soviet government immediately release ErichHonecker and extradite him to German justice official, theOsnabrueck newspaper quoted Gerster, a member of Kohl's ChristianDemocrats, a saying.Honecker's fate is one of the first issue facing Bonn andMoscow since they signed several treaty designed to draw the twonations closer together.Ousted East German leader Erich Honecker, whois expected to be indicted for high treason, wa arrested Mondaymorning upon release from a hospital and taken to prison, theofficial news agency ADN said.The news agency said the 77-year-old Honecker wa arrested afterbeing released from East Berlin's Charite hospital, where he hadundergone surgery for a malignant kidney tumor.Honecker wa immediately taken to East Berlin's Rummelsburgprison, the brief dispatch said. Honecker join other member ofhis ousted Politburo already in prison awaiting trial.Earlier this month, East German prosecutor said Honecker andformer state security chief Erich Mielke would be charged withtreason and corruption charge for misuse of their position andstate funds.Honecker, the aging hard-line Stalinist leader who ruled EastGermany for 18 year until his ouster on Oct. 18, had previouslybeen declared too ill to withstand imprisonment.ADN said that the director of Charite urology clinic, Dr. PeterAlthaus, repeated on Monday that in his opinion Honecker wa stillnot well enough to be jailed.On Sunday, West Germany's mass-circulation Bild newspaper saidHonecker would be arrested, but that he would be held at a prisonhospital because of his condition. ADN made not mention ifRummelsburg prison wa equipped with a medical facility.Earlier this month, East Germany's Luthern Church had offered toput Honecker up in a home for the aged upon his release from thehospital.East Germany's ousted secret policechief threatened to break former Communist leader Erich Honecker'sneck when the two faced each other in jail, a West German newspaperreported Wednesday.You traitor! 82-year-old former security chief Erich Mielkeshouted at Honecker, according to Bild newspaper.Mielke also screamed at Honecker I'll break your neck! thenewspaper quoted witness a describing the scene when the two metin an East German jail. Honecker, 78, wa jailed for one day inJanuary.Mielke for year headed the dreaded secret police, known asStasi, which built up file on 6 million East Germans and kept atight rein on the population. He wa one of Honecker's closestaides.After the popular revolt last fall that ousted the Communistregime and opened the way to German unification, Mielke and otherformer Communist leader were jailed.Mielke remains in custody. Honecker wa released from jail forhealth reasons.West German authority on Tuesday opened a criminalinvestigation of Mielke. He is suspected of giving sanctuary tomembers of West Germany's leftist terrorist group, the Red ArmyFaction, and of setting up contact between the group andPalestinian guerrillas.Honecker is also the target of several criminal investigations,one in West Germany for obstruction of justice.Bild said the imprisoned Mielke also accused other formerCommunist official of betrayal and threatened to retaliate againstthem.One prison warden told Bild that many of the guard had workedfor Mielke's Stasi and that they might interpret his threat againstHonecker a an order to kill the former Communist chief.Bild said Mielke and other member of Honecker's ruling circlewill be moved to a West Berlin prison after German unification onOct. 3.Honecker also will be moved to the same jail if his healthimproves enough for him to be imprisoned. He is suffering fromkidney cancer and is being kept at a Soviet military hospitaloustide East Berlin.Former East German leader ErichHonecker may be moved to a monastery to protect him from a possiblelynching by enraged citizen, a newspaper said Wednesday.In a front-page story, the mass-circulation Bild newspaper saidLynch Danger Church Wants to Grant Honecker Asylum.Since Honecker wa ousted Oct. 18, the former Communist Partyleader and other party official have come under investigation forcharges of corruption and living in luxury at the cost of the state.In December, seven former Politburo member were arrested, andHonecker wa placed under house arrest in the government housingarea of Wandlitz outside East Berlin.The Wandlitz home, including the one in which Honecker stilllives, are being converted to a medical rehabilitation center forchildren. Honecker is expected to be forced out of the compound inFebruary.Bild said it had information that Lutheran and Catholic churchsources have offered Honecker who is threated by public rage protection and refuge.This is the only possibility to protect Erich Honecker fromthe rage of the East German people, Bild quoted the source assaying.It wa the church that became the venue for gathering ofpro-democracy group that eventually brought the overthrow of his18-year leadership.In recent week, East German group have called for punishingHonecker and for moving him to smaller quarter with an outsidetoilet, Bild said.The current leadership fear that in such a situation, Honeckermight be attacked and become a victim of lynch justice, Bildsaid.Honecker, 77, underwent gall-bladder surgery in August, and EastGerman medium reported he remains seriously ill.Sources say the ailing ex-leader may be placed in achurch-operated home for the elderly, or even in a monastery,Bild reported.East Germany's deposed Communist leader ErichHonecker is too sick to be held in jail but is fit enough to betried, the official news agency ADN reported Monday.ADN, quoting a Health Ministry statement, said Honecker wasstill recovering from surgery for kidney cancer in January and wasnot well enough to be incarcerated.But a medical exam by a team of doctor found him in conditionto be questioned and to stand trial, ADN said.Honecker, 77, ruled East Germany for 19 year until he wasousted in October a a wave of pro-democracy demonstration sweptthe country, leading to the peaceful overthrow of the Communistgovernment and the opening of the Berlin Wall.The medical panel concluded that seven other former Communistofficials, who had been among Honecker's closest aide, were allfit to prosecute and to be placed in custody, ADN said.It said former secret police chief Erich Mielke, formereconomics czar Guenter Mittag and former labor chief Harry Tischwere under arrest, while the other four remained free. All threehad been member of the ruling Politburo under Honecker. Mielke wasarrested on Thursday.Honecker and the seven are charged with corruption and abuse ofoffice. They had been arrested soon after Honecker's fall but werelater released because of advanced age and poor health.Honecker ha been staying at a Soviet military hospital outsideEast Berlin.ADN quoted Federal Prosecutor Guenter Seidel a saying heintended to continue his investigation against the former EastGerman leader, although their poor health often disrupted theproceedings.BFN[Text] Berlin -- Erich Honecker, the former GDR head of state, died at his house in Santiago, Chile on Sunday morning [29 May], according to his lawyer. Lawyer Nicolas Becker, who had represented 81-year-old Honecker before the Berlin court in 1992 and early 1993, told DPA on Sunday afternoon that Honecker had rejected an operation. However, everything that wa sensible had been done with regard to his cancer.Becker could not comment on the exact cause of Honecker's death. His colleague, Wolfgang Ziegler, had said earlier that the former most powerful man in the GDR had obviously died from his liver cancer.Becker said he did not know whether Honecker ha left a will or where the funeral would be held. This will be decided by the family.He also said he cannot say whether Margot Honecker, who had informed Becker of her husband's death, will be allowed to stay in Chile. After being released from prison in 1993, Honecker had traveled to Santiago to join his daughter, who is married to a Chilean. Since then, he and his wife had been living in a house in a wealthy Santiago area.Ousted East German leader Erich Honecker willnot stand trial in East Germany a long a the formerly Communistcountry exists, a West German newspaper reported.The Hamburg-based Bild am Sonntag said Saturday that it wouldreport in it Sunday edition that Honecker could be prosecuted ina united Germany, however, for violation of property laws.Bild quoted Guenter Seidel, an East German prosecutor, a sayingthat Honecker had used $42 million for stocking a private housingestate for leader of the former Communist government.However, Seidel said that the investigation wa not far enoughalong to determine whether charge could be filed against Honeckerbefore East Germany merges with West Germany on Oct. 3.Negotiators are still working out the merger of the two Germanlegal systems.Honecker, 78, wa ousted a East Germany's leader on Oct. 18,paving the way for the country's first freely elected government inMarch. Honecker is in poor health and remains confined to a Sovietmilitary hospital in Beelitz outside East Berlin.He is under investigation on allegation of abuse of powercorruption, harboring terrorist and issuing shoot-to-kill ordersto prevent East Germans from escaping to West Germany when heserved a the country's leader.Bild said that Erich Mielke, the ex-head of East Germany'sformer secret police, wa also unlikely to go to court in EastGermany.I am at the end. I am a dead man, Bild quoted Mielke, 82, assaying at his last interrogation.Ousted East German leader Erich Honecker wasarrested and taken to prison today, and a prosecutor said he willtried for high treason in March.Honecker, 77, wa detained after his release from East Berlin'sCharite hospital, where he had undergone surgery for a malignantkidney tumor, the official ADN news agency said.Chief Prosecutor Hans-Juergen Joseph told Parliament thatHonecker and former Politburo member Erich Mielke, Guenter Mittagand Joachim Herrmann would be tried by the Supreme Court on treasoncharges in March. All four have been expelled from the party.Mielke wa Honecker's security chief, Mittag oversaw the economyand Herrmann headed the party's propaganda department. Elevenmembers of Honecker's ousted Politburo already are in prisonawaiting trial.Honecker's lawyer, Wolfgang Vogel, asked the chief prosecutor tofree the former leader from Rummelburg prison based on a doctor'sstatement that he is too ill to stay in jail, ADN said. Vogel isEast Germany's most prominent lawyer.One of Honecker's doctor, Horst Vogler, said the former leaderwas very depressed and his mental state impaired followingtwo major surgical operation since August.West German television showed an impassive Honecker being ledout of the hospital by his wife, Margot, in pre-dawn darkness. Shekissed him goodbye before he wa taken away in a large limousine.Honecker's daughter, son-in-law and youngest grandchild alsocame to see him off at the hospital, ADN quoted Vogler a saying.The charge of high treason carry a maximum life imprisonment.The conviction used to carry the death penalty, but that wasabolished in reform that followed Honecker's ouster Oct. 18.East Germany ha been caught up in a virtual frenzy to root outcorruption and abuse of office.Honecker, the aging hard-line Stalinist leader who ruled EastGermany for 18 year, had previously been declared too ill towithstand imprisonment.ADN said the director of Charite urology clinic, Dr. PeterAlthaus, repeated today that in his opinion Honecker is still notwell enough to be jailed.On Sunday, West Germany's mass-circulation Bild newspaper saidHonecker would be arrested but that he would be held at a prisonhospital because of his condition. ADN did not say whetherRummelsburg prison is equipped with a medical facility.Earlier this month, East Germany's Luthern Church had offered toput Honecker up in a home for the aged upon his release from thehospital.East Germany authority on Fridayinterrogated former Communist leader Erich Honecker about his rolein the killing of people who tried to flee the country.Honecker and Erich Mielke, head of East Germany's once-fearedsecret police agency, were interrogated by federal prosecutors,said Peter Przybylski, a Justice Ministry spokesman.More than 200 people were shot to death or killed by land minesas they tried to escape from East Germany's Communist rule.The government announced in June that Honecker, Mielke andseveral border guard would be investigated on possible murdercharges in connection with those deaths.Honecker, 77 and in failing health, and several other member ofhis ousted regime already have been charged with corruption andabuse of power.The murder charge could put Honecker behind bar for life, buthis poor health make prosecution questionable. He is staying in aSoviet hospital outside Berlin.Last month, a medical panel ruled that Honecker wa too ill tobe jailed pending investigation but fit enough to be prosecuted.Mielke wa ordered jailed.East Germany's democratic government ha changed it mindseveral time on whether to pursue charge against the agingmembers of the former hard-line regime that wa toppled in lastautumn's pro-democracy protests.As protest gathered strength last fall, EastGermany's longtime orthodox leader Erich Honecker lost touch withreality, according to the man who succeeded him a Communistleader only to be ousted later.Egon Krenz, the successor, and former Politburo member GuenterSchabowski on Wednesday gave their version of the bunker mentalitythat engulfed the hard-liners toward the end.There wa the notion in the former party leadership thateverything outside of planned event and demonstration staged bythe Communist youth group wa an action organized by enemyforces, Krenz told an investigating commission in East Berlin.The testimony wa broadcast on East German television.Schabowski said Honecker had personally ordered police attacksagainst demonstrator in early October, working closely with histhen-secret police chief, Erich Mielke.Honecker took thing into his own hand, Schabowski said.All decision and order that led to the police action againstdemonstrators and to their arrrest went exclusively throughHonecker and Mielke.Like Krenz, Schabowski denied any personal responsibility forthe order to attack the demonstrator in the capital.The attempt at suppression were engineered by Honecker andMielke, bypassing the other 19 member of the ruling Politburo,Krenz insisted.Then-general secretary Erich Honecker and the internalsecurity chief Erich Mielke immediately after each session of thePolitburo consulted with each other on the security situation ofthe German Democratic Republic, Krenz said.Honecker and Mielke are now targeted for an indictment for hightreason.The East Berlin city government commission is probing possiblecriminal charge stemming from police brutality during the Octoberattacks in the capital.Club-swinging riot police brutally beat demonstrator on Oct. 7and 8, when Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev wa in town tocommemorate the country's 40th anniversary. The uprising wa aturning point that speeded Honecker's downfall 10 day later.Krenz, who had responsibility for many internal securityfunctions before Honecker's ouster, criticized the use of forceduring his testimony Wednesday.The excessive action of law enforcement authority wasneither politically nor morally justifiable, he told the panel,speaking confidently and wearing a gray suit.Krenz, who wa thrown out six week after succeeding Honecker onOct. 18, insisted he knew nothing about any order to shootdemonstrators. Numerous news medium account have said Honeckereither planned or issued such orders.Krenz said he accepted joint responsibility for misjudgingdissident citizen and dissident group for years.From today's viewpoint it is incomprehensible that there wasno general Politburo discussion about the negative developmentsthen taking place in society, said Krenz, an influentialPolitburo member even before Honecker's fall.Krenz added that he and other then-members of the Politburofailed to realize that the Roman Catholic and Lutheran churcheswere not working against but rather for the German DemocraticRepublic.Honecker had lost touch with reality and had unrealisticperspectives, Krenz said of his one-time patron, who for yearstreated him like a son.Honecker ha been in ill health following gallbladder surgerylast summer. He wa recently operated on for a malignant kidneytumor.Krenz's current occupation ha not been publicized, followinghis fall a party chief on Dec. 3.Germany want to try him for ordering the shooting of people who attemptedto flee to the West during his year in power. But speculation lingers thatGerman politician have little real interest in trying a man who may possessembarrassing secrets.;"Let's forget about the issue of Erich Honecker forseveral day. Let's hope this special issue will be resolved," Gorbachev'sspokesman, Andrei Grachev, quoted the Soviet president a telling Germanmedia.;But Tass quoted Gorbachev a saying he did not exclude thepossibility that Honecker would leave Russia for North Korea in the next fewdays.;Gorbachev had served a Honecker's protector until the Sovietleader's political fortune declined. Last week Russia abruptly orderedHonecker to leave the country or face expulsion.;North Korean and Russiandiplomats confirmed that talk were held Tuesday about a North Korean offerfor Honecker to travel to Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, for medicaltreatment.;Li Cher Gvan, a consul at the North Korean Embassy, said acommercial North Korean airliner remained at Moscow's Sheremetyevo Airportready to fly Honecker to Pyongyang. But he said his country wa still awaitinga positive reply from the Russian government on the offer to accept Honecker.The Russian Foreign Ministry said it had not yet formulated a response.; Outside the Chilean Embassy, several dozen demonstrator continued theirvigil, demanding humane treatment for Honecker.
column9: Honecker, former head of East Germany, arrested and charged following his ouster by pro-democracy forces.
column10: Erich Honecker, former head of East Germany, died in 1994 in Chile.  He had lived there since his release from prison in 1993.  Honecker was toppled from power in 1989 after 18 years of his oppressive regime.  Following his downfall, he was arrested and charged with treason, corruption, abuse of power and manslaughter.
column11: Erich Honecker, former head of East Germany, died on 29 May 1994 in Santiago Chile. He had been living there since his release from prison in 1993.  Honecker and his regime were toppled in October 1989,  by  pro-democracy demonstrators, leading to the eventual unification of East and West Germany.  He, along with several members of his Politburo, were arrested and charges with treason, corruption, and abuse of power.  Honecker was also charged with manslaughter, stemming from his orders, which resulted in the deaths of East Germans attempting to flee to the West.  Honecker ruled East Germany for 18 years by using extreme repression.
column12: Erich Honecker, former head of East Germany, died on 29 May 1994 in Santiago Chile.  He and his wife Margot had been living with their daughter in Santiago since his release from prison in 1993.  Honecker and the Communist regime he headed, were toppled in October 1989 by pro-democracy demonstrators, leading to the eventual unification of Germany.  He along with several members of his Politburo were arrested and charged with treason, corruption and abuse of power.  Honecker was also charged with manslaughter, stemming from his shoot-to-kill order, which resulted in the deaths of East Germans attempting to flee to the West.  Honecker had been seriously ill since his downfall and had spent much time in hospital and under house arrest. Honecker ruled East Germany for 18 years using his secret police, known as Stasi, which built up files on 6 million East Germans and kept a tight rein on the population.  As protests gathered strength in the fall of 1989, Honecker "lost touch with reality" according to former members of his regime.  Club swinging police brutally beat demonstrators, when Soviet President Gorbachev was in town to commemorate the country's 40th anniversary.  The uprising was a turning point that speeded Honecker's downfall days later.
column13: The trials and tribulations of East German leader Erich Honecker.
column14: In 1989, former East German leader Erich Honecker was arrested to await trial for treason, corruption, and possible murder charges. Judged too ill for imprisonment, he was placed in an East German hospital. In 1992, he was tried, imprisoned, and released in 1993. He died in Santiago, Chile in 1994.
column15: In October 1989, after being hospitalized for kidney surgery, former East German leader Erich Honecker--along with other Party officials--was arrested and imprisoned to await trial for treason and corruption. Judged too ill from imprisonment, he was placed in a Soviet East Berlin hospital. He also faced a murder charge about his role in killing people trying to escape from East Berlin.In 1992, Honecker took refuge in the Chilean Embassy in Moscow but was soon ordered to leave. In Germany, he was tried, imprisoned and released in 1993. He died in Santiago, Chile in 1994 at age 81.
column16: Former East German leader Erich Honecker was under house arrest outside East Berlin since being ousted in October 1989. Honecker and other party officials have been investigated for corruption and treason. After hospitalization for kidney surgery, he was arrested and imprisoned to await trial. Judged too ill for imprisonment but fit enough for prosecution, he was placed in a Soviet East Berlin hospital.In August, Honecker was interrogated about his role in the killing of some 200 people trying to escape from East Berlin. A murder charge would put him away for life. His trial was delayed because of East German-West German merger negotiations. In December, Soviet authorities refused to return him to Germany claiming it would "burden" Moscow and Bonn's "outstanding relations."In December 1991, Honecker took refuge in the Chilean Embassy in Moscow. Gorbachev was his protector until his political fortunes declined and he ordered Honecker to leave the country. He was tried and imprisoned in Germany in early 1992 but was released in 1993. He traveled to Santiago, Chile to join his daughter who had married a Chilean. He lived with his wife in a wealthy Santiago area where he died in 1994 at age 81.

column3: The expensive practice of using ballooncatheters to force open heart artery immediately after heartattacks, now routinely done at many large hospital, is unnecessaryand should be abandoned, according to a major study released Tuesday.The study found that if heart attack victim quickly receiveclot-dissolving drug, they usually don't need the extra step of thecommon balloon procedure, known a angioplasty.Some expert said the result are good news, because they meanthat most heart attack patient can be treated in communityhospitals, where angioplasty is not available.The study also ha an important financial message. Its authorsestimated that if angioplasty wa widely adopted after heartattacks, it could raise the nation's annual medical bill by $704million.This trial ha settled one of the most important question inmodern-day cardiology, commented Dr. J. Ward Kennedy of theUniversity of Washington, Seattle.The study is phase 2 of the Thrombolysis in Miocardial InfarctionTrial, or TIMI-II, directed by Dr. Eugene Braunwald of Brigham andWomen's Hospital in Boston.The first phase of the study showed that giving people aclot-dissolving drug called tissue plasminogen activator, or TPA,immediately after heart attack dramatically improved their chancesof survival.The latest study, presented at the annual meeting of the AmericanHeart Association, wa intended to see whether people did betterstill if doctor tried to clear away any remaining blockage aftergiving TPA.At 50 hospital across the United States, doctor randomlyassigned 1,636 patient to get angioplasty within two day of theirheart attack if test showed there wa any chance they mightbenefit. Sixty percent of them actually underwent the procedure,which temporarily inflates balloon in dangerously narrowed heartarteries to squeeze them open.A comparison group of 1,626 also got TPA. But they were notconsidered for angioplasty unless they had lingering heart pain orabnormal exercise test during their recovery.After 42 day, 11 percent of those in the angioplasty group haddied or suffered further heart attack, a did 10 percent of thosein the comparison group.A year after the treatment, there wa no difference in survival.About 93 percent of both group were still alive.There doe not appear to be any additional benefit fromangioplasty, Braunwald saidDr. Thomas J. Ryan of Boston University Medical Center commented,We have the answer in this trial to a very important question ofhealth care delivery.While small hospital can give clot-dissolving drug to heartattack patient, most of them do not have the sophisticated labswhere angioplasty is performed.If the study had found that immediate angioplasty improvessurvival, it would have meant that many more angioplasty lab wouldneed to be established and more doctor trained to give theprocedure.The watch word is watchful waiting to see if patient needangioplasty. This ultimately make it possible for patient to betreated in community hospital and be transfered to terciary carecenters if angioplasty is needed, said Dr. Howard Morgan,immediate past president of the heart association.Heart attack occur when a clot block an artery that feed theheart muscle. The purpose of TPA and similar drug is to dissolvethese clot before the muscle dy.
