I'd have to blacken my teeth first, he quipped,alluding to the Academy's fondness for actor who portray bum anddowntrodden characters.Alfred Hitchcock also had a lighthearted comment on why hefailed to win an Oscar: I suppose it wa a matter ofcarelessness.The overlooking of classic film and the industry's mosttalented filmmaker ha provided historian with cause for dispute.For example, Citizen Kane, which customarily place No. 1 onpolls of the greatest American film, wa nominated in 1941 forbest picture (there were 10 nominee in those days), for OrsonWelles' performance, direction and co-scripting with HermanMankiewicz, Gregg Toland's camera work, plus art direction, sound,music and editing.The only Oscar for Citizen Kane wa for the script. HowGreen Was My Valley wa named best picture.Billy Wilder's classic comedy, Some Like It Hot, failed tobe nominated a best picture, a did Chaplin's Modern Times,Hawks' Red River and Woody Allen's Manhattan.Oh, well. Oscar might use Joe E. Brown's final line from SomeLike It Hot: Nobody's perfect.The Oscar statuette, one of the mostrecognizable image in the entertainment world, ha no copyrightprotection, a federal judge ha ruled.The small Academy Award statue is part of the public domain,US. District Court Judge Laughlin Waters said in a ruling releasedThursday.The decision wa a setback for the Academy of Motion PictureArts and Sciences, which had sued a Chicago-based manufacturer ofan employee-incentive trophy similar to the Oscar.Academy President Karl Malden said the ruling come a a shockto me. The academy said it would appeal.The academy claimed that the Star Award, the trophy look-alikemade by Creative House Promotions, violated copyright law, dilutedthe academy's trademark and represented unfair competition.The Star Award depicted a naked, muscular male much like theOscar, just two inch shorter and holding a star instead of asword. It had a gold finish similar to the Oscar, and stood on acircular gold cap mounted on a cylindrical base.Although Waters acknowledged that the Creative House trophy isvery similar to the Oscar, he rejected all of the academy'slegal claim, saying that the statuette became part of the publicdomain prior to Jan. 1, 1978, the effective date of the CopyrightAct of 1976.The film industry's top award wa distributed from the firstceremony in 1929 until about 1941 without the c mark indicatinga copyright.The judge ruled, too, that the Oscar not only wa an honoraryaward but also wa used to promote the film industry, and thereforedid not have a limited purpose, a required by the copyrightact.The academy noted that the ruling applied only to the statuetteand that the academy's trademark and service mark for the Oscarand the Academy Award name and symbol are unaffected.We are surprised that the court would base it decision onevents which occurred half a century ago, overlooking themeticulous fashion in which the Academy ha protected the integrityof it institutional symbol for decade, Malden said in astatement.Free enterprise ha collided with the AcademyAwards, and everybody's trying to pick up the pieces.With Oscar statuette selling at auction for more than $10,000and a Chicago trophy company casting alleged Academy Award clones,the National Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences isscrambling to make sure Oscar's golden sheen isn't tarnished byHollywood hucksterism.If you know about an infringement and fail to object to it, yourisk having your trademark become public domain, said Bruce Davis,the Academy's executive administrator, in explaining the lawsuitsthe organization ha filed to protect it beloved hunk ofelectroplated pewter.But despite the Academy's crusade against crass commercialism,this year's award ceremony will feature a new merchandisingwrinkle: Some 800 limousine delivering the most famous star to theOscar telecast will be equipped with door-mounted cooler jammedwith Diet Coke, Coca-Cola Classic and other Coca-Cola Co. beverages.When the limo door swing open in front of the Shrine Auditoriumand the celebrity tumble out, the Coke logo will be on display infront of an audience that includes million around the world.It seemed like a good marketing opportunity, said Coca-Colaspokesman Ira Gleser. The Academy approached our local bottler inLos Angeles and said we're going to have a lot of thirsty people.But even a the Academy embrace this new intrusion ofmerchandising, it ha lashed out at whatever else it considers ablemishing of the Oscar name.When MGM-UA, the distributor of Rain Man, published newspaperadvertisements touting the film's Oscar nomination before thenominations were even announced, the Academy issued a harshstatement condemning MGM-UA's promotional gamble. After the adsappeared, Rain Man collected nine nominations.We regard this a a serious matter, and we have communicatedour concern, said Richard Kahn, president of the Academy.For nearly 50 year, the Academy ha maintained strict securityaround both the nomination and the award winner. It also hasenvisoned the statuette itself a something of an icon.So auctioning the Oscar ha greatly distressed the Academy.The Collector's Book Store, local sponsor of monthlyentertainment memorabilia auction, ha sold off seven Oscars in thepast year, including the best picture trophy for 1951's AnAmerican in Paris ($15760), Marlon Brando's best actor prize for1954's On the Waterfront ($13,000) and the black and whiteinterior decoration Oscar for 1941's How Green Was My Valley($17,715).None were sold by the original recipients; heir or friend whohad later received the trophy put them on the block.When Malcolm Willits, the book store's owner, announced that hewould hold a February auction for the 1957 best-picture trophy forAround the World in 80 Days, the Academy said enough, initiatinga court action that, for now, ha blocked any future trophy sales.The Academy insists that a contract signed by Oscar winnersmandates that they will not sell the trophy without first offeringthem to the Academy for a nominal fee.But now that the word is out that these award are worth$10,000 to $50000, people are reluctant to sell them back to theAcademy for $10, Willits said.The Academy ha created something of great value here. This isthe most famous award in the world the most instantly recognizableaward. The Nobel Prize might be a greater honor, but people knowmore about what an Academy Award look like.And they're very limited, too. There's not too many of themaround. . Twenty year ago, you wouldn't have a movie poster inyour living room unless you were a college student. Now, you can gointo Beverly Hills home and there's a movie poster, and the darnthing's worth $10,000 or $20,000 dollars.When the Academy won a court order temporarily blocking futureauctions, Willits decided to sell his store. It seemed to be thefinal straw. I don't like lawsuit, he said. I'm getting olderand I'd like to write movie scripts.Yet the Academy ha lost it most recent attempt to save itstrophy's integrity: A copyright infringement suit brought againstthe Houston International Film Festival wa dismissed March 16 in aCalifornia federal court.The Academy had claimed the Lone Star Statuette, designed andbuilt by Chicago's Creative House Promotions, wa practicallyidentical to the Oscar. The court found otherwise.The motion picture industry's most covetedaward, Oscar, wa created 60 year ago and 1,816 of the statuetteshave been produced so far.Weighing 8{ pound and standing 13{ inch tall, Oscar wascreated by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer studio art director Cedric Gibbons,who went on to win 11 of the trophies.Oscar, manufactured by the RS. Owens Co., Chicago, is made ofBritannia metal, copper plate, nickel plate and gold plate. From1942 to 1944, the trophy wa made of plaster, but winner werelater presented with the real thing.According to the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences,the only engraving mistake wa in 1938 when the best actor trophygiven to Spencer Tracy for Boy's Town read: Best Actor: DickTracy.The Academy hold all the right on the statue and reservesthe right to buy back an Oscar before someone take it to a pawnshop, said Academy spokesman Bob Werden.The most-nominated film wa All About Eve in 1950. It got 14nominations. Ben-Hur in 1959 wa the most-awarded film with 11,and Walt Disney wa the most-awarded person with 32.Oscar selection ha come under scrutiny a filmstudios go to new length to pull vote out of the Academy of MotionPicture Arts and Sciences.And with the flood of Oscar vote enticement from free coffeemugs to complimentary buffet dinner Academy member areacknowledging that some Oscar voting is done by committee, inviolation of the rule. Secretaries, spouse and friend, severalAcademy member say, are marking ballot in what is supposed to bethe entertainment industry's most esteemed award competition.It's like a local election of judge, said Academy memberHarry Clein, who said he's witnessed team voting. A lot of peopledon't know who the candidate are. So they take a look at who'saround them and see what the consensus is.As far a election go, it's not bad. But I've never beenthrough an election in Argentina.Dan Lyle, who oversees the Oscar balloting for the accountingfirm Price, Waterhouse Inc., said that there is no guarantee thatAcademy member have actually filled out their own ballots.All we know is that a properly numbered ballot ha beenreturned, he said. Members are on the honor system to fill outthe ballot themselves.More than 4,600 member were given ballot this year for the 61stAnnual Academy Awards, which will be telecast on March 29 from theShrine Auditorium in Los Angeles. Academy member vote on their areaof specialty. The Academy's actor branch, for example, is the onlygroup to select nominee in the four acting categories.Since the voting is done secretly member do not sign theirballots the ballot's authenticity is ensured solely by a numericcontrol number, Lyle said. Ballots are invalidated only if there ismore than one vote in a given category, and only the vote in thatspecific category are not tallied, he said.Nominations for acting, directing, art direction and allspecialized category are handled by select branch and committeescomposed of Academy members.All voting member of the Academy can participate in the bestpicture nomination and may vote for the final award in allcategories. Winners for best documentary feature, best animatedshort film and best live-action short film are chosen by only thosemembers who have seen all the nominees.Academy constituent Julian Blaustein said that most of hiscolleagues take the voting very seriously. I don't even vote (in acategory) if I'm not familiar with the picture in that category. And I've never told someone to vote for a film, even when I'vedone some of them.Meanwhile, other Oscar voting rule are perhaps being broken,speculates veteran Academy member Millard Kaufman. Although you'reasked to vote in the nomination for five picture, I think a lot ofpeople figure out that they have a better chance if they just votefor their own picture and leave the other four blank, he said.Given the tremendous impact both an Oscar nomination and an Oscarvictory have on a film's fortune, it's not entirely surprising thata certain degree of artifice might surround the Oscars.The Last Emperor took in $18.9 million, close to half thefilm's gross, after it won last year's best picture trophy. Morethan 70 percent of the revenue generated by 1986's best picturePlatoon, came after the film wa nominated. On average, a bestpicture award is worth about $20 million these days.A $500,000 Oscar promotional campaign mounted by a studiotherefore, can be a good investment. In the case of this year'sawards, a flurry of Academy-oriented newspaper advertisementsbanquets, complimentary gift and photo mailing tied to five latereleases appears to have been remarkably successful.This year, all best picture nominee and the large majority oftop acting nominee came from movie released in December: TheAccidental Tourist, Dangerous Liaisons, Rain Man andWorking Girl were all released after Dec. 16.While these five movie might be good, the nearly completeexclusion of film from the rest of the year ha highlighted thestudios' mastery of Oscar marketing.I think the Academy Awards are crap, said Terry Gilliam,director of Brazil and the current The Adventures of BaronMunchausen.It's about selling film is all it's about, he said. It'sone more way of flogging some film. When `Brazil' got nominated (in1986), they asked me to be a member of the Academy. And I wouldn'tjoin. I just don't want to be a part of that at all.And at least one prominent Academy member, director Carl Reiner,says that the manipulation of Oscar voter ha reached new depths.Reiner said that Universal Studios' all-out effort to bag vote forSigourney Weaver, a best actress nominee for Gorillas in theMist, could lead him to vote against the film.I have in my house more color reproduction of Sigourney Weaverand a beautiful gorilla than I need, Reiner said of promotionalmaterial sent to his home. We've got to tell the Academy to stopthis advertising. I'm getting turned off on the picture I like.HOLLYWOOD (AP) Like all great contest, the annual AcademyAwards ceremony ha generated a wealth of statistic and triviaover it 60 year of existence, all carefully chronicled by Oscarhistorians.Here, courtesy of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts andSciences, are 20 question about Oscar:1. What actress ha received the most Oscars? Katharine Hepburn,42. What actor ha received the most Oscars? Walter Brennan, 33. What director ha received the most Oscars? John Ford, 44. Who is the most nominated actress? Katharine Hepburn, 125. Who is the most nominated actor? Laurence Olivier, 106. Who is the most nominated director? William Wyler, 127. How long wa the longest Oscar ceremony? 3 hour, 45 minutesin 19858. What film ha won the most Oscars? Ben-Hur, 11, 19599. What wa the most nominated picture? Gone With The Wind,Mary Poppins and Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf, each with1310. What studio ha won the most Oscars? MGM, with nearly 20011. Who wa the youngest performer to win an Oscar? TatumO'Neal, 10, supporting actress, Paper Moon, 197312. Who wa the oldest performer ever to win an Oscar? GrouchoMarx, 83, an honorary award in 1974. George Burns is the oldestactor to win a performing Oscar, 80, for the The Sunshine Boysin 197613. What actor won a posthumous award? Peter Finch, Network,197614. What father-son team won Oscars in the same picture? WalterHuston, supporting actor, and John Huston, director-writer, TheTreasure of Sierra Madre, 194815. What actor wa nominated in two category for the samerole? Barry Fitzgerald, Going My Way, 1944. He won in thesupporting category16. Who decapitated his Oscar while practicing golf swingsindoors? Barry Fitzgerald. His 1944 supporting actor statuette wassubsequently replaced by the Academy17. What performer have refused their Oscars? George C. Scottand Marlon Brando18. How many people view the Oscar ceremony on television? Lastyear, the Oscarcast wa seen by one billion people in 79 countries19. Who hold the record for the fastest televised reading ofthe famed Academy rule? Actor-comedian John (Federal Express)Moschitta, 25 second, 198320. What multiple Oscar winner ha never appeared to collect heraward? Katharine Hepburn, all four times.Spencer Tracy's acting technique wa simplyless is better, and that helped make him the screen's greatestactor. The Tracy credo is recommended to future producer ofAcademy Award shows.Wednesday night's orgy of self-congratulation wa dazzling,glamorous and all those familiar Hollywood adjective. Also toomuch.Too many endless production number. Too much forcedconversation between couple. Too many award with meaning lost tothe general public.The use of couple, co-star, compadres and companion, aspresenters for the 61st Academy Awards at the Shrine Auditorium wasclever but wearing.The best Oscar show have been emceed by Will Rogers, Bob Hope,Johnny Carson and other funnymen who provided continuity a well asa leavening of pomposity.The brightest moment of the 61st Awards came from BillyCrystal, Robin Williams and Bob Hope, but they were all too brief.Tom Selleck remarked that Douglas Fairbanks Sr. handed out thefirst award in 1929 in five minute. The present award could bestaged in two hour instead of the 3 hour and 15 minute they tookWednesday night on ABC-TV.But the show will never be shorter. Reason: The time is neededto sell all those 30-second add at $375,000 per.Since the Academy Awards are a night of superlative here are afew more:The most heartfelt acceptance: Dustin Hoffman.The most intelligent acceptance: Jodie Foster.Warmest reception: Lucille Ball and Bob Hope.Best looking legs: Cyd Charisse.Second-best looking legs: Martin Short.Worst desecration of an icon: Snow White portrayed a a whiningwould-be starlet.Best comedy routine: Billy Crystal imitating Yul Brynner a BabeRuth.Best walk-on music: The Second Time Around for MelanieGriffith and Don Johnson.Least promising rock singer: Rob Lowe.Most overworked butt of jokes: Vice President Dan Quayle byCrystal, Hope and Williams (twice).Most prevalent fashion: Strapless gowns.Seemingly endless number: Oscar Winners of Tomorrow.Most relentless double entendre: Bo Derek and Dudley Moore.Most questionable taste: Kurt Russell's proposal of marriageto Goldie Hawn.Most mentioned agent: Michael Ovitz of Creative Artists Agency.Most recurrent dance routine: The Rockettes-like line of kickers.Best exchange of banter: Sean Connery, Michael Caine and RogerMoore.Most welcomed elimination: Singing of the nominee for best song.Most stunning beauty: Michelle PfeifferWorst reader of Teleprompter: Walter Matthau.
column5: OSCAR WORTH MILLIONS TO STUDIOS, NO COPYRIGHT ON FAMOUS SYMBOL
column6: In its 61-year history, many of Hollywood's highest achievers, among them directors Brooks (1988), Spielberg (1988) and Lee (1989) did not win nominations for the famous, but not copyright protected, award of the Academy of Arts and Sciences. Millions watch the televised presentation of awards worth millions to film studios.
column7: The Oscar nomination and selection process is under scrutiny as studios campaign to influence voting by Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences members. Directors  Brooks (1988),  Spielberg (1988), and Lee (1989) are among the luminaries who were overlooked in the annual voting during the award's 61-year history.Millions watch the televised awards show which can take over three hours. The 1989 show is memorable for the number of films honored and for a musical number that sparked a Disney suit against the Academy.The highly recognizable statue is not protected by copyright. Walt Disney was the most-awarded person (32).
column8: Director Spike Lee, speaking at Syracuse University Monday, shrugged off the treatment of his movie by Academy Award voters. Though praised by critics, his 1989 film was not considered in the best picture or best director categories. The Academy, however, has a history of overlooking achievers. In 1988, directors James Brooks and Steven Speilberg were both passed over.  Selection for the award is under scrutiny as studios mount major campaigns to influence voting. On average a best picture award is worth about $20 million, but there is no guarantee that Academy members actually complete their own ballots.Millions watch the awards presentation. The last awards show took a long three plus hours. The opening number, a song-and-dance routine by Eileen Bowman portraying Snow White, was particularly lamentable and led to a Disney suit against the Academy for its unauthorized use of the character. Though long, the 1989 ceremony will be favorably remembered for the spread of the awards. Ten movies split 17 awards. The Oscar, created in 1928, is one of the most recognizable symbols in the entertainment world and is not protected by copyright. Katherine Hepburn and Walter Brennan are the actress and actor, respectively, with the most awards.
column9: High-stakes Oscar is prized, promoted, presented with pomp, and protected
column10: Oscars increase film earnings, prompting studios to woo votes. The Thalberg award recognizes overlooked giants like Steven Spielberg. Oscar shows have been criticized for their excesses. Disney sued over an unauthorized Snow White routine, and the academy  sued when other awards resembled the Oscar too much. The gold-plated Oscar is manufactured by R.S. Owens Co.
column11: Oscar nominations and victories increase film earnings, and studios woo academy  members' votes. The Irving Thalberg award is useful for acknowledging overlooked giants. Steven Spielberg received it in 1987. Spike Lee blamed the few "Do the Right Thing" nominations on generational politics and racism. Oscar shows have been criticized for their excesses. Disney sued when the 1989 program opened with an unauthorized Snow White routine. The academy sued when other awards resembled the Oscar too closely, but a federal judge ruled the statuette was not copyrighted. The academy has tried to block Oscar sales. The gold-plated, 8-pound, 13-inch Oscar is manufactured by Chicago's R.S. Owens Co.
column12: Oscar nominations and victories increase film earnings, and studios woo the 4600 voting members of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to get their votes. The annual awards ceremony has generated a wealth of Oscar award trivia. The Irving Thalberg award for consistently high quality has become useful for acknowledging overlooked giants and salving the academy's conscience. Steven Spielberg, never nominated for an individual achievement even though his films are record moneymakers, received it in 1987. 32-year-old Spike Lee blamed the paucity of nominations for his critically acclaimed "Do the Right Thing" on generational politics and racism. Oscar shows have been criticized for their excesses of commercialism, production numbers, and meaningless awards.  In 1989, Disney sued the academy for opening the program with a Snow White routine. The academy closely protects the Oscar's name and image. It sued when a film festival award and an employee-incentive trophy were too similar, but a federal judge ruled that the statuette had no copyright protection. The academy has also tried to block the sale of statuettes. The Oscar, manufactured by Chicago's R.S. Owens Co., weighs 8 pounds and stands 13 inches tall. It is made of Britannia metal and plated with copper, nickel, and gold.

column3: Beverly Sills, Lauren Bacall, Betty Comdenand Phyllis Newman are among performer who will sing, act and makeguest appearance at a birthday bash in August for conductorLeonard Bernstein.The Leonard Bernstein Gala Birthday Performance is a benefitconcert scheduled for the composer's 70th birthday, Aug. 25, toraise money for the Tanglewood Music Center, where Bernstein gothis conducting start.Sills will be host. Performances will include the BostonSymphony Orchestra, the Boston Pops Orchestra and the TanglewoodFestival Chorus under the direction of some of the many conductorswhose career have been guided by Bernstein.Bacall and soprano Barbara Hendricks will perform a movementfrom Bernstein's Symphony No. 3, Kaddish. Violin soloist Midoriwill play two movement from his Serenade.The concert will celebrate Bernstein's accomplishment inpopular music with excerpt from West Side Story, On theTown and others. Dame Gwyneth Jones and Frederica von Stade willbe among those performing highlight from Fidelio, Tristanund Isolde and other work to honor Bernstein's landmark operarecordings.Tickets start at $20 for a spot on the lawn and run up to $5,000for benefactor, who get a seat in the open-air auditorium.Leonard Bernstein, whose 70th birthday in Augustwas marked with a gala at Tanglewood, returned to Carnegie Hall withthe New York Philharmonic 45 year after he made his triumphantconducting debut there with the orchestra.And of course, Monday night's program consisted of threeBernstein composition that were played shimmeringly well. As wellit should: It wa the 1,215th time Bernstein conducted the orchestra.On Nov. 14, 1943, Bernstein, the Philharmonic's then-assistantconductor, filled for an ailing Bruno Walter on such short noticethere wa no rehearsal. The concert wa broadcast nationally onradio. And there wa such acclaim that Bernstein, who had never ledthe orchestra in concert until that day, wa catapulted to fame, atage 25.At intermission, Mrs. Artur Rodzinski, whose late husband wa thePhilharmonic music's director in 1943 and hired Bernstein a hisassistant, wa introduced from a box.Violinist Jacques Margolies, who played in the Philharmonic thatSunday, is still a member and wa playing on Monday night. Eightothers who also were member in 1943 violinist Louis Fishzohn,oboist Albert Goltzer, timpanist Saul Goodman, bassist Homer Mensch,cellist Martin Ormandy, assistant concertmaster Michael Rosenker,and trumpeter James Smith and William Vacchiano went on stage.Bernstein gave bear hug to all nine.I feel older than all of them, said Bernstein.Bernstein wa given a silver box engraved with a reproduction ofMonday evening's program cover a caricature of him, with juttingchin, bright eye, flowing hair and baton, and reading with loveand thanks of the Philharmonic family to Lennie.Will this birthday never end?, he told the audience.Monday's concert began with Bernstein's Chichester Psalms,with the splendid Westminster Symphonic Choir. Todd Caruso, a memberof the American Boychoir whose voice is high, pure and moving, sangthe solo part.Violinist Gidon Kremer, a native of the Latvian town of Riga inthe Soviet Union, wa soloist in Serenade for Violin, StringOrchestra, Harp and Percussion. Kremer's sound isn't warm but histechnique is breathtaking.Pianist Krystian Zimerman, who wa born in Zabrze, Poland, oftenperforms with Bernstein in Europe. He wa the respectful andthoroughly engaged soloist in the final work on the program,Bernstein's Symphony No. 2 for Piano and Orchestra, subtitledThe Age of Anxiety after WH. Auden's poem.All the performer donated their service, with proceedsbenefiting the Philharmonic's effort on behalf of Americanconductors.For the New York Philharmonic, it wa supposedto be a night of Beethoven and Shostakovich. The fate made it anight of Leonard Bernstein.The official catalog of his work say Bernstein led 74orchestras. But this wa HIS orchestra, and the musician came topay tribute to THEIR laureate conductor, who led them through 1,244concerts during his 47-year association with the Philharmonic.They let his music do the talking.Tonight's concert is not an evening in which we want to dwellon the passing of a giant, but rather what he ha left u, guestconductor Leonard Slatkin told the audience at Avery Fisher Hall onThursday night.So four night after Bernstein's death at age 72, Beethoven'sViolin Concerto became Bernstein's Serenade for Solo Violin,String Orchestra, Harp and Percussion (1954); Shostakovich'sSymphony No. 4 became Bernstein's Symphony No. 1(Jeremiah), written in 1942.Also added were his Chichester Psalms (1965) and hisoverture to Candide (1956). The substitute Bernstein programwas being repeated Friday night, Saturday and Tuesday.It wa an extraordinary concert.There weren't many smiling face among the audience ormusicians. Slatkin's brief introductory comment, followed by thewhimsical Candide, broke some of the tension.Then came the eclectic Serenade, which Bernstein's programnotes say is supposed to be based on Plato's Symposium. Itbegins with a lyrical praise of the Eros, the god of love. Thepiece is sometimes jocular, sometimes melancholy, sometimesassaulting and sometimes hedonistic. It end in drunken revelry, anintrusion of jazz - a if Bernstein wa looking down from heavenand telling the audience, It's OK. to smile tonight.The soloist - concertmaster Glenn Dicterow - played with muchagility, especially through the difficult double stop andespecially considering the lack of preparation time.The mourning returned after intermission, but not withoutoptimism.Jeremiah begin with suspenseful string, followed by acantorial French horn, a melodic return to the string and then aprophetic blaring of brass. The second movement continues thepoint-counterpoint of brass versus string (Jeremiah versus thecorrupt priest, with Nebuchadnezzar looming on the horizon). Inthe third movement, Jerusalem ha fallen to the Babylonian king.Judea is exiled. Jeremiah weeps.How she sits desolate -The city once so full of people -She is become a a widow.During her chanting of the prophet's Lamentations,mezzo-soprano Wendy White had to wipe a tear from her eye. S didmembers of the audience.Last on the program wa another Hebraic elegy, ChichesterPsalms. The New York Choral Artists and a boy soloist joined theorchestra.Two harpist dominated the center of the crowded stage.Awake, psaltery and harp! the choir begin in Hebrew.I will rouse the dawn.In the second movement an angelic 8th-grader, Evan Weber, singsKing David's 23rd Psalm, The Lord is my shepherd, I shall notwant.After he finish, the men's chorus bellows: Why do thenations rage?The piece, however, end in a Mahlerian motif and chorusdeclaring a message Bernstein had sought for society:Behold how good,And how pleasant it is,For brother to dwellTogether in unity.To emphasize the point after the final note, Slatkin suspendedhis hand for several long moment of silence. Then came thecascade of applause. For Leonard Bernstein.Actresses Lauren Bacall, Betty Comden andPhyllis Newman are among performer in the birthday bash beingthrown in August for conductor Leonard Bernstein at the musiccenter where he got his start.The Tanglewood Music Center also is celebrating the 50thanniversary of it Music Shed this summer with a special concert bythe resident Boston Symphony Orchestra featuring the same music,Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, that inaugurated the building in 1938.The Bernstein weekend alone, with ticket a high a $5000each, may bring in more than $1 million for the festival'sendowment fund, according to Caroline Smedvig of the symphony.Because Tanglewood is so special for him and, conversely, he'sso special to u, the combination will produce what we hope will bea unique event, she said.The Leonard Bernstein Gala Birthday Performance is a four-dayaffair beginning on the composer's 70th birthday, Aug. 25, to raisemoney for the music center.Beverly Sills, who announced last month that she will step downas general director of the New York City Opera, will be the host ofthe event. Bacall and soprano Barbara Hendricks will perform amovement from Bernstein's Symphony No. 3, Kaddish. Violinsoloist Midori will play two movement from his Serenade.Dame Gwyneth Jones and Frederica von Stade will be among thoseperforming highlight from Fidelio and other work to honorBernstein's landmark opera recordings.The concert will also celebrate Bernstein's accomplishment inpopular music with excerpt from such work a West Side Storyand On the Town.The orchestra opened the nine-week season with the special July1 concert marking the first half-century of the Music Shed.The season of classical music will be expanded with performancesby such popular rock, jazz and folk artist a The Beach Boys,George Benson and Leo Kottke.But the highlight of the new season is the celebration ofBernstein's birthday.The BSO is even billing the birthday party a one of the musicworld's great occasion and is negotiating the television rightsin the United States and Europe.Among the conductor's friend who have been invited to the bashare pop star Michael Jackson and British Princess Diana, althoughTanglewood official say the have not yet received an answer fromthe celebrities.Bernstein wa a member of the original Tanglewood Music Centerclass of 1940, where he became a protege of Tanglewood founderSerge Koussevitzky.When Koussevitzky retired in 1949, he tried to have the youngBernstein named a his successor, but the BSO's trustee choseCharles Munch because they considered Bernstein too young andtainted by popular music.He later wrote the score for the musical West Side Story andreturned every summer to conduct and teach.Conductors Seiji Ozawa, John Williams, John Mauceri and MichaelTillson Thomas will share the poduim featuring some of his work onthe night of his birth.The following night, Ozawa and special guest will appear in aMusic Shed concert for a performance intended to show Bernstein'sinfluence on other musiciansAug. 27 will be given over to a performance of Bernstein'sMass by a 250-member troupe from the Indiana University schoolof music.The four-day celebration concludes with Bernstein conducting theannual Serge and Ola Koussevitzky Memorial Concert, including aperformance of Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 5, on Aug. 28.All proceeds go to the music center's endowment fund, and to afund Bernstein established for aspiring young conductor. Ticketprices start at $20 for a space on the lawn and go up to $5,000 forfront row seat for benefactors.Other highlight of the new season include several major debuts,including that of Soviet painist Vladimir Feltsman, who arrived inthe United States last August after an an eight-year battle toemigrate; a return visit by the Israel Philharmonic; and a recitalby Irish flutist James Galway.This summer is the second in a four-year jubilee of thefestival's 50th anniversary. Events climax in 1990 with observancesmarking the 50th year of the music center, the festival's school.Leonard Bernstein, whose wide-ranging talentsand flamboyant personality helped make him the first Americanmaestro to conquer music's international podium, wa buried todayalongside his wife.Bernstein, who died of lung failure Sunday at age 72, wa buriedthis afternoon in private ceremony at Greenwood Cemetery inBrooklyn. His wife, Felicia Montealegre, died in 1978.Flags at Lincoln Center, where the New York Philharmonicperforms, were lowered in memory of the orchestra's firstAmerican-born music director. Bernstein wa appointed in 1958 andstepped down in 1969 to spend more time composing.The Philharmonic will perform an all-Bernstein program beginningThursday and continuing through Oct. 23. The schedule had calledfor work by Shostakovich and Beethoven.A memorial concert also is planned for Carnegie Hall on Nov. 14,the 47th anniversary of Bernstein's Philharmonic debut.Famed for his gymnastics at the podium, Bernstein composedsymphonies a well a movie score and Broadway show such asWest Side Story, On the Town and Candide.His Emmy-winning Young People's Concerts on televisionintroduced thousand to classical music.He wa the most unique musician of this century, there is nodoubt about it, said Zubin Mehta, music director of the New YorkPhilharmonic and the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra.Larry Kert, who played Tony in the Broadway production of WestSide Story, said Bernstein himself played the piano for himduring rehearsals.He could have gotten a rehearsal pianist, but he cared toomuch, Kert said. I wa the new kid on the block and he strokedme and took care of me - and I will never forget him for that.Conductor Leonard Bernstein, the West SideStory composer who mesmerized audience with his passion andphysical flair at the podium, is giving up the baton because ofpoor health.The 72-year-old maestro suffers from a lung tumor, emphysema andpulmonary infection and ha been told by his doctor to stopconducting and performing on the piano, his spokeswoman saidTuesday.Leonard Bernstein will henceforth devote his professionalenergies to composing, writing and education, said MargaretCarson.He last conducted Aug. 19 at the Tanglewood Music Center inwestern Massachusetts.Bernstein's announcement wa met with dismay in the music world,especially at the New York Philharmonic, which he directed from1958 to 1969. I receive this unfortunate news in utter shock,said Zubin Mehta, music director.Albert K. Webster, managing director of the Philharmonic, said:Leonard Bernstein ha BEEN the New York Philharmonic for morethan 45 year. We all will be le for the loss of his magicbaton.Bernstein still hope to participate in an AIDS benefit atCarnegie Hall on Oct. 28 but canceled all appearance withorchestras in New York, Israel, Vienna and London and with festivalorchestras at Tanglewood, Germany and Japan.Bernstein, known for his vigorous style at the podium, once ledan orchestra performance at a liberated concentration camp. LastChristmas, he celebrated the tumbling of the Berlin Wall byconducting Beethoven's Ninth Symphony.In May, he canceled plan to conduct opening night of theSpoleto Festival in Charleston, S.C., citing a near brush withpneumonia.Carson said Bernstein ha had increased difficulty breathing inpast week. Dr. Kevin M. Cahill attributed the problem to emphysemacomplicated by a tumor and pulmonary infection. Bernstein wa oncea heavy smoker.Bernstein is not hospitalized. Carson said the conductor wastold that rest offer the best hope for returning to limitedactivities.She said Bernstein plan to continue work on a new chamber musicpiece to be performed next spring, a new musical theater work hehopes to finish by summer and several educational, film andrecording project, a well a his memoirs.Bernstein wa the wunderkind of American music at a time whenall respected conductor in the United States were born and trainedin Europe.His first published composition wa The Clarinet Sonata in1942. He conducted his first symphony, the Jeremiah, with thePittsburgh Symphony in 1944. That year his ballet, Fancy Free,choreographed by Jerome Robbins, opened and became the basis forthe Broadway musical On the Town.After Boston Symphony Orchestra conductor Serge Koussevitzkydied in 1951, Bernstein became head of the orchestra and conductingdepartments at Tanglewood. His first opera, Trouble in Tahiti,was performed in 1952. He composed Candide in 1956 and WestSide Story in 1957.In 1969, he retired from the post to concentrate on composingand wa appointed the Philharmonic's laureate conductor for life.He ha conducted 1,244 New York Philharmonic concert, more thanany other conductor.On the stage where Leonard Bernstein made hissensational New York Philharmonic conducting debut 47 year ago,the orchestra remembered the maestro at a concert that includedselections from his Mass and Chichester Psalms.Wednesday's midday concert at Carnegie Hall also came on the90th birthday of the late composer-conductor's close friend, AaronCopland. And it wa the 36th anniversary of the first TV broadcastby Bernstein, who died Oct. 16.Speakers, introducing various selection and often quoting fromBernstein's writing, included Bernstein's three children,son-in-law and friend Lauren Bacall and Schuyler Chapin.Bernstein's daughter Jamie Thomas said her father had lovednumerical coincidence and today there's a flock of them.The concert began with selection from Bernstein's Mass,which he composed for the opening of the Kennedy Center forPerforming Arts in Washington, and ended with Psalm 133, in Hebrew,from Bernstein's Chichester Psalms.Conductors were Michael Tilson Thomas, Michael Barrett,Christoph Eschenbach and James Levine. The orchestra played theoverture to Bernstein's Candide with a symbolically emptypodium, which brought tear to some of the invited audience and astanding ovation.Cellist Mstislav Rostropovich played a Bach sarabande. Singerswere the Westminster Choir, mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne andChrista Ludwig, soprano Clamma Dale, tenor Jerry Hadley andbaritones Thomas Hampson and Chester Ludgin.First chair musician from the Boston Symphony, IsraelPhilharmonic, London Symphony, Santa Cecilia Orchestra and ViennaPhilharmonic flew here, at their orchestras' expense, to take part.Two piece by Copland were played. The concert also includedSchumann, Haydn and Mahler a well a excerpt from six Bernsteinworks.Bernstein wa the New York Philharmonic's 25-year-old assistantconductor on Nov. 14, 1943, when he filled in at the last minutefor an ailing Bruno Walter.Conductor Leonard Bernstein ha canceled severalperformances in Japan due to exhaustion and lingering illness andwill return to the United States to recover, his manager announcedtoday.Leonard Bernstein is suffering from exhaustion a a result oftrying to fulfill his professional obligation while not havingfully recovered from several ailment he suffered this spring.Complete rest for an extended period is required if this remarkableman is to regain his usual high energy level, said Dr. KevinCahill, the conductor's personal physician.Bernstein, 71, ha suffered from severe influenza, pleurisy, andpneumonia since the beginning of the year, Cahill said in astatement released by Harry Kraut, Bernstein's managerDr. Angelo Aquista, an associate of Cahill, flew to Japan toaccompany the conductor back to New York, it said. Kraut did notprovide the time or date of Bernstein's departure.Bernstein had been scheduled to conduct the London SymphonyOrchestra in four performance in Japan, ending with a concert onJuly 22.Bernstein issued a separate statement apologizing to his fansand sponsor and saying that he had asked LSO principal conductorMichael Tilson Thomas and Japanese conductor Eiji Oue to fulfillhis conducting responsibilities.On Saturday and Sunday, Bernstein canceled appearance with anorchestra of young musician from the Pacific-Asia region who hadbeen training under principal of the LSO during the three-weekPacific Music Festival in northern Japan.Bernstein inaugurated the festival last month. He started theevent along the line of the Tanglewood music festival inMassachusetts, where young musician train with the Boston SymphonyOrchestra.The Japan festival is believed to be the first festival in Asiawhere young musician can train with a professional orchestra.Kraut's statement said it wa not known whether Bernstein wouldbe able to conduct next month at the Tanglewood festival or duringthe Tanglewood Music Center Orchestra Tour in Europe later thissummer.
column5: Classical Music World and Broadway Mourn Lenny, Dead at 72
column6: Internationally acclaimed maestro Leonard Bernstein died on October 14th at 72 of lung failure after a long illness. The New York Philharmonic, which he conducted for 12 years, remembered him with a special all-Bernstein program. A special show at Broadway's Majestic Theater also honored the composer of "West Side Story."
column7: Leonard Bernstein, the beloved internationally acclaimed maestro died on October 14th at 72 of lung failure. Within days, the New York Philharmonic, in tribute to its 47-year association with the brilliant conductor played a special program, as did several other orchestras. Recently, Broadway also honored Bernstein, composer of "West Side Story," with a special show at the Majestic Theater. Several record companies will accelerate re-releases of Bernstein recordings.Bernstein though ill for some time, did participate in his 70th birthday celebrations at Tanglewood and Carnegie Hall. The latter occurred on the 45th anniversary of his directorial debut with the Philharmonic.
column8: The tributes to the musical genius, Leonard Bernstein, who died on October 14th at 72 from lung failure, continue. Thursday, a capacity audience filled the Broadway's Majestic Theater to hear recollections about the man who etched an indelible niche in American popular culture with his composition for West Side Story and to listen to classic Bernstein songs. Four days after his death, the New York Philharmonic, in tribute to the internationally acclaimed maestro who directed it from 1958 to 1969, replaced its regular program with an emotional all Bernstein program. The Los Angeles Philharmonic and the American Youth Orchestra also remembered him with special selections in their programs the weekend after his death. After his death, radio stations featured his work and a special section ran in the New York Times for public condolences. Several record companies announced accelerated programs to re-releases Bernstein recordingsA brilliant conductor, pianist, composer and teacher, Bernstein had canceled public appearances with increasing frequency. He did, however, appear at two 70th birthday celebrations. The first, a four-day event at Tanglewood, was a benefit for the music center. The other, at Carnegie Hall was held on the 45th anniversary of his directorial debut with the New York Philharmonic.
column9: Bernstein, America's Maestro, dead; lauded on 70th Birthday and posthumously.
column10: Leonard Bernstein--pianist, composer, conductor, recording star, teacher, TV personality, liberal, and bon vivant--died October 14 from lung disease.  He was the first American conductor to attain world fame.  Posthumous plaudits have come from everywhere.  Memorial concerts in New York and Los Angles were reminiscent of his 70th birthday celebrations.
column11: America's maestro, Leonard Bernstein died at 72 on October 14.  Suffering from lung diseases since spring, he announced his retirement four days earlier.  "Lenny" was the first American conductor to attain world fame.  He composed both classical and popular music and introduced thousands to classical music on television.  He made more than 200 classical recordings, many now being examined for re-release.  Posthumous plaudits have come from everywhere, with memorial classical concerts in New York and Los Angles, as well as a goodbye from Broadway.  His 70th birthday celebrations had featured all-star fundraising concerts at the Tanglewood Music Center and Carnegie Hall.
column12: Leonard Bernstein--pianist, composer, conductor, teacher, TV personality, liberal, and bon vivant--died at 72 on October 14, just four days after announcing his retirement from conducting.  He had been in failing health since last spring, suffering from a variety of lung diseases, and cut short a Japanese tour in July.  He was buried on October 16.  "Lenny", the first American conductor to attain world fame, was the well-educated son of Russian Jewish immigrants.  A member of the first class at Tanglewood, he achieved instant stardom at 25 as an emergency fill-in to conduct the New York Philharmonic on nation-wide radio.  He conducted this orchestra over 2000 times.  He composed both classical and popular music and introduced thousands to classical music on television.  He made more than 200 classical recordings, many now being examined for re-release.  Plaudits have come from everywhere and the New York Philharmonic presented four all-Bernstein nights of classical selections.  In Los Angles, three orchestras and two radio stations honored him.  On November 14, his career was commemorated at Carnegie Hall and Broadway said goodbye on December 13.  He had savored the celebrations of his 70th birthday, which featured all-star fundraising concerts at the Tanglewood Music Center and Carnegie Hall.

column3: Hurricane Gilbert's growth from a harmless lowpressure zone off Africa to a ferocious killer in the Gulf ofMexico wa fueled by a combination of heat, moisture and wind thatbaffles forecasters.It's a matter of getting everything together in the rightplace in the right time, Gil Clark of the National HurricaneCenter said Thursday. It doesn't happen very often. How itdevelops, we don't know.Gilbert came to the attention of center forecaster Sept. 3 a adry low pressure trough moving west out of Africa.We get 50 or 60 of these off Africa every summer. About one ofsix develop, said Clark.By Sept. 8, the system became a depression. It reached tropicalstorm status by Saturday and a hurricane Sunday.A tropical wave becomes a depression when wind start swirling.When sustained wind reach 39 mph, the system becomes a namedtropical storm. It reach hurricane status when sustained windshit 74 mph.Why Gilbert organized and strengthened while other systemsdidn't is a mystery more or le, said University of Miamimeteorology Professor Rainer Bleck.The first part of the summer we were biting our nails,wondering why these (other) disturbance didn't develop, he saidThursday. That's something meteorologist would like to know moreabout.But the scientist do know what fuel a budding storm oncedevelopment begin. And they know that development is sparked whenwinds converge, and that growth is affected by time and place.If that happens in an area where there's plenty of moisture inthe lower atmosphere (the bottom 10,000 foot or so), thisconvergence may lead to upward motion and cloud formation, Blecksaid.If cloud form, the heat of condensation in the cloudsoccasionally provides `positive feedback' to the convergencepattern. That strengthens it, he said, adding that storm canbegin budding only off the equator because of the Earth's rotation.Eventually, a vortex is created.Any time you contract an air mass, they will start spinning.That's what make the tornado, hurricane and blizzard, thosewinter storm, Bleck said.Hurricanes are useful to the climate machine. Their primaryrole is to transport heat from the lower to the upper atmosphere,he said. The sun put energy into the water, the top of theoceans and lowest part of the atmosphere. That ha to bedistributed from the bottom to higher level of the atmosphere.When the depression that would become Gilbert neared Barbados,warm Atlantic water nurtured it.This time of year in the northwest Caribbean is best fordevelopment, Clark said. If you get a storm in this area inSeptember, when the water's warmest, it can just explode. This iswhere Camille formed and exploded, referring to the 1969 stormthat slammed into the Gulf Coast.It is an exciting thing to watch. If you're on the beachwatching the storm surge, it's a different story, he said.The hurricane center said Gilbert wa the most intense storm onrecord in term of barometric pressure, measured at 26.13 inchesTuesday night. That broke the 26.35 inch of the 1935 hurricanethat devastated the Florida Keys.Hurricane Gilbert swepttoward the Dominican Republic Sunday, and the Civil Defense alertedits heavily populated south coast to prepare for high wind, heavyrains and high seas.The storm wa approaching from the southeast with sustainedwinds of 75 mph gusting to 92 mph.There is no need for alarm, Civil Defense Director EugenioCabral said in a television alert shortly before midnight Saturday.Cabral said resident of the province of Barahona should closelyfollow Gilbert's movement. An estimated 100,000 people live in theprovince, including 70,000 in the city of Barahona, about 125 mileswest of Santo Domingo.Tropical Storm Gilbert formed in the eastern Caribbean andstrengthened into a hurricane Saturday night. The NationalHurricane Center in Miami reported it position at 2 am. Sunday atlatitude 16.1 north, longitude 67.5 west, about 140 mile south ofPonce, Puerto Rico, and 200 mile southeast of Santo Domingo.The National Weather Service in San Juan, Puerto Rico, saidGilbert wa moving westward at 15 mph with a broad area ofcloudiness and heavy weather rotating around the center of thestorm.The weather service issued a flash flood watch for Puerto Ricoand the Virgin Islands until at least 6 pm. Sunday.Strong wind associated with the Gilbert brought coastalflooding, strong southeast wind and up to 12 foot foot to PuertoRico's south coast. There were no report of casualties.San Juan, on the north coast, had heavy rain and gustsSaturday, but they subsided during the night.On Saturday, Hurricane Florence wa downgraded to a tropicalstorm and it remnant pushed inland from the US. Gulf Coast.Residents returned home, happy to find little damage from 80 mphwinds and sheet of rain.Florence, the sixth named storm of the 1988 Atlantic stormseason, wa the second hurricane. The first, Debby, reached minimalhurricane strength briefly before hitting the Mexican coast lastmonth.Hurricane Gilbert, one of the strongeststorms ever, slammed into the Yucatan Peninsula Wednesday andleveled thatched home, tore off roof, uprooted tree and cut offthe Caribbean resort of Cancun and Cozumel.Looters roamed the street of Cancun, stealing from store whosewindows were blown away. Huge wave battered the beach resort andthousands were evacuated. Despite the intensity of the onslaughtand the ensuing heavy flooding, official reported only two minorinjuries.The storm killed 19 people in Jamaica and five in the DominicanRepublic before moving west to Mexico. Prime Minister Edward Seagaof Jamaica said Wednesday the storm destroyed an estimated 100,000of Jamaica's 500,000 home when it throttled the island Monday.The Jamaican Embassy reported earlier that 500,000 of thenation's 2.3 million people were homeless.In Cancun, amateur radio operator said an oil tanker from thefleet of the government oil monopoly Pemex, the Lazaro Cardenas,had run aground on the beach in the Cancun hotel zone. Pemexofficials however said all their vessel were secure.Army official in Mexico City said about 35,000 people wereevacuated from Cancun, but Cancun Mayor Jose Sanchez Zapata saidabout 11,000 fled.More than 120,000 people on the northeast Yucatan coast wereevacuated, the Yucatan state government said.The eye of the storm passed over Cozumel and Cancun with howlingwinds clocked at 160 mph at about 8 am. EDT. The wind bent andtoppled utility pole and uprooted slum dwellings.Ham radio operator around Cancun said Gilbert knocked down aradio and television communication tower, uprooted tree and blewthe roof off buildings.Floods prevented official from reaching the hotel zone inCancun and there were no relief effort under way by lateWednesday. Shelters had little or no food, water or blanket andpower wa out.We can't do it yet. The wind would blow them away, said anarmy official at city hall who declined to give his name.Bands of 25-30 youth roamed the street of Cancun Wednesday,looting store with shattered window, said Alfredo Moro Sanchez,investigative coordinator of the Quintana Roo state judicial police.He said he asked for army troop to halt the looting but nonehad arrived by late Wednesday.About 150 tourist took refuge at the Cancun city hall.Honeymooner Sheila Fournier of Long Island said she and herhusband, Pete, had been evacuated from the Villas Playa Hotel.It had an ocean-front view which is now washed away, shesaid.Officials were checking low-lying area of Cancun for strandedresidents. There wa heavy damage visible to the humble wood andthatch home typical of the Yucatan.There were some people who did not want to leave yesterday,the army official said. It wa something new. They didn't knowwhat a cyclone was.At midnight EDT Gilbert wa centered near latitude 21.5 north,longitude 90.2 west and approaching the north coast of Yucatan,about 60 mile east-northeast of the provincial capital, Merida,the National Hurricane Center in Coral Gables, Fla., said. Thestorm wa about 550 mile southeast of Brownsville, Texas, thecenter said in a statement.Gilbert wa moving west-northwest at 15 mph and wind haddecreased to 125 mph. The Mexican National Weather Service reportedwinds gusting a high a 218 mph earlier Wednesday with sustainedwinds of 179 mph.Earlier Wednesday Gilbert wa classified a a Category 5 storm,the strongest ad deadliest type of hurricane. Such storm havemaximum sustained wind greater than 155 mph and can causecatastrophic damage.By Wednesday night the National Hurricane Center downgraded itto a Category 4, but center director Bob Sheets said:There's noquestion it'll strengthen again once it come off the YucatanPeninsula and get back in open water.As Gilbert moved away from the Yucatan Peninsula Wednesdaynight, the hurricane formed a double eye, two concentric circle ofthunderstorms often characteristic of a strong storm that hascrossed land and is moving over the water again.One eye wa about eight mile wide, and the second about 25miles wide, said hurricane center meteorologist Jesse Moore. Thisis one of the feature that we expected to see a the hurricanemoved back over the water, and we do expect intensification, hesaid.Only two Category 5 hurricane have hit the United States the1935 storm that killed 408 people in Florida and Hurricane Camillethat devastated the Mississippi coast in 1969, killing 256 people.Oil company evacuated thousand of worker from rig in theGulf of Mexico.The peninsula port of Campeche, Celestum, Progreso, SinzalUcaltepen, Tel-Chac, Cancun, Puerto Morelos, and Ciudad del Carmenwere closed, the government news agency Notimex said. Airports inthe region were closed.The sound of the wind outside is horrible, said receptionistPablo Torres at Cancun's Hotel Carrillos a the storm approached.The National Hurricane Center said a hurricane watch wa ineffect on the Texas coast from Brownsville to Port Arthur and alongthe coast of northeast Mexico from Tampico north.In Mexico City, the National Civil Defense System said it losttelephone contact with Cancun and Cozumel at about 8 am. EDT.Public building in Cancun were used a shelter, said CecilaLavalle, a spokesman for Quintana Roo state government in Chetumal,155 mile southeast of Cozumel.Jennie Valdez, a US. consular representative in Cancun, saidshe did not know how many tourist were in Cancun, but governmentfigures estimate 40,000 to 65,000 monthly visitors.Hurricane warning were in effect for the entire YucatanPeninsula and widespread evacuation were reported.Winds destroyed at least 100 home in slum of Valladolid, atown of about 45,000 about 100 mile from Cozumel, Alberto Pol, ajudicial police officer, said by telephone.The National Hurricane Center said Gilbert wa the most intensestorm on record in term of barometric pressure. It wa measured at26.31 inch, breaking the 26.35 inch recorded for the 1935hurricane that devastated the Florida Keys.That's the lowest pressure ever measured in the WesternHemisphere, said forecaster Mark Zimmer.On Sunday, Monday and Tuesday, Gilbert pounded the DominicanRepublic, Jamaica and the Cayman Islands.Seaga said Jamaica would need $8 billion in aid. Officials inthe Dominican Republic, sideswiped Sunday by the storm, reportedfive dead.Gilbert also buffeted the Cayman Islands, but no death werereported.Hurricane Gilbert slammed into Kingstonon Monday with torrential rain and 115 mph wind that ripped roofsoff home and building, uprooted tree and downed power lines.No serious injury were immediately reported in the city of750,000 people, which wa hit by the full force of the hurricanearound noon.For half an hour, the hurricane lashed the city, tearingbranches from tree, blowing down fence and whipping paper throughthe air.The National Weather Service reported heavy damage to Kingston'sairport and aircraft parked on it fields.The first shock let up a the eye of the storm moved across thecity. Skies brightened, the wind died down and people waited foran hour before the second blow of the hurricane arrived.All Jamaica-bound flight were canceled at Miami InternationalAirport.Flights from the Cayman Islands, reportedly next in the path ofthe hurricane, arrived in Miami packed with traveler cutting shorttheir vacation. People were running around in the main lobby ofour hotel (on Grand Cayman Island) like chicken with their headscut off, said one man.A National Weather Service report said the hurricane wa movingwest at 17 mph with maximum sustained wind of 115 mph. It saidJamaica would receive up to 10 inch of rain that would causeflash flood and mud slides.Right now it's actually moving over Jamaica, said BobSheets, director of the National Hurricane Center in Miami.It look like the eye is going to move lengthwise across thatisland, and they're going to bear the full brunt of this powerfulhurricane, he said.Gilbert reached Jamaica after skirting southern Puerto Rico,Haiti and the Dominican Republic. Hurricane warning were issuedMonday for the south coast of Cuba east of Camaguey, the CaymanIslands, and Haiti, while warning were discontinued for theDominican Republic.High wind and heavy rain preceding the storm drenched Kingstonovernight, toppling tree, causing local flooding and litteringstreets with branches.Most of Jamaica's 2.3 million people stayed home, boarding upwindows in preparation for the hurricane.The popular north coast resort area, on the other side of themountains, wa expected to receive heavy rain but not a muchdamage from the hurricane a the south coast, where official urgedresidents to seek higher ground.Havana Radio, meanwhile, reported Monday that 25,000 people wereevacuated from coastal area in Guantanamo Province on the nation'ssoutheastern coast a Gilbert's wind and rain began to brush theisland.In Washington, the Navy reported it base at Guantanamo BayCuba, and Roosevelt Roads, Puerto Rico, had taken variousprecautionary step but appeared to be safe from the brunt of thehurricaneLt. Ken Ross, a spokesman, said the Navy station at Guantanamoreported that a of 2:30 pm. EDT, the brunt of the storm appearedto be passing southeastern Cuba. They have reported maximum windsof 25 knot and gust up to 50 knot, said Ross. But there areno report of injury or damage.The spokesman said earlier in the day, Guantanamo had moved toCondition Two, meaning electrical power usage wa cut back toonly essential us and all non-essential personnel sent to theirbarracks.The storm also skirted Puerto Rico without causing any damage tomilitary facility, Ross said.Sheets said Gilbert wa expected next to sweep over the CaymanIslands, on it westward track, and in two to three day veernorthwest into the southern Gulf of Mexico. Residents of theneighboring Caymans, a British dependency to the northwest, wereurged to rush all preparatory actions.The National Weather Service warned that the Caymans couldexpect high water and large wave which may undermine buildingsalong the beaches.All interest in the Western Caribbean should continue tomonitor the progress of this dangerous hurricane, the serviceadvised.Forecaster Hal Gerrish on Sunday described Gilbert certainlyone of the larger system we've seen in the Caribbean for a longtime.Hurricane Gilbert, packing 110 mphwinds and torrential rain, moved over this capital city today afterskirting Puerto Rico, Haiti and the Dominican Republic.There were no immediate report of casualty. Telephonecommunications were affected.Right now it's actually moving over Jamaica, said BobSheets, director of the National Hurricane Center in Miami. We'vealready had report of 110 mph wind on the eastern tip.It look like the eye is going to move lengthwise across thatisland, and they're going to bear the full brunt of this powerfulhurricane, Sheets said.Forecasters say Gilbert wa expected to lash Jamaica throughoutthe day and wa on track to later strike the Cayman Islands, asmall British dependency northwest of Jamaica.Meanwhile, Havana Radio reported today that 25,000 people wereevacuated from Guantanamo Province on Cuba's southeastern coast asstrong wind fanning out from Gilbert began brushing the island.All Jamaica-bound flight were canceled at Miami InternationalAirport, while flight from Grand Cayman, the main island of thethree-island chain, arrived packed with frightened travelers.People were running around in the main lobby of our hotel (onGrand Cayman) like chicken with their head cut off, said onevacationer who wa returning home to California through Miami.Hurricane warning were posted for the Cayman Islands, Cuba andHaiti. Warnings were discontinued for the Dominican Republic.All interest in the Western Caribbean should continue tomonitor the progress of this dangerous hurricane, the servicesaid, adding, Little change in strength is expected for the nextseveral hour a the hurricane move westward over Jamaica.The Associated Press' Caribbean headquarters in San Juan, PuertoRico, wa unable to get phone call through to Kingston, where highwinds and heavy rain preceding the storm drenched the capitalovernight, toppling tree, causing local flooding and litteringstreets with branches.Most Jamaicans stayed home, boarding up window in preparationfor the hurricane. Some company broadcast appeal for techniciansand electrician to report to work.The weather bureau predicted Gilbert's center, 140 milessoutheast of Kingston before dawn, would pas south of Kingston andhit the southern parish of Clarendon.Flash flood warning were issued for the parish of Portland onthe northeast and St. Mary on the north. The north coast touristregion from Montego Bay on the west and Ocho Rios on the east, farfrom the southern impact zone and separated by mountain, wasexpected only to receive heavy rain.Officials urged resident in the higher risk area along thesouth coast to seek higher ground.It's certainly one of the larger system we've seen in theCaribbean for a long time, said Hal Gerrish, forecaster at theNational Hurricane Center.Forecasters at the center said the eye of Gilbert wa 140 milessoutheast of Kingston at dawn today. Maximum sustained wind werenear 110 mph, with tropical-storm force wind extending up to 250miles to the north and 100 mile to the south.Prime Minister Edward Seaga of Jamaica alerted all governmentagencies, saying Sunday night: Hurricane Gilbert appears to be areal threat and everyone should follow the instruction andhurricane precaution issued by the Office of Disaster Preparednessin order to minimize the danger.Forecasters said the hurricane had been gaining strength a itpassed over the ocean after it dumped 5 to 10 inch of rain on theDominican Republic and Haiti, which share the island of Hispaniola.We should know within about 72 hour whether it's going to bea major threat to the United States, said Martin Nelson, anothermeteorologist at the center. It's moving at about 17 mph to thewest and normally hurricane take a northward turn after they passcentral Cuba.Cuba's official Prensa Latina news agency said a state of alertwas declared at midday in the Cuban province of GuantanamoHolguin, Santiago de Cuba and Granma.In the report from Havana received in Mexico City, Prensa Latinasaid civil defense official were broadcasting bulletin onnational radio and television recommending emergency measure andproviding information on the storm.Heavy rain and stiff wind downed power line and causedflooding in the Dominican Republic on Sunday night a thehurricane's center passed just south of the Barahona peninsula,then le than 100 mile from neighboring Haiti.The storm ripped the roof off house and flooded coastal areasof southwestern Puerto Rico after reaching hurricane strength offthe island's southeast Saturday night.Flights were canceled Sunday in the Dominican Republic, wherecivil defense director Eugenio Cabral reported some flooding inparts of the capital of Santo Domingo and power outage there andin other southern areas.Hurricane Gilbert swept toward Jamaica yesterday with 100-mile-an-hour wind, and official issued warning to resident on the southern coast of the Dominican Republic, Haiti and Cuba. The storm ripped the roof off house and caused coastal flooding in Puerto Rico. In the Dominican Republic, all domestic flight and flight to and from Puerto Rico and Miami were canceled. Forecasters said the hurricane wa gaining strength a it passed over the ocean and would dump heavy rain on the Dominican Republic and Haiti a it moved south of Hispaniola, the Caribbean island they share, and headed west. "It's still gaining strength. It's certainly one of the larger system we've seen in the Caribbean for a long time," said Hal Gerrish, forecaster at the National Hurricane Center in Coral Gables, Fla. At 3 pm. EDT, the center of the hurricane wa about 100 mile south of the Dominican Republic and 425 mile east of Kingston, Jamaica. The hurricane wa moving west at about 15 mph and wa expected to continue this motion for the next 24 hour. Forecasters said the hurricane's track would take it about 50 mile south of southwestern Haiti. The hurricane center said small craft in the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico should remain in port until condition improve. The forecaster said the Dominican Republic would get a much a 10 inch of rain yesterday, with similar amount falling in Haiti last night and tonight. Hurricane warning were issued for the south coast of Haiti and Cuba by their respective government. In Jamaica, the government issued a hurricane watch for the entire island. Tropical Storm Gilbert formed in the eastern Caribbean and strengthened into a hurricane Saturday night. In Puerto Rico, besides tearing off several roof, the storm caused coastal flooding and brought down power line and tree along road and highway in the west and southwestern region. Three people were injured in Guayanilla, Puerto Rico, when a tree fell on their vehicle a they traveled along Route 97, police reported. Four policeman stationed on Mona Island, between Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic, were stranded a a result of the weather.
column5: Baffling, ferocious, Hurricane Gilbert roars through the Greater Antilles and strikes Mexico
column6: Since Saturday, the ferocious Hurricane Gilbert has roared through the Greater Antilles.  Gilbert killed five in the Dominican Republic and hit Jamaica with its full force, killing 19 and causing extensive damage.  Its 160 mph winds pummeled Mexico's Yucatan peninsula, causing flooding and outages.  Forecasters ask why did Gilbert become so intense?
column7: Hurricane Gilbert has cut a destructive swath through the Caribbean.  The third hurricane of 1988 buffeted the southern coasts of Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, the Dominican Republic, Haiti and Cuba.  Five were killed in the Dominican Republic.  On Monday, the storm hit Jamaica with its full force, killing 19 and causing extensive damage.  Wednesday, Gilbert hit the resorts of Cancun and Cozumel on Mexico's Yucatan peninsula with winds of 160 mph, causing extensive damage.  Gilbert then headed for the Gulf of Mexico.  Forecasters remain baffled by why Gilbert became such an intense storm, attaining the lowest barometric pressure ever recorded.
column8: Since September 10, Hurricane Gilbert has cut a destructive path through the Caribbean, hitting Jamaica and the Yucatan peninsula of Mexico with its full force.  Gilbert became the third hurricane of the 1988 season on Saturday.  On Sunday, it passed south of the Greater Antilles, causing flooding, power outages, and airport closures, and knocking down trees and tearing off roofs in Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, the Dominican Republic, Haiti and Cuba.  In the Dominican Republic, five were killed and 10 inches of rain fell.  The eye of the storm hit Kingston, Jamaica, on Monday, then moved lengthwise across the island, at about 17 mph with sustained winds of 155 mph, causing extensive damage.  Nineteen were killed in Jamaica.  The storm buffeted the Cayman Islands, then struck the resorts of Cancun and Cozumel on the Yucatan with winds of 160 mph.  Power and communications were cut, flooding was extensive, and bands of youths began looting in Cancun.  By midnight, Gilbert was northeast of the Yucatan and heading for the Gulf of Mexico.  Gilbert was an extremely intense storm, attaining the lowest barometric pressure ever recorded in the Western Hemisphere.  Forecasters remain baffled by why this trough became such a ferocious storm.
column9: Record Intensity Hurricane Gilbert Causes Havoc In The Caribbean.
column10: Hurricane Gilbert, a category 5 storm, caused death, massive flooding and damage as it moved through the Caribbean Islands and on to the Yucatan Peninsula.  After skirting several island nations, it caused major death and destruction in Jamaica.  It then pummeled the Yucatan Peninsula before moving out to sea.
column11: Tropical Storm Gilbert strengthened into a hurricane on Saturday night, September 10th in the eastern Caribbean.  It tracked westerly at about 15mph while building in intensity.  After skirting southern Puerto Rico, Haiti and the Dominican Republic, it hit Jamaica with high winds and torrential rains, destroying 100,000 of the countries 500,000 homes and taking nineteen lives.  It then passed over the Cayman Islands before slamming into the Yucatan Peninsula causing heavy damage in the Cancun and Cozumel regions.  Gilbert is the most intense hurricane ever recorded with a record low barometric pressure of 26.31 inches and sustained winds of 179mph, gusting to 218mph.
column12: Tropical Storm Gilbert strengthened into an eastern Caribbean hurricane on Saturday night, September 10, 1988.  Government officials of the island nations in its westerly path issued alerts, warnings and orders to evacuate their southerly-exposed coastal areas.  Puerto Rico, Haiti and the Dominican escaped with only some coastal flooding and a few deaths before Gilbert continued on to strike Jamaica with 110mph winds and torrential rains.  The storm, now one of the largest systems seen in the Caribbean for a long time, slowly traversed the length of the island causing massive damage and nineteen deaths.  100,000 of Jamaica's 500,000 homes were destroyed leaving 500,000 people homeless.  The storm then passed over the Cayman Islands located south of Cuba.  Cuba and our American military bases there both avoided the brunt of the storm before it slammed full force into the Yucatan Peninsula.  By now Gilbert had strengthened into the most severe hurricane ever recorded with barometric pressure of 26.31 inches and sustained winds of 179mph, gusting to 218mph.  Relief efforts for the heavily damaged Cancun and Cozumel areas were hindered due to massive flooding and power and phone outages.  Scientists do not fully understand why some minor tropical storms strengthen into hurricanes, while others do not.

column3: Two corporate executive sat down in an office here last month to talk business with a bunch of clown. The subject wa no laughing matter, but rather the serious endeavor of finding South Korea's Ronald McDonald. Seven year after the US. hamburger giant first tried to bring it Big Macs to South Korea, the golden arch were finally going up. McAhn Industries Ltd. recently opened the first of what it expects will be a string of burger outlet in Seoul. The company is a 50-50 joint venture of McDonald's Corp., Oak Brook, Ill., and an accountant-turned-entrepreneur, Ahn Hyo Young. McDonald's is flourishing in 11 other nation in the region. But it entry into South Korea, which ha Asia's fastest-growing economy, had been frustrated by it inability to find a suitable partner and to win agreement from Seoul on term. South Korea may be one of McDonald's most promising foreign market, business analyst say. The country is developing an essential ingredient for the success of a fast-food enterprise: a middle class. Hamburger-related fast-food sale in South Korea totaled $87.5 million last year, a 30% rise from 1986, according to the Ministry of Finance. Analysts say this year's rise could be much bigger, helped by a 25% increase in wage in mid-1987 and another big pay increase expected soon. The business is likely to profit from the 1988 Olympic Games in Seoul in September, and from an anticipated post-Olympic economic boom here. However, the competition is heating up, and there is "a good possibility that South Korea already ha reached the fast-food saturation point for it current average income bracket," an official for the South Korea Chamber of Commerce and Industry say. The competition, besides Wendy's International's 11 shop and six of Burger King, a unit of Pillsbury Co., includes home-grown burger chain. McDonald's strategy is to take thing slowly, avoiding extravagance, Mr. Ahn and Awad Sifri, McDonald's marketing director, say. "We are starting small," say Mr. Ahn. "We're hoping to open three outlet this year and five next year. After that, we'd like to open five every year." Equally modest, he say, will be the initial menu: no breakfast, no Chicken McNuggets and no product tailored to national taste, a offered elsewhere. The venture is rejecting television commercial in favor of a cheaper, more oldfashioned approach: a brief advertising campaign in newspaper, distribution of flier and word of mouth. Mr. Sifri say the emphasis will be on developing McDonald's image a an affordable place for the emerging middle class, rather than a a familiar name for foreigner in South Korea. Attention will be given to attracting child, he add. Mr. Ahn say McDonald's talked to 16 potential partner before choosing the Harvard-trained accountant in 1984. Two year later, McDonald's and Mr. Ahn each put up $1 million in capital and borrowed an additional $4 million to form McAhn. McDonald's struggled with the government over McAhn's royalty payment to the US. partner -- the issue wa resolved -- and over tight import restriction on food product. The import question "came down to finding a supplier locally who could supply high-quality beef and potato at a value," McDonald's said. Even McDonald's golden arch symbol ran into red tape, since the city regulates the size and color of sign. "It may be against the law, but we're putting them up anyway," Mr. Ahn says.McDonald's hamburger, fry and goldenarches came to China on Monday when the fast-food chain opened itsfirst restaurant in a nation famed for it distinctive cuisine.Hundreds of Chinese waited for hour outside the restaurant inShenzhen, an economic boom town near Hong Kong, for their firsttaste of a McDonald's hamburger, fry or shake.I travelled for four hour from a village to get here, saidHuang Rongti, 70, who ha lost most of her teeth because of age.You think hamburger are too challenging for my age?Later, after purchasing her first Big Mac, she inspected itcarefully before taking a bite.It taste good, I like it, she announced before slowlyeating the rest.The opening of a US. fast-food restaurant in China, wherecooking ha long been considered a culinary art, may seem odd togourmets. It is estimated there are more than 5,000 differentChinese dishes.In Canton, 125 mile northwest of Shenzhen, chef specialize insome of the more exotic Chinese dish, such a cat stew, bearpaws, chicken foot and a famed snake dish - Dragon and TigerLocked in Battle - made from three kind of poisonous snakesstewed with leopard meat, and garnished with 20 spice, lemonleaves and chrysanthemum petals.However, many Chinese, who earn an average $32 a month, arestill unable to afford fancy meal at restaurants.In Shenzhen, a Chinese special economic zone where foreigninvestors have built factory, salary are higher and workersearn an average of $53 a month.At the restaurant, a Big Mac cost $1.14, a bag of fry 48cents and a shake 74 cents.Another US. fast food outlet, Kentucky Fried Chicken, opened arestaurant in Beijing in 1987, and it now ha four outlet there.McDonald's hope to open a restaurant in Beijing later.Although Kentucky Fried Chicken ha become popular, the averageChinese still regard a meal there a a treat, rather than aconvenience, and McDonald's could face the same problems.The 500-seat McDonald's restaurant in a three-story building isoperated by McDonald's Restaurant Shenzhen Ltd., a wholly ownedsubsidiary of McDonald's Hong Kong. McDonald's Hong Kong is a 50-50joint venture with McDonald's in the United States.It is managed by a Chinese national, Chen Tikang, and his son,Chen Yin, who is the restaurant manager. The younger Chen returnedrecently from a course at McDonald's hamburger university in OakBrook, Ill.Most of the ingredient used at the restaurant are now importedfrom Hong Kong.
