But McDonald's executive hope eventually to gettheir supply of beef and potato from China.Daniel Ng, chairman of McDonald's Restaurant Shenzhen Ltd., saidit took two year to prepare for the restaurant's opening and hisambition now is to serve 10 million burger a year.Last month, when McDonald's advertized for 240 staffer for therestaurant, it received application from more than 9,000 persons,including college graduate, official said.I feel I have a better job prospect working here, and it paysbetter, said Henry He, 25, who ha a master's degree in garmentand textile. He is an assistant manager at the restaurant.A waiter at the restaurant can earn 53 cent an hour.A factory worker, who waited several hour before she wa ableto purchase her hamburger, said she liked it because of it sweettaste - the result of tomato ketchup, which is not commonly usedin traditional Chinese cooking.AS THE value of the rouble plunge and potential foreign investor worryabout a host of obstacle to investing in Russia, Russian official hadseveral reason yesterday to feel thankful for McDonald's hamburgers.Opening the second McDonald's restaurant in Moscow, along with a 12-storeyoffice block, Mr George Cohon, head of McDonald's Canada, could well bedescribed a the Russian authorities' idea of a model investor.McDonald's proven determination 'to be here for the long term' and to serveRussians in their own currency a opposed to the dollar charged by mostother foreign joint venture are just a couple of reason for Russiangratitude.Mr Viktor Khlystun, the agriculture minister, praised the fact thatMcDonald's get most of it supply from inside Russia after setting up aDollars 45m processing plant outside Moscow.He also thanked McDonald's for providing job, a model of western standardsfor the country's decrepit service industry, and finally for what hedescribed a 'the most delicious food'.But despite the jolly opening ceremony - with Big Macs, musician playingthe balalaika, and hundred of yellow balloon forming a giant M - life hasbeen tough for McDonald's since it opened it first restaurant in Moscow 31/2 year ago.Although the first Moscow restaurant is the busiest McDonald's in the worldthe plunging rouble, high inflation and constantly changing tax rule havebeen a challenge to McDonald's management, who admitted that they have noidea of when it could recoup it initial Dollars 50m investment.'It will depend on how rapidly we can open new restaurant, what happens tothe rouble, what happens to raw material that we buy. We don't have anestimate of how long it will take. There are too many variables,' said MrCohon.Apart from housing the restaurant on the ground floor, the McDonald's officeblock is rented out to western company in an attempt to generate hardcurrency alongside the mountain of rouble made from selling hamburgers.Communism suffered it first Big Macattack Thursday a McDonald's opened a restaurant in Yugoslavia,and police were called in to keep customer who lined up for hoursfrom getting too unruly under the golden arches.I just wanted to taste genuine American hamburger, saidMilica Nikolic, a high school student who waited for three hour totaste her first Big Mac.People curiously examined the renovated restaurant's plushinterior and the back-lit sign depicting the hamburger, frenchfries, milk shake and other fare more familiar in the West. Italso featured amber-colored table and floor, pastel-coloredupholstery, modern art painting and discreet illumination.The fast-food outlet, located on a downtown square, had drawncrowds in recent day, and they began gathering long before itopened Thursday.Police kept watch on the line of customer snaking around theblock, and they regulated the number who came inside to avoidovercrowding.No opening of a restaurant in Belgrade ha created such asensation a this one today, one policeman said.I think this restaurant ha no competition in Belgrade, saidMilica Danic, a housewife who treated her son to a cheeseburger.It is much cleaner, the service is faster, the interior is nicerand it is not too expensive.The Belgrade medium have suggested that the success of McDonald'sin Yugoslavia depends on it acceptance by citizen long accustomedto a hamburger-like fast-food dish called the Pljeskavica: groundpork and onion on a bun.In fact, this is a clash between the Big Mac andPljeskavica, said Vesna Milosevic, an official of Genex, aYugoslav state-run enterprise that ha contracted a joint ventureagreement with McDonald's.Our aim is not to destroy the Pljeskavica on the Yugoslavmarket, said Predrag Dostanic, managing director of theGenex-McDonald's. We want to change custom of the local peopleused to completly different eating habits.He said that lounging at table for a long time after a finishedmeal will draw a warning. Also, smoking is forbidden and alcoholwill not be served.This contrast sharply with the Balkan and Yugoslav custom ofsitting with a drink in smoke-filled restaurant and chatting withfriends after the meal.The Big Mac meal, consisting of a hamburger, soft drink andfrench fry cost the equivalent of $2.57, or about a much thesimilar meal would cost in numerous Pljeskavica joint around town.Sadik Seljami, a waiter in a small Pljeskavica outlet just a fewhundred yard from the McDonald's, suggested that the Americanrestaurant want to drive Yugoslav fast-food outlet out ofbusiness.However, we will not give up the fight even if we have tolower the price, said Seljami.Glen Cook, an executive of the McDonald's Corp., said during theopening ceremony, We are very excited about the opening of thisrestaurant, not only because it is the first one in a communistcountry, but also because it is one of the nicest in Europe.McDonald's and Genex contribute $1 million each for the flagshiprestaurant. They will also share the profit equally even though itwill be managed entirely by Yugoslavs.The restaurant ha 350 seat and employ 110 people capable ofserving 2,500 meal per hour. In an effort to keep a high level ofservices, the management is entitled to fire any employee who failto perform.The American corporation plan to open five additionalrestaurants Yugoslavia in the next five year. The next EastEuropean McDonald's, and the first in a Soviet bloc country, is toopen next month in Budapest, Hungary.The communist world get it firstMcDonald's next week, and some people here are wondering whetherits American hamburger will be a popular a the local fast-foodtreat, Pljeskavica.The long-awaited opening of the restaurant on one of Belgrade'smain downtown square will take place March 24, the Yugoslav newsagency Tanjug reported, and it will offer Big Macs, fry and theother speciality familiar to McDonald's customer in the West.The Belgrade medium have suggested that the success of theAmerican restaurant depends on it acceptance by Yugoslavians whoare long accustomed to the hamburger-like Pljeskavica.Pljeskavica is made of ground pork and onion, and it is servedon bread and eaten with the hand. It is sold at fast-foodrestaurants across the country and cost about a dollar.In fact, this is a clash between the Big Mac andPljeskavica, said an official of Genex, Yugoslavia's largeststate-run enterprise that will operate the McDonald's.John Onoda, a spokesman at McDonald's Oak Brook, Ill.headquarters, said it wa the first of the chain's outlet in acommunist country.The next East European McDonald's is scheduled to be opened inBudapest, Hungary, by the end of this year, said Vesna Milosevic,another Genex official.Negotiations have been going on for year for expanding thefast-food chain to the Soviet Union, but no agreement ha beenannounced.Thousands of queue-hardened Soviets on Wednesdaycheerfully lined up to get a taste of gamburgers,chizburgers and Filay-o-feesh sandwich a McDonald'sopened in the land of Lenin for the first time.The world's largest version of the landmark American fast-foodchain rang up 30,000 meal on 27 cash register, breaking theopening-day record for McDonald's worldwide, official said.The Soviets, bundled in fur coat and hat, seemed unfazed,lining up before dawn outside the 700-seat restaurant, the first of20 planned across the Soviet Union. The crush of customer wa sointense the company stayed open until midnight, two hour laterthan planned.I only waited an hour and I think they served thousand beforeme, said a happy middle-aged woman who work at an aluminum plant.And it wa only 10 ruble for all this, she said. I'mtaking it back for the girl at the factory to try.Big Macs were priced at 3.75 ruble and double cheeseburger at3 ruble about two hours' pay for a starting McDonald's stafferor the average Soviet, but much cheaper than other privaterestaurants that have sprung up recently.The official exchange rate is $1.59 per ruble but foreignvisitors can buy ruble for 16 cent each, about what the currencyis worth on the black market.Half the day's sale were donated to the Soviet Children's Fund,which provides medical care and assistance to orphan anddisadvantaged child, Gary Reinblatt, senior vice president ofMcDonald's Canada, said from Toronto.The restaurant, built by the company in a joint venture with thecity of Moscow that began 14 year ago, brought to 52 the number ofcountries where McDonald's operates.The previous opening-day record for sale wa in Budapest,company official said. Besides it restaurant in the UnitedStates, the leading number of McDonald's are in Canada and Japan,the official said.Soviets got a first-hand look at such alien concept asefficiency and fast, friendly service. Normally dour citizen brokeinto grin a they caught the infectious cheerful mood fromyouthful Soviet staffer hired for their ability to smile and workhard.Accordions played folk song and woman in traditional costumesdanced with cartoon character, including Mickey Mouse and BabaYaga, a witch of Russian fairy tales.One Muscovite, accustomed to clerk who snarl if they sayanything at all, asked for a straw and wa startled when a smilingyoung Soviet woman found him one and popped it straight into hisdrink.For most customer, it wa their first experience with ahamburger. Sandwiches were served in the familiar bag marked withthe golden arch, but were packed in wrapper bearing Cyrillicletters, approximating gamburger.They tried them one-handed. They picked their sandwich apartto examine the content. One young woman finally squashed herBeeg Mak to fit her lip around it.It tasted great! a 14-year-old boy said.It's a lot different from a stolovaya, he continued with asmile, referring to the much cheaper but run-down dirty cafeteriasthat slop rice and fat or boiled sausage.Under the sign of the golden arch, accented by the Soviethammer-and-sickle flag, hundred lined up for the long-awaitedgrand opening at 10 am. on Pushkin Square, reaching out excitedlyfor McDonald's flag and pin a the hamburger chain's armyfulfilled the Soviet penchant for souvenir with Western logos.Publicity-conscious manager had the staff shout Good morning,America! in English and Russian, for an American TV network.McDonald's of Canada Chairman George Cohon, the man behind thedeal, said many people were buying multiple order and therestaurant served 15,000 to 20,000 people in just the first fivehours of operation.The restaurant limited purchase to 10 Big Macs per customer inhopes of preventing burger-scalping.McDonald's built it own factory, including bakery, dairy,meat-processing plant and even potato storage yard, to provide itsown guaranteed supply in a country where up to 25 percent of theharvest rot en route to the consumer.One McDonald's associate said the company wound up importingwooden crate from Finland for storing potato because when theywent to build crate, they found there wa no wood, and no nails.They found you need a permit to buy nail.
column5: McDonald's opens restaurants in Korea, Yugoslavia, the Soviet Union, and China.
column6: McDonald's moved into new markets, opening restaurants in Korea, Yugoslavia, the firstcommunist country to get a McDonald's, the Soviet Union, and China. The opening daycrowds were large and  enthusiastic about the flavor of the Big Mac. The openings cameafter years of negotiations which, in some cases, stipulated that McDonald's buy itssupplies locally.
column7: The Big Mac debuted to mixed review as McDonald's opened restaurants in Korea,Yugoslavia, the Soviet Union, and China. Large crowds stood in line for hours atopenings in Belgrade, Moscow, and Peking. Customers in Yugoslavia, the firstcommunist country to get a McDonald's, and China raved about the taste of the Big Mac.In Moscow, the Russians were less enthusiastic about its taste but gave a thumbs up tothe shakes. The openings came after long negotiations which, in most cases, sawMcDonald's contracting with local farmers for the beef, potatoes and other suppliesneeded for its restaurants.
column8: McDonald's has expanded into non-western markets. After years of negotiations, McDonald's has been able to open restaurants in Korea, Yugoslavia, the Soviet Union, and China. Most significantly, the opening of the McDonald's in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, gave communism its first taste of a Big Mac. Moving into new markets meant that McDonald's had to overcome a number of problems. These problems range from competing with local fast food, such as the Pljeskavica in Yugoslavia, to finding reliable supplies for its restaurants. In the Soviet Union and Korea, finding supplies means contracting with local farmers for beef and potatoes. In Russia, this meant building a 50M supply facility, a cost which had not been recouped at the time of opening of the second McDonald's in Moscow. While the taste of the Big Mac met with approval, its cost could be a factor in its success. In Moscow and Peking, the high cost of a Big Mac, fries, and a shake could mean that McDonald's will viewed as a treat and not a convenience food. In the Soviet Union,  taking a family to McDonald's could cost the average worker two-days wages. Only in Korea, with its middle class, does McDonald's stand a chance of becoming a convenience food.
column9: McDonald's "Golden Arches" Continues Its World-wide Expansion
column10: McDonald's continues its worldwide expansion.  To participate in Asia's fastest expanding economy, came their first restaurant in South Korea.  Moving into communist countries, its opening in Belgrade, Yugoslavia was followed by a record shattering opening of its largest outlet anywhere in Moscow.  Then came Shenzhan, McDonald's first foray into China.
column11: To capitalize on Asia's fastest-growing economy McDonald's opened its first outlet in South Korea.  Moving into communist countries, on March 24, 1988 it opened in Belgrade, Yugoslavia.  There to compete with the locally favored "pljeskavica", a pork and onion sandwich, initial reaction was favorable.  Two years later came its largest outlet to date.  In Moscow thousands lined up for an opening day record of 30,000 meals being served at 27 cash registers.  Next, McDonald's opened in China, where cooking is a culinary art.  McDonald's worldwide restaurants are joint ventures with locals of the country in which they operate.
column12: "Golden Arches" continues its worldwide expansion.  In 1988, seven years after its first attempt to bring a restaurant to South Korea, McDonald's successfully joint-ventured with Ahn Hyo Young, a Harvard schooled entrepreneur. McAhn Enterprises Ltd. had to fight government red tape and develop local suppliers in order to open in Seoul.  That year, Big Mac also braved the communist world.  On March 24, 1988, McDonald's successfully opened in Belgrade, Yugoslavia.  Its local competition was the hamburger-like pljeskavica, i.e., ground pork and onion served on bread and eaten by hand.  Two years later, McDonald's had their most successful opening ever, worldwide.  In Pushkin Square, Moscow, thousands of people waited in line for hours at the largest McDonald's in the world for hamburgers, fries and shakes.  This opening day "Mac attack" resulted in 30,000 meals being served over fourteen hours at 27 cash registers.  Customers were surprised and pleased to find efficient, friendly workers in this country of generally surly service.  And then, China, where cooking is a culinary art.  A restaurant opened in Shenzhen, a special economic zone outside of Hong Kong where the average worker's pay there is considerably higher than in the rest of China.  McDonald's hopes to soon expand into Mainland China.

column3: The mass emigration of thousand of disaffected East Germans ha rekindled reunification talk in West Germany, where some legislator plan to begin exploring the possiblity of reuniting the two Germanys. No one is predicting a date for a possible reunification. Proponents acknowledge the risk of assuming too much of East Bloc reform trend, and most hedge their thought with careful reference to Washington and Moscow. Yet growing sign of ferment in East Germany have given Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government reason to consider the possibility. Eduard Lintner, parliamentary speaker on German affair for the joint Christian Democrat and Christrian Socialist caucus in the Bundestag, said his committee ha placed reunification on it October agenda. He said the session, which will include government official and outside expert, hopefully can devise reunification model to discus with West Germany's Western ally, particularly the US. "It ha become clear to the world that the Communist system in East Germany is in trouble," Mr. Lintner said. "The time ha come for u to show our ally, but also reform-minded people in the East, that German reunification is no longer just a theory but a subject requiring a serious appraisal of how it could come about." "There are still a number of imponderables," Mr. Linter conceded. "For instance, we want the federal government to approach our ally and get their thought on the reunification topic." The US. ambassador to Bonn, Vernon A. Walters, earlier this month reaffirmed Washington's policy of supporting a German reunification based on free, democratic election. But Mr. Walters caused a stir by predicting that reunion could occur in the relatively near future. Emerging opposition to uncompromising Communist rule in East Germany ha raised question on how long East Berlin's leader can resist the democratic reform sweeping through neighboring East Bloc country. Reforms in Poland, Hungary and even the Soviet Union have magnified East Germany's Stalinist control. Fledgling protest group, and the influential Protestant church, have begun pressing for reform in East Germany which, if allowed to include free election, could eventually lead to a reunited Germany, according to some Western expert. Dorothee Wilms, Bonn's cabinet minister for inter-German affair, said in an interview in the newspaper Welt am Sonntag that recent poll show that between 85% and 90% of all West Germans favor a reunifed Germany. "The desire for reunification, a feeling of togetherness, a sense of nationhood -- all this ha strongly increased in recent years," Ms. Wilms told the newspaper. "The recent escape movement from the DDR make especially clear that people of both German state want to live free amongst themselves," she said, but cautioned that reunification cannot occur overnight. The first step, she added, "is the reform process in the DDR." Most West German government since 1949 have paid only lip service to the reunification goal set down in the preamble of West Germany's constitution. Political reality have prevented the topic from becoming a serious issue. Analysts say that four decade of different system would make reunification difficult. Further, many West German worker worry that a mass influx of East Germans could threaten their job. Thousands of East Germans have emigrated to West Germany over the Austro-Hungarian border since Budapest ignored East Berlin's protest and opened it border. Close to 80,000 East German refugee have arrived in West Germany so far this year, either legally or by escaping, and a total of more than 100,000 are expected by December. The Soviets have joined East Berlin in criticizing Bonn for welcoming the East German refugee, and chided Hungary for violating an emigration treaty with East Germany by allowing them to leave. Moscow, which ha tolerated reform elsewhere in the East Bloc, is said to be concerned by condition in East Germany, perhaps the most important of it Warsaw Pact satellite. Unconfirmed West German intelligence report appearing in the West German medium said Moscow fear a growing dissident movement and mass demonstration in East Germany by next year. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev accepted an invitation to attend East Germany's 40th anniversary celebration, providing an opportunity for serious discussion with Erich Honecker, East Berlin's ailing party leader. East Germany's Communist leadership, commented the newspaper Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, "has no illusion a to why Gorbachev is honoring their 40th anniversary. He certainly will not say 'well done, keep it up.'"The government on Thursday allowed for thepossibility of a reunified Germany, but said such a state must beformed gradually and respect Poland's borders.In the Solidarity government's first definitive statement on theissue, Foreign Minister Krzysztof Skubiszewski told Parliament thetwo German state could be joined a part of the process of unitingEurope.He said German reunification cannot go ahead of thereunification of Europe.A reunited Germany will not be created tomorrow or the dayafter tomorrow, Skubiszewski said. Fears and concern appearingevery now and then, including in Poland, are unjustified, althoughalertness is recommended.Asked about German reunification at a news conference in Gdansk,Solidarity labor leader Lech Walesa said he prefers no politicalchanges in Europe, but there should be all kind of economicintegrations.Western European country have agreed to form an economic unionby the end of 1992.Sweeping democratic reform have taken hold in East Germany inthe past several week under the pressure of mass protests,spurring talk of reuniting the two German state divided at the endof World War II. West Germany ha proposed a plan for greaterunity, but East German leader reject reunification.The specter of a powerful, reunited Germany ha troubed manyPoles, especially the older one who recall the 1939 Nazi invasionof Poland that began World War II.A reported surge in anti-Polish sentiment in East Germany inrecent week ha heightened Polish anxieties.Skubiszewski's speech seemed designed to reassure Poles that thegovernment doe not see unification in the near future and willinsist on Poland's current borders.Skubiszewski faulted West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl'sprogram for gradual German reunification, offered last week, fornot making clear that reunification would respect the existingborder between Poland and East Germany.Some right-wing West German politician have called forrecovering the 40,000 square mile of territory that Germany lostto Poland at the end of World War II. The territory is aboutone-third of present-day Poland.East Germany and West Germany each separately ha recognized theborder, but there ha been no official assurance that a reunifiedGermany would also acknowledge the border.One can only unite within established border and withoutterritorial argument, said Skubiszewski.He also said German reunification is unlikely a long a WestGermany belongs to NATO and East Germany to the Soviet-led WarsawPact military alliance.The Berlin villa where the Nazi leadership metto implement the final solution against Europe's Jewishpopulation will be the site of a World Jewish Congress conferenceon German reunification.The New York-based organization announced Tuesday that themeeting is scheduled for May 8, the 45th anniversary of V-E Day.The world is expecting a Jewish statement on reunification,said Edgar Bronfman, the president of the World Jewish Congress.I think that the place where they decided on the `finalsolution' is the right place to have such a meeting, and theanniversary of the victory in Europe seems to be the right day.Some 100 member of the World Jewish Congress from about 70countries will attend the conference at the villa in WannseeBerlin, where on Jan. 20, 1942, high German government and partyofficials adopted a plan to exterminate the Jews.Jews have a right to state a moral position on Germanreunification and we will make a moral statement. And part of thatmoral statement is to see that it (the Holocaust) doesn't happenagain, Bronfman said.In the long run, he said, a united Germany can be a verypositive thing for Europe, but certain precaution must be takento prevent a repeat of history. For example, Germany's bordersmust be sealed in cement, and the country should not be allowednuclear weapon, he said.Bronfman said he doe not fear a resurgence of anti-Semitismonce the two Germanys are united. In fact, he said, reunificationmight cause a decline in anti-Jewish feelings.Now that reunification is about to be a fact, they won't beblaming the Jews for a divided Germany, Bronfman explained.The conference will convene May 6 and a formal declaration onGerman reunification will be issued May 8. It will be the firstmeeting ever held on German soil by the World Jewish Congress,which wa founded in 1936 in response to Hitler's threat againstJews.Three decade ago, a West Germanpolitician said German reunification wa a sleeping lionessthat would awake one day with a mighty roar.Now, there is growing speculation the awakening may be at handto create a giant political and economic machine that coulddominate Europe.Reunification is coming closer, but I can't say whether itwill take 10, 15 or 20 year, say West German conservativelawmaker Eduard Lintner. We have the impression that thing aremuch more concrete than we could have imagined five year ago.The daily sight of thousand of refugee fleeing East Germanleader Erich Honecker's hard-line Communist rule for the capitalistWest ha revived international interest in the debate.Once dismissed a a nostalgic daydream, the idea of Germanreunification ha gotten a public nod from President Bush andsomething short of a categorical no from President Mikhail S.Gorbachev of the Soviet Union.The idea make East German leader virtually apopletic.If there were a free choice under the present circumstance inthe German Democratic Republic (East Germany), certainly 80 percentto 90 percent would vote for national reunification with theFederal Republic of Germany, added the 44-year-old Lintner in anAssociated Press interview.The West German constitution call for a united Germany, but ithas not been a paramount concern of the West Germans in the yearssince the ruin of Nazi Germany were divided into East and West atthe end of World War II.Full national reunification would completey rework the postwarEuropean order mapped out by the conquering Allies. It is aprospect that creates unease in Britain and France, and in Polandin the East bloc.London's prestigious Sunday Times on Sept. 10 mapped out apossible scenario that includes massive troop reduction in Europe,Honecker's death and further Westernization of Poland and Hungary.Moscow unilaterally abolishes the Warsaw Pact after guaranteesfrom Poland and Hungary they will not join other alliance, theTimes' futuristic view continued. West Germany withdraws fromNATO; and a referendum in both East and West Germany vote forreunification and neutrality.That sort of talk is being heard more and more a Moscow loosensits hold on the East bloc and country like the Soviet Union,Poland and Hungary explore democratic reforms.The implication of pulling down the Berlin Wall and otherbarriers to link the two German state are enormous and, for many,ominous.As much of Western Europe head towards it own unification in1992, the economic center of gravity would be shifted even furtherto the German side with a powerhouse of nearly 80 million people 61.1 million West Germans and 16.6 million East Germans.West Germany is already Europe's largest exporting nation, anddespite it many flaw East Germany's economy is the envy of manySoviet bloc neighbors.A unified Germany could become the political focal point of acontinent already in flux, a democratic movement sweep part ofthe Soviet bloc.Older generation recall eerie echo of Nazi dictator AdolfHitler's boasting that he had brought about the unity of theGerman nation.Eva Kulesza, head of research for the Soviet Union and EasternEurope at the French Institute of International Relations, say shebelieves that a far a public opinion there is new sort ofmistrust toward Germany.This new fear of Germany is linked to German economic trends.Germany is much stronger, much more dynamic than France, sheadded.Since West Germany and East Germany are at the front line oftwo competing alliance, any sign for eventual reunification wouldhave to come from Washington and Moscow.During a news conference last week in Montana, Bush said thatreunification is a matter for the Germans to decide.But he added: If that (reunification) wa worked out betweenthe Germanys, I do not think we should view that a bad for Westerninterests.For his part, Gorbachev evaded the issue during a newsconference in Bonn in June, saying only, the situation in Europetoday wa determined by historical realities.Outside Germany, political leader and commentator have beensharply divided on the issue.In thinking about the German Question, we ought not to begoverned by old prejudice and out-of-date assumption, wrotecommentator Peter Jenkins in London's The Independent. column5: A concerned world watches a divided Germany unite.
column6: With growing numbers of disgruntled East Germans emigrating to West Germany, the idea of reunification seemed possible and became actively discussed among western leaders.  Some people and neighboring states had concerns about reunification, but after Soviet and East German communists dropped their opposition, things moved quickly to that end.
column7: Political unrest and a collapsing economy prompted tens of thousands of skilled East German workers to rush through recently opened borders to West Germany.  Western leaders saw that a reunified Germany was possible.  The East bloc communists, initially opposed to the idea, softened by urging reunification as a longer-term goal, to be reached in gradual stages.  Serious concerns about the future relations of NATO and the Warsaw Pact, the impact a strong, united German state would have on the evolving European integration, trepidation by neighboring states and the fears of Jews world-wide had to be addressed.  Reunification occurred.  It was inevitable.
column8: Democratic reforms elsewhere in the Eastern Bloc magnified the emerging opposition to uncompromising Communist rule in East Germany.  The mass emigration of tens of thousands of skilled East German workers to West Germany led West German officials to conclude that reunification, which was codified in the West German constitution, was possible.  Polls in West Germany supported the idea, as did the U.S. President, George Bush.  Soviet President Gorbachev and East German leader, Erich Honecker, did not.  Eventually, Honecker was arrested for treason and abuse of power and Gorbachev softened his position.  He and interim East German Premier Hans Modrow realized that the East German socialist system had failed and reunion would occur.  However, they envisioned a gradual, no-timetable approach toward confederation while European-wide issues were being worked out.  Of paramount importance to Gorbachev was the effect reunification would have on NATO and Warsaw Pact relationships.  Poland was concerned that a united German might want to recover 40,000 square miles of land that was part of Germany before World War II.  And Jews worldwide feared that a militarily resurgent Germany could inflict another Holocaust.  After Gorbachev abolished the Warsaw Pact things moved quickly.  All European and Jewish issues were addressed.  Reunification occurred.
column9: East's Economy Sagging. Soviets Endorse German Reunification. World Awaits Change
column10: Woeful economic conditions and massive demonstrations in East Germany gave impetusto German reunification. Soviet endorsement of reunification in 1990 made it imminent.Many perceived a strong unified Germany as a danger, but that was accepted as a lesserthreat than East Germany in turmoil.
column11: East Germany was near chaos by the end of 1989. Woeful economic conditionsprevailed. Massive demonstrations for democratic reform swept the nation. The hard-lineCommunist government admitted its failure, giving strong impetus to the Germanreunification movement. The Soviets endorsed it in February as the World War II Alliesdid later. Unification was now imminent.The specter of an economically and politically powerful Germany disturbed many, butparticularly the Poles, Soviets and world Jewry. Despite concerns, reunification would beaccepted as a lesser threat than a chaotic East Germany.
column12: Through the first three months of 1989, 80,00 East Germans fled their country, andmassive demonstrations raised doubts that Erich Honeker the, hard-line Communistleader could resist the democratic reforms sweeping his country. Street demonstrationsoccurred throughout East Germany in November 1989, and the East German CommunistParty was forced to admit the its system had failed.The West German constitution called for a united Germany, but it received little attentionuntil late 1989. The specter of a powerful undivided Germany troubled many, butparticularly the Soviets and Poles.Matters moved quickly in early 1990. Soviet President Gorbachev gave West Germanyan unequivocal promise that German reunification would be honored. Two days later, onthe 12th of February, said that negotiations with East Germany should begin as soon aspossible after the 18 March East German elections. In time the World War II Allieswould endorse reunification.With reunification imminent, world Jewish leaders asked for guarantees that theHolocaust would not be repeated. Most prominent American historians agreed that astable Germany was a lesser threat to stability than the woeful conditions and near chaosin East Germany.

It is senseless. One simply wonder whatsort of mentality can even contemplate such meaningless act. It isappalling.He paid tribute to the 12 injured men, five of whom werecritically wounded.The prince wa accompanied by Viscountess Mountbatten, daughterof Lord Mountbatten, who wa killed by an IRA bomb on his boat in1979. Mountbatten wa India's last viceroy and a cousin of thequeen.British military installation are a frequent target of theIrish Republican Army in it campaign to end British rule inNorthern Ireland and unite the predominantly Protestant provincewith the Roman Catholic Republic of Ireland.Defense Secretary Tom King said Sunday he ha issued an alert toall military installation to prevent other attack. He would notgive details.The perpetrator of the latest outrage are at large and thereis a risk of other attack, King said. That is why we aretaking a number of other steps.King defended the use of private security firm hired to guardthe Deal school and 29 other low-risk military installation inBritain. Local resident and grieving relative have said securitywas lax and should be turned back to the marine. King said theprivate firm will remain.It is important to remember that what we need in these casesare eye and ear and observation, King said on BritishBroadcasting Corp. radio.Private security guard can be a very useful additionalassistance. They also help to reduce the amount of time soldiershave to spend on what is not the most enjoyable part of theiractivity.At church service throughout the small port, clergyman urgedmourners to pray for and forgive the bombers.The Rev. Charles Howard, a Royal Navy chaplain, asked the300-member congregation inside the barrack, if you can find roomin your heart . pray for the men who perpetrated this terribleact, that God will soften their heart and turn them from theirviolent and evil ways.Many cried a Howard read aloud the name of the 10 servicemenkilled during a coffee break between band practice. It wa theworst IRA attack on the British mainland since July 1982.At nearby St. George's Church, formerly the Royal Marines'church, Lings said, no one say forgiveness is easy; no one saysthe terrorist deserves forgiveness.But . forgive them, they not what they do.An explosion today flattened a militarybarracks and tore through nearby home, killing 11 people andinjuring 22, police said. The IRA claimed responsibility for theblast.More than 100 rescue worker frantically dug through the rubbleof a three-story building that collapsed at the Royal Marines Schoolof Music near Deal. Stunned neighbor gathered outside home thatwere damaged or destroyed.Chief Police Inspector Alan Butterfield of Kent, who who providedthe casualty figure and coordinated the rescue effort, firstreported that one person wa missing but later said everyone wasaccounted for.He said many of the injured were seriously hurt.There wa a terrific crash which reminded me of the Blitz.After that, the ceiling started to fall down around me, saidpensioner Joan Betteridge.Defense Secretary Tom King, inspecting the wreckage, said: Itis not yet absolutely confirmed that it is a bomb, but all theevidence is quite clearly that this is an IRA atrocity.British military installation are a frequent bombing target ofthe Irish Republican Army in it campaign to rid Northern Ireland ofBritish rule, but today's explosion in the coastal town 70 milessoutheast of London wa the worst IRA attack on the British mainlandin more than seven years.The explosion occurred at at 8:26 am. in a lounge in thebarracks. One of the band had just stopped playing on the paradeground, said a ministry spokesman, speaking anonymously in keepingwith British custom.Dozens of home near the school were damaged, including four thatwere destroyed. Witnesses reported hearing the explosion two milesaway.The Defense Ministry would not say how many serviceman andcivilians were included in the casualty figure. However, King toldreporters the attack wa directed against unarmed bandsmen.Firefighters used heavy lifting equipment and thermal camera tosearch through the debris, said Kent Fire Brigade spokesman KevinSimmons.Ten doctor were giving emergency treatment at the scene and 11ambulances were taking the injured to two hospital, the ambulanceservice said.A statement telephoned to Ireland International, a Dublin newsagency, said we have visited the Royal Marines in Kent inresponse to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's visit to NorthernIreland nine day ago.The IRA said Mrs. Thatcher went to the British province with amessage of war, but we still want peace and we want the Britishgovernment to leave our country. It wa signed P. O'Neill, a nomde guerre the IRA usually us to claim responsibility for actionsoutside Northern Ireland.Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey issued a statement in Dublincondemning the attack, calling it an outrage.The last IRA bomb attempt on the British mainland wa in Februarywhen about 60 soldier were evacuated from their barrack inShropshire, western England, just before a bomb exploded. Onesoldier wa killed and nine wounded in an IRA bomb attack on an armybarracks in north London in August 1988.In July 1982, eight soldier died in IRA bombing near theHousehold Cavalry barrack in central London and at a bandstand inthe capital's Regent's Park where an army band wa playing. Threepeople died later and a total of 51 were injured in the bombings.The music school is the training center for young recruit whowant to play in the seven Royal Marines band. Up to 250 young men,most between 16 and 20, are based at the school, where they receivemilitary and musical training.The roof of Janet Minnock's house wa torn off by the force ofthe blast and all the back window were shattered.The house ha been blown to bit, she said. We are allshaken upMrs. Minnock's next-door neighbor, Heather Hackett, said she wasstanding at her kitchen window facing the barrack at the time ofthe explosion. She wa holding her 4-month-old son Luke in her armswith her other boy, Ben, 3, and Joshua, 2, at her side.I looked up from the sink and I just saw the whole buildingexplode, she said. I told the boy to run and a Joshua turned aslither of glass embedded itself in his back. The whole window wasblown across the kitchen. I just screamed and ran out of the room.The bang wa so loud I thought the whole house wa coming in.Sean Minnock said: I wa asleep but woke up with a hell of ajolt.As worker tried to patch hole in his roof, he said: Thebedroom ceiling fell in on me. I woke to find huge slab of plasteron the bed and floor. I wondered what it wa. As soon a I got up Ilooked out of what wa left of the window and knew it wa thebarracks.
column5: IRA blast kills 10 at Royal Marines School of Music.
column6: A barracks belonging to the Royal Marines Music School in Deal was blown up by the Irish Republican Army on Friday, killing 10 and injuring 22.  The IRA said the bombing was in response to a speech by Prime Minister Thatcher to the Ulster Defense Regiment; a speech they considered an act of war.
column7: An Irish Republican Army bomb destroyed a barracks belonging to the Royal Marines Music School in Deal on Friday. The blast killed 10 and injured 22 others and also damaged or destroyed neighboring houses. Neighbors and opposition politicians blamed lax security and condemned the use of private security firms at this and 29 other bases in Britain considered to be low risk. The IRA said the blast was in response to a speech by Prime Minister Thatcher to the Ulster Defense Regiment, calling the speech an "act of war." This is the latest of a series of attacks as the IRA seeks the withdrawal of British forces from Northern Ireland.
column8: A barracks at the Royal Marine Music School in Deal was leveled in an explosion on Friday, which killed 10 persons and injured 22 others, 12 seriously.  Responsibility for the blast was claimed by the Irish Republican Army, which said the attack was in response to a recent speech made by Prime Minister Thatcher to the Ulster Defense Regiment. Calling the speech an "act of war," the IRA said such attacks would continue until the British withdrew their forces from Northern Ireland and allow a unification of the protestant Northern Ireland with the Roman Catholic Republic of Ireland. The explosion, which could be heard two miles away, came at 8:30 in the morning, just as the musicians were taking a coffee break. Destroying the barracks, it also severely damaged a number of neighborhood homes, causing minor injuries among their residents. Neighbors of the barracks as well as opposition politicians blamed the use of private security firms, which, they say, caused the security at the base to be lax. Defending the use of the firms, Defense Secretary Tome King issued an alert for all military bases in Britain. The attack is the latest in a series of deadly attacks against British bases in the last 20 years.
column9: 10 Word SummaryIRA Bomb Destroys Barracks in Deal with 10 Reported Dead
column10: The IRA claimed responsibility for a bomb that destroyed a military barracks on 22September. Ten bandsmen of the Royal Marines School of Music were killed.Neighboring homes in Deal were damaged. Government policy of using private securityfirms at some installations, including the School, is being criticized.
column11: An explosion on 22 September destroyed a military barracks in Deal. Ten men assignedto the Royal Marines School of Music were killed. The IRA claimed responsibility forthe bombing, the most devastating attack against the British mainland since 1982.No serious injuries to civilians were reported, but neighboring homes suffered severedamage.Private security firms guard the Music School and 29 other "low-risk" militaryestablishments in Britain. Victims' families and opposition party leaders blamed thedisaster on lax security. Police were seeking three men with Irish accents who lived in thearea for a brief time.
column12: An explosion at 8:28 A.M. on 22 September destroyed a military barracks in Deal, a townsoutheast of London in County Kent. The barracks was home to the Royal MarinesSchool of Music. Ten military bandsmen were killed, and as many as 22 were injured,eight seriously.Neighbors expressed shock at the strength of the blast. No serious injuries to civilianswere reported, but neighboring homes suffered heavy damage.The IRA claimed responsibility for the attack, linking it what they called a warlikespeech delivered by Mrs. Thatcher during a recent visit to Northern Ireland. Investigatorssaid the damage was illustrative of that caused by a bomb. The IRA has a record ofattacking military installations, and this latest attack was the more damaging than any inmore than seven years. The Prime Ministers of Britain and Ireland have denounced theattack. Police are seeking three men with Irish accents who lived near the barracks for ashort time.Private security firms serve the barracks at Deal and 29 other bases in Britain. Families ofthe victims and opposition party leaders have criticized the arrangement, blaming theattack on lax security because of the private guards.

column3: Insurers face the prospect of paying out billion of dollar for damage caused by this week's California earthquake. Getting a grip on the extent of the damage is proving a far more difficult task than what insurer faced after Hurricane Hugo ripped through the Caribbean and the Carolinas last month. The earthquake's toll, including possible deep structural damage, go far beyond the more easily observed damage from a hurricane, say George Reider, a vice president in Aetna Life & Casualty Insurance Co.'s claim division. But investor are betting that the financial and psychological impact of the earthquake, coming so soon after the hurricane, will help stem more than two year of intense price-cutting war among business insurer. Reflecting that logic, insurance-company stock posted strong gain. Aetna and other insurer are hiring engineer and architect to help them ass structural damage. Most insurer already have mobilized their "catastrophe" team to begin processing claim from their policyholder in northern California. Since commercial air travel is interrupted, Aetna, based in Hartford, Conn., chartered three plane to fly claim adjuster into Sacramento and then planned for them to drive to the Bay area. About 25 adjuster were dispatched yesterday afternoon, along with laptop computer, cellular phone and blank check. Some adjuster, already in other part of California, drove to the disaster area with recreational vehicle and mobile home that could be used a makeshift claims-processing center. Insurers will be advertising 800 number -- probably on the radio -- that policyholder can call to get assistance on how to submit claim. State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Co., the largest home and auto insurer in California, belief the loss from the earthquake could be somewhat le than the $475 million in damage it expects to pay out for claim resulting from Hurricane Hugo. State Farm, based in Bloomington, Ind., is also the largest writer of personal-property earthquake insurance in California. Earthquake insurance is sold a a separate policy or a specific endorsement "rider" on a homeowner's policy in California, because of the area's vulnerability to earthquake. State Farm said about 25% of it policyholder in California have also purchased earthquake insurance. Allstate Insurance Co., a unit of Sears, Roebuck & Co., said about 23% of it personal property policyholder -- about 28% in the San Franciso area -- also have earthquake coverage. The Association of California Insurance Companies estimated damage to residential property could total $500 million, but only $100 million to $150 million is insured, it said. Officials from the American Insurance Association's property-claim service division, which coordinate the effort of the claim adjuster in an area after a natural disaster, will be flying to San Francisco today. They expect to have a preliminary estimate of the damage in a day or two. Roads and bridge in the Bay area appear to have suffered some of the most costly damage. Highways, such a the section of Interstate 880 that collapsed in Oakland, generally don't have insurance coverage. Industry official say the Bay Bridge -- unlike some bridge -- ha no earthquake coverage, either, so the cost of repairing it probably would have to be paid out of state general operating fund. However, the bridge, which charge a $1 toll each way, doe have "loss of income" insurance to replace lost revenue if the operation of the bridge is interrupted for more than seven day. That coverage is provided by a syndicate of insurance company including Fireman's Fund Corp., based in Novato, Calif., and Cigna Corp., based in Philadelphia. Earthquake-related claim aren't expected to cause significant financial problem for the insurance industry a a whole. Instead, even with the liability of two natural disaster in recent week, analyst said the total capital of the industry is likely to be higher at year end than it wa at midyear. Indeed, the earthquake could contribute to a turnaround in the insurance cycle in a couple of way. For example, insurer may seek to limit their future exposure to catastrophe by increasing the amount of reinsurance they buy. Such increased demand for reinsurance, along with the loss the reinsurers will bear from these two disaster, are likely to spur increase in reinsurance price that will later be translated into an overall price rise. Reinsurance is protection taken out by the insurance firm themselves. "We are saying this is the breaking point, this is the event that will change the psychology of the marketplace," said William Yankus, an analyst with Conning & Co., a Hartford firm that specializes in the insurance industry. His firm, along with some others, issued new buy recommendation on insurer stock yesterday. Among the insurance stock, big gainer included American International Group, up $3.25 to $102.625; General Re Corp., up $2.75 to $86.50; Aetna, up $2.375 to $59.50; and Marsh & McLennan Inc., up $3.125 to $75875. Still, a few individual company, most likely smaller one, could be devastated. "I think there is a damned good chance someone is going to hit the skid on this," said Oppenheimer & Co. analyst Myron Picoult. He suspect some insurer who had purchased reinsurance to limit their exposure to catastrophe will discover that reinsurance wa used up by Hurricane Hugo. British, West German, Scandinavian and other overseas insurer are bracing for big claim from the San Francisco earthquake disaster. Although it's unclear how much exposure the London market will face, UK. underwriter traditionally have a large reinsurance exposure to US. catastrophe coverage. Jack Byrne, chairman of Fireman's Fund, said this disaster will test the catastrophe reinsurance market, causing these rate to soar. The catastrophe loss sustained by insurer this year will probably be the worst on an inflation-adjusted basis since 1906 -- when another earthquake sparked the Great San Francisco Fire. Orin Kramer, an insurance consultant in New York, estimate that the 1906 San Francisco destruction, on an inflation-adjusted basis, included insured loss of $5.8 billion. He is estimating this week's disaster will generate insured loss of $2 billion to $4 billion, following about $4 billion in cost to insurer from Hurricane Hugo.The White House is making sure nobody will accuse it of taking this crisis lightly. In the aftermath of the California earthquake, President Bush and his aide flew into a whirlwind of earthquake-related activity yesterday morning. Some of it wa necessary to get federal help flowing to victim, but some seemed designed mostly to project an image of a White House in action. Mr. Bush and his aide were accused of responding too slowly after the Exxon Valdez oil tanker split open in Alaskan water and Hurricane Hugo struck the Carolina coast, and they clearly don't want a repeat of those charge now. So the White House announced that Mr. Bush got his first earthquake briefing of the day at 6:30 am. from chief of staff John Sununu. By noon, Mr. Bush had taken two phone call from Vice President Dan Quayle, who wa in California; made a televised statement of concern; signed a disaster proclamation; received a written report from the Federal Emergency Management Agency; and visited FEMA headquarters. Mr. Bush himself essentially acknowledged that he and his aide were trying to head off criticism. On his FEMA visit, Mr. Bush said that he hoped there would be "less carping" about the emergency office's performance this time, adding that the agency "took a hit" for it reaction to Hurricane Hugo. The White House already is talking of Mr. Bush visiting the California earthquake site this weekend. He visited the Hugo devastation but not until after local leader urged him to do so.Most San Francisco-area homeowner mayhave to pay for damage from Tuesday's earthquake out of their ownpockets, while insurance company may reap long-term benefit fromhigher rate, industry spokesman and analyst said Wednesday.Only 15 percent to 20 percent of California homeowner haveearthquake insurance, which typically requires a 10 percentdeductible and cost between $200 to $400 a year for a $100000home, according to industry spokesmen.The Association of California Insurance Cos. in Sacramento saidthat in the San Francisco area roughly 25 to 30 percent of thehomes have earthquake insurance. The organization estimatedresidential damage from Tuesday's earthquake at $500 million inthe Bay area, with between $100 million to $150 million insured.Insured homeowner without earthquake protection will getreimbursed only if their home were ravaged by fire, which iscovered under basic homeowner insurance police, said Hugh Strawn,director of catastrophe service at the Property Loss ResearchBureau in Schaumburg, Ill.Insurance company attempted Wednesday to ass the amount ofquake-related damage they're likely to have to pay. In addition tohome damage, the company likely will get claim for automobiledamage, broken glass, theft and burglary, business interruption dueto electrical outage, water damage and, possibly, workerscompensation.Some estimated that insurer might face bill totaling $1billion or more from the quake. But industry observer said theydon't expect any company to suffer serious financial damage fromquake-related claims.We don't think any company is going to have problem payingclaims, said Elisa Siegal, public affair manager for theAmerican Insurance Association, a Washington-based trade group.The insurer actually could benefit. Industry analyst predictedinsurers would be able to reverse three year of declining ratesand win rate hike from state regulator due to the quake damagesand the estimated $4 billion in damage from Hurricane Hugo, whichhammered South Carolina and other part of the southeastern UnitedStates earlier this month.An increase in insurance rate could translate into greaterprofitability in the long term, the analyst said.There's a perception that this could turn the cycle . thatthis could be enough to firm pricing, said Gloria L. Vogel, ananalyst with Bear, Stearns & Co. Inc. in New York.Despite their prediction for the long run, the analyst warnedthat fourth-quarter earnings among insurance company are likelyto be disappointing.It's going to be a meaningful loss, perhaps a big a Hugo,said Robert Glasspiegel, an analyst with Hartford-based LangenMcAlenney.On the New York Stock Exchange, some insurance company stockrose on Wednesday. Aetna Life & Casualty Co. rose $2.37{ to $59.50a share; ITT Corp., parent of The Hartford, wa up 37{ cent to$59; and the Travelers Cos. rose $1 to $40.87{.Reinsurance company, which absorb risk from policy writers,did especially well. General Re Corp. rose $2.75 to $86.50 andMarsh & McLennan Cos. rose $3.12{ to $75.87{.In California, earthquake insurance is an emotional andpolitically-charged issue. Roughly two-thirds of all insurancepolicies written in the United States are sold in California, wheremany of the nation's most damaging earthquake have occurred..Under a 1985 California law, insurer are required to offerearthquake insurance to homebuyers, but homebuyers are not requiredto buy the coverage.Insurers aren't required to offer earthquake insurance tocommercial property owner, but the percentage of business propertywith the coverage is very high, industry spokesman said. Theyestimated that at least 25 percent, and probably many more,business property are insured.Because of it high cost, earthquake insurance ha become atarget of the controversial Proposition 103 approved by Californiavoters last year. The proposition call for a 20 percent rollbackin insurance rate. Insurers and state regulator are battling overthe rate and how they're set.
column5: Responses to the Northern California Earthquake of October 17, 1989
column6: California struggled to recover from the earthquake of Oct. 17, 1989. The Governor called a special session of the legislature to deal with the disaster and despite heavy losses, the insurance industry appeared optimistic. In Washington the White House launched into furious activity to answer critics of its performance in earlier crises.
column7: The California earthquake of Oct. 17, 1989 caused extensive damage. Despite heavy insurance losses, insurance company stocks posted gains as investors bet on increases in insurance rates producing a long-term increase in profits. In Washington, the White House appeared hyperactive, anxious to show its responsiveness to the disaster. In Sacramento, Governor Deukmejian called a special session of the legislature to deal with the crisis. Critics accused him of blaming others for the collapse of freeways and called on him to get on with reconstruction and a temporary increase of the gasoline tax so hundreds of thousands of commuters could get to work.
column8: The northern California earthquake of October 17, 1989 caused extensive damage to buildings and roadways. An official of the California Seismic Safety Commission said that assessing the disaster was "like the blind man trying to feel an elephant." Another on-site observer commented that the quake "was like somebody slugging a punching bag. Usually earthquakes pass, but this one went on and on...It was very very bad." Estimates of the loss to insurers ranged from $2 billion to $4 billion. Ironically, despite the record losses to insurers, insurance company stocks posted strong gains as investors bet that market forces and action by state regulators would result in higher insurance rates and long-term profits. In Washington the Bush White House flew into a whirlwind of activity to show the administration's ability for rapid response. In Sacramento Governor Deukmejian called a special session of the California legislature to deal with the disaster, but was perceived as blaming others for the collapse of freeways. Critics called on him to stop pointing fingers and get on with reconstruction. The Governor had earlier opposed an increase in the gasoline tax intended to augment transportation funding -- a step which appeared highly desirable after the quake left hundreds of thousands of commuters unable to reach work.
column9: Insurers will not suffer financial damage due to California earthquake.
column10: The White House and the California government are provided aid to Tuesday's California earthquake victims. Only 25-30% of homes in the San Francisco area are insured. Insurers may have to pay billions but no company is expected to suffer financial damage. Insurers price-cutting may end as prices rise from reinsurance investments.
column11: In the aftermath of California's earthquake Tuesday, the White House reacted quickly to get federal aid flowing. The governor of California assured victims the state also would provide aid. Only about 25-30% of homes in the San Francisco area are said to be insured.Insurers may have to pay billions of dollars for the earthquake but no company is expected to suffer serious financial damage. Insurers as a whole are likely to increase the amount of reinsurance they buy which, in turn, will translate into an overall price rise, thus ending the price-cutting war between them the past two years.
column12: In the aftermath of California's earthquake Tuesday, the White House reacted quickly--partly to get federal aid flowing--and also to protect an image of the White House in action. The White House and the Federal Emergency Management Agency were accused of slow response to the Exxon Valdez oil spill and Hurricane Hugo. The Governor of California is assuring victims that the state will provide aid.  Analysts and industry spokesmen say only about 25-30% of homes in the San Francisco area have earthquake insurance.Insurers may have to pay billions of dollars for the earthquake.  The damage goes far beyond that of Hurricane Hugo last month.  Insurers are rushing into the area to process claims but no company is expected to suffer serious financial damage. Investors hope the financial and psychological impact of the earthquake will stem price-cutting wars between insurers the past two years. It is predicted that the quake damages may in fact lead to rate hikes. Insurers and state legislators are battling over rates and how they are set. Insurers as a whole are likely to increase the amount of reinsurance they buy, which will translate into an overall price rise.

column3: SAM WALTON wa arguably the most important retailer of his generation. Theson of an Oklahoma real-estate broker, he opened the first general store inwhat wa to become the Wal-Mart chain in Bentonville, in the backwater ofArkansas, in 1950, writes Martin Dickson.By 1991 the chain's sale had risen to nearly Dollars 44bn, making it theworld's largest retailer in term of revenue, and the Walton familyprobably America's richest.Wal-Mart now operates in 43 US state, selling good ranging from detergentsto golf clubs.The chain's success stemmed both from Mr Walton's personality andwillingness to challenge accepted retailing orthodoxy.He wa a frugal, modest man who worked extremely long hour from a spartanroom in his Bentonville headquarters but delighted in getting out of theoffice to tour store and meet customer and staff, whom he insisted oncalling 'associates.'He would deliver pep-talks to employee extolling the virtue of thrift andcustomer satisfaction, long before these became fashionable managementbuzz-words.Employee satisfaction - an idea which is only now gaining wider acceptancein US service industry - wa also a vital ingredient in the Waltonphilosophy.He buoyed staff morale with cheer-leading session, bonus payment for goodperformance and profit-sharing plan which allowed some employee of verymodest mean to retire relatively wealthy.Eight year ago, when Wal-Mart's profit were better than expected, he kepta promise to staff by dressing in a grass-skirt to dance the hula on WallStreet.Also essential to Wal-Mart's growth wa it pioneering of high volume,cut-price retailing throughout the year, rather than the periodic saleswhich rival relied on to generate customer loyalty.'Low price always' became Wal-Mart's motto.Mr Walton also disproved the conventional wisdom that large discount storescould not operate successfully in the small, rural town of the US south.It wa precisely such location which became the bedrock of the business,though in the process Wal-Mart put out of business hundred of small mainstreet store, prompting bitter resistance in some town which Mr Waltontended to blunt with generous charitable donations.Forty year after Sam Walton first hungout his shingle, Walton's 5&10 will reopen to show how a littlerural storekeeper built a discount retail empire.Wal-Mart Stores Inc.'s Visitors Center open Wednesday in thesame building on the downtown square where Walton first opened forbusiness on May 9, 1950.The center chronicle the rise of the nation's fastest-growingdiscount chain, using display and audio-video presentation. Itconcentrates on how the free enterprise system work and howWal-Mart thrived when similar company didn't.The window display date back to the store's opening, withSimplicity pattern and Johnson's Glo-Coat, a box of Dreft and someIvory Snow. Inside, an electronic map detail the company's1,500-plus store chain today.Also on display at the center is the hula skirt that Sam Waltondonned for his dance on Wall Street, which he performed afterchallenging the company to reach a record 8 percent pre-tax profitin 1984. The goal wa accomplished and he danced.The old and the modern together reflect the corporate culture ofthe nation's biggest discount retailer behind K mart Corp. ofDetroit.Walton and his brother, Bud, opened the first Wal-Mart DiscountCity in 1962. Both will be on hand for the opening, along with asprinkling of other dignitary, including Gov. Bill Clinton, thededication speaker.Aside from the other display and presentation, the center alsohas a replica of Sam Walton's original office at the store,including many fixture he used 40 year ago.Also on display is a photograph of young Sam Walton, a fat-facedbaby born in Oklahoma in the 1920s. Typical of the Wal-Martoutlook, Dust Bowl Oklahoma is termed a place to grow and todream in a video on the Walton family.After a stint with JC. Penney Co. and the Army, he opened a BenFranklin store in Newport in 1945. He lost the lease on that one,and relocated to Bentonville. That's where the story took off.Sam Walton convinced Bob Bogle, then a public health officer, totake over management of his Bentonville Ben Franklin store in 1955.Walton said he wanted to put in about a dozen store andneeded someone to tend the shop in Bentonville while he and hisbrother built a chain of Ben Franklins, Bogle said in a recentinterview.That's when Bogle found himself in Walton's learn a you gotraining program.I got home at 10 o'clock that night after scrubbing and waxingthe floor with Sam, Bogle said.Inauspicious first impression are part of the story. In onevideo, David Glass, who succeeded Sam Walton a chief executive ofWal-Mart in 1988, recalled his impression after attending theopening of the second Wal-Mart Discount City at Harrison in 1964.The first store, at Rogers, opened two year earlier.I thought to myself this is absolutely the worst discountstore, or retail store, I have ever seen, said Glass, who waspresident of a drugstore chain at the time.And Wal-Mart Vice Chairman Donald Soderquist recall that whenWalton took his idea of putting discount store in rural area toBen Franklin headquarters in Chicago, official there just reallydidn't see a future in it.Don Shinkle, Wal-Mart's director of corporate and publicaffairs, attributed Wal-Mart's success to it associate theterm for employee first coined in 1972 to stress that all Wal-Martemployees are partner in the company and to Sam Walton'sleadership and knack for hiring the right person at the righttime.At the start of 1990, Wal-Mart owned 1,402 store, employed272,000 and listed sale of $25.8 billion. Sam's Wholesale Clubclosed out the year with 123 unit and Wal-Mart announced plan toenter the California market.MADE IN AMERICA: MY STORYBy Sam WaltonDoubleday, Dollars 2250. 269 pagesBeing an American folk hero is a tricky assignment, a Ross Perot found out.The problem is that the great American public like it boot-strapentrepreneurs to be very rich and very upright. In a country where businesspractices are not overly genteel, this is a tough combination to achieve. Avast medium circus, meanwhile, is quick to expose any flaws.Sam Walton, founder of the Wal-Mart chain of discount supermarket who diedof cancer in April, negotiated these pitfall much better than most. When,in 1985, Forbes magazine declared him America's richest entrepreneur, thepaparazzi descended on the obscure corner of Arkansas, mainly occupied bychicken farmer, where Walton made his home. What they found wa a happilymarried, much-liked billionaire who enjoyed quail hunting, breakfasted atthe local Holiday Inn, and drove a battered pick-up truck, minus twohub-caps. Folksy wa an understatement.Since then, some aspect of Wal-Mart's business - it anti-union policies,the impact of it Dollars 40bn annual sale on hundred of Mom-and-Pop shop -have been subject to critical scrutiny. So, to an extent, have the lesswholesome adventure of the four Walton child. But no one ha ever beenable to make Sam himself look bad. The worst that ha been said is that hewas rather dull.Walton is not about to dash anyone's illusion. Readers will either find hisautobiography lashed with 'good ol common-sense and a lot of harmless, ifcharming, anecdote. Or they will find it dreary and downbeat. Walton makesno excuses: 'I realise this may sound boring to most you,' he writes at onestage, 'but one of my best item ever wa a mattress pad called a Bedmate . . .'A few snippet are more revealing about the character. There cannot be manybillionaires who admit that they 'never learned handwriting too well' - andhave the gut to include a photograph which demonstrates the point.Meanwhile, the competitive energy which Sam Walton applied to his businessis inescapable. In one of many contribution from friend and family, DonSoderquist, Wal-Mart's chief operating officer, tell of finding Sam oneSaturday morning on his hand and knee at the local Kmart store, analysinghis rival's stock. And his wife, in a casual aside, note that when thecouple wa on holiday in Italy their luggage vanished while her husband wasoff on a similar scouting mission.But it is David Glass, Wal-Mart's current chief executive, who perhapscaptures the entrepreneurial Walton spirit best. Explaining the annualcontest in which Wal-Mart executive choose one 'volume producing item' topromote, he recall the time Sam (who usually won) selected minnow bucketsfor carrying bait. Glass wa more happily teamed with apple juice. 'So Iwould go down to the store, and get them to take that minnow bucket . . .put ice in it, ice down the juice and give away sample out of his minnowbucket. I particularly did it in store I knew (Sam) wa going to visit. Itdrove him crazy, and he got off that minnow bucket pretty quick . . . .'But the reader can't help feeling that the cosy yarn tell only half thetruth. Sam Walton wa a salesman to the core, and seems to have packagedhimself with all the skill that he once applied to selling a gooey southernsweet called Moon Pies.For the most part, this make for an engaging, if one-dimensional, portrait.Occasionally, it just grate. 'I had bought a bank in Bentonville, for aboutabout Dollars 300,000,' Walton remark, for example, 'just a little old bankwith only about Dollars 3.5m in deposit. But it helped me learn a lot aboutfinancing things.' Oh, come on Sam, is that the whole story?The real truth, one suspect, come right at the end of the book - whenWalton admits that 'if I hadn't gotten sick, I doubt I would have writtenthis book'. Given the pleading of publisher - Doubleday paid about Dollars4m for the manuscript - and a rather natural desire to have a final say, hecan hardly be blamed for agreeing to write it. But these are unlikely to becircumstances which make for the most critical self-analysis. At the end ofthe day, Sam Walton's heritage is in the shopping mall, not the bookstores.The store manager of the Wal-Mart in thiscommunity on the outskirt of Dallas tell a story that give aninsight into the man considered responsible for a retailingphenomenon.Manager Don Bost remembers one day last summer when a secretarytelephoned from Wal-Mart Stores Inc.'s corporate headquarters inBentonville, Ark. Chairman Sam Walton wa about to land at a nearbyairport and the secretary asked if someone could fetch him and bringhim to the De Soto store.Paying unexpected call on store is one way Walton ha kept inclose touch with everyday goings-on. His example is followed byother Wal-Mart executive and most make a point of spending a lot oftime in the field.Says Ed Nagy, district manager for 9 store in the Dallasmetropolitan area, It's not like `Uh-oh, someone's coming,'because they're always out.By all account, Sam Walton's personality permeates operationsthroughout the company.Everyone, from Wal-Mart President and Chief Operating OfficerDavid Glass down to an hourly store worker, can readily quote thegospel according to Sam, a he is called.To paraphrase Sam's primary rule of retailing, Rule No.1 isthe customer is always right. Rule No.2 say just in case thecustomer's wrong, revert to rule No.1.If the principle sound old-fashioned and homespun, they arebecause that's the way Sam is, people who know him say.He shuns the limelight that his company's success ha shed on himand ha decided to refuse almost all press request for interviews.He's happy to chat with folk in his store, though.He also regularly reminds Wal-Mart associate thathospitality to customer is crucial. He preaches it in person or viahigh-tech satellite hookup with his stores.Wal-Mart employee became known a associate under a companyeffort to prove it cared about employee, partly to thwart a unionorganizing effort in the late 1960s.One of the most sensitive subject for Walton is the fortune he'samassed.A close associate say Sam would probably give anything notto be named on Fortune magazine's list of the country's wealthiestpeople. The magazine ha estimated that his immediate family's stakein Wal-Mart stock is worth about $6.8 billion.Sam Walton is more interested in his backhand than he is in hisbank account, say Don Shinkle, Wal-Mart spokesman.Samuel Moore Walton turn 71 on March 29. He wa born inKingfisher, Okla., and grew up a the son of a farm-mortgage banker.He graduated from the University of Missouri with an economicsdegree in 1940 and joined JC. Penney Co. a a management trainee inDes Moines, Iowa. After serving three year in the Army, he went toArkansas and opened a Ben Franklin five-and-dime store, eventuallybecoming the company's biggest franchisee.The seed of the Wal-Mart empire were sown when Sam and hisbrother James L., or Bud, opened the first Wal-Mart Discount City in1962. The rest will probably earn an entry in the history of U.S.retail trade.Bud is a senior vice president and board member of Wal-Mart.Three of the four grown child Sam and his wife Helen had areinvolved with the company in various capacities.Sam hasn't slowed much, enjoying hunting and tennis a much asever, and is said not to suffer after effect from a bout withleukemia, now in remission. He spends le time in the office sincehanding over most responsiblities to David Glass. Sam is stillchairman of the board.Glass doesn't hesitate when asked if Wal-Mart can flourishwithout Sam. The answer is an emphatic yes because, he say, Wehave great people. The Walton family will always be involved, headds.Commenting on the future, Glass says: We'll be judged on whatwe produce today. Tomorrow, what we've done in the past won'tmatter.Wal-Mart founder Sam Waltonpitched in to help check-out clerk at his store in this FloridaPanhandle city when an electronic glitch shut down the cashregisters.The 71-year-old Walton, considered to be one of the world'srichest people, grabbed a note pad Tuesday evening and startedhand-writing merchandise price for customer so their bill couldbe tallied on calculator quickly.People began recognizing him and coming up and greeting him,said store manager Paul Sively. He shook their hand and talked toeveryone he could. The register were out for about 45 minute, andI don't think we had one customer complain.Walton, known for his down-home style, made a surprise visit tothe store that later Tuesday staged a concert by country singer JanaJea in it parking lot. Walton often attends promotional event forhis Arkansas-based chain, and Sively said he had suspected the bossmight make an appearance.Walton continued talking with customer during the concert. Healso joined the singer on stage to sing a duet and led customer inthe Wal-Mart cheer.He wa up there saying, `Give me a W, give me an A,' and thecustomers went right along with him, Sively said. He even gotdown to do a cheerleader's squiggle.'WAL-MART: A HISTORY OF SAM WALTON'S RETAIL PHENOMENON' by Sandra S. Vanceand Roy V. Scott Twayne Publishers, New York, Dollars 14.95 240 pagesMany people might be said to be the personification of the American Dream;few are better qualified for that title than Sam Walton.Walton is a character it would be difficult to invent, an all-American boywho became one of the world's most successful businessmen. The church-goingson of a farmer born in 1918 near Kingfisher, Oklahoma, he founded a storechain which made him America's richest man, and which, shortly before hisdeath in 1992, became the world's biggest retailer.His company, Wal-Mart, made sale of Dollars 55bn last year, and afterWalton's death Fortune magazine reported that his wife and four childrenheld between them the second-largest fortune in the world - Dollars 23.5bn.What is most startling about Wal-Mart is the speed of it growth. AlthoughWalton built up a small chain of Ben Franklin variety store franchise from1945, it wa not until 1962 that he opened his first Wal-Mart discountstore.At the time of it incorporation in 1971, Wal-Mart had only 38 outlet withsales of Dollars 44m - not enough to earn a place in trade journal DiscountMerchandiser's list of the 71 biggest US discount retailer. Ten yearslater, with 330 store and Dollars 1.6bn sale, it wa only the 33rd-biggestretailer in the US. Its turnover wa only 9 per cent of that of SearsRoebuck, the biggest, and 11 per cent of K mart, the second-biggest. Withinanother 10 year, Wal-Mart had overtaken them both.Apart from Walton's autobiography completed shortly before his deathhowever, published material about the company is curiously scarce. This bookattempts to fill the gap, to provide a 'scholarly account' of the rise ofWal-Mart, setting it in the wider context of US retailing, and explaininghow it wa achieved.One strength the author identify is Wal-Mart's ability to copy and adaptfrom other retailers.Sam Walton did not invent discount retailing. Rather, he realised the threatdiscounting posed to his own variety store business and studied in depthmany of the US's leading discounter of the early 1960s, including Ann andHope, E J Korvette, Spartan's, Fed-Mart, and K mart.Walton learned from them all, but wa unique in taking his discount storesinto small town of a few thousand people, where shopper used to travellinglong distance were delighted to have a cut-price store nearby sellingeverything they needed.Another strength is Wal-Mart's openness to technology. As early a the1950s, Walton realised he wa wasting too much time travelling and bought asmall aircraft to pilot between store himself - something he continued todo to the end of his life.Sometimes, Walton wa more reluctant to invest in technology, and had to bepersuaded by colleague to introduce computer, and scanning at check-outs -long before most retailer had recognised their importance - and to investDollars 20m in an internal satellite communication system. This technologyhelped Wal-Mart build one of the most efficient distribution system of anyretailer.
